shortDescription: The priory of Salagon, a major medieval ensemble in Haute-Provence, is composed of a 12th century Romanesque church with contemporary stained glass windows created by Aurélie Nemours, a Renaissance dwelling and ethnobotanical gardens.

label: Façade Renaissance
comment: Vast private residence with structured façade, large window adorned with François I era gypseries decorated with grotesques, doorway in a basket handle four-centred arch, basket handle porch.
shortDescription: Vast private residence with structured façade, large window adorned with François I era gypseries decorated with grotesques, doorway in a basket handle four-centred arch, basket handle porch.

label: Porche de La Rue Gambetta
comment:
The town’s largest, beautiful stone structure, perhaps part of the ancient medieval gate, curved arches.

Discover the rich past of Ollioules and the anecdotes that have shaped its character through guided visits
shortDescription:
The town’s largest, beautiful stone structure, perhaps part of the ancient medieval gate, curved arches.

Discover the rich past of Ollioules and the anecdotes that have shaped its character through guided visits

label: Parc Saint-Bernard
comment: Surrounding the Villa Noailles, the garden St Bernard was built between 1924 and 1930 by the villa’s architect Robert Mallet-Stevens. A ‘cubist garden’ was also conceived by architect and landscape designer Gabriel Guevrekian. Under the villa, Charles de Noailles starts working in 1925 on a narrow terrace Mediterranean garden where he cultivates local plants such as lavender and rosemary as well as rarer species like angel’s trumpet (datura), silverberry, bignonia, wisteria, pittosporum, heliotrope, helichrysum italicum. In 1973, the town purchases the garden, which offers an unbeatable view on the entire coast.
shortDescription: Surrounding the Villa Noailles, the garden St Bernard was built between 1924 and 1930 by the villa’s architect Robert Mallet-Stevens. A ‘cubist garden’ was also conceived by architect and landscape designer Gabriel Guevrekian. Under the villa, Charles de Noailles starts working in 1925 on a narrow terrace Mediterranean garden where he cultivates local plants such as lavender and rosemary as well as rarer species like angel’s trumpet (datura), silverberry, bignonia, wisteria, pittosporum, heliotrope, helichrysum italicum. In 1973, the town purchases the garden, which offers an unbeatable view on the entire coast.

label: Plage d'Aiguebelle
comment: Aiguebelle (literally  « beautiful water ») takes its names from the sea. The sand is a transparent as the water and merges with the sea in a astonishing game of mirrors – a game which ushers you into a world of happiness and charm.
shortDescription: Aiguebelle (literally  « beautiful water ») takes its names from the sea. The sand is a transparent as the water and merges with the sea in a astonishing game of mirrors – a game which ushers you into a world of happiness and charm.

label: Eglise Saint Jacques le Majeur
comment: Restored in the 18th and 19th century, square bell tower with campanile. Very beautiful statues in stone or cardboard stone gilded with gold leaf as well as ex-votos. New restored organ.
shortDescription: Restored in the 18th and 19th century, square bell tower with campanile. Very beautiful statues in stone or cardboard stone gilded with gold leaf as well as ex-votos. New restored organ.

label: Médiathèque de Fayence
comment: As in every Mediatem network media library, it will be easy for you to borrow novels, documentaries, CDs, DVDs, comic strips... whether you are a young person or an adult.
shortDescription: As in every Mediatem network media library, it will be easy for you to borrow novels, documentaries, CDs, DVDs, comic strips... whether you are a young person or an adult.

label: Écomusée Apiland
comment:
Discover the fascinating world of bees in a magnificent setting at the foot of the Serre-Ponçon dam! From the hive to the anatomy of the bee, Apiland offers you a complete and playful animation around the beekeeping world.
Paris 2018 Award of Excellence.
shortDescription:
Discover the fascinating world of bees in a magnificent setting at the foot of the Serre-Ponçon dam! From the hive to the anatomy of the bee, Apiland offers you a complete and playful animation around the beekeeping world.
Paris 2018 Award of Excellence.

label: La Maison des Bêtes à laine - La Bergerie Brunet - Ferme de découverte
comment:
Visit of the farm: Discovery of pastoralism and visit of the sheepfold
  Work of the wool "from fleece to thread"
Lambs, sheep, Mazurka the Kashmir goat, the rabbits as well as the hens will receive you in their fold.
shortDescription:
Visit of the farm: Discovery of pastoralism and visit of the sheepfold
  Work of the wool "from fleece to thread"
Lambs, sheep, Mazurka the Kashmir goat, the rabbits as well as the hens will receive you in their fold.

label: Site du Château de Cadenet
comment: The listed site of the Château, with its troglodytic habitat and its theatre of greenery from which you can contemplate beyond the Durance, the Montagne Sainte-Victoire, the Alpilles mountain range and further north, the Luberon.
shortDescription: The listed site of the Château, with its troglodytic habitat and its theatre of greenery from which you can contemplate beyond the Durance, the Montagne Sainte-Victoire, the Alpilles mountain range and further north, the Luberon.
streetAddress: ["11 place du Tambour d'Arcole", 'Site du Château de Cadenet']

label: Le Pont du Moulin ou Ancien Pont d'Ondres
comment: This donkey-backed bridge spans the Verdon River at 41 metres. Built in the 2nd half of the 17th century, it allowed the hamlet of Ondres to be reached and facilitated the passage of herds going up to the summer pastures.
shortDescription: This donkey-backed bridge spans the Verdon River at 41 metres. Built in the 2nd half of the 17th century, it allowed the hamlet of Ondres to be reached and facilitated the passage of herds going up to the summer pastures.

label: Musée du Garde-champêtre
comment: This museum is dedicated to telling the story of rural police. It further enriches the  cultural heritage of Bargemon and exhibits many historic items such as english pistol from the 19th century, side arms, medals, law texts ... The collection has been gathered over the last 20 years. This  museum is unique in France.
shortDescription: This museum is dedicated to telling the story of rural police. It further enriches the  cultural heritage of Bargemon and exhibits many historic items such as english pistol from the 19th century, side arms, medals, law texts ... The collection has been gathered over the last 20 years. This  museum is unique in France.

label: Musée archéologique de Montclar
comment: Discover the archaeological peculiarities of Montclar in the village museum. Thematic exhibitions: peasant life, prehistoric times, Roman times...
shortDescription: Discover the archaeological peculiarities of Montclar in the village museum. Thematic exhibitions: peasant life, prehistoric times, Roman times...

label: Hôtel Benedetti
comment: The façade of this monument houses a staircase with balusters serving different levels of a house that belonged to a family of bollenois lawyers.
shortDescription: The façade of this monument houses a staircase with balusters serving different levels of a house that belonged to a family of bollenois lawyers.

label: Sculpture "Le Devoir de Mémoire" de Benjamin Vasapolli
comment: Go back in time and discover our villages rich with masterpieces. These have been inspired by magical places and history of mankind. The sculpture "Le Devoir de Mémoire" (The Duty to Remember) was achieved by Benjamin Vasapolli.
shortDescription: Go back in time and discover our villages rich with masterpieces. These have been inspired by magical places and history of mankind. The sculpture "Le Devoir de Mémoire" (The Duty to Remember) was achieved by Benjamin Vasapolli.

label: Monument aux morts
comment: With its sober forms, it was erected in 1919 with stones coming from a quarry in the commune of Artignosc at a place called les estrilles.
shortDescription: With its sober forms, it was erected in 1919 with stones coming from a quarry in the commune of Artignosc at a place called les estrilles.

label: La Ferme de la Montagne
comment:
Welcome to our farming !
Visit to the Ferme de la Montagne '' From the fleece to the wool ball". Mohair, alpaca, cashmere, angora.. You are invited to discover their secrets, approach animals, know everything about shearing, enjoy the wool spinning, knitting, weaving.
shortDescription:
Welcome to our farming !
Visit to the Ferme de la Montagne '' From the fleece to the wool ball". Mohair, alpaca, cashmere, angora.. You are invited to discover their secrets, approach animals, know everything about shearing, enjoy the wool spinning, knitting, weaving.

label: Le site archéologique du Bourguet
streetAddress: ['Avenue de la Bastide', 'Ferme de font Robert']

label: Village de Saorge
comment: A village in the shape of an eagle's nest, Saorge is a monument in itself, a witness to medieval architecture. This village, which looks like a "Tibetan village", entirely listed, is an ancient fortress clinging to the side of the mountain in the shape of an amphitheatre.
shortDescription: A village in the shape of an eagle's nest, Saorge is a monument in itself, a witness to medieval architecture. This village, which looks like a "Tibetan village", entirely listed, is an ancient fortress clinging to the side of the mountain in the shape of an amphitheatre.

label: Plage Riviera Beach
comment: Sheltered from the hustle and bustle of the famous Croisette, the private Riviera Beach is located not far from the Old Port.
shortDescription: Sheltered from the hustle and bustle of the famous Croisette, the private Riviera Beach is located not far from the Old Port.

label: Exposition sur l'Ancienne Mine de Cuivre
comment:
This exhibition retraces the history of the copper mine
The copper mine of St Véran or Clausis is located upstream from St Véran, just below the chapel.
shortDescription:
This exhibition retraces the history of the copper mine
The copper mine of St Véran or Clausis is located upstream from St Véran, just below the chapel.

label: Eglise Saint Etienne
comment: With its 17th century bell tower, Saint-Etienne church  is an integral part of the defence wall. The angel heads on the main altar have been allegedly made by some of  Pierre Puget students.
shortDescription: With its 17th century bell tower, Saint-Etienne church  is an integral part of the defence wall. The angel heads on the main altar have been allegedly made by some of  Pierre Puget students.

label: Eglise Saint-Michel du hameau de Libre
comment: The elegant facade of the Church of Saint-Michel, of classical composition, presents a set of neo-baroque stuccoes typically Ligurian: angel heads, scrolls and scrolls, medallions with petals, friezes, capitals composites, shell…
shortDescription: The elegant facade of the Church of Saint-Michel, of classical composition, presents a set of neo-baroque stuccoes typically Ligurian: angel heads, scrolls and scrolls, medallions with petals, friezes, capitals composites, shell…

label: Jardin de l’Atelier du Mille Pattes
comment: Just a stone's throw from the town centre, you will be seduced and amazed by our intimate garden created at the beginning of the 20th century, overlooking the town of Forcalquier, the Luberon, the Valensole plateau and the Southern Alps.
shortDescription: Just a stone's throw from the town centre, you will be seduced and amazed by our intimate garden created at the beginning of the 20th century, overlooking the town of Forcalquier, the Luberon, the Valensole plateau and the Southern Alps.

label: Le Bersac
comment: The small rural commune of Bersac dominates the Buëch valley, between the Arambre mountain and the Révuaire.
shortDescription: The small rural commune of Bersac dominates the Buëch valley, between the Arambre mountain and the Révuaire.

label: La Citadelle
comment: The town of Saint-Tropez has been dominated by its Citadel since the early 17th century. For centuries it was the most important defensive element between Antibes and Toulon and is one of the few remaining monuments, of this size, on the Var coast.
shortDescription: The town of Saint-Tropez has been dominated by its Citadel since the early 17th century. For centuries it was the most important defensive element between Antibes and Toulon and is one of the few remaining monuments, of this size, on the Var coast.

label: Plage des Gireliers
comment:
Les Gireliers beach on the Corniche road at Les Issambres is ideal for families.
This sandy beach has a picturesque pine forest and is equipped with seats and a petanque pitch. Ideal for swimming and relaxing.
shortDescription:
Les Gireliers beach on the Corniche road at Les Issambres is ideal for families.
This sandy beach has a picturesque pine forest and is equipped with seats and a petanque pitch. Ideal for swimming and relaxing.

label: Couvent des Récollets
comment: In 1627, the friars of the Reformed Franciscans, who lived in the church and the cloister of St. Peter's, one of the four parishes of the city, of which the Romanesque oculus can still be seen, had an important convent here.
shortDescription: In 1627, the friars of the Reformed Franciscans, who lived in the church and the cloister of St. Peter's, one of the four parishes of the city, of which the Romanesque oculus can still be seen, had an important convent here.

label: Mémorial de l'armée noire
comment: This monument is inspired by the monumental sculpture erected in Rheims, taken from the same mould in Bamako, a memorial paying homage to the Senegalese Riflemen.
shortDescription: This monument is inspired by the monumental sculpture erected in Rheims, taken from the same mould in Bamako, a memorial paying homage to the Senegalese Riflemen.

label: Plage de la Tortue
comment: Small multiple beaches of sand and red rocks that offer a magnificent view of the Golden Island. A shaded promenade (lit at night) leads to the small port of Boulouris.
shortDescription: Small multiple beaches of sand and red rocks that offer a magnificent view of the Golden Island. A shaded promenade (lit at night) leads to the small port of Boulouris.

label: Oratoire Notre-Dame d'Espérance
comment: This oratory has a square pillar, masonry made of squared and seated rubble stones, and mortar-weighed. Its niche is formed by four large ashlars and receives the votive statuette of the Virgin.
shortDescription: This oratory has a square pillar, masonry made of squared and seated rubble stones, and mortar-weighed. Its niche is formed by four large ashlars and receives the votive statuette of the Virgin.

label: Village perché du Poët
comment: Last high Alpine step before the Provence, the village of Le Poët is built on the river banks of the Durance.
shortDescription: Last high Alpine step before the Provence, the village of Le Poët is built on the river banks of the Durance.

label: Mémorial de la division aéroportée "Rugby Force"
comment: Inaugurated on 15th August 1988, this monument is a stony block on which a parachut is resting. This was erected in remembrance of the famous Dragoon operation on 15th August 1944, when parachutings were meant to free Provence region.
shortDescription: Inaugurated on 15th August 1988, this monument is a stony block on which a parachut is resting. This was erected in remembrance of the famous Dragoon operation on 15th August 1944, when parachutings were meant to free Provence region.

label: Écomusée du Pays Sisteronais
comment: The Ecomuseum of the Sisteron Country presents a permanent collection and a temporary exhibit every year.
shortDescription: The Ecomuseum of the Sisteron Country presents a permanent collection and a temporary exhibit every year.

label: Église romane de Saint-Cyrice
comment:
There was a succession of canons until the 15th century; the land was then managed by the Abbot of Lagrand until the French Revolution.
Many buildings were plundered of "safre", soft stone that was particularly prized when it bore the hallmarks of the stonecutter.
shortDescription:
There was a succession of canons until the 15th century; the land was then managed by the Abbot of Lagrand until the French Revolution.
Many buildings were plundered of "safre", soft stone that was particularly prized when it bore the hallmarks of the stonecutter.

label: Bibliothèque municipale de Guillestre
comment: A reader's paradise! Welcome to the world of Lucie and Clarisse, who will guide you through more than 10,000 adult and children's books, DVDs and audio CDs...a break in the literary world, time stands still within its walls!
shortDescription: A reader's paradise! Welcome to the world of Lucie and Clarisse, who will guide you through more than 10,000 adult and children's books, DVDs and audio CDs...a break in the literary world, time stands still within its walls!

label: Eglise Saint-Pierre
comment: Sitting on a rocky promontory overlooking Briançon, the church of Saint-Pierre is rather simple in design. Restored in 1902, it is appreciated for its clarity and elegance.
shortDescription: Sitting on a rocky promontory overlooking Briançon, the church of Saint-Pierre is rather simple in design. Restored in 1902, it is appreciated for its clarity and elegance.

label: Plage de la Bouillabaisse
comment: The Bouillabaisse beach welcomes you on the edge with the town of Saint-Tropez.
shortDescription: The Bouillabaisse beach welcomes you on the edge with the town of Saint-Tropez.

label: Vestiges du passé
comment: An informed eye will be able to discover, scattered throughout the commune, the remains of a canal covered with water supply, an aqueduct abutment, the ruins of an aqueduct or millstones.
shortDescription: An informed eye will be able to discover, scattered throughout the commune, the remains of a canal covered with water supply, an aqueduct abutment, the ruins of an aqueduct or millstones.

label: Eglise Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption

shortDescription: Dating from the 18th century, Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption is a Baroque church  nestled in the medieval village.

label: Plaque historique commémorative
comment: Carved and engraved on the cliff on the left bank of the Roya. It can be seen from the road.
shortDescription: Carved and engraved on the cliff on the left bank of the Roya. It can be seen from the road.

label: Plaque Commémorative du Passage de La Princesse Ludovica de Savoie
comment: Sealed above the room where Princess Louise Gabrielle of Savoy, future queen of Spain, resided during her visit to Breil sur Roya on September 17, 1701.
shortDescription: Sealed above the room where Princess Louise Gabrielle of Savoy, future queen of Spain, resided during her visit to Breil sur Roya on September 17, 1701.

label: Ruines du Château de Lesdiguières
comment: Ravaged in 1692 by a violent incursion by the men of the Duke of Savoy, the castle of Lesdiguières is now in ruins. It was once the proud home of the controversial Duke of Lesdigières, one of the most successful men in the history of France.
shortDescription: Ravaged in 1692 by a violent incursion by the men of the Duke of Savoy, the castle of Lesdiguières is now in ruins. It was once the proud home of the controversial Duke of Lesdigières, one of the most successful men in the history of France.

label: Vestiges de l'abbaye de Clausonne
comment: Clausonne Abbey is located in the Commune of Saix, a small village in the canton of Veynes, in the Upper Maraize Valley, a tributary of the Buëch, in the Hautes-Alpes.
shortDescription: Clausonne Abbey is located in the Commune of Saix, a small village in the canton of Veynes, in the Upper Maraize Valley, a tributary of the Buëch, in the Hautes-Alpes.

label: La vieille pompe à incendie
comment: Fire was for a long time the greatest fear of the inhabitants of Saint-Véran, because the houses were certainly made of stone on the lower level, but mostly of wood, and hay, straw and grain were stored there.
shortDescription: Fire was for a long time the greatest fear of the inhabitants of Saint-Véran, because the houses were certainly made of stone on the lower level, but mostly of wood, and hay, straw and grain were stored there.

label: Observatoire de Saint-Véran
comment: Book in advance your night at the Observatory of Saint-Véran Paul Falenbok to discover the starry sky! Located under the summit of the Pic de Châteaurenard, in the summer you can go up there on foot, in the winter you will have to make your way up, with snowshoes or ski touring.
shortDescription: Book in advance your night at the Observatory of Saint-Véran Paul Falenbok to discover the starry sky! Located under the summit of the Pic de Châteaurenard, in the summer you can go up there on foot, in the winter you will have to make your way up, with snowshoes or ski touring.

label: Musée Comtadin du Cycle
comment: Discover the Musée Comtadin du Cycle, which traces the history and evolution of the velocyde through a remarkable collection of a hundred bicycles. FREE - Open from April to the end of September
shortDescription: Discover the Musée Comtadin du Cycle, which traces the history and evolution of the velocyde through a remarkable collection of a hundred bicycles. FREE - Open from April to the end of September

shortDescription: Cultural place of the village of Loriol-du-Comtat.

label: Potager des Princes

shortDescription: Within the Palais Carnolès, the Vegetable Garden of the Princes constitutes an escape space. It owes its name to the hundreds of vegetables from multiple varieties, sometimes forgotten or old, planted and staged to accompany citrus fruits and sculptures.

label: Jardin Elisée Reclus

shortDescription: Collection of earthenware from the Renaissance to the French Revolution.

shortDescription: Nestling on the side of a wooded cliff, between Céreste and Reillanne, the priory is on the edge of cultivated areas to the south and hills covered with centuries-old oaks to the north.

shortDescription: Located on the banks of the Reppe, in the heart of the city centre, this public garden is a relaxation area for everyone.

label: Eglise Saint-Ruf
comment:
The Saint-Ruf parish church, in neo-Romanesque style, was built in 1912 by the architect Léon Véran.
It remained unfinished, as its bell tower was never built.
shortDescription:
The Saint-Ruf parish church, in neo-Romanesque style, was built in 1912 by the architect Léon Véran.
It remained unfinished, as its bell tower was never built.

shortDescription: Built between 1508 and 1522 on the site of a 12th century church and enlarged in the 17th and 18th centuries, of late-Gothic type.

shortDescription: The surprising presence of this precious work in a village, one of the smallest in the region, which had only 200 inhabitants when, on 15 January 1499, the altarpiece was placed in the church.

shortDescription: Discover this old market garden which has kept its ancestral watering system, its sculptures on plants, its rose garden, its permaculture vegetable garden, its dry fountains and its culture secrets...

shortDescription: The Centre Jean Giono, groups together an exhibition space and a documentation centre inside the Hôtel Raffin, located not far from the Porte Saunerie, and Le Paraïs, the writer's house and gardens, located at the foot of the Mont d'Or.

shortDescription: The exceptional site of "Vallis Clausa" - the Closed Valley, which gave this beloved Vaucluse county its name, and the village of Fontaine de Vaucluse too !

This church was built in the early 1300's, where an older church in the Fustiers quarter had once stood. 
The relics of Saint Agricol, patron saint of Avignon, are kept here.
shortDescription:
This church was built in the early 1300's, where an older church in the Fustiers quarter had once stood.

A living space for all ages!

This circuit allows a visit of the village and its hamlets. Where the writer Jean Giono used to spend his holidays.

shortDescription:

shortDescription: Imposing building, half-feudal (XIIIth century keep), half-Renaissance, classified as a Historic Monument as well as its park. High place of the Provençal history, it was built by the Castellane family.

This Maginot infantry structure was built between 1932 and 1940.

Henri Jansoulin (born in La Cadière in 1867, died in 1930) .

label: Le village de Vaumeilh

Sisteron-Vaumeilh airfield, famous for its gliding club, stands on the vast Vaumeilh Plateau.
The name Vaumeilh comes from "Vallis mellis", meaning valley of honey. Dominated by the Pied de Hongrie peak, it is typically Provencal.

The construction of this chapel was decided and financed by the bishop of Ventimiglia in 1935.
It was inaugurated on October 3, 1937 by the bishop and dedicated to St Teresa of Lisieux.
Today, it is abandoned.

shortDescription: Bathe in the heart of a unique heritage with a preserved shoreline, and enjoy a menu with regional specialities revisited by our chef in a restaurant with its feet in the water. A magical setting in the Azur colours

label: Palais des Papes
comment:
Avignon has a magnficent urban landscape. The Rocher des Doms overlooks the city and the Rhône. Here there is an exceptional architectural group which includes the Pont d'Avignon (also known as Pont Saint Bénezet, the Ramparts, the Petit Palais, the Doms Cathedral and the massive walls of the Palace of the Popes, with four impressive towers in each corner. 
This unique architectural ensemble has been ranked as a UNESCO World Heritage site. 

The biggest Gothic palace in the world: tour 24 rooms!
Museum space, priceless frescoes. Audioguide in 11 languages. 
See all the hours and prices on our website: 
>>> www.palais-des-papes.com
shortDescription:
Avignon has a magnficent urban landscape. The Rocher des Doms overlooks the city and the Rhône. Here there is an exceptional architectural group which includes the Pont d'Avignon (also known as Pont Saint Bénezet, the Ramparts, the Petit Palais, the Doms Cathedral and the massive walls of the Palace of the Popes, with four impressive towers in each corner. 
This unique architectural ensemble has been ranked as a UNESCO World Heritage site. 

The biggest Gothic palace in the world: tour 24 rooms!
Museum space, priceless frescoes. Audioguide in 11 languages. 
See all the hours and prices on our website: 
>>> www.palais-des-papes.com

Each recess is used to reconstruct a craftsman's workshop. A temporary exhibition area has just been added to the collection, randomly entertaining your eyes on your visit.

Testimony to the Middle Ages, the ruins of the old castle on the hill

comment: Eourres underwent a rural exodus in the late 19th century and at the end of both world wars. However, new momentum has been created by the clearing of barren land and the arrival of new families, some of whom have embraced organic farming.
shortDescription: Eourres underwent a rural exodus in the late 19th century and at the end of both world wars. However, new momentum has been created by the clearing of barren land and the arrival of new families, some of whom have embraced organic farming.

shortDescription: The entrance hall, the large living room, the marble staircase and the music room are inscribed under the title of historical monuments (28/12/79), the facades, the roof and the garden on 17/10/12. The former hotel received the 20th century heritage label in 2013.

Guilhem Pierre was the notary of William IV, the last of the
Comte de Forcalquier. He owned a house located all

La Bastide aux Violettes welcomes you !
Here, you can learn about the history of Tourrettes, the characteristics of the land, the many ways in which violets are used, observe our growing methods, and see the flower in high season as a part of our greenhouse tours.

shortDescription: It is the main defensive structure, which faces the Mallemort castle on the right bank of the Roya. Of medieval origin, the site was modernised in the late seventeenth c. and in the eighteenth c. before being dismantled in the nineteenth c.

shortDescription: Built in 1882, this infantry structure located at an altitude of 2230 m was used to watch over the border crossings with Italy on the passes of L'Échelle, Acles and Thûres. It will also be improved to reinforce the continuity of the Maginot Line .

label: Site préhistorique classé de l'Abri de Pendimoun
comment: This rock shelter is located 4 kms as the crow flies to the north of the town of Menton and 750 metres from the French-italian border. It opens up to the west at an altitude of 690 metres, at the foot of the 1 132 metre high "Roc d'Orméa" limestrone mountain range. A great number of stone tools carved from flint, polished stone axes and fragments of pottery demonstrate a continuous settlement during the Neolothic Age. Some tombs found there also date back to that time.

It opens up to the west at an altitude of 690 metres, at the foot of the 1 132 metre high "Roc d'Orméa" limestrone mountain range. A great number of stone tools carved from flint, polished stone axes and fragments of pottery demonstrate a continuous settlement during the Neolothic Age. label: Monument de la Résistance

Barbed wires sculpted at the buttom of the statue remind of  the time when France was occupied (1939-1945). Clavier, a focal point for Resistance, saw on 16th August 1944 three of its resistance fighters killed at the Estau Bridge, on the road to Draguignan.

label: Fontaine de la Rotonde
comment:
The most imposing fountain in Aix-en-Provence is probably the Rotunda fountain.
Its construction in 1860 marked a turning point  not only were its dimensions exceptional for this city but it was also the first to have a cast iron basin.
shortDescription:
The most imposing fountain in Aix-en-Provence is probably the Rotunda fountain.
Its construction in 1860 marked a turning point  not only were its dimensions exceptional for this city but it was also the first to have a cast iron basin.
description:
12 meters high and 32 meters wide, the fountain shows above all the wealth and genius of the city. Aix is the water capital of the region since the Roman period, its terms and its fountains numbering 23 give it this reputation, and that a fountain takes this role of symbol was an evidence. 
The fountain is decorated at the top with 3 sculptures of women, "the 3 Graces". Their clothing and postures indicate for each of them an activity of Aix en Provence.

The statue of justice is located opposite the Cours Mirabeau in the direction of the Palais de Justice.
The statue of commerce and agriculture is facing Marseille and all the industrial part working between these 2 cities.
The statue of the fine arts turns towards the road to Avignon and shows the establishment of the higher universities in the city.

The fountain, active at night, is also illuminated during this time for the happiness and admiration of our eyes.

label: Eglise Saint Laurent
description: The new Saint Laurent Church dates from the 20th century and is Neo-Romanesque in style. The old Saint Laurent Church, on the other hand, was built in the Romanesque style in the 12th century; its bell tower was destroyed during the Revolution and then rebuilt under the Second Empire. The lower annex, built during extensions to the church, dates from the 13th century.

label: Jardins du Pavillon de Vendôme
comment: Large French-style park, where the Pavillon de Vendôme, a 17th century Aix-en-Provence residence, is located.
shortDescription: Large French-style park, where the Pavillon de Vendôme, a 17th century Aix-en-Provence residence, is located.
description:
The garden of the Pavillon de Vendôme is located in the heart of downtown, on the northwest side in the Faubourg des Cordeliers district. The main entrance is on the south side by rue Celony, passing in front of the pleasant rose garden, then the Chinese-inspired forged gate and its park, or by the gate on the north side, by rue de la Molle.

The Pavillon de Vendôme and its garden were built in 1652 for Lucrèce de Forbin-Solliès, known as La Belle du Canet, at the request of Louis de Mercoeur, Duke of Vendôme and Governor of Provence. At her death, the pavilion belonged successively in 1682 to Gautier de la Molle, attorney general, in 1730 to Jean-Sébastien Van-Loo, painter, and in the 19th century to Henri Dobler, who then bequeathed it to the city for the creation of a museum.

Today, the garden has been restored according to engraved documents of the 17th century, in its simple and powerful geometry.

The Pavilion now houses a museum. Embellished by its French garden, the museum invites you to a walk in the heart of history. Pruned boxwoods, fountains and a rose garden accompany you on this journey. This space of 9000 m² is the privileged place of expression of the passionate gardeners who, every year, decorate the flowerbeds in a singular way.

label: Les Bories
comment: Bories are dry stone constructions.
shortDescription: Bories are dry stone constructions.
description:
They were once used as a resting place and shelter for shepherds
About fifty bories have been spotted in the commune.

label: Eglise Saint Vincent
description: The church of Saint Vincent is a beautiful 18th century building. It is the third church of Roquevaire. The High Altar is attributed to the master marble mason Emmanuel Carvalo. It gathers small treasures. The painting "the Companions of Emmaus" classified by the Beaux-Arts, is the work of an anonymous Provencal. The Merovingian Altar placed on a modern pedestal contains the relics of Saint Vincent. The monumental organ integrates the personal console of Pierre Cochereau, prestigious holder of the great organs of Notre Dame de Paris.

label: Villa Paradis
comment: The name of the Villa Paradis, carved in relief on the lintel of the door, speaks volumes about the aspirations of the bourgeoisie of the Belle Epoque who built these suburban villas.
shortDescription: The name of the Villa Paradis, carved in relief on the lintel of the door, speaks volumes about the aspirations of the bourgeoisie of the Belle Epoque who built these suburban villas.
description:
Its name, carved in relief on the lintel of the door, speaks volumes about the aspirations of the bourgeoisie of the Belle Epoque who built these suburban villas

The Villa Paradis faces that of the Camoin family and is located at number 12 of Avenue Jean Jaurès, the former Chemin d'Aix

Its history remains less well known than that of its counterpart, although oral tradition attributes the initiative of its construction to the same Félicien Philippe Camoin in the 1910s, and its execution to the same mason of Berroise origin, Joseph Louis Marie Jauffret (1869 - before 1934)

However, the cadastral archives point to a property owned by the notary Barthélemy Poyet (1866-1930), built after 1915 on former vineyards adjoining the possessions of Marius Ruinat, nurseryman and administrator of the local agricultural credit union. Originally from Vienne in the Dauphiné, Poyet had married Mathilde Aubert, granddaughter of the painter and director of the former school of drawing in Marseille. President of the Chamber of Notaries of Aix, also residing in Marseilles, he occupied in Marignane, until 1911 at least, a house in the rue d'Aix probably adjacent to this new building. But only the ornament at the key of the central window could be a clue to the first occupants: a sea anchor behind which is stretched a sculpted rope

Now a medical practice, and a youth center in the 1950s, it has retained its appearance as a half bastide, half private mansion between courtyard and garden. Unlike the Villa Camoin, the Villa Paradis has kept its fence. It rests on a rustic low wall of rubble stone interrupted by a gate framed by two pillars whose size and proportions cleverly match those of the entrance door

With a quasi-square plan with three bays flanked by two ashlar quoins, it rises to a floor highlighted by a balcony with sculpted balusters. A continuous frieze of glazed tiles finished with two half spheres underlines the roof. A polychrome plant decoration can be seen, drawing on the Art Nouveau repertoire and confirming a dating close to the period 1900-1914. According to the principles of eclecticism in vogue at the time, the transom of the central door adopts the older style of 17th century ironwork. Like that of the Villa Camoin, the ridge of the four-sided roof has an openwork terracotta ridge limited by two bulbous finials. A discreet glance inside reveals the existence of an entrance hall covered with a low stuccoed arch supported by elaborate brackets.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Forêt domaniale des Calanques
comment: The Massif des Calanques, classified as a National Park, is also home to the national forest of the same name.
shortDescription: The Massif des Calanques, classified as a National Park, is also home to the national forest of the same name.
description:
La Gardiole Forest: 839 ha, composed of Aleppo pines, with the highest point being Mount Puget.
Forest of the Calanques: 432 ha.
Numerous hiking trails allow access to the Calanques.

Management of natural areas: State forest
Protected area: Biological reserve
Listed site
Listed site

label: Parc Henri Fabre
description: The Henri Fabre park offers shady paths which bring a freshness much appreciated by the many walkers. Playgrounds for the youngest make it a very popular place. Nearby, the park's pine forest regularly hosts numerous associative and popular events in a typically southern setting.

label: Domaine de Méjanes
comment: In the heart of the Camargue, on the edge of the Vaccarès pond, the Méjanes estate knows how to reconcile respect for a unique, mythical place and its openness to visitors.
shortDescription: In the heart of the Camargue, on the edge of the Vaccarès pond, the Méjanes estate knows how to reconcile respect for a unique, mythical place and its openness to visitors.
description:
In the heart of the Camargue, on the edge of the Vaccarès lake, the Méjanes estate knows how to reconcile respect for a unique and mythical place with its openness to visitors. A land of wide open spaces, where horses and bulls live freely, among thousands of migratory or sedentary birds that find here one of their last natural refuges. The little train of Méjanes, designed by my father, Paul Ricard, will take you for a family walk in this paradise, born from the marriage of land and water.

Professional and passionate herdsmen regularly present bull and horse shows.
Nature tourism, with a mountain bike reception, a trail with unpredictable encounters... horse or pony rides, the possibility of sleeping in caravans or in places steeped in history... two restaurants with local cuisine to taste, a shop selling local products, room hire and the Paul Ricard Museum.

The Domaine de Méjanes is also the ideal place to organise your private or professional events, with a multitude of indoor and outdoor spaces, to receive small groups in a privileged atmosphere in complete privacy, as well as conferences and tailor-made seminars, prestigious or huge parties for thousands of guests.

Leisure activities, restaurants, accommodation, room hire: come and discover the spirit of the Camargue, and enter the legend of Méjanes!

label: Abbaye Saint-Victor
comment: The bishop of "Aix", Lazarus, (whom tradition has long confused with Saint Lazarus, a disciple of Jesus) holds in the region a monk who came from Palestine after a long retreat in Egypt with the Desert Fathers.
shortDescription: The bishop of "Aix", Lazarus, (whom tradition has long confused with Saint Lazarus, a disciple of Jesus) holds in the region a monk who came from Palestine after a long retreat in Egypt with the Desert Fathers.
description:
The bishop of Aix, Lazarus (tradition has often confused him with Saint Lazarus, disciple of Jesus), retained in the region a monk from Palestine after a long retreat in Egypt with the Desert Fathers.
Proculus, bishop of Marseille (380-430), welcomes John Cassian.Cassian, an anachorete, certainly started monastic life in Marseille. However, he is probably not the founder of the abbey, as the archaeological evidence of Saint Victor only goes back to the end of the 5th century. Worship is organized on the site of the present abbey, around a tomb which is venerated. Tradition, once again, has it that it contains the relics of the eponymous martyr of Marseille from the 4th century.
In reality, the crypta preserve highly valuable archaelogical evidence proving the presence of a quarry exploited in Greek times, then of a Hellenic necropolis (2nd century BC) which remained in use in the Christian era. It is lost between the 7th and the end of the 10th century. Saint Victor, like the whole of western Europe, has dark periods with Norman and Saracene invasions.
In 977, monastic life begins again, thanks to bishop Honorat and the first Benedictine abbot Wilfred who submitted the abbey to the rule of Saint Benedict. In 102, a Catalan monk, Isarn, becomes master of the novices and starts extensive building. He constructs the first upper church to which the tower belongs (called Isarn tower), today the access to the church. The main altar is consecrated in 1040. From the end of the 12th century to the 13th century, the abbey is entirely rebuilt according to the rules of the Romanesque builders.
Guillaume de Grimoard, then abbot of Saint Victor (he became pope in Avignon under the name of Urban V) fortified the monastery. The entire complex is included in the port defense system by his successor Grégoire XI.
From the 11th century until the 18th century, Saint Victor has total hegemony over the Christians of the Mediterranean area, from Catalonia to Italy.
Gradually, monastic fervour diminishes and the abbey is secularized by order of the pope in 1739.
The Revolution transforms the church into a fodder store, a prison and a barracks. This avoids its demolition. The abbey is again used for worship under the Premier Empire and restored in the 19th century.
The church was made into a minor basilica in 1934 by Pope Pius XI.
Every year at Candlemas, there is an important pilgrimage at Saint Victor. On 2 February, in the morning, a procession leaves the Old Port for Saint Victor along Rue Sainte. The black Madonna kept in the crypta is arrayed in her green cloak and is presented to the public on the square in front of the church. The archbishop blesses her, celebrates mass and then goes to the "Four des Navettes".

label: Plage de Bonnieu
comment: Sandy Beach. Cove marked in summer time.
shortDescription: Sandy Beach. Cove marked in summer time.
description:
Free parking nearby.
The coastal trail passes close to the beach. 
Swimming not supervised.

label: Parc de Trigance
comment: The park of Trigance is a natural area with a Mediterranean character of 2.5 hectares with more than 450 shrubs
shortDescription: The park of Trigance is a natural area with a Mediterranean character of 2.5 hectares with more than 450 shrubs
description: Trigance Park is a natural area in Mediterranean character of 2.5 hectares with more than 450 shrubs. It hosts a MultiSport of 300 m2, a playground for children consisting of 3 structures and 6 games in spring, a health course composed of 9 structures, benches and of baskets and a public lighting network.

label: Plage Couronne - Vieille
comment: Calm and serenity await you on this picturesque site and charmers where the clear water invites to swimming and diving.
shortDescription: Calm and serenity await you on this picturesque site and charmers where the clear water invites to swimming and diving.
description:
Sandy and pebble beach of approx. 50 m. It is enshrined between an old stone quarry and a cliff.

Swimming not supervised.

label: Parc de Bagatelle
comment: Park of 1.3 hectares with playgrounds for children. Park of the city hall of the 6th and 8th districts. Host to a free music festival in summer.
shortDescription: Park of 1.3 hectares with playgrounds for children. Park of the city hall of the 6th and 8th districts. Host to a free music festival in summer.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained


1.3 hectare park with children's playgrounds. Park of the town hall of sector 6th and 8th districts. Hosts a free music festival in the summer.

label: Unité d'Habitation Le Corbusier (Cité radieuse)
comment: It is the work of the Swiss architect Charles-Edouard Jeanneret, better known as Le Corbusier.
shortDescription: It is the work of the Swiss architect Charles-Edouard Jeanneret, better known as Le Corbusier.
description:
It is the work of the Swiss architect Charles-Edouard Jeanneret, better known as Le Corbusier. This impressive structure, 165 meters long, 24 meters wide and 56 meters high, was built between 1947 and 1951. Its layout is intended to suggest an urban steamboat anchored in a park.
Powerful elements such as the unsurfaced exposed concrete, pilings and blank gable walls are combined with other more sophisticated aspects, such as the subtle arrangement of the multi-coloured loggias, or the superstructures on the terrace roof. This plastic richness, typical of the great architect, associates visual effects with technical organisation that was exceptional at the time. This laboratory for a new "housing system" comprises 337 flats, with 23 different layouts, providing comfortable living spaces for between one and 10 people. The most typical layout is designed for 4 people. It is a duplex on two levels. On one level it takes up the whole width of the building, with a large volume for the living room. A glass panel opens the double height living room onto a balcony. In addition to these technical refinements, numerous extensions of the living space were introduced, designed to induce a new way of living in collective housing: an indoor street with shops, and a hotel for resident's visitors and family members. On the top level is a nursery school and gymnasium. Finally, the terrace roof provides an area for relaxation with a children's paddling pool, play areas and a stage sheltered by a wind-break for open air shows.
Ignoring the mockery summed up by the term "Maison du Fada” (The Crackpot's House), its inhabitants adore the Cité Radieuse. Several flats are still inhabited by the original residents of 1952, and many others have attracted a clientele of well-to-do teachers and architects. It even gained acceptance, since Le Corbusier built other “cités radieuses” in the 1950s based on the Marseille model.

label: Stèle Henri Fabre
comment: The engineer, born in Marseille in 1882, made the first seaplane flight on March 28, 1910.
shortDescription: The engineer, born in Marseille in 1882, made the first seaplane flight on March 28, 1910.
description:
6 km on the Etang de Berre between La Mède and Martigues, thus opening a new era.
The commemorative stele of the exploit was inaugurated on June 18, 1936 in the city of Pradine à la Mède.

label: Le Mas de la Pyramide
description: A rural museum located in the former Roman quarry and its Pyramid, a rock more than 20 m high which testifies to the cutting work carried out in prehistoric times and continued by the Roman occupants. It is also possible to visit part of the troglodyte Mas.

label: Musée Jean Moulin de Saint Andiol
comment: Museum retracing the life of the resistance fighter Jean Moulin, explaining his Provencal roots and his attachment to the village of Saint-Andiol.
shortDescription: Museum retracing the life of the resistance fighter Jean Moulin, explaining his Provencal roots and his attachment to the village of Saint-Andiol.
description: -A dive unique in the life of Jean Moulin - in a historic building, once municipal school where Jean Moulin was student - the discovery of his Provencal roots - more than 200 m² of exhibition - 200 rare photos, archives, objects of era and films - videos teaching - Reconstitution with sound and Visual effects of the cabin of the aircraft which dropped Jean Moulin near Saint Andiol on January 2, 1942, "Remember my country": this is how Jean Moulin was the village of Saint Andiol.The Jean Moulin Saint-Andiol Museum gives its visitors all of the keys to understanding, in an interactive way, the life course: a history born in Provence, before national and European paths in the service of ideals humanists to the ultimate sacrifice.OPENING hours from 9 July 2018.July & August: Monday/Saturday: 9 h 30 / 12 h - 14 h/17. Sunday: 14: 00 / 18: 00. September-December: Monday/Saturday: 9 h 30 / 12 h.Closed public holidays. RATES 2018 entry: 4EUR rate reduced: 2EUR - school group from 10 persons with disabilities upon presentation of a certificate, children 10 to 18 years, former combatants.Free: St. Andiolais, holder of a press card on presentation of a certificate, children up to 9 years, teachers planning a school visit. TO follow all the news of the Museum on FACEBOOK: Museum Jean Moulin Saint - Andiol - "Remember my country"
streetAddress: ['Place du Maréchal de Lattre de Tassigny']

label: Monument Etienne Richaud
comment: Monument inaugurated on July 2, 1899, dismantled in 1943 under the Vichy regime to be melted down and recovered overnight by the Richaud family, it was hidden in Mimet then returned to the Liberation and put back in place.
shortDescription: Monument inaugurated on July 2, 1899, dismantled in 1943 under the Vichy regime to be melted down and recovered overnight by the Richaud family, it was hidden in Mimet then returned to the Liberation and put back in place.
description:
This sculpture of a bronze bust on a pedestal is a homage to Etienne Richaud (1841-1889) provided by public funds. Etienne Richaud, son and grandson of fishermen, was born at no. 7 Rue Galinière in 1841. He was a brilliant student and had senior positions in the public service.
The first governor general of Indochina, then inspector of the marine and colonies, he died at sea on 31 May 1889 on the Calédonien.

label: Parc Borély
comment: The Borély park, which covers 18 hectares (including 1.2 hectares for the botanical garden), is the most popular green space in Marseille.
shortDescription: The Borély park, which covers 18 hectares (including 1.2 hectares for the botanical garden), is the most popular green space in Marseille.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


This 17-hectare garden is home to an 18th-century country house, enhanced by a French garden and a 19th-century landscaped park. The garden retains the imprint of the engineer and architect Embry (1775). From this project remain the symmetrical lines of the present garden with two main axes (N-S/E-W), the rectangular basins and the geometrical parterres. Between 1860 and 1880, the City of Marseille called upon Alphand (planting engineer for the City of Paris) to create a public park on the property. He entrusted the execution of the project to his collaborator Barillet-Deschamps. The juxtaposition of the park and the French garden gives Borély an additional charm. Its paths are very popular with joggers and walkers who also enjoy strolling through the rose garden or discovering the rare species of the botanical garden. The lake, its pier, its refreshment bar and its restaurant (awaiting a new manager) complete the multiple attractions of the site. Borély is also a children's paradise with two playgrounds... In 1995, the 19th century rock waterfall was chosen to serve as a setting for Jean-Michel Folon's original work "L'Homme aux oiseaux". In the same year, an educational trail was set up to discover the various treasures of the park. The signposting of the plants presents the most remarkable trees of the park. The identification of the birds of the lake is approached in a similar way.

label: Eglise Sainte Anne
description: Saint Anne Church, built in 1628 on the site of a Romanesque chapel, was the second parish church in the village at the time. It was deconsecrated in 1875 in favour of St Joseph Church and was turned into a cultural centre in 2009.

label: Médiathèque - Le Jardin des mots
comment: Novels, documentaries, comic strips for adults and children, 90 subscriptions to periodicals (regional and national daily newspapers, various magazines, children's magazines...) she also lends DVDs and audio readings.
shortDescription: Novels, documentaries, comic strips for adults and children, 90 subscriptions to periodicals (regional and national daily newspapers, various magazines, children's magazines...) she also lends DVDs and audio readings.
description:
The media library organizes special events around a theme every 2 to 3 months, in addition to the regular events that take place throughout the year:
For adults: reading itineraries, thematic reading committee (once a quarter), monthly writing workshop, Thursdays, For children: Croqu'histoires : stories told to children : 2 age groups, Wednesdays and Fridays.
Les Mots plein la bouche: children's favourite.
For teenagers: a video game or cinema evening: 1st Friday of the month.
Registration to the Médiathèque is free for the residents of the commune. A contribution of 8 euros per family for the year is required for the loan of DVDs.
Please bring your identity card or family record book and proof of address. You can borrow up to 8 books per card, plus 2 DVDs per section per week.

label: La Tour de l'Horloge
comment: The Clock Tower in Aureille.
shortDescription: The Clock Tower in Aureille.
description: La Tour de l'Horloge - neo-Romanesque style - erected in place of the bell tower of the first church of the village Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption (formerly Sainte-Marie parish church)

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de Miséricorde dite Notre Dame des Marins
comment: This 17th century chapel dedicated to the Virgin was of particular importance for sailors returning to port.
shortDescription: This 17th century chapel dedicated to the Virgin was of particular importance for sailors returning to port.
description:
Fishermen used to offer votive offerings here when they survived a storm.
Guardian of the city, the votive offerings and the statue of the Virgin are exhibited at the Ziem museum.
The panorama over the city, the Etang de Berre, to the peaks of Sainte-Victoire is magnificent.

The name of the bell is Césarie, with mention of the names of Gaby Charroux, deputy mayor of Martigues and Benoît Delabre, parish priest.
On the bell is engraved the words: "Salve Regina Mater Misericordiae, ora pro Martiguensis Deum."
A drawing of a Virgin of Mercy (mantle) is also shown.

label: Granet XXe, collection Jean Planque
comment: The Granet Museum has expanded in the Chapel of the White Penitents, a jewel of 17th century Aix-en-Provence architecture. More than 700 m2 of additional exhibition space is now available to the public.
shortDescription: The Granet Museum has expanded in the Chapel of the White Penitents, a jewel of 17th century Aix-en-Provence architecture. More than 700 m2 of additional exhibition space is now available to the public.
description:
The modern art collection at the Granet Museum was considerably expanded in 2010 when the Jean and Suzanne Planque Foundation made a 15-year donation of the Jean Planque collection, named after the Swiss painter and collector, who died in 1998. The collection includes some 300 paintings, drawings and sculptures by Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh, Degas and Redon, and the major artists of the 20th century, including Bonnard, Rouault, Picasso, Braque, Dufy, Laurens, Léger, Klee, Bissière, de Staël and Dubuffet.
The Granet Museum develops a dynamic policy towards the public, considering wider access to the arts and culture as a priority. 
Guided visits for groups and individual visitors are on offer to the permanent collections and temporary exhibitions at the Granet 20th site in French, English, German and Spanish. Audio-guides are available for rent in a number of languages (French, English, German, Italian, Spanish and Japanese) for adults for 3 euros and for children aged 6 and over (French and English) for 2 euros.

Activities for children and families are on offer all through the year (guided visits and workshops). A game booklet about the collections is available free at the site entrance on request. 

The Granet 20th site, Jean Planque collection, was given the Tourism and Disability label in June 2017.
streetAddress: ['Chapelle des Pénitents Blancs', 'Haut de la rue Maréchal Joffre', 'Place Jean Boyer']

label: Tour Tourreluque
description:
Until 1848 the city was enclosed within a wall. The Tourreluque tower and a section of the 14th-century curtain are all that remains of this mediaeval wall.

Polygonal corner tower of the wall from the time of the Hundred-Years' War (before 1375).

label: Temple Romain de Vernègues
description:
The small Roman temple of Vernègues is the last standing vestige of an ancient settlement in Corinthian style, built in the years 20-30 BC. Classified as a Historical Monument, it was probably dedicated to a water cult deity, as there is a spring nearby. Only part of the eastern wall and the north and west bases are still visible. A Romanesque chapel, rehabilitated in 1997 by the Monuments Historiques, is attached to the eastern wall of the temple. An excavation campaign started in 1999, to the west of the temple will undoubtedly enrich our knowledge of this beautiful building.

A short walk allows you to admire it (free access), as well as to enjoy this sublime place.

label: Le Château d'Eguilles
description:
Built for the Boyer d’Eguilles family in the 17th century, on the foundations of the feudal castle, the château now houses the town hall. 

The view from its esplanade stretches as far as the Etang de Berre. Its frontage is listed as a Historical Monument and its inner staircase is listed as a regional-class historical monument.

label: Bibliothèque Départementale des Bouches-du-Rhône
comment: The departmental library is dedicated to the development of reading in municipalities with less than 20,000 inhabitants.
shortDescription: The departmental library is dedicated to the development of reading in municipalities with less than 20,000 inhabitants.
description:
The departmental library is dedicated to the development of reading in municipalities with less than 20,000 inhabitants.

 The role of the departmental library: To constitute a multimedia resource centre for public reading libraries and other communities

Loans are made by Bookmobile tour or by on-site borrowing for 96 municipal libraries and 27 deposit locations: schools, rural centres, cultural centres. This service is also offered on an ad hoc basis to other structures.

Supporting the construction, fitting out and equipping of public reading libraries with computers (cyber space) and multimedia

Participate in the professional training of library professionals: initial training cycle, continuing education days, study days

Propose cultural events: travelling thematic exhibitions, literary shows, in particular on the occasion of Lire en Fête

A few figures: Documentary collection: 354,000 books, 16,000 large-format books, 68,000 CDs, 10,500 videocassettes, 32,800 DVDs, 1,100 CD-ROMs, 4,000 musical scores, 150 exhibitions. Network: 100 communes are served by the departmental library, the communes in the north of the department being particularly served by the Saint-Rémy-de-Provence establishment.

label: Eglise Saint Amand
description:
At the end of the 11th century, the lords of Sénas had three chapels built, including that of Saint-Amand, which was later promoted to parish church. The bell tower, built in 1306, is distinguished by a spire decorated with rostrums. The frescoes were made in the 19th century.
On the north wall, rebuilt at the beginning of the 12th century, is the burial place of the family of the Knight and Marquis Charles de Jarentes.
The paintings, the baptismal font, the stoup and the statues were the subject of a meticulous restoration in 2009 as well as the entire interior of the church.

label: Atelier de Louis Jou
comment: The Louis Jou Foundation is pleased to open the doors of the master typographer's studio and invites you to take a free stroll through the life and work of the illustrious artist from Baux-de-Provence.
shortDescription: The Louis Jou Foundation is pleased to open the doors of the master typographer's studio and invites you to take a free stroll through the life and work of the illustrious artist from Baux-de-Provence.
description:
In addition, the Foundation organizes a guided tour of printing, typography and the history of the book. Discover printing techniques through demonstrations of printing on Stanhope presses, the first all-metal models
July and August, guided tours at 3pm, 4pm and 5:30pm.

label: Les Roches Plates
description:
Slabs (flat rocks) plunging into the sea. Bars and restaurants nearby. Natural, unsupervised "beach". Difficult access to the sea.
Cassis direction La Presqu'île, then parking on the Bestouan or Presqu'ile car park. Access to the regulated car parks, on weekends in July and August, shuttles from the free car park of Les Gorguettes.

label: Musée d'art local et d'archéologie de lambesc
description:
The museum presents to its visitors collections retracing the past of the village of Lambesc: furniture, costumes, tools and archaeological remains. Three rooms expose the historical heritage of the village, two rooms are reserved for archaeological finds discovered in the town. An agricultural space has been installed under the old courtyard.
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 300
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 60

label: Musée du Calisson - Confiserie du Roy René
comment: From nougat to Calisson: the Roi René Calissons, a family story in Provence.
shortDescription: From nougat to Calisson: the Roi René Calissons, a family story in Provence.
description:
The Calisson of Aix is fully recognized as a heritage of the city of Aix-en-Provence and more generally as one of the gastronomic emblems of Provence. Boeotians or enthusiasts can continue their journey in the heart of the authentic flavors of the Calisson by visiting the magical environment of the Roy René, house soon a hundred years old.

Just 10 minutes from downtown Aix-en-Provence, surrounded by more than 2 hectares of young almond trees, stands the Confectionery Factory of Roy René, which combines tradition and modernity. Made with stone blocks from Castillon, labeled the Mediterranean Sustainable Building, it contains a state-of-the-art production area.

La Fabrique hosts the Musée du Calisson, which offers a true gourmet epic!

In this place, suspended between the past and today, one passes from one epoch to another, from one season to another, from the blossoming of the almond trees to the harvest gestures, from an old chip tool to this virtual one that allows realizing in real time a batch of real calissons!
The public follows the work of the confectioners and the stages of production of the little "hugs of Provence" and offers a total diving in this fascinating and gourmet world that is confectionery.

Round off a trip to the Calisson Museum with a bit of fresh air to uncover the history of the almond tree in Provence in 2ha of grounds open to the general public.
Jardins du Roy René is home to an almond tree orchard with 300 trees, a regional and Mediterranean plant garden and heirloom orchard protecting fifty almond trees from nineteen different Provençal species. The grounds were set up in 2016 and symbolise a commitment to revive Provence's almond tree and fuel sustainable development. The grounds showcase our region's wealth of plantlife. Whether it be flowers or trees, the idea is to itemise, collect, tend and, most importantly, protect these species. Everything is grown in line with organic farming and agroecology methods.

label: Domaine de Marseilleveyre
comment: Sea, peaks, breathtaking viewpoints... The departmental domain of Marseilleveyre is a thousand hectares of verticality at the gates of Marseille.
shortDescription: Sea, peaks, breathtaking viewpoints... The departmental domain of Marseilleveyre is a thousand hectares of verticality at the gates of Marseille.
description:
At the southern end of the city, this jewel conceals treasures so precious that it attracts seasoned hikers from the other side of the world. Here live and reproduce plants that tell the story of the planet

From the heights, after having taken sometimes difficult paths, one discovers the astonishing scenery of the harbor of Marseille and its islands.
In this space, apart from the smell of the mountains, each corner reveals a marvel. And in winter, as if by a miracle, there is a very mild climate

Department staff, including the forestry workers' board, are permanently ensuring the protection of this incomparable site.

Management of natural areas 
Domain of the General Council

label: Lavoir
comment: In the 19th century, the covered washhouse was built in Fontvieille stone. The fresh water comes from the "vieille font" fountain, located next door. At the time, it was used by the inhabitants of the village to wash their clothes during the "bugado" ("laundry" in Provencal).
shortDescription: In the 19th century, the covered washhouse was built in Fontvieille stone. The fresh water comes from the "vieille font" fountain, located next door. At the time, it was used by the inhabitants of the village to wash their clothes during the "bugado" ("laundry" in Provencal).
description:
This is a very attractive wash house made of Fontvieille stone.
The fresh water came from the 'Vieille Font' fountain nearby. At the time, the inhabitants used it to wash their clothes during the 'bugado' ('washing' in Provençal).
It is fairly large, as the village's population was growing steadily over time, and the wash house had to meet everyone's needs.
It is a timeless place; it is in the country and thus has a calm atmosphere.
The water was then removed via a small irrigation canal called a 'roubino', which ran through the fields.
This 19th century wash house is covered with timbers on pillars. Visitors can see the protective wall made of Fontvieille stone during the second half of the 19th century.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Gris
description:
The exact date of construction of the chapel is not known.
The Brotherhood of the White Penitents was founded in 1646.
Its members wore a balaclava and a dawn made of cloth (hence their name "Bourras") in order to erase any social differences.
They observed strict rules and gave service to the community through charitable works such as assistance to the elderly and homeless.
The chapel now serves as a home for young parishioners.

label: Parc de la Mirabelle
comment: Park of 2 hectares. Playgrounds, bowls, festivals in summer.
shortDescription: Park of 2 hectares. Playgrounds, bowls, festivals in summer.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.


Park located in the heart of the ZAC des Caillols south designed on a 2 hectare property bought by the town in 1975, and developed in 1981. Playgrounds, boules games, festivals in summer.

label: Le Puy Sainte Réparade
description:
Le Puy Sainte-Réparade is a Provençal village in the north of the Bouches-du-Rhône department. 


Its location, in contact with Aix en Provence and on the edge of the Durance, is in the centre of the area marking a transition between Greater Aix and the towns of the Lubéron. 


The territory of Le Puy is enclosed by natural frontiers: the Rognes massif to the west, the Trévaresse range to the south and the Durance river to the north. 


The Quilho (Keel) hill, a natural fortress overlooking the present village, gave its name to Le Puy, "Puech" or Hill in Provençal. 
It is an active village, with a renovated municipal swimming pool, tennis courts, a gymnasium, a bowling alley, walking and cycling routes, and fishing in the Durance. 


See also the Château d'Arnajon (historical monument) and the church of the Assumption of Sainte Marie. 


"Sainte Réparade" is probably a corruption of the name "Sainte Réparate", a saint whose relics were transferred to the parish of Saint Maurice du Puy in the 11th century.

label: Vallon du Saut
comment:
The valley of the jump presents very varied aspects.
the circuit has been selected by the Departmental Plan for Small Hiking Trails (PDIPR).
shortDescription:
The valley of the jump presents very varied aspects.
the circuit has been selected by the Departmental Plan for Small Hiking Trails (PDIPR).
description:
You will find on site:
- Prehistoric sites (campaniform chalcolithic): Desbaussadou cave and Fortin du Saut.
- Rock walls conducive to the installation of famous climbing sites.
- Geological curiosities: pierced rock, needles and rock formations.
- At the top, a magnificent panorama of the Berre and Bolmon ponds, with the main mountain ranges of Provence as a backdrop.

label: Pont Levant
comment:
It replaces the 1929 swing bridge.
Opening hours of the lifting bridge:
- All year round: 9:05 a.m. / 2:05 p.m. / 7:05 p.m.
- Additional hours from June 15 to September 15: 6:05 am / 10:55 am / 9:00 pm.
shortDescription:
It replaces the 1929 swing bridge.
Opening hours of the lifting bridge:
- All year round: 9:05 a.m. / 2:05 p.m. / 7:05 p.m.
- Additional hours from June 15 to September 15: 6:05 am / 10:55 am / 9:00 pm.
description:
Said bridge opening and located at the end of the pass of Jonquieres. 
The work will begin in 1959 to be completed in 1962.It opens in two flights of 28m50 each. It is carried by an electric manoeuvre controlled from the lookout of a nearby Bridge House.

label: Monument aux morts
description:
The execution of this monument was entrusted to the sculptor Henri Raybaud and the architect Gaston Castel

The statue is composed of two groups, described as follows in the explanatory memorandum of the "Monument to the memory of the Victorious Children of the City, who died for France"

"On a base of beautiful white stone stands the allegorical group in Carrara marble, representing the winged Victory flying over two soldiers, a young alpine hunter and a hairy old man. Warrior attributes, cannon wheel, carriage, old Kraut helmet are at their feet.

At the bottom of the monument, the City of Aubagne, symbolized by a noble woman, shows a child the respect and admiration one should have for these soldiers, artisans of the Great Peace - and with a simple gesture, she holds out an olive branch to her sons, valiant heroes of whom she is proud."

label: Parc du Pigeonnier
description: Public garden of 6000m².

label: Place Gérard Tenque
comment: Semi-shaded square surrounded by terraces of restaurants, breweries and bars.
shortDescription: Semi-shaded square surrounded by terraces of restaurants, breweries and bars.
description:
A commemorative plaque in the Île-de-France district also celebrates the memory of the illustrious martgal whose statue stands on the facade of the Saint-Genest church in Jonquières.
Blessed Gérard Tenque (1040-1120) is from Martigues, he founded the Saint Jean de Jerusalem hospital.
He is the founder of the Order of Hospitallers known as Malta.

label: Abbaye cistercienne
comment: 13th century abbey.
shortDescription: 13th century abbey.
description:
The Cistercian abbey known as the "Dames de Mollégès" dates from the 13th century. At that time, the development of the village was due to its establishment. The abbey was ravaged and partly destroyed by Raymond de Turenne around 1360. At the end of the 16th century, it was restored and fortified. A beautiful fortified gate and part of the rectangular enclosure remain. A covered way starts on each side of the gate. In the 16th century, it was transformed: beautiful Renaissance windows, framed by fluted pilasters and Ionic capitals, each window is topped by a triangular pediment. It became a stately home for the Châteauneuf-Mollégès family. Today it is called "The Castle" and is inhabited
The abbey cannot be visited and can be admired from the outside.

label: Eglise Saint-Maurice de Pélissanne
description:
This 19th century church is the third to be built on this site following a first Romanesque church (1069) and a church built in 1625.
Its dimensions are imposing: 42m long, 27m wide and 17m under the vault.
It has a beautiful neo-classical façade.
Its Tuscan architecture makes it a sober and massive building that contrasts with the interior.
Inside there is a 15th century triptych altarpiece with a Virgin and Child on the central panel, St. Roch on the left and St. Sebastian on the right.
The Gothic bell tower dates from the church of 1625.
It was immortalized by Jacques Daguerre in 1837 for his first outdoor photographic experience.
During the terrible earthquake of 1909, the spire of the bell tower collapsed. It was rebuilt in 1913. A photograph of the bell tower and its original spire is kept at the Musée archéologique municipal de Pélissanne.

label: Plage du Rouet
comment: In a natural cove with turquoise colors, it is the largest beach of the town with a sandy part and a pebble part. It is partially reserved for deckchairs (private beaches). It is also a surf spot in winter.
shortDescription: In a natural cove with turquoise colors, it is the largest beach of the town with a sandy part and a pebble part. It is partially reserved for deckchairs (private beaches). It is also a surf spot in winter.
description:
Plage du Rouet
"Plage du Rouet" is Carry-le-Rouet's largest and hence busiest beach! Fully fitted out with showers, toilets and disabled facilities, it is also attended by a lifeguard in summer. 
This delightful, sandy beach benefits from shallow waters where children can dabble in all safety, play their favourite beach games or take part in the swimming lessons given by qualified instructors. The nearby diving club offers exciting discovery itineraries along the Côte Bleue coast  you can also hire out a kayak if the fancy takes you. The beach is situated adjacent to a choice of restaurants and bars, and sun lovers can also hire out a lounger to make the most of their day.

label: Le centre historique de Lambesc
description: The golden age left Lambesc with a rich collection of mansions. Erected as a principality by King René, the town was indeed in the 17th and 18th centuries, the annual seat of the assembly of the communities of Provence. It was during this period that the Hôtel Pagy de Valbonne and the Hôtel Cadenet Charleval were built. The church Notre Dame de la Rose and its collection of Provencal paintings contribute to the charm of Lambesc. From this period, there remains in the old centre of Lambesc only a remarkable set of private mansions and several fountains inspired by those of Aix en Provence. The city has however many other remarkable monuments: the church Notre Dame de la Rose, a wash house classified as a historical monument, the building of the Hôtel Dieu and thirteen oratories.

label: Hôtel de Divonne
description:
(formerly Hôtel du Roure)
This mansion, built in the same style as the Parisian mansions of the time, has façades on which it is still possible to see all the particularly sophisticated original decoration, as well as most of its interior layout.
From the street, visitors can admire the porch bearing the coat of arms of the Le Roure family, the three wings surrounding the courtyard, the décor of supporting wall ties on the ground floor and the elegance of the large windows.
HISTORY
The Le Roure family, one of the most brilliant in the town, was confirmed in its nobility by letters patent in 1758. An alliance with the Du Laurens family gave them the Barony of Beaujeu and the Barbegal estate, which contained a large vineyard in the late 19th century. Several members of the family played important roles in local life, such as Henri du Roure (born in 1741), Mayor of Arles from 1805 to 1807 and Host Jérôme Scipion, known as the Baron du Roure (1858-1924), The heritage funds of the municipal media library house the family archives. A descendant, Anna, born in 1859, married Count Laforest de Divonne, who bought and gave his name to the family residence on Rue de la Roquette in 1900. The mansion is now divided into several apartments.

label: Parc du Gour
comment: 2 hectares built in 2 storm basins and decorated with 300 trees and shrubs (Montpellier maples, acacia, willows, poplars, pines, plane trees).
shortDescription: 2 hectares built in 2 storm basins and decorated with 300 trees and shrubs (Montpellier maples, acacia, willows, poplars, pines, plane trees).
description: Its tarmacked and hilly paths are ideal for rollerblading, skateboarding and children's cycling. It is home to a skate park.

label: Parc du Corbusier
comment: Park of 2.8 hectares, playgrounds, open all year.
shortDescription: Park of 2.8 hectares, playgrounds, open all year.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.


Park of 2.8 hectares, playgrounds, open all year round.

label: Peypin
description:
Surrounded by hills, the Provencal landscape of this village has kept all its authenticity and will delight lovers of hiking
In the 12th century, the lord of Auriol had a castle built which was destroyed at the end of the 16th century
The small winding alleys, flower-filled and welcoming squares and the ochre-coloured palette of the houses in this village give Peypin a very special charm to which many visitors have already succumbed
Do not miss to visit the ruins of the old castle, the parish church and its beautiful bell tower
Not forgetting, at the entrance of the village, a beautiful oil press of yesteryear.

label: Musée du santon Le Moulin à Huile
description:
The Return to the Source: history of the santon of Provence.
Come and discover the wonderful museum presented by the Oil Mill, "the return to the sources", find the trades and life of Provence at the end of the 19th century.
Panoramic crib of 320m2 more than 500 santons and automatons.
Open from Monday to Friday from 8.30am to 12pm and from 2pm to 5.30pm

label: Plage Rives d'Or
comment:
Golden Shores Beaches
Sausset-les-Pins, a small seaside resort on the Côte Bleue, is part of the Marine Park.
shortDescription:
Golden Shores Beaches
Sausset-les-Pins, a small seaside resort on the Côte Bleue, is part of the Marine Park.
description:
Plage des Rives d’Or
Sausset-les-Pins – a small resort on the Côte Bleue coast -, is part of the "Marine Park": a protected area where fishing and underwater hunting are prohibited. Diving and snorkelling fans will simply adore exploring the crystal-clear waters of "Plage des Rives d’Or" beach, overflowing with every imaginable Mediterranean fish species.
The beach itself is not very large, but is handily located just 200 metres from the town centre and fitted with full amenities including an adjacent paying car park, refreshment stands, showers, toilets, lifeguards and bins, so users can clean up behind them!
