"Plage des Rives d’Or" also bears the "Tourism & Handicap" label and offers disabled parking spots, plus special equipment operated by the lifeguards ("Tiralo" amphibious chair and "Hippocampe" beach wheelchair).

label: Phare du Cap Couronne
comment: The lighthouse stands at the south of La Couronne village, at the eastern entrance of Golfe de Fos.
shortDescription: The lighthouse stands at the south of La Couronne village, at the eastern entrance of Golfe de Fos.
description:
It is the only lighthouse on the Côte Bleue, between the small port of Carro to the west and Estaque in the east, very close to Marseille. The monument is in a magnificent setting surrounded by small inlets. 
It was built in 1959. 

A cylindrical tower, the lower part is white and the top is red. The lighthouse has a radar antenna. Automated and guarded 24/7. It is 36 metres high. The scope of the light is 20 miles. The light is provided by a 650 W halogen lamp and a red light occults every 3 seconds.

Not open to visitors.

label: Lavoir
description: Located under the Town Hall Square, this wash-house was built around 1905, during the development of the square. It is laid out with mannequins depicting the laundry. Staged restores a laundry such that she could take place at the beginning of the twentieth century. Wax mannequins are quick around the basin can also distinguish various "instruments" (blow bars, tubs, racks...), as well as instructions or arrested municipal regarding the use of the premises: defense is for example made of washing of sick people.Restored in 2007 by the Town Hall and laid out by the Association of Conservation of heritage this space is visible during guided tours of groups, on the occasion of the visits that take place in the summer on Thursday morning. During the European heritage days, the laundry is put into water and a bugado is made.

label: Oppidum des Caisses de Jean Jean
comment: It is an oppidum located at the top of a rocky spur, in a basin surrounded to the north and south by steep limestone cliffs, which meet to the east to form an acropolis.
shortDescription: It is an oppidum located at the top of a rocky spur, in a basin surrounded to the north and south by steep limestone cliffs, which meet to the east to form an acropolis.
description:
Fortifications from several periods have been identified, attesting to the settlement of this oppidum from the 6th to the 1st centuries BC. The first rampart predates 500 BC, however, it has been the subject of successive reconstructions and the last rebuilding - the remains of which are now visible - can be dated to between 180 and 150 BC. The defensive apparatus was reinforced to the west by 4 successive ditches alternating with earth embankments and a line of spiky rocks acting as frieze horses.
In the fragments of the ramparts, we find blocks in reuse (steles, lintels...) representing one and the same motif: that of a rider armed with a javelin. This element suggests that the site would have sheltered a sanctuary around the 7th or 6th century BC.
The spur and its southern slope were inhabited until the end of the 3rd century AD. The oppida of the region are indeed gradually abandoned at the time of the Romanization of Provence, a Romanization which accelerates under the reign of Augustus (end of the 1st century AD). For some, the abandonment will be definitive but others, such as the Baux or Castillon (at Paradou), will be recovered in the Middle Ages.
The site was listed as a historical monument by a decree of February 2, 1974. It is accessible via a signposted route.

label: Eglise dédiée à Saint Mitre et Saint Blaise
comment: The church has a pretty steeple with hooks inspired by the late Gothic style, built in 1651 by local master masons.
shortDescription: The church has a pretty steeple with hooks inspired by the late Gothic style, built in 1651 by local master masons.
description:
From the terrace of the church, beautiful view of the pond of Pourra.
Below, springs a source which supplies a fountain and a wash house.

label: La Quille
comment: La Quille, or Quiho in Provençal... This original estate, with its 19 hectares of greenery and oak woods, was bought in 1994 by the Department.
shortDescription: La Quille, or Quiho in Provençal... This original estate, with its 19 hectares of greenery and oak woods, was bought in 1994 by the Department.
description:
The investment proves to be judicious since every weekend La Quille receives families amazed by the originality of the place, spread out on a small hilly plateau in the south of the commune of Le Puy-Sainte-Réparade, in the chain of La Trévaresse
On the top: the traces of an old castle and a splendid view of the surrounding area. Further down: quality fittings. The old terrace crops have been renovated and made practicable. A classic water point has been transformed into a fountain. A sports trail, a picnic area and an orientation table complete the facilities. Finally, as in La Manueye, a voluntarist policy has allowed the maintenance of a shepherd who grazes his flock here. He thus participates in the maintenance of the site. A simple and natural way to clear the brush...

Management of natural areas: Domaine du Conseil Général

label: Le Phare
description: Built in Cassis stone at the beginning of the 20th century, it was damaged in 1944 and rebuilt by local quarrymen (notably Evariste Gambi).

label: Préau des Accoules
comment: The former Jesuit college in the 17th century, then the Royal Observatory of the Navy and finally the headquarters of the Academy of Sciences, Letters and Fine Arts, the complex now houses a primary school.
shortDescription: The former Jesuit college in the 17th century, then the Royal Observatory of the Navy and finally the headquarters of the Academy of Sciences, Letters and Fine Arts, the complex now houses a primary school.
description:
The Academy Hall (1782-83), designed by Esprit-Joseph Brun, is rich in history and surprises behind the austere façade, with its harmonious neoclassical architecture, its elevation and its flat vault. Today it hosts exhibitions inspired by the rich collections of the Museums of Marseille and specially designed for children in nursery and primary schools.

Since January 22nd, the museum is only open by appointment: you must phone beforehand. You can leave a message on the answering machine and the team will call back afterwards
In the morning the museum is open to school groups, in the afternoon to individuals.

label: Pont du Bosquet dit romain
description: Also known as the Roman bridge. This beautiful romantic bridge, however, only dates from 1812 and spans the Canal des Alpines, dug on the eve of the Revolution and completed around 1840. It was renovated in 2005

label: Tour carrée du Roy René
comment: At the time of the Crusades, the site had been granted to the Hospitallers of Saint John of Jerusalem, who settled on this steep promontory and raised their Commandery there to transport troops to the Holy Land.
shortDescription: At the time of the Crusades, the site had been granted to the Hospitallers of Saint John of Jerusalem, who settled on this steep promontory and raised their Commandery there to transport troops to the Holy Land.
description:
The Hospitallers occupied the former chapel of St. John the Baptist and then began construction of a new church, the hospital and the Commander's palace. The complex was completed in 1365. Control of the entrance to the port was ensured by a chain of 226 large rings linking the two towers of Saint-Nicolas and Maubec. When the Aragonese sacked Marseille in 1423, the chain was completely destroyed and the chain was taken away as a trophy by the Spaniards. Roy René, wishing to defend the port more effectively, had a new tower built on the same site as the Maubec tower, which bears his name: Tour du Roy René or Square Tower (1447-1453). The tower is 28.50 metres high and consists of 4 rooms served by a spiral staircase with 147 steps. A first room of 42 m2, a second room of 58.60 m2, a third one of 44.20 m2, and a last one of 42.20 m2. The roof terrace has a surface area of 180 m2 that can be used

It now houses part of the Mucem, the Museum of the Civilizations of Europe and the Mediterranean, and is only open for temporary exhibitions.

label: Médiathèque de la Bouilladisse
description:
Registration upon presentation of proof of identity.
For the book: free of charge for residents and €5.00 per year for non-residents over 14 years of age.
For multimedia: €15.00 per year per family.

label: Le Beffroi de Pélissanne
description: The first Belfry was built in 1556 on the site of the drawbridge that commanded the entrance to the "Castrum". When it was rebuilt in 1702, it was adorned with a magnificent wrought-iron dome, the work of master watchmaker Quintrand de Lambesc, and a few years later with a sundial on the south façade.

label: Le jardin de la Vierge
comment: Enclosed garden in Rognonas.
shortDescription: Enclosed garden in Rognonas.
description: At the end of the XIXa century, the cemetery of the town was moved and a garden was created. The 10 number 1875, a statue of the Virgin was inaugurated, making this garden the "garden of the Virgin". The last Sunday of August at 9 pm held a procession with live tables remember Elisa Seisson, 10th miracle of Lourdes in 1882.
streetAddress: ['Avenue de la Libération', 'Place de la Vierge']

label: Théâtre Nô
comment: Among the most special monuments in Aix-en-Provence is the Noh Theatre. It was donated to the city of Aix-en-Provence in 1992 by the Kano family, a renowned dynasty of the ancestral art of Noh
shortDescription: Among the most special monuments in Aix-en-Provence is the Noh Theatre. It was donated to the city of Aix-en-Provence in 1992 by the Kano family, a renowned dynasty of the ancestral art of Noh
description:
Among the most peculiar monuments of Aix-en-Provence is the Théâtre Nô. It was offered in 1992 to the city of Aix-en-Provence by the Kano family, renowned dynasty of the ancestral art of No.

The scene of the Théâtre Nô of Aix-en-Provence is made of cypress wood from Japan (hinoki), original, built and used in the country of the Rising Sun. This gift of great brand was the starting point of many exchanges with Aix-en-Provence. Indeed, the No Theater is an important element in the relations of the City with Kumamoto city.

Its installation in the Parc Saint Mitre will mark the stage (the butaï) and its envelope as a cultural element in a vast natural ensemble, allowing the search for synergies with its natural, patrimonial and urban environment.

label: La plage des Beaumettes
comment:
Beach of Very Fine Pebbles
Equipment : Shower, first-aid station
shortDescription:
Beach of Very Fine Pebbles
Equipment : Shower, first-aid station

label: Cadéraou et Figuerolles
comment: The hills of Cadéraou and Figuerolles are a forest area of 426 hectares, located towards Saint Miter. It constitutes a pleasant walk made of paths and paths which dominate the pond of Berre, far from its industrial part.
shortDescription: The hills of Cadéraou and Figuerolles are a forest area of 426 hectares, located towards Saint Miter. It constitutes a pleasant walk made of paths and paths which dominate the pond of Berre, far from its industrial part.
description:
Bring walking shoes and water and go for a 3 or 4 hour walk that will take you to a small secluded beach made up of mounds of shells.
The decor is magical, you will come across the local fauna: song thrush, oak jay, wood chaffinch, pichou warbler, the turtledove and the circaetus Jean-le-blanc who hide in the middle of a rich and dense flora: junipers , lavender, rosemary, cistus, Aleppo pines, kermes oaks, holm oaks, tamarisks and Montpellier maples.

The trails are signposted and the views over the Etang de Berre dazzling. This walk takes you to discover a little-known corner of the department.

Natural space management:
Domain of the Conservatory of Coastal Space and Lake Shores

label: Lavoir de Naud
description: Old fountain used since the Middle Ages. It was transformed into a wash-house in the 19th century.

label: Château Pastré
description:
This beautiful 19th century Provencal bastide, which dominates the Pastré countryside and its vast park open to walkers, has been entirely restored
The castle, which during the Second World War housed many intellectuals and artists who had taken refuge in Marseille during the Second World War, was home to the Musée de la Faïence (Earthenware Museum) until 31 December 2012 (its collections were transferred to the Château Borély, which became the Musée des Arts Décoratifs (Museum of Decorative Arts) in June 2013.
Its salons will host receptions for personalities and prestigious events.

label: Parc marin de la Ciotat
comment: La Ciotat is home to a regional marine park in its bay, a protected and regulated area, a veritable reserve which allows the preservation of the species and riches of the Gulf of Love.
shortDescription: La Ciotat is home to a regional marine park in its bay, a protected and regulated area, a veritable reserve which allows the preservation of the species and riches of the Gulf of Love.
description:
The Blue workshop of Cap d'Aigle allows, thanks to guided tours and projections, to learn about the beauties of the coast.

Natural space management: Regional natural park

label: Pavillon de Travail du Poète Provençal Emile Ripert
description:
Emile Ripert carried the glory and the charm of the Provençal literature, he is next to Frédéric Mistral, to Alphonse Daudet and to number of famous characters of the Provençal literature. 
In an intact half-witted environment, the visit of the place is accompanied by Véronique Ripert, grand daughter of the poet. The visit is livened up by poetic readings. The small working detached house in the middle of the nature has only a room but it is there that it spent its days to read, to make up its poems, to draft its notes, its conferences, its newspaper articles, to prepare its courts .. 
Visit proposed of from 2 pm to 6 pm by appointment with Mrs Ripert.

label: Couvent et Tour des Trinitaires
comment: The convent was established at the beginning of the 13th century. The bell tower, of which  the only vestige of the work of M. Portal, dates from 1700.
shortDescription: The convent was established at the beginning of the 13th century. The bell tower, of which  the only vestige of the work of M. Portal, dates from 1700.
description: The bell tower is composed of three levels of different heights and a basement.

label: Bibliothèque municipale Bernard Monge
comment: Created in 1982, the mission of the Bibliothèque municipale Bernard Monge is to promote public access to the written word, images, sound, information and communication technologies.
shortDescription: Created in 1982, the mission of the Bibliothèque municipale Bernard Monge is to promote public access to the written word, images, sound, information and communication technologies.
description:
The library is a place of leisure and relaxation for the public. It participates in cultural development, the dissemination of information, research, training, education and culture for all, respecting the diversity of tastes and choices.
The Library regularly conducts activities around books and reading, creation, digital technology and video games: meetings with authors, writing workshops, the "P'tits bouts" corner (reserved for 0-3 year olds), Raconte-moi une histoire (Tell me a story)... (reserved for 3-7 year olds), video game sessions, the "Night of Reading", the comic book festival "Bulles électriques", drawing competition...

Regularly, new acquisitions are added to the library's catalogue, respecting a plurality of collections (novels, documentaries, albums, books, audio books, comics, dvd, cd).
streetAddress: ['Bibliothèque municipale Bernard Monge, rue Fernand Rambert']

label: Arènes de Pélissanne
comment:
Capacity: 1,200 places.
Shows, cockade races, equestrian shows, village festivals.
shortDescription:
Capacity: 1,200 places.
Shows, cockade races, equestrian shows, village festivals.
description: They are only open during demonstrations.

label: Les Marais du Vigueirat
comment: Situated at the junction of the Camargue and the Crau, the Marais du Vigueirat are home to a remarkable biodiversity. In this vast wild space live 286 species of birds, 641 species of plants and bulls and horses, so specific to the Camargue.
shortDescription: Situated at the junction of the Camargue and the Crau, the Marais du Vigueirat are home to a remarkable biodiversity. In this vast wild space live 286 species of birds, 641 species of plants and bulls and horses, so specific to the Camargue.
description:
A naturalist guide accompanies visitors on a circuit equipped with four observatories and two towers, which allow them to observe the fauna without disturbing it. Visitors can also discover the area in a horse-drawn carriage at the pace of draught horses. Finally, free discovery is possible on paths equipped with wildlife observatories, and interpretation booklets offered to visitors provide additional information on the natural environments. Among them, the Cabanes trail, built on stilts, is perfectly adapted to families and people with reduced mobility, its 8 interactive cabanes spread along the route leading visitors to the marsh.
The site is well advanced in its responsibility towards the planet, and highlights its efforts with regard to water, air and energy in a message of protection for man and nature.
Partner site of WWF France, the Marais du Vigueirat is a reference in terms of sustainable tourism and eco-responsibility.

label: Corniche John Fitzerald Kennedy
comment: Begun in 1848, the work on the Corniche led in 1863 to the construction of two viaducts to cross the Auffes and Fausse-Monnaie creeks.
shortDescription: Begun in 1848, the work on the Corniche led in 1863 to the construction of two viaducts to cross the Auffes and Fausse-Monnaie creeks.
description: The Corniche is considered a public maritime domain. While walking along it, you will discover the islands of Marseille, beautiful residences, the Memorial of the Repatriates, the Orient Gate, the tide gauge, hidden beaches and restaurants.

label: Médiathèque municipale
description:
Access to culture for all.
Lending of documents (books, CDs, DVDs, magazines...)
Regular and occasional activities
Home for schoolchildren, nursery school assistants, crèche...
Exhibitions

label: Le château
comment: The castle, emblematic vestige of the village of lançon-Provence
shortDescription: The castle, emblematic vestige of the village of lançon-Provence
description:
In the 11th century, the Lords of Lançon built a first castle, while the village was situated around the Saint-Cyr chapel.
In the 12th century, the Lords of Baux settled in Lançon because of its strategic position overlooking the Touloubre. They built a new castle in the place of the old one. It was at this time that the inhabitants left the plain to take shelter behind the ramparts.
The castle was fortified according to an original military design, even unusual in Provence. It has the shape of an ellipse flanked by square towers joined together by machicolations on an arcade.
On the occasion of its 900th anniversary in 2016, a 3D show (mapping) retracing part of its history was projected on its ramparts.
If this monument is now privately owned, it remains the emblem of our village!

label: Médiathèque municipale
comment: Municipal media library.
shortDescription: Municipal media library.

label: Eglise de Saint-Pierre-les-Martigues
comment: In the heart of the Saint-Pierre hamlet, the high white steeple of Église de Saint-Pierre emerges from the surrounding pine forest, indicating the presence of the church.
shortDescription: In the heart of the Saint-Pierre hamlet, the high white steeple of Église de Saint-Pierre emerges from the surrounding pine forest, indicating the presence of the church.
description:
A simple visit is insufficient to understand the genesis of this modest work, from the construction which probably dates back to the medieval period, and more than likely on the foundations of a former antique temple... 

It was extensively restored and re-opened on 19 June 2018. 
The church now resembles its appearance at the end of the 19th century. Unpleasant additions were removed and the original harmonious volumes were restored to human proportions. 
Patrice Sales is the heritage architect responsible for the restoration. (Sources: Direction Culturelles/Les RDV du mardi 2018)

label: Hôtel de Gallifet
comment: Convinced that "artists are the most able to speak about our time", Nicolas Mazet has opened wide the doors of this family home in order to allow everyone to measure and apprehend with another look the world in which we live.
shortDescription: Convinced that "artists are the most able to speak about our time", Nicolas Mazet has opened wide the doors of this family home in order to allow everyone to measure and apprehend with another look the world in which we live.
description:
The Gallifet art centre stands in an 18th century manor in Aix's Mazarin area and is a go-to for any art lover who likes to discuss their favourite subject and meet artists. Five large exhibition halls shaded by century-old trees introduce visitors to exciting artists and contemporary talents. On top of that there are outdoor concerts, supper clubs and conferences about art figures on the agenda depending on the season.

Between June and September you can enjoy a simple and sophisticated lunch featuring ingredients from the next door kitchen garden in the garden, a cup of tea or snack during an afternoon jazz concert or a glass of house rosé in the evening.

Disabled facilities: the grounds and exhibition halls are all disabled-friendly.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de Miséricorde
comment: The chapel overlooks the Etang de Berre and the village. Some of its ex-votos, naive paintings have been restored and are in the Paul Lafran municipal museum.
shortDescription: The chapel overlooks the Etang de Berre and the village. Some of its ex-votos, naive paintings have been restored and are in the Paul Lafran municipal museum.

label: Hôtel de Montauron
description:
This walnut door dates from the seventeenth century.

It is a classical tripartite single door. Garlands are present on either side of the door.

The top panel is composed of florets with foliage, unlike the central panel which is largely undeveloped.

Text : OTAIX/ENTE

label: L'église et sa table d'orientation
comment: From the top of the tower, admire a breathtaking view of the Alpilles with the help of the orientation table
shortDescription: From the top of the tower, admire a breathtaking view of the Alpilles with the help of the orientation table
description:
The new church was built in 1876 on foundations dating back to the 10th century. Its construction has evolved many times over the years.
In 1052, William, Viscount of Marseille, gave Sanctus Martinus de Palud Majori Church to the Cannons of Arles.
In 1061, Raimbaud, Archbishop of Arles, gave it to the Chapter of Saint Trophime. If we examine the original state of the bell tower, we can see a high door accessible by a ladder or a wooden staircase. Vestiges of the dressed stone gun casements remain, testifying to the building's defensive role. On the northern façade, it is possible to see an arch surmounted by a coat of arms. The construction as a whole confirms the fact that the building was a watch tower, with the primitive church located at the side of the tower.
During the Great Plague of the 17th century, a second bell tower was built on the former watch tower. Then, in 1720, an oratory was constructed. It disappeared some time between 1929 and 1933. In 1790, the Arles Chapter appointed a priest for the 800 inhabitants of Saint-Martin de Crau de la Palud; this was one of the first parishes re-established by the Concordat. The new church dates back to 1876.
In the 19th century, the opening of the arch destroyed the proportions of the primitive church. The construction of lean-tos against the side aisle obstructed the entrance to the bell tower.
In 1992, the renovation work undertaken by the commune made the bell tower accessible again. Other renovation work has been carried out since 1995, including repairs to the façade, stained glass windows and wall of the nave, the retaining structure of the walls and ceiling and the lighting of the façades.
Admire the magnificent view of the Alpilles from the top of the tower. A panoramic table was installed in 2007 to help visitors appreciate the view.

label: Petit lavoir et fontaine du planet
description: In 1810, Doctor Denis-Honoré Quenin paid for the construction of a fountain and small wash house on his land. The water collected by the Grand Moulin Mill in Manville was brought to the heart of 'Old Maussane' by ceramic piping.

label: Eglise Saint-Jacques
description: Located in the heart of the old village, the church of Saint-Jacques is characteristic of the second Romanesque art of Provence. Partly destroyed by the earthquake of 1909, it has been restored. Former sacristy in consolidation work.

label: Eglise Saint-Pierre
description:
The church of Saint Peter, which dates back to the 11th century, was enlarged in the 16th and 19th centuries. It has an altarpiece dating from the 16th century.
It is now undergoing a complete interior renovation. Work carried out after the exterior refurbishment in 2003.
Interior renovation work: heating, sound system and renovation of the furnishings: carried out from 2008 to 2010.
Inauguration on 20 February 2010.

label: Les lavoirs de Cornillon Confoux
comment: The commune of Cornillon Confoux includes several washhouses dating from the 19th century:
shortDescription: The commune of Cornillon Confoux includes several washhouses dating from the 19th century:
description:
The wash-house of Saint-Raphaël or Cassade
Hammer and Channel Washhouse
The wash-house of the Ice House
Laundry of Pont de Rhaud
Village wash house

label: Musée du savon
comment: Inside the galley's arsenal built by Louis XIV, the soap museum invite you to  discover  this universal product : fresco retraced its crazy epic.
shortDescription: Inside the galley's arsenal built by Louis XIV, the soap museum invite you to  discover  this universal product : fresco retraced its crazy epic.
description:
A manufacturing unit of the last  century introducing the differents steps.
There is  a grindstone of granite which driven by  a donkey, helped to get raw material. We can also admire a  lavender distiller .For generations, our  soap  is enhanced by  essential oil extracts.

Many others treasures are exposed in this magical place (washerwoman washing machines, molds and documents etc.)

In a  second part, a manufacturing unit is still in operations.
 You  can exchange your voucher in the  shop which  will allow you to visit the museum.

Visits and participation  in soap making  :
11 AM, 12 AM and 3, 4 and 5 PM.

Groups on appointment.

label: Eglise Saint Geniès
comment: Located in the Jonquières district, along the Caronte canal, it is dedicated to the martyr Saint Geniès.
shortDescription: Located in the Jonquières district, along the Caronte canal, it is dedicated to the martyr Saint Geniès.
description:
Rebuilt in the 17th century, very sober, it was built in 1625 in a "counter-reform spirit", in reaction to the Baroque period.

The classical facade houses the statue of Gérard Tenque, born in Martigues in 1040, founder of the Order of Hospitallers known as Malta.
The statue was sculpted in the years 1880-1890 by a mason from Martigues, Nazaire Bernard.
The west facade was renovated in 2019.

label: Parc Balnéaire du Prado
comment: With the creation of the Prado seaside park, 26 hectares of green spaces now blend in with 10 hectares of sandy beaches.
shortDescription: With the creation of the Prado seaside park, 26 hectares of green spaces now blend in with 10 hectares of sandy beaches.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.



Before 1975, despite its 20 km of coastline, Marseilles had no facilities allowing bathers easy access to the sea

With the creation of the Prado seaside park, 26 hectares of green spaces now blend in with 10 hectares of sandy beaches. Beaches that follow one another over nearly 2 km. The creation of such a facility on the 40 hectares reclaimed from the sea was a real challenge because of the many constraints of the site (storms, sea spray, mistral, pollution...). Every year, three and a half million visitors enjoy the lawns, which are fully accessible to the public, the esplanades, the rest and play areas

This very friendly seafront park is attractive in all seasons because of its many facets. In addition, an internationally renowned skateboard track is available to all skateboarding enthusiasts.

label: Chapelle Saint-Blaise
comment: The former Romanesque chapel of Saint-Blaise has an architecture characteristic of the sobriety and simplicity of Romanesque religious buildings in Provence in the Middle Ages.
shortDescription: The former Romanesque chapel of Saint-Blaise has an architecture characteristic of the sobriety and simplicity of Romanesque religious buildings in Provence in the Middle Ages.
description: The old Romanesque chapel of Saint Blaise, erected by the weavers' and carders' association in honour of their patron saint, dates back to the 12th century. It became the seat of their Brotherhood in the 18th century. The Chapel was built of dressed stone and has a single central nave. The semi-circular entrance door is surmounted by an oculus, a small round opening that allows light to enter (religious symbol). On top of the chapel is a restored bell-turret whose bell, still used today, was baptised by Mme Claude Pompidou. The architecture of this chapel is characteristic of the sobriety and simplicity of Romanesque religious buildings in Provence in the Middle Ages.

label: Eglise Notre Dame de Saint-Antoine
comment: After being destroyed three times, the present church dates back to the 19th century. The bell tower has recently been restored and the east and south sides have been removed.
shortDescription: After being destroyed three times, the present church dates back to the 19th century. The bell tower has recently been restored and the east and south sides have been removed.
description:
After three earlier churches were destroyed, the present building dates from the 19th century. The bell tower was recently restored and the east and south sides have been cleaned. 


Originally a 12th-century parish (dedicated to St Mary). 
The church of Châteauneuf traditionally has two patron saints and therefore two festivals: St Anthony the Great (not to be confused with St Anthony of Padua), whose festival falls on 15 January, and the Virgin Mary who is celebrated on 15 August. 


Destroyed in the Revolution, it was rebuilt in 1825.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de la Mer
comment: Listed as a Historic Monument since 1965, the present chapel, mentioned in 1153, stands on a rocky outcrop, which dominates on the western side an important necropolis dating back to the 7th century, used until the 18th.
shortDescription: Listed as a Historic Monument since 1965, the present chapel, mentioned in 1153, stands on a rocky outcrop, which dominates on the western side an important necropolis dating back to the 7th century, used until the 18th.
description: Built in beautiful freestone, with two bays with barrel vaults, it is characteristic of the second classical Romanesque art (12th century), represented in Fos-sur-mer by the Château de l'Hauture and the church of St Sauveur, buildings also classified as Historical Monuments (1937 and 1964 respectively). These buildings bear witness to the golden age that the 12th-13th centuries were for the town, then held by the turbulent lords of Fos.

label: Bibliothèque Saint André
comment: The library, which was formerly a school and was converted into a library in 1988, is located right next to the church of Saint-André. It offers 35,000 documents (books, cd's, dvd's, readings and periodicals) in the youth, adult and music sections.
shortDescription: The library, which was formerly a school and was converted into a library in 1988, is located right next to the church of Saint-André. It offers 35,000 documents (books, cd's, dvd's, readings and periodicals) in the youth, adult and music sections.
description:
As of Wednesday, May 19, 2021, Marseille's libraries will continue to welcome you but will adapt to the new sanitary measures linked to Covid-19 and will try to meet your expectations and needs as best as possible.

RECEPTION CONDITIONS

- Wearing a mask is compulsory for children aged 11 and over,

- Disabled people can be exempted from wearing a mask on presentation of a medical certificate,

- Hand washing with hydroalcoholic gel is compulsory, available to users,

- Respect for distancing,

- Respect for the directions of circulation in the spaces,

- Airing the conference room and the Alcazar auditorium for half an hour between each event.

SERVICES OFFERED

- Loan and return of documents in the libraries.

- Reopening of the document return terminals

- Click and collect in all open libraries:

Log on to the bmvr.marseille.fr website under the heading my account with your user number and your secret code (day + year of birth unless you have personalized it).

Choose the document you are interested in and click on reserve (on the right). The document must be available (DI) or on loan. You can reserve up to 5 documents. Choose the location of withdrawal.

When you receive a confirmation email with a deadline, your reservation is available!

- The external return boxes are available 24 hours a day in the Alcazar and La Grognarde libraries. The Castellane return box is available from 9am to 5pm from Tuesday to Friday and on Monday from 1pm to 5pm.

- Appointments can be made for consultation in the Rare and Precious Materials department at the following e-mail address: dgac-patrimoine-bmvr@marseille.fr, and at the Ile aux Livres at the following e-mail address: ileauxlivres-bmvr@marseille.fr.


THE FOLLOWING SERVICES ARE ONCE AGAIN AVAILABLE

- Consultation of the press,
- Consultation of documents on site,
- Access to computers,
- Access to the reprography service (computers and photocopiers),
- Staying on site.

CULTURAL PROGRAM
 
- The cultural program starts again on May 19th,

- Information on the program available on the website of the libraries and dedicated social networks,

 - Conferences filmed online on our Youtube channel.


OPENING HOURS AND CAPACITY OF THE LIBRARIES

Saint André Library
 
Tuesday, Thursday and Friday from 1pm to 6pm
Wednesday and Saturday from 10am to 1pm and from 2pm to 6pm (except Saturday 22 May)

Simultaneous capacity: 25 people.

__________________________________


A former school converted into a library in 1988, the library is located right next to the church of Saint-André. The library offers 35,000 documents (books, CDs, DVDs, texts and periodicals) in the youth, adult and music sections. From the computers, you can access the Internet and print your documents. Free WiFi access. A courtyard with tables and benches and a small amphitheatre allow readers to read outside.

To discover :

- Meetings for toddlers Stories and nursery rhymes for toddlers and Musical awakening with the association A petits sons, alternating once a month on Wednesday or Friday morning.
- Story time: Every Saturday morning at 11am. The librarians read their favourites and new releases and also extend the children's cinema sessions at the Alhambra with themed readings.
- Toy library: the Petit Camaïeu association provides board games for children aged 3 and over and the Dascla association raises awareness of disability through games.
- Scientific workshops for 7-12 year olds and Science Apéro for adults led by the Petits débrouillards on the occasion of the science festival, the brain week...
- Shows, readings, meetings with authors, concerts... throughout the year.
- Homework help for primary school children by the association SALC (St-André Loisirs et Culture) and Addap 13 every Tuesday and Thursday evening from 4.45pm to 6pm.
- Groups of adults and children are welcome by appointment.

label: Calanque d'En Vau
comment: The most spectacular with its white, steep and jagged cliffs. It is the privileged place of the lovers of the climbing, amateurs or confirmed, who find here the unique sensation to be able to climb on walls between sky and sea.
shortDescription: The most spectacular with its white, steep and jagged cliffs. It is the privileged place of the lovers of the climbing, amateurs or confirmed, who find here the unique sensation to be able to climb on walls between sky and sea.
description: It is also one of the favorites of the bathers by its water of an unbelievable transparency.

label: Fondation Vincent van Gogh Arles
comment: The V. van Gogh Foundation is dedicated to enhancing its artistic heritage by questioning the resonance of its work in art. The perspective of his painting with the work of contemporary artists will reveal a dialogue
shortDescription: The V. van Gogh Foundation is dedicated to enhancing its artistic heritage by questioning the resonance of its work in art. The perspective of his painting with the work of contemporary artists will reveal a dialogue
description:
Vincent van Gogh is a key figure in 20th century art. To this day, his influence continues among artists and his work exerts an unprecedented magnetism on the public. It was in Arles that he produced his most beautiful masterpieces in just fifteen months. 

The Vincent van Gogh Foundation in Arles offers a unique approach to Van Gogh by exploring the resonance of his work with current artistic creation. Thanks to partnerships with public and private collections, the Foundation presents one or more of Van Gogh's paintings throughout the year alongside works by modern and contemporary artists in temporary exhibitions - such as Laura Owens, Roni Horn, David Hockney, Urs Fischer, Alice Neel, and Nicole Eisenman in 2022.

21 May - 23 October 2022: "    . , , . »

Discover the work of Nicole Eisenman - one of the most remarkable artists on the American scene today - exhibited alongside 25 modern artists, including Picasso, Edvard Munch, James Ensor...

This exhibition includes two magnificent paintings by Van Gogh:    - , Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, autumn 1889 (on loan from the Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam) and  , June 1890 (on loan from the Kunstmuseum Den Haag, The Hague)

label: Chapelle de la Mère de Dieu
comment: This chapel, attested in 1082, was rebuilt in 1710
shortDescription: This chapel, attested in 1082, was rebuilt in 1710
description: It is located "three hundred paces" from the castle. This chapel, was dedicated to Our Lady of the Nears, but commonly called in the region, "Chapel of the Mother of God".

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Noirs - Saint Joseph
description:
When Saint Anne's brotherhood settled down in the Chapel, Black Penitents moved a few meters away from there. 
Built, in six months, the Chapel keeps a beautiful door in sculptured walnut.
In 1819, what stayed of the Brotherhood, gave way to Saint Joseph's congregation and the Chapel was dedicated to the saint in June, 1821. 
Saint Joseph's statue which we find inside the chapel, restored in 1950, is the one which was in the niche above the original front door.

label: Château de St Andiol
comment: Large Renaissance-style building that houses the village hall and sports halls.
shortDescription: Large Renaissance-style building that houses the village hall and sports halls.
description: This large old house look massive and important successively belonged to families of Alba, Varadier and Estourmel by the marriage of girls from each of them. Once living centre, it is today by its vocation of social and cultural centre, the intellectual lighthouse and keeper of the traditions of the village of Saint-Andiol.

label: Plage de la Calanque St Estève
comment: To reach the beach of the calanque St Estève, you have to start by coming to the Vieux-Port in Marseille.
shortDescription: To reach the beach of the calanque St Estève, you have to start by coming to the Vieux-Port in Marseille.
description:
Plage de la calanque St Estève
To reach "Plage de la calanque St Estève", you first need to come to Marseille's Old Port (Vieux Port), where you can get the Frioul Express boat bus to the offshore islands. The 15-minute crossing takes you past Château d’If (of Count of Monte Cristo fame) and on to the pretty port of the Frioul archipelago, lined with restaurant terraces. If you head along the shore to the right you will come to this gorgeous natural fjord, with its half-sand, half-pebble beach. Leave the trouble and strife of city life behind you for a while and lay your towel down on the sand just like the many locals who come here every summer. Sheltered from the Mistral wind and attended by a lifeguard, St Estève beach offers a truly different holiday experience and the chance for parents to let their kids dabble in deliciously clear, warm and shallow waters.

label: Hôtel Quiqueran de Beaujeu
description:
The Hôtel Quiqueran de Beaujeu testifies to the history of Arles in more than one respect.
It is a vestige of a period of prosperity in the town, during which rich bourgeois and nobles made their mark by constructing their sumptuous private mansions.
The building bears witness to the majesty and charm of Classical architecture inspired by Parisian mansions.
Its name evokes a powerful old Arles family, which provided a number of public figures and had a profound effect on the history of the town.
Today, it is part of the town's new Image-based identity, as it houses the National Photography College.
The main façade, to the south, has a sophisticated décor, with the regular pattern of its windows with their beautiful moulded frames and the large triangular fronton which surmounts it.
Together with the building's two side wings, it frames a vast courtyard which overlooks the street via an imposing porch.
As well as the wonderful conservation of its exterior décor, the beautiful wrought iron staircase inside has also been preserved.

label: Eglise Saint Hippolyte
comment: Visit the church of Saint Hippolyte de Venelles, built in 1911 and extended in 2008
shortDescription: Visit the church of Saint Hippolyte de Venelles, built in 1911 and extended in 2008
description: Following the earthquake, the church, then located in Venelles le Haut, had to be rebuilt and largely demolished. After many quarrels, it was decided to establish the new building in Venelles le Bas, which was then beginning to develop. Some of the church's furniture was moved there, including the works of the local sculptor Louis-Félix Chabaud, a former mayor of the town and friend of Charles Garnier, architect of the Paris Opera. But the church, built in 1911, for a population ten times smaller, proves to be too cramped at the end of the 20th century, hence its extension, consecrated in 2008.

label: Place Portail Grignolet
comment: The square is located in front of the House of the 50s.
shortDescription: The square is located in front of the House of the 50s.
description:
When entering the square from the Cours Carnot, there is a rather imposing wall on the left. It is the remains of the old ramparts. They opened here on a door and then continued at the level of the Cours Carnot. Many houses in the old village and in particular in the Cours, were built with stones from the ramparts.
The fountain on this square represents the emergence of a spring (a "font" in Provencal).

label: Chapelle Saint-Marc La Morée
comment: This Romanesque chapel, wedged between the A8 and the RD7N is a place steeped in history: Salyans, Celts, Gauls, Greeks, Ligurians, Romans succeeded one another there.
shortDescription: This Romanesque chapel, wedged between the A8 and the RD7N is a place steeped in history: Salyans, Celts, Gauls, Greeks, Ligurians, Romans succeeded one another there.
description: This Romanesque chapel, stuck between the A8 and the RD7N is a place full of history: Salyens, Celts, Gallic, Greek, Ligurian and Roman succeeded each other. Ancient Roman temple dedicated to Mars, rebuilt around the year 1000, the chapel is a place of pilgrimage from the fifteenth century and for Saint Mark, a procession left Aix. Very well restored, the chapel is re-enacted every April 25, St. Mark's Day, during an open-air mass with a picnic.

label: Plateau du Grand Puech
description: Starting point of the history of Vernègues, the Grand Puech plateau is a vast open space overlooking the Durance valley. It has been the privileged place of human occupation since the Neolithic period. The orientation table installed on the old mill offers a panoramic view from the Sainte-Victoire to the Etang de Berre.

label: Hôtel Garcin
comment: Historic building in the town centre of Eyguieres
shortDescription: Historic building in the town centre of Eyguieres
description: Façade of the Garcin hotel classified as a historical monument: 3 Atlantes support a balcony with a wrought iron gate. Building of the 18th century which would have been built for the de Sade family. The Garcin family, traders in oil and soap, owned it from 1830 to 1950.

label: Jardin du Bois Sacré
comment: Located at the foot of the hill of Notre-Dame de la Garde, this 1.1 hectare garden hosts the beginning of the ancient pilgrimage path to the basilica.
shortDescription: Located at the foot of the hill of Notre-Dame de la Garde, this 1.1 hectare garden hosts the beginning of the ancient pilgrimage path to the basilica.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.


Situated at the foot of the hill of Notre-Dame de la Garde, this 1.1 hectare garden is at the beginning of the old pilgrimage route to the basilica. The northern and southern slopes of the hill are planted with Aleppo pines, cypresses, holm oaks, cedars and olive trees. Recent developments: lawns, a footpath through the pine forest, bowling alleys and sports fields. This garden is not enclosed, so it is always accessible.

label: Site archéologique de Tholon
comment: Remains of a Gallo-Roman conurbation, Maritima Avaticorum.
shortDescription: Remains of a Gallo-Roman conurbation, Maritima Avaticorum.
description:
The Tholon site is located in the city of Martigues, on the western shore of the Etang de Berre, about 1500 m north of the Caronte Channel and the Ile district, the historic center of the city.

Since 1998, research conducted by archaeologists from the town of Martigues to Tholon has explored or uncovered numerous remains and buildings buried in the ground or in the pond of Berre. These works now make it possible to reconstruct the main stages of the occupation of one of the major sites in the history and heritage of Martigues.

There are springs, cisterns, laundries and hydraulic installations.

label: Promenade de la Torse
comment: Located in the eastern part of the city, near the Torse stream, the Torse promenade is located between the Cezanne road and the Nice road. The park is open every day of the week.
shortDescription: Located in the eastern part of the city, near the Torse stream, the Torse promenade is located between the Cezanne road and the Nice road. The park is open every day of the week.
description:
A path alongside the Torse stream, between the Cezanne Road and Route de Nice, in the eastern part of the city. The entrance is on the Cezanne Road (Route du Tholonet). 

The footpath and the fitness trail follow the stream, sometimes crossing it by wooden foot bridges. Some huge plane trees give the path a very natural feel of being in the country. Poplars, cypresses, maples, weeping willows, walnut, chestnut and ash trees, oaks, pines and beautiful avenues lined with privet add to the charm of the walk. 

A huge lake of 2,500m2 has been created, edged with aquatic and marginal plants and populated by fish and ducks. The existing vegetation has been supplemented by hardy trees and shrubs selected from the surrounding vegetation to preserve a natural appearance.

label: Négreiron
comment: Roman remains are numerous in the Pays d'Arles. The site of Négreiron-Négrès shelters the vestiges of this period.
shortDescription: Roman remains are numerous in the Pays d'Arles. The site of Négreiron-Négrès shelters the vestiges of this period.

label: Lac des Iscles
comment: A natural lake on the banks of the Durance, the Lac des Iscles is not a swimming spot but is reserved for fishermen (regular trout releases).
shortDescription: A natural lake on the banks of the Durance, the Lac des Iscles is not a swimming spot but is reserved for fishermen (regular trout releases).
description:
A picnic area is offered on site in the shade of trees near the cool water. A hiking trail ("Noves au fil de l'eau" available at the Tourist Office) allows you to get there while discovering Noves and the banks of the Durance.
It is accessible on foot, by bike or on horseback all year round via the Bonpas stadium or on the opposite side by a path behind the Lou Roucas restaurant
Access by car can only be done on the days of fishing competitions or in agreement with the association of the fishermen of Noves. A pontoon has been set up.
On the road to Châteaurenard, just at the level of the Lou Roucas restaurant, take the path to the water intake. Almost in front of you, you will find a small car park with a barrier. Except on competition days when the barrier is lifted, you will have to park there and follow the path that winds through the undergrowth and leads you to the lake (about 1km)
A special fishing permit is required to fish in this lake as well as in the Malautière which feeds it.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de Bonaventure
description:
In 1475, it was decided to have a chapel built in front of the Saint Nicolas hospital, near the Saint Jean gate (formerly the Oule gate). The beautiful altarpiece by the beaucairois Léonard Vissert which adorns the altar is installed in 1542.
In the 16th century it became the headquarters of the guild of carpenters and fustiers (carpenters): the decapitated statue above the doorway attests to this. Sold in 1796 as a national asset, it then passed to Abbot Julian, who donated it to the hospital in 1828. At that time, St. Nicholas was transformed into a mixed hospital: patients suffering from contagious diseases were treated in the chapel. Later on, it was used as a retirement home, which is now closed.
Architectural description:
The facade, now visible from the street, presents a beautiful condemned portal, in flamboyant gothic style, uncommon in Provence. The ogive of the bay is surmounted by a worked gable and framed by two pinnacles.

label: Les Méjanes - Bibliothèque patrimoniale Méjanes et archives municipales Michel Vovelle
comment: Since February 2020, the heritage collections of the Méjanes library and the municipal archives of Aix-en-Provence have invested a new location within the cultural forum.
shortDescription: Since February 2020, the heritage collections of the Méjanes library and the municipal archives of Aix-en-Provence have invested a new location within the cultural forum.
description:
Memory of our city, the Archives service retains many documents tracing the communal activity since the 12th century.

The Archives have as essential missions to collect, classify, preserve and communicate the documents.

label: Eglise Saint Valentin
comment:
Priest: Father Olivier Salmeron.
Mass on Sundays at 10:30 a.m
shortDescription:
Priest: Father Olivier Salmeron.
Mass on Sundays at 10:30 a.m
description: Father Salmeron is on call every Wednesday from 5:00 to 7:00 pm.

label: Fontaine des Neuf Canons
comment: The Nine Cannons Fountain was built following the demolition, in 1690, of another fountain which was used as a drinking trough.
shortDescription: The Nine Cannons Fountain was built following the demolition, in 1690, of another fountain which was used as a drinking trough.
description:
Because sheep from Arles passed through the city on their way to their summer pastures, the municipality decided to build a new watering point accessible to animals, with a very low edge. 

The architect, however, wanted an aesthetic structure, and the water flows into the large basin from nine outlets (flattened cannons) so that the fountain is both functional and pleasing to the eye.

label: Plage de Ferrières centre-ville
comment: The sandy beach located at the edge of the pond of Berre and in the city centre of Martigues, is certified "bathing waters", recognition of the actions taken by the municipality for the management of a bathing site. The beach has showers and toilets.
shortDescription: The sandy beach located at the edge of the pond of Berre and in the city centre of Martigues, is certified "bathing waters", recognition of the actions taken by the municipality for the management of a bathing site. The beach has showers and toilets.
description:
The beach is equipped with showers and toilets.
From May to September, it is cleaned daily.
Safety: the beach is marked out and swimming is supervised:
- On the weekends of 4/5/6, 11 and 12 June 2022, from 11am to 7pm.
- From 18 June to 28 August 2022, from 11am to 7pm, every day.

Musical animations are regularly programmed around the 3 huts:
- La cuisine de Zebuline et zigoto.
- C'Pêché.
- Le Crépophile.

The green areas have been redesigned, the redone asphalt and children's playground are available.The place participates in dynamization of the city centre and the process of inscription of the pond of Berre to the world heritage of UNESCO.

label: Fontaine Coquille
comment: The Shell Fountain is an emblem of Eyguières
shortDescription: The Shell Fountain is an emblem of Eyguières
description: The fountain was built in 1887 and stood at the foot of the church. In 1923 it was moved to its present location.

label: Le pigeonnier de Monsieur le Prieur
description: Declared national property under the revolution.

label: Ancienne église
comment: From the old church of Venelles, you can see the Sainte-Baume, the Etoile mountain range and even the Luberon.
shortDescription: From the old church of Venelles, you can see the Sainte-Baume, the Etoile mountain range and even the Luberon.
description: Exterior visit - The old church, built in Venelles le Haut, on the ancient Celtic oppidum, was a victim of the 1909 earthquake: only the bell tower and the facade remain, which was later added to a water tower. The exceptional view of Concors, Sambuc, the Durance plain and Sainte-Victoire, as well as this moving testimony to the last earthquake disaster in France, make a visit to this promontory a must.

label: Les poneys et l'enfant
comment: Les Poneys et l'Enfant association is a wildlife therapy centre providing activities to create natural and nurturing bonds between people and animals.
shortDescription: Les Poneys et l'Enfant association is a wildlife therapy centre providing activities to create natural and nurturing bonds between people and animals.
description:
The supportive relationship with the animals helps children, teenagers and adults improve their behaviour, emotions, responses and patterns.
Animal therapy is for children and adults of all ages and anywhere we can provide it: schools, high schools, colleges, health centres, care homes etc. 
There are countless goals from a nurturing experience with the animal and rehabilitation to school apprenticeships and work on relationships.
The animals helping us to achieve these many goals are ponies, dogs, the cat, rats and Aix's quiet country residents: crickets, bees, butterflies, tits etc.

➜ 1-hour workshops Wednesday and Saturday morning (ages 3 and over)
➜ Birthdays, activity 2pm-3pm then games and snack under parents' supervision (minimum 8 children)
➜ Half-term courses: 4 half-days Monday to Thursday afternoon or morning subject to season
Closed for a fortnight in early August.

label: Bois de Tourtoulen
comment: The Bois de Tourtoulen is a forest bordering the Grand Rhône, composed of very tall white poplars and white willows.
shortDescription: The Bois de Tourtoulen is a forest bordering the Grand Rhône, composed of very tall white poplars and white willows.
description: 44 ha.

label: Plaine du Comtat
comment: The Comtat plain, located at the confluence of the Rhone and the Durance, is more widely developed in the Vaucluse.
shortDescription: The Comtat plain, located at the confluence of the Rhone and the Durance, is more widely developed in the Vaucluse.
description: It is the largest agricultural plain of the department. Such countryside landscape is marked by the omnipresence of canals. The alignments of plane trees along the roads are bordered to the south by the Alpilles.

label: Musée du Patrimoine
comment:
The museum proposes to you to discover very beautiful collections: Saint Eloi, costumes, daily life, agriculture, pharmacy .........
The museum is air-conditioned.
shortDescription:
The museum proposes to you to discover very beautiful collections: Saint Eloi, costumes, daily life, agriculture, pharmacy .........
The museum is air-conditioned.
description: Located on the ground floor of the country house, in the Park of the poets. This new space allows to present the best very diverse collections of objects reflecting the past of Eyragues, of the country of Arles, in Provence. Throughout the year the Museum houses temporary exhibitions.

label: Façade du palais comtal
comment: Superb vestige of medieval architecture.
shortDescription: Superb vestige of medieval architecture.
description:
Built in the 12th and 13th centuries, it is a rare example of medieval civil architecture in Provence with a Roman façade and gemelled arched picture windows, discovered in 1981. 
The interior is not open to visitors.

label: Le Château d'Arnajon
comment: Bastide built in the 17th century, 17th century terraces, vegetable garden, 19th century gardens and its factories, cactus gardens. An estate that has retained its authenticity. Same owners for nearly two centuries.
shortDescription: Bastide built in the 17th century, 17th century terraces, vegetable garden, 19th century gardens and its factories, cactus gardens. An estate that has retained its authenticity. Same owners for nearly two centuries.
description:
Built in the 17th century, this magnificent country house, reflected in the water of its immense Provençal pond, is a treasure of architectural heritage. 

The entire site (except for the former farmhouse) was listed as a Historical Monument by prefectural order on 2 December 2010. 

Now privately owned by the Pascal family, it was originally a hunting lodge. A chapel has been built on the western wall of the house, which boasts beautiful French-style gardens and a courtyard with a fountain. 



The cold room, a remarkable grotto in Italian-inspired Baroque style, nestles at the foot of one of the dovecotes in this outstanding property. 

The Queen Mother of England visited the Château in the early 1960s.

label: Domaine de Pichauris
comment: The Pichauris estate, covering an area of over 1,300 hectares, where the river Le Jarret has its source, is located to the north-east of the commune of Allauch, in a belvedere position, 12 kilometres north-east of Marseille.
shortDescription: The Pichauris estate, covering an area of over 1,300 hectares, where the river Le Jarret has its source, is located to the north-east of the commune of Allauch, in a belvedere position, 12 kilometres north-east of Marseille.
description:
It borders the communes of Peypin, Roquevaire, Aubagne, Cadolive, Mimet, Saint-Savournin and Marseille. This property offers a picturesque landscape of steep cliffs and gentle valleys. This large natural area has a remarkable ecological richness compared to the surrounding hills: the humidity level, the depth of the soil and the flow of a temporary watercourse favour the development of species that are rare in our region. Indeed, its vegetation offers a clear contrast between the Adret "with degraded scrubland" and the Ubac where magnificent deciduous trees (holm oak, white and black poplar...) grow.

The filmmakers were not mistaken and immediately recognized the place as an ideal setting for filming. Yves Robert shot most of his films there, such as "La gloire de mon père" and "le Château de ma mère" from Marcel Pagnol's book.
Access by the D908 coming from Allauch

Management of natural areas 
Domain of the General Council

label: Fontaine Erasme Guichet
comment: Since 1911, the statue of Erasmus Guichet has dominated the fountain which was dedicated to him in order to pay homage to him, for all he has contributed to the city of Château-Neuf les-Martigues, particularly in the field of the distribution of 'water, and electricity.
shortDescription: Since 1911, the statue of Erasmus Guichet has dominated the fountain which was dedicated to him in order to pay homage to him, for all he has contributed to the city of Château-Neuf les-Martigues, particularly in the field of the distribution of 'water, and electricity.
description:
Sculptor: Clément Clastrier.
The rear face bears the following inscriptions: "This monument was erected by public subscription, in memory of our friend and fellow citizen E. Guichet, general counselor, director of the Montperrin asylum, cowardly murdered on September 21, 1910, in the 'exercise of its functions, under the municipality Gamaud C .. "

label: Tiki Beach
comment: Private beach on the beach of Le Rouet.
shortDescription: Private beach on the beach of Le Rouet.
description: On the beautiful sandy beach of Le Rouet, you can rent deckchairs and umbrellas at Tiki Beach for a day or a week.

label: Pont des Trois Sautets
description:
This single-span hump-backed bridge straddles the Arc river. It was built in 1655 and is now a listed historical monument. 

The bridge takes its name from the three little jumps (or "sautets") which were needed to cross the Arc at this point before the bridge was built. 


It was also below this bridge that Paul Cézanne saw and painted a crowd of "Bathers".


Later, the British Prime Minister Winston Churchill relaxed here during his free time.

label: Bibliothèque de la Grognarde
comment: The library of La Grognarde is the public reading facility covering the eastern districts of Marseille.
shortDescription: The library of La Grognarde is the public reading facility covering the eastern districts of Marseille.
description:
As of Wednesday, May 19, 2021, Marseille's libraries will continue to welcome you but will adapt to the new sanitary measures linked to Covid-19 and will try to meet your expectations and needs as best as possible.

RECEPTION CONDITIONS

- Wearing a mask is compulsory for children aged 11 and over,

- Disabled people can be exempted from wearing a mask on presentation of a medical certificate,

- Hand washing with hydroalcoholic gel is compulsory, available to users,

- Respect for distancing,

- Respect for the directions of circulation in the spaces,

- Airing the conference room and the Alcazar auditorium for half an hour between each event.

SERVICES OFFERED

- Loan and return of documents in the libraries.

- Reopening of the document return terminals

- Click and collect in all open libraries:

Log on to the bmvr.marseille.fr website under the heading my account with your user number and your secret code (day + year of birth unless you have personalized it).

Choose the document you are interested in and click on reserve (on the right). The document must be available (DI) or on loan. You can reserve up to 5 documents. Choose the location of withdrawal.

When you receive a confirmation email with a deadline, your reservation is available!

- The external return boxes are available 24 hours a day in the Alcazar and La Grognarde libraries. The Castellane return box is available from 9am to 5pm from Tuesday to Friday and on Monday from 1pm to 5pm.

- Appointments can be made for consultation in the Rare and Precious Materials department at the following e-mail address: dgac-patrimoine-bmvr@marseille.fr, and at the Ile aux Livres at the following e-mail address: ileauxlivres-bmvr@marseille.fr.


THE FOLLOWING SERVICES ARE ONCE AGAIN AVAILABLE

- Consultation of the press,
- Consultation of documents on site,
- Access to computers,
- Access to the reprography service (computers and photocopiers),
- Staying on site.

CULTURAL PROGRAM
 
- The cultural program starts again on May 19th :
 Wednesday May 19: 4pm - Alcazar
"Big and bad, the wolf?" Story for children from 5 years old

 Exhibition "Les Héroïnes de BD à la une, 80 ans de presse BD" - Alcazar Until June 26th 2021

- Information on the program available on the libraries website and dedicated social networks,

 - Conferences filmed online on our Youtube channel.


OPENING HOURS AND CAPACITY OF THE LIBRARIES

La Grognarde Library

Tuesday, Thursday and Friday: from 1pm to 6pm,
wednesday, Saturday: from 10am to 1pm and from 2pm to 6pm (except Saturday 22 May)

Capacity: 25 people at a time.
Document return box available 24 hours a day.

____________________________________


La Grognarde library is the public reading facility covering the eastern districts of Marseille. Inaugurated in September 1988, enlarged in 1997, it was renovated in summer 2013 to welcome its users in the best conditions.

With a surface area of 330 m², it offers modern and varied resources for all audiences: 11,000 adult books, 14,000 books for young people, 7,000 CDs and 2,000 DVDs as well as 49 newspaper and magazine titles. The library also offers 3 Internet accesses for subscribers and 3 public stations allowing to use the digital services of the BMVR.

A 60 m² room can host free shows and events for all audiences: storytelling, readings, workshops, exhibitions, meetings with authors, film screenings, video game tournaments, etc.

In addition, partnerships with schools and social-cultural centres in the area allow regular presentations of the library for children.

label: Archipel de Riou
comment: The Riou archipelago is located off the coast of Marseille, facing the Calanques National Park
shortDescription: The Riou archipelago is located off the coast of Marseille, facing the Calanques National Park
description: The archipelago of Riou includes the island of Riou, the island Maire, the island Calsereigne, and the island of Jarre.

label: Les Tours de Castillon
description:
Situated on the Pène mountain range above a crossing point in the Vallée des Baux, over the course of history the site of Castillon has taken advantage of its dominant position on the marshland and traffic routes.
There is a first oppidum in the protohistoric period followed by a habitat in the Hellenistic period. The Romans left some traces of it before abandoning it in part.
From the 11th century onwards, the site acquired new importance when the Lords of Les Baux integrated it into the defensive system of their territory. The castle then rests on 4 towers, three of which are still visible. The place counts 40 homes. The lord of Les Baux had the castle chapel of Sainte-Marie-de-Castillon built there.
The site will be abandoned in the 14th century without any trace of destruction, it will serve as a "quarry" for the extension of the village of St-Martin-de-Castillon.
Elements of the excavation of the site are to be seen in the hall of the town hall of the village.

label: Musée de l'Uniforme de la Légion étrangère
comment: The museum brings together a unique collection on the history and evolution of the Legionnaire's uniform from 1831 to 1962. More than 150 uniforms are on display as well as numerous historical memorabilia, weapons and a rich iconography
shortDescription: The museum brings together a unique collection on the history and evolution of the Legionnaire's uniform from 1831 to 1962. More than 150 uniforms are on display as well as numerous historical memorabilia, weapons and a rich iconography
description:
The Museum contains a unique collection in the world about the history and evolution of the uniform of the Legionnaire from 1831 until 1962. 
It's more than 150 uniforms which are exposed as well as numerous historical memorabilia, weapons and a rich iconography. Before or after visiting the Museum, you have the option to lunch at the restaurant of Captain Danjou (reservation required) and continue your trip through the store memories of the area.

The restaurant remains open during the works.
streetAddress: ['Chemin De la Pallière', 'Domaine Capitaine Danjou', 'Institution des invalides de la légion étrangère']

label: Chapelle Saint Marcellin
description: The bottle procession takes place in Saint Marcellin Chapel on 1 June every year. On this day, all male residents of Boulbon go to the Chapel carrying a bottle of wine. After the Provençal service, the bottles are blessed. Each participant can then have a sip of wine, while the village police officer distributes glasses to the clergy and the authorities. The wine blessed in the name of the Saint is believed to have beneficial effects against fevers and stomach aches. Saint Marcellin Chapel was built in the pure Romanesque style and dates from the 11th century, apart from the Chapels, which were erected at a later date. In one of the chapels of the primitive parish church is a beautiful 14th century crypt erected by the Lord of the village. Behind the main altar was the Altarpiece of Boubon; this has been sold and is currently on display at the Louvre. Guided visits possible subject to reservation.

label: Les Allées
comment: The Allées (formerly Allées Provençales) date from April 2007 and form the most recent district of the city, they constitute a true extension of the historic center
shortDescription: The Allées (formerly Allées Provençales) date from April 2007 and form the most recent district of the city, they constitute a true extension of the historic center
description:
During your stay in Aix en Provence you will be invited to travel in time. Your steps will take you into an outstanding architectural and cultural heritage.

Les Allées (previously none as Les Allées Provençales) date from April 2007, making them both the newest district of the city and an extension of the historic centre.

The Rotonde and Méjanes car parks, situated at the bottom of Cours Mirabeau, offer 2,300 parking spaces for easy access to Les Allées and the city centre.

Les Allées are the ideal place to enjoy the city and shopping: with more than 45 names such as FNAC, H&M and Zara, they combine historical charm with the latest trends.

Find the latest in fashion, beauty, decoration, phones ... Les Allées also offer a choice of places to eat or just relax with a drink. 

Grand Théâtre de Provence, designed by the architect Vittorio Gregotti, is a strong architectural statement in the heart of this new urban centre, which has become the new hub of the city. In this modern architectural complex is also the Pavillon Noir (Black Pavilion), the choreographic centre of the Preljocaj Ballet, the Cité du Livre with the Méjanes library, the St John Perse Foundation, the videotheque of Lyric Art, the future new school of music, and Aix en Provence Tourist Office.

Shops:
Zara, H&M, Seven's, Le Temps des Cerises, Passionata, Banana Moon, Olly Gan, Adidas, Oysho, Darjeeling, Massimo Dutti, Jules, Bizzbee, Capsule, Levi's Store, Superdry, Swarovski, Diamant Factory, Bijou Brigitte, Histoire d'Or, Prime Time, 1894 - L'Immobilier, Fram, Pharmacie des Allées, Société Générale, Club Bouygues Telecom, Orange, Micromania, Fnac, Nature & Découvertes, Maisons du Monde, Zara Home, Schmidt, Nocibé, JR Coiffure, Body Minute, Sephora, Chez Augustine, Nicolas, Darius café, La Croissanterie, Brasserie Les Artistes, La Cure Gourmande, Monoprix, Des Ailes aux Pieds, Le Tanneur, Optique des Allées, Générale d'Optique, Lovmyb

A telephone charging station is settled at Les Allées in the covered passage between Banana Moon and Passionata.

label: Le Rougadou
comment: The Rougadou is a very small (254 ha), isolated in the midst of very few wooded areas. It is located to the Northwest of the Department, near the Durance and the continuity of the Rhone corridor.
shortDescription: The Rougadou is a very small (254 ha), isolated in the midst of very few wooded areas. It is located to the Northwest of the Department, near the Durance and the continuity of the Rhone corridor.
description: The Rougadou massif consists of several hills globally oriented in a direction North / South, the low average height, but the relatively steep relief.Due to its positioning in the axis of the Rhone Valley, the massif of the Rougadou is strongly subject to influence by the mistral, blowing sustained a large part of the year.Forming a set of wooded hills, the Rougadou massif presents a very high rate of afforestation (83%), these stands are mainly composed of pine forests in good health condition, accompanied by green oak.Despite its small size the Rougadou massif is a very frequented by the local population (families, hunters, school,...) due to its isolated situation of other larger clumps. Thus, a reception area of the public in the forest (ZAPEF) premiered in limit of massif, in the town of Chateaurenard.Because of its small size, the urban problem is little developed, even if it can report the problem of subdivisions quite difficult to defend in the commune of Noves.

label: Jardin des simples
description:
This Garden was created in 2003, in the heart of the Château de l'Empéri, on the occasion of the 500th anniversary of the birth of the illustrious doctor renowned for his effective fight and medicines against the plague.

It is composed of plants that Nostradamus used in his recipes, grouped together in plessis (braided chestnut branches), each square creating a link with his texts: square of jams, make-up, dyers...

The garden is now a "Garden of History", a pretext for all sorts of activities and is accessible with free entrance.

label: Les Remparts
comment: Cultural heritage of Orgon : The Ramparts.
shortDescription: Cultural heritage of Orgon : The Ramparts.
description:
The western part of Orgon's first ramparts bordered the village of 'La Savoie', nestled at the foot of the château. They linked the Porte de l'Hortet to the Porte du Four de Ville and stood on the current site of the town hall and the church. Some remnants of the wall can still be seen to the left of the town hall, where the seigniorial prison was located.
Orgon grew in size after the 16th century and new ramparts appeared. This second set of surrounding walls was built in 1591, during the Catholic Holy League, a religious war whose apparent aim was to defend the Catholic religion against the Calvinists, but whose real purpose was the conquest of the French throne by the House of Guise. The ramparts are approximately one metre thick and between 6 and 7 metres high; they were built quickly thanks to provincial subsidies.

label: Chapelle de la Charité
description:
Visit during the events.
Chapel between Baroque and Classicism (1719), unique vestige of the former Charity Hospital, it also hosts exhibitions and concerts.

label: Chapelle des pénitents gris - dits Bourras
comment: The chapel has occupied the site of the former chapel of the Black Penitents since 1859. One can admire there, among other things, a monumental "mise au tombeau", attributed to Jean Guiramand, author of the doors of the cathedral St-Sauveur of Aix
shortDescription: The chapel has occupied the site of the former chapel of the Black Penitents since 1859. One can admire there, among other things, a monumental "mise au tombeau", attributed to Jean Guiramand, author of the doors of the cathedral St-Sauveur of Aix
description:
This 18th-century chapel adjoins the Cordeliers' monastery.

The Grey Penitents or Bourras ("sacks" in Provençal) replaced the Cordelier Black Penitents in 1859. In the 19th century the chapel was adorned with a monumental Pieta in carved wood (by the sculptor Jean Guiramand).

Catholic mass according to the extraordinary rite on Sundays at 10.00.
Open on Sundays and after mass, or by appointment with the manager.

label: Église Saint-Nicolas
comment: The parish church of Saint-Nicolas (11th - 19th century) is an architectural monument that bears witness to religious life in the Middle Ages and the Renaissance. Among the most remarkable elements, the monumental gilded wooden altarpiece from the 16th century.
shortDescription: The parish church of Saint-Nicolas (11th - 19th century) is an architectural monument that bears witness to religious life in the Middle Ages and the Renaissance. Among the most remarkable elements, the monumental gilded wooden altarpiece from the 16th century.
description:
The parish church, first known as "Sainte Marie de Marignane", became known as Notre-Dame de Nazareth and then as Saint-Nicolas

It has been constantly growing since its first mention in the 11th century

The core would be four north side chapels, later doubled by a large nave leading to a pentagonal choir characteristic of the years 1360-1370, originally abundantly lit by five bays. Weakened at an unknown date (15th or early 16th century?), the broken barrel of the nave was rebuilt, lowered and consolidated by a succession of eleven double arches of beautiful blonde molasse stone

The 16th century marks the richest period of its history. Two chapels were added to the choir around 1520, followed by an elevation of the western tower, probably originally defensive on the rampart, which became a bell tower in honor of François I between 1533 and 1535, stamped with his personal royal shield (now gone). It shelters a tribune delicately vaulted with lierne and tierceron, the whole entrusted to the Aixois lapicide Guillaume Benoît assisted by the Marignanais Maurice Reynier. The vaulting of the side chapels, resting on figurative bases, in which a crowned salamander can be seen, probably dates from this same period

This was followed by the construction of the sacristy, also vaulted, around 1570, then the addition of a side chapel of Purgatory to the south around 1665

It is on this side that the symmetry of the building was completed in the 1840s, by the erection of the last chapels on clay soil, hence their plaster vaults supported by wooden arches imitating stone

Definitely oriented east-west, the church opened up to the west under the bell tower in 1823, accessible by a new forecourt overlooking an airy outdoor boulevard

One can see to the north the extension of the chapel of the white penitents, built between 1609 and 1610 by the Roman brothers, associated with the church in 1804 and amputated of its choir in 1903. The altarpiece of the Circumcision, painted in 1624 by Esprit Castagnier of Marseille after the masterpiece of the Bruges artist Louis Finson, remains (today visible in the red room of the Hôtel de Ville-Château des Covet).

The choir of the church preserves the monumental and triumphal altarpiece of gilded walnut probably offered by Anne de France, lady of Marignane between 1521 and 1522.
