It honors the descendants of Saint Anne and the Holy Marys, whose relics were rare in the church, up to the Nativity sheltered under the central arch. Executed in the entourage of Jean Guiramand, part of it is attributable to the sculptor Jean Paumier, known as Lagrimo, paid in Marignane in 1522. Two large canvases are next to it in the choir, a Saint Eloi between Saint Clair and Saint Marguerite coming from the altar of this brotherhood and painted by Honoré de Caron de Saint-Mitre in 1646, and a Saint François de Paule in prayer (Marseille school of around 1700) transferred from the chapel of the convent of the Minimes fathers

The walls of the monument are punctuated by an important group of stained glass windows by the Aix master Louis André, dated from 1895 to 1897, from which emerges a Baptism of Christ illuminating the baptismal font, assembled after the work of the Nazarene painter Julius Schnorr von Carosfeld

Classified as a historical monument in 1992, the church has recently been restored and its surroundings have been completely remodeled.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Médiathèque "La Mine de Mots"
comment:
The media library of Trets offers regular events, conferences, screenings, writing workshops, creative workshops ..
Don't forget to consult the program at the Media Library!
shortDescription:
The media library of Trets offers regular events, conferences, screenings, writing workshops, creative workshops ..
Don't forget to consult the program at the Media Library!
description:
The mission of media libraries is to provide equal access to reading and documentary sources. More widely, they make available to everyone what to respond to his curiosity, organize his leisure, expand his knowledge ... In Trets, it has become a place of meetings and exchanges.
Your media library is evolving, it is now accessible online.
You can now consult the catalogue and see from home if we have the document you are looking for, as well as its availability. You also have access to various information concerning the places, animations, favourites..

label: Oppidum de Notre-Dame de Pitié
comment: Fortified perched village (oppidum) identified by excavations (now covered) from the 4th century BC on the hill of Marignane
shortDescription: Fortified perched village (oppidum) identified by excavations (now covered) from the 4th century BC on the hill of Marignane
description:
From the 4th century B.C., a fortified perched village (oppidum) was founded by a Celto-Ligurian population (the Tricorii?) on the borders of the Greek domain of Marseille (Massalia)

Discovered in the 1960s thanks to the excavations of the Marignan brothers Octave and Aimé Sicard, the site has revealed through various campaigns, notably those led by Louis Gantès, the existence of an Iron Age settlement at the highest point of the commune

This first Marignan village developed on the promontory of the Notre-Dame chapel, but also on the entire western ridge, thus covering several hectares. This habitat was deserted at the beginning of the 2nd century BC
It is composed of various housing units grouped into three blocks representing four phases of occupation. The complex is surrounded by a rampart flanked by towers and served by a cart track
The archaeological material consists mainly of ceramic remains, notably pseudo-Attic, Massalian amphorae, black-glazed tableware from Latium (delicate bowls with dolphin or fleuron motifs from the workshop of the Petites estampilles), and native shaped vases
There is also a millstone in basalt

These testimonies of daily life from the excavations can be seen in the Albert Reynaud Museum

The oppidum and the entire archaeological remains of Notre-Dame de Pitié were classified as historical monuments by decree on April 28, 2004. Most of the excavations have been covered up, but a signposting system makes it possible to see the main landmarks

Every third weekend in May, a historical re-enactment under the name of "Grannus" is organized by the association of the Heritage Workshop, in partnership with the City of Marignane. It testifies and proposes an experiment of the life at the time of the Gauls.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Plage Lumière
comment: Sandy beach watched in season. Nature of the ground: sand.
shortDescription: Sandy beach watched in season. Nature of the ground: sand.
description:
Panel of identification on the site. Paying parking area near the beach. Plan of access for disabled people, put at the disposal of specific armchairs of bathings, staff " handiplage ". Not accepted dogs. Non-smoking beach.
A zone of baths nearby. Activities for the children. Activity Beach volleyball organized on the beach. Presence of numerous shops.

label: Maison du Lézard
comment: The House of the Lizard was built in the 17th century, in which Frédéric Mistral lived with his mother from 1855 (when his father died) until 1876, when Frédéric Mistral married.
shortDescription: The House of the Lizard was built in the 17th century, in which Frédéric Mistral lived with his mother from 1855 (when his father died) until 1876, when Frédéric Mistral married.
description:
The Maison du Lézard was built in the 17th century and was inhabited by Frédéric Mistral and his mother from 1855 (on the death of his father) to 1876, when Frédéric Mistral got married.
It is a beautiful manor house with a Virgin in a corner niche and a sundial that Mistral installed in 1903:
'Gai lezert, bèu toun soulèu
l’ouro passo que trop lèu
e deman ploura belèu' 'Gay lizard, drink in the sun
time passes too quickly
and tomorrow it may rain'. This building has been listed as a national Historic Monument since 31 July 1930.
Jeanne de Flandreysy bought the Maison du Lézard in 1957 and donated it to Maillane Town Hall.
On the western side of the façade is a plaque installed by the Jeanne de Flandreysy Association:
'A la memóri unenco de Frederi Mistral et de sa maire tant amado, Adelaido. Enremembranço dis an benesi ounte lou pouèto compligue Mirèio, oubrajé Calendau, Lis Isclo d’Or e Lou Tresor dóu Felibrige, festejant d’illustris ami e plourant Lamartine après soun paire. Aquesto lauso avèn dreissa contro l’oustau que lis acaté tóuti dous de 1855 à 1876'. 'In memory of Frédéric Mistral and his much-loved aunt, Adélaïde. In remembrance of the blessed years when the poet completed 'Mireio', composed 'Calendau', 'Lis Isclo d’Or' and 'Lou Tresor dóu Felibrige', welcoming illustrious friends and mourning Lamartine after his father.' This plaque was placed on the house which housed them both from 1855 to 1876. It is now the municipal library, the tourist office and the Mistralian research centre.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Bleus
comment: The chapel of the Blue Penitents is a disused chapel located in Aix-en-Provence, at 2, rue du Bon-Pasteur. The monument is the subject of a partial registration as a historical monument since 1942
shortDescription: The chapel of the Blue Penitents is a disused chapel located in Aix-en-Provence, at 2, rue du Bon-Pasteur. The monument is the subject of a partial registration as a historical monument since 1942
description: The chapel dates from 1771, today it houses an institute for American students.

label: Les jardins méditerranéens du parc de Figuerolles
comment:
The Mediterranean gardens of the Parc de Figuerolles are located on
the location of the former estate of the Sunhary Deverville family,
acquired by the City of Martigues in March 1999.
shortDescription:
The Mediterranean gardens of the Parc de Figuerolles are located on
the location of the former estate of the Sunhary Deverville family,
acquired by the City of Martigues in March 1999.
description:
The plantations are organized according to the theme of resistance to
drought, around six gardens spread over 4 spaces.
Each garden therefore corresponds to a level of resistance, ranked 1
to 6: the plants of the garden 1 can withstand 1 month to the drought the plants of the garden 6, up to 6 months.

In addition to the 27 native plant species (Aleppo pine, green oak, ...), or introduced by the family Sunhary Deverville (Yucca, Lilac of India, Laurel rose, ...), this site gathers nearly 300 species
representative plants of a flora adapted to the Mediterranean climate, on an area of about two hectares.

An area where protected plants thrive (Marsh-leaved Hummingbird and Thornless Bugrane) is delineated near the main entrance.
In addition to the plantations, a mirrored basin with a jet of water in the center was built in the middle of an old yucca plantation.
Indeed, it is important to note that the plants presented in these gardens have very different origins: Mediterranean Basin, South America, South Africa, China, Southeast of the United States, California, Australia, ... These are places where the Mediterranean climate is well established.
streetAddress: ['Avenue du Grand Parc', 'Grand Parc de Figuerolles']

label: Bibliothèque médiathèque Fernand Boulan
comment: Since May 2001, Châteauneuf-Le-Rouge has been equipped with a media library
shortDescription: Since May 2001, Châteauneuf-Le-Rouge has been equipped with a media library
description:
Châteauneuf-Le-Rouge has had a media library since May 2001. 

The cultural centre is much appreciated and popular among the general public: 1418 active members (data from May 2008) and regular visits from 250 Sainte Victoire school group students prove the appeal and position of the media library.

The Bibliothèque Médiathèque Fernand Boulan is perfectly in keeping with the château: a barn and former wine cellars in the château's south-west wing have been renovated to create a spacious and light-filled 400m2 play area with lots of windows providing views of the château grounds and a patio with a fountain where readers can linger.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
description:
Peyrolles-en-Provence is above all a village whose agricultural vocation dates back to its origins. However, history teaches that at the time of King René, the castle was a mecca for culture and science.

The local heritage has thus been enriched by the historical remains of the castle, the chapel of the Holy Sepulchre, but also the Church of Saint Peter and Our Lady of Astors. Even older is the Palm Grotto, a unique site in Europe and attracting more and more visitors.

While preserving the rural aspect which makes it so charming, Peyrolles-en-Provence wishes to open up to the outside world by welcoming tourists inspired by its heritage, but also by the proximity of the Massif de Concors or the Lac de Peyrolles which offers more and more activities around the water.

With the help of institutional or associative partners, including the C.P.A, the C.D.T des Bouches-du-Rhône, the Tourist Office of Aix-en-Provence, but also the Grand Site Concors-Sainte Victoire or Peyrolles Rétro, our tourist proposals are diversifying, both in terms of accommodation and activities on offer.

label: Vieux village de Gardanne
description: Discover the old centre of Gardanne, unknown to the general public. Provencal alleys, village houses, mills, chapel, bell tower and 360 degree viewpoint.

label: Eglise Saint Eugène d'Endoume
comment: The beautiful church of Saint Eugène, built in the 19th century, is located a little off the rue d'Endoume, in the eponymous district, at the beginning of a series of small streets that lead to the Kennedy corniche and the Vallon des Auffes.
shortDescription: The beautiful church of Saint Eugène, built in the 19th century, is located a little off the rue d'Endoume, in the eponymous district, at the beginning of a series of small streets that lead to the Kennedy corniche and the Vallon des Auffes.
description:
The church is bright: the warm colors of its stained glass windows, its walls and its organ evoke a Provencal style palette. The whole is maintained with great care.
A few meters away, on a facade of Tolstoy street, a plaque commemorates the visit of Marseille schools by the great writer in 1861.

The church is part of the parish of Roucas Blanc with Saint-Antoine de Padoue.
Administrator: Father Xavier Manzano
Mass on Sunday 9:30 am

label: Vallon de Riaux Bas
description: In the summer of 1908, Braque returned to l'Estaque for the third time and took as his motive a group of houses still visible today. Thus was born Maisons à l'Estaque, a painting for which the word cubism was coined. Two years earlier, Braque had depicted the same motifs in a Fauvist work.

label: Le Moulin d'Alphonse Daudet
comment: Alphonse Daudet's mill was built in 1814 and operated until 1915. In 1935 the Société des Amis d'Alphonse Daudet restored it and dedicated it to the author.
shortDescription: Alphonse Daudet's mill was built in 1814 and operated until 1915. In 1935 the Société des Amis d'Alphonse Daudet restored it and dedicated it to the author.
description: The Ribet mill, Saint-Pierre, or Alphonse Daudet's mill, was built in 1814 and operated until 1915, when the wheat was requisitioned for the war. In 1935, it is this mill, which is the most recent and best preserved, that the Société des Amis d'Alphonse Daudet is restoring. It corresponds best to the description of the mill dreamed of by the author because it has the lower room and will be dedicated to the author.

label: Fontaine au Sanglier
comment: Firstly exposed at the City Hall in the 1980s, the fountain similar to the one in Florence is a reinterpretation in bronze of the one made in italian Renaissance de Tacca marble.
shortDescription: Firstly exposed at the City Hall in the 1980s, the fountain similar to the one in Florence is a reinterpretation in bronze of the one made in italian Renaissance de Tacca marble.
description: It represents a wild boar whose snout is used as a canon. At the base we can find snakes, turtles and snails, that provide a natural decoration.

label: Oratoire Saint Eloi
description: Built at the beginning of the 18th century in the southeast of the village. Patron saint of the "household", easy layer of the peasantry, pet owners of labour who practiced cultivation of cereals. Nearby was also an area of hype.

label: Les Oratoires de Noves
comment: Oratories of Noves.
shortDescription: Oratories of Noves.
description:
- Oratory Notre Dame à Noves (Avenue Agricol Viala): It is the oldest of the village. Votive oratory erected against the plague of 1721, it aims to protect the village against epidemics. It was moved during the construction of the railway line.
The current statue of the Virgin and Child Jesus was sculpted by Daniel Chereches, an artist of Romanian origin, in 2001. This statue replaces the original stone statue of Lens in plaster very damaged by time.
The oratory is smaller than at its origin, due to the raising of the road and the sidewalk. It has a rectangular base with a cornice entablature. The niche has a quadrangular opening and the roof has two slopes, topped by a stone cross.

- Saint Eloi Oratory (Route de Châteaurenard): Built in 1869 (restored in 1982 and 1994), this oratory dedicated to Saint Eloi is one of the most widespread votive buildings in our territory.
The restoration in 1994 allowed the association of the Novais Heritage to revive the tradition of the Saint Eloi cart in Noves. This carreto ramado takes place every year on the first Sunday of June.
The building has a rectangular base decorated with cartouches. On the molded base, a cornice forming the entablature supports a large semicircular niche, with an angel's head in the keystone, framed by volute buttresses decorated with acanthus leaves. The roof, formed by a cornice in a lowered arc, supports an iron cross. On the base, above a rose window we read: MDCCCLXIX (1869).

- Oratoire Saint Roch (Avenue de la République): Very nice oratory that is located in the center of the Paluds de Noves. Dedicated to Saint Roch, patron saint of the plague victims, a traditional feast is dedicated to this saint on the first Sunday of September.
The building has a rectangular section and is made of large ashlars. Above a low base, a molded entablature supports a large semicircular niche framed by pilasters with capitals, supporting a frieze and a cornice surmounted by a flat roof adorned at the corners with scrolled brackets in the form of acroteria. A wrought iron gate with a radiating transom protects the statue of the saint. On the keystone you can read the date of construction 1866, and under the niche the dedication "Saint Roch, pray for us".

label: Rive Neuve (rive Sud du Vieux Port)
comment: The former Arcenaulx of Marseille occupied a space between the rue Breteuil, the quai des Belges, the quai de Rive-Neuve and the rue Fort Notre-Dame.
shortDescription: The former Arcenaulx of Marseille occupied a space between the rue Breteuil, the quai des Belges, the quai de Rive-Neuve and the rue Fort Notre-Dame.
description:
The Thiars place.
The history of the Arcenaulx began under Charles VIII at the end of the 15th century and ended in the middle of the 18th century when the last galley slaves were distributed among the chiourmes of Brest, La Rochelle and Toulon.

About 10,000 galley slaves lived there in deplorable conditions, chained day and night, freezing to death in winter (especially in 1710 when the port froze!), suffocating from the heat in summer... Nevertheless, some of them kept stores on the port or worked in the soap factories of the rue Sainte and the Place aux Huiles, thus ensuring a meager income. The "chiourme" was created by Charles IX in 1564. It was originally made up of Turks, "negroes" and common law prisoners, then in the 17th century Protestants were added. The Arsenal des Galères was a city within a city where galley slaves, non-commissioned officers and officers lived together in an extreme stench, sometimes masked by the great celebrations given by these gentlemen of the officers' corps.
In 1494, Charles VIII left for the Italian wars and had six galleys armed in Marseille, then in 1512 Louis XII had six new terceneaux (shipbuilding and repair sheds) built. Over the centuries their number increased. But it was not until 1660, when Louis XIV came to Marseille, that a Grand Arsenal des Galères was built and a new urban plan was drawn up for Marseille. Less than six years later, Nicolas Arnoul, Colbert's trusted advisor, undertook the modernization of the arsenal, which was to become one of the elements of the city's remodeling. The city grew from 65 to 195 hectares and was equipped with a new wall. The 1666 expansion was the most important urban planning operation carried out in Provence in modern times, and for the first time in its history, the port was at the heart of the city. Indeed, the Greek city was founded on the north side of the harbor and it was only in the 17th century that residential areas were built on the south side of the harbor. The Grand Arsenal now extends as far as rue Paradis and the bottom of the Canebière where the administration buildings are arranged around the Pavillon de l'Horloge. Other existing buildings, such as the convict hospital, are reused and included in the perimeter of the new arsenal.

The fish auction
In 1909, a fish auction was opened and remained in operation until 1975, when the fish market was transferred to the north of the city to the industrial port of Saumaty. The building was then completely redesigned from the inside, but its façade retained its original layout. The Théâtre National de Marseille was inaugurated in 1981 by the Mayor of Marseille, Gaston Defferre. Directed for more than ten years by Marcel Maréchal, "la Criée" has a very good program each season.
Vincent Scotto was born on April 21, 1874 at number 32 of the Rive Neuve quay.
Almost opposite the ferry landing is the Bar de La Marine, which owes its fame to Marcel Pagnol. It remains the main setting for the trilogy "Marius, Fanny, César", whose action takes place on the Old Port in 1930s Marseille.
*** Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator (free version) ***

label: Le Bateau de Suffren
comment: Registered as a historic monument on 23 July 2009, this stone ship lies on the banks of the Etang de Berre, behind the Heures Claires nautical base.
shortDescription: Registered as a historic monument on 23 July 2009, this stone ship lies on the banks of the Etang de Berre, behind the Heures Claires nautical base.
description: Registered as historical monuments on July 23, 2009, this stone vessel lies on the banks of the etang de Berre, on the back of the nautical base of clear hours.By erecting this monument on the cliff of Saint-Pierre (then name) around 1785, the Roch of Regis Jesuit wished to pay tribute to his kinsman, the Bailli de Suffren bold who became famous on the seas. This Rock long 23 meters wide by 5 meters and 6.50 metres heavily degraded, it is today difficult to trace the engraving of François-Denis born (circa 1795), which inspired Roch of Regis to shape his work.Premises owners, the cave of the Régis Abbot and the bastide covering the underground Church (Chapel St Pierre) nearby, the Regis, having no seed, Laurent de Suffren, who inherited the property of his brothers-in-law. Married Marguerite-Jeanne of Regis January 17, 1748, Laurent de Suffren, Salon Knight, inherited property that had at Istres Regis, whose kinship with the bailiff is not established.The corniche of Suffren, mas de Suffren at Entressen, yet maintain the memory of this illustrious family in our city.Attention however, the access to this historical monument is unfortunately prohibited and inaccessible because considered dangerous. The cliff is now very unstable, all access to the monument are prohibited.Security and site reclamation projects are mentioned for several years.

label: Hôtel de Bausset
description: The windows of the " Renaissance " period : n°3, " Laget " street. The building was the hotel of Bausset.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Noirs
comment: Religious heritage, in the neo-classical style.
shortDescription: Religious heritage, in the neo-classical style.
description: The " Penitents noirs " church (Black Penitents) : built in 1551. Its frontage is inspired from the Pantheon of Rome. This was the first place where the people of Aubagne could vote during the French Revolution.

label: Réserve naturelle volontaire Tour du Valat
comment: Representative biotope of the Camargue fluvio-lacustrine.
shortDescription: Representative biotope of the Camargue fluvio-lacustrine.
description: Representative biotope of the fluvio-lacustrine Camargue.Site open to the public only during the days open (one to two times per year).

label: Presbytère d'Aurons
description:
Opposite the church, the former presbytery now serves as the town hall.
In the basement, the primitive church of the village dating from the 11th century has been converted into a wedding hall and sometimes hosts exhibitions.

label: Château des Rolland
comment: Old castle of Cabannes located near the church.
shortDescription: Old castle of Cabannes located near the church.
description: Old, abandoned château of mediaeval origin, restored at different times. Impressive construction with ancient ceilings and timbers.

label: Parc du château
comment: Beautiful wooded park of 2 hectares, ideal for strolling, picnicking or spending a friendly time with family or friends.
shortDescription: Beautiful wooded park of 2 hectares, ideal for strolling, picnicking or spending a friendly time with family or friends.
description:
Beautiful wooded park of 2 hectares, ideal for strolling, picnicking or spending a friendly time with family or friends.
Stone picnic tables and benches, children's playground, tennis, boules court and municipal arenas.

label: Hôtel d'Olivary
comment: This 17th century mansion is located in the Mazarin district near the Place des Quatre Dauphins and the Cours Mirabeau in the heart of the city of Aix-en-Provence.
shortDescription: This 17th century mansion is located in the Mazarin district near the Place des Quatre Dauphins and the Cours Mirabeau in the heart of the city of Aix-en-Provence.
description:
This 17th-century mansion is in the Mazarin district, near Place des Quatre Dauphins and Cours Mirabeau in the heart of Aix.


It was built in 1656 to the plans of the Flemish architect Jean Daret (1613-1668) and listed in 1943. The work was carried out by the master masons Jean Jaubert and Laurent Vallon and the decoration by the master plasterworker Jacques Escursan, assisted by the surveyor Louis Cundier, the master carpenters Augustin Reynaud and Nicoles Menard, the sculptor Jacques Fosse and the painter Jacques Macadre.


The mansion boasts a vast stair well with a wrought iron Louis XV handrail among the most elegant in the Mazarin district.


Its three communicating drawing rooms, Les Salons d'Olivary, tastefully decorated with piers and plasterwork, and Regency-style wall hangings in Lyons silk, have been designed for receptions.


The leafy French gardens of 700 square metres, with avenues of box trees, a listed pond and a bowl-shaped fountain, add to its attractions. In 1798 the old Aix Parliamentarian d'Olivary family became the owners of this charming residence. The mansion still belongs to their descendants and has thus been in the same family for more than 200 years.


Since 1984 it has been open to the public for exhibitions, concerts, receptions, conferences and historic tours.

label: Ile Degaby
comment: Former to the famous islands of If, Ratonneau and Pomègues, Degaby Island is famous for its Fort Vauban, built under Louis XIV to reinforce the defenses of the city of Marseille, then restored in 1861.
shortDescription: Former to the famous islands of If, Ratonneau and Pomègues, Degaby Island is famous for its Fort Vauban, built under Louis XIV to reinforce the defenses of the city of Marseille, then restored in 1861.
description:
It was around 1914 that the island became the fashionable place prized by the personalities of the time after a rich industrialist from Marseille gave it to his mistress, the artist Liane Degaby, who gave it her name. Abandoned for several decades, it was only at the end of the 1980s that the famous creator and sculptor Pascal Moarabito revived this magical place steeped in history.
Today you can rent the island for a private event: parade, filming, gala evening etc. by contacting the SARL "Société d'exploitation de l'Île Degaby" now benefits from the lease concerning the exclusive exploitation of this place (www.ile-degaby.com)

label: Eglise Saint-Cannat les Prêcheurs
comment: The church of the Dominican friars (friars preachers) built in the 16th century, became in turn a parish in 1803 under the name of Saint-Cannat, former bishop of Marseille.
shortDescription: The church of the Dominican friars (friars preachers) built in the 16th century, became in turn a parish in 1803 under the name of Saint-Cannat, former bishop of Marseille.
description:
The façade was built by the Gerard brothers in Roman style (from 1739 to 1744), which contrasts with the late Gothic nave. The baptistery is located in the first chapel on the left. A gilded gate gives access to it. It is dominated by the classified painting by Pierre Parrocel (18th century) representing the baptism of Christ

Also to be seen: the high altar in polychrome marble (1755) and paintings by Serre, Reisson, Faudran. 17th century pulpit. Priest : Xavier Autonès.
The Isnard organ case of 1747 is a two-body case. The instrumental part which was at the beginning of Isnard has been restored by Borme. Several restorations were necessary after the Revolution: that of Génoyer and that of Blondeau. In 1936 important recomposition by Merklin, Dunand and Chéron. The sideboard is classified as a historical monument.

The church is open Monday, Tuesday, Thursday from 9am to 1pm, Wednesday from 9am to 7pm, Friday from 9am to 12pm, Saturday from 3pm to 7pm.

label: Plage de Patorgues
comment: Sandy beach on the commune of St Mitre les Remparts
shortDescription: Sandy beach on the commune of St Mitre les Remparts
description:
Sandy beach. Parking area near the beach. Disabled access. Dogs accepted. No nautical activities.
Cleaning of the beach and collection of ulves (seaweed) from June 15 to September 15. Daily water check. Bacteriological sampling twice a week.
Beach prohibited to swimming.
The beach is no longer abandoned.
Unsupervised beach.
CD 52 avenue de Varage
Arthur's Beach driveway for car access.

Management of natural areas 
Domain of the Conservatoire de l'Espace Littoral et des Rivages Lacustres (Conservatory of Coastal Areas and Lake Shores)

label: Musée d'Art et d'Histoire
description:
The Museum of Art and History is housed in the Old Cloister of Cordeliers. There remains today a cloister and the old parlor.
This museum houses a semi-permanent exhibition of the legendary Tarasque and Tartarin's curiosity cabinet. Punctual exhibitions come to enrich this place rich in history.

label: Fontaine Gilouse
comment: The Gilouse fountain overlooks Eyguières
shortDescription: The Gilouse fountain overlooks Eyguières
description: This resurgence emerges from a fault at the foot of the hill of the Defense and dominates the village.

label: Statue Notre Dame d'Aurons
description: Statue of the virgin and child in Oppède stone formerly installed in the gardens of the Château Florans. During the Second World War, it miraculously escaped the fire caused by the German occupiers. Sold to an antique dealer, it was bought back by the Auronnais a few years later and sealed to the rock overlooking the village so that it could watch over its inhabitants.

label: Ferme pédagogique des Pennes Mirabeau
comment: Created in 1989, in the heart of agricultural land located in the Renardière district south of the city, the Educational Farm allows children to discover the world of the farm, a hinge between nature and man.
shortDescription: Created in 1989, in the heart of agricultural land located in the Renardière district south of the city, the Educational Farm allows children to discover the world of the farm, a hinge between nature and man.

label: Les Jardins d'Albertas
comment: This 8-hectare French-style garden, dating back to the 17th century and a listed Historic Monument, inspired by the Italian renaissance gardens, harbours statues, ponds and pruned box hedges. The Albertas gardens are criss-crossed with 2 kilometres of underground tunnels and there is also an old oil mill nearby.
shortDescription: This 8-hectare French-style garden, dating back to the 17th century and a listed Historic Monument, inspired by the Italian renaissance gardens, harbours statues, ponds and pruned box hedges. The Albertas gardens are criss-crossed with 2 kilometres of underground tunnels and there is also an old oil mill nearby.
description:
Tours all year round for groups from 20 people, prior booking required.

Every year, the last weekend in May is reserved for the Albertas Plant Festival. An event devoted entirely to rare and Mediterranean plants. On the programme: 180 exhibitors, sale, exhibition of plants, guided tours, activities for children, conferences and musical activities..

label: Chapelle Saint Sébastien
comment:
Small chapel dedicated to Saint Sebastian (a Roman centurion of the 3rd century, beaten to death for having reproached the emperor for his cruelty)
In front of the chapel stands a cross.
shortDescription:
Small chapel dedicated to Saint Sebastian (a Roman centurion of the 3rd century, beaten to death for having reproached the emperor for his cruelty)
In front of the chapel stands a cross.
description: Small chapel surrounded by houses, once in the countryside. It is said that this place, dedicated to St Sebastian, invoked to fight against the plague, was built during an epidemic in the 16th century.

label: Eglise Sainte Marie-Madeleine
comment: Long called "The Cathedral" by the martégaux, the most imposing of the town's churches characteristic of Provencal architecture and Baroque decor with an Italian influence has been classified as Historic Monuments since 1947.
shortDescription: Long called "The Cathedral" by the martégaux, the most imposing of the town's churches characteristic of Provencal architecture and Baroque decor with an Italian influence has been classified as Historic Monuments since 1947.
description:
Built between 1670 and 1680, it testifies to the prosperity of the city in the 17th century and the attachment of the inhabitants of the Island who participated in its financing.
The facade has two levels separated by a volumetric cornice with modillions. Its lower part is animated by four columns with Corinthian capitals, fluted pilasters and a broken pediment. The upper part is crowned by a triangular pediment.

The tribune organ, built around 1850 by Prosper Antoine Moitessier, is located above the entrance porch of the church.
The sideboard, classified as a historical monument in 1908, is of Italian inspiration, the rich gilded ornaments in leaf, take up decorative elements of the building.
The instrumental part is in the French style of the time with 26 stops, distributed over 2 keyboards as well as pedals and 1500 pipes.

We will pay particular attention to the Virgin and Child (classified as a historic monument in 1908) and the portal, remarkably carved, inside, in addition to a rich painted decoration, the organ of the Montpellier organbuilder Moitessier (1851 ), the tables of the chapels of Michel Serre (1694), the pulpit to preach in walnut (1677).
The 15-year restoration campaign was awarded the heritage ribbon in 2000.

label: Bibliothèque Municipale de La Barben
comment:
The Library is located on the first floor of the municipal school "Palamède de Forbin".
Open every Saturday from 9.30 to 11.30 am.
Registration is free.
shortDescription:
The Library is located on the first floor of the municipal school "Palamède de Forbin".
Open every Saturday from 9.30 to 11.30 am.
Registration is free.
description: Part of the stock is renewed every quarter thanks to the bookmobile.

label: Parc du Fauge
comment: Park in the heart of the village of Gémenos.
shortDescription: Park in the heart of the village of Gémenos.
description:
Named after the river that runs through it, it is located in the centre of the village.
It is an ideal place for walking, with a playground for children, a bowling green and rest areas in shady spots.
The water and the trees offer a pleasantly cool temperature.

label: Villa Santa Lucia
comment: Located in Marseille, in the heart of Roucas Blanc, this property overlooks the Corniche Kennedy, above the Anse du Prophète.
shortDescription: Located in Marseille, in the heart of Roucas Blanc, this property overlooks the Corniche Kennedy, above the Anse du Prophète.
description:
The complex, dating from the 19th century, comprises a residence on the upper part of the land and a vast walled garden, consisting of a series of terraces on several levels leading down to the sea.
The house and the garden, leaning against the rock, merge into a complex architecture of grottoes, waterfalls, a greenhouse, a belvedere and a basement converted into rooms for pleasure. The villa is the setting for superb rocaille decorations: the art of rocaille is brought to its apogee (some decorations are signed by Gaspard Gardini).

The garden presents a collection of Mediterranean and subtropical plants gathering more than 200 species, including many rare species.

Open to the public all year round by appointment, and from mid-June to the end of September without appointment from Sunday to Wednesday inclusive, as well as for the European Heritage Days.

Possibility to rent the gardens for an event, a seminar or a film shoot.

label: Le Grand Abandoux
comment:
Le Grand Abandoux in St Martin de Crau

Coussous de la Crau (110 ha).
shortDescription:
Le Grand Abandoux in St Martin de Crau

Coussous de la Crau (110 ha).
description: Coussous of Crau (110 ha).

label: Etang du Tampan - phare de la Gacholle
comment: The Gacholle Lighthouse, built in 1882, was automated in 1967. Partially destroyed during the World War II, it was restored in 1947.
shortDescription: The Gacholle Lighthouse, built in 1882, was automated in 1967. Partially destroyed during the World War II, it was restored in 1947.
description: The buildings are now used by the Camargue National Reserve. The sea dyke offers the possibility of long walks or bike rides along the coast of the reserve, between sea and lagoons. A dedicated public reception area is available in the Gacholle Lighthouse since 2002. An exhibition, a small book store, picnic tables and an observatory on sansouire are at your disposal.

label: Croq'jardin
comment: Croq'Jardin" is an educational and family garden, on one hectare of land. It is a space entirely dedicated to the discovery of nature through organic vegetable and fruit growing.
shortDescription: Croq'Jardin" is an educational and family garden, on one hectare of land. It is a space entirely dedicated to the discovery of nature through organic vegetable and fruit growing.
description: The garden is composed of about twenty gardening plots, a botanical trail on the history of vegetables and organic gardening, an educational pond, a medicinal garden, a trail of water mechanisms, an orchard, a water trail designed for children, a tasting area with solar kitchen ... This set of facilities can accommodate all types of public, for animations on composting, insects, biodiversity, plant colours.

label: Fontaine des quatre renards
comment: Fountain dating from the end of the 20th century.
shortDescription: Fountain dating from the end of the 20th century.
description:
Built at the end of the 90s, at the junction of Marx Dormoy and Barbés streets
It consists of a square column, with a bronze fox's head on each side, from which water comes out, and a small basin.

label: Plage privée du Sportbeach Café
comment: The Sportbeach is a bar-restaurant on the seafront, a small artificial paradise where you can enjoy the specialties of the chef, who composes a menu of Mediterranean flavors and fresh market products.
shortDescription: The Sportbeach is a bar-restaurant on the seafront, a small artificial paradise where you can enjoy the specialties of the chef, who composes a menu of Mediterranean flavors and fresh market products.
description:
The "Sport’s Beach Café" is a seaside bar-restaurant located at "Escale Borely" in Marseille, in the city's southern quarters.
Offering delightful views over the sea from its terrace, the establishment is literally a step away from the water's edge. But in fact, the Sport Beach Café is particularly popular for its vast indoor pool, topped with a hanging bridge and lined with palm trees and spongy sun loungers, where you can enjoy laying back and chilling out to your heart's content. You can also enjoy a range of Mediterranean and market specialities concocted by chef Fabrice Amar and served at the poolside in this hand-crafted little paradise…

label: Esplanade Fréderic Mistral
comment: The esplanade of the mills offers a wonderful panoramic view of Marseille with Notre Dame de la Garde and sometimes the islands of Frioul and Riou when the clarity of the sky allows it.
shortDescription: The esplanade of the mills offers a wonderful panoramic view of Marseille with Notre Dame de la Garde and sometimes the islands of Frioul and Riou when the clarity of the sky allows it.
description: The mills were first was probably located within the Castle (12th century), and then North Dame Street before to find on the current place of the San Sebastian Church. The construction of cutting them wind and requires to move, once again, to the current Plaza which was then only a mound at the major works of water, around 1950, a large basin reservoir was built at the end of the Hill. It could therefore not do better to just smooth out to install a garden Belvedere and thus receive a table of orientation in 1977. Today, a mill, the mill Camoin, has been entirely renovated. This privileged place, found the city of Marseille, with our Lady of the guard and sometimes the islands of Friuli and Riou where the clarity of the sky.

label: Tourvieille et les tours de Camargue
comment: The Tampan tower was built at the beginning of the 17th century to control and monitor the access of ships to the Rhone delta and the port of Arles.
shortDescription: The Tampan tower was built at the beginning of the 17th century to control and monitor the access of ships to the Rhone delta and the port of Arles.
description:
The Towers of Camargue, little of which remains on the ground, are nevertheless still present in the toponymy of the delta and in written sources.
They were subject to the many fluctuations of the branches of the Rhône and their history also testifies to a range of different functions.
The towers were originally defensive, and also acted as lighthouses for sailors, as visual communication aids ('farots'), and as a commercial surveillance post.
Some were attached to large estates and later testified to the appearance in Camargue of solid, well-built agricultural and domestic architecture.
The Tourvieille Tower, once one of the largest, now lies in ruins between Salin de Giraud and the Beauduc golf course.

label: Maison de maitre, Calagovière
comment: 19th century house: the Villa Calagovière is one of the most beautiful Provençal creations in the art of the Rocailleurs.
shortDescription: 19th century house: the Villa Calagovière is one of the most beautiful Provençal creations in the art of the Rocailleurs.
description:
Located in the Moulin and Calagovière districts, the villa and its garden face the north-east corner of the Parc Camoin building complex

This remarkable residence is located on a plot of land that may have been known since the Middle Ages as the Mulberry Tree, near a leper colony. The current name of the district, derived from "cacalaus" or snails, evokes the humidity of a land irrigated by the canals of the stream of Font-Marignane, formerly dug for the large garden of the castle

Just as picturesque as its name, the Villa Calagovière is one of the most beautiful Provençal creations in the art of the rockworkers
Built in the second half of the 19th century, it belonged to the Olivier, Béranger, Camoin and Delplanque families

If its main façade remains wisely classical, its north and south sides offered to the eye of passers-by multiply the trompe-l'oeil in cement, drawing from sources as eclectic as the mannerist art of the Renaissance, the rococo curiosities of the 18th century or the more recent neo-gothic architecture of the 19th century. The side facades are clad in false cladding, open to false windows with false shutters ajar or wobbly, one of which is even animated by a cloth carelessly hung on a string. The whole is sheltered under a roof with croupettes, lined with cut wood edges and brackets. Attention is focused on a carved figure leaning against the window of the south gable. Is it a birdwatcher hiding his hand and his catch under the lapel of his jacket?

Unfortunately, we do not know the authors of these masonry illusions, of which a certain number of Italian craftsmen based in Marseille have made a speciality. The mysterious occupant at the window is in any case reminiscent of the same subterfuge adopted in 1877 on a house in Châteauneuf-lès-Martigues

There are other works of rockwork in Marignane, notably in the Saint-Joseph cemetery.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021


The house cannot be visited but can be seen from the outside.

label: Médiathèque Louis Aragon (patrimoine architectural)
comment: Inaugurated in 1981, the multimedia library was extended in 2004 and now measures 3,600 m² making it one of the largest in the region.
shortDescription: Inaugurated in 1981, the multimedia library was extended in 2004 and now measures 3,600 m² making it one of the largest in the region.
description: Built on concrete stilts dug into the spongy subsoil, the multimedia library was designed by Emile Pamart. It has original architectural features including the layout and the use of traditional materials like brick and wood.

label: Niches urbaines de Châteaurenard
comment: Urban niches of Châteaurenard.
shortDescription: Urban niches of Châteaurenard.
description:
When the churches were closed, the population displayed their devotion to the saints by building wall niches for religious protection.
Often they are in cul de four. They accommodate medium-sized statues.
Do not hesitate to discover this type of urban decoration which testifies to an omnipresent religious practice in the life of the inhabitants of the commune.

- Niche de Marie Madeleine : dedicated to Mary Magdalene in the rue de l'Hôtel de ville.

-  Niche of Saint Jean-Baptiste : dedicated to Saint Jean-Baptiste in the street of the Hôtel de ville

- Niche of Saint Martin (3 Montée des Pénitents): Almost opposite the Grey Penitents is a niche with a statue of St. Martin (contemporary workmanship, placed there by the Association for the Safeguarding of the Heritage).

label: BALADE NATURE  sur le Plateau ( à pied, à cheval ou à vélo)
comment: With a colour ranging from white limestone to red clay and sandstone, this natural space is located on the Arbois massif. The cliff with a cuesta relief rich in fossils offers exceptional panoramas of the Etang de Berre and the Sainte-Victoire.
shortDescription: With a colour ranging from white limestone to red clay and sandstone, this natural space is located on the Arbois massif. The cliff with a cuesta relief rich in fossils offers exceptional panoramas of the Etang de Berre and the Sainte-Victoire.
description:
To be seen:
< The cliff, rocky bar offering many points of view.
<The radar visible from almost the whole plateau and which is used for the air control of the landing zone of the airport of Marseille-Provence.
<The location of the Chappe telegraph, built in 1821
<The wildlife observatory, an old hunting lodge restored by a young construction site, which allows to observe several species of birds.
<The quarry, whose rock can be used as marble.
<In the southern neighbourhoods, Valbacol is a natural green space where the town has set up a municipal leisure centre which welcomes children for sports activities and an introduction to the environment.

Biodiversity map available at the Municipal Tourist Office in the town centre and at the village hall.

Access for persons with reduced mobility is limited to portions of the roadways
Dogs must be kept on a leash due to: the passage of riders from the Valbacol Equestrian Centre and the proximity of hunting reserves

Caution during hunting season! In the interests of safety, all users of the countryside - including hikers - should check with the Prefecture or the Hunting Federation about opening days and equip themselves to be seen.

In summer, forest areas are more exposed to the risk of fire. Therefore, to protect walkers and sites, traffic, the presence of people and work in forest areas are regulated by prefectoral decree. Accessibility to the massifs is determined on a daily basis depending on the weather and drought.

To find out more? go to the prefecture's website: www.bouches-du-rhone.gouv.fr

label: Bibliothèque municipale
comment:
Unlimited knowledge, culture and information for young and old. The René Blanc public library has its own collection.
The library holds books on loan from the General Council.
shortDescription:
Unlimited knowledge, culture and information for young and old. The René Blanc public library has its own collection.
The library holds books on loan from the General Council.
description: Possibility of obtaining books (CDs and/or cassettes) for the visually impaired from the Departmental Lending Library.

label: Chapelle Ermitage Saint-Ser
comment: In the 5th century, Servus DEI (Servant of God), a hermit from Lyon, lived in this place. The reputation of sanctity that he acquired in the region overshadowed the Visigoth king Euric who reigned in Provence at the time.
shortDescription: In the 5th century, Servus DEI (Servant of God), a hermit from Lyon, lived in this place. The reputation of sanctity that he acquired in the region overshadowed the Visigoth king Euric who reigned in Provence at the time.
description:
Servus, a hermit from Lyon, lived here in the 5th century. 

The reputation for holiness which he gained in the region offended the Visigoth king Euric who was reigning over Provence at the time.

 One day, in the year 484, Euric had the hermit executed after having his ears cut off. 

The martyr's body was buried by shepherds at the back of the cave where he had lived, and a small chapel was later built in front of the cave, in praise of Servus, who was canonised under the name of Saint-Ser. 

The sanctuary was dedicated on 5 January 1001 by Amalric, the bishop of Aix en Provence. 
The chapel itself has had a chequered history, having been destroyed and rebuilt several times. 

In 1998 the building was crushed by a landslide, caused by erosion following the terrible fire of the Sainte Victoire mountain in 1989. It was rebuilt identically in 2000 by the Municipality under the presidency of the Mayor, Frédéric Guinieri. 

The reconstructed chapel was solemnly inaugurated on Sunday 27 May 2001, a thousand years after its dedication.

label: Eglise de la Mission de France Saint Pie X
comment: Church built under Louis XIV between 1648 and 1673 by the Lazarists during the expansion of the city. This church remained in this state until about 1840.
shortDescription: Church built under Louis XIV between 1648 and 1673 by the Lazarists during the expansion of the city. This church remained in this state until about 1840.
description:
Closed during the Revolution, it became national property and was put up for sale in 1795. It was rented to the "Poor Clares" ( les Clarisses) from 1806 to 1833, then entrusted to the Jesuits by Bishop Eugène de Mazenod in 1839. The latter undertook its restoration from 1844 onwards. It was in fact a real reconstruction which completely changed the appearance of the building.

In 1860 Désiré Michel, a cement manufacturer, created the very original façade that we can still see today. Organ case designed by the architect and engineer Henry Condamin from Marseille. Closed to worship in 1901, it became a concert hall, then after various tribulations, a masonry school and a warehouse for school furniture until 1979. It was finally given back to worship by the City of Marseille to the Priestly Fraternity of Saint Pie X, the 18th of  October 1982.

label: Musée des Tapisseries, Palais de l'Archevêché
comment: Created in 1909, now an accredited Musée de France, the tapestry museum is housed on the 1st floor of the former Archbishop's Palace, in the staterooms.
shortDescription: Created in 1909, now an accredited Musée de France, the tapestry museum is housed on the 1st floor of the former Archbishop's Palace, in the staterooms.
description:
The palace, a listed Historic Monument, is made up of four wings and an interior courtyard and was, until the beginning of the 20th century, the residence of several Aix prelates. The different eras and residents have left their mark on the palace's architecture, which has been renovated and restored to its former glory.

The collection, made up of 17th and 18th century tapestries, consists of three suites, with: 'The Grotesque', inspired by Berain, 'The Story of Don Quixote', by Natoire and 'Russian Games', by Leprince. There are also some remarkable pieces of furniture (cabinets, chairs, dressers). 

On the ground floor, the 'Gothic' room hosts temporary exhibitions, while the courtyard houses the Theatre of the Archbishop, one of the venues of the Aix-en-Provence Festival (Opera Festival).

Boasting an international reputation, the Aix Festival has given a new direction to the museum since the 1970s. It has resulted in the creation of a collection of textile arts, contemporary arts and performing arts with the aim of creating an 'Opera Centre' to house the town's opera heritage collections originally created for the Aix Festival and the Jeu de Paume theatre.
streetAddress: ['28 Place Des Martyrs de la Résistance', "Palais de l'Archevêché"]

label: Chapelle Saint-Denis
comment: Located south of Rognes, the Saint-Denis chapel is clearly visible from the departmental road 543. This monument whose construction began in 1720 was built to preserve the village and its inhabitants from the plague that raged in Provence at that time.
shortDescription: Located south of Rognes, the Saint-Denis chapel is clearly visible from the departmental road 543. This monument whose construction began in 1720 was built to preserve the village and its inhabitants from the plague that raged in Provence at that time.
description:
A first chapel dedicated to Saint Denis, patron saint of Rognes, was built between 1567 and 1590 in the rue Droite (center of the village).
Around 1610, the chapel was given to the brotherhood of the White Penitents who held it until the Revolution.
Heavily damaged by the 1909 earthquake, it was razed to the ground, but some remains are still visible.
The epidemic of the Great Plague of 1720 gave rise to a second chapel of Saint-Denis on the road to Aix, built to protect the Rognens from this plague. Construction began at the end of 1720 and lasted several years. The town was spared, thanks in particular to the closing of the rampart doors at night
The chapel has a single nave with high windows and ends in a circular apse whose vault was restored in 1877. In front of the chapel, a stone cross was erected.
Until the 1960s, the chapel contained, as a relic, the aprons made of waxed cloth that were used by the priests to protect themselves from contagion when distributing communion.
Aniseed-flavored bread rolls are distributed during the mass celebrated every year on October 9 for the feast of Saint Denis.
(Source: Les Amis du Patrimoine de Rognes)

label: Tour Anglica
comment: The Anglica Tower is a 14th century tower overlooking the village of Barbentane.
shortDescription: The Anglica Tower is a 14th century tower overlooking the village of Barbentane.
description: Built on the northern flank of the montagnette, the city is dominated by the Tower Anglica. Built in 1365 by the Cardinal Grimoard, brother of Pope Urban V, the tower measures 28 m high and 10 m wide. It remains the great witness of medieval times, it has been restored in the eighteenth century. The Angelica, topped by a turret, Tower was sung by Mistral in the Golden Iscles. To his left, (XIV) Sequier door lock village. The tower is classified historical monument since 1925. The site is closed to the public.

label: Le Musée Provençal
comment: The museum retraces life in the Marseille regions from th e 18 th to the  19 th century: furniture, costumes and objects recreating the traditional way of life in Provence.The  collections of religious art, nativity scenes and santons evoke festivals and customs.
shortDescription: The museum retraces life in the Marseille regions from th e 18 th to the  19 th century: furniture, costumes and objects recreating the traditional way of life in Provence.The  collections of religious art, nativity scenes and santons evoke festivals and customs.
description:
An agrarian room presents " the evocation of crops in the Marseille region with scenes referring to harvests, grape harvest and olives picking.

The tour is  guided by  baptistin, born of the museum's collaboration with polytech Marseille, the  engineering school of Aix-Marseille University based in the technology centre. The  guide has a surprise  for  visitors.Created by Jean-Bptiste Pignol, the theatre offers differents kind of  events such as ballet,performances, recitals, music of the world.

A library and an archive dedicated to local traditions ans  history complete the museum.The activites, events and temporary exhibitions which makes this place a real temple of Provecal culture.

A  few examples of  activites: " boutis" workshop, paleography course, generealogy circle, restoration of eathenware, bookbinding, gilding, culture and provençal language. Themed days and evenings: international foot  open, calendar  night, New year's eve.

Besides, a shop offers  different souvenirs such as liquors, 'calissons', books, housewares. Every second monday of the  month, the museum offers a  guided tour to individuals on registration.

Surface of the permanent exhibition :10000
surface  are  of temporary  exhibition: 100

label: Marais du Vigueirat
comment: The Marais du Vigueirat is a protected natural site of 1,200 hectares at the junction of two remarkable ecosystems: the Rhone delta and the steppe plain of the Crau.
shortDescription: The Marais du Vigueirat is a protected natural site of 1,200 hectares at the junction of two remarkable ecosystems: the Rhone delta and the steppe plain of the Crau.
description:
The Marais du Vigueirat is one of the most remarkable properties of the Conservatoire du Littoral in the Camargue.
The natural heritage of the Marais du Vigueirat is recognized on a national and international scale, benefiting notably from a classification as a National Nature Reserve, and constitutes a central zone of the Camargue Biosphere Reserve.
All year round, the Marais du Vigueirat can be discovered on a self-guided tour along the Etourneau trails (a trail on stilts for families) or on a guided tour by horse-drawn carriage or on foot. For nature and bird lovers, a 5 km hike is proposed in the heart of the nature reserve, on a route punctuated by various wildlife observatories and observation towers.
The Marais du Vigueirat also offer a "sustainable" store (local products, from Mas-Thibert and Camargue, a bookshop, a nature section, etc.) and a refreshment bar open every day from 11am to 5pm from April to the end of September, and during the All Saints' Day vacations.

label: Eglise Saint-Jean de Malte
comment:
The fortified church owes its name to the Knights of Saint-John of Jerusalem. 
Built outside the ramparts in the 13th century, this was the first Gothic construction in Provence. It used to contain the graves of the Counts of Provence in its side chapels.
shortDescription:
The fortified church owes its name to the Knights of Saint-John of Jerusalem. 
Built outside the ramparts in the 13th century, this was the first Gothic construction in Provence. It used to contain the graves of the Counts of Provence in its side chapels.
description:
Next to the church, palais de Malte, built in 1676, was formerly the Commander's residence before becoming the present-day Granet Museum. 

Inside the museum are numerous archaeology exhibition rooms and major collections of 16th to 20th-century paintings, including a few works by Cézanne.

label: L'Ile Verte
comment: A piece of land covered with greenery, more than 400 meters from the continent, opposite the Bec de l'Aigle and the shipyards of La Ciotat ...
shortDescription: A piece of land covered with greenery, more than 400 meters from the continent, opposite the Bec de l'Aigle and the shipyards of La Ciotat ...
description:
Integrated in the classified site of Cap Canaille, the exceptional île Verte is one of the jewels of the departmental heritage.

Its acquisition dates back to 1963. Its modest dimensions (420 meters long and 260 wide) nevertheless reveal a territory of 13 hectares rich in a beautiful diversity of landscapes and places.

To discover: at the highest point, at 49 meters above sea level, a hill surmounted by Fort Saint-Pierre, a delicate wooded area that fires have not attacked since 1957, Napoleonic forts and blockhouses dating from the last world war , The intimate beaches of Saint-Pierre, the Plageolle and Seynerolles, and traces of protohistoric habitat. Around, the magnificence of the marine environment attracts many fans of diving.

label: Eglise Saint-Denis
comment: Visit the Romanesque church of Saint Denis in Ventabren
shortDescription: Visit the Romanesque church of Saint Denis in Ventabren
description: Built in 1650, of Romanesque style, the church of Ventabren is dedicated to the mother of God and to Saint-Denis in memory of an insignia relic offered by Queen Jeanne and consisting of the lower jaw of Saint-Denis the Areopagist. Restored and enlarged in 1877, the Romanesque church has few openings, it is surmounted by a magnificent bell tower, it has inside various valuable paintings, a gilded wooden high altar from the 17th century and the baptismal font from the 16th century. Through these different aspects, the church of Saint-Denis is worthy of interest and remains a testimony to the importance of religious concerns in the life of villages such as Ventabren.

label: Apié
comment: Bee wall (apis), built of dry stone.
shortDescription: Bee wall (apis), built of dry stone.
description: This apie, which is probably very old, has 36 niches (the oldest apiés date back to Roman times). The one in La Roque, well preserved, is one of the longest in Provence. It is oriented towards the rising sun, protected from the Mistral wind. Located on a private property, it can be admired from the road.

label: Colline Notre-Dame
comment: The Notre-Dame hill, with a maximum altitude of 104 meters and a surface area of 65 hectares, is a real green lung for Marignane. Today, the site offers a combination of natural, sporting and historical assets.
shortDescription: The Notre-Dame hill, with a maximum altitude of 104 meters and a surface area of 65 hectares, is a real green lung for Marignane. Today, the site offers a combination of natural, sporting and historical assets.
description:
The Notre-Dame hill, with a maximum altitude of 104 meters and a surface area of 65 hectares, is a real green lung for Marignane
Composed of a limestone cover resting on a clay mattress dating from the terminal Cretaceous (-70 million years), the hill could contain the remains of dinosaur eggs, as suggested by a fossil unearthed in the lime kiln district and preserved in the Albert Reynaud Museum
At present, it is covered by a low scrubland developing under a pine forest resulting from reforestation operations
The vegetation on the western flank, on a bed of damp clay, is composed of riverside species

In the Middle Ages, the hill was included in the seigniorial domain, under the name of Deffens or Devens, rich in its wooded and mineral resources, and its game population. From 1447, it was gradually granted rights and land to the inhabitants and the community by Gabriel Valori and his successor Charles du Maine, lords of Marignane. Pastoral activities, wood gathering and lime exploitation were then developed. There are ruins of a sheepfold on the ridge path, as well as several scattered traces of ovens

Today, the site presents a combination of natural and historical assets
-	an oppidum from the 4th century BC. (covered excavations, partially visible to this day),
-	notre-Dame de Pitié chapel, a 15-minute walk from the car park (open to the public every first Sunday of the month and on the occasion of events organised by the Association des Amis de Marignane et de la Provence),
-	calvary erected in 1533 at the end of the rocky outcrop,
-	panoramic table,
-	remains of a small quarry from the end of the 15th or beginning of the 16th century below, a large quarry exploited in the 1950s and 1960s used as a setting for cultural events

In terms of sports facilities, the hill is criss-crossed by a health course consisting of 16 workshops over a distance of 1650 meters, punctuated by sports equipment near the car park (relaxation, bodybuilding ...), a track and a grassy ring of 700 meters
They are next to a botanical trail "of the children of Marignane" created in 1997 on a 1700-meter path, playgrounds and picnic areas, the Square le Duff, a pleasant landscaped area, playgrounds and picnic areas, all crossed by the Marignane section of the GR2013, linking the Pas-des-Lanciers train station to the Jaï by following the cuesta and then winding through the hill.

Attention, the access to the forest massifs is regulated from June 1st to September 30th in the Bouches-du-Rhône to prevent forest fires. Information is available on 
- by calling 0811 201 313 (chargeable call)
- by consulting the application MyProvence Envie de Balade
- on the internet: https://www.myprovence.fr/enviedebalade

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Arc de Triomphe
comment: The Triumphal Arch of the door of Aix " L'Arc de Triomphe de la Porte d'Aix" was realized by the architect Penchaud. Started in 1823, it was not inaugurated until 1839. The decoration was entrusted to David d'Angers and Jules Ramsey.
shortDescription: The Triumphal Arch of the door of Aix " L'Arc de Triomphe de la Porte d'Aix" was realized by the architect Penchaud. Started in 1823, it was not inaugurated until 1839. The decoration was entrusted to David d'Angers and Jules Ramsey.
description:
Eight  figures of military virtues, now destroyed, dominated this ensemble. Started under Charles X, it was only finished under Louis-Philippe. 
The decoration of the monument  was affected by the change from the flag to the tricolour flag. And, afterwards, the successive regimes changed the dedication of the pediment. 

Composed of the single arch and an attic supported by four corinthian columns, it has a harmony inspired by the arches of antiquity. But it would have benefited, no doubt, from being placed in the heart of the city, on a beautiful road, and not on this square which already has a suburban aspect. Its height and width are the same : 17m68. The arcade measures 6m13 of opening and 10m40 of height.

label: Croix de Marignane : un circuit à découvrir
comment: The itinerary of the crosses: several crosses and oratories have marked the urban or rural landscape of Marignane, among which a certain number still remain.
shortDescription: The itinerary of the crosses: several crosses and oratories have marked the urban or rural landscape of Marignane, among which a certain number still remain.
description:
Several crosses and oratories have marked the urban or rural landscape of Marignane, among which a certain number still remain

The cross of the jubilee of 1769, first erected in front of, was moved to the side of the chapel of Saint-Nicolas, today Saint-Joseph (rue du Souvenir-Français). It commemorates the pilgrimage to Rome made that year to obtain the plenary indulgences decreed by Pope Clement XIV at the very beginning of his pontificate. Of the original set, only the metal crucifix with its curved ends remains, bearing a classically built Christ who has unfortunately lost his forearms. The stone pedestal was, until the beginning of the 20th century, more slender and elaborate, replaced by the one that can be seen today, much more massive

On the edge of the old town, on the old mall (now avenue Jean-Jaurès), the cross known as the Missionaries of Provence has been put back in place. Dated 1846, it commemorates the mission of the four companions of Eugene de Mazenod who came to Marignane in 1816

In the rural area on the hill, the 1712 cross located at the crossroads of the Chemin du Collet Rouge and the old Chemin de la Vierge, now rue Jean-Louis-Calderon, seems to punctuate the route of the ancestral Rogations procession. Although the date of its construction is clearly engraved on the pedestal, nothing is known of its history. It appears on the Napoleonic cadastre of 1818, probably in its original location, as it does today. Carved in stone like the cylinder it surmounts, it was located near the very first convent of the Minimes fathers established on the slope of the Collet Rouge and abandoned around 1700 for their new residence adjoining the seigneurial park. A cavity dug in the pedestal could have been intended for the deposit of the first fruits of agriculture, grains or others, whose protection was requested during the Rogations procession in May. This procession is attested in Marignane since at least 1628, when it was led by the penitents to ask for rain, and until the second half of the 19th century. The tradition was that the procession made a stop and devotions at each cross of the parish encountered on the way. The way of the Virgin, whose cross of 1712 marks the beginning, led then to the crosses of the culminating point, those of the calvaries of 1533 and 1867 punctuating the rocky spur of Devens. They marked the end of the path of the seven oratories of 1541, and were also very probably the final point of the spring procession of the Rogations allowing to immunize the whole territory by aerial blessing.

Several other disappeared crosses have marked the history of the urban landscape of Marignane, such as the one erected in the Middle Ages in the immediate vicinity of the city gate (common house called the belfry, place Camille-Desmoulins), cited as a landmark in a land document of 1462. It probably gave its name to the Auberge de la Croix Blanche, known at the entrance of the town of Marignane (current Bar de la Cigale unfortunately burned in 2017) from the 16th to the end of the 19th century

A mission cross, known as the Cadière bridge cross, dated from before 1730, the year in which the community council paid for its repairs. It still existed in 1818, listed on the Napoleonic cadastre and located on the small square at the crossroads of the current avenue Jean-Jaurès and rue Puits-Madame

Finally, a monumental but sketchy cross appears on an ex-voto of 1861 (visible in the Notre-Dame de Pitié chapel) depicting an accident that probably occurred in a sandy hole on the edge of a pond, of Bolmon or Berre. It is not known whether it really marked the coastal landscape or whether it represented, through the image, the sole votive intention of the painting's sponsors.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Le Castellas
description:
Le Castellas (which means "castle in ruins" in Provençal), was built in 1150 by Pierre Brémond, lord of Auriol, probably on the ancient Roman villa of Solobie (Solobium in Latin).
It was destroyed in 1593 during the reign of Henry IV, when the fortified castles of Provence were dismantled under the command of the Duke of Epernon. The current ruins consist of two towers that frame the ramparts (97m) and the keep, a vaulted room.

label: Baie de La Ciotat
comment: The Baie de la Ciotat stretches from the Pointe de l'Aigle (the rocky peak overlooking the sea) to Saint Cyr sur Mer. This bay includes the green island off La Ciotat and many sandy or rocky beaches.
shortDescription: The Baie de la Ciotat stretches from the Pointe de l'Aigle (the rocky peak overlooking the sea) to Saint Cyr sur Mer. This bay includes the green island off La Ciotat and many sandy or rocky beaches.
description: The Bay of La Ciotat, also called the Gulf of Love, offers magical landscapes in the heart of the Calanques National Park. It is home to the Soubeyranes cliffs, among the most imposing in Europe, the Cap Canaille, the Beak of the Eagle, the ochre creeks of Figuerolles and Mugel, or the Green Island, all sites that justify its title of most beautiful bay in the world, received in 2019!

label: Fontaine de la Durance
comment: Fountain of the 20th century.
shortDescription: Fountain of the 20th century.
description:
Built in 1909, this fountain pays tribute to the River Durance which flows to the north of Châteaurenard. Its inscription, 'Eici, l’aigo es d’or' (Here, water is gold) reveals the importance of this river, not only for the Châteaurenard region, but also for a large part of the Pays d'Arles.  Its canalisation and distribution throughout the territory by means of a hydraulic network of small streams and canals allowed a flourishing fruit and vegetable production industry to develop on this arid or marshy land.
Allegorical work by the sculptor Farigoule. It represents the Durance as a young, impetuous, large river holding in its arms a horn from which healing waters are flowing. The central character represents the Durance, which seems to burst force from the heart of the work and spread at its feet water contained in a vase. To the right sits Demeter (Roman equivalent: Ceres), goddess of agriculture, sporting the headdress of Mireille; with her generous breasts, she symbolises Mother Earth, fertility and fecundity. Clusters of fruit and ears of wheat are strewn over the earth at her feet. To the left is Hermes (Roman equivalent: Mercury), god of trade. He also represents the prosperity generated by agriculture. The fountain was inaugurated by Mayor Hubert Pleindoux in September 1909.

label: Site archéologique de la Via Agrippa
description:
In this area known for the richness of its ancient past, the construction site of an electrical transformer station located in Graveson (Bouches-du-Rhône) was an opportunity for RTE, the operator of the public electricity transmission system, to entrust an archaeological excavation to INRAP, the National Institute for Preventive Archaeological Research, in 2015.

In particular, archaeologists have unearthed a road built from the 1st century BC and rebuilt in the 1st century AD, the Via Agrippa, which linked Lyon to Arles. Also found on the site of the funeral pyres, a building, a well and a secondary road.

A particularly well-preserved section of the track has been developed and is accessible to the public
The research carried out around this discovery is presented in educational materials, including a 30-metre-long mural fresco accompanied by explanatory cartoons.

These well-documented teaching materials have been designed in a playful way to appeal to a wide audience, especially children.

label: Fontaine des Trois Ormeaux
comment: The Three Elms Fountain, built over the well in 1632 after various earlier structures had been destroyed, is surrounded by three tall trees which protect the square from the sun and keep the water cool.
shortDescription: The Three Elms Fountain, built over the well in 1632 after various earlier structures had been destroyed, is surrounded by three tall trees which protect the square from the sun and keep the water cool.
description:
In 1524 Constable Bourbon, leading the troops of Charles V, arrived in procession to take the key of the city from the provost Honoré de Puget. Bourbon's procession was to be acclaimed by the crowd, but when the provost asked a Provençal peasant to shout "Long Live Bourbon!" he refused. 

Three elms stood there, all of them shading a small well, and the peasant was hanged on one of them. It is said that the elm died within a year.

As the fountain bears this name, it is likely that the trees in question were elms however, a disease destroyed these trees in the 19th century, and they were replaced first by plane trees and then by maples.

The fountain was recently renovated, but its shape and decoration remain unchanged.

It stands on an octagonal basin and has an elegant pedestal supporting a cylindrical block, a vase of Calissanne and Bibémus stone, decorated with vine leaves and flowers, with a superb cluster of grapes at its top.

The basin is thick and high, and passers-by can sit there and rest, listening to the music of the water flowing from the four outlet pipes. 

The Three Elms Fountain has stood the test of time with its modest and simple beauty.

The focus of the square is the fountain, and on three sides the houses seem to withdraw, leaving us in the enchantment of the majestic trees and the sound of the water.

label: Médiathèque Marcel Pagnol
description:
Registration and loan are free. To obtain a reader's card, simply present :
an identity document: identity card or passport or driving licence or livret de famille or residence permit a proof of residence of less than 3 months (EDF, rent or telephone receipt)
An accommodation certificate for the persons concerned.

The Marcel Pagnol media library provides its users and visitors with a free Internet connection via Wi-Fi, accessible from their personal laptop or any other mobile terminal.
The connection is subject to prior registration on the www.aubagne.fr portal. The connection time is 3 hours, renewable.

label: Abbaye de Saint Pons
description: Near the chapel of St. Martin, we discover the Cistercian abbey of Saint-Pons, founded by Dame Garcende in 1205 of which she was the first abbess. Nuns of the order of Citeaux lived there cloistered in poverty and prayer until 1427. This majestic building is the most complete example of a female monastery. This completely renovated abbey belongs to the General Council. The abbey is open at certain times of the year on request and on Heritage Days.

label: La maison des Templiers
comment: House of the Templars
shortDescription: House of the Templars
description: The house known as the Templars' house is located in a street with the evocative name of "Pavé d'Amour". Classified as a historical monument, and dating from the 16th century, this mansion of Renaissance style and aristocratic taste, was built by Lord Foresta, a native of Italy. Capricious, he decided to build a fashionable hotel, more modern and more comfortable than the historical castle. Unfortunately, in the 20's, this hotel met a sad fate. M. de Kassel, baron, undertook to demolish it stone by stone, to rebuild it on his land in Cannes. But he died on a trip to America before the work was completed. So there are pieces of the hotel scattered on the French Riviera, and in Lançon we still have this magnificent vestige... The inscription "sub silen" is perhaps an abbreviation of "sub silentium", that is to say that we keep under silence... but keep under silence what? It remains a mystery...

label: Réserve naturelle volontaire Château de la Barben
comment: Voluntary nature reserve of 285 hectares in the commune of La Barben
shortDescription: Voluntary nature reserve of 285 hectares in the commune of La Barben
description: Nesting of Bonelli's Eagle.

label: Plage Calanque de Port Pin
comment: A cove of pebbles and gravel, 50 meters long and 20 meters wide. Its cliff is abrupt, the relief rough. The waters are of a deep blue in the shape of a ribbon.
shortDescription: A cove of pebbles and gravel, 50 meters long and 20 meters wide. Its cliff is abrupt, the relief rough. The waters are of a deep blue in the shape of a ribbon.
description:
Access only by foot with the hiking trail GR98-51 from the parking of the peninsula in Cassis, or from La Gardiole. 
This cove is now included in the National Park of Calanques.

label: Parc Départemental de Saint Pons
comment: Saint-Pons is a valley formed by the park, where the waters of a main torrent meander: the Fauge, whose source never dries up, an exceptional thing.
shortDescription: Saint-Pons is a valley formed by the park, where the waters of a main torrent meander: the Fauge, whose source never dries up, an exceptional thing.
description:
In the past, deep glaciers dug into the Sainte Baume massif refreshed the Marseilles area every day (one of them, located under the cliffs of the Pic de Bertagne, has been preserved).

The valley of Saint-Pons enjoys an archaeological and historical heritage that is surprising to say the least. There are caves inhabited as early as the Neolithic period, a chapel, named Saint-Martin, of medieval origin, a solitary nave dating from the 13th century and now restored, a mossy waterfall, an old wheat mill driven by the force of the water, then again, eaten away by the vegetation,

 At the bottom of the park, there are meadows to welcome families (parking, picnic, large areas for children).

A walk up to the Nave (passing by the waterfall, the old mill) following a shady path along a stream (very refreshing in summer).
