It is then possible to continue climbing up the valley to reach the Sainte Baume massif (and its marked trails) and then to the highest point of the Bouches-du-Rhône (the Pic de Bertagne - 1042m)
The Parc de Saint-Pons can be reached by car either by the RD 2 coming from Plan d'Aups or by the A50 motorway, exit Aubagne then direction Gémenos and then Parc de Saint-Pons
Nearly one kilometre from the town centre of Gémenos, a car park has been redesigned to welcome you.


Management of natural areas: Domaine du Conseil Général

label: Musée provençal des transports
comment:
The museum retraces the history of transport: wagons, trams, trolley-buses, locomotives.
The small train of 60 (wheel gauge) allows a walk in the countryside on a route of 1 km 800 on Sunday afternoons.
shortDescription:
The museum retraces the history of transport: wagons, trams, trolley-buses, locomotives.
The small train of 60 (wheel gauge) allows a walk in the countryside on a route of 1 km 800 on Sunday afternoons.
description:
It's not a merry-go-round or a big toy. It is made with professional equipment from coal and bauxite mines, quarries and public works.
You can also discover about twenty locomotives and tractors, wagons and wagons, and visit a complete mail wagon.
Finally, an old Canebière-Corniche trolley-bus fitted out as a projection room allows you to discover the old transports of Marseille with the help of an audio-visual montage.
You can rent old buses, as well as the site for various events such as weddings, birthdays, photo shoots ...
Tourist animations are proposed to visitors throughout the year as well as gatherings of old vehicles ...
streetAddress: ['Chemin de la Bergerie', 'Gare SNCF de La Barque']

label: Chapelle Saint-Thomas
comment: Romanesque style chapel.
shortDescription: Romanesque style chapel.
description:
It was built around 960 in a simple Romanesque style and originally had a Roman altar for the glory of the Earth and its fertility. It is around it that the first Molegean settlement was organised, mainly consisting of shepherds' huts. Today it is located within the cemetery grounds, the village having moved to the site of the parish church and then the Benedictine abbey.
It is a small rectangular building made of rubble stones, supported on either side by two buttresses, of Romanesque style with a Renaissance façade. Its only lighting comes from a small bay in the centre above the portal.
It is not open to the public and can be admired from the outside.

label: Commanderie Ste Luce
comment: The Commandery of Sainte-Luce presents a set of buildings of high architectural quality. It combines the characteristics of a Provencal House from the end of the middle ages.
shortDescription: The Commandery of Sainte-Luce presents a set of buildings of high architectural quality. It combines the characteristics of a Provencal House from the end of the middle ages.
description: The history of the building is very marked by religious history. Firstly it houses the Templars, and then, after the dramatic episode of their removal, of the order of Malta.The portal of the building, completely restored, has retained flamboyant late fifteenth-century décor. The building itself is organized around a courtyard with a well. The west facade was pierced by windows mullions, topped by an important decoration of mouldings. The angle of this façade and the North facade, there is a hexagonal tower with a spiral staircase.Arcaded loggias allow traffic on the ground floor and the floors.The façade North, built in 1587, has favorable Renaissance characteristic décor. Windows mullioned originally, but modified in the eighteenth century, are framed by fluted pilasters quite antiquisants.The building belonged first to the Knights of the Temple (or Templars), military and religious order founded in 1119, fought and removed at the beginning of the 14th century. He became follows the property of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem, or order of Malta, installed in the sixteenth century in the nearby Grand Priory. Four bodies from the building, one probably dates from the 13th century, two are from the 15th century, and another has been redesigned in the sixteenth.The building was restored in the 1980s.

label: Parc des Soeurs franciscaines missionnaires de Marie
comment: The 6th district of Marseille now has a new green space and a new place dedicated to culture, the domain of the Franciscan Missionary Sisters of Mary.
shortDescription: The 6th district of Marseille now has a new green space and a new place dedicated to culture, the domain of the Franciscan Missionary Sisters of Mary.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


The 6th arrondissement of Marseille now has a new green space and a new place dedicated to culture, the estate of the Franciscan Missionary Sisters of Mary (5 rue de Lacédémone).

The space is made up of a building complex and a park of approximately 10,000 m². The public park opened on December 2, 2019.

Considered a relic property, it includes a large L-shaped building with a wing leaning against the neo-Romanesque Saint-Michel chapel, a gatehouse leaning against the slope that closes the perspective of Rue Escat, a vast grove to the north (pines, fig trees, plane trees, lindens, cedar), a terraced orchard to the south (almond, apricot, plum, medlar trees) and an olive grove.

In this context, the City wished to acquire this 1.1 hectare estate, founded in 1885.

This pre-emption by the City of Marseille meets specific needs in the 6th arrondissement, such as the creation of a landscaped public park, a new green setting in the heart of the city, by offering green spaces (classified wooded areas, previously private) to the inhabitants of the district.

A real green lung for the 6th arrondissement, the Park of the Franciscan Missionary Sisters of Mary will link the Vauban district to the rue Breteuil, with :
- a playground for children ;
- spaces for relaxation with benches
- a landscaped environment ;
- shared gardens and biodiversity areas...

A new place dedicated to art and culture within the convent.
In the heart of the park of the Franciscan Missionary Sisters of Mary, the Saint-Raphaël pavilion, a former convent with a chapel, will allow the Town Hall of the 6th and 8th arrondissements to benefit from more than 3,000 m² for the creation of a "Centre for Arts and Culture".
This new decentralised facility will combine learning and practising artistic activities by providing the inhabitants of the area with a real place to live and enjoy cultural activities.

label: Médiathèque de Plan d’Orgon
comment: Municipal media library of Plan d'Orgon.
shortDescription: Municipal media library of Plan d'Orgon.
description: Establishment founded by a team of volunteers in the 1980s.

label: Château de Peyrolles
description: Listed as a Historic Monument. Initially owned by the Archbishops of Aix en Provence, the castle became by exchange the property of King René from 1475 to 1480. Royal possession until the 17th century, it was then sold to nobles of the region. These successive owners gave the castle its present appearance. Partly bought by the commune in 1864, the town hall and schools were installed there. Consisting of a central body and two wings arranged around a vast courtyard, the classical building is imposing. The interior is vast and decorated with gypseries, paintings and beautiful 18th century marble fireplaces. From the terrace, the view is panoramic: the Durance valley, the Luberon, the Mirabeau parade and the Condors massif

label: Chapellerie Cezanne
comment: Home of Louis-Auguste Cezanne.
shortDescription: Home of Louis-Auguste Cezanne.
description:
After working in the Aix factory of the wool merchant Dethés, Paul's father Louis-Auguste Cezanne left and went to Paris to learn the hatter's trade.

On his return in 1825, he worked in the Carbonnel workshop at this address and met Anne-Élisabeth Aubert, who was a hat-maker at the time. After the birth of Paul, Anne-Élisabeth Aubert and her baby moved in with the child's father.

label: Porte de la Cavalerie
comment:
Date: 1588
Era: Renaissance
Type: Fortified military architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1928.
shortDescription:
Date: 1588
Era: Renaissance
Type: Fortified military architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1928.
description:
The two round towers of the Porte de la Cavalerie stand at the northern entrance to the old town centre.
Its name recalls the settlement of the Knights of the Temple in this district in the Middle Ages.
In the 13th century, after the founding of new districts such as Bourg-Neuf (current La Cavalerie district), the town's perimeter, which remained almost unchanged until until the 19th century, was completely surrounded by ramparts.
Beyond the gate were fields and pasture land, now occupied by the Place Lamartine and the station district (19th century) and later by the districts to the north of the agglomeration.
The building was rebuilt in the 16th century and completed in the 18th century, but was partially destroyed during the Revolution and then again in 1877.
The gate on a plan from 1743
All that remains of the building today are two round bossage towers and north and east fragments of the surrounding walls; the gate itself has been demolished.
It was constructed with large stones from the towers of the Porte de Laure and had a drawbridge, which straddled the Roubine du Roy (drainage canal intended to dry the marshes).
This canal ran in the open along the rampart before gushing into the Rhône, and was rediscovered in 1901.
In the 18th century, a half-moon shaped defence (semi-circular space placed in front of the structure) was added to the gate.

label: La fontaine pointue
description: The Pointed Fountain dates from 1882 with a pointed obelisk and circular basin

label: Hôtels de Gastaud
description: Built in 1670 or thereabouts, the Hôtels de Gastaud were never completed: the curved pediments with oculus on the doors are unfinished.

label: Le Vieux Vernègues
description: The old village of Vernègues was destroyed by an earthquake on 11 June 1909. The castle, the houses and the church are in ruins. You have to leave your car at the car park and walk for a few minutes, before arriving on the thyme-covered plateau, which is swept by the winds on Mistral days. The panorama will make your heart race.

label: Parc de la Tour de Nedon
comment: 1 hectare landscaped park
shortDescription: 1 hectare landscaped park
description: Park of 1 hectare

label: Bibliothèque Sonore
comment: The Bs d'Aix en Provence was created 40 years ago, on March 17, 1980. It moved in April 2018 in a small house in Puyricard. With a car park and a bus stop, it is very easy to access and has seen its number of audio-readers increase
shortDescription: The Bs d'Aix en Provence was created 40 years ago, on March 17, 1980. It moved in April 2018 in a small house in Puyricard. With a car park and a bus stop, it is very easy to access and has seen its number of audio-readers increase
description:
The Pays d'Aix Talking Library is aimed at people unable to read (visual impairment, motor impairment, tremors, ataxia, dystonia, dyslexia and other cognitive disorders) and offers the free loan with free postage of talking books and magazines recorded in MP3 format on a CD, USB key, SD card and for downloading. 

It is run by the Association des Donneurs de Voix, a French charity created in 1972 on the initiative of the Lions Clubs of France. The association currently has 114 libraries across France managed by volunteers. 
The Pays d'Aix Talking Library is run by a team of volunteers who give up their time to ensure a weekly opening on its premises, and to record new titles (potentially upon request).

label: Cloître des Cordeliers
description: The former Cloister of the Friars Minor, built circa 1550, stands on Place Frédéric Mistral. This beautiful Renaissance-style cloister belonged to the convent founded in Tarascon by this Order in 1362. The monks stayed there until the Revolution, when the convent was sold as a national asset. The town bought the building in 1861 in order to open a crèche, which would be managed by the Sisters of Notre Dame l'Auxiliaire. Their initials (N.D.A.) are engraved on a cross above the entrance door, which leads to a simple room with a wooden ceiling. It is thought that this room, lit by a small-paned window, could have been the Convent's parlour. There are three galleries which open onto an inner courtyard through wide ogival arches. In the northern gallery, it is possible to see two arches framed by rich garlands representing Provençal fruits. In the three galleries are ten keystones featuring either a crest or an ornamental motif. The capitals are more meticulously decorated, with antique designs such as ova and leaf-and-dart motifs. Today, only part of the original building can be seen, corresponding to just over half of the real surface area. It was originally square in shape and had 20 bays; only 12 can still be seen today, as the others have been deconsecrated and turned into houses.

label: Viaduc Saint Léger
comment: The viaduct, a historical monument, was built between 1843 and 1847. The cross vaults allow the crossing of the Touloubre river. It is composed of 49 arches and is 25 m high. It supports the Paris, Lyon and Marseille railway lines.
shortDescription: The viaduct, a historical monument, was built between 1843 and 1847. The cross vaults allow the crossing of the Touloubre river. It is composed of 49 arches and is 25 m high. It supports the Paris, Lyon and Marseille railway lines.

label: Calanque de Sormiou
comment: You reach the Calanque de Sormiou via the Baumettes district in Marseille via the Col de Sormiou pass and by taking a wonderful little winding road lost in the garrigue.
shortDescription: You reach the Calanque de Sormiou via the Baumettes district in Marseille via the Col de Sormiou pass and by taking a wonderful little winding road lost in the garrigue.
description:
Calanque de Sormiou
Sormiou is one of the only "Calanques" coastal fjords accessible by car. However, traffic is restricted in summer due to fire risks. You can reach the fjord by crossing the Baumettes quarter of Marseille, then Col de Sormiou mountain pass, and taking the marvellous little winding road heading through the arid garrigue.
Braver walkers can reach the site on foot via the signposted footpaths, and sailors can moor in the creek sheltered from the wind.
The views over the Mediterranean Sea from Col de Sormiou are simply breathtaking, and you can clearly make out the islands of Jaïre, Plane and Riou. Down below, the turquoise waters of the fjord are dotted with swimmers and sunbathers.
Sormiou is also one of the only inhabited "calanques". Around a hundred little cottages huddle around the little, sheltered harbour and sandy beach, where the people of Marseille love to come to revel in the fjord's quiet atmosphere and beautiful setting.

label: Sculpture d'Eugène Piron / Monuments aux morts
comment: On August 9, 1919, the Municipal Council of Salon launched a subscription for the construction of a monument to the dead and voted a sum of 10,000 francs for this purpose. The location chosen was the cliff of the St-Roch Cemetery.
shortDescription: On August 9, 1919, the Municipal Council of Salon launched a subscription for the construction of a monument to the dead and voted a sum of 10,000 francs for this purpose. The location chosen was the cliff of the St-Roch Cemetery.
description:
Eugène Piron's project was selected, and here is how the artist himself described his project: "The monument, entirely carved out of the rock, represents a breach that seems to access the vault where the dead are deposited. At the entrance of this breach, a bugle sounds the "Sublime Awakening" which brings out the image of those who sleep there. 

The bugle is the modern version of the angel sounding the Last Judgment and the Resurrection. The monument is solemnly inaugurated on November 11, 1925 and is unanimously recognized as unique in its kind. It remains unique in its monumentality, its hyper realism, but above all its humanity. Eugene Piron will unfortunately end his life three years later, on November 17, 1928. He will be buried in the St-Roch cemetery, at the foot of the work that immortalized him along with all the sons of Salon who died for France.

label: Croix en fer forgé
description:
Father Roy, a former missionary and parish priest of Verquières from 1870 to 1894, made five crosses because he was an amateur ironworker, with taste and talent. These are more or less elaborate crosses, on rather low bases, made at the end of the 19th century.
They are perfect reproductions of 12th century models from the Cluny monastic order (a monastic order that established a very ornate architectural style).
There is one on the road to Saint Louis, on the road to Les Paluds, very elaborate on a fluted column with a Latin inscription that reads: "O crux ave spes unica jubile de 1851", which means: "I greet you, o cross, our only hope of joy of 1850."
Another, on the road to Cabannes, at the intersection of the road to Mollégès: it is a very simple cross, replaced, on a square cippe. An inscription to note: "Jubilee 1865".
Another one, on the road to Mollégès, is a cross on a cylindrical base and a column with an entablature
Currently, its disappearance remains an enigma.
One, also, at La Monède: a very elaborate cross with lateral figures but it is located in a private property.
Finally, one in the cemetery (radiating cross on a central pillar) with a modest grave near it, which consists of a rudimentary stele with a wrought iron cross in black. On the stele is inscribed in a heart surmounted by a cross: "Here lies Abbé Roy, parish priest of Verquières, who died on October 25, 1894, aged 63. He was the father of the poor and the friend of the unfortunate. Pray for him."

label: Bastide du Jas de Bouffan
comment: Historical monuments, the Jas de Bouffan mansion and its park are open to you for guided tours to discover what the homestead was for the painter: a place to live, an anchor, a place for his early work and a painting studio.
shortDescription: Historical monuments, the Jas de Bouffan mansion and its park are open to you for guided tours to discover what the homestead was for the painter: a place to live, an anchor, a place for his early work and a painting studio.
description:
The Bastide is closed for refurbishment.

For lovers of Cezanne in France and around the world, as well as for the residents of Aix and Provence, the Jas de Bouffan estate, never before opened to the general public, is a fascinating attraction, a place which retains an aura of mystique despite its direct links with so many of the painter's celebrated works.

The XVIII century mansion belonged to Cezanne's family between 1859 and 1899.

At the age of 20, Paul Cezanne started out painting on the walls of the living room and outside in the park. A guided visit all around will let you see the different points of view taken by Cezanne himself while painting. As in the oval living room, a virtual recollection of his works can be seen.

label: Chapelle Saint Michel
comment: The chapel Saint Michel dates from the 13th century and is in Romanesque style. It was restored in the 19th century.
shortDescription: The chapel Saint Michel dates from the 13th century and is in Romanesque style. It was restored in the 19th century.
description: It is possible to see in Le Rove the ruins of the old fortified village of Gignac (12th/14th century) and those of the castle whose particularity is to have a square keep.

label: Fontaine Moussue
comment: The hot fountain of Cours Mirabeau, renamed the Mossy Fountain, was the first one built on the Cours in 1667. Its water is at 18°C.
shortDescription: The hot fountain of Cours Mirabeau, renamed the Mossy Fountain, was the first one built on the Cours in 1667. Its water is at 18°C.
description:
No one can be certain, today, how the fountain is decorated. Only the moss-covered rock is visible inside the basin, which used to be fed with spa water.

This unique vegetation has built up over decades, like the present symbolically hiding the past with its charm and delicacy.

Botanists are attracted by the diversity of mosses and plants which have covered the fountain, today an integral part of Cours Mirabeau.

label: Les lavoirs Ste Anne
description:
The washhouses were born in the last quarter of the 19th century, with the financial support of the French state (participation for a third of the work by the national will to stop the plagues, by encouraging all the town halls of France to improve the hygiene of the population). Water had become a public health issue.
The washhouses played this role to the full until drinking water arrived in every house.

label: Trompe-l'œil place Verdun
comment: The city of Aix-en-Provence has created a permanent trompe l'oeil in the Place de Verdun, while respecting the exceptional character of the Places Comtales district.
shortDescription: The city of Aix-en-Provence has created a permanent trompe l'oeil in the Place de Verdun, while respecting the exceptional character of the Places Comtales district.
description: This fresco, entrusted to artist Vincent Ducaroy, adorns the facade of a building beyond the fountain, at the corner of rue Marius Reynaud and gives passersby the illusion that they are seeing actual windows in an apartment block.

label: Les carrières de Baou Tailla
comment: Located at the extreme south-west of La Nerthe peninsula, the shelly limestone quarries (tender pink rock) in La Couronne are well known for having provided stone for Marseille constructions at different times.
shortDescription: Located at the extreme south-west of La Nerthe peninsula, the shelly limestone quarries (tender pink rock) in La Couronne are well known for having provided stone for Marseille constructions at different times.
description:
Baou Tailla means hewn cliff.
The activity of quarrymen marked the landscape around the village of La Couronne and Carro, the small port from where materials were sent to Marseille for constructions like the Vieille Charité and the town hall.

label: Les Carrières de Pierre de Fontvieille
comment: The exploitation of Fontvieille stone dates back to Roman times. The construction of the Tarascon castle gave it a significant boost. From then on, the quarries have been continuously exploited until today.
shortDescription: The exploitation of Fontvieille stone dates back to Roman times. The construction of the Tarascon castle gave it a significant boost. From then on, the quarries have been continuously exploited until today.
description:
Fontvieille stone was first quarried in Roman times. However, it was not until the early 15th century, with the Château de Tarascon site, that it expanded significantly. From that time, the quarries were operated continuously until modern times.
The extracted stone has a number of qualities which have made it famous far beyond the boundaries of the Alpilles; it is a fairly soft conchiferous limestone, easy to extract but very resistant to crushing. The layer of cullet which rapidly forms on its surface when it dries makes it impermeable. In 1914, the Fontvieille quarries produced 24,000 m3 of stone a year (compared with just 2,000 today); it was exported to neighbouring towns and regions such as Arles, Lyon via the Rhône, or Nice, as well as to different countries in Europe and the Mediterranean basin.
1914 sounded the death-knell for the stone industry, as the majority of the labour force was requisitioned and reinforced concrete supplanted dressed stone in the construction industry after the war. After a brief resumption of activity due to the great need for housing in the immediate post-war period, the quarries began their definitive decline, despite the efforts of the architect Fernand Pouillon, who tried to demonstrate through his 'project-challenges' that it was possible to build housing for large numbers of people using traditional materials. Only one quarry remains operational (Les Taillades quarry).
The remaining operations are open quarries and the galleries dug over several centuries are closed to the public for safety reasons. These galleries contain many testimonies to the lives of the quarriers who 'inhabited' them, particularly the drawings made in the soot with ochre and coal and the sculptures and simple graffiti.

label: Maison dite du Figaro
description: The oldest house on the Canebière, dating back to the 17th century, rebuilt in the 19th century, houses an information service of the City of Marseille.

label: Jardin Botanique E.M. Heckel
comment: The Botanical Garden covers an area of 1.2 hectares and presents approximately 3,000 different plant species from five continents, presented in nine thematic areas.
shortDescription: The Botanical Garden covers an area of 1.2 hectares and presents approximately 3,000 different plant species from five continents, presented in nine thematic areas.
description:
A little history

It was only in the 19th century that botanical gardens became public pleasure gardens, then called "Jardins des plantes". The first botanical garden of Marseille was created by King René, near the Saint-Victor abbey.

In 1802, a second garden was inaugurated in the Chartreux district, with Empress Josephine as its godmother. Thanks to its director, M. Gouffé-Lacour, it became very famous. Unfortunately, this garden, located on the axis of the Marseille-Toulon railroad, disappeared in 1856. In exchange, the director of the Lyon-Méditerranée railway company offered the city the land of Parc Borély.

In 1880, the Botanical Garden was moved to the current rose garden in Parc Borely. The Buhler brothers then imagined a true botanical garden. Dr. Heckel, who supervised the creation of the park, quickly judged it to be too small and tried to acquire the Fournier property, adjacent to the park.
In 1913, the City of Marseille bought the land to create the new botanical garden. It was inaugurated in 1918 on its current site.

Today, the Botanical Garden covers 1.2 hectares and presents about 3,000 different plant species from five continents, presented in nine thematic areas: Japanese, Chinese, Mediterranean, climbing plants, succulents, medicinal plants, vegetable garden, palmetum and South African greenhouse. A true "museum of life", the botanical garden offers a real journey of discovery, fun, sensory and unusual.

Since April 2016, this biodiversity garden has also been home to the first large insect hotel in the city of Marseille.
 
Visit the gardens:

The Chinese Garden

Inaugurated in 2004 in the respect of Chinese traditions, this garden is the result of the collaboration between Marseille and Shanghai in the framework of the twinning of the two cities.
This traditional garden aims to recreate the image of an ideal nature. It is articulated around a pavilion, a kiosk and a pond in which Koi carp are evolving.
 
The Japanese Garden

Inaugurated in 2011, to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Kobe-Marseille twinning. It is realized in the style "Chisen kai yu shiki" ("garden of walk around a pond") style very representative of Japanese gardens. This garden is meant to be a place of relaxation and serenity. It has all the elements of the traditional Japanese garden (Kare-sansui, tea pavilion, pond, rocks, water course...). Its vegetation is composed of about 20 different species of trees and more than 100 species of shrubs and perennials, all native to Japan.

It represents a place of contemplation and meditation. Every year in October, it hosts the "Autumn Festival" in collaboration with the Japanese Consulate.
 
The Garden of Medicinal Plants

Inspired by the Jardin des Simples of the Middle Ages, it presents local plants with medicinal virtues used by man or the pharmaceutical industry. They are presented by theme, according to their curative effect: digestion, skin, nervous system...

Plants of South Africa

South Africa offers the greatest plant biodiversity on the planet.
The garden shelters about 300 species from this vast country with its varied climates and reliefs, in outdoor flowerbeds and the greenhouse presents many succulent plants, typical of desert areas.
 
Climbing plants

Created in 1980, this pergola garden includes nearly 100 plant species from the five continents and adapted to our climate.
 
The Garden of succulent plants

Within a contemporary layout, this garden is mainly composed of about fifty species of agaves that can withstand the Mediterranean climate. The most frigid are grouped together in a tunnel greenhouse with other cacti of collection.
 
The Palmetum

It features about sixty species of palm trees that can adapt to our climate, from all regions of the world.
 
The Mediterranean Garden

This dry garden gathers plants from the Mediterranean basin or from other regions of the world, whose climate is comparable to that of Marseille. It is composed of an area of terraces and a rocky area with a pond and a waterfall.
 
The vegetable garden

The garden presents a selection of botanical vegetables from different parts of the world that grow in a temperate climate.

  
Practical information

In order to protect the species presented and to encourage a serene and peaceful visit, free visits are subject to registration.

New in 2022 !

Would you like to know more about the flora present and follow a tour with a guide? Would you like to register for a workshop? Registration is now done online.

Registration and calendar: https://www.marseille.fr/environnement/jardin-botanique

label: Parc de la Poudrerie Royale de Saint-Chamas et Miramas
comment: Come and discover this exceptional place: La Poudrerie Royale, a former army factory that has become a natural area!
shortDescription: Come and discover this exceptional place: La Poudrerie Royale, a former army factory that has become a natural area!
description:
To the north of the Etang de Berre, straddling the communes of Miramas and Saint-Chamas, the site of the Ancienne Poudrerie Royale de Saint-Chamas extends over 118 hectares. This black powder and then explosives factory, which operated for nearly three centuries, ceased production in 1974...
In this unoccupied place, closed to the public for about thirty years, a vegetation remarkable for its diversity has developed. As we walk along the paths of this space, which has been partially returned to the public, we discover an exceptional and wild site, although shaped by human activity.

Several animations and exhibitions are proposed to you throughout the year.

Group visits (naturalist or historical) by reservation on 04 90 58 27 93

label: Église Saint-Laurent Imbert
comment: Church of recent construction, dedicated to Monsignor Laurent Joseph Marius Imbert, born in Marignane on March 23, 1796, martyr of Korea, canonized in 1984.
shortDescription: Church of recent construction, dedicated to Monsignor Laurent Joseph Marius Imbert, born in Marignane on March 23, 1796, martyr of Korea, canonized in 1984.
description:
Attached to the parish of Marignane and Saint-Victoret, it is located in the Fontinelles district on the banks of the Bolmon pond

The Saint-Laurent Imbert church is of recent construction, inaugurated in 1995, offering the characteristics of a modern architecture. Its roof spreads its fan-shaped sides around a hexagonal bell tower where a carillon of eight bells of different sizes tinkles. A vast forecourt welcomes the faithful and visitors under a triangular canopy that invites them to enter a luminous, sober and harmoniously proportioned space. The sanctuary adjoins a cloister where the priest lives, and a path between the two allows the life of the incumbent to be told through the windows

The building is dedicated to Monsignor Laurent Joseph Marius Imbert, born in Marignane on 23 March 1796, on the Bricard farm
Bishop of Capse in Korea, he was martyred in Sai-Nam-Hte to preserve the lives of the Christians of the country
With his companions Pierre Maubant and Jacques Chastan, he gave himself up to the soldiers and all of them were put to death, beheaded with sabres
Martyred at the age of 43, he was beatified in 1925 and canonized in 1984

A delicate relief inlaid in the plaster presents a portrait of him from the forecourt
Inside, a contemporary stained glass window depicts his mission in Korea through a scene set in an Asian landscape evoked by luminous touches
In the choir, a vast panoramic painting evokes and juxtaposes the places of his distant life, including a very recognizable view of Halong Bay
In front and from behind, Saint Laurent Imbert, with his arms open, embraces the East and the West

The diocesan association of Aix, in partnership with the Missions Etrangères de Paris, published in 2013 the book by Françoise Buzelin "Marignane à Séoul, le voyage sans retour" devoted to the life of Monsignor Imbert (on sale at the Marignane Tourist Office for 22 euros)

The 180th anniversary of the martyrdom of St. Laurent Imbert was celebrated in September 2019 in Marignane and Calas in partnership with the diocese of Aix and Arles, marked by the arrival of a large delegation from Korea.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Forêt domaniale de Castillon
comment: Also known as the Massif des Etangs, the state-owned forest of Castillon is located south of the Bouches-du-Rhone, between the Etang de Berre and the Gulf of Fos, and north of the town of Port de Bouc.
shortDescription: Also known as the Massif des Etangs, the state-owned forest of Castillon is located south of the Bouches-du-Rhone, between the Etang de Berre and the Gulf of Fos, and north of the town of Port de Bouc.
description:
Also referred to as the Massif des Etangs, the Massif de Castillon is located to the South of the Bouches-du-Rhône, between Etang de Berre lake and the Gulf of Fos (Golfe de Fos). Of relatively small size (less than 10,000 acres),

The Massif de Castillon comprises a more or less continuous stretch of small, low-lying and wooded brows, with a fairly uneven relief, linking two small, North-South facing chains situated at the eastern and western ends of the massif.

This massif is located at the limit of the Bas Rhône and coastal Provence climate zones. …

Average temperatures there are warm (13 to 14 °C) and variations are tempered by maritime influences. Rainfall is low: between 500 and 700 mm/year on average, although sea mist generally causes humidity to rise. 

Despite its predominant North-South topography, this massif is located along the Rhône valley and as such is exposed to frequent, strong and sometimes violent Mistral winds.

Part of the small series of chalky, secondary ranges known as the Chaînons, the Massif de Castillon is characterized by fairly dense forestation (59 %), despite high urban pressure. … 

Its tree populations mainly comprise adult Aleppo pines (90 %) with local substages of evergreen oaks, plus dense areas of young Aleppo pines which have re-seeded further to forest fires (15 % of natural surface area) and a few areas of garrigue and heath with more-or-less stationary vegetation.

The Massif de Castillon is a genuine green lung, home to a wealth of natural and archaeological riches, set within a highly-developed and industrialised area. The proximity of Etang de Berre and presence of 4 lakes adjacent to the forest environment make it a popular place of call for avifauna (it is home to numerous Natural Zones of Ecological, Faunistic and Floristic Interest (ZNIEFF) and two Natura 2000 sites).

These natural treasures are crowned with an outstanding archaeological heritage at Domaine de Castillon, including the Saint-Blaise archaeological site and numerous remains inside the forest (ancient roads, tombs, etc.).

But the Massif de Castillon is also characterised by major peri-urban influences, with a highly-developed central area (many isolated or widely spread houses) and sophisticated communications network. 

Human activity in the forest is also of note (Valentoulin and Trappil dumps).

This strong human presence, coupled with the massif's attractiveness, has led to high demand in terms of public welcome, in particular at Domaine de Castillon (450,000 visitors/year), the Saint-Blaise archaeological site, and Parc de Figuerolles (300,000 visitors/year). 

An extremely popular "Forest Welcome Site" (ZAPEF) has now been opened at Parc de Figuerolles, forming part of the town of Martigues.

label: Maison Diamantée
comment: The Maison Diamantée may flatter itself to be the most beautiful private mansion in Marseille, but it is not rich in any precious stones.
shortDescription: The Maison Diamantée may flatter itself to be the most beautiful private mansion in Marseille, but it is not rich in any precious stones.
description:
It owes its name to the bosses, cut into points representing diamonds, which decorate its facade and was built from 1570. The interior decoration is an example of mannerism

It houses municipal services and is not open to the public.

label: Chapelle de Sainte-Croix
comment: Built in the 17th century. Just in front of it remains a ruin, that of the old chapel from the 12th century.
shortDescription: Built in the 17th century. Just in front of it remains a ruin, that of the old chapel from the 12th century.
description:
Built on the site where Saint Lazarus once planted a Cross.
The pilgrimage of Holy Cross was very famous.
In 1832, the place welcomed the Duchess of Berry.
Three brotherhoods from Martigues came barefoot to do penance on May 3 and September 14.

label: Parcours des Oratoires
description: By car, by bike or on foot for the bravest, this 20 km long route takes you to discover the 13 oratories that make up the commune of Lambesc. 3 are classified since 1912 and 1 still retains its period status to this day, the others are decorated with mosaics.
streetAddress: ['2 Rue Du Jas', 'Musée du Vieux Lambesc']

label: Les Belvédères des Bolles et de la corniche de Suffren
comment: Viewpoints offering a splendid panorama on the pond of Berre
shortDescription: Viewpoints offering a splendid panorama on the pond of Berre
description:
The Belvederes of the Bolles and the cornice of Suffren offer a magnificent view of the Etang de Berre and the surrounding hills. They include small plateaus facing the pond and parking and relaxation areas with tables and benches for picnicking.

A footpath connects the two lookouts along the pond to the Ranquet.

label: Le Platane d'Aurons
description: Majestic plane tree with a trunk of more than two metres wide. Since 1820, it has been enthroned on the pretty paved square, Louis Estienne, opposite the church.

label: Oratoire Saint-Joseph
description: This shrine stands at the corner of Route de la Bégude, opposite the cooperative. The saint's statue is hidden behind a wrought iron grille. It was restored in 1934 by the Abbot Michelier.

label: Hôtel du Poët
description:
Built by Georges Vallon in around 1725 on the site of a water mill, for Henri Gautier, originally a notary's clerk who made his fortune and became lord of Le Poët.


This mansion was ennobled by Louis XV when it became the Treasury of the Parliament of Provence. Its perfectly balanced frontage is a superb example of Provençal Baroque. 


The mansion has three storeys held strongly together by pilasters, and its arched doorways are crowned with a delightful variety of gargoyles. The balcony on the first floor is decorated with complex metalwork.

label: Plage de la Pointe Rouge
comment: The Pointe Rouge beach is sandy and extensive: it precedes the marina of the same name. It hosts a first-aid post, lockers, sanitary facilities, restaurants, refreshment stands and garbage garbage cans.
shortDescription: The Pointe Rouge beach is sandy and extensive: it precedes the marina of the same name. It hosts a first-aid post, lockers, sanitary facilities, restaurants, refreshment stands and garbage garbage cans.
description:
The sanitary facilities are accessible to people with reduced mobility. 
The surveillance team is in place in July and August.
Metro Castellane or Rond Point du Prado + bus 19.

label: Musée du Santon ( coll.privée M.Carbonel )
comment: Our santons are  made of  fired clay, they  are  stamped and decorated  by  hands. Every  figure of  clay  is unique: it is the result  of an entirely traditional production process.
shortDescription: Our santons are  made of  fired clay, they  are  stamped and decorated  by  hands. Every  figure of  clay  is unique: it is the result  of an entirely traditional production process.
description:
All of our  production comes from our workshop, in Marseille, in Provence. We  welcome  groups and individuals for  worshop and museum visits take place all year long, tuesday  and thursday at  2.30 PM. They  can  welcome a party of  30 people at  a time. This guided tour  are free and will last 45 minutes. Including  an explanation of manufacturing  steps and video  screening in the museum and ended up in our  shop.
Exhibition permanrent surface: 60
Temporary   exhibition: 0

label: Saint-Nicolas de Myre église grecque melkite
comment: Built in 1821 at the request of Christian refugees, the Church of Saint Nicholas of Myra is the oldest Eastern church in Europe and one of the first Greek Catholic churches.
shortDescription: Built in 1821 at the request of Christian refugees, the Church of Saint Nicholas of Myra is the oldest Eastern church in Europe and one of the first Greek Catholic churches.
description:
Founded by the Archbishop of Myre, Mgr Maximos Mazloum and inaugurated by the Archbishop of Aix en Provence, Mgr Fd de Beausset, this building is original by its typically oriental architecture, its decoration and especially by its bi- ritualism: since its creation, offices of Roman and Byzantine rites have been celebrated alternately. Created to welcome French and Eastern Catholics, it appears to be the best illustration of the spirit of tolerance and openness of the Melkites but also of their desire to be a bridge between East and West. Testimony to the history of the Christians of the East, this church is nonetheless one of the most fabulous vestiges of Marseille's Levantine past. The Fondation du Patrimoine is associated with the restoration of the church by mobilising the patronage of individuals and companies through the present subscription.
Curé Antoine Forget. The church is open from 3pm to 6pm from Tuesday to Saturday, mass on Sunday at 10.30am.

label: Musée Archéologique
comment: Didactic Museum of Prehistory located in the basement of Simiane Town Hall.
shortDescription: Didactic Museum of Prehistory located in the basement of Simiane Town Hall.
description:
Open the first Saturday of the month. Wednesdays workshops for children. Compulsory registration: 04.91.47.67.72. Workshops are paying. Journey through Prehistory, from the Bing Bang to writing, through the formation of the earth, the appearance of life, the evolution of mankind. Then come the great technical achievements: the tool, the mastery of fire, art. After predation, man will dominate his environment and will become a producer: agriculture, animal husbandry, metallurgy.
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 200

label: Château des Remparts
comment: The Château des Remparts is the emblematic historical site of Trets, it welcomes the public all year round on the occasion of numerous artistic exhibitions or cultural events. Dating from the 12th-13th and 16th centuries, it is well worth a visit.
shortDescription: The Château des Remparts is the emblematic historical site of Trets, it welcomes the public all year round on the occasion of numerous artistic exhibitions or cultural events. Dating from the 12th-13th and 16th centuries, it is well worth a visit.
description:
The Château des Remparts was originally a fortified castle, the beginning of its construction dates back to the end of the 12th century or the beginning of the 13th century. Initially defensive in character after its various loopholes, its machicolations and its system of ramparts, it was transformed over the centuries by the co-lords of Trets to make a beautiful seigneurial residence of pleasure and comfort.
It was notably nicely decorated in the 17th century in the Baroque style, the main elements of which can be seen in the Wedding Hall today.

Today the Château de Trets is a dynamic place, where different cultural events are organized during the season. Artistic exhibitions, school workshops, shows, theatres, concerts, conferences... animate the castle all year round. The courtyard of the castle is also used as a performance venue during the summer season with the hosting of concerts and open-air cinema.
The Trets Tourist Office also offers guided tours of this major heritage site for the town and for local history.

label: Réserve du Cap Couronne (réserve Richard Fouque)
comment: Following the evolution of the environment linked to the management and protection of the Carry-le-Rouet reserve, the representatives of professional fishermen from Martigues wished to carry out a development project for the seabed in front of Cap-Couronne. .
shortDescription: Following the evolution of the environment linked to the management and protection of the Carry-le-Rouet reserve, the representatives of professional fishermen from Martigues wished to carry out a development project for the seabed in front of Cap-Couronne. .
description:
This project took shape in 1996, with the creation of one of the largest fully protected marine areas in the Mediterranean.

This 210 ha area begins about 50 meters from the coast, between Cap-Couronne and Pointe Noire. Two spar buoys mark these two coastal ends. It stretches out to sea about 1 mile to a depth of 50 meters.
The seabed consists of corraligenous, sand, rock and Posidonia meadows. The reserve is delimited to the south by 2 light buoys. Three spar buoys are placed in an intermediate position, each on one of the east, west and north sides. The buoys are all surmounted by a Cross of Saint Andrew.

For the protection and repopulation of the marine environment, the following activities are prohibited throughout the year:
- Professional fishing,
- Underwater fishing,
- Angling,
- Scuba diving,
- Mooring of boats.
• Ministerial decree of 01/07/2014
• Decree of the Maritime Prefecture 16/12/2014

label: Ferme pédagogique Collet des Comtes
comment: Eat organic! Sale of vegetables, fruit, eggs and other jams and farm products.
shortDescription: Eat organic! Sale of vegetables, fruit, eggs and other jams and farm products.
description:
Objective: to make children aware of and responsible for their environment through the observation of plants and domestic animals

Activities: discovery of the rural world and farm work: animal care, vegetable garden, gardening

Topics covered: the adaptation of living beings to their environment, the interdependence of living beings, the milk circuit, etc

Public: large kindergarten sections, primary schools, leisure centres. Reception free of charge (transport remains the responsibility of the visitors), exclusively by appointment (registration at the end of the school year for the following year, or at the very beginning of the year at the latest). Half-day or full-day sessions, simple visit or follow-up.

label: Parc Emmanuel Vitria
comment: Children, teenagers, families, bowlers, the Emmanuel Vitria park welcomes you in the Saint-André district.
shortDescription: Children, teenagers, families, bowlers, the Emmanuel Vitria park welcomes you in the Saint-André district.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


Children, teenagers, families, bowlers, the Emmanuel Vitria park welcomes you in the Saint-André district. After the earthworks, planting and embellishment, the new park is spread over 3 large restanques on 7500m2. The upper restanque is a children's garden. Easily accessible on foot, closer to the nursery school on Rue du Boisseau and the village centre of St-André, it offers a shaded and protected play area for the youngest

Safety and the preservation of play areas reflect the desire to ensure a good cohabitation between families, young people and other users. A sports and recreational area has replaced the wasteland. Its creation offers two new entrances on the Pas de Faon Boulevard. A 365m2 mini multi-sports field allows teenagers to play basketball and football. The game is safe thanks to the 80 m. fence around the field. Below the garden, the large bowling green of St-André is very popular with the inhabitants of the district. The retaining wall, the pergola and the bleachers have been rehabilitated and made safe according to current standards

A pedestrian pathway facilitates and secures access to the school on Rue Boisseau. Ten parking spaces, including one for people with reduced mobility, have been created with protective posts and railings, under an alley shaded by large hackberry trees.

label: Parc Marcel Guelfucci
comment: This 22-hectare park is located near the town centre, the etang de Berre and the Cultural and Educational Centre! Completely pedestrianised and secure, you can explore this park by bike, scooter, on foot or roller skates... with your children.
shortDescription: This 22-hectare park is located near the town centre, the etang de Berre and the Cultural and Educational Centre! Completely pedestrianised and secure, you can explore this park by bike, scooter, on foot or roller skates... with your children.
description:
You can also have a go at one of the many sports and leisure activities in complete tranquillity: children's playground, tennis, football, skateboarding, toilets... with the free facilities provided.
A botanical trail to introduce your children to the environment and biodiversity is also provided.

label: Plage Massane
comment: Sandy beach in Saint Mitre les Remparts
shortDescription: Sandy beach in Saint Mitre les Remparts
description:
Unsupervised sandy beach. Beach of 150m x 25m.  Swimming is allowed, parking area near the beach, no charge. Bar-restaurant, rubbish bins. Disabled access. Daily control of the physical quality of the water. Bacteriological sampling twice a week.
Campsites, showers and sanitary facilities, water sports and leisure activities...
Beach cleaning and algae collection from 15th June to 15th September.
Unsupervised beach.
CD 52 "avenue de Varage"

label: Médiathèque "la Regalido"
comment: "La Regalido" media library
shortDescription: "La Regalido" media library
description:
The Media Library is...

A municipal cultural service open to all.

Its entrance is free and free of charge.

However, registration is required to borrow documents

 
How do I register?

 

    Show proof of identity and proof of residence
    Parental permission for unaccompanied minors
    Registration is renewable for one year:

 

Annual Subscription Rate 

 - Children:             FREE

 - Adults: 12 euros / year

 - Exteriors: 20 euros / year

label: Jardins de la Bastide de Romégas
comment:
The current flowerbed was designed in 1884 in front of the new bastide façade.
From 1960, new plantations, such as cedars, accompanied a vigorous restoration and the property became a main residence around 1980.
shortDescription:
The current flowerbed was designed in 1884 in front of the new bastide façade.
From 1960, new plantations, such as cedars, accompanied a vigorous restoration and the property became a main residence around 1980.
description:
The archetype of an Aix house of the mid-17th century: plain frontage, hipped roof, tile overhang, adjoining farm, threshing floor. 18th-century French gardens with traditional boxwood border, shaded by ancient pine trees, leading to a hunting hedgerow typical of the period. 

In addition, a chapel, ponds, wash-house, fountain, viburnum maze. View of Sainte Victoire mountain. All beautifully preserved and maintained. House built in 1660 by the Romégas family, members of the Aix nobility. 


Purchased in the 18th century by the ancestors of the present owners, who include the historian, academician and ambassador François Mignet. 

The gardens are open to visitors between 1 May and 31 october by appointment.

label: Cinémathèque Gnidzaz Martigues
comment: Martigues was already a chosen spot for film-makers in the 1910s. In 2007, Prosper Gnidzaz, a passionate cinema collector offered his collection to the city of 2,250 reels and 79 projectors, the oldest of which dates back to 1880.
shortDescription: Martigues was already a chosen spot for film-makers in the 1910s. In 2007, Prosper Gnidzaz, a passionate cinema collector offered his collection to the city of 2,250 reels and 79 projectors, the oldest of which dates back to 1880.
description:
The City decided to create an exhibition space dedicated to the cinema in his name.
The Espace Cinéma Prosper Gnidzaz was inaugurated in May 2011 in a renovated 17th-century chapel . In the 260 m2 area, visitors can discover the evolution of filming techniques from the first animated images to 3D. In 2013, it became the Cinémathèque Gnidzaz.
All sessions are public, free and non-commercial.

Film is the star of the show with projections and educational events in the 30-seat cinema. 
Surrounded by the collection of about 20 projectors, the museum proposes the following tour:
- Room 1: The invention of cinema
A timeline presenting reproductions of the thaumatrope, the zootrope, and cinematographic and other magical lanterns until the creation of 3D. 

- Room 2: A tribute to the collector
Prosper Gnidzaz, a trained pastry chef and lively character, presents his passion for cinema in the privacy of his lounge. 

- Room 3: Martigues and film
Numerous extracts from fictional films and archives about modern and traditional Martigues.

Activities: 
- Running projections: a series of cycles about film history and heritage.
Extracts of films made in Martigues including: Toni by Jean Renoir, La cuisine au beurre by Gille Grangier, Dieu vomit les tièdes by Robert Guédiguian, Marche et rêve, les homards de l'Utopie by Paul Carpita.
-An amusing tour with an interactive treasure hunt + projection 
-Discovery guided tour + projection
- Workshop.

label: Théâtre de verdure de Brise-Lames
comment: Emblematic place in the heart of the historic center, the Green Theatre is dedicated to the promenade, it is the new place of reception of the demonstrations of the city of Martigues.
shortDescription: Emblematic place in the heart of the historic center, the Green Theatre is dedicated to the promenade, it is the new place of reception of the demonstrations of the city of Martigues.
description:
Green lung in the heart of the city center, it completes, next to the beach of Ferrières, the development of the trail of the pond of Berre.This wooded garden, with an area of about 10 000 square meters of which 1 300 square meters of landscaped bleachers can accommodate 300 people seated and its configuration allows a attendance of about a thousand people.

A vegetal palette composes the garden, offering a new quality place with a view of the entire pond.More than 70 trees of high stems (2 to 5 m high) surround the theatre of greenery: pine umbrella, ash, poplar but also Grevillea, eucalyptus, camphor. 27 different types of Mediterranean and exotic species compose a varied and harmonious ensemble.

This landscaping is a vegetable filter, at the back of the bleachers to house the Mistral and shade in summer.The seating of the bleachers planned for the reception of the public has the appearance of wood and will be made of composite material from recycled plastic materials. 

The essences and type of grass installed at the level of the bleachers are chosen for their resistance to the climate. The drip irrigation system for trees and sprinkling on grassed areas is both efficient and economical.

label: Eglise Saint-Pierre
comment: Church of Rognonas.
shortDescription: Church of Rognonas.
description:
Built on the site of a chapel erected by Pope Adrian IV (1154-1159) and dedicated to St. Peter and his followers. Built and first enlargements in the 16th and 17th centuries, the present building was remodelled in 1758 and enlarged in 1832 and 1894. The present bell tower dates from 1932 when it replaced the 1843 one built on poor foundations.
The church is characterized by the presence of four side chapels, one of which was used for a reconstruction of the cave of Lourdes.
Several paintings and sculptures decorate the interior.

label: Eglise Sainte-Agathe des Camoins
comment: The church of Sainte-Agathe is part of the parish of Notre-Dame de la Salette.
shortDescription: The church of Sainte-Agathe is part of the parish of Notre-Dame de la Salette.
description: Agatha is the patron saint of the Camoins. She lived in Sicily in the third century.

label: Ludothèque Françoise Dolto
description: In a nice space dedicated to games, it welcomes children and parents. Various games are offered.
streetAddress: ['26 Avenue Ravel Timothée', 'Cité de la Jeunesse']

label: Temple
comment: The Temple (XIXth c) is part of the 10 stages of the "Chemin des Temples du Luberon".
shortDescription: The Temple (XIXth c) is part of the 10 stages of the "Chemin des Temples du Luberon".
description: He signed La Roque's membership of the Vaudoise and Reformed community of the Luberon. Of very sober construction, it is the second temple of the commune: we do not know where the bases of the first one are, which was the first reformed building in the valley after the tragic events of 1545. During the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes, 90 families emigrated, among them several left to build South Africa (Valley of the French).

label: Cloître des Oblats
comment: The cloister is only open by appointment
shortDescription: The cloister is only open by appointment
description:
Inside the Oblates' Chapel, the former Carmelite monastery chapel. 

The plans and decoration are by Thomas Veyrier, nephew of Christophe Veyrier, himself the nephew and pupil of Puget.

The cloister is only open by appointment.

label: Prieuré Saint Peyre d'Entremonts
comment: The first known mention of the existence of the priory of Saint-Peyre d'Entremonts dates back to 1213. However, its construction certainly predates this.
shortDescription: The first known mention of the existence of the priory of Saint-Peyre d'Entremonts dates back to 1213. However, its construction certainly predates this.
description:
The first known mention of the existence of Saint Peyre d'Entremonts Priory dates back to 1213. However, it was constructed before this date.
The remains of the buildings are currently being restored; the 'Apier ou le Mur a des Oreilles' Association is organising volunteers to work on the site. The first job was to clear the site of the vegetation and scree that had invaded it and made it inaccessible, then the walls will gradually be rebuilt.

label: L'Alouette
comment: Memorial formed by a helicopter in a metal frame
shortDescription: Memorial formed by a helicopter in a metal frame
description:
At the Raumettes traffic circle, in Marignane, there is an amazing memorial made of a helicopter in a metal frame

Installed there since December 1993, first in a white-khaki livery, restored and renovated in blue by the Eurocopter Helicopter Maintenance and Repair Department in 2011, it bears witness in its own way to the success of a model whose production exceeded thirteen thousand units!

Identifiable with its large glass cabin, its three blades and skids, it is indeed an Alouette II, the first industrialized mechanical turbine helicopter in the world!

First manufactured in Ile-de-France, then in Provence, this light and utilitarian aircraft, which broke several world altitude records, rolled off the Marignane production line in 1961, soon at a rate of 16 units per month. The machine perched in the middle of the D. 9, with no visible serial number, is in fact composed of various elements recovered in the workshops: a beautiful tribute is thus paid to a legendary flying machine and to the former employees of the Sncase who built it for years.

Source: Patrick Boulanger May 2022

label: Square Emile Arnaud (1896 - 1987)
description: 3000m² for a space of relaxation and leisure with children's playground, benches, water and green spaces.

label: Fort d'Entrecasteaux et fort Saint Nicolas
comment: As early as 1660, the Chevalier de Clerville built Fort Saint-Nicolas on the orders of Louis XIV, who wanted to hold Marseille in respect in case of rebellion.
shortDescription: As early as 1660, the Chevalier de Clerville built Fort Saint-Nicolas on the orders of Louis XIV, who wanted to hold Marseille in respect in case of rebellion.
description:
Previously, at this location was a tower used to manoeuvre the chain that closed the entrance to the harbour. Taken away as a trophy after the sacking of the Aragonese, this chain is now in the cathedral of Valencia, Spain. During the Second Empire, during the construction of the Imperial Residence (the Pharo), the fort was cut in two to create an access road, thus destroying the symbol of royal authority: on the sea side, the fort of Saint Nicholas, which houses the military garrison and its officers' mess, and on the land side, the fort of Entrecasteaux.

The fort occupies a limestone spur between the port, Saint-Victor Abbey and the Pharo. For a while, the construction enclosed the Saint-Nicolas chapel, built in the Middle Ages, then it was destroyed. The fort is composed of two tiered units, the lower one, serving as a low courtyard on the port is isolated since 1862 by the breakthrough of the boulevard (now Charles Livon). The high fort consists of two interlocking enclosures whose quadrangular plan clings to the escarpment. The quality of the masonry, a large device of pink limestone from the Crown, and the way it is built (bossed corner links and cord creating arabesques of counter-curves on the slopes) contribute to creating an impression of serene power, characteristic of the style of the Chevalier de Clerville.
The fort was classified as a Historic Monument in 1969.

label: Parc ornithologique du Pont de Gau
comment: The Park is a concentrate of Camargue. In the heart of the marshes, footpaths and observatories offer a rare proximity with the wildlife. All year round, it is the ideal site to discover, observe and photograph numerous species of birds.
shortDescription: The Park is a concentrate of Camargue. In the heart of the marshes, footpaths and observatories offer a rare proximity with the wildlife. All year round, it is the ideal site to discover, observe and photograph numerous species of birds.
description: The park combines the enjoyment of walking with the discovery of most Camargue birds or transiting species. It manages its natural areas for environment conservation, nature protection and improvement of public awareness. Since 1974, it operates a wildlife clinic. Information panels, identification cards, migration cards and more bring everyone, beginners or experts, very clear information on bird life, the hosts of the Camargue. Over one hectare, large aviaries are the species the most difficult to observe in the wild, each in its biotope faithfully recreated. Several miles of trails between marshlands and reeds let visitors approach the birds and hold any surprises for the attentive observer. In the Gines marshland, in which a herd of bulls graze in summer, an observatory allows you to see without being seen, thus respecting the privacy of fauna. The park's surface area is 60 hectares.

label: ITER
comment: ITER: a world-class scientific project in the field of energy production.
shortDescription: ITER: a world-class scientific project in the field of energy production.
description:
Fusion is the nuclear reaction that powers the Sun and stars. It is potentially an almost inexhaustible source of energy that is safe and has little impact on the environment. ITER aims to harness this energy: the programme is an essential step between the research facilities that preceded it and the fusion power plants that will follow.

If you would like to visit the site, please see the ITER site tour details. If not, come to the next open days.

label: Tour de l'Ecorchoir
description:
Date: 1372
Era: Middle Ages
Type: Fortified architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1927
Built during the decline in security which followed the mediaeval boom, Ecorchoir Tower experienced some four centuries of threats and sporadic assaults.
To the south-west, it borders the Vieux-Bourg (now the La Roquette district) and remains one of the last vestiges of the mediaeval rampart on the banks of the Rhône.
After having a succession of different names, the one used today is not related to its military history, but to its more recent use as the town abattoirs.
The tower, isolated from the now disappeared rampart, and recently restored, still bears witness to a time when the river was also used during military manoeuvres.
Built of stone near the Rhône, and still partly crenellated, the Ecorchoir Tower is 16 metres high.
It has an internal staircase which led to the rampart wall walk
It could contain several dozen soldiers. As an artillery platform and a watchtower, it played a role in a number of battles until the 18th century.
In 1758, at the request of the boatmen, a derrick (a kind of post for carrying signals) was installed to signal the arrival of the boats and barges.
The building thus reconnected with its original vocation of river surveillance.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
description: In the centre of the village, next to the town hall, the library has a free lending service for the people of the village and organizes every Wednesday afternoon the hour of the tale for the youngest and one Friday by me the reading club takes place there. It takes part in the events like the festival of the book, the contest of Christmas tales and drawings. It is attended by the children of the schools which benefit from particular slots. It has a free Internet consultation point.

label: Eglise Sainte-Marie-Magdeleine Les Chartreux
comment: The Chartreux Church is also known as Sainte-Marie Magdeleine. Designed by D. Berger, it was built from 1680 on a basilical plan of a three naves church.
shortDescription: The Chartreux Church is also known as Sainte-Marie Magdeleine. Designed by D. Berger, it was built from 1680 on a basilical plan of a three naves church.
description:
The façade is composed of ionic and Corinthian orders, and a peristyle decorated with three columns. To see: the oak door with Magdeleine and Saint Bruno, the statues of Botinelly, the pulpit, a painting by Serre, the high altar, the crib during Christmas time. 
The organ case of local manufacture and the instrumental part of Mutin date from 1912. The instrumental part is a design by Messener. In 1985, the Provençal organ factory carried out a restoration.
Parish priest : P. Raphael Vincent
Masses : Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday at 6:30 pm
On Sunday, at 10:30am and 6:30pm

label: Parc Valmer
comment: At the bend in the Corniche, a promontory overlooking the harbour of Marseille and its islands is home to the Villa Valmer and its luxuriant 1.6 hectare park.
shortDescription: At the bend in the Corniche, a promontory overlooking the harbour of Marseille and its islands is home to the Villa Valmer and its luxuriant 1.6 hectare park.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


At the bend in the Corniche (after the Fausse-Monnaie bridge), a promontory overlooking the harbour of Marseille and its islands is home to the Villa Valmer and its luxuriant park. Its proportions and architecture make this villa look more like a small castle. It was built at the end of the last century by a rich merchant from Salone, Charles Gonnelle. The villa originally bore the name "Vague à la mer" which was later changed to Valmer. The driveway, which winds towards one of the most beautiful viewpoints of the town, winds its way through exotic vegetation (palms: trachicarpus fortuneï excelsa, chamaerops humilis, washingtonias filifera, phoenix canariensis, buttias capitatia) and endemic trees of a rare beauty. Among these species are native trees (olive trees, Aleppo pines, holm oaks, pistachio trees, mastic trees, arbutus trees) and cascading perennials: dimorphotecas, lantanas agathaea, carpobrutus, lavender, arctotis. In the style of the 19th century rock gardeners, a rock garden follows the slope of the slopes. Fake stone, fake rocks with strange round shapes are sculpted in the cement and softened by harmonious compositions of perennial plants.

label: Plage de la Romaniquette
comment: The large beach of La Romaniquette (7,300 m2), located to the east of the town, close to the historic centre, by the quality of its site, the panorama it offers over the Etang de Berre and its easy access, is the paradisiacal place of the summer.
shortDescription: The large beach of La Romaniquette (7,300 m2), located to the east of the town, close to the historic centre, by the quality of its site, the panorama it offers over the Etang de Berre and its easy access, is the paradisiacal place of the summer.
description: The beach of Romaniquette (7,300 m2), located east of the city, near the historic centre, by the quality of its website, the panorama it offers on the etang de Berre and its easy access, is the beach become Istres. Its design enables a space equipped to host many holidaymakers and a diversified entertainment offer. Facilities - expansion of the beach - construction of a new access to the beach, securing the crossroads and strengthening of implementing traffic light signaling - Creation of parking of 50 parking spaces - Installation of an educational trail through the Reed bed for valuing wetlands - Creation of a picnic and playground area : bocce and Beach Volleyball - implementation of floating platforms anchored to 2.5 m deep for bathers - accessibility and parking for persons with disabilities - completion of a relief and self-contained sanitary opening to the public (supervised swimming) post from June to September a library is accessible on the Romaniquette beach. Boaters may have books for free, from a choice of 350 books. Novels, comics, publications, magazines, destined for 7 to 77 years old, were donated to the city of Istres by the lending library to 'feed' this beach library. Two agents, made available by the Office of tourism of Istres, are present from 11 h to 18 h (7 days) in July and August, in order to manage the library and help readers in their choice.
streetAddress: ['Corniche de Suffren - Plage de la Romaniquette']

label: Plage de Carro
comment: Sandy beach with a water access ramp for people with reduced mobility. Carro is a charming little fishing port still in operation near Martigues.
shortDescription: Sandy beach with a water access ramp for people with reduced mobility. Carro is a charming little fishing port still in operation near Martigues.
description:
Its fish market attracts people from throughout the region and is a real treat for the eyes and the taste buds! 

Situated just a stone's throw from the port, "Plage de Carro" is a fairly small shingle beach, just big enough to accommodate the families and surfers who come here to tackle the waves when the wind is blowing. Like much of the Côte Bleue coast, this is also an excellent diving spot: Carro is particularly renowned for the Baou Tailla quarry lying just under its waves, which experienced divers can explore by passing through a heart-stopping siphon. 

The stones from the quarry now offer a perfect habitat for local fauna and it is not uncommon to come across an octopus, lobster or dalmatian discodoris – a charming little mollusc covered with brown spots, reminiscent of a dalmatian's coat.

The beach is supervised every day:
- From 20 June to 1 July 2022 from 11am to 7pm.
- From 2 July to 28 August 2022 from 10am to 7pm.
Access for blind guide dogs only.

label: La Mourgue
comment: Roughly carved stone, probably representing a pre-Roman pagan fertility deity.
shortDescription: Roughly carved stone, probably representing a pre-Roman pagan fertility deity.
description:
The Mourgue is a coarsely carved stone and probably represents a pre-Roman pagan deity of fertility
The term would come from the novel "Morga", which became "Mourgue" in Provençal and "Moniale" in French. It has inspired many poets (Louis Renard, Frédédic Mistral, ...) and local historians.

label: Fontaine des Thermes
comment: Within the spa and the location of the Celto-Ligurians and Romans remains, is the fountain of Spa Sextius originating from the source of Queen Jeanne.
shortDescription: Within the spa and the location of the Celto-Ligurians and Romans remains, is the fountain of Spa Sextius originating from the source of Queen Jeanne.
description: It offers a chemically stable hydrotherapy water with healing properties.

label: Parc du Moulin Peyre
comment: Enjoy the park of the Moulin Peyre, the old oil mill in Mouriès.
shortDescription: Enjoy the park of the Moulin Peyre, the old oil mill in Mouriès.
description: Old oil mill

label: Croix des missionnaires de Provence
comment: Like many municipalities in the department, Marignane has kept track of the missions initiated by Eugene de Mazenod at the very beginning of the Restoration.
shortDescription: Like many municipalities in the department, Marignane has kept track of the missions initiated by Eugene de Mazenod at the very beginning of the Restoration.
description:
Like many municipalities in the department, Marignane has kept track of the missions initiated by Eugene de Mazenod at the very beginning of the Restoration

Born into a family of Provençal nobility exiled to Nice during the Revolution, he entered the orders, first in Paris, notably at Saint-Sulpice, before returning to Provence in 1813, after the Concordat. Settled in Aix, before his late appointment in 1837 as head of the bishopric of Marseille, he conceived an apostolate turned towards a re-evangelization of the rural, poor, and young populations, relying on the Provençal language. Joined by a few vicars, he created the work of the Missionaries of Provence, gathering nine founding members. It was renamed the Oblates of Mary Immaculate in 1826, following a foundation in Nîmes in Languedoc

Their first mission took place in Grans on February 24, 1816, followed by the one in Marignane. This mission covered the period from November 17 to December 15, 1816, and is recounted in detail in the Journal de Mazenod published only in 1995 by the Oblates

It was carried out by four of Mazenod's companions, Fathers Deblieu, Mie, Maunier and Tempier, who were welcomed by the parishioners in the chapel of Saint-Nicolas. They made many visits to Marignane and met a population that was largely described as dechristianized, with several anecdotes focusing on situations of cohabitation, separation, or disabilities left to their own devices. Preaching, sermons from the pulpit and conferences in the church, confessions, women's assembly in the chapel of the penitents, will thus follow one another. On November 24, 1816, a spectacular procession, barefoot and with a rope around the neck, took up the tradition of the penitents, whose large cross the missionaries borrowed

It is quite natural that the commemoration of this mission will be marked by the planting of a cross, first and apparently, on the old mall known as Cours Saint-Nicolas (current avenue Jean-Jaurès) near the chapel of the penitents. It appears on the Napoleonic cadastre of 1818 and is cited in the Statistique du préfet de Villeneuve in 1824 (without ever being identified as the one of the 1816 mission). During the Restoration, it would have marked this end of the tree-lined promenade on which the parish church would finally open in 1826. A whole part of its history has disappeared with the archives of this period. It seems that a replacement for the original cross, perhaps made of wood, is dated by the 1846 date on the cartel stamped on the one we see today. It is very likely that the penitents, reconstituted in 1843, were the instigators. Wooden cross (?)... Iron cross, this one comes from a delicately serrated iron work, surmounting a truncated pyramidal pedestal of fine limestone animated by some dentils

The set was the object of a first displacement in Guynemer street, before finding, in 2021, its supposed original place, thanks to the association of the Friends of Marignane and Provence, in partnership with the City of Marignane

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Oratoire Saint Gens
description: The oratory Saint Gens is located in a vineyard on the right when you arrive in Eyguières by Orgon (Private Property). Saint Gens was a young ploughman from Monteux, at the beginning of the 11th century he retired to the Bausset gorge near Vaucluse to live there as a hermit. Tradition tells us that he made 2 springs spring up by planting 2 fingers in a rock, one of water and one of wine.

label: Chapelle Saint Bonnet (Domaine de Lagoy)
description:
This estate has been occupied since the Gallo-Roman period, first by a villa, then a castrum around the 12th century chapel.
The 17th century saw the construction of the dovecote and a house surmounted by a crenellated tower. In 1705, an oil mill was built near the dovecote. In 1713, the current building was constructed using stones from the ruins near the church The château was destroyed in the Revolution. The Marquis restored the estate in 1806.

label: Culture et Bibliothèques pour tous - CBPT 13
comment: The association is a member of the National Union of Culture and Library for All, which includes 85 departmental associations.
shortDescription: The association is a member of the National Union of Culture and Library for All, which includes 85 departmental associations.
description:
Different locations: 

➜ Aix-Centre (regional centre)
Tuesday 2pm to 5pm, Thursday 10am to 12pm and Saturday 10am to 12pm.

➜ Les Milles: 29 rue E. Chaudon, 13290 Les Milles, cbpt.lesmilles@gmail.com
Monday 10am to 12pm, Tuesday and Thursday 4.30pm to 6.30pm, Wednesday 3.30pm to 5.30pm and Saturday 10am-12pm.

label: Musée Frédéric Mistral
comment:
Frédéric Mistral Museum invites you to discover the intimacy of the famous Provencal poet.
The museum has been awarded the Maison des Illustres and Maison des écrivains labels.
shortDescription:
Frédéric Mistral Museum invites you to discover the intimacy of the famous Provencal poet.
The museum has been awarded the Maison des Illustres and Maison des écrivains labels.
description:
The poet Frédéric Mistral (1830-1914) lived in Maillane, where he composed all his work; in 1904 he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. He was also the founder of the Félibrige association.
