The house where he lived from 1876 until his death on 25 March 1914 has retained the authentic look of Mistral's time, thanks to restoration work carried out from 1992 to 1995 by the Historic Monuments service. The house became a museum in 1944, following the death of Mme Mistral in 1943. Visitors can discover all the souvenirs and works of art which were given to the poet throughout his life (objects, books, photos, etc.) and which help to conserve the atmosphere that Mistral created in his home, which was given to the commune under a will in 1907. The building was listed as a Historic Monument on 10 November 1930.
It is a charming bourgeois residence in the form of a two-storey Aix batide, with a string course separating the two levels. The windows have grip frames and above the ground floor windows are sculpted figures of Mireille and Esterelle (the heroines of Mistral's works, Mireille and Calendal), and of the stars of the Félibrige association. The house has a large sculpted fronton composed of symbols of regional culture, such as fruit, vegetables, the three-pronged fork of the guardians and an anchor. The initials VM (Vincent and Mireille) and EC (Esterelle and Calendal) can be seen, as well as the poet's motto, 'The sun makes me sing'.
No independent visits. Guided, commented visits.

label: Château du Castellan
description: It has two floors and a tower. It was a secondary residence of the Marquis of Villargelle. At present, it is a bed and breakfast type of accommodation.

label: Chapelle Sainte Croix
comment: Magnificent building of pure Romanesque style, classified as a historical monument in 1921.
shortDescription: Magnificent building of pure Romanesque style, classified as a historical monument in 1921.
description: Built between year 989 and 1000 a.d., this place of worship is part of the oldest monuments in Romanesque style can be found in the region. The monks of the Abbey of Saint-Victor de Marseille would have built it to serve their offices.

label: Calanque des Eaux salées
comment: Pebble beach located under a railway viaduct dating from 1914 and the subject of a real architectural feat
shortDescription: Pebble beach located under a railway viaduct dating from 1914 and the subject of a real architectural feat
description: This small cove is only accessible on foot (or by boat) from the beach of Rouet. It is necessary to take the GR51, also called the "sentier des douaniers", for about twenty minutes to get there.

label: Chapelle Saint Germain
comment:
The Chapel of Saint Germain, next to Venel, is built on the road that came from Marseille through the oak and pine woods of Aleppo.
It was built 2 km from the feudal castle of Venel.
shortDescription:
The Chapel of Saint Germain, next to Venel, is built on the road that came from Marseille through the oak and pine woods of Aleppo.
It was built 2 km from the feudal castle of Venel.
description:
The semi-circular porch opens through a thick, old wooden door assembled with hand-forged nails. The two-sloped roof was surmounted by a stone cross on the façade, which is decorated with a niche and an oculus.
The arcaded bell tower is important. Two buttresses on the right and another on the left, support the rough stone side walls which draw inside 3 large round arches.
The Romanesque vault is also of stone, only the triumphal arch is of rough-cut stone. A stone bench runs at the base of the walls.

The chapel is open to the public every last Saturday of the month. An annual mass is held on the first Sunday of September on the feast of Saint Germain

label: Bibliothèque Marie Rose Poggio
description: Loan conditions (adult section / children's section): 5 documents (books or periodicals) + 1 CD + 1 DVD = 3 weeks (1 week for "new" novels)

label: Plage de Bottai
comment:
Bottaï beach on the seaside of the town of Port-de-Bouc with a family atmosphere.
Labeled Blue Flag
shortDescription:
Bottaï beach on the seaside of the town of Port-de-Bouc with a family atmosphere.
Labeled Blue Flag
description:
Plage de Bottai
"Plage de Bottaï" is one of the six beaches bordering the village of Port-de-Bouc. Boasting a fun, warm and family-style atmosphere, the beach also operates an environmentally friendly policy and the town council, backed by the locals, pays particular attention to keeping the coast clean and well-kept in both winter and summer. Along with its neighbours – "Plage des Combattants" and "Plage des Ours" -, "Bottaï" also offers facilities and equipment for the disabled and benefits from the "Tourism & Handicap" label.

label: Village d'Aureille
description: This is an old fortified village perched on a foothill of the Alpilles. The peaks and rare vegetation make the access road to the village extremely attractive. The village is overlooked by the 12th century ruin of Le Castellas.

label: Mosquée Islah islamnique dite du marché aux puces
comment: The mosque is managed by the association islamque Islah Marseille. It is adjacent to the flea market.
shortDescription: The mosque is managed by the association islamque Islah Marseille. It is adjacent to the flea market.
streetAddress: ['130 Chemin De la Madrague Ville', 'Marché aux Puces']

label: Eglise St Blaise
description:
The Monks' Chapel of Saint Césaire Abbey, founded in the 6th century by the Bishop of the same name, Saint Blaise Church is of interest to historians and archaeologists alike.
It was mainly built in three stages, starting in the 12th century, but earlier remains have been found.
It was deconsecrated during the Revolution and had a range of different utilitarian uses, before being excavated in 1972 and 1982.
Today, it is recognised as a heritage site of considerable interest, which may be further developed as part of the project involving the Saint Césaire enclosure, which is currently being examined.
The current building still has traces of its various extensions and developments.
The oldest part has a non-salient transept with two semi-domed vaulted absidioles.
The cross reveals a cloister vault.
A short semi-circular vaulted bay in the nave, separated from the chancel by two large cruciform pillars, is supported by very small side-aisles.
The second part, of a simpler architectural style, sees the disappearance of the two narrow side-aisles.
Finally, the third part, which is slightly narrower, has acoustic vases at the start of the vault which reduced the echo from the nave.
The only item of furniture to survive is a main altar made of painted gilded wood, which is currently in Notre-Dame-de-la-Major Church.

label: Église Saint Pierre
description: St Peter's Church will survive the events of the 14th and 18th centuries. It was rebuilt in 1715, lengthened by a third in 1858 and the bell tower was erected in 1868. The Parish was created in 1665 by dismembering that of Tarascon. The church has in the choir magnificent statues of the Virgin and Child and of Saint Roch. A Chapel of the Blessed Virgin and a Chapel of Saint Peter are decorated with beautiful statues.

label: Prud'homie de Pêche
comment: It was built in 1930 and has since served as the headquarters for the Martigues maritime labour relations court, created in the 15th century.
shortDescription: It was built in 1930 and has since served as the headquarters for the Martigues maritime labour relations court, created in the 15th century.
description: The beautiful neoclassical façade is decorated with a curious carefully made high-relief. It is designed like a Versailles trophy with the subtle style of 17th-century sculptures, except that fishing equipment and produce replace war symbols.

label: La Ferme du Tadorne
comment: Guided tour of the farm and its marshland. Discovery of the fauna and flora around the marsh.
shortDescription: Guided tour of the farm and its marshland. Discovery of the fauna and flora around the marsh.

label: Cimetiere des juifs
comment: The cemetery has occupied this site since at least the early 15th century. The surrounding wall and gate were built in 1847.
shortDescription: The cemetery has occupied this site since at least the early 15th century. The surrounding wall and gate were built in 1847.
description:
The cemetery has been on this site since at least the early 15th century. The enclosure wall and the portal were built in 1847.
The sixty remaining tombs date back to the 15th and 19th centuries. They are raised and flat and are organised in rows along the walls. A few monumental tombs stand amidst the trees. The first mention of the cemetery was in the early years of the 15th century, when a relatively large Jewish community lived in Saint-Rémy, as testified by the synagogue and the Rue de Juiverie in the town centre. Louis XII expelled the Jews from Provence a century later, in 1500, and the cemetery was abandoned. It was given a new lease of life when the Jews returned during the Revolution. The last burial took place in 1910 and its is now unused.

label: Cosquer Méditerranée
comment: In June 2022, Kléber Rossillon opened a restitution of the cave in the Villa Méditerranée, property of the Southern Region, on the esplanade of the J4 in Marseille, a few meters from the Mucem.
shortDescription: In June 2022, Kléber Rossillon opened a restitution of the cave in the Villa Méditerranée, property of the Southern Region, on the esplanade of the J4 in Marseille, a few meters from the Mucem.
description:
A restitution of the Cosquer cave, masterpiece of cave art, visitable in exploration modules (small autonomous vehicles)

An interpretation trail on prehistory, the relationship between man and the sea during the Paleolithic period and the theme of the rising waters, of which the Cosquer cave is a unique witness

A scenography evoking diving

A film on the history of the discovery in the Jean Courtin amphitheater

label: Grand Parc de Figuerolles - Paul Lombard
comment: The Grand Parc de Figuerolles - Paul Lombard is a wooded estate on the northern outskirts of the city on the shores of Europe's largest lagoon: Etang de Berre.
shortDescription: The Grand Parc de Figuerolles - Paul Lombard is a wooded estate on the northern outskirts of the city on the shores of Europe's largest lagoon: Etang de Berre.
description:
With 130 hectares of pine forests, dry-stone walls and scrubland, the park is a fabulous green lung ideal for family activities, sports and walking. 
The park offers a range of outdoor activities with an educational farm, pony rides, treetop adventure park and mountain bike area. Nature lovers enjoy the walking trails for discovering magnificent viewpoints over the lagoon.

label: Jardin Salvador Dali
comment: A place of rest and relaxation in a very pleasant green setting in the heart of the city, with a bandstand; evocations of the works of Dali, originally from the Catalan city of Figueras, twinned with Marignane.
shortDescription: A place of rest and relaxation in a very pleasant green setting in the heart of the city, with a bandstand; evocations of the works of Dali, originally from the Catalan city of Figueras, twinned with Marignane.
description:
Now open to the public, it is a survival of two former private gardens: that of the castle and then of the Villa Camoin, now the Caisse d'Epargne

Of the first, known as the "grand garden" of the lord and attested since 1450, we still have precious inventories from 1540 (vegetable plants, including a preeminence of lettuce, hemp and cougourds), and from 1693 (quince trees, laurels, boxwoods, myrtles, asparagus and strawberries), before it became the grand park of the château, redesigned in the French style in the 18th century, made up of flowerbeds, embellished with pavilions, ponds and statues

From the villa of the notable Philippe Camoin, the garden has retained the original appearance of a 19th century bourgeois property, characterized by its winding paths linking groves

Inaugurated in 2011, it was named after the surrealist painter from the Catalan town of Figueras, which is twinned with Marignane. Evocations of his works are scattered throughout the landscaped park

The Salvador Dali garden has recently been enlarged and completely renovated in 2019 and 2020. It now covers an area of 3150 m², decorated with a bandstand in connection with the nearby conservatory. This green setting located in the city centre favours Mediterranean plant species cohabiting with beds of annual and melliferous flowers, and an insect pollinator hotel.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Eglise Saint Blaise
comment: Church of Saint-Blaise de Ceyreste
shortDescription: Church of Saint-Blaise de Ceyreste
description: The church and the Roman fountain quarter are listed in the inventory of historical monuments.

label: Carrières de Lumières
comment: In the heart of the Alpilles in the village of Les Baux-de-Provence, the monumental Carrières de Lumières, 14 metres high, host multimedia shows that are unique in the world.
shortDescription: In the heart of the Alpilles in the village of Les Baux-de-Provence, the monumental Carrières de Lumières, 14 metres high, host multimedia shows that are unique in the world.
description:
Each year a great new show is proposed presenting the greatest names in the History of Art. These shows are projected onto the immense 14-meter high walls, pillars and floors of the quarry and transport you in music into the colored worlds. A new lighting of the Quarries will help you discover the unique and unusual character of the place and reveal its mineral beauty.

Multimedia equipment unique in France: The Carrières de Lumières benefit from state-of-the-art equipment and processes

label: Chapelle Saint-Bonnet
comment: Above the entrance is a magnificent small Roman tympanum representing Temptation.
shortDescription: Above the entrance is a magnificent small Roman tympanum representing Temptation.
description: This was originally known as the Chapelle des Pucelles or the Chapelle des Vierges. This chapel has, of course, paid the traditional homage to time and undergone a series of transformations which have made it even more interesting. Don't miss the relatively rudimentary bas-relief tympanum representing the theme of Adam and Eve, the serpent and the tree of life. Remarkably, the tree of life is represented by a fig tree.

label: Ombrière du Vieux Port
comment: For 26 centuries, the Old Port has been the prestigious theater where the history of Marseille is played out.
shortDescription: For 26 centuries, the Old Port has been the prestigious theater where the history of Marseille is played out.
description:
During Antiquity and the Middle Ages, the Greek city (Massalia), then the Roman city (Massilia) and the medieval city (Masiho) developed on the north shore and then towards the south in the 17th century. From then on, the entrance to the port was guarded by two forts, Fort Saint-Nicolas and Fort Saint-Jean.

In 2013, the Old Port was renovated: easier access to the port, reduced traffic, creation of a shade by Norman Foster. The Old Port is still the nerve center of Marseille.
The Quai de la Fraternité is perpendicular to the Quai de Rive-Neuve to the south, and to the Quai du Port to the north. It is the place where the fish market is held, the shade house and many events and gatherings.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame du Château
comment: Formerly Chapel Notre-Dame de Belvézer or de Beauvoir, to recall the magnificent panorama that you can admire from this place, the Chapel Notre-Dame du Château, located at 310m altitude, dates from the 12th century.
shortDescription: Formerly Chapel Notre-Dame de Belvézer or de Beauvoir, to recall the magnificent panorama that you can admire from this place, the Chapel Notre-Dame du Château, located at 310m altitude, dates from the 12th century.
description: Formerly Chapel Notre Dame de Beauvoir, to remind the magnificent panorama you can enjoy from this location, or Belv��zer our Lady of Ch��teau date from the 12th century. It has retained its foundations and some walls of origin. Several times restored, formerly Parish Church of Allauch, it is still very picturesque with its statue Golden of the Virgin of the castle with a sceptre of vermeil sunk with jewellery offered by the faithful, and the bourdon of 2500 kilos... It has in its interior of many ex-votos of the XVIII and XIX centuries systems. It is an annual pilgrimage in the second week of September and is celebrating also the Sunday of the fortnight, 15 days after Easter following the vow made during the epidemic of plague of 1720.
streetAddress: ['Chapelle Notre Dame du Château, montée Notre Dame du Château']

label: Chapelle Saint-Véran
comment: Chapel of Saint-Véran in Orgon.
shortDescription: Chapel of Saint-Véran in Orgon.
description:
This chapel is located on private property by the side of the Chemin de Saint-Véran. The quality and perfect stone-setting of this building, most of which is in ruins, make it one of the most characteristic in Romanesque Provence. It had a single nave, with a barrel vault resting on transverse arches and built around a semi-domed apse; on each side of the entrance to the apse were rubble stones decorated with foliage with plant and geometrical designs. There was a side chapel to the south.
Only the eastern side of the building, including the well-preserved apse, is still standing. Built in honour of Saint Véran, Bishop of Cavaillon, the chapel was plundered and demolished by the Saracens, then rebuilt in the 10th century. It is possible to see stones decorated with Roman sculptures which were reused for its construction; the walls also feature masonry seals, including that of Pontius, the contractor for Saint Gabriel Chapel in Tarascon.
Closed to visitors.

label: Jardins du Domaine de la Violaine
Les Médiabus
comment: The Médiabus of the Méjanes library provide a local service in the remote districts of the Cité du livre or its annexes.
shortDescription: The Médiabus of the Méjanes library provide a local service in the remote districts of the Cité du livre or its annexes.
description: They develop actions for audiences far from reading (social centres, associations, retirement homes, etc.), and interventions for the promotion of libraries and cultural events.

label: Chapelle Saint Martin
description: At the entrance to the Saint Pons estate, the Saint Martin chapel, which dates from the 13th century, owes its survival to its sturdy buttresses and its heavy vault. In Romanesque style, it has been restored by associations. It is composed of a single nave and is surrounded by an important vegetation.

label: Chapelle Saint-Mitre-des-Champs
comment: The Saint-Mitre-des-Champs chapel is located in Aix-en-Provence, in the western district that bears its name and which has been considerably urbanized over the last 20 years.
shortDescription: The Saint-Mitre-des-Champs chapel is located in Aix-en-Provence, in the western district that bears its name and which has been considerably urbanized over the last 20 years.
description:
The Saint-Mitre-des-Champs chapel is in Aix-en-Provence. It is located in the western district of the same name, which has been greatly urbanised over the past 20 years. The city's patron saint, Saint Mitre, is thought to have worked as a farmhand on the land nearby, along the old Roman road, at the turn of the 4th and 5th centuries.
An oratory was first built for the saint and, in 1657, a chapel was dedicated to him, near today's chapel. The land was donated by Balthazar d'André, Counsellor of Accounts. The Canon Mallet paid for all the construction work, which was supervised by Louis Jaubert. It was finished the same year. "This rural chapel was the last of the religious buildings built in Aix in the 17th century. The layout seems to have been inspired by a Roman temple" (J. Boyer). In the late 17th century, the Saint-Mitre priory became part of the new parish of Saint-Jean-Baptiste-du-Faubourg led by the Christian Doctrine Fathers. After being sold as national property during the Revolution, the building was extended in the 19th century and used as an outbuilding for a neighbouring farm. It is still privately owned. 

In the 19th century, a project was launched to build today's chapel, and the architect Huot was commissioned to design it. The date 1865 is written on the spire. For a long time the chapel was associated with and under the jurisdiction of Notre-Dame de la Seds church. For a few years, it also became a parish church.

An association, the Friends of Saint-Mitre Chapel, was set up in 1967 and presided by Emilien Tousche, with the aim of giving new life to the chapel. The association was highly active until 1995. In 2001, with Jean-Luc Galéa as president, the association was revived and plans were made for restorations.

Begun in 2002, restoration work intensified from 2008. Absolute respect for the old building and the preservation of the original aspects of the construction were always a main concern. The work was faciliated and supported by an agreement with the Heritage Foundation.
All the inside walls were decorated with murals in the 19th century. The association aims to preserve them in the best possible condition.
The painting of "The Holy Family" is by an unknown artist from the 19th century. The work was given to Monseigneur de Panafieu, the former archbishop of Aix-en-Provence, by an old Aix family. The painting was completely restored in 2017 with the help of donations.

Mass at 9.30 am on the last Sunday of the month.

label: Beffroi (ancienne Maison Commune)
comment: The former town hall, known as the belfry, was the seat of civil power from the 16th century until 1892: the Renaissance architecture is embodied by its exterior clock which bears the date 1516.
shortDescription: The former town hall, known as the belfry, was the seat of civil power from the 16th century until 1892: the Renaissance architecture is embodied by its exterior clock which bears the date 1516.
description:
Nicknamed the "belfry", the old town hall hosted the community meetings from the 1550s to the Revolution, then served as the town hall until 1892. It surmounts the gateway to the Place Camille-Desmoulins, the main entrance to the town, whose existence is attested since the 15th century

Probably given to the community in 1516, this former guardhouse was the subject of documented improvements from 1552, first for the clock entrusted to a craftsman vitrollais. Its dial was placed on a relief commemorating the date of 1516 and decorated with two winged genii on a cut leather background, in the purest mannerist style of the Renaissance. The facade and its bell tower were entirely remodelled in 1643 by the mason Jean Gaffarel, as they are today, with a cross window illuminating the main room, a half-cross window indicating the clock's weight well, and a bastard window under the roof used for the archives. The whole is crowned with sculpted gargoyles with lion heads. The battlements have disappeared, as well as the three tapered pyramidions of the bell tower

In 1662 a second clock, on the Victor Hugo street side, came to mark the course of time on a delicate dial probably chiseled by the mason Laurent Arvel. It led to the installation of a new mechanism, still preserved and presented in the room, linking the two clocks by a system of gears and a transmission shaft running through the rooms. The monument is thus distinguished by this double watchmaking device, whose main piece dating from 1740 is still in action, with a two-day autonomy. It is driven by a rotating and alternating movement, equipped with two drums with a weight of 7 kg for the hourly movement and 20 kg for the sound movement. These weights are lowered into a 12-metre shaft, partly underground. The rehabilitation of this system lasted 2 years, from 1992 to 1994, carried out by the association of the Friends of Marignane and Provence which had been sitting in the monument since 1965

Restored between 1986 and 1996, the common house still reveals many curious details such as a set of engravings in the stone, visible inside and outside.

Visits are organized from time to time by the association in partnership with the Tourist Office. All information on the website of the Tourist Office.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021


Visits are organized from time to time by the association in partnership with the Tourist Office. All information on the website of the Tourist Office.

label: Eglise Les Récollets - Saint-Théodore
comment: The church of Saint-Théodore is only open for services and certain occasional guided tours (Heritage Days).
shortDescription: The church of Saint-Théodore is only open for services and certain occasional guided tours (Heritage Days).
description: The reformed Franciscan religious (Récollets), settled there in 1633. The present church, classified as a historical monument, was rebuilt in the 18th century. It became a parish after the Revolution. The baptistery is located on the right as you enter. The overall composition evokes a gushing fountain. The church has been classified as a historical monument since 1991. Also to be seen: the side altars, the holy water fonts, the organ case and Beaufo's painting. Parish priest: Jacques Julien. Mass on Sundays at 10 am.

label: Le Vieux Bassin
comment: The Vieux Bassin is the old water reservoir of the village built between 1885 and 1887. The most beautiful achievement of the 19th century was the water conveyance that the inhabitants had always been waiting for...
shortDescription: The Vieux Bassin is the old water reservoir of the village built between 1885 and 1887. The most beautiful achievement of the 19th century was the water conveyance that the inhabitants had always been waiting for...
description: Built by j. Chevillon, at the top of the Notre Dame district, the old pool was inaugurated in 1887. It would then serve reserve, pumped water to the station of the Blacassins, in the canal de Marseille. Beautiful cut stones that form the vaults and walls were made to confine the waters.Today, it has become a beautiful room of cultural exhibitions, and hosts each year the superb cr��che of Gilbert Orsini with more than 600 santons from end of November to end of January

label: Plage du Liouquet
description: Shingle beach. Panel of identification on the site. Parking area near the beach, not paying. Equipment nearby: restaurants, accommodation. Nautical activities on the spot: scuba diving. No handicaped accesses. Naturism tolerated in the naturist part (left-hand side behind the rock). Admitted dogs. Prohibited access on the right part (risk of collapse).

label: Bastide Marin
description:
The natural case of The Bastide Marin reveals four centuries of history. Secular trees and gardens: an educational vineyard of 14 vines, an olive grove, a garden of flavors, a medieval garden, a magic and medicinal garden, fallow lands for the biodiversity. At the heart of gardens, spaces are dedicated to the rest and meditation. An educational farm and an apiary are to be discovered at the bottom of the property. 
Opening to the public on Wednesday from 1:30 pm till 5 pm and Saturday from 9:30 am till 12 am.

label: Statue de Calendal
description: Statue built in Cassis stone by Auguste Cornu in 1930, destroyed in 1944 by occupying troops during the liberation of Cassis, new statue completed in 1999 by Bouvier and inaugurated on 24 June 2000. Calendal is the hero of the work of the same name written by Frédérique Mistral, still available in bi-lingual writing (Provencal, French).

label: Chaîne de l'Etoile
comment: Located in the south-east quarter of the department, the Etoile and Garlaban massifs largely surround the towns of Marseille and Aubagne, located to the south.
shortDescription: Located in the southeast quarter of the department, the Etoile and Garlaban massifs largely surround the cities of Marseille and Aubagne, located to the south.
description:
Located in the southeastern quarter of the Bouches-du-Rhône, the Massifs de l’Etoile and Massif du Garlaban encircle a major part of the territories of Marseille and Aubagne, situated to the South. These chains are bordered by the Arbois, Montaiguet, Collines de Gardanne and Regagnas chains to the North, by the Valley of Aubagne to the East and the A7 highway to the West, which forms a barrier between the massif and the Côte Bleue coast.

The two massifs are separated by the D908 main road. 

The Massif de l’Etoile forms a semi-circle comprising an East-West oriented peak of 14 km in length and 7.5 km in width: it rises to an altitude of 778 metres at Grand Puech, while its lowest point (172 metres) is located to the South of Vallon Dol. To the southeast, it extends into the Massif du Garlaban: a circular massif rising to an altitude of 729 m at Plan de l’Aigle, and descending to 120 m in the Valley of Huveaune. The many steep slopes and numerous North-South facing valleys (East-West on the western face) carving out its relief make terrestrial fire-fighting in this chain extremely difficult. It forms a genuine natural barrier, with an extremely hilly relief, at the gateway to Marseille.

The relief and general East-West orientation of the Etoile-Garlaban chain provoke a strong masking effect, with striking contrasts between the adret (South-facing) and ubac (North-facing) slopes. 

The southern slopes of the Etoile and Garlaban are characterized by a typical Mediterranean climate.

The northern slopes are characterized by a cooler and wetter micro-climate, with lower temperatures, higher rainfall and shorter summer droughts. …

The Massif de l’Etoile's marked relief and high-altitude gradient lends it a highly varied character, with fairly fertile northern slopes (often-veteran Aleppo pines, Norway pines, Durmast oaks and even Austrian pines), contrasting with the rather barren southern slopes, with predominant Aleppo pines growing mainly in the bottom of valleys spared from fires. Scrubland populated with gorse or kermes oak and rosemary, covers the plateaux and shallow-soiled slopes, as a result of climatic and pedological constraints, coupled with repeated forest fires. Forests cover 12,800 acres of the Etoile chain, i.e. 58.46 % of its surface area.

The Massif de l'Etoile and Massif du Garlaban comprise a natural barrier between Marseille, Aix, Gardanne and Aubagne, and largely influence the urban dynamics of the surrounding towns. Their peri-urban location means they are the target of extensive development projects moreover, the absence of a transition zone between the highly urbanized and natural areas is extremely apparent.

In their role as a peri-urban massif and genuine green lung of Marseille, Aubagne and their neighbouring towns, the Massif de l’Etoile and Massif du Garlaban play a significant social role, with an estimated frequentation of 250,000 visitors per year, most of which are locals due to their somewhat "confidential" access routes.

The massifs are home to numerous historic and prestigious sites, including oppida (ancient fortified hilltop settlements), oratories, Notre-Dame des Anges monastery, the Pilon du Roy rock and Garlaban hills. 

…

They form part of the Etoile-Garlaban Natura 2000 site.

label: Aqueduc de la Penne sur Huveaune
comment: Aqueduc de la Candolle is a bridge-aqueduct, a semicircular arch bridge
shortDescription: Aqueduc de la Candolle is a bridge-aqueduct, a semicircular arch bridge
description: The aqueduct of the Candolle known as the Arcades consists of sixteen arches, is 122 meters long and up to 12 meters high. It was built in 1866 and was put in water in 1873 in order to bring the water from the Durance to the agricultural lands of the Commune. The water of the canal stopped flowing in 1986 due to a lack of farms.

label: Quatre Termes
comment: The Four Terms Massif is the natural extension of the Lançon Range. It takes the form of a slightly sloping plateau
shortDescription: The Four Terms Massif is the natural extension of the Lançon Range. It takes the form of a slightly sloping plateau
description:
Situates in the central area of the Bouches-du-Rhône, the Chaîne de Lançon and Massif des Quatre Termes are bordered to the North by the Chaîne des Côtes and Trévaresse massifs, to the South by Etang de Berre and the Massif de l’Arbois, to the East by the town of Aix-en-Provence, and to the West by the Massif du Pont de Rhaud.

Chaîne de Lançon is a low-lying plateau (average altitude 170 m), descending steeply northwards and southwards. Its western relief is relatively uneven and features numerous cliffs. The plateau is carved with several North-South facing valleys, with the exception of Vallon des Pièces, La Croix de Ferri and Gramenier, which cross the massif from East to West. The chain is crossed by several major roads: A7, N113 and D21. 

The Massif des Quatre Termes is a natural extension of the Chaîne de Lançon. This plateau slopes slightly to the northwest it is delimited to the North by the Vallée de la Touloubre and RD972 road, and to the South by the A8 highway, agricultural plains of La Fare-les-Oliviers and Lançon. Its eastern border is marked by the agricultural plain and the urban zones of Aix and Eguilles. Lastly, its western border is marked by the EDF (Electricity Board) canal. This plateau stretches down from a height of 90 m to the extreme northwest, then rises slowly to the southeast to a height of 308 m (average altitude 240 m). It is crossed from East to West by the RD17 road, and from North to South by the RD 67E road.

The Chaîne de Lançon and Massif des Quatre Termes are exposed to strong Mistral winds. Annual rainfall is around 600 mm, with an average annual temperature of between 14 and 14.5° C.

As a result of repeated forest fires, both massifs are populated primarily by garrigue and wooded garrigue, comprising evergreen oaks or Aleppo pines. Woodland covers just 10 % of Lançon, with seedling forests of Aleppo pines and evergreen oaks on the piedmont and in the valleys. Les Quatre Termes is more densely forested (Eguilles, La Barben), with woodland covering 40% of surface area however, the plateau is mainly covered with garrigue and wooded garrigue. 

Despite the close proximity of major urban centres, the Chaîne de Lançon and Quatre Termes remain essentially rural and home to remarkable and well-preserved natural areas, mainly situated around Chaîne de Lançon, Aix-en-Provence and Salon. These massifs are part of a Special Protection Zone (ZPS) and their biota is protected (Bonelli's eagle).

label: Complexe sportif Serge Messones (ex la Botte)
description: 2 hectares equipped with spring games 3 to 8 slides 3 to 8 years old - Supernova (turnstile) 6 to 12 years old - Spica (balance game) 6 to 12 years old - Zibal (climbing structure) 6 to 12 years old. Accessible grassy areas accompanying sports fields and gymnasiums. 900 m fitness trail, benches, table tennis tables.

label: Plage des Aigues Douces
comment: 150m x 30m sandy beach made up of natural coves.
shortDescription: 150m x 30m sandy beach made up of natural coves.
description:
Supervised beach in summer from 1 p.m. to 6:45 p.m.
Two items of equipment that improve the comfort of people with reduced mobility are available and delivered to the beaches on request from the supervisors: the "Hippocampe" wheelchair facilitating movement on the sand and entering the water and the "Tiralo", wheelchair amphibious, allowing accompanied swimming.
By the way along the coast.

label: L'Etang des Aubettes
comment: Private fish pond with trout, carp, roach... Open all year round 7 days a week
shortDescription: Private fish pond with trout, carp, roach... Open all year round 7 days a week
description: For trout-fishing, for the whole family.

label: Oppidum celto-ligure de Saint-Marcel - Baou de Saint-Marcel
comment: "An oppidum in ancient times referred to a kind of citadel, a natural eminence fortified and therefore suitable for defense."
shortDescription: "An oppidum in ancient times referred to a kind of citadel, a natural eminence fortified and therefore suitable for defense."
description:
"Among the oppida established in Ligurian Provence is the very strategic one of Saint-Marcel. The site of the Baous plateau of Saint-Marcel covers three hectares at an altitude of 167 metres: it occupies a platform protected by steep cliffs on the south and west sides, while to the north the terrain slopes steeply down. The oppidum was built as a real entrenched village. The dwellings were erected side by side. The floors were made of pebbles bound with clay, and the streets were very narrow. The presence of springs at the foot of the cliffs also explains the choice of this place and at least one well was established in this fortified enclosure which offers us the most beautiful archaeological site in Marseilles visible after that of the remains of the Stock Exchange"
 H. Hardouin.

label: Digue à la mer
comment: 20 km long, the dam was built in the last century to isolate the Rhone delta from seawater inlets.
shortDescription: 20 km long, the dam was built in the last century to isolate the Rhone delta from seawater inlets.
description:
Twenty 20 km long, the dyke was built in the last century to isolate the Rhone delta water inputs from sea water. The sea dyke (prohibited to motorised vehicles) provides access to 20 km of walking and cycling trails from the Gacholle car park.
Easy access to the sea from the south of the car park or 2 km after the flagship of the Comtesse lighthouse. Discover the beautiful wilderness of the sansouires and lagoons in the heart of the National Reserve. Sea birds and brackish environments can been seen: seagulls, terns, herring gulls, flamingos, ducks, herons and shoreline birds. This very fragile environment must be protected. Visitation of the dunes is strictly prohibited, even on foot!

label: Porte de la Condamine
description: The remains of the ramparts are very interesting from an architectural point of view. They include the Porte Saint Jean (17th-18th centuries), the Porte de Jarnègues (12th-17th centuries) and the Porte de la Condamine (14th century). The Porte de la Condamine is listed as a national Historic Monument and the Porte Saint Jean is listed as a regional Historic Monument.

label: Chapelle de la Persévérance
description:
La Persévérance Chapel is actually the remains of a house founded in 1677 to take in 'women and girls of ill repute'. Entrusted to the care of the sisters of Notre Dame du Refuge, the establishment was a moral and financial failure and was forced to close by a Royal order. In 1803, the chapel was attached to the catechism of perseverance, i.e. the more advanced teaching that children follow once they have received their first solemn communion, and took its name from this. It currently houses contemporary art exhibitions.
Architectural description:
The façade is an expression of Baroque art; the depressed arch portal is framed by two capitals with Ionic capitals, adorned with garlands of flowers and an entablature which features a three-sided architrave, a frieze and a cornice on modillions. The décor is completed by a semi-circular niche without a statue; the niche's semi-dome is decorated with a shell. It is flanked by two small pilasters and bas-relief scrolls. Two consoles support a triangular broken pediment. Vases on either side of the niche complete the décor.

label: Le moulin à vent de Bertoire
description:
On the plateau of Bertoire stands a windmill from the beginning of the 19th century, witness of the pre-industrial heritage of Lambesc.
It is the only vestige of the 9 watermills and windmills which existed in Lambesc .
Thanks to a meticulous and authentic restoration, completed in 2013, it has recovered its millstones, its roof, its wings and its mechanism, making it one of the rare working windmills in the region.

label: La Grande Synagogue
description:
The synagogue of Saint-Nathan was built in the 19th century (project chosen in 1860). It is built on a basilical plan and in Romano-Byzantine style. It was inaugurated in 1864
To see: the furniture, the silver and bronze lighting, the women's gallery and the organ case.

Visits from Monday to Thursday from 10am to 1pm.
Guided tour of 25 mn, or conference visit of 1h30.

label: Eglise Saint Vérédème
comment: Romanesque style church.
shortDescription: Romanesque style church.
description: Saint Vérédème Church was built in the Romanesque style, fortified in the 14th century and then extended in the 19th century. Its old square tower is now a bell tower. The church comprises a broken barrel nave and a semi-circular apse. Saint Vérédème Church and its bell tower are listed as regional Historic Monuments.

label: Les oratoires
description:
The oratories of Saint-Zacharie are located on a north-west/south-east axis. They seem to serve as a link between the former towns of La Canorgue in the North, Rastoin in the Centre (Saint-Zacharie) and Orgnon in the South.

Starting on the north side and going down south:
Saint-Roch, Saint-Antoine, Saint-Victor, Saint-Bernard, Notre-Dame-de-Lourdes, Saint-Pierre, Nativity, Sainte-Marthe, Sainte-Madeleine, Saint-Lazare, Saint-Jacques Le Majeur.

The oratory is a place where one cannot enter, but constitutes a "niche" interior, where a venerated character, generally of a religious nature, is placed.

label: Jardin méditerranéen
comment: Located near the Saint Sulpice chapel and overlooking the etang de l’Olivier, the Mediterranean garden was developed from 1997 by Istres’s Green Areas department. It is home to one hundred varieties of plants and bushes from the Mediterranean basin.
shortDescription: Located near the Saint Sulpice chapel and overlooking the etang de l’Olivier, the Mediterranean garden was developed from 1997 by Istres’s Green Areas department. It is home to one hundred varieties of plants and bushes from the Mediterranean basin.
description:
A key element behind our 4-flower award for the ‘Villes & villages fleuris’ label, the Mediterranean garden offers a unique and perfect setting for a walk. When the fair weather arrives, come and stroll through this garden which offers a superb panorama on the etang de l’Olivier and its water jet. With more than 100 species from the Mediterranean basin, the garden features a high-quality plant environment. An ideal choice for family outings.

Visits can be booked with a botanical specialist, through the tourist office.

label: Villa Nadar
description: Beautiful Empire style villa, which was inhabited by the photographer Nadar at the end of the 19th century.

label: Collines de Barjaquets
comment: The Arbois massif includes the areas called "Collines de Barjaquets" and "Arbois".
shortDescription: The Arbois massif includes the areas called "Collines de Barjaquets" and "Arbois".
description:
The Arbois massif forms a vast plateau of more than 15,000 hectares surrounded by 3 major urban centres: Etang de Berre, Aix-en-Provence and Marseille. Its contours are generally bounded to the north by the A8 motorway, to the south by the A51 motorway, the D6 and the N113, to the west by the Etang de Berre industrial estate and to the east by the D543.
The Arbois massif forms a vast plateau offering good visibility (highest point at 270 m) and quite distinct from the plains that border it. We can distinguish globally 4 particular entities:

- the cuestas of Vitrolles to Velaux which mark the western edge of the plateau and constitute steep and rocky foothills, with a few valleys and agricultural basins (the overall altitude goes from 50 to 60 m in the plain to 180 m on the edge of the plateau)

- the central plateau of the Grand Arbois, vast and tabular with its garrigue as far as the eye can see: it is also crossed by many infrastructures (power lines, TGV, CET Aix-en-Provence ...)

- the small wooded hills, culminating at 230-250 m, which form the forested hems of the plateau to the north, east and south

- the agricultural plains in contact with the hills (Velaux basin in the north-west, the plain of large lands in the north-east, the Saint-Pons valley in the east and the Arbois plain in the south-east).

The centre of the plateau is little travelled, but its northern, eastern and southern fringes have many communication routes in relation to a large diffuse or isolated habitat. The network of DFCI trails is essentially centred on the northern half of the massif.

The Arbois Massif is mainly subject to a strong mistral, with a north-west/south-easterly orientation, but also to the south wind. This massif is located in the climatological zone of coastal Provence (...) The average temperatures on this massif are between 13 and 14.5° C.

More than 65% of the vegetation is composed of low formations of scrubland or young reconstituted stands related to the passage of fires. The great majority of the central plateau is composed of low scrublands, whereas the "constituted" forest formations are mainly articulated on the small hills of the North and East and on the southern part of the massif. The majority of these wooded formations are made up of mature Aleppo pine forests, the deciduous stands remaining very marginal and limited to the fresh valley bottoms.

With a great diversity of natural environments, ranging from the wetlands of the Réaltor and the riparian formations of the Arc and Grand Torrent to the xeric zones of the plateau, the Arbois massif overlooking the Etang de Berre has been part of the Arbois Plateau Special Protection Area (SPA) under the Birds Directive since August 2003.

The massif also encompasses the entire area of the General Interest Project (PIG) for the protection of the Arbois since October 2001. In spite of the image of a massif degraded by repeated fires and by the strong urban pressure that it suffers on its fringes, the Arbois still presents areas recognized for their great naturalness, which are subject to specific protection.

The use of the massif remains local: it is practised daily by the inhabitants of the neighbouring towns, who find there a natural area nearby for more or less sporting strolls.

label: Chapelle du Lycée Thiers
comment: In the 18th century chapel, classified as a historical monument, is the theater " les Bernardines" promoting contemporary creation and dance. The chapel is accessible only to attend the shows.
shortDescription: In the 18th century chapel, classified as a historical monument, is the theater " les Bernardines" promoting contemporary creation and dance. The chapel is accessible only to attend the shows.

label: Jardin de la poste – Square Verdun
description:
Timetable: Monday: 08h30-12h00 / 13h45-17h00
Tuesday: 08h30-12h00 / 13h45-17h00
Wednesday: 08h30-12h00 / 13h45-17h00
Thursday: 08h30-12h00 / 13h45-17h00
Friday: 08h30-12h00 / 13h45-17h00
Saturday: 09h00-12h15

label: Chapelle des Pénitents
description:
Church known as the Chapel of the White Penitents (old), also known as the Chapel of Notre-Dame-de-Pitié (old)

Choral woodwork, stalls.

This chapel, which was built in 1844, is currently registered on the list of historical monuments and preserves beautiful works.

label: Château de Peynier
comment: The château is key to the village's architecture. It was built in the mid-16th century by a Matheron (family of Peynier lords) and is typical of Provencal Renaissance architecture
shortDescription: The château is key to the village's architecture. It was built in the mid-16th century by a Matheron (family of Peynier lords) and is typical of Provencal Renaissance architecture
description:
Two large round towers stand on either side of the main wall and used to have cross-shaped windows. A brick “M” for “Matheron” lies in the small courtyard in the middle of the cobbles. The château was then passed onto the Isoard de Chênerilles family then the Arbaud de Matheron family before it became the property of Thomassin de Peynier in the mid-17th century. 

In the 18th century, the Marquis Louis de Thomassin de Peynier had it fully renovated. He had the gypsum redone in the reception rooms and redesigned the grounds with a beautiful feature gate in 1769 (date engraved on the pillar). The inside still has part of its feature staircase (similar to the ones you can see in Aix's mansions), a French-style ceiling in the main reception room and marble fireplaces.

The château remained the property of the Thomassin de Peynier family and their heirs until 1933 when it was sold to Aix's archbishop's palace. It is now home to a private school and was taken over by the town.

label: Statues de bronze "Le pêcheur et la ramendeuse"
comment: The statuary ensemble has become an essential step in the visit of Martigues.
shortDescription: The statuary ensemble has become an essential step in the visit of Martigues.
description:
Bronze sculpture installed on the port of Martigues-Ferrières.
Created in 2010 by Sébastien Langloys. She is an early 20th century fisherman and net mower.

Dimension: 100 x 300 x 180 cm / 39.4 x 118.1 x 70.9 in.
Weight 900 kg / 1984.14 lbs.

label: Le monument du Cheval
comment: Monument representing a horse.
shortDescription: Monument representing a horse.
description: It represents a draught horse, brother of all those who worked the rich and fertile lands of Mollégès and who allowed the reconquest and the development of the plaluds. Sculpted in a block of Oppède stone by Camille Soccorsi, a sculptor from Tarascon, it was inaugurated on 7 May 1989 on the Place du Lavoir. There are, to our knowledge, only two other monuments dedicated to the draught horse: one in Callac, the other in Landivisiau in Brittany but it is the only one carved in stone.

label: Remparts
comment: the remains of the ramparts can be seen on rue des Allées
shortDescription: the remains of the ramparts can be seen on rue des Allées
description: The enclosure, made of blocks of stone, was about 1200 metres long. Affecting the layout of a square with rounded corners surmounted by a parapet walk protected by crenellations. Nowadays there is practically nothing left of this enclosure: a few sections of wall here and there, and, to the north of the village, the outer wall of the houses, one metre thick, is made up of the old decapitated ramparts of the parapet walk and the crenellations.

label: Moulin de la Roque
description: This old mill is located at the southern end of the chemin des deux eaux (pedestrian-friendly). This water-powered mill bears witness to the importance of water and canals, as well as to a bygone industrial past. It preserves all the grinding mechanisms inside. On the outside, the lock mechanism for directing water to the mill is still present.

label: Parc de la Romaniquette
comment: The Romaniquette park, overlooking the Etang de Berre pond, offers a beautiful lawn on the edge of a pine forest (1.5ha), ideal for relaxing and strolling.
shortDescription: The Romaniquette park, overlooking the Etang de Berre pond, offers a beautiful lawn on the edge of a pine forest (1.5ha), ideal for relaxing and strolling.
description: The Park of the Romaniquette overlooking the etang de Berre, offers a beautiful lawn on the edge of pine forest (1, 5ha), ideal to relax and stroll.

label: Hôtel de Forbin
comment: Built on the plans of Pierre Pavillon in 1656, its broad flat façade is enlivened by the slight projection of each of its eight bays, which is accompanied, up to the cornice, by the superposition of classical orders.
shortDescription: Built on the plans of Pierre Pavillon in 1656, its broad flat façade is enlivened by the slight projection of each of its eight bays, which is accompanied, up to the cornice, by the superposition of classical orders.
description:
Built on the plans of Pierre Pavillon in 1656, its broad flat façade is enlivened by the slight projection of each of its eight bays, which is accompanied, up to the cornice, by the superposition of classical orders. 

The balcony, as is often the case in Aix, was left unfinished.

label: Château (Mairie) de Cornillon Confoux
comment: The Town Hall of Cornillon Confoux takes place in a XIIth century castle
shortDescription: The Town Hall of Cornillon Confoux takes place in a XIIth century castle
description:
Castle probably built in the 12th century by the monks of Montmajour, against the second wall the enclosure.
Around 1869, the castle was sold to the commune which fitted out the town hall and the school

label: Planétarium Peiresc
comment: The Peiresc planetarium is located near the gorgeous Saint Mitre Park, in the west part of the city.
shortDescription: The Peiresc planetarium is located near the gorgeous Saint Mitre Park, in the west part of the city.
description:
The planetarium offers to visitors a complete set of learning experiences including and not limited to Astronomy, Astrophysics and Earth Science. Our team will guide you through a 8 meters dome equipped with a cutting edge star projector.

The planetarium has free lectures held every month on a wide variety of scientific subjects. You can visit the planetarium by bus from the Rotonde plaza or by car (free parking on site).

label: Chapelle Sainte Anne de Goiron
comment: Built in the 11th century by the precursors of the monks of Silvacane, the Romanesque chapel is installed on an ancient pagan site on the Manivert plateau overlooking the village of La Roque d'Anthéron.
shortDescription: Built in the 11th century by the precursors of the monks of Silvacane, the Romanesque chapel is installed on an ancient pagan site on the Manivert plateau overlooking the village of La Roque d'Anthéron.
description: The chapel Sainte Anne de Goiron is in Romanesque style despite its restoration in the 19th century. It is situated in a wild site and was a place of pilgrimage for the rain. It is composed of a single nave with a broken barrel vault and an apse in the cul de four. It has a triangular-shaped campanile. There are some beautiful ex-votos from the 17th century.

label: Place des Anciens Combattants à Pélissanne
description:
The Place des Anciens Combattants is located between the banks of the Touloubre river and the shopping centre le Galion. It opens onto a green and wooded park, laid out as a fitness trail
It is the place of celebration of French commemorative days.
An ideal place for a short family walk, or an outing with your dog!
(Place equipped with "doggie bags")

label: Tableau Saint-Eloi et le miracle du pied de cheval coupé
comment: Religious painting.
shortDescription: Religious painting.
description: This oil on canvas, classified as an object of historic monuments since 1975, is signed by Nicolas Mignard (1606-1668), "King's painter" under Louis XIV.Saint Eloi, Advisor to King Dagobert is considered to be the Patron Saint of goldsmiths, blacksmiths and wheelwrights the corporations. The painted canvas in 1645 represents Saint Eloi, size natural, kneeling, questioning the sky. In response, the clouds open, showing two little angels. The left hand of Eloi, in Ecstasy, returns on his chest the other refers to the cross and a mitre placed alongside heavy wrought iron objects. The background scene, is the representation of one legends attached to the life of Saint Eloi.The upper part of the sumptuous gilded wood frame represents a sheaf of wheat, which is very symbolic of the food that the Earth gives us.This restored work in 2019 is visible in the Church Saint-Denys.

label: Station biologique de la Tour du Valat
comment: The Tour du Valat Biological Station was created in 1954 by Luc Hoffmann. An independent organisation, the Tour du Valat was declared a non-profit foundation in 1976.
shortDescription: The Tour du Valat Biological Station was created in 1954 by Luc Hoffmann. An independent organisation, the Tour du Valat was declared a non-profit foundation in 1976.
description: The Tour du Valat aims to promote and contribute directly to the conservation of Mediterranean wetlands. The central part has been designated as a Voluntary Nature Reserve since 1984. It is the largest in France. The station and the reserve are only open to the public for 2 days a year, during an open day in January and February. Normally, access to the Station is reserved for scientists.

label: Chapelle Saint-Jean
description: Romanesque chapel of the 12th century characteristic of the first Provençal Romanesque art: single nave plan, triumphal arch, apse in cul de four. The discovery, on the apse, of a fireplace of the 5th century B.C. showed the antiquity of the occupation of this area.

label: Centre ancien historique
comment: The historic old town centre corresponds to the old town of Marignane, originally described as a "castrum" or fortified village, according to a term that appeared in 1022.
shortDescription: The historic old town centre corresponds to the old town of Marignane, originally described as a "castrum" or fortified village, according to a term that appeared in 1022.
description:
It corresponds to the old town of Marignane, originally called "castrum" or fortified village, according to a term appearing in 1022. It was surrounded by ramparts of which some portions can still be seen
The town, which was built on a slight prominence, became truly "enshrined" at the beginning of the 13th century with the fortification of the seigniorial house

The walls or ancestral "barri" have undergone several campaigns of repair and reinforcement, probably from 1396-1399 against the troops of Raymond de Turenne, and at the time of religious and civil unrest from 1574 to 1589. The enclosure was punctuated by 3 gates in the Middle Ages: the town gate, the "false gate" (on the site of the main entrance to the town hall, which disappeared in 1605), and the postern, now rue de la Cité

In the 16th century, the breach opened for the entrance of the grape harvest was added, later closed by the chapel of the white penitents, the new gate in 1607, the gate of the rue des Fours in the 18th century
A medieval moat, regularly filled with water, ran along the foot of the walls, fed by the Font-Marignane valley and bordered by gardens which eventually covered it from 1519

The first extra muros extensions attested from the 1650s in the rue Charles Esmieu, were followed by the development of the malls in the 18th century, then the opening of the triumphal Cours Mirabeau under the Second Empire
A few towers stood out, such as the base of the bell tower, a probable defence and surveillance structure originally attached to the rampart, the "keep" of the castle known as the "falconry" (collapsed in 1921), and a small tower mentioned in 1450 but not located.
 Inside, there is a hospital for the poor, a weight building, a well (still visible), lordly and private ovens, a forge, a public butcher's shop and a fishmonger's shop, oil mills, as well as houses and shops, sometimes remarkable for their ornate windows, doors bearing the date of the year, or niches and sculpted aedicules (some of them emblazoned with the name) housing traditional images of saints, which have now disappeared

For a long time, the village was only served by five streets and as many crossings, and was ventilated by a single square, that of the castle, which was very late in being completed by those of the Sun and of the Star

Gathering about 500 or 600 souls estimated around 1450, 2000 until 1914, Marignane reached 5500 inhabitants in 1954, thanks to the development of industries and the airport. In 1962, the city had 8500, to reach a population of 34000 inhabitants today

After a campaign of salvage excavations, the historic centre is undergoing a major rehabilitation and urban renewal campaign. The rich and numerous testimonies of a town that, already, visitors of the Renaissance, following a royal procession, qualified in 1564 of "beautiful small city and castle", and the first excursionists of Marseilles of "pretty village" in 1875, are waiting there.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Orgue de Saint Laurent
description: The buffet and the instrumental part are by Baker and Verschneider and date from 1865. It is the first organ built with an electric system by Peschard. There has been a modification of the mixtures and a rebuilding by Merklin in 1974.

label: Vieux Lavoir
comment: This washhouse was built in 1873 and was fed by water from the gallery dug by the Société des Mines.
shortDescription: This washhouse was built in 1873 and was fed by water from the gallery dug by the Société des Mines.
description: The practicality of the washhouse fed by this gallery was one of the elements that improved the daily life of the villagers in the 19th century. It was used until 1968.

label: Hôtel de Valbelle
description:
This mansion was built in 1655 for Joseph de Valbelle, Marquis of Tourves, and was enlarged in the 18th century. 

Today it is the premises of the Sub-Prefecture of Aix-en-Provence

label: Plage Anse de la Bonne Brise
comment: Sandy beach after the Pointe Rouge and before the small port of the Madrague de Montredon.  Equipped with toilets, and a parking lot.
shortDescription: Sandy beach after the Pointe Rouge and before the small port of the Madrague de Montredon.  Equipped with toilets, and a parking lot.

label: Les coussouls de la Crau
comment: The Natural Reserve of the Coussouls de Crau allows a strong protection to preserve and bring to life a heritage both natural and pastoral.
shortDescription: The Natural Reserve of the Coussouls de Crau allows a strong protection to preserve and bring to life a heritage both natural and pastoral.
description:
In 2001, more than 7,400 hectares of Coussouls de Crau were classified as a Natural Reserve. It is co-managed by the Conservatory of Southern Alps - Provence Ecosystem Studies (CEEP), and the Chamber of Agriculture of Bouches-du Rhone. Since May 2008, a portion of this reserve is available under the "Draille des Coussouls Interpretive Trail".
The Coussouls de Crau Nature Reserve provides strong protection to preserve and keep alive both the natural and pastoral heritage.
- On the natural level, the Nature Reserve features an original and remarkable fauna and flora ecosystem.- On the pastoral level, the endless landscapes of the Crau have been covered for millennia by shepherds and their flocks. In addition, the ancestral activity of pastoralism contributes to maintain the delicate balance that exists between agriculture and the environment. 
Of this vastness, only 147 hectares of the Peau de Meau Reserve are accessible to the public after obtaining a compulsory Pass (3 €) to the Crau Ecomuseum. Since May 2008, this pass allows visitors to go on "Draille des Coussouls Interpretive Trail", a 4.7 km pathway in a protected environment. In about two hours of walking, it offers children and adults the opportunity to explore the unknown aspects of the dry Crau. To guide them, 15 panels have been installed on site. They describe landscapes, the fauna and flora, the work of a shepherd and driving herds... Biotope protection.

label: Porte de l'Horloge
description:
Built on the site of the north gate of the old city walls. The Clock Gate marks the passage from the modern city to the ancient city. It was built in the 17th century, topped by a campanile de Roland. Each day of the week is represented according to the planets, the Sun for Sunday, the Moon is on Monday, Mars is on Tuesday, Mercury is on Wednesday, Jupiter is on Thursday, Venus is on Friday, Saturn is on Saturday.
The Clock Door was completely renovated in the spring of 2003, so come and admire the work of this goldsmith.

label: Plage du Prophète
comment: The beach of the Prophet is a small sandy beach, with shallow waters, equipped with a refreshment bar, garbage cans, games for children, a volleyball court, first aid station, toilets, showers.
shortDescription: The beach of the Prophet is a small sandy beach, with shallow waters, equipped with a refreshment bar, garbage cans, games for children, a volleyball court, first aid station, toilets, showers.
description:
The surveillance of the beaches will be from June 1st to August 31st 2022, 7 days a week from 9:30 am to 7 pm.
Access with bus 83 (Vieux Port - Rond-point du Prado).

label: Maison à chapeau de gendarme
comment: This atypical house has been painted and photographed many times since the 19th century.
shortDescription: This atypical house has been painted and photographed many times since the 19th century.
description:
The “Maison à chapeau de gendarme” was built in the 18th century. It is recognisable for its the folded fretted gable and wrought-iron balcony. 
In 1963, Gilles Grangier filmed the comedy “La cuisine au beurre” here, starring French actors Fernandel and Bourvil. 
It housed an eel smokehouse on the ground floor for at least a hundred years.
The interior is not open to visitors.

label: Anim'O Parc
comment: The Anim'O Parc leisure farm offers you educational outdoor activities and the opportunity to discover farm animals!
shortDescription: The Anim'O Parc leisure farm offers you educational outdoor activities and the opportunity to discover farm animals!
description:
On a 2.5 hectare wooded course, you will discover the animals of the farm: rabbits, ponies, horses, sheep, goats, pigs, chickens, birds, goldfish....
Educational and fun activities are offered: mini golf, inflatable structures, pedal go-karting, giant board games, sandbox...
Picnic area
Snack bar
Possibility for children to celebrate their birthdays with or without an animator.
Visits possible for school children

label: Port de Cassis
description:
Nestled between the high golden cliffs of Cap Canaille and the white majesty of the Calanques, the small fishing port of Cassis symbolizes the sweetness of life in Provence
The alleys of the old town centre, its colourful and lively quays invite you to stroll and to make gourmet discoveries
Sheltered from the Quai des Moulin, the basin is closed on the north and west sides by a colourful alignment of old fishermen's houses which make it one of the prettiest ports in the Mediterranean
You can moor there on pendentives, sheltered from the "Mistral", the north-west wind which quickly clears the sky of its clouds
The Port of Cassis is a Heritage around which the life of the city has been organized throughout its history. It is a familiar landscape that has retained all its authenticity
The town of Cassis is nestled at the bottom of the bay which is bordered to the west by the Pointe de Cacau and to the east by the Soubeyranes cliffs and the Cap Canaille
All the urbanization of the city, since its origin, was made around a small cove, located at the outlet of a valley dug in contact with the reliefs which dominate the bay
This cove was developed into a port as early as Roman times and social life developed there over the centuries to the point of making the port the very heart of the city "Carsicis Portus". The city lives with the port and the port is the image of what the city is, a unique site due to the setting and the animation that reigns there.

label: Le quartier Mazarin
comment: This grid-pattern district was designed in the 17th century by Archbishop Mazarin, the Cardinal's brother.
shortDescription: This grid-pattern district was designed in the 17th century by Archbishop Mazarin, the Cardinal's brother.
description:
It was a "luxury housing estate" for members of Parliament and the bourgeoisie of the period, arranged around two main roads: rue Cardinale and rue du 4 Septembre.

Rue Cardinale: its name still recalls Archbishop Mazarin, who became a Cardinal. Its magnificent private mansions make it one of Aix's most attractive streets.

It crosses place de la fontaine des Quatre Dauphins the fountain dates from 1667 and was created by the sculptor Jean-Claude Rambot. Its circular basin is made of Sainte Beaume stone. Its four dolphins rest on waves with their fins raised, supporting the obelisk topped with pine cone, and illustrate the Baroque art that was so popular with Aix's nobility. The Mignet College where Paul Cezanne, Emile Zola, Darius Milhaud and many others have studied is also located in this street!

Rue Cardinale leads to the Church of Saint Jean de Malte and the Granet Museum.

The Church of Saint Jean de Malte stood on open ground before the construction of the Mazarin district it was the church of the Order of St John of Jerusalem (the future Order of Malta), established in Aix in the middle of the 12th century. It is designed in the Provençal Gothic style and has, above its nave, a 16th-century bell tower 67 metres high with an arrow at its top at sunset, its tapering proportions evoke the shape of a minaret. Next to the church is the Granet Museum, the city's art gallery.

The second thoroughfare of this district is rue du Quatre Septembre. This was the first street built when the city was enlarged. Mazarin named it rue Saint-Sauveur, after his church in Paris, but the locals called it rue des Quatre Dauphins, after the square it crossed. 

In this street is the Arbaud Museum, named after its founder. In 1910 this erudite man bequeathed to the city of Aix one of the largest existing collections of Provençal pottery, and a large number of manuscripts and paintings. The Museum houses a regional library (closed for an indefinite period).
In the district ... rue Joseph Cabassol with Hôtel de Caumont built between 1715 and 1742 under the guidance of Georges Vallon for the Marquis of Cabanes, President of the Court of Auditors. It is now the Centre d'Art.

The district is crossed by Rue d'Italie, the oldest street in Aix, since it follows the route of the Aurelian Way where it entered the Roman colony.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents blancs
comment: Headquarters of the Brotherhood of Penitents of Lançon
shortDescription: Headquarters of the Brotherhood of Penitents of Lançon
description:
The brotherhoods of the penitents were born in the 13th century in Italy. They were religious associations of laymen. The members committed themselves to lead a Christian life, they were subjected to the same practices as the monks.
their habit consisted of a hood, a large cloth garment and a rope. It ensured them a perfect anonymity; thus several social classes lived together.
the white penitents assisted the sick, and in times of famine lent or gave grain.
They were also in charge of transporting corpses during burials.

label: Chapelle Saint Julien
description: This is a rural 12th century Romanesque chapel.

label: Fontaine des Tanneurs
comment: The square is at the crossroads of rue des Tanneurs, rue de l'Aumône Vieille, rue de la Couronne, rue Fermée (closed in 1664 to contain an epidemic of the plague) and rues Brueys and d'Entrecasteaux.
shortDescription: The square is at the crossroads of rue des Tanneurs, rue de l'Aumône Vieille, rue de la Couronne, rue Fermée (closed in 1664 to contain an epidemic of the plague) and rues Brueys and d'Entrecasteaux.
description:
The tanners settled in this district more than two centuries ago, around this three-sided square which has a high flat part on which the fountain was built in 1761 according to plans by Georges Vallon.

It was fed by water from the town hall fountain, but aquatic plants clogged the pipes and it stopped flowing. In addition, the ceramic pipes were too close to the ground and were broken by the traffic at the crossroads, especially horse-drawn vehicles.

Attempts at cleaning and repair were made, but they did not succeed in making it work for long, and the fountain remained inactive for 50 years.

In 1861 the city decided to repair the supply pipes and restore the fountain.

Today it is formed of an octagonal basin whose edges are alternately straight and curved. In the centre is a square base whose corners are rounded into four volutes linked by a garland of flowers in soft stone. 

On each of the four sides of the pedestal, the water flows from a cast-iron lion's head gargoyle into the basin with a pleasant sound. A magnificent vase by the sculptor Jean Chastel adorns the top of the monument.

The square, centred around the fountain, has several elm trees which create a shady, restful atmosphere.
It is another place in the city where you can see the beauty of Aix's fountains

label: Oratoire Saint-Marc
description: Restored by Colonel Négrel in 1934.

label: Maison médiévale
comment: Medieval house
shortDescription: Medieval house
description: Late 15th century house with a corbelled facade, located in the old centre on the Place de la Concorde.

label: LA TOUR SARRASINE
comment:
Registered in the inventory of Historic Monuments since 1929,
the tower, now in ruins, measured 4 m x 4.30 m.
Thickness of the walls / 1.10 m thick - height / 6m
shortDescription:
Registered in the inventory of Historic Monuments since 1929,
the tower, now in ruins, measured 4 m x 4.30 m.
Thickness of the walls / 1.10 m thick - height / 6m
description: Included in the inventory of Historic Monuments since 1929, the Tower, today in ruins, measured 4 m x 4,30 m thick walls / 1.10 m thick - height / 6 m was probably part of a fortified and would have served as garrison, even in prison.The adjective 'sarrasine' is that of the 20th century.This tower appears on the arms of Vitrolles in the colours (yellow) gold and red, the colours of Provence.

label: Jardin de la Colline Puget
comment: It is the oldest public garden in Marseille.
shortDescription: It is the oldest public garden in Marseille.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.


Playground, lake, parking. The water basin was created in the 19th century. Made of wood and sand, the space for the little ones symbolizes the past. The original works of art of the workshop of Launay, a dry river, a sand fountain, are made of wood carved in the mass.

label: Val de Vignes
comment: One hundred hectares in the northern foothills of the Arbois Massif, on the territory of the commune of Velaux... One hundred beautiful hectares of Tuscan countryside, acquired in 1991 by the Department.
shortDescription: One hundred hectares in the northern foothills of the Arbois Massif, on the territory of the commune of Velaux... One hundred beautiful hectares of Tuscan countryside, acquired in 1991 by the Department.
description:
The Val des Vignes is therefore the poetic musicality of nature. It is also a privileged hillside location, which gives yet another idea of the variety of the Bouches-du-Rhône's relief. To the north-east, the estate borders the banks of the Arc. To the south, it overlooks the Etang de Berre where the small river flows. As a result, the panorama is unique. It plunges into the salty waters of
the pond, the surrounding hills and goes beyond, to the eastern districts of Martigues, under the Estaque mountain range

In the Arbois and its surroundings there are wild rabbits, which sometimes take advantage of small plantations resulting from educational work carried out by the schools of Velaux. The youngest of these rodents make excellent main courses for predators: large birds of prey like Bonelli's eagle.

Management of natural areas 
Domain of the General Council

label: Plage de Carteau
description: 500m x 150m beach. Ground type: sand. Road sign. Identification sign on site. Dedicated, free car park near the beach. Car park capacity: 30 vehicles. Equipment: refreshments, toilets, bins, telephone booths. Water activities: windsurfing, sailing, sailing competitions.

label: Eglise Sainte Famille
comment: This attractive copper-clad building was constructed in 2004 in a contemporary style,
shortDescription: This attractive copper-clad building was constructed in 2004 in a contemporary style,
description:
This attractive copper-clad building was constructed in 2004 in a contemporary style, featuring a monumental dome and stonework by the compagnons de devoir apprentices. The beautiful mosaics on its entrance door and tympanum are the work of Jesuit Father Marko Rupnik, an artist whose masterpieces can also be admired at Lourdes, Fatima and San Giovanni Rotondo.
Entering the church through a huge narthex, visitors are immediately struck by the imposing dimensions of its egg-shaped dome rising 19 m above them and measuring 18 m long by 26 m wide. The dome rests on four ten-metre high pillars of reinforced concrete, which weigh 50 tonnes each.
Each pillar is crowned with capitals of Chandoré stone sculpted with symbols representing the four evangelists: St Matthew is shown in human form, while the lion stands for St Mark, a bull symbolises St Luke and St John is represented by an eagle. As well as a Tavel stone baptismal font for children, made up of a basin resting on a cross-shaped base that twists a quarter of a turn, the church – unusually – contains a baptismal pool for adults, to the left of the altar.

label: Fontaine d'Albertas
comment: The Albertas Fountain is located in the centre of Albertas Square. It was erected in 1862.
shortDescription: The Albertas Fountain is located in the centre of Albertas Square. It was erected in 1862.
description:
In the 18th century the Albertas were one of the city's leading families.

In 1724, Henri Rainaud d'Albertas instructed Laurent Vallon to design the frontage and entrance of his private mansion.

To create an open outlook, between 1735 and 1741 he bought the houses opposite and had them demolished. He wanted a square to be built on the Parisian model of the royal palaces. It was Jean-Baptiste d'Albertas, his son, who continued his work from 1742 to 1746, assigning the project to Laurent Vallon's son Georges.

The fountain in the centre was built in 1862.

label: Musée Paul Ricard
comment: In 2021, the Paul Ricard Museum will open its doors at the Domaine de Méjanes.
shortDescription: In 2021, the Paul Ricard Museum will open its doors at the Domaine de Méjanes.
description: The Paul Ricard Museum is the first museum dedicated to the fabulous destiny of Paul Ricard, visionary and humanist entrepreneur. It is also an opportunity to discover the history of the Domaine de Méjanes, which is closely linked to that of the Camargue and all the people of the Camargue.

label: Eglise Saint Baudile
comment: Originally a Roman place of worship, the first Christian chapel was built in the 10th century.
shortDescription: Originally a Roman place of worship, the first Christian chapel was built in the 10th century.
description:
The present church is known to be built on the site of a Roman place of worship. The first Christian chapel was built there in the 10th century. All that remains of the 12th century Romanesque church is the semi-circular apse, followed by a window surmounted by a cupola which supports a bell tower and a nave with three vaulted broken barrel bays.
The church was extended circa 1430; two north and south aisles were added, each with two bays, forming a transept, and the entry door was extended to the south (Gothic-style additions). The 17th century saw the construction of the western gallery and a sacristy to the south-east of the chevet. In the 18th century, the north and south chapels were added to the arms of the transept. Saint Baudile Chapel houses wood panelling enshrining canvases which portray episodes from the life of Saint Baudile. Haphazard lateral chapels added subsequently (17th to 20th centuries) have marred the appearance of this exceptional church.
Architectural description
This church has Provençal Romanesque features, such as a stone paving roof and a broken barrel vault. The chancel is topped with an octagonal dome mounted on squinches. The Romanesque section was built by the same masons who extended the fortified castle. The roofs are made of layered slate stone.
