shortDescription: Located in the heart of the Five Avenues district, the library has been open since 1991. The historic building houses the Centre Fissiaux on the ground floor, the crèche above and the library on the third floor.
description:
The Panier and Cinq-Avenues libraries are currently closed.
all info here : https://www.bmvr.marseille.fr/lien-covid

___________________________________


Located in the heart of the Cinq avenues district, the library has been open since 1991. The historic building houses the Centre Fissiaux on the ground floor, the crèche above and the library on the third floor.

A space for everyone

Adults have a rich and varied collection at their disposal: 11,000 novels and documentaries, including foreign language novels, large print books, comics and manga, audio texts. 35 magazines and daily newspapers can be borrowed or consulted on site.
The children's section is on the mezzanine. There are nearly 10,000 books: albums, novels, comics and mangas, stories and documentaries for children and teenagers. 18 magazines are also available for loan or consultation on site.
The multimedia area offers a vast choice of 6,000 CDs as well as 2,000 DVDs of fiction and documentaries for children, young people and adults. They can of course be borrowed.

A place to live

Two work tables in the adult area and two in the youth area are available to the public
Each area also has a computer station that allows the consultation of the catalogue of all the libraries, the different events, the general regulations and the consultation of the subscriber file.
The library also has two Internet stations offering free consultation for one hour per day with the subscriber card.

Finally, this local library welcomes classes on Tuesday and Thursday mornings and organises regular activities for young people and adults.

label: Hôtel de Gras
description:
This remarkable walnut door is a classically inspired tripartite assembled door.


It includes delightful details which reflect the people of Aix's persistant taste for naturalism. The facade is plain while the woodwork is quite strong.


Text : OTAIX/ENTE

label: Esplanade Bargemon
comment: The current location of the Town Hall has been occupied since the 13th century by the Town Hall, which brought together merchants and consuls, and then, in the 15th century, the Town Hall.
shortDescription: The current location of the Town Hall has been occupied since the 13th century by the Town Hall, which brought together merchants and consuls, and then, in the 15th century, the Town Hall.
description:
But it was not until the 17th century that the Town Hall was built. It symbolises the new political status of the city ordered by Louis XIV who henceforth imposed the management of the city by aldermen and changed the port regime. Attributed to Mathieu Portal and Gaspard Puget, this beautiful baroque building also owes much to Pierre Puget, an architect from Marseille. Its particularity was to voluntarily separate the merchants on the ground floor from the aldermen on the first floor

Classified as a Historic Monument in 1948, the Puget Pavilion now houses the offices of the Mayor and 1st Deputy Mayor.

The underground development of the adjoining square by architect Franck Hammoutène led to the creation of the Espace Villeneuve-Bargemon, which won the 2006 Equerre d'Argent, the national architecture prize. This new space houses the City Council Chamber, work rooms and a vast museum area.

label: Hôtel Meyronnet de Saint-Marc
description: Hôtel de Meyronnet-Saint-Marc is a mansion which belonged to the Pignolo family in the 16th century. One of the family members, Louis Pignoli, was the first consul of Aix. It then belonged to Alphonse Meyronnet, attorney general at the Court of Audit.

label: Calvaire, Oratoires, Croix et Statues
description: A Calvary has been carefully restored on the Place de l'Eglise, between La Crau and the Alpilles.

label: Médiathèque Boris Vian
comment: A rich cultural programme with unmissable events for adults and young people. Lending, consultation of books, magazines, regional documentation, games, CDs and DVDs, internet access, free wifi
shortDescription: A rich cultural programme with unmissable events for adults and young people. Lending, consultation of books, magazines, regional documentation, games, CDs and DVDs, internet access, free wifi

label: Hôtel de Châteaurenard
description:
This mansion was built in 1650 by Pierre Pavillon, assisted by Jean Daret for the staircase painted in trompe-l’œil in around 1654, for the Member of Parliament Jean-François d’Aimar d’Albi, Baron of Châteaurenard. 

Famous as the house where the young Louis XIV stayed during his visit to Provence in 1660, this mansion has a magnificent state staircase, on a square well, decorated with trompe-l’œil paintings by the Flemish painter Jean Daret (1614-1668) who settled in Aix in 1636.

Inspired by Italian art, the artist painted a Doric colonnade behind which splendid architecture can be seen. 

Surmounting a classic frieze entablature, a skilful composition represents the allegories of the liberal arts – rhetoric, music, astronomy and painting – where the arms of the Châteaurenard family can be seen. 

Two cherubs are trying a padlock bearing the names of Aimar and Daret.

Delighted with this composition, the young Louis XIV appointed Jean Daret as painter to the King, which earned him countless commissions in Aix.

label: Parc des Sports et des Loisirs
comment: Sports and Leisure Park of Rognonas
shortDescription: Sports and Leisure Park of Rognonas
description: This amusement park, inaugurated in may 2013 is located over 4 hectares. To get there, you will follow a roubine this small canal for irrigation is a brand of agricultural territory. This recreation area has a track athletics, a synthetic and lawn, a fitness trail, a Mediterranean garden. Also the refuge of the Bird Protection League. 80 species have been identified 45 insect which some are protected. Accommodations have been made to preserve the ecosystem: birdhouses, hotel for insects, ramp output channel, local aromatic plants. A pedagogical path will explain the local botanical species and their specificities. This Park adjoins the area of Oleon where centuries-old plane trees and a St. Joseph statue visible from the Park.

label: Parc du Domaine de La Tour
comment: An eight-hectare urban sports park built on a former winegrowing estate with numerous sports facilities.
shortDescription: An eight-hectare urban sports park built on a former winegrowing estate with numerous sports facilities.
description:
It is a former agricultural domain transformed into an eight hectare park. 
1,5 km fitness trail with hedges to be jumped, block of drive, abdominal board and parallel bars. Fontainerie equipped with sprays and fountains. 
Vast open-air sports space, in free access. 600 m2 city stadium, beach volleyball ground, petanque fields, playground for children with an eight meter high tower and a bridge of ropes. Skateboard-park and street workout park. 
Amphitheater-shaped open-air theater of 600 places in terraces. Place for shows (concerts, theater performances, outdoor projections).

label: Hôtel de Simiane dit Hôtel de Grignan Simiane
description: The last house in the street, sold in 1730 by the grand-daughter of Madame de Sévigné, Pauline de Castellane, widow of the Marquis de Simiane.

label: Chapelle Saint-Etienne
comment: The Saint-Etienne (or Saint-Symphorien) chapel was built on the hill of the same name. Erected at an altitude of 116 metres near the ‘Vulturno’ plateau, it overlooks the etang de Berre, etang de l’Olivier and an area to which it has given its name: the Saint-Etienne district. It is reached via the aptly named ‘Chemin de Saint-Etienne’ which departs from the ‘Chemin du Tour de l'Etang’ after a very beautiful oratory.
shortDescription: The Saint-Etienne (or Saint-Symphorien) chapel was built on the hill of the same name. Erected at an altitude of 116 metres near the ‘Vulturno’ plateau, it overlooks the etang de Berre, etang de l’Olivier and an area to which it has given its name: the Saint-Etienne district. It is reached via the aptly named ‘Chemin de Saint-Etienne’ which departs from the ‘Chemin du Tour de l'Etang’ after a very beautiful oratory.
description: The chapel Saint-Étienne (or Saint-Symphorien) is located on the Hill of the same name. Erected at an altitude of 116 metres near the plateau called "Vulturno", it overlooks the étang de Berre, that of the olive tree and a sector to which it gave its name: the Saint-etienne area. Is accessed through the aptly-named "path Stephen 's" leaving the "path of the Tour de l'Etang" after a very beautiful oratory.It is a place full of history. Indeed, for many centuries all istreens roamed the "Chemin de Saint-Etienne" once per year during the traditional "Recampado" organised on 22 August. This procession, followed by a mass and a meal outdoors on the site of the Chapel, commemorated the vow made in 1720 when the "great plague". While the epidemic was severely Marseille and its surroundings, all the inhabitants of the village had promised to honour each year Saint-etienne if their sector was spared. This Chapel, located near the vault Saint-Michel, a spectacular view awaits you... Anxious to give life to one of heritages, among the oldest and the most symbolic of the town of Istres, Saint Etienne Renaissance association is working on its restoration.

label: Eglise Saint Maxime
comment: St Maxime Church
shortDescription: St Maxime Church
description: Don't miss St Maxime Church with its 11th or 12th century Provençal Romanesque nave, its apse and Gothic-style northern side-aisle, as well as the two Romanesque chapels which form a pseudo-transept. The origin of the Chapel of Christ (a regional Historic Monument) is controversial; some authors believe it to be Paleo-Christian. It received the 'Ruban du Patrimoine' award in 2003.

label: Fontaine des Quatre Saisons
description: This fountain, constructed circa 1869, is an unexpected masterpiece in a village which at the time had only 1,800 inhabitants.

label: Médiathèque Municipale
description: Eyguières has always been a rural village, with its olives, oil and soap brought to the Salon-de-Pce soap factory. There were many mills in Eyguières, water, wind and blood mills like here. Indeed, the media library is located in an old olive oil mill, known as a blood mill, which has been restored and fitted out to house books. We will discover there the millstone that used to grind the olives. It was powered by human or animal force, hence the name "moulin à sang" (blood mill). The paste thus obtained was deposited on scourtins (a kind of flat rope basket) which were superimposed under the press. The oil was collected in settling tanks and decanted into vats. Inside, you can admire a monumental fireplace and a well. Upstairs is the attic where the olives were stored.

label: Carrières de Bibémus
comment: The ochre molasse quarries of Bibemus used to supply the pale stone that is so characteristic of numerous monuments in the city of Aix en Provence.
shortDescription: The ochre molasse quarries of Bibemus used to supply the pale stone that is so characteristic of numerous monuments in the city of Aix en Provence.
description:
Situated between the route du Tholonet and the route de Vauvenargues, Bibémus refers to a rocky plateau, part of which was used as a stone quarry for a long period.

Use of the quarries goes back to ancient times and the stones were used to build Aix in the 17th and 18th centuries. In Cezanne's era, the quarries were practically abandoned. The painter rented a small hut there where he could keep his canvases and even sleep if he needed to. There he painted 11 oils and 16 watercolours in this landscape where mineral and vegetable complement each other.

As well as the viewpoint of Mont Sainte-Victoire and the nature portrayed in the painter's works, the site contains the very unusual motif of the orange rocks in geometrical shapes, from which Cezanne drew striking works that heralded Cubism and are renowned the world over.

Guided tour compulsory (reservation at the Tourist Office and on reservation.aixenprovencetourism.com). Unaccompanied tour not allowed.
Duration: 1 hour.

The site is located in the middle of nature, steep path requiring a good level of mobility. Walking shoes recommanded. The Tour takes around 1 hour.

label: Château de l'Empéri
comment: Perched on the rock of the Puech, the Empéri dominates the living room. This castle was from the ninth to the eighteenth s, residence of the archbishops of Arles.
shortDescription: Perched on the rock of the Puech, the Empéri dominates the living room. This castle was from the ninth to the eighteenth s, residence of the archbishops of Arles.
description: The book, which also hosted Kings of France, is a Museum of art and costumes and military history. It houses collections formed from the beginning of the century by Raoul and Jean Brunon, who, since 1967, are property of the Army Museum. The Museum presents in 30 rooms: the history of the French army of Louis XIV to 1918. Collections of the Museum of the army. Free for the military and personal defense. Final architecture, Roman, Gothic, renaissance.The visit to the castle is free, the Museum is paying off.

label: Eglise paroissiale Sainte-Agathe
comment: The parish church, of Romanesque origin (13th century), bore the name of Our Lady of Bethlehem. It is replaced by that of Sainte-Agathe, patron saint of the village
shortDescription: The parish church, of Romanesque origin (13th century), bore the name of Our Lady of Bethlehem. It is replaced by that of Sainte-Agathe, patron saint of the village
description: The parish church of Romanesque origin (13th century), was dedicated to our Lady of Bethlehem. He is replaced by that of Sainte-Agathe, patron saint of the village. In the seventeenth, the menacing building ruins, began restoration work, which will be supplemented by a larger campaign in 1760 - the Church had been forbidden to worship because deemed too dangerous. One built by a master Mason of Tarascon chorus, the sacristy, the Bell Tower and two chapels (St. Agatha and Virgin).The furniture and decoration are of the nineteenth century: the most notable item is a magnificent historiated XVIITH century marble altar. Acquired in 1793, after the devastation of the Church by the Patriots, he was ranked in 1907, at the request of the parish priest of the time, supported by Mistral. It comes from the Church of the Seminary of Sainte-guard of Avignon. The altarpiece, marble white, illustrated the said episode "pilgrims of Emmaus" described in the Gospel according to St. Luke: the risen christ is on his way two pilgrims desperate by his death and fleeing from Jerusalem. They offer him hospitality without knowing who he is. It is during the meal, when he takes the bread and give it to them that they recognize. It's that last scene is represented here.The Notre-Dame chapel also houses a Black Madonna of Walnut of the XIV °, Notre-Dame-de-Grace. Invoked against cholera in 1854, it is celebrated by a procession on August 28 & 29, remembrance of the miracle that she realized then. In provencal plate located on the front of the Church: "Dins aquesto gleiso're esta bateja Fred Mistral e lou weed day of the Anounciado, its Bell, Daiano, souna per ensen angelus a e clar dou poueto inmourtau lou.""In this church was baptized Frédéric Mistral and, the day of the Annunciation", the Daillane the bell rang with the angelus and the death knell of the immortal poet."

label: Moulin du Calanquet
description: Tour and explanation of mill - video film of the manufacturing - tasting products duration of visit: 30 to 40 minutes, reservation required for sold products groups: olive oil, tapenade, jams

label: Jardin de la Magalone
comment: In the heart of this garden nestled on the boulevard Michelet (surface 1,4 hectare), we find one of the rare bastides of the XVIIIth century, its owner Messire Raphaël de Magalon, gave it his name.
shortDescription: In the heart of this garden nestled on the boulevard Michelet (surface 1,4 hectare), we find one of the rare bastides of the XVIIIth century, its owner Messire Raphaël de Magalon, gave it his name.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.



In the heart of this garden nestling on Boulevard Michelet (surface area 1.4 hectares), we find one of the rare 18th century bastides. Its owner, Messire Raphaël de Magalon, gave it his name

The general design of the H-shaped bastide highlights the courtyard. Further on, on the left, stands a chapel.

Two decorative fountains symbolize the Rhône and the Saône. Beyond the last of the three terraces, a lawn bowls bordered by pruned boxwood, ends in a circular basin: in the four corners are placed vases from the castle of Grignan

On the sides, four statues on pedestals, represent the four seasons. The parterre on the right of the bastide is decorated with a hexagonal basin. Four other vases from the castle of Grignan highlight the four ends

The garden was redesigned in 1901 by the landscaper Edouard André. A true baroque garden, the values and perspectives, the spaces and depths take on their full relief by drawing geometric shapes.

label: Rue de la Machine
comment: In the heart of the village, there is a charming little street whose name is full of history: rue de la Machine. It is here that the first modern oil mill of Lançon was located
shortDescription: In the heart of the village, there is a charming little street whose name is full of history: rue de la Machine. It is here that the first modern oil mill of Lançon was located
description: It belonged to Mr. Emile Rassen. This mill was driven by a steam engine and the olives were pressed by a hydraulic press. The seven other mills in Lançon at that time were blood mills, that is to say that they were operated by animal or human force. Unfortunately the frost of 1957 sounded the death knell of the Lançon mills. If in the 18th century, olive groves occupied half of the agricultural land, no less than 50,000 olive trees are planted today in our commune. Today in Lançon, only the Château Virant estate has a working oil mill. It opened in 1996 and has a certain reputation in Provence and elsewhere. Many people from Lançon continue the ancestral tradition by bringing their olives to taste the oil.

label: Chapelle Saint-Alexis
description:
Raised in the 17th century and dedicated to Our Lady of the Assumption, this
chapel of dissimilar old stones was enlarged in 1704, as a result of the
as evidenced by the inscription on its new portal


Its bell tower was blessed by the Cardinal Archbishop of Aix Monsignor de Grimaldi. It is located in a magnificent Provencal hamlet, in a rural setting, attached to Eguilles and equipped with a very well restored wash house and a small oratory

Interior visit during Sunday Mass at 8am.

label: Marseille côté Sud
description:
Parc Chanot comprises an exhibition centre, a conference centre and a public park with numerous play areas for children. This is where the Marseille International Fair is held every year in late September and early October.
Dance school.
Inaugurated in 1992 and built by Simounet, the school houses the Marseille National Ballet Company. The building is turned in on itself, in the same way as a cloister, to maximise the dancers' concentration. 20, Boulevard Gabès.
Borely Château and park.
Formerly the property of the "Borély" family, which had its country house built here in 1766. This rich family of merchants held an enviable position in Marseille, and like other well-off merchants in the city, they owned many buildings and mansions. But more than a mansion, the Marseille soul was obsessed with the idea of "la bastide", a Provençal country house. The Borély bastide, which we now call a château, was at that time no doubt the largest and finest of them all, just as Louis Borély had wished.
In the middle of the 19th century, the city authorities bought part of the estate. After housing an Archaeological Museum there for many years, the Municipality has now handed the château over to the Regards de Provence Foundation which organises cultural events there. The grounds of 17 hectares, with lake, garden in the French style, rose garden, botanical gardens, shady lawns and cycling tracks, is a very popular park with the people of Marseille. It is located between the Huveaune river, the sea and the race course, right at the heart of new developments which are further emphasising its attractiveness: canoekayak centre on the Huveaune River, golf range at the race-course and huge circular track reserved for roller skaters, skate boarders and other non-motorised vehicles.
Château Pastré.
This former bastide stands in grounds of 1.1 square kilometres, between the sea and the hills. It was built during the 1860's by the architect Jean Danjoy in a reinterpretation of the Louis XIII style, subtly mixing Marseille bricks and the blonde stone of Arles. Since 1994 it has been the home of the Earthenware Museum, which boasts more than 12,000 ceramics from Marseille, the region, France and Europe, from Neolithic times to the present-day.

label: Parc Régis Vidal
description: Inside this park you will find an educational trail open to all, offering splendid views of the Castilian landscape. Its ambition is to contribute to the education of the youngest in the field of the environment. Educational trail, sports trail, skate board, climbing wall, picnic area.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
description:
1. On-site consultation is free of charge.
2. The loan of books is free of charge for Belcodènois and EUR 8 per year for non-residents. Each reader can borrow 4 books for one month.
3. The annual fee for the multimedia loan is 15 EUR per family and 23 EUR for non-residents, with a deposit of 45 EUR. Each family can borrow 4 audio CDs or CDRoms or Videos or DVDs for a period of one week
4. Internet subscription is free. For minors, parental authorisation is required.

label: Les canaux de la Crau et des Alpilles
comment: The Crau and Alpilles canals cross the northwestern part of the Bouches-du-Rhône
shortDescription: The Crau and Alpilles canals cross the northwestern part of the Bouches-du-Rhône
description: The ancient construction of the Crau and the Alpilles canals are essentially used for agricultural irrigation. However, they also provide drinking water and water for industrial use.

label: Un village en Pierre de Fontvieille
comment: Fontvieille has a relatively singular and homogeneous architecture, due to the use of ashlar in the construction. The village developed from the 15th century around the exploitation of stone quarries.
shortDescription: Fontvieille has a relatively singular and homogeneous architecture, due to the use of ashlar in the construction. The village developed from the 15th century around the exploitation of stone quarries.
description:
Fontvieille has relatively distinctive and homogeneous architecture, due to the use of dressed stone in construction. The village actually grew up in the 15th century around the operation of the stone quarries. The early part of the century saw the construction of the Château Royal de Provence in Tarascon, a huge and lengthy project which launched the quarry industry in Fontvieille. Originally located on the small plateau of Le Castelet, the village moved to the Vieille Font district around this time and thus got its name. Stone extraction provided employment for more than 200 workers at the time; they came and settled here with their families and were at the origin of the large-scale growth of the village. Over the centuries, the village developed the amenities required for its expansion. In 1765, Saint Pierre Church replaced Saint-Jean-du-Grès, which had become too small and in the 19th century, a huge covered wash house was built near the Vieille Font. This flourishing industry prospered until 1914, when almost all the labour force was requisitioned. After the War, the new materials which came onto the market supplanted dressed stone, which was very expensive.
To a certain extent, the current village was shaped by the presence of the quarries. Very simply laid out, the old houses of Fontvieille, most of them quarriers' houses, are cubic and relatively low (one or two storeys). The dressed stone used is generally exposed. The two storeys are sometimes separated by a slightly protruding string course.
Take the time to stroll through the old streets and discover this local architecture.

label: Parc Sainte-Catherine
comment: This 5ha park is a delight for walkers and children with its square. Very close to the banks of the etang de l’Olivier, the Mediterranean garden, the Castellan oppidum and Dinosaur'Istres, you can combine several walks on the same site.
shortDescription: This 5ha park is a delight for walkers and children with its square. Very close to the banks of the etang de l’Olivier, the Mediterranean garden, the Castellan oppidum and Dinosaur'Istres, you can combine several walks on the same site.
description: In this garden we find the unusual universe of Art Zoo, an artistic bestiary where animals have been given a new look by contemporary artists. There is also free access to a children's play area.

label: Chapelle Saint-Joseph
comment: Linked to the Baux family, traces of this chapel can be found as early as 1143. The brotherhood of Saint-Nicolas, gathering the seafarers, used to sit there.
shortDescription: Linked to the Baux family, traces of this chapel can be found as early as 1143. The brotherhood of Saint-Nicolas, gathering the seafarers, used to sit there.
description:
Renamed "Saint-Joseph", the former Saint-Nicolas chapel is located on the way to Berre and the pond

It was originally dedicated to the patron saint of bargemen, a particularly powerful trade in Marignane from the Middle Ages to the 17th century

We find traces of it as early as 1143, linked to the Baux family, and as such it remains the oldest of the three rural chapels in the area. It was the seat of the brotherhood of Saint-Nicolas, bringing together seafarers who, as in all port and maritime cities, enjoyed the right to bury their loved ones in the building or nearby. Some archaeological traces of burials have been discovered there. The patronal feast day of December 6 was also held there, which was in force in Marignane until the beginning of the 20th century, with Saint Nicholas having even eclipsed the ancient title of the parish church of Notre-Dame de Nazareth

The monument is well known according to its successive states, with its furniture and ornaments regularly described in the reports of the episcopal visits of the 17th and 18th centuries. It was rebuilt between 1693 and 1696, with eight buttresses and a new classical facade that can still be seen today. It is organized around a Doric style portal, a sober order adapted to a male saint, crowned by an aedicule with a niche. The whole is flanked by two rectangular bays and pierced by an oculus in the centre of the pediment. The chapel adjoins a communal cemetery opened in 1864, thus perpetuating the tradition of burial of former bargemen

Classified as a historical monument in 1983, it has been entirely restored. One can still see in the presbytery of the parish church the 17th century walnut statue of Saint Nicolas which was probably carried in procession during a sumptuous patronal feast that fell into disuse and was almost entirely secularized in the 19th century.

It can be visited in summer as part of the tours in the little tourist train organized by the Tourist Office of Marignane.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Polaris - Centre d'Art
comment: The main objectives of the Contemporary Art Center are to support young creation, the dissemination of contemporary art and artistic education. It hosts exhibitions and artistic workshops all year round.
shortDescription: The main objectives of the Contemporary Art Center are to support young creation, the dissemination of contemporary art and artistic education. It hosts exhibitions and artistic workshops all year round.
description:
Every year, its programme includes three exhibitions with the primary objective of supporting young creativity, the spread of contemporary art and artistic education, relying primarily on painting, drawing, illustration and the issue of the figure in present-day art.
The search for partnerships with intercommunal and regional cultural bodies, other art centres in France and Europe, and the meeting of disciplines and artists are at the centre of a synergy bringing creativity and sharing.
Numerous cultural actions complete the programme (internships, talks, debates...). Guided tours of the exhibitions can be booked.

label: Remparts et portes médiévales
comment: Ramparts and medieval doors of Noves.
shortDescription: Ramparts and medieval doors of Noves.
description: 12th and 14th century ramparts, including a belfry and two mediaeval gates in perfect condition.

label: Oppidum de Roquefavour
description: The Oppidum de Roquefavour, a perched site forming a real village with a preconceived plan, is the proof of an important indigenous occupation. It is located in the commune of Ventabren, a place called "Camp des Romains" or Baou de Mario. Covering an area of 6 hectares, it is recognized as one of the largest oppidas in Western Provence. Tradition and imagination wanted to see in the fortified village of Roquefavour a camp entrenched by the famous General Marius, but the stratigraphic study and the archaeological material collected allow us to affirm that the Oppidum of Roquefavour presents the characteristics of a Celto-Ligurian occupation.

label: La Maison des Années 50
comment: House from the 1950s
shortDescription: House from the 1950s
description:
The house of our elders takes us back to the 1950s. Everything has been recreated from that time, come and discover furniture, household linen and a multitude of objects from "another time".

Accompanied visit for the European Heritage Days and for the Christmas market.

label: Chapelle Sainte Croix
description: The Sainte Croix Chapel is located at the top of a rocky bar and has watched over the town of Auriol since 1554, when it was built. It was then partially demolished in the winter of 1793 and rebuilt in 1831. As early as 1563, 14 oratories were erected along the access road to the hill on which the Chapel of Saint Croix stands. Each oratory described the station it represented, painted on a wooden board, placed at the bottom of the niche.

label: Église Saint-François-d'Assise
comment: Parish located in the western part of the city.
shortDescription: Parish located in the western part of the city.
description: Mass on Wednesday at 8:30 am, Friday at 6:30 pm and Sunday at 11 am.

label: Parc Jourdan
comment: Parc Jourdan is a public garden located in the immediate vicinity of downtown, on the way to the University. It is one of the largest parks in the city and certainly the most emblematic. It is also one of the favourite places for a walk in Aix-en-Provence
shortDescription: Parc Jourdan is a public garden located in the immediate vicinity of downtown, on the way to the University. It is one of the largest parks in the city and certainly the most emblematic. It is also one of the favourite places for a walk in Aix-en-Provence
description:
This city park, covering 40,000m2, is reached from Rue Anatole France or Avenue Jules Ferry. It is on two levels: the lower part is in the style of a classical French garden, and a monumental double staircase leads to the upper part which is laid out as a romantic garden. 

In the upper part, a mansion houses "L'Oustaou de Provenco" in the Boissy Pavilion. There is open-air entertainment in the park throughout the summer. The park also contains a 17th-century statue called "Winter", Bottinelly's bust of Frédéric Mistral, and Philippe Solari's bust of Emile Zola. 

Bowling ground and children's play areas. 

History of the park: the creation of a municipal park and the expropriation of the Gavoty and Blachet lands, which were needed for the project, were decided upon in 1926 by the Debazac municipality, but it was not until 1929 that the Joseph Jourdan municipality purchased the plots.

The architects Couelle (the designer) and Peslier were the successive project managers of the landscaping works which began in 1932. In 1935 the municipal park was given the name of Joseph Jourdan Park.

label: Eglise Sainte-Anne
comment:
Weekday mass on Tuesday and Thursday at 8:00 am.
Sunday at 10:30 am alternating with St. Francis Xavier.
shortDescription:
Weekday mass on Tuesday and Thursday at 8:00 am.
Sunday at 10:30 am alternating with St. Francis Xavier.
description: Priest Jordi LLambrich.

label: Eglise Saint-Marc
comment: This small church presents on the façade above the monumental portal dated 1689, a small statue of Our Lady of the Rose from the 11th century, a remnant of the old church, and a stained glass oculus representing a lion, the symbol of St. Mark.
shortDescription: This small church presents on the façade above the monumental portal dated 1689, a small statue of Our Lady of the Rose from the 11th century, a remnant of the old church, and a stained glass oculus representing a lion, the symbol of St. Mark.
description: Inside the church is a monumental wooden altar-piece and a painting by the Aix artist Claude Arnuphy.

label: Place Jean Jaurès
comment: Restaurants, breweries and bars surround this very pretty place.
shortDescription: Restaurants, breweries and bars surround this very pretty place.
description:
In the immediate vicinity of the blue bridges and Ferrières beach.
Place of various activities such as the local producers' market (April to September).

label: Chapelle des Oblats - Eglise de la mission
comment: The Oblate Chapel (also known as the Church of the Mission) is a chapel of classical architecture located in the center of Aix-en-Provence. It is located on Place Forbin, at the top of Cours Mirabeau
shortDescription: The Oblate Chapel (also known as the Church of the Mission) is a chapel of classical architecture located in the center of Aix-en-Provence. It is located on Place Forbin, at the top of Cours Mirabeau
description:
Situated at the top of Cours Mirabeau, the chapel stands on the site of the former Carmelite convent (1625), then outside the city walls it was rebuilt between 1695 and 1701 to the plans of Thomas Veyrier who was also responsible for its decoration. His uncle was a pupil of Pierre Puget, architect of the Vieille Charité chapel in Marseille which had one of the first oval cupolas in the region. 


The Oblates' Chapel also has an elliptical cupola over the nave which is in the shape of a Latin cross, without side aisles, accentuating the impression of height. Bathed in natural light from a lantern skylight and four oeil-de-boeuf windows, it rests on composite pilasters with original decoration.


Two bas-reliefs by Thomas Veyrier which originally adorned the high altar are now kept in the Tapestry Museum. 


The frontage of the Oblats was redesigned by Laurent Vallon in 1697, and enhanced by a flight of steps. The chapel was listed in 1911.

label: Fontaine des Augustins
comment: Built in 1620, the fountain on Place des Augustins was converted into a public wash-house in 1786. It was rebuilt by the city in 1820, when it was adorned with a classical column of granite from the Gallo-Roman mausoleum of the Palace of the Counts of Provence.
shortDescription: Built in 1620, the fountain on Place des Augustins was converted into a public wash-house in 1786. It was rebuilt by the city in 1820, when it was adorned with a classical column of granite from the Gallo-Roman mausoleum of the Palace of the Counts of Provence.
description:
The base of the fountain is made of very hard Peynier limestone, and the structure was designed by an Aix architect, Mr Beisson.

For many years, in the days of steam locomotives, the water from the fountain was used to fill the station pond in order to supply the Alps trains. 

At the top of this column is a 12-branched copper star. It was listed in 1949.

label: Chapelle Saint-Symphorien
description:
Located in the Cazan valley at the exit of the village, the Saint-Symphorien chapel founded in the 12th century is a high place of pilgrimage. The original small chapel was modified until the 17th century in order to be able to welcome an ever-increasing number of pilgrims. It preserves many ex-voto, the oldest of which dates from 1654, paintings from the 17th and 18th centuries as well as precious statues of Saints. The pilgrimage takes place every year on 21 August and the third Sunday in October

You are a group and would like to take a guided tour? Contact the Tourist Office of the Massif des Costes on 04 90 55 15 55

label: Hôtel de L'Estang Parade
description:
Built in 1650 by Pierre Pavillon and Jean Claude Rambot, this private mansion is arranged around a square courtyard.

Its sober frontage shows the classical order: Tuscan, Ionic and Corinthian

label: Moulins du Cativel
description: Mills dating from the 16th century. These mills are typical of an agricultural village, they have areas (places where wheat was threshed). Precise date of the mills: 1567.

label: Eglise Saint Vincent
comment: Building classified as a historical monument in May 1908.
shortDescription: Building classified as a historical monument in May 1908.
description: The Church of Saint Vincent is an achievement its Abbots of Saint-Victor. She was in the 11th century, a simple Chapel of Romanesque style which was subsequently fortified.It contains a Gothic ciborium, floral art from the 15th century, of rare beauty.

label: Musée d'Archéologie Méditerranéenne
comment: Museum offers a  wide range of the Art of Mediterranean countries. A  full departement  is  devoted to Egypt.
shortDescription: Museum offers a  wide range of the Art of Mediterranean countries. A  full departement  is  devoted to Egypt.
description:
This collection is the most important in France after that of the Louvre. The Mediterranean Basin and Near East department has a very rich ceramic and lapidary collection, some of which are unique. One example is the Cretan oenochoe, decorated with the marine fauna of the Mediterranean. 

The richness of the collections
 Currently located on the second floor of the former hospice of La Charité, the Mediterranean Archaeology Museum presents collections mostly acquired during the 19th century and the first decades of the 20th century. Representing the eastern and central civilizations of the Mediterranean, they come from private collections, some of which have been assembled since the 18th century, from archaeological excavations and chance discoveries. By acquiring them from collectors and their heirs, or from art dealers, the museum does not become a simple collector. 
By making these collections public, it gives them meaning, on a scientific and cultural level. This is an opportunity to recall the history of a museum with more than 150 years of experience, which is now responsible for presenting its collections of antiques.

The department "Near East, Mediterranean Basin" of the Museum of Mediterranean Archaeology embellishes and enriches to offer the public from June 15, 2018 a new museography. A sociological and geo-thematic course will now offer visitors a better understanding of ancient civilizations by discovering what they have brought us and what they have left us ... From the birth of the city to the first alphabets, from the invention of glass to the technique of Greek ceramics, from the omnipresent polychromy on all ancient works to the most elaborate techniques of casting ... All these inventions, still used today, will be detailed and illustrated by a collection of 400 pieces. This new department, innovative in its discourse, will make the link between ancient and immediate history.
Some rooms may be closed. Please contact the museum before visiting.
Surface of the permanent exhibition : 800
Surface of the temporary exhibition : 1500

Due to a temporary technical failure, the museum's elevator is currently out of order. The Museums of Marseille apologize for the inconvenience and will do everything possible to welcome you in the best conditions.
streetAddress: ['2 Rue De la Charité', 'Centre de la Vieille Charité']

label: Hôtel de Ville
description: In classical style despite the two watchtowers that decorate its façade, the Town Hall was built between 1655 and 1658. Its orientation proves that the city had then freed itself from the belt of the ramparts that surrounded it in the Middle Ages. On its façade, two statues symbolize Prudence and Temperance. Its colour is due to the use of the stone of Rognes, or Saint Laurent.

label: Musée Grobet-Labadié
comment: Grobet-Labadié museum houses, in a  beautifuk XIXth century  private  mansion owning rich collections belonging to a merchant family from the Marseille bourgeoisie, at  its heigh after 1848.
shortDescription: Grobet-Labadié museum houses, in a  beautifuk XIXth century  private  mansion owning rich collections belonging to a merchant family from the Marseille bourgeoisie, at  its heigh after 1848.
description:
After Louis Grobet's death in 1917, Marie Grobet bequeathed the private  mansion and all the  collection it  housed to the city of Marseille.
Reflecting the tastes of a refined bourgeois society, fascinated and seduced by all forms of art, the French collections assembled in the second half of the  19th century admirably illustrate the artistic electicism of the " enlightened " connoisseurs of that  time.
The XVIII th century occupied  a  major part  in collections of the museum however High middle age, the  Rebirth  and XIX centrury are also represented.

Guided public tours on saturdays and sundays at  3 pm.
On appointment for  groups.
Worshops for  children during  holidays.
Library  opened to public, on wednesdays and fridays all day  long .
On thursday  afternoons on appointment.
 Museum welcome scolarship groups for  on reservations.

Surface  permanent  exhibitions: 550
Surface temporary exhibition : 0

label: Bibliothèque Yvan Audouard
comment: The Yvan Audouard library has more than 18,000 books for all ages.
shortDescription: The Yvan Audouard library has more than 18,000 books for all ages.
description:
It welcomes all the inhabitants who wish to borrow books or magazines and who wish to get information thanks to the encyclopaedias and documentaries at their disposal.
 The library also welcomes young and old at various cultural events.

label: Place des Martyrs
comment: Pedestrian area which hosts part of the large Jonquières market.
shortDescription: Pedestrian area which hosts part of the large Jonquières market.
description: Brasserie terraces and bars welcome you in this completely renovated and pedestrian area in 2013.

label: La ferme de Sedona
comment: Animal paradise on an American ranch
shortDescription: Animal paradise on an American ranch
description: At Sedona's farm, all the animals live together: gander, llama, rabbit, parrot, donkeys, chickens, cows...cohabit, and are released in the middle of the public who are delighted to get up close and personal with them. Fun activities are also offered: duck fishing, water slide, trampoline, sack race...

label: Chapelle Saint Jean
description: The chapel was built in 1935 by the Lumière Family which possessed lands all around. Of modern style, spacious and clear, with its 20 meters long and 8 meters wide, it is the place of worship of the area of beaches. A big court sheltered under reed screenings allows to celebrate services in summer.

label: Plage de la Calanque du Mugel
comment: "Plage de la calanque du Mugel" is a heavenly spot bordering translucent, turquoise waters.
shortDescription: "Plage de la calanque du Mugel" is a heavenly spot bordering translucent, turquoise waters.
description:
The site actually comprises two shingle beaches - one small and one large - both overlooking the surprising bay of La Ciotat, Bec de l'Aigle mountain and the nearby Ile Verte island.
This is an ideal place for all types of leisure activity: swimming, snorkelling, kayaking, paddle boarding or - if the weather is too hot - strolling in the park located just above.
The fjord and its park are sheltered from the Mistral wind by Bec de l'Aigle mountain. Thanks to its microclimate, the site is also home to a fascinating variety of tropical plants and animals, such as cacti, bamboos and birds of paradise.

label: Château de la Barben
comment: The castle and its garden have been classified as historical monuments since 1984. Their reopening is planned for July 1, 2021 under the auspices of the Rocher Mistral project
shortDescription: The castle and its garden have been classified as historical monuments since 1984. Their reopening is planned for July 1, 2021 under the auspices of the Rocher Mistral project
description: The 11th century fortress built on a rocky outcrop, the castle was the property of good King René in the 15th century and then the Marquis de Forbin for 500 years. Arranged in pleasure in the 17th century castle, it has magnificent gardens à la française designed by Le N��tre. Tapestries of Flanders, Brussels and Aubusson, ceilings to French, decorations of plaster, painted canvas, leather of Cordoba, the castle is fully decorated and furnished with time.Jumble of the castle in the old barns on Sundays.Shop at the entrance of the castle in a large vaulted room: souvenirs, objects of decoration, local products, Knights and princesses, educational games, library...Drinks, ice cream, cakes are served on a shaded terrace.

label: Niches urbaines de Maillane
comment: Eight niches are to be discovered in the streets of the village. Do not hesitate to raise your head.
shortDescription: Eight niches are to be discovered in the streets of the village. Do not hesitate to raise your head.
description: Niches are arranged at the corners of streets or above the entrances to homes.Small size (a few tens of centimetres), these niches usually draw an arc and their background is masoned in apse. This symbolically reminds the chorus of our churches.These modest arrangements have a role to protect the House and its inhabitants, or may be ex-votos, materialization of a vow to a Holy character.Eight niches are to discover the streets of the village. Feel free to lift the head.Architectural description-Niche of the Virgin (18 avenue Auguste Dailey): votive aedicula dated 1665 - Niche of the Virgin (angle of course Joan of Arc and avenue Auguste Dailey): located in the corner of a House, it is dated 1762. -Niche Saint-Roch (course Jeanne d'Arc): Niche dating from the 18th century, into a nice hotel in stone. It is a molded canopy topped by a dome, the lower portion is conical and decorated with leaves. Saint Roch is here accompanied by a dog, one of these attributes. -Niche Notre-Dame-de-Grâce (Notre Dame): built in 1855 in the rubble of a House wall, semicircular niche retains behind a grille the statue of the Saint. -Niche of Notre-Dame-de-Grâce (course Jeanne d'Arc): dated 1855, it still has its stem to lantern and is surrounded by pilasters. -Niche of the Virgin and child (rue Saint Pierre): one can still see the stem supporting the Lantern. The niche is semicircular, a small pedestal overhanging is supported by a jewel. -Niche of Saint-Roch (the giant Street): great niche dating from the 18th century, pyramidal scales four-poster. The statue is polychrome but severely damaged. -Niche of the Virgin (avenue Lamartine): Niche from the 17th century depicting the Virgin Mary on the façade of the House of the lizard (where lived Mistral with his mother from 1855 to 1876).

label: Chapelle Saint-Césaire
description: By following the D22 from Cazan, you arrive at Château-Bas, a large residence built in the 15th century and transformed in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries. To the south of the castle stand the ruins of a Roman temple dating from the 1st century BC. A chapel typical of Provençal Romanesque architecture is attached to the eastern wall of the temple. Consecrated in 1054 by the archbishop of Arles, it consists of a single nave with a semicircular vault and ends in the east with an apse covered with a cul de four. It was accessed through a door on the side of the nave only during guided tours of the Château-Bas site.

label: Terrain des peintres
description:
The queen of his childhood landscapes, and the obsession of his life as an artist, the Sainte-Victoire mountain dominates the painter's work: 44 oil paintings and 43 water-colours of it are conserved in the world's great museums and in private collections.

The most famous pictures were painted from this marvellous vantage point on Chemin de la Marguerite on the Lauves hill. 

The city of Aix-en-Provence has created the Painters' Ground here: facing the mountain, nine reproductions on lava stone of Cézanne's finest "Saint-Victoires" invite you to contemplation...

⚠ ⚠ There is no public toilets on site.

label: Le Mas
comment: Building used as a place of exhibition...
shortDescription: Building used as a place of exhibition...
description:
The first Provençal building in the village, it appears on the cadastre in 1830.
3 dates evoke its history
- 1670 on the basket-handle vault.
- 1770 on the lintel of the entrance door.
- 1869 on one of the windows of the first floor.
The municipality bought the building in 2008 and decided to restore it. A companion of the duty will participate in its renovation for all that concerns the size of the stones. Inside, a wall made "in tapie" has been preserved, at the time of the buildings were built in tapies i.e. in compacted raw earth. Now the mas is a building that is used for exhibitions, concerts and official wedding celebrations.

label: Hôtel Colla de Pradines
comment: The impressive Baroque mansion, completed in 1678, stands in the heart of the city.
shortDescription: The impressive Baroque mansion, completed in 1678, stands in the heart of the city.
description:
Built on the edge of an island of houses, once marshland recovered from the former Canal de Vauroux, the Hôtel de Colla de Pradines, opposite the contemporary Église Sainte Marie-Madeleine opens onto the lively Place de la Libération.

It was the holiday home of the powerful Italian family, de Colla de Pradines, from Aix.

With corner buttresses, pilasters and a balanced distribution of large picture windows, it is reminiscent of the homes built in the Aix area at the same time.

On the façade, a plaque paying tribute to Gérard Tenque (1047-1120), founder of the Hospitaller Order and who, it is said, was born in Martigues. His statue can be seen on the façade of the Église St Genest de Jonquières. Town hall from 1808 to 1983, the building sheltered the courthouse until 2018.

label: La Tour - Panorama de la Friche de la Belle de Mai
comment: The  year  2013 saw the inauguration of  a new  facility dedicated to a  contemporary  creation.The view, more precisely the rehabilitation  of La Friche de la belle de Mai gives a  new  impulse to the  Comtemporary  Art in the city.
shortDescription: The  year  2013 saw the inauguration of  a new  facility dedicated to a  contemporary  creation.The view, more precisely the rehabilitation  of La Friche de la belle de Mai gives a  new  impulse to the  Comtemporary  Art in the city.
description:
A new space for international and prospective contemporary art: the Panorama is a project labeled Marseille-Provence European Capital of Culture and in operation since 2013. Its architecture, designed by Mathieu Poitevin, interweaves large reversible and modular exhibition platforms that encourage the design of large-scale exhibitions, with intermediate formats that are conducive to partnerships and invitations. A new space where the accessibility to the roof terrace is thought as a real public square, where the relationship to the city is also offered as a panorama.

The Panorama is an imposing exhibition hall, a white box overlooking the Jobin courtyard, opening onto a large terrace with the proportions of a public square and offering a panoramic view of the city of Marseille (475 m2 and 150 m2 of glass surface, with 9m high ceilings).

Its programs are based on a policy of artists' residencies that are part of a dynamic of local, national and international networks and that offer another artistic permanence to temporary exhibitions. It aims to offer a panorama of plural contemporary creation in several ways.
streetAddress: ['41 Rue Jobin', 'Friche de la Belle de Mai']

label: Tour de l'horloge (Notre Dame de Lausa)
description:
Medieval church, it was built between 1150 and 1250, at the same time as the castle and the medieval village. Only its bell tower, known as the "Tour de l'horloge", overlooks the village.
This church has left as a legacy the beautiful cross, the choir lectern and the stalls which are in the present Saint-Vincent church.

label: Le Vieil Etal
comment: The Old Stall of the Right Street in Pertuis
shortDescription: The Old Stall of the Right Street in Pertuis
description:
Mostly from the 16th century, this house has preserved, on the first floor, a stall, or stone slab, on which the merchant or craftsman displayed his merchandise.
Above this old store, we notice, on the second floor, a beautiful window, or crossing, whose mullion and transom are molded
The distribution of the façade, the dimensions of the building, its location in a narrow and tortuous street, with a typically medieval layout, testify to a way of life at the end of the Middle Ages.
However, this street has been called "rue Droite" by the people of Pertuis since the beginning of the 16th century.

label: Les oratoires de Saint-Roch et de Saint-Eloi
description:
The oratory of Saint Roche was erected in 1884 at the expense of the population, in thanksgiving for the protection of the village during the cholera epidemic of the same year.
The oratory of Saint Eloi was erected on the occasion of the jubilee of the year 2000 by the brotherhood of Saint Eloi. Designed by Mr. Jean Vargas, it was made by volunteer sculptors from Mollégès. It marks the starting point of the "Carreto Ramado" race of Saint Eloi.

label: Le mur d'abeilles
comment: Also known as "apier", the bee walls were once used for the production of honey and wax.
shortDescription: Also known as "apier", the bee walls were once used for the production of honey and wax.
description:
The Cornillon Wall, located in the Camp Long district, is composed of 55 niches over 60 m long
It is carefully assembled with lintels and supports in large lauzes, the bottom covered with a large slab.

label: Château d' Alleins
description: Located in the heart of the village, the castle of Alleins presents remarkable vestiges. Known to have been the residence of the Renaud family from the end of the 15th century until the French Revolution, its history is much older. A 10th century cartulary evokes the existence of a primitive castle: "Allenii castrum" probably located in the same place. Property of the Counts of Provence in the 12th century, it passed into the hands of the archbishop of Marseille, Benoît d'Alignan in the 13th century. It is at the end of the XVth century that the Renaud family, of Arlesian origin, obtained this seigneury in reimbursement of expenses incurred in the service of the King. The Renaud family had the castle rebuilt to settle there permanently. At the end of the 17th century, the seigneury became a marquisate. But at the French Revolution, it is abandoned, the castle and land are sold as national property and the buildings are dismantled.

label: Ermitage Notre-Dame des Anges
comment: This site, inhabited in the Neolithic period and invested by a hermit in 1220, was dug and built in and on the rock (two caves were built in the church in 1625).
shortDescription: This site, inhabited in the Neolithic period and invested by a hermit in 1220, was dug and built in and on the rock (two caves were built in the church in 1625).
description:
Oratorians settled there in 1640, but from their vast settlement
the only thing that remains is the women's hostelry, of which one can
see the imposing size at the turn of a bend, next to the arches of the one
men

The discovery, at a distance, of this major place of pilgrimage in Provence is the pretext for a magnificent walk in the massif of
the Star, a short distance from the King's Pestle, and which provides a view of the
breathtaking views of Marseille, its islands and the Etang de Berre, as well as all the massifs of the region (Calanques, Garlaban, Nerthe, Sainte-Baume and Sainte-Victoire).

Pedestrian access to the unmarked viewpoint on the site (45 minutes) from the Sainte-Anne Pass.

label: Fontaine Fossati
description: 18th century fountain classified as a historical monument, on the only crow's-foot square in Marseille, formerly called Place des Fainéants.

label: Rue de la République
comment: It was in 1860 that it was decided to open the Imperial Street according to the urban planning principles of the Second Empire but also to hygienist theories and a clear concern for beautification.
shortDescription: It was in 1860 that it was decided to open the Imperial Street according to the urban planning principles of the Second Empire but also to hygienist theories and a clear concern for beautification.
description:
La Rue de la République.
In 1860 a decision was taken to create the Rue Impérial in order to meet with Second Empire town planning demands but also to comply with theories concerning public health and to beautify the town. This long straight street was in the Parisian Haussman style and was also intended to connect the city's historic centre to the newly-built Joliette port. The port was built in 1844 to cater for the rapidly increasing trading sector.
Two major problems, that of a downward slope and the natural wall formed by the Carmes Hill, were quickly overcome when a decision was taken to cut a 150-metre wide breach in the hillside in order to accommodate the new street. The 800,000 square metres of excavated earth were used to construct new port buildings.
Work began on the street in 1862 and the demolition and excavation work took two years to complete. 16,000 people were ordered to leave approximately 1,000 homes and the cost of this housing operation came to over one million Francs, more than a third of which was spent on compulsory purchase.
The Rue Impérial was officially opened on 15th August 1864 but the buildings still had to be constructed. These buildings, which were intended as an investment, were constructed in an eclectic style that combined the charm of the Renaissance with the rigor of the Neo-Classical. The people of Marseille, however, were not taken with the buildings despite every floor being provided with utilities such as running water and gas. The promotion of the street proved a complete failure. Also included in this town planning project was the reconstruction of Place Sadi-Carnot and that of Rue Colbert unfortunately this plan was only partly completed.
The present Rue de la République is a street of outmost importance to Marseille as it connects the south districts to the north districts and is at the centre of the Euroméditerranée project.
Saint-Cannat Church.
(listed in the Additional Inventory of National Heritage Sites in 1926)
The monastery of the Dominican Friars (Order of Preachers) was built at the end of the 16th Century. Building work on the church was started in 1558. It was consecrated in 1619 and dedicated to the Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary. In the middle of the 18th Century the Gérard brothers built the large Romanesque-style façade, the pediment and the upper section of which were removed in 1926 for safety reasons. The monastery was destroyed when the Rue Colbert was opened. The church became a parish church in 1803 and was dedicated to Saint Cannat, the former Bishop of Marseille. As in many other churches in Marseille, Saint Cannat contains precious works of art: the organ case, the polychrome marble high altar, the Notaries' chapel and paintings by the Provençal painter Michel Serre.

label: Jardin Place Mireille
description: Garden place Mireille

label: Chapelle Saint-Pancrace
comment: The chapel, dedicated in 1056, has been entirely renovated:
shortDescription: The chapel, dedicated in 1056, has been entirely renovated:
description:
Reconstruction of the ten side buttresses and an interior vault, repair of frontages and interior rendering, creation of a paved area around the building, improvement of surroundings.

It was built on the ruins of a Gallo-Roman villa.

label: Eglise Saint Jacques le Majeur
description:
The present church is located on the site of the former chapel of Saint-Jacques, which is already mentioned in archives dating back to the 11th century. The young parish of Mouriès (it only obtained the status of parish church in 1639) had no less than 3 of them. At the end of the 1760's, several deliberations alluded to the construction of a new church, better adapted to the large number of parishioners, which was completed in 1783. During the Revolution, the building was disused for worship and suffered relatively serious damage. Seven years later, it regained its original function thanks to the tenacity of Father Riousset. The bell tower, originally topped by a sort of bulb, was broken by an earthquake in 1909 and then rebuilt in its present form.

The façade, in classical style, is pierced by a rectangular portal framed by two monumental Corinthian pilasters supporting a triangular pediment. The date of the building's inauguration is engraved on the tympanum of the pediment. A semicircular bay at the top of the portal illuminates the nave. A standing statue stands on the sill. The aisles are articulated around the central part by means of counter-curves. Two fire pots punctuate the extremities. The interior is reminiscent of its Mausanese neighbour, Saint Croix. The four bays are sheltered by a barrel vault on a double hip pierced with low arch openings and marked by double arches. The almost flat chevet was covered with murals.

label: Croix Gardianne
description: The Guardian Cross, conceived and drawn at the beginning of the century by the painter PAUL Hermann. This cross is the symbol of the Camargue.

label: Presbytère
comment: Facing the side entrance of the church, the presbytery was known as a priory, cloister house or cloister since at least 1429. It cannot be visited
shortDescription: Facing the side entrance of the church, the presbytery was known as a priory, cloister house or cloister since at least 1429. It cannot be visited
description:
Facing the side entrance of the church, the presbytery was known as a priory, cloister house or cloister since at least 1429

This parish enclosure has always been organised around an inner courtyard, which was once bounded by crenellated walls

You enter it from the street that used to be the square, by climbing a few steps in front of a 17th century door
Bordered by pedestals with Doric capitals, it can still be identified with the work of the mason Claude Arvel, who was responsible for rebuilding the facades in 1615. The habitable part was only raised by one floor between 1624 and 1630

To the west, the house adjoins a large agricultural hall known as the tithe hall or, originally, the "tinel". It housed the wine fermentation vats (the "tynes"), made of oak from 1622 onwards, as well as the tenth part of the harvests owed by the farmers of the lands belonging, through the parish, to the chapter of Arles. It has the peculiarity of a ceiling with arches very similar to those of the nave of the church, but with diaphragms supporting a floor
At the back, the space with a cross was conceived as a grain storage room, initially isolated by a partition that has now disappeared

The side courtyard along Charles Esmieu Street (the former town pit) contains the old cemetery, which was enlarged several times between 1597 and 1651, until it was moved in 1864 to the vicinity of the chapel of Saint-Nicolas (now Saint Joseph)

The presbytery still has a 17th century walnut statue of Saint Nicholas, as well as a set of 19th century painted tin shields representing the Ascension, probably ornaments for torches or processional sticks used during the Rogations celebrated at that time in the agricultural localities.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Plage du Phare
comment: In Fos-sur-Mer, in the extension of the marina and the Saint Gervais beach, is the beach of the Lighthouse, a small beach of sand and pebbles that the Saint Gervais Lighthouse seems to protect
shortDescription: In Fos-sur-Mer, in the extension of the marina and the Saint Gervais beach, is the beach of the Lighthouse, a small beach of sand and pebbles that the Saint Gervais Lighthouse seems to protect
description:
Plage du Phare
"Plage du Phare" is situated in Fos-sur-Mer, just after the marina and "Plage Saint Gervais". This small, shingle beach, stretching out under the watchful eye of the "Phare de Saint Gervais" lighthouse, has also benefited from the immense efforts made by local authorities and inhabitants to reinstate this stretch of the coast to its rightful status as a bathing and water sports venue. "Plage du Phare" offers basic facilities and an adjacent car park. It has been awarded the European "Blue Flag" for ports and beaches since 2006.

label: Site et grottes de Calès
comment: After taking the Calade (stone path), one enters the circus through a fortified enclosure on both the north and south sides.
shortDescription: After taking the Calade (stone path), one enters the circus through a fortified enclosure on both the north and south sides.
description:
Inside, at the base of the two cliffs to the east and west, you can discover 58 of the 116 troglodyte caves found in the Calès site. Initially, these caves were created by extracting blocks of stone necessary for the construction of the feudal castle (which overlooked the cirque). They were then transformed into troglodyte dwellings to accommodate the population living in this circus under the lord's supervision (up to 220 people). You can see suspension rings, silos, dripstones on the outside, beam holes). A green arrow allows you to discover the Cirque de Calès. Start 100 m behind the village church. You can continue your walk by discovering the church of Saint-Denis de Calès, and the ruins of the chapels Ste-Marie and St-Jean.

[Currently closed to the public for works]

label: Les Docks de la Joliette
comment: This district dates back to the beginning of the 19th century, a period marked in Marseille by strong economic growth and major urban development.
shortDescription: This district dates back to the beginning of the 19th century, a period marked in Marseille by strong economic growth and major urban development.
description:
This district dates from the beginning of the 19th century, a period of great economic expansion for Marseille and of major urban development. The Old-Port had reached saturation point, due in particular to the arrival of steamships. So in 1842, a project to extend the port to the Joliette area was adopted. Work on the port ended in 1853.
A brand new port facility was built at the meeting of land and sea routes, and the "Compagnie des Docks et Entrepôts" was founded. Building of the docks, which are more than 400 metres long, was directed by Gustave Desplaces from 1858 to 1863. The docks include four groups of warehouse buildings that are connected to each other and end with the company's magnificent administration building (built in a neo- Louis XIII style). Each warehouse has six levels of storage space and is built around a central courtyard. They can be compared to London's docks, which no doubt were a source of inspiration for Desplaces. They are the most modern of Marseille' Second Empire development projects and the most expensive after the Cathedral and the Prefecture.
After a period of almost total neglect, the Docks have been restored to their former splendour thanks to the remarkable rehabilitation project undertaken by architect Eric Castaldi.

label: Parc de la Révolution
description:
Right in the city centre, this park is located along the Rhône and regularly hosts events organised by the city's various associations.
Its surface area and its privileged location on the banks of the river make it an ideal location for the organisation of large-scale celebrations.

label: Chapelle Saint-Roch
comment: Chapel of Saint-Roch in Orgon.
shortDescription: Chapel of Saint-Roch in Orgon.
description:
This walk ends with the discovery of the site of Saint Roch Chapel on Mont Savoy hill.
To get there from the Municipal Tourist Office, cross the D7n, turn right at the start of the Chemin de la Mine and then climb the Saint Roch gravel path at the start of the Chemin des Piellettes.
Saint Roch Chapel is on the wooded site of Mont Sauvy. The cross you passed was erected in 1803 as testimony to the religious revival that followed the Revolution.
Saint Roch, who was born at the end of the 13th century and spent his entire life working to help plague victims, has his chapel on this site; it was erected in the 17th century and extended in 1720. In that year, a terrible plague epidemic desecrated Provence. This scourge had many victims in Orgon, but the number of deaths was considered small compared with neighbouring communes. The people of Orgon and their consuls then vowed that they would hold a solemn procession to Saint Roch Chapel on 16 August every year, to thank Providence for saving them from this danger,
The Chapel is open on Easter Monday and 16 August.

label: Chapelle Saint Estève
comment: St Estève Chapel, the central point of St Estève Janson
shortDescription: St Estève Chapel, the central point of St Estève Janson
description: This 12th century chapel is dedicated to Saint-Estève (Saint Etienne, in Occitan). It is the central point of the village, at the time "lieu-dit Saint Estève", which was built around the chapel.

label: Plan d'eau de Plantain - Lac de Peyrolles
description:
On the former quarry site, the nautical base was inaugurated in 1997 and the site is gradually being developed to offer visitors ever more activities, space and comfort.

You will find at your disposal :

A refreshment bar,
Two toilet blocks with showers,
Picnic tables and playgrounds for children from 3 to 14 years old,
Petanque, beach volleyball and beach soccer fields,
Ping pong tables,
A paddling pool reserved for children under 6 years old,

Supervised swimming on weekends in June and then every day in July.

Parking is charged during the summer (rates available at the Peyrolles Tourist Office).

label: Plage le Petit Méjean
comment: Pebble beach in the calanque du Petit Méjean
shortDescription: Pebble beach in the calanque du Petit Méjean
description:
Pebble beach. Road sign. Identification sign on the site. Paid parking area (100 to 120 vehicles). A restaurant nearby. Small beach with low capacity. Dogs accepted. No sanitary facilities.
Direction les calanques from the town centre. Pass the Redonne in the direction of Méjean.

label: Village de Miramas le Vieux
description:
The remains of Miramas le Vieux are very well restored. The village is carried by a rocky table which is bordered by an enclosure. From the Old Village one has a very extensive view of the wild side of the Etang de Berre and the hinterland. The village has preserved its old houses with double entrances. The remains of the castle, built in the 12th century, show a vaulted passage with a cross vault. The 15th century church is decorated with a bell-tower-arcades.
The chapel Saint Jullien XII°inscribed in the inventory of the historic monuments is a jewel of the Provençal Romanesque art.

label: Chapelle Sainte Consorce
description:
It is the furthest place of pilgrimage from the village: on the side of the Concors, 8 km away and at an altitude of 750 metres. One goes there on pilgrimage on Whit Monday and, in times of drought, to beg for rain. The chapel is mentioned in a collection of the archbishop's rights and revenues kept at the National Library and probably written between 1282 and 1323. It was administered by a brotherhood
The building is very small: six meters by four. A wooden statue, the work of Joseph Armulphy of Aix-en-Provence in 1466, discovered in a path after the Wars of Religion, is now in Arbaud's office in Aix-en-Provence.
According to legend, Consorce and Tulle were daughters of Senator Eucher and his wife Galla in the 6th century. Eucher, probably a widower, retired to his estate, either at Beaumont or at the Baume Lyonnaise, where ambassadors from the church of Lyon would have gone to make him their archbishop. Tulle would then have retired to Sainte-Tulle (Alpes de Haute-Provence) and Consorce, after a stay in the mountain of Concors, would have devoted himself to charitable works. (Allègre 1956)

label: Four banal
description:
Restored in 2007 by the town hall and fitted out by the Association for the Conservation of Heritage, this space can be seen during guided group visits on Thursday mornings in summer. During the European Heritage Days, the oven is revived and batches of breads are distributed.

It was around this communal oven that the demands for freedom crystallized as early as 1788. This "right to bake" which required everyone to come to this place to bake their bread, with an obligation to pay 20% to the lord, disappeared with the night of August 4, 1789 which saw the abolition of privileges.

label: Eglise Sainte Marie
comment: St. Mary's Church is the historical church of the village. It was built in the Middle Ages and is a former dependency of the feudal castle. It is attested that some lords of the village are buried there
shortDescription: St. Mary's Church is the historical church of the village. It was built in the Middle Ages and is a former dependency of the feudal castle. It is attested that some lords of the village are buried there
description:
This disused church, on the upper square of Puyloubier village, was the first parish church of the canton. Its construction began in the 9th century, and it became the church of Sainte Marie in the 11th century. 


After being rebuilt and added to several times between the 13th and 16th centuries, it was finally abandoned in the 19th century.


In 2005, restoration work began on the walls and staircase with a view to creating a cultural venue in the future.

label: Plage de Saint Gervais
comment: The Saint Gervais beach, very close to the marina, is part of it and its configuration, a sheltered cove, protects it from the Mistral wind.
shortDescription: The Saint Gervais beach, very close to the marina, is part of it and its configuration, a sheltered cove, protects it from the Mistral wind.
description:
Plage de Saint-Gervais
Fos-sur-Mer is home to 6 km of well-kept beaches. The town suffered from the effects of pollution from its nearby petrochemical plants for many years, but huge efforts have been made by the local authorities and inhabitants to protect the environment and improve its quality. These efforts have now been rewarded for some years by the European "Blue Flag" label, granted for the quality of its waters. "Plage Saint Gervais", situated adjacent to the marina, is a delightful cove sheltered from the Mistral wind. This little, pebble beach is easy to reach and also offers toilet and shower facilities and a nearby bar-restaurant.

label: CHAPELLE SAINT JULIEN
description:
Situated "outside the walls", at the foot of the ancient castrum of Miromaris, inside the current cemetery, the Chapel of Saint Jullien, a jewel of Provencal Romanesque art of the 12th century.
Classified since 1928.

label: Hôtel de Ville de Tarascon
description: In 1644, the decision was made to build a new consular house. Four years later, Tarascon Hôtel de Ville was born (Louis XIII style). The façade was inspired by examples in Arles and has a corbelled stone balcony and a niche which houses the statue of Saint Martha with the Tarasque. Tarascon Hôtel de Ville was considered a very fashionable building in the mid-17th century. The other characteristics, which include pelmets, plant-based sculptures and bouquets of acanthus on the façade and around the windows, are very sombre in style. The Hôtel de Ville has been restored a number of times over the years and its façade was listed as a national Historic Monument in 1976.

label: Village des Saintes Maries de la Mer
comment: Make a detour to Saintes Maries de la Mer, this town "on the sand" is home to a large part of the Camargue national reserve. The access is done by crossing the landscapes of the Camargue, a change of scenery guaranteed!
shortDescription: Make a detour to Saintes Maries de la Mer, this town "on the sand" is home to a large part of the Camargue national reserve. The access is done by crossing the landscapes of the Camargue, a change of scenery guaranteed!
description:
The city was built by the sea, in the Rhone delta (Camargue delta), between the marshes and the Mediterranean. This considerably limits the cultivation of crops but was favourable to grazing. Thus horses and bulls are undoubtedly part of the landscape and life of the Saintois and are associated with festivals throughout the year.
Also, when one moves away from the historical centre, one crosses on the road the "cabanes de gardian", modest residences of the gardians, the fishermen, the salt workers, the paluniers and the shepherds.

label: Statue de Tartarin et d'Alphonse Daudet
description:
"Large white canvas baggy pants, small sticky jacket with metal buttons, two red belt feet, around the stomach, naked neck, shaved forehead, on his head a gigantic chechia (red hat) and a blue stream of a length!...With that, two heavy rifles one on each shoulder, a large hunting knife on the belt, on the belly a cartridge belt, on the hip a revolver swinging in his leather pocket. That's all... Ah! Sorry, I forgot the glasses, a huge pair of blue glasses that came in handy to correct what was a little too fierce in our hero's face!"

This man was Tartarin, Tartarin of Tarascon, the intrepid, the great, the incomparable Tartarin of Tarascon."

"In France everyone's a bit of Tarascon": Alphonse Daudet.

The city of Tarascon, famous thanks to the adventures of the famous Tartarin lion hunter, inaugurated this statue in 2013 in homage to Alphonse Daudet, the Provencal writer who described so much about the landscapes of our region and its inhabitants.
This statue is the work of the artist Christiane CHAMAND-DEBENEST and the foundryman Joël DESMET from the company Artfonte.

label: Calanque du Mugel
comment: The Calanque du Mugel is an exceptional natural site nestled in the shelter of the Bec de l'Aigle massif.
shortDescription: The Calanque du Mugel is an exceptional natural site nestled in the shelter of the Bec de l'Aigle massif.
description:
A true geological fortress built on the secondary streams whose pebbles formed during the eras, in a reddish conglomerate, the "Poundingue" of La Ciotat, the Calanque du Mugel is an exceptional natural site nested in the shelter of the Bec de l'Aigle massif.
