The calanque is home to the Parc du Mugel, a verdant setting that invites you to take a walk and discover the many plants of our region.

label: Le jet d'eau
comment: The jet of water on the etang de l’Olivier, located more than 80 metres from the shore in the Castellan cove, reaches a record height of 50 metres.
shortDescription: The jet of water on the etang de l’Olivier, located more than 80 metres from the shore in the Castellan cove, reaches a record height of 50 metres.
description: Huge flag liquid, it embodies the ambition and the vitality of a city respectful of its environment and turned towards the future. It also helps to facilitate the oxygenation of the pond of the sole Olivier in France!Technical innovation the water jet is installed on a chassis of 6 metres, surrounded by 50 cm below the level of the water for a better integration in the pond. This metal structure, stainless steel, weighs 2200 pounds. The water column is powered by a pump with a power equivalent to 125 horsepower, 3.5 meters under water. Aesthetic prowess the water jet is lit the night by a beam of 14 projectors. 8 projectors diffuse white light directly in the column. 6 projectors installed on the float Alternatively diffuse red, green or blue light. In numbers average height of the Jet: 50 meters water output speed: 120 km/h flow rate: 80 litres/second pump with a total output of 92,000 watts of lighting power: 2100 watts

label: Jardin du Prieuré
comment: Acquired by the city of Martigues in 1990, it has a surface of 1.2 ha.
shortDescription: Acquired by the city of Martigues in 1990, it has a surface of 1.2 ha.
description: It is the place of important events. Today, a simple relaxing meadow dotted with majestic linden trees, this park will be enriched with Mediterranean tree species.

label: They de la Gracieuse et They de Roustan
description:
- Location:
Continuation of the Napoleon beach. 
- Size: 1,387.85 ha.
 - They de la Gracieuse: long sand spit of 6 km to the west limit of the Gulf of Fos. It forms a natural breakwater and is driven mainly by the sandy flows from the Rhone, which provoked the grounding of shipwrecks causing a deviation from frontal "folds" to the Gulf and the anchorage of Carteau. The spit itself is the result of the convergence in the 19th century of four Theys: Roustan, at the mouth of the Grand Rhone, Eugene, the Balancelle and the Gracious ("they" means fast evolving sand spit incorporating a deltaic headland or an adjunct sedimentary body).
This area includes all of the They de Roustan and the They de Gracious dunes. This is a supralittoral environment where the vegetation cover is mainly formed by ammophiletum, agropyretum, Salicornietum fruticosae and Thero-Brachypodion for environments less exposed to salt.
- Flora and natural habitats:
The flora and vegetation are composed of several species and psammophytic and halophytic formations near sansouire, with some interesting elements: Spartina versicolor formation, Echinophora spinosa and Pancratium maritimum dunes, temporary brackish waters at Ruppia or Zostera and especially Matthiola tricuspidata, known in mainland France only in two site; the latter and that of the Giens Peninsula. Schoenoplectus pungens populates the banks of the Rhone and plays a major role in the alluvium and which also exist on ZNIEFF facing the They de la Palissade.
- Fauna:
They de la Gracieuse et le They de Roustan boast four major species and 12 remarkable species. They host an interesting parade with colonies of night herons and little egrets, as well as Bittern singers, Anatidae including Red-crested Pochards, raptors including Western Marsh-harrier, waders including the Redshank, the Eurasian Oystercatcher, the Black-winged Stilt, the Avocet, the Tern and the Little Tern and sparrows including the Greater Short-toed Lark and the Savi's Warbler mostly related to salt marshlands and wetland formations. The otter, becoming very rare in France and in Provence, is present in this area.

label: Moulin Saint-Joseph
comment: In the hollow of a shady and green valley lies the Saint-Joseph Mill, which dates back to the 16th century. It is the last mill in the Bouches-du-Rhône.
shortDescription: In the hollow of a shady and green valley lies the Saint-Joseph Mill, which dates back to the 16th century. It is the last mill in the Bouches-du-Rhône.
description:
All made of wood, where the MONTEAU family perpetuates the ancestral moulding thanks to the hydraulic energy of the waters of the Touloubre, resulting in huge millstones transforming into flour cereals from organic, controlled and certified farming.

The mill has been listed as a Historic Monument since 1933.

This mill is still in operation and produces organic flours (wheat, rye, spelt, buckwheat, khorasan, rice, chickpea) on sale in sachets of 1 to 25kg.

label: Le mur végétal
description: Created by the famous botanist Patrick Blanc, the vertical garden covers and decorates the northern part of the Max Juvenal bridge : a wall of living, breathing greenery in a built-up area.

label: Hôpital Caroline
description:
The Caroline Hospital is located at the end of Ratonneau Island, which together with the islands of Yew, Pomeges and Tiboulen forms the Friuli archipelago. A major work by Michel-Robert Penchaud (1772-1833), this sanitary facility was designed as a "machine to cure" yellow fever. But by the time it was handed over to the health authorities in 1828, this terrible scourge no longer threatened the Mediterranean basin

Rehabilitated by the architect Vaucher, the Caroline Hospital became the new lazaret of Marseille, after the destruction around 1850 of the continental lazaret of Arenc. Its activity is still mentioned during the inter-war period. In 1944, the islands of Frioul were bombed by the air force of the French Liberation Forces for the surrender of the occupying German garrisons. The buildings were "blown up". The Caroline Hospital is nothing more than a field of ruins

In 1978, the association for the revival and animation of the Caroline Hospital was created to safeguard the site and undertake its restoration, thanks to an agreement that links it to the City of Marseille, owner of the premises. Today it hosts concerts during summer festivals.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de la Roque
description:
From the 12th to the 15th century, it was the parish church, camped on the hill with a breathtaking view over the valley
Its Romanesque nave is flanked by a Gothic chapel which houses many ex-voto's including some paintings evoking the times and daily life of the Jouquards in past centuries
The chapel stands next to the remains of the former seigneurial castle, of which only one tower remains.

label: Vestiges de l'ancienne Abbaye Saint-Honorat
description:
Saint Honorat Abbey in Tarascon was founded in accordance with the wishes of a layman, Rostaing de Gantelme; having survived the massacre of the Sicilian Vespers in 1282, he ended up in the Lérins Islands, opposite the city of Cannes, while fleeing the Italian coast. There was a Clunisian monastery on the islands at the time, founded by Honorat of Arles in the 5th century. Rostaing de Gantelme swore to found a Benedictine monastery to prove his gratitude to God. He was not to fulfil his promise, which was not executed until 1352, by his grandson Jean, Seneschal of Provence. The Tarascon Benedictines were placed under the authority of the monastery of Lérines and Jean Gantelme granted them the Campredon estate on the current territory of St Pierre de Mézoargues, property he obtained from Queen Jeanne. Of the 30 nuns who lived in Saint Honorat, Gantelme stipulated that at least 15 had to come from Tarascon families and be accepted free of charge. The first Abbess was therefore Béatrix d'Albe de Roquemartine, a member of a famous local family. The 'Great Convent', as Saint Honorat was generally known, did not close until the Revolution in 1790.
Architectural description:
Only the Abbey portal is visible from the street. Opposite the château is a curious, high and very narrow façade, on which two pilasters with Ionic capitals frame a depressed arch opening. Above this are two high rectangular bays. Both sides of the façade are bordered by monumental pilasters supporting a large triangular fronton surrounded by a cornice with very wide eaves. The frieze on the entablature features alternating triglyphs and metopes, decorated with bucrania.

label: Médiathèque de Rousset
comment: On more than 1000 m² you can consult and borrow works among more than 35 000 books and periodicals for adults and children, 5000 music CDs, more than 1900 films.
shortDescription: On more than 1000 m² you can consult and borrow works among more than 35 000 books and periodicals for adults and children, 5000 music CDs, more than 1900 films.
description: Library

label: Cimetière du Grand Saint-Jean
comment: Situated 12 km from Aix-en-Provence town centre, on wooded land in a magnificent setting of Provençal forest made up of Aleppo pines, umbrella pines, evergreen oaks, pubescent oaks and junipers.
shortDescription: Situated 12 km from Aix-en-Provence town centre, on wooded land in a magnificent setting of Provençal forest made up of Aleppo pines, umbrella pines, evergreen oaks, pubescent oaks and junipers.
description:
The town of Aix-en-Provence first envisaged the creation of a cemetery back in 1975. The estate of Grand Saint-Jean, bequeathed by the family of Estienne de Saint-Jean to the town, was selected as a suitable site: 45 of the 200 hectares of the estate were reserved for this purpose. A mixed cemetery was created, with traditional sections and landscaped sections, preserving as many of the existing trees as possible. 

Today, with its 8 000 plots and its exceptional landscapes, the cemetery of Grand Saint-Jean is classed among the most beautiful landscaped cemeteries in Europe.

Electric buggies are available for elderly people or people with reduced mobility and the cemetery is accessible to people with reduced mobility.

The cemetery is regularly used as a film set for television series.
streetAddress: ['Cimetière paysager du Grand Saint Jean', 'Route Du Grand Saint Jean']

label: Souleiado
comment: Founded in 1988, this atypical museum mixes memories of the Souleiado house and the history of fabric printing in Provence.
shortDescription: Founded in 1988, this atypical museum mixes memories of the Souleiado house and the history of fabric printing in Provence.

label: Eglise Saint Vincent
description:
Albaron Church existed in the Middle Ages and depended on the château of the same name. It was originally dedicated to Saint Vincent and became a parish church in 1230.
It was ruined by the Religious Wars and rebuilt in 1638. It was paid for by the faithful, thanks to the resolve of Archbishop Aubert de Barrault and donations from Don Antoine de Rampelle.
It was destroyed during the Revolution. The current church was built in 1884.

label: La Grande Plage
comment: The Grande Plage de Fos-sur-Mer, Tourism & Handicap certified
shortDescription: The Grande Plage de Fos-sur-Mer, Tourism & Handicap certified
description:
Sandy beach, toilets, restaurants, refreshment bar, parking.
From the RN568 exit Fos Ville then direction Les Plages and the port.

label: Abbaye Saint-Pierre-des-Canons
description:
Visitors arriving in Saint-Pierre-des-Canons will gladly linger to contemplate the grandiose panorama and taste the charm of this soothing site.

At the end of an alley, the abbey building: the gable, the facade and the terraces are closely related, by their style, to these vast povençal bastides spread in the 18th century in the Aix-en-Provence region. However, the chapels leaning against the cliff, the wing of a cloister, and various outbuildings, including former troglodytic dwellings, bear witness to a much more distant past.

At present, the Dominican Contemplative Sisters of St. Mary Magdalene have undertaken a new rehabilitation of the abbey to offer a monastic welcome.
It is now a place of spiritual retreat (rooms, troglyte rooms) that can be visited by appointment.

label: Oppidum du Castellan
comment: The oppidum du Castellan is a rocky promontory in the southern part of the etang de l’Olivier. Steeped in history, it has a magnificent view of the town and the lagoon.
shortDescription: The oppidum du Castellan is a rocky promontory in the southern part of the etang de l’Olivier. Steeped in history, it has a magnificent view of the town and the lagoon.
description:
It is approximately 250 m wide by 500 m long and rises to 40 m above sea level at its highest point. The path on the eastern side of it (not marked) leads up to the summit. This path probably replaced an ancient staircase carved into the rock. Close to the summit you can see a Gallic inscription carved into the rock wall. We can read the word ‘MATPON’ with the M and A joined. According to scientists, it is an invocation to the Mother Goddess.
You can also see the remains of a rutted track. The site was occupied from the 6th century BC until the High Middle Ages. The highest point of the Castellan was the site of the tomb and skeleton of a man who, at 1.80 m or 5' 11", was tall for that period.

Today, the Castellan hill is home to Dinosaur'Istres, a dinosaur discovery trail, with more than forty specimens represented

‘The gardens of the etang’ trail introduces you to this site steeped in history.

label: Parc de Carlevan
comment:
Carlevan Park is located in a privileged, pleasant and welcoming site.
It offers a place of relaxation allowing walks and leisure activities for the youngest.
shortDescription:
Carlevan Park is located in a privileged, pleasant and welcoming site.
It offers a place of relaxation allowing walks and leisure activities for the youngest.
description: Carlevan Park is located in a privileged, pleasant and welcoming site.It provides a place of relaxation for the promenade and leisure for the smaller activities.You will find on this site about two hectares, a former building known as "The castle of Carlevan" implemented since the 19th century.True remnant of Provencal gardens of the 18th century, this park is home to a rare heritage.Aware of this asset to preserve commune focussed to restore and promote the heritage tree and historical existing, preserve a space of calm and rest in the heart of the garden, evoke through different development memory of places and the Proven��al classical gardens and finally create places of life educational and useful: arboretum, thematic and playgrounds for children (Swing)(, Eagle's nest, cabin and giant mushrooms).Greenery in the heart of Allauch to discover without more waiting...

label: Mémorial de la Marseillaise
comment: It is located in the room of  the Paumme game  where the corps  of Marseille federates  who made the ' chant de l'armée" du Rhin' famous before it was baptised " des marseillais" and later raised to the rank of national hymn.
shortDescription: It is located in the room of  the Paumme game  where the corps  of Marseille federates  who made the ' chant de l'armée" du Rhin' famous before it was baptised " des marseillais" and later raised to the rank of national hymn.
description:
It is all about  a unique history interpretation centre where the  spectacular is supported down by  an impressive wealth  of cultural and historical resources.

How to visit : 

- Tuesdays and fridays at  10 am and 2 pm Reception of schoool children, day-care centres, public of the social field on  reservation only by email.

- Tuesdays and fridays 10.30 am and 3 pm Reception of  individual public without reservation. You  need to go to musée d'histoire de Marseille first in order to  buy the  tickets .Indeed, it is a combined ticket with  Musée des Docks romains and Musée d'histoire de Marseille.

label: Presqu'île de Port-Miou/ Sentier du Petit Prince
description:
In the footsteps of the "Path of the Little Prince".
A walk of wonder and discovery of the Calanques from 1h - 1h30 from the Presqu'île.
In front of you stands the highest sea cliff in Europe, a real listed natural monument overhanging the sea by nearly 394 m.
This massif, known as the Soubeyrannes cliffs and the Cap Canaille, stands out by its colour. Unlike the white limestone of the Calanques, the geology of this site is largely composed of brown limestone sandstone and siliceous pebbles of river origin which give it its characteristic ochre colour.
In front of you, "the most beautiful and saddest landscape in the world"!
This is where the Little Prince disappeared. It was here, off the coast of Cassis, that Antoine de St Exupéry completed "his march towards God" in 1944.
He took part in the last reconnaissance missions before the landings in Provence. He will have seen neither the landings nor a liberated France, nor the victory of good over evil.
Thus, Antoine de St Exupéry will have fulfilled his destiny, that of a free man committed to collective action in defence of the values of humanism, that of a noble soul in search of perfection.

label: Eglise Saint-Jean Baptiste du Faubourg
comment: The project designed by Laurent Vallon in 1697 was never completed. Fine high altar, 18th century.
shortDescription: The project designed by Laurent Vallon in 1697 was never completed. Fine high altar, 18th century.
description: The pulpit is by Jean-Baptiste Rambot.

label: Monastère des Clarisses Capucines
description: The monastery is home to the Clarisses nuns of the order founded by St François of Assisi and St Claire (1212).

label: Marais de Saint Chamas
comment: To the north-west of the Etang de Berre, lie the marshes of Saint-Chamas, made up of the Petite Camargue and the Palous.
shortDescription: To the north-west of the Etang de Berre, lie the marshes of Saint-Chamas, made up of the Petite Camargue and the Palous.
description:
This wetland of more than 100 hectares corresponding to the Touloubre delta offers an unusual approach to the banks of the Etang de Berre, of great ecological interest.
The paths open to the public that run through the site allow you to discover a mosaic of very different environments: scrubland, salt meadows, pine forests, ripisylve, freshwater reedbed, sansouïre, barrier beach, where rare plants and birds (about 2000 species observed), mammals, fish, amphibians and various insects (31 species of dragonflies) live side by side.

Management of natural areas 
Domain of the Conservatoire de l'Espace Littoral et des Rivages Lacustres (Conservatory of Coastal Areas and Lake Shores)

label: Lou Pitchoun Museon Dou Calissoun
comment: Inaugurated on November 10, 2018 by Serge Billet, MOF and World Pastry Champion, the small museum dedicated to the 15th century Aix delicacy the calisson is located just a stone's throw from the Saint-Jean de Malte church and the Granet museum, Mazarin district
shortDescription: Inaugurated on November 10, 2018 by Serge Billet, MOF and World Pastry Champion, the small museum dedicated to the 15th century Aix delicacy the calisson is located just a stone's throw from the Saint-Jean de Malte church and the Granet museum, Mazarin district
description:
This space, (new headquarters of the Confrérie des Compagnons du Calisson), is an important tourist visit for lovers of Provencal culture and anyone interested in the history of the calisson and the almond. Let us not forget that Aix was the world capital of almonds in the last century. You can discover old tools of calissonniers and confectioners such as a drainer for candied fruits, a sieve for almonds, a machine to make calissons, a plodder for almond paste, as well as period archives such as the order of requisition of the bells of the Saint-Jean-de-Malte church by Bonaparte, the history of the Martelly vow of 1630 and the legendary blessing of the calissons and other documents retracing the history of this delicacy that has become part of the gourmet heritage of the city of Aix.

Guided tours, intended for individual visitors or for groups (20 people maximum) can be scheduled by the museum. Conferences on the history of the calisson can also be organized by the dean of the calisson makers of Aix on request.

Good discovery or rediscovery to all!

label: Médiathéque d' Entressen
comment:
220,000 documents, on-site and remote services :
Novels, comics, films, documentaries, albums, magazines, daily and local press...
shortDescription:
220,000 documents, on-site and remote services :
Novels, comics, films, documentaries, albums, magazines, daily and local press...
description: Pole adult

label: L'EGLISE Saint-Gérard
comment: In the heart of the old village, discover the church of Saint Gérard Tenque. Within it, several remarkable elements, including paintings from the 17th and 18th centuries, classified as regional cultural heritage, and a gilded wooden high altar.
shortDescription: In the heart of the old village, discover the church of Saint Gérard Tenque. Within it, several remarkable elements, including paintings from the 17th and 18th centuries, classified as regional cultural heritage, and a gilded wooden high altar.
description:
The first parish church dedicated to Saint-Gérard Tenque, founder of the Order of Malta, was located at the bottom of the old cemetery of Roucas (vestiges still visible)
With the roof leaning on the side of the rock, rock falls and damage were frequent. The Council of the community decided to build a new church outside the ramparts, completed in 1744. The coordination of the work was entrusted to the architect from Aix-en-Provence, Georges Vallon

It was designed in the Romanesque style with a bell tower with a Byzantine dome, and within it: a gilded wooden high altar symbolizing the Old and New Testaments, attributed to the sculptor Pierre Puget, and several paintings from the 17th and 18th centuries, classified as regional cultural heritage and restored in 2004 at the same time as the church, including the Assumption of the Virgin (1709), signed by Jean-Claude Cundier, as well as two busts made of plastered wood (St. Peter and St. Gerard)

A detailed brochure is available from the Municipal Tourist Office.

label: Porte St Jean
description: 14th century. It has crenellations and barbicans for defensive reasons and took its name from St John the Baptist Chapel, which is in the same area. The superb golden Virgin was installed in 1866, with the inscription: 'posuerunt me custodem', which translates as 'They (the people of Tarascon) made me keeper'. The gate has been a regional Historic Monument since 1930.

label: Plage du Verdon
comment:
Sand beach.
Verdon beach is a beautiful beach of 300m, made of sand and therefore very popular with the inhabitants of Martigues.
Protected by a large cove which shelters it from the wind, it has all the necessary facilities for coming with the family.
shortDescription:
Sand beach.
Verdon beach is a beautiful beach of 300m, made of sand and therefore very popular with the inhabitants of Martigues.
Protected by a large cove which shelters it from the wind, it has all the necessary facilities for coming with the family.
description:
The beach is supervised, the toilets are equipped, the bars and restaurants are nearby.
The little extra of the Verdon beach is the pedal boats which allow you to go for a ride and admire the scenery from the sea.

Swimming assistance for people with disabilities: 
- The tiralo is not a boat but an aid to swimming
used with a companion. It allows you to swim without leaving your wheelchair.
- The Hippocampe: a multi-activity wheelchair, all terrain and floating. It allows its user to move on the sand to the sea, to enter the water and to leave the chair while swimming.
Available from Monday to Friday from 11am to 5pm (excluding public holidays) on prior registration at least 24 hours in advance with the Pôle Santé Handicap on 04 86 64 19 91.
Blind guide dogs accepted.

The beach is supervised:
 - On the weekends of 4/5/6, 11 and 12 June 2022, from 11am to 7pm.
- From 18 June to 1 July 2022, from 11am to 7pm, every day.
- From 2 July to 28 August 2022, from 10am to 7pm, every day.

Schedules of showers and WCs available on site:
From June to August: 9 a.m. - 8 p.m. In September: 11 a.m. - 8 p.m.

label: Plage Prado Nord
comment: Prado Sud beach is a pebble and gravel beach, 280 meters long, preceded by large areas of lawn. It is equipped with a first aid station, lockers, snack bars and garbage garbage cans.
shortDescription: Prado Sud beach is a pebble and gravel beach, 280 meters long, preceded by large areas of lawn. It is equipped with a first aid station, lockers, snack bars and garbage garbage cans.
description:
In July and August 2022, the Grand Bleu association will offer swimming lessons (free activity in collaboration with the City of Marseille)
From June 1st to August 31st 2022, the beaches will be supervised 7 days a week from 9:30 am to 7 pm.

In order for all Marseilles residents to fully enjoy the beaches and swimming, the City of Marseilles has multiplied initiatives in favor of the disabled and more generally those with reduced mobility.
The beaches of Prado Sud and Prado Nord were the first coastal beaches to be awarded the "Tourism and Disability" label in France
the beaches of Prado Sud and Prado Nord were the first coastal beaches in France to be awarded the "Tourism and Disability" label in 2005.
This label was renewed in 2016.
Several criteria contributed to obtaining this label: taking into account the various disabilities, the quality of the reception, the beach and sports activities.
The Prado South and Prado North beaches are fully accessible to wheelchair users and to blind or visually impaired people and mentally or psychologically handicapped people.
Eight "Tiralos", amphibious vehicles, are available for the more severely disabled to reach the water and enjoy the swim.
For those who are able to swim independently, physical assistance is available for entering and exiting the water.
The staff of the Division of Disabled Persons is present all summer long to welcome and individually accompany people with disabilities.
This staff is reinforced by 9 seasonal workers for the months of July and August.
Two prefabricated structures and a tent complete this system by offering air-conditioned changing rooms, toilets, accessible showers, as well as a medical bed and a patient lift to facilitate transfers.

Reservations must be made by contacting the Division des Personnes Handicapées at 06 32 28 93 99
Metro Castellane or Rond Point du Prado + bus 19 and bus 83.

label: Eglise La Viste St Paul
description:
Curé "in solidum": for the parishes St Louis, La Viste, La Cabucelle: Jean Christophe Leurent (Cté de l'Emmanuel).

Mass on Sundays at 9:00 a.m.

label: Mas de la Cure
comment: The Mas de la Cure is composed of an important built heritage of more than 3000 m² (farmhouse, chapel, wine cellar, old forge, old refectory, farm sheds, sheepfold...).
shortDescription: The Mas de la Cure is composed of an important built heritage of more than 3000 m² (farmhouse, chapel, wine cellar, old forge, old refectory, farm sheds, sheepfold...).

label: Site archéologique de Saint-Laurent de Cabardel
description: The Saint-Laurent de Cabardel site has provided many elements of the history of the village. Archaeological digs begun in the 1970s have led to the discovery of many remains from the Neolithic period (4000 years before our era), a Gallo-Roman villa dating from the 1st century before our era as well as the foundations of a 5th century church and its necropolis.

label: Château d'Avignon
comment: The Château d'Avignon in Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer was built by the Avignon family in the 18th century. The estate consists of a landscaped park, in the middle of agricultural fields. Guided tour on the 1st Sunday of each month.
shortDescription: The Château d'Avignon in Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer was built by the Avignon family in the 18th century. The estate consists of a landscaped park, in the middle of agricultural fields. Guided tour on the 1st Sunday of each month.
description:
The Château, in the heart of Camargue, takes its name from one of the estate's owners: François Joseph d'Avignon d'Arlatan, who constructed the first building there in the 18th century. But its finest moment came at a time when the rich Marseille businessman Louis Noilly Prat bought it and turned it into a hunting lodge. However, the interest of this building lies mainly in the rather crazy dream that he achieved here. To make it more comfortable and provide the equipment needed for agricultural work, he installed everything the era had to offer in terms of up-to-date technology, including electric lighting, central heating, hot and cold running water and fully fitted bathrooms. It was the 1890s palace of modern conveniences.
You will be able to see all this when you reach the château, together with works of art including paintings, ceramics and embroideries; everything is still in its place, from the linen to the chamber pot, via pots and pans.

label: Oratoire Saint Marc
description: Oratory erected by the brotherhood of winegrowers and farmers. It is in front of this oratory that the procession of Saint Mark stopped on April 25th on his return from Saint Peter's by the Glauges.
streetAddress: ['Chemin De Saint Roch à Saint Marc']

label: Musée départemental Arles antique
comment: Built near the remains of the Roman circus of Arles, on the banks of the Rhône, the museum offers its visitors a fascinating vision of archaeology.
shortDescription: Built near the remains of the Roman circus of Arles, on the banks of the Rhône, the museum offers its visitors a fascinating vision of archaeology.
description:
A careful scenography, a classification that mixes chronology and thematic, models and plans, try to make the ancient testimonies of the city, from prehistory to late antiquity, accessible to everyone.

Since its opening in 1995, and in order to constantly diversify its offer of visits to the public, the museum has added an auditorium and the Roman-inspired Hortus garden adjacent to the museum and the remains of the Roman circus.
Excavations in the Rhône have considerably enriched the collections, and an 800 m2 extension has been added to the building in order to present nearly 500 objects relating to trade and navigation, including the 31 m long barge Arles Rhône 3, which was brought out of the river and restored, an imposing testimony to trade by river in Roman times. A policy of temporary exhibitions, general or thematic visits of the collections, courses and workshops for all types of public allow us to apprehend the richness of an archaeological heritage of which we are the heirs. Coming to the museum means going back in time to meet a tangible antiquity and to measure how close it is to us.
streetAddress: ['Avenue de la 1er division Française libre', "Presqu'Ile du Cirque Romain"]

label: Le lavoir "Lou Lavandou"
description:
Dated 1759. It is a solid building made of Lambesc stone, like many hotels. Indeed, until the end of the XIXth and beginning of the XXth century, the quarries of Lambesc gave appreciated stones
by the master builders. The arches support a stone roof
which houses four double basins fed by the waters of the Bonne Fontaine.

label: Musée des Alpilles
comment: Located in the historic centre, the Alpilles museum is housed in the Mistral de Mondragon hotel, a former Renaissance mansion. Listed as a historical monument since 1862, the building is built around an admirable interior courtyard.
shortDescription: Located in the historic centre, the Alpilles museum is housed in the Mistral de Mondragon hotel, a former Renaissance mansion. Listed as a historical monument since 1862, the building is built around an admirable interior courtyard.
description:
Museum of the Alpilles in Saint Rémy de Provence
Located in the historic centre of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, the Museum of the Alpilles is situated in the Hôtel Mistral de Mondragon, a former Renaissance private mansion. Classified as a historic Monument in 1862, the building, with its impressive architecture, is built around a magnificent inner courtyard.
The museum was created in 1919 by Pierre de Brun and was completely renovated from 2002 until early 2005.
Ethnology...
A visit to this museum offers a greater understanding of the current natural and human landscapes of this part of Provence, which extends between the Rhône, the Durance and the Alpilles Massif.
A walk in time and space, the permanent exhibition of the Museum of the Alpilles evokes different unsuspected or little-known facets of regional heritage:
from the Hypselosaurus, the gentle dinosaur who once roamed the area, to traditional costumes and Camargue bull-fighting, via the growing and trading of teasel, opium poppies and seeds
... and modest art
Internationally famous works by Vincent van Gogh and Albert Gleizes were created here. But alongside these is the often remarkable work of inconspicuous, anonymous or locally famous creators, to which the museum also wants to attract attention. They include the ex voto placed in the chapels in the 18th and 19th centuries, decorated reels and canes, santons made of unbaked clay and astonishing illuminations by Augustin Gonfond.
The photography and graphic arts collection and the typography and engraving studio reveal the establishment's new focus on works on paper and on contemporary engraving.

label: Village de Saint Zacharie
description:
Saint Zacharie is rightfully called ‘the fountains village'. It is watered by 16 fountains adorning public places, most of them erected by the mid 19th century.
Saint Zacharie is one of the access doors to the Sainte Baume Mountain.
The village has also other various elements of heritage :
The ‘Saint Jean Baptiste church', (inscribed to the additional Ancient monuments inventory) with parts dating from the 11th century, the ‘Holy shoe of the Virgin' relic (named 'Lou San Sabatoun' in Provencal language).
The ‘Saint Clair chapel', dating from the 16th century
The ‘Penitents chapel', (inscribed to the additional Ancient monuments inventory), dating from 1844: woodworks of the choir, stalls, preach-pulpit, stand with balustrade, communion gate...

The Farouquette: this house was offered by Reda Caire (a famous French singer of the 1930's and 1940's) to his mother, in 1934.

label: Plage du Jaï
comment:
Beach labeled Blue Flag!
Pleasant, with sand and lawn, over 600 meters long. The bathing area is moved to the entrance to the Jaï with development of the first-aid station and installation of fun activities (football and beach volleyball fields).
shortDescription:
Beach labeled Blue Flag!
Pleasant, with sand and lawn, over 600 meters long. The bathing area is moved to the entrance to the Jaï with development of the first-aid station and installation of fun activities (football and beach volleyball fields).
description:
Jaï beach is the large beach of Marignane. It is supervised in the summer, from July 1 to August 31 from 10:30 am to 6 pm, Monday to Sunday.

A strip of land more than 5km long and 250m wide on average, which marks the separation between two ponds, that of Berre and that of Bolmon.

Suffice to say that its surface is immense and that the wind, often frequent in this corner of the department, allows a high practice of board sports such as kitesurfing or windsurfing but also water sports. Especially since part of the beach is prohibited for swimming to let thrill seekers express themselves on the water. In addition, a fitness area has been set up at the entrance to the Jaï with a dozen devices made available (bodybuilding, elliptical bike, etc.) which are self-service and free!

The Blue Flag has been floating there since 2016.

Jaï beach and all its equipment are accessible to people with reduced mobility. Indeed, 2 parking spaces are reserved for them as close as possible to the swimming area. A fitted path leads to the swimming area as well as the sanitary block with 2 showers and 2 accessible toilets (women and men). It is also possible to reserve an amphibious wheelchair made available free of charge with the help of a support staff: reservation at 06 61 30 61 72 it has the label: Handiplage level 2.

label: Place du Lavoir
comment: Place where the horse monument is located.
shortDescription: Place where the horse monument is located.
description: The Place du lavoir et des " tanfasian " was built in 1924 on the square next to the castle by the Viscount de Bonfils, mayor of Mollégès. This construction was part of a series of urbanization works that were relatively expensive. As a result, the opponents of the mayor said in Provençal "amé tant de frés, tant fasian aco ... o tant fasian come aco ... "(With so many expenses, we would have done this... or that...) So that, out of derision, the friends of the mayor spoke of this square as "place des tanfasians".

label: Mucem
comment: Thee sites,  three different  athmospheres offering rewarding and  amazing proposals to be  discovered on 40 000 m2: the  Mucem is  a true  21 century  museum able to  seduce with  a wide range  of activities.
shortDescription: Thee sites,  three different  athmospheres offering rewarding and  amazing proposals to be  discovered on 40 000 m2: the  Mucem is  a true  21 century  museum able to  seduce with  a wide range  of activities.
description:
Some would be able to travel thanks to exhibitions, the others will enjoy a reading, a concert,  a projection.. Or simply enjoy  an  open air  walk in  the Mediterranean gardens of the  Fort Saint-Jean. On the  ground floor, a  permanent exhibition dedicated to the main steps of the Mediteranean civilizations history. On the  second floor, two big exhibitions a year will be devoted to society, cities, places or  human beings playing a part in Mediteranean.

Saint Jean fort: 15 000 m2.

The vaulted rooms in the  stone bowels of Fort saint Jean, a  12 th century historical monument will feature exhibition galleries on the themes of celebration  and performance.

Mucem retains a unique heritage bringing together a diversity of  objects that is original in the museum world: paintings, prints on sculptures alonside furniture, tools, vehicles, jewellery, shop decorations, festive on traditional clothing etc..

The  conservation and resources centre: 10 000 m 2.

 Nearby the train station in district of la Belle de mai, a third site houses the conservation centre designed by the  architect  Corinne Vezzoni. 
The place of the collections' conservation is an innovative place and also open to the  public.

Permanent exhibition surface: 15 000.
Temporary exhibition surface : 4700.

label: Les forts du Vieux Port et les consignes sanitaires
comment: The harbour is surrounded by two forts: Fort St. John and Fort St. Nicholas.
shortDescription: The harbour is surrounded by two forts: Fort St. John and Fort St. Nicholas.
description:
Saint-Jean Forteress.
The area around the forts is believed to have been inhabited since antiquity but it was not until the 13th Century that the Hospitallers of the Order of Saint John of Jerusalem (later to become the Knights of Malta) settled here and gave its name to the quarter. Some remains of their presence may still be seen. King René had the huge square tower erected following the attack by the armies of Aragon in 1423. It was built where the Maubert tower had stood and was used to protect the entrance to the port. The navigation light-tower was built in 1644 and the Chevalier de Clerville built the fort as part of Louis XIV's instructions that formed the large-scale plans for Marseille. He had a flood-proof pit dug to isolate the fort from the city. The fort was used as a garrison and later as a prison during the Revolution. During the Second World War the German army used the fort as an ammunition store. In 1944 the store exploded causing major damage to the fort itself and to the Pont Transbordeur. The fort became a National Heritage Site in 1964.
Saint Nicolas Forteress.
From the middle of the 17th century, favoured by the Fronde insurrection, Marseille defies and and holds up to ridicule royal authority. As soon as peace with Spain leaves the king with his hands free, the city is occupied by the army. To enter the city, Louis XIV, in March 1660, does not hesitate to open a breach in the medieval walls. Some of its stones are used again – as a symbol – in the construction of the Saint Nicolas citadel. Louis XIV orders the building of a fort as well as the extension of the town and the creation of a new Arsenal. Several sites are considered for the building of the citadel and finally a hill « at the entrance of the port, behind the Saint Victor abbey whose area is reasonable enough to build a strong enough fort to maintain the King of authority forever ». The work progresses at a frenzied rhythm by Chevalier de Clerville. In 1663, the high fort (Entrecasteaux) is finished, and in 1664 the low fort (Ganteaume). Vauban, during a visit to Marseille, criticizes the construction which he judges to be « the worst of the universe » !

label: Chapelle des Trémaïe
comment: The funerary steles of "Trémaïe" and "Gaïe" are located at the foot of the rocky spur and the castle. The bas-relief is interpreted as a representation of the Three Marys, "Tre Maïre" in Provençal.
shortDescription: The funerary steles of "Trémaïe" and "Gaïe" are located at the foot of the rocky spur and the castle. The bas-relief is interpreted as a representation of the Three Marys, "Tre Maïre" in Provençal.
description:
At the foot of the Les Baux rock, to the east, is the site of Les Trémaïe.
A stele cut into the rock represents three characters in Roman dress. For centuries, it was traditionally thought to be the Roman general Caius Marius, his wife Julia, Caesar's aunt, and Martha, their supposed prophetess. In the mid-19th century, the increase in popular piety and the will of the local clergy made this stele a place of homage to the 'Three Marys' According to Christian tradition, Saints Mary Magdalene, Mary Jacobe and Mary Salome (the Three Marys) came ashore in Les Saintes Maries de la Mer in order to evangelise Provence. In the mid-19th century, the site became a place of worship and annual pilgrimage, on 25 May, but was later abandoned. It followed a path which descended from Saint Vincent Church via the Porte d’Eyguières, passed under the Les Baux rock to the south and led to the chapel in the east. It then climbed the main street as far as the village church. The pilgrimage has been reintroduced, but without the procession. The path still exists and provides a pleasant walk around Les Baux (approximately 2 kilometres and a 150 metres change in altitude). The Trémaïe are sculpted in a rock to the south-east of the Baux-de-Provence plateau, below the Château des Baux. According to the Prefect of Les Bouches-du-Rhône, Christophe de Villeneuve-Bargemon, this rock fell from the plateau. It measures 7.6 by 4.5 metres. The bas-relief is sculpted in a niche measuring 2 by 1.35 metres; this niche is also sculpted and adorned with acroteria. The Trémaïe bas-relief is 4 metres above ground level, just above the chapel roof. It portrays three people: one man and two women, all life-size. The statues measure between 1.75 and 1.83 m. The heads of the two off-centre people are turned slightly towards the central character. An adjoining chapel, the Trémaïe Chapel, was built in 1845. It was extended in 1873. The fresco which adorns it was created in 1879. The chapel was restored in 1987 and returned to the Church in 2003.

label: Tour Musée
comment: A true symbol of Velaux, the tower overlooking the village is the only remnant of an ancient medieval castle.
shortDescription: A true symbol of Velaux, the tower overlooking the village is the only remnant of an ancient medieval castle.
description:
After a major restoration, this 15-metre high building is now a museum exhibiting municipal archaeological collections ranging from the Neolithic to the Palaeochristian period.
Several rooms are dedicated to the remains found on the Roquepertuse site and to the Gallic habitat. Another room is devoted to the Gallo-Roman pottery kilns and the early Christian city of Sainte Propice
Two panoramic terraces give visitors an exceptional view of the town and the Etang-de-Berre.

label: Oratoires de Fontvieille
comment: Oratory of St. Theresa, Oratory of St. Roch, Oratory of St. Victor. All three oratories are registered in the inventory of historical monuments.
shortDescription: Oratory of St. Theresa, Oratory of St. Roch, Oratory of St. Victor. All three oratories are registered in the inventory of historical monuments.
description:
Oratory of St Theresa: Oratory built in the 17th century.
The building, constructed of medium-sized stones, consists of three storeys separated by moulded cornices. The central part is cut through with four rectangular bays supporting the lantern-shaped niche, whose four sides have semi-circular arches. The roof consists of a stone dome. 
Oratory of St Roch: Erected during the great plague of 1721, it is dedicated not only to Saint Roch (who was traditionally invoked in the event of an epidemic), but also to the Virgin, Saint Joseph and the Sacred Heart, representations of whom can be found on the monument. On the square plinth is a niche, whose four sides feature a semi-circular niche. At the back of each of these niches is a terracotta plaque with a haut-relief representation of a saint. Below each niche is a marble plaque on which can be read: Under St Roch: 'IN THE YEAR 1721, WITH SICKNESS IN PROVENCE, AGNES AUBERT HAD THESE FOUR LIKENESS OF SAINTS ERECTED FOR COMMON DEVOTION. ST ROCH, PROTECT US'. Under the Virgin: NOTRE-DAME DU MONT CARMEL, HOPE OF SINNER SOULS, DEIGN TO GRANT US THE HEALING OF OUR WEAKNESSES FROM THE HEAVENS'. Under the Sacred Heart: IN THE YEAR 1895, CONTAGION WAS RIFE IN THIS TOWN, THE PEOPLE VOWED TO RE-ESTABLISH THE FORMER MONUMENT TO HIS PEITY THAT WAS TAKEN AWAY ON 28 May 1888 AND TO COME HERE IN JUNE EVERY YEAR TO THANK THE HEAVENS FOR THE CEASING OF THE SCOURGE SACRED HEART OF JESUS SAVE US' Under Saint Joseph: '.......SAINT JOSEPH PRAY FOR US........WHO CHOSE YOU AS A FATHER......WILL SAVE US THANKS TO YOU......PLAGUE, FAMINE AND WAR'.
Oratory of Saint Victor: Erected during the plague epidemic of 1721 in thanks to the saints for protecting the town from the illness; it has four sides, two of which house representations of Saint Roch and Saint Victor. As well as its dual dedication, the Oratory is original in that the figures of the saints are in bas-relief and not in the form of statues, as is the case in most oratories.
These small buildings were particularly popular in the region due to the great devotion of the local population. Saint Roch was one of the names most commonly given to oratories, due to the serious epidemics which devastated the region on several occasions. They were also landmarks on the landscape.
This oratory is located on the site of a former chapel, no trace of which remains.
The three oratories are listed as regional Historic Monuments.

label: Eglise de La Dormition de la Mère de Dieu
comment: Orthodox church of Empire style, it was opened to the faithful in 1845 ( oldest church in France). All sunday services are celebrated in Greek. To see : the iconostasis and the furniture.
shortDescription: Orthodox church of Empire style, it was opened to the faithful in 1845 ( oldest church in France). All sunday services are celebrated in Greek. To see : the iconostasis and the furniture.
description:
Opening times of the church :  every day from 9am to 12pm and from 2pm to 6pm. 
Mass on Sunday at 10am.

label: Les croix de Châteaurenard
comment: Cross of Châteaurenard
shortDescription: Cross of Châteaurenard
description:
There are six crosses in the local countryside. They are the Croix de Piquette, the Croix de l’Oratoire, the Croix de la Mâtarde, the Croix du Mas de Cartier, the Croix Rouge and the Croix de la Crau. They were erected during the second half of the 19th century and some of them have recently been restored.
The following crosses are located in the town: the Croix du Rond Point (at the intersection of Bd Gambetta and Bd Jules Ferry and Avenue Général de Gaulle and Avenue Trouillet) was erected in 1865. The Croix de l’Ancien Calvaire is on Rue de l’Ancien Calvaire, near the Oratory of St Eloi.
A large cross, known as the Croix du Jubilé, was erected circa 1836 in the first plot of the cemetery. It dates from 1875. According to the Book of Leviticus and the Law of Moses, a Jubilee year is dedicated to God. There is no sowing or harvesting, debts and sold assets are cancelled and slaves are freed. It occurs every 50 years. The tradition of a Jubilee year was abandoned during Antiquity; in the Middle Ages, however, Pope Boniface VIII established a holy year in 1300 and forgave the sins of the pilgrims to the Basilicas of the Apostles in Rome.
Near the Monument to the Dead is a Cross from the 1956 Mission.
1844 Calvary
Until the 1950s, a Way of the Cross led from the church to the Calvary. This Calvary, erected in 1844, consists of a monumental cross on top of a large stone base. This representation of the passion of Christ is located in the middle of a pine groves, half-way up the hill. The Way of the Cross provided easy access to the Calvary; from there, it is possible to climb up to the Golden Virgin.

label: Fontaine de Saint-Jean de Malte
comment: The fountain, which was first built in 1759 to plans by Vallon, stands in front of the entrance to the Church of St John of Malta.
shortDescription: The fountain, which was first built in 1759 to plans by Vallon, stands in front of the entrance to the Church of St John of Malta.
description:
It was destroyed and replaced by the present fountain in 1862. Its basin is in hardstone and the water flows into it from two small pipes. 

It is built against a wall and its design is inspired by the order of the Hospitaliers of St John of Malta (which is omnipresent around it, with its church and priory). 

Two Maltese crosses can be seen on the pediment. One is carved inside while the other protrudes from the first, so that eight branches are visible in all, probably symbolising the eight languages of the countries where the order is present in Europe (Provençal, Auvergnat, French, Italian, Aragon, English, etc). 

This fountain does not intrude: it is a part of the square, but its modest and simple beauty do not draw attention to itself.

label: Place Mirabeau
comment: One of the most beautiful places in Martigues: Place de l'Arénier took the name Place Mirabeau in 1881.
shortDescription: One of the most beautiful places in Martigues: Place de l'Arénier took the name Place Mirabeau in 1881.
description: Beautiful mansions The former community house 17-century upright fountain renovated in 1997, once on the main square of the Jonquières district. Note the small sculpted centenary cicada on the ridge of the roof on the corner of the Rue du Jeu de Paume and Place Mirabeau.

label: Fontaine d'Argent
comment: Standing in a corner, at the intersection of rue de la Mule Noire and the former rue des Jardins (now rue de la Fontaine d'Argent), the Black Mule fountain was built according to the Baroque-influenced plans of Georges Vallon in 1758, with sculptures by Jean Chastel.
shortDescription: Standing in a corner, at the intersection of rue de la Mule Noire and the former rue des Jardins (now rue de la Fontaine d'Argent), the Black Mule fountain was built according to the Baroque-influenced plans of Georges Vallon in 1758, with sculptures by Jean Chastel.
description: Today the water comes from the Verdon and is not carbonised, so that the fountain does not require frequent cleaning.

label: Eglise Saint-Julien
description:
Adjacent to the castle whose old square tower became its bell tower, the church of Saint-Julien dates from the 17th century and was built with the financial help of the powerful Boyer family, the last lords of Eguilles, parliamentarians and influential humanists


In order to attend the services, they had a direct access from their castle through a grandstand. The renovation of the building, begun in 1908, was interrupted one year later: the earthquake of 1909 was unfortunately fatal


Its reconstruction, by the diocesan architect Lazare Huot, was completed in 1913 and offers the visitor a curiosity, a choir fresco depicting a statue of Christ on the cross


The site, as a belvedere, offers a remarkable view of this terroir where the cultivation of vines and olive trees dates back to the Celto-Ligurian period, which sees tens of thousands of sheep passing through every year on their way to the summer transhumance.


Halt for the pilgrims of Santiago de Compostela.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
comment: The library has a total of more than 8,000 books for all ages.
shortDescription: The library has a total of more than 8,000 books for all ages.
description:
The library of the commune welcomes all the inhabitants who would like to borrow books, magazines or CDs, to get information thanks to the encyclopaedias and documentaries at their disposal, or simply to read.

Apart from public openings, we receive kindergartens and primaries. Some classes come with pedagogical projects and others simply take advantage of the diversity of the works on offer.

label: Chapelle de la Charité
comment:
Date: 1634, 1702
Period: Classical period
Type: Religious architecture
Status: Private property chapel classified Historical monument (1927)
shortDescription:
Date: 1634, 1702
Period: Classical period
Type: Religious architecture
Status: Private property chapel classified Historical monument (1927)
description:
The Carmelites have been present in Arles for several centuries.  However, the vicissitudes of history have driven them away on several occasions, and the congregation has experienced no less than three successive settlements. Today established in the Mouleyrès district, the Carmelites settled at the beginning of the seventeenth century, near the current esplanade of the Lices. 

The construction of their convent is part of a context of strong architectural development of the city, on the initiative of the nobility, the bourgeoisie, but also the clergy.

Apart from the remarkable presence of the Chapelle de la Charité, on the Boulevard des Lices, the rest of their buildings, now refurbished as a hotel, is hardly visible. The conventual buildings and the cloister, although transformed into a hotel complex, were respected. The architect Bentz, who chose the Provençal style, chose the colonnade visible from the outside, inspired by that of the municipal casino in Aix-en-Provence, to design the building.

The chapel on the Boulevard des Lices was also preserved. Its facade consists of two double columns with Corinthian capitals that frame the porch. The whole is surmounted by a large triangular pediment, itself enhanced by a curvilinear tympanum (hammered at the Revolution), where one can notice a heart pierced by an arrow, in the middle of a cloud where angelots appear. 

Apart from the communion table, transported in the choir of the church of Saint-Trophime, the chapel still retains an important part of its original furniture. One can admire the wooden pulpit made by the Avignonnais sculptor Péru, also author of the Baroque altarpiece of the high altar.

label: Moulin de Bretoule
comment: This mill was built shortly before the French Revolution and operated until 1845. It is located not far from the Anglica Tower, surrounded by pine trees.
shortDescription: This mill was built shortly before the French Revolution and operated until 1845. It is located not far from the Anglica Tower, surrounded by pine trees.
description: This mill was built shortly before the French Revolution and worked until 1845. It is located not far from the Tower Anglica, enshrined in the pines. Private property.

label: La Porte d'Arles
comment: A listed historical monument. The Portail d’Arles was constructed between 1771 and 1773 on the site of the old entrance in the collapsed ramparts.
shortDescription: A listed historical monument. The Portail d’Arles was constructed between 1771 and 1773 on the site of the old entrance in the collapsed ramparts.
description: The portal of Arles was built by the master masons Jean Tabusteau of Istres and François Peytrau de St Mitre with stones from a local quarry. Slightly concave in shape, its anterior surface of great sobriety, is decorated with two flower garlands. The arch rests on two pillars and his Keystone is decorated with a coat of arms of Louis XV style. A great short ledge at the top of the monument.

label: Hôtel des Monnaies
description:
Tarascon enjoyed many privileges under the reign of the Counts of Provence. In August 1272, an Act of Charles I of Anjou, the uncle of King René, authorised the founding of a Maison de la Monnaie (Mint), thus allowing Tarascon to mint money in the same way as Tours. Coins were minted here from 1387 to 1520. During this time, a real coin and a fake coin were nailed to the door, in order to inform the population and discourage forgers. The mint ceased operation between 1518 and 1526 and between 1543 and 1591, as its activity was contested by the Provence Parliament. From 1591 to 1593, under the reign of Henri IV, it minted 'pinatelles' (double sols).
Architectural description:
Two types of architecture are visible, Gothic and Renaissance (small, late-Gothic windows at the very top). A spiral staircase leads to the corbelled turrets which housed the study. This building has the oldest sundial in town; it is possible to see the remains of a Latin inscription which means, 'They all wound, the last one kills'. It is referring to hours, of course.

label: Le Vieux Marseille et Le Panier
comment: Behind the Hôtel de Ville, the historical heart of the city called "Le Panier" develops. The origin of the name comes from the sign of an inn "Le Logis du Panier", installed in the 17th century.
shortDescription: Behind the Hôtel de Ville, the historical heart of the city called "Le Panier" develops. The origin of the name comes from the sign of an inn "Le Logis du Panier", installed in the 17th century.
description:
Behind of the City Hall, the heart of the city’s old quarter is called “The Panier” (The basket). It’s name apparently derives from the sign of the 17th century inn “Le Logis du Panier” located there.

The Maison Diamantée was built by rich Spanish and Italian trading partners. It was then lived in by well-established Marseille families before it was divided up into apartments during the Revolution. The Maison Diamantée is a perfect example of Provençal mannerism with its unusual façade decorated with raised diamond-shaped tips and the decorated panelled staircase that is unique in Marseille.
At the end of the 19th Century the Maison Diamantée housed port workers and Italian immigrants. At the beginning of the 20th Century it was in a dilapidated state and set to be demolished. In 1922 it was bought by the "Art and Charity" foundation who then made the Committee of Old Marseille its owner. The Maison Diamantée became a National Heritage building in 1925 it was spared from being blown up in 1943 and since 1967 has housed the Musée de Vieux Marseille (Museum of Old Marseille). The museum undertakes to bring to the fore the city's unique qualities and historic traditions using theme-based exhibitions such as the King's galley ships, the 1720 plague, the model of the city centre built by Mr. Lavastre, traditional Marseille costume, interior decoration and furniture, santons and playing cards.
Today, the Maison Diamantée is one of the few remaining souvenirs of the old city that no longer exists, of its aristocratic dwellings in the rich quarter of the city centre that was so dependent on the sea and on commerce.

Pavillon Daviel
The Palais de Justice de Marseille (Marseille Courthouse) was built in the middle of the 18th Century by the Gérard brothers who were Marseille architects. It was built on the site where a 16th Century courthouse had originally stood. The building is built in the pinkish stone from the Couronne quarries and has a façade that is relatively narrow yet perfectly harmonious and that evokes the simple and pleasant architecture of 18th Century Provençal houses. The front section of the building projects slightly outwards and is decorated with an allegorical pediment. The upper floor has a splendid wrought iron balcony comprising panels built in the "marguerite" (daisy) style that was so popular among Marseille craftsmen in the 18th Century. The sculptures of the hand of justice and the torch of Themis, the angels carrying the King's arms (damaged during the Revolution) and children carrying the Tables of the Law and the coat of arms of Marseille are all the work of the sculptor Verdiguier
During the Revolution, sentences were delivered from this balcony, under which stood the guillotine in the square below.
In the Second Empire a new Courthouse was built. From 1875 to 1893 the new building was used by the School of Medicine before it eventually became a Town Hall annexe.(Partially listed as a National Heritage Site in 1945).

The Grand'Rue.
The Grand'Rue follows the ancient road that may still be seen today in the Jardin des Vestiges (Garden of Greek Remains) and that eventually opens into the Place de Lenche, the ancient Greek market place. The original Greek road lies 3 metres under the modern street level. In the 6th Century B.C. it was already a busy street that connected the various public buildings with one another and provided space for markets and local craft and business transactions. It is amusing to realise that in fact very little has changed over 26 Centuries! Various side streets named after guilds led from the Grand'Rue to the port, the centre of the city's commerce.

The Hôtel de Cabre.
The Hôtel de Cabre is on the corner of Rue Bonneterie and the Grand'Rue. This private residence, that was built in 1535 in an unusual mixture of gothic and renaissance styles for the trader and Consul Louis Cabre, is one of the oldest houses in Marseille. When the old quarter was blown up in 1943 the house was saved but later lifted in one piece on jacks and rotated through 90° in order to align it with the present streets to meet with town-planning requirements. The façades have been listed as National Heritage Sites since 1941.

The Hôtel Dieu
The original Saint-Esprit hospital was founded in the 12th Century. It was extended over the centuries and was joined to the Saint-Jacques de Galice hospital in the 16th Century. It eventually became the Hôtel-Dieu a century later. A nephew of the famous architect Hardouin-Mansart then undertook its reconstruction but his ambitious project was only partially completed and the Hôtel-Dieu did not attain its present appearance until the Second Empire. Like all 18th Century hospital buildings it was enclosed on all 4 sides and divided into two main courtyards, one for women and one for men. The architect Blanchet decided to open the southern façade of the hospital to create two wings that end in square pavilions. The three arcades are open to the air and form the walking galleries that are also typical features of hospital architecture of this period. The stairway is the work of Joseph-Esprit Brun and, like that of the Hôtel de Ville, is a fine example of stone vaulting. The handsome wrought iron hand-rail demonstrates the quality of ironmongers' work in Marseille in the 18th Century. The Hôtel Dieu has been included in the Inventory of Additional National Heritage Sites since 1963.
Since Antiquity Marseille has always occupied an important place in medical practice and scientific research. Medicine is still today one of the city's most technologically advanced sectors.
A bronze bust of Jacques Daviel stands in the Hôtel-Dieu forecourt. He was an eye surgeon and practised in Marseille during the 1720 plague. In 1745, while practising at the Hôtel Dieu, he carried out the world's first cataract operation involving removal of the crystalline lens. Three years later he became Louis XV's eye specialist.

Accoules church.
All that has survived of the original church is the bell tower and some remains of the nave. The present church, with its circular architecture, dates from the 19th century. The parish of Accoules is one of the oldest in Marseille.
Le preau des accoules
At the beginning of the 17th Century the Jesuits founded the Eglise de Sainte-Croix (Church of the Holy Cross) and the Collège des quatre langues (School of Four Languages). The school specialised in teaching oriental languages to the young marseillais who were destined to become traders. In 1701 the school became the Royal Observatory in compliance with orders from Louis XIV and also in keeping with the King's wish to develop commerce in Marseille. 
The observatory had a series of famous directors including Saint-Jacques de Silvabelle, Pezenas and Pons who discovered the existence of 37 comets and thus set the observatory on a European footing. By 1863 the observatory was considered too small and was moved to the Longchamp Palace gardens. A school has since taken over the old observatory premises while the Preau des Accoules has moved to the great hall of the Academy of Literature, Science and the Arts designed by Joseph-Esprit Brun. This museum is entirely consecrated to children and hosts theme-based cultural activities that are linked to the major exhibitions held in museums throughout Marseille.
Nearby lies the Fonderie Vieille street where originally the Royal foundries were established and later housed various guilds and monastic communities.
When you go down the Montée des Accoules, you may notice that the houses are unusually tall and narrow. This is because people were only allocated a very limited area of land on which to build they therefore had to build upwards. An unusual feature is the fine hand rail that divides the street and that was known as the "conversation" rail, so called because it enabled people to lean on the rail while chatting to the person opposite.

The Place de Lenche.
The Place de Lenche is on the site of the ancient Greek market place, from which the townspeople could keep an eye on events in the port. The square was originally enclosed on all four sides and in the 6th Century Saint Cassien founded the convent of Saint-Sauveur that was built facing the Saint-Victor monastery on the opposite side of the port. In the 8th Century the nuns cut off their noses in order to disgust the Saracen invaders who were intent on raping them. They became known as desnardo (no noses) !. The Saint-Sauveur cellars that lie under the square were, in fact, the water-tanks of the Greek city in the 3rd Century B.C. . They were declared National Heritage Sites in 1840 and are considered to be ancient constructions that have remained in their original condition.
The name "Lenche" comes from that of a Corsican family, Lincio, who left their mark on the square in the 16th Century by establishing a coral-working studio and shops, and by building a sumptuous private residence. In 1553 Thomas Lenche founded the Coral Company to collect coral along the Algerian coastline and in 1561 the Bastion was founded, a company that was used as a base for the company's shipping and trading activities. The Bastion was the origin of the French presence in Algeria and the family became one of the richest in Marseille. They later married into the highest families, even earning the privilege of accommodating Louis XIV during his stay in Marseille in 1660.
Even though the square was not at the centre of the explosions that destroyed the old quarters during the Second World War, the German authorities ordered the South side to be blown up in the winter of 1943. Concrete buildings have since been built on this side of the square.
Streets leading down to the Vieux-Port have been rebuilt to provide view points and the sculptures scattered throughout the quarter are constant reminders of the area's links with the port.

La Vieille Charité.
n 1640 the Town Council decided to "lock up the poor inhabitants of Marseille in a selected clean place", in compliance with the Royal policy of "enclosing the poor".
In 1670 a charity organisation within the Council of Aldermen commissioned Pierre Puget, the King's architect whose childhood was spent in the quarter, to design a Public Hospital intended to accommodate beggars and the poor. The plan was slow in taking shape and the first stone was not laid until 1671. It was to be one of Pierre Puget's most successful architectural achievements but was not, however, completed until 1749.
The building has four wings that are closed to the exterior but comprise a 3 floored-gallery on the inside that overlooks an inner rectangular courtyard. The 3 levels, forming passages between the large work and living areas, correspond to 3 floors inside the building that separated men and women.
The chapel in the centre of the courtyard was built between 1679 and 1707 and it proved to be the most remarkable piece of architecture that Pierre Puget was ever to create for his home town. This chapel with its egg-shaped dome is a perfect example of pure Italian baroque.
The present façade was not built in the 18th Century but dates from 1863. It depicts Charity taking in pauper children  this group is flanked by two pelicans feeding their young.
 After the Revolution, and until the end of the 19th Century, the Vieille Charité was used as a hospice for old people and children. In 1905 the building was occupied by the army and later became a shelter for the destitute. After the Second World War the architect Le Corbusier was struck by the building and called attention to its abandoned state. It had been scheduled for demolition but finally became a National Heritage building in 1951. The Malraux laws resulted in the beginning of remarkable restoration work on the Vieille Charité in 1968. Since 1986 the building has fulfilled a variety of scientific and cultural functions, housing museums and hosting temporary exhibitions. The Vieille Charité is in the heart of the Panier and is a must for every tourist visiting Marseille.

The Place des Moulins
The location of the Place des Moulins has been known since Antiquity and lies at the highest point in the Panier overlooking the surrounding old town. This upper part of the town was used to defend Marseille against sea and land attacks and it was from here that the canons were fired.
For many years the square was also occupied by windmills whose sails were easily rotated by the wind in this exposed spot. In 1596, fifteen windmills could be seen, giving Marseille its characteristic appearance. However, the use of water to drive machinery gradually took over from the windmills and eventually caused them to close down. In the 19th Century only three windmills were still operating and their stone bases can still be seen today. In the middle of the 19th Century the city authorities ordered the buildings to be demolished in order to create a new square with all the buildings constructed in a more or less identical architectural style. The new Place des Moulins included trees, benches, an area for playing French bowls and, later, a school that gave it a more village-like atmosphere. In 1840 water tanks were built under the square to supply the city with water. A local organisation set up to promote the interests of the Panier is presently studying the possibility of opening a museum based around "The History of Water in Marseille".
Since 1983 the City of Marseille has been working towards rehabilitating the Panier and one of the initial phases of the plan is centred around restoring the friendly atmosphere of the Place des Moulins. The project is already well under way and the results can be seen in the buildings that have been restored, the apartments that have been rebuilt and the streets and squares that have been redesigned.

label: Le Jardin de Gaston
comment: The arboretum of Gaston's Garden, a little green jewel
shortDescription: The arboretum of Gaston's Garden, a little green jewel
description:
This 49,000 m² garden is named after its designer, Gaston Therras.
The Gaston Garden arboretum is a green gem that extends over four hectares. Since June 2004, it offers visitors a tranquil and natural setting conducive to botanical discoveries, relaxation and walks.
Today, more than 150 species of trees and shrubs are on display.
Amongst the familiar trees, you can find trees such as the sweetgum, the ginko biloba (maidenhair tree), the decorative bark birch tree, the nissa (tulepo) and more. Signs planted around trees allow you to easily identify them.
The arboretum also has a volatile rich life, with more than 40 recorded species: black and white swans, peacocks, pigeons, geese Magellan and all kinds of waterfowl.
To promote relaxation, the development of the arboretum has steadily improved since its inauguration: accessibility for persons with reduced mobility, additional benches, a new lawn, new waste baskets and a new pedestrian entrance at the Mas de Cura.
Moreover, access to the arboretum is forbidden to unleashed dogs. Dog excrement collection bags are available to owners.
Ideal for walking, the Garden Gaston paths cover about 1,200 metres. To extend the walk, discovery of the arboretum is part of the green ways.
Do not hesitate to find out!

label: Musée du Savon de Marseille
comment: The Marseille soap museum offers a unique  tour inside the Savonnerie  du  midi factory
shortDescription: The Marseille soap museum offers a unique  tour inside the Savonnerie  du  midi factory
description:
Discover a museal area opened in decembre.This comes  from  an educational, regional and touristic will !

This walk has been created by one of the oldest soap factory of the region. You can discover  how the Marseille soap was created, its traditional manufacturing process. its former uses, its  regional rootedness, its  industrial  background. One  of the  most  beautiful  collection of  Marseille soap  is displayed.
This collection belongs to Josette and Vittorio Quittard, two people from Marseille who have been passionate about  Marseille soap  for   years. Indeed, they  made two movies, wrote  a book and created 93 exhibitions.

Photographies, tanks, former soaps, advertisments, boxwood stamps, washing boards bearters...Total of nearly  objects of all kinds  are on display in three areas.

 Built in the  cauldrons  area,, this is  the very  heart  of the  factory, the museum gives  also the opportunity to  discover  the saponification process and a  complete tour of the visit in order to better understand  the  different stages of the famous  "made in Marseille".

Mandatory  reservations
For  individuals on wednesdays and saturdays at  10.30 am
 and during  holidays: tuesdays, wednesdays and thursdays at 10.30 am

For  groups ( more than 10 people) from monday to thursday  from 1.30 pm to 4.30 pm and friday from 10.30 to 4.30.
Permanent surface exhibition : 285.

label: MAC Arteum - musée d'art contemporain
comment: By multiplying partnerships and varying the themes, the Arteum art space has become in recent years a place for meetings and exchanges between artists of regional, national and international renown,
shortDescription: By multiplying partnerships and varying the themes, the Arteum art space has become in recent years a place for meetings and exchanges between artists of regional, national and international renown,
description:
Since 1990, the Arteum museum of contemporary art has promoted Art in the magnificent rooms of the château (17th century) of Châteauneuf le Rouge town hall. 


The ARTEUM museum (Artistes Représentatifs des Tendances et Unités Méridionales – Artists Representing Southern French Trends and Unity) has a collection of 100 works, the earliest by painters of Marseille's Péano and Quai de Rive Neuve, and the contemporary works of plastic artists living in the Provence-Côte d'Azur region. 


The museum has a permanent collection of works by artists from 1900 to the present day. 


There is also a reconstruction of the studio of painter Arsène Sari. This artist, born in 1895, was advised by Renoir and Guillaumin....
streetAddress: ['Le Château - Hôtel de Ville', 'Place Auguste Baret', 'RN7']

label: Eglise Saint Nicolas
comment: Saint-Nicolas is the most beautiful example of flamboyant gothic style built in Provence.
shortDescription: Saint-Nicolas is the most beautiful example of flamboyant gothic style built in Provence.
description:
FROM THE CHAPEL TO THE PARISH CHURCH
At the end of the 12th century, it was only a modest chapel, adjoined by a cemetery. Probably because of the port and the ferry of Pertuis on the Durance, it was dedicated to Saint-Nicolas, patron saint of boatmen
Located on the market square, very close to the new castle, it gradually became more important
In 1398, the church of Saint-Pierre (1) threatened to collapse and the parish seat was transferred to Saint-Nicolas.
A new, larger building replaced the old chapel. It consists of a nave of three bays with ribbed vaults (2), reinforced by external buttresses, and an apse.
In the 15th century, chapels were built on both sides of the nave. Only those on the north side remain today.

A CHOIR AND A COLLATERAL OF THE XVIth CENTURY
The church, dilapidated and too narrow, had to be enlarged. On April 24, 1535, part of the vaults collapsed following an earthquake, it seems.
It was the master masons Jean Martin, from Manosque and Jaume Jean, from Pertuis, who built the remarkable ribbed vaults of the choir and the first three bays of the side aisle, between 1535 and 1543. Made of cut stone, all different, the design of their ribs is varied and complex. In the same way, the capitals present a diversity of forms and motives (leaves, horns of plenty, human or animal heads...)
In 1587, the church was finally enlarged by one bay and the western façade was built (3)

The meridional chapels of the 17th century
In the 17th century, chapels were successively opened on the south side of the collateral. The most beautiful is undoubtedly the one on the west side, covered with a dome with a lantern. Dedicated to Saint Raymond, it was founded in 1660 by Esprit de Ravely, "squire of the city of Pertuis"

"LIBERTY, EQUALITY, FRATERNITY"
In 1877, the facade was remodeled and decorated with a new portico. The republican motto was only inscribed on the entablature in 1882, under the Third Republic, almost a century after the Revolution.
The 1909 earthquake shook the vaults and destroyed the small bell tower built in the 18th century

The church was classified as a historical monument on October 14, 1911.

(1) The first parish church of Pertuis was located north of the city (Place Saint-Pierre).
(2) These vaults were rebuilt identically in 1684.
(3) The knowledge of these works is due to the research of Dr Marsily.

label: Bibliothèque Les Méjanes - Allumettes
comment: The library Les Méjanes - Allumettes was established in 1989 in the heart of the building of the former match factory in Aix-en-Provence.
shortDescription: The library Les Méjanes - Allumettes was established in 1989 in the heart of the building of the former match factory in Aix-en-Provence.
description:
The Méjanes library was installed in 1989 in the heart of the old match factory in Aix-en-Provence. It provides the public with a range of services: collections of documents on all subjects, on all media, for all public, digital resources, access to the Internet heritage collections, old and contemporary, including the 60,000 documents of the Marquis de Mejanes.
