This library of about 9 000 m2 is the central point of a public reading network with three annexes, the Deux Ormes, the Halle aux Grains, the Li Campaneto and a mediation service.

Facilities Handicap: the library is fully accessible for people with reduced mobility. For the visually impaired or blind people, it is provided with equipment for reading and internet use: tele-magnifying machine, reading machine, computer and adapted software.

label: Plage Napoléon
comment: The Napoleon beach is perfect for relaxation. It is one of the largest beaches in the Camargue with 10kms of fine sand.
shortDescription: The Napoleon beach is perfect for relaxation. It is one of the largest beaches in the Camargue with 10kms of fine sand.
description:
The Napoleon beach is perfect for relaxation. It is one of the largest beaches in the Southern Region with 10kms of fine sand. You can come here to swim, practice sand sports, water sports, picnic...
A place of relaxation but also of discovery because at the end of the beach is the mouth of the Grand Rhone that you can admire after a pleasant walk with your feet in the water.

label: Castellas de Roquemartine
comment: Ruins of the Castellas de Roquemartine
shortDescription: Ruins of the Castellas de Roquemartine
description: The ruins of the Castellas de Roquemartine dominate the road to Cavaillon. This essential crossing point between Avignon and the Etang de Berre pond welcomed, in the Middle Ages, a famous love court. It is a private site, therefore not accessible. A brochure relating the history of the castle is on sale at the tourist office

label: Eglise Saint-Pierre-ès-liens
comment: se Saint-Pierre-ès-liens, in classical style (not classified). Mentioned for the first time in 1207, it was rebuilt, enlarged and inaugurated in 1772 after having collapsed in 1769.
shortDescription: se Saint-Pierre-ès-liens, in classical style (not classified). Mentioned for the first time in 1207, it was rebuilt, enlarged and inaugurated in 1772 after having collapsed in 1769.
description: The very airy and well-lit edifice has a single nave with 3 bays, vaulted with ridge vaults divided by high double doors, with low sides covered with lean-to windows. The balanced elevation is on two levels, with large basket-handle arcades opening onto side chapels and tribunes with light ironwork. The doubleaux rest on pilasters with concave ionic capitals, the keys of the large arcades are decorated with rolled leather. The five-sided chevet is vaulted with flat ribs. Inside, a 17th century processional polychrome wooden Christ, and stained glass windows dated 1887.

label: Gare Saint-Charles
description: Although the railway arrived in Marseille in 1848, it was not until 1911 that the city opened a competition for the construction of the staircase. A monumental staircase, decorated with colonial sculptures from Africa and Asia illustrating the commercial vocation of Marseille Porte de l'Orient. The station itself was built in the mid-19th century. The Avignon-Marseille line by Tarascon was one of the major projects in Marseille. The staircase of the Gare Saint-Charles is famous for its scale and decoration: its wide successive flights, the metal footbridges, the baroque decor form a scenography in the 1900s taste, even if the works were only started in 1923. The Marseille-St-Charles centre brings together under the same roof access to rail, road and urban transport to serve the entire region. Today, the Pole irrigates all modes of public transport: the 16 tracks of the station (TGV, Corail and TER), the 20 bus parking spaces at the bus station, the 2 metro lines, the 2 drop-off points, the taxi station, the shuttles, urban accesses?Intermodality in figures: 45,000 passengers per day, 300 trains per day, 80 TGVs per day, 27 coach parking spaces and 700 coach rotations per day, 785 parking spaces located in the Pôle's interior spaces, more than 1,000 parking spaces in total (including exterior spaces).

label: La Touloubre
comment: The Touloubre is the river crossing the Bouches-du-Rhône, which flows into the Mediterranean Sea through the Etang de Berre.
shortDescription: The Touloubre is the river crossing the Bouches-du-Rhône, which flows into the Mediterranean Sea through the Etang de Berre.
description: The Touloubre river has its source in Venelles, runs along the Trévaresse massif, crosses, among others, the villages of La Barben, Pélissanne, Grans...following an East-West route. After a 65 km journey, it flows into the Etang de Berre. The basin is 420 Km² for a population of 100 000 inhabitants.

label: Eglise Saint-Barnabé
comment:
Church built in the 19th century.
The parish complex is composed of six bell towers: St Barnabé, Ste Anne des Caillols, St Augustin, St Julien, Beaumont (Ste Bernadette), Bois-Luzy (Ste Louise de Marillac).
shortDescription:
Church built in the 19th century.
The parish complex is composed of six bell towers: St Barnabé, Ste Anne des Caillols, St Augustin, St Julien, Beaumont (Ste Bernadette), Bois-Luzy (Ste Louise de Marillac).
description: The Caire square where it is located is planted with trees, and hosts the metro exit, the terrace of a café restaurant, and the Maison pour Tous.

label: Villa Tiflis (actuel musée Raimu)
comment: The Villa Tiflis, also known as Monchablon, and now the Raimu Museum, was built in the 1880s. It is one of the four 19th century bourgeois villas in Marignane, half private mansion, half country house
shortDescription: The Villa Tiflis, also known as Monchablon, and now the Raimu Museum, was built in the 1880s. It is one of the four 19th century bourgeois villas in Marignane, half private mansion, half country house
description:
The Tiflis villa is one of the four 19th century bourgeois villas in Marignane, half private mansion, half country house

The Villa Tiflis, also known as Monchablon, and now the Raimu Museum, was built in the 1880s on a plot of land detached from the former large seigneurial garden, indicated in the Middle Ages as a meadow of the estate. It overlooks the prestigious Cours Mirabeau, which was built alongside the large park when it was opened during the Second Empire

The building owes its name and its existence to the couple Marius-François Martin and Catherine Vincent, who settled as hoteliers in Tbilisi (Tiflis) in Georgia, in the wake of the imperial court of Nicolas II

Marius-François served as cook, and probably master chef, to the Tsar. Having made his fortune, he and his wife acquired the land in 1881 and had the house built under the care of his brother before returning from Tbilisi to move in

The house is almost square in plan and is limited in height to a single storey with a four-sided roof. It has an entrance on the courtyard side and a side entrance on the garden side, both in the middle of a perfectly rhythmic facade with high windows framed by simple mouldings, a key and discreet brackets. The whole is solidly framed at the corners by harpooned quoins. On the private side, overlooking the garden, the only distinctive feature of the door lintel is a richly decorated cartouche around the founders' number consisting of the intertwined initials V and M. From the Vincent and Martin family, the villa passed into the hands of their daughter, married to the mayor of Marignane, Joseph Cadenel, and then into the hands of their niece, who was allied to the Dejeans and who experienced the humiliation of the requisition of the family property by the Kommandantur in 1943. Since then, the former "Tiflis" has been rented to the Monchablon doctors and has housed an office and then a medical imaging centre, before being acquired by the city of Marignane in 2009

Since 2014, it has been home to the Raimu Museum founded by Isabelle Nohain-Raimu, a descendant of the actor Jules Muraire known by this pseudonym. The rooms of the villa are now dedicated to the memory of this historic figure of the theater and cinema, from his early childhood to his greatest successes on the screen, all evoked both by his real memories and by audiovisual media. The building has been refurbished and restored by the architect Nicolas Masson, who worked with André Stern in 2006 on the Château de la Buzine, which has been rehabilitated as the Maison des Cinématographies de la Méditerranée, and in 2013 on the legendary Eden cinema theatre in La Ciotat. A contemporary extension has been added to the rear of the building in Marignane, marking the uninterrupted history of the villa. Inside, the museographer Jean-Louis Mylonas and the scenographer Catherine Marquet were involved, while the external lighting of the building, which was particularly well thought out in view of its current purpose, was entrusted to the LM5P agency.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Place du Général de Gaulle et son Jardin d'enfants
description: Park for children (swings, slide, skill games etc.) for small pieces of cabbage...In downtown of Salon de Provence, with parking for your vehicle nearby.But also: Square Francois Blanc (recreation area) Garden-St-Exupery (Square of relaxation). Magic Garden (garden for children up to 6 years). Square Place des Martyrs (with Bandstand)

label: La Côte Bleue - Massif de la Nerthe
comment: The Cote Bleue has a limestone and indented coastline that stretches over some thirty kilometres between Martigues and Marseille.
shortDescription: The Cote Bleue has a limestone and indented coastline that stretches over some thirty kilometres between Martigues and Marseille.
description:
The Côte Bleue (Blue Coast) is a jagged limestone coastline that stretches for 30 kilometres between Martigues and Marseille. It is a succession of calanques (coves), little creeks and beaches nestling against the Estaque Hills

One side of this chain encloses the Bay of Marseille on the north-west and, at the same time, its other side protects the basin of Berre Lagoon. It is a limestone arc of wild landscape, cut into by narrow winding vales at medium altitudes (180 - 280 m).
The hills drop sharply into the sea along most of the coast; sometimes fishermens hamlets and weekend cabins cling to the steep crags. In the western part, the chain softens into plateaux and there are fine sandy beaches. 
A regional marine park  was created in 1983 on the initiative of four local councils. It includes a 70 hectares conservation area off the coast from Sausset, and a peripheral area of 3,000 hectares that includes the entire coastline of the Blue Coast.
There are splendid views from the coastal railway, which was built at the start of the century with several viaducts and tunnels.
The best way to explore this coastline by car is to take the roads that go around little pleasure ports, skim the cliffs and wind through the rocky vales and the pinewoods. There are many suitable places for taking casual walks or longer hikes. A footpath called the "Customs officers footpath" is being built along the coastline.
There is an abrupt descent into the calanque of La Redonne and then acrobatic paths lead to the calanques of Figuières and Méjean. A little further on are Madrague-de-Gignac and Niolon, a small village hanging on the rocky slopes at the end of the calanque of the same name, flanked by a 19th century fort with its cannons, where there is a very active diving centre.
Bare and windswept Cap Couronne has a magnificent panorama of the coast and the Bay of Marseille.

label: Médiathèque Saint-Antoine Salim Hatubou
comment: The media library opened in December 2020: it is aimed at all audiences, offers a rich cultural program, creative and practical workshops, access to digital, and a fablab.
shortDescription: The media library opened in December 2020: it is aimed at all audiences, offers a rich cultural program, creative and practical workshops, access to digital, and a fablab.
description:
A prolific author with a free and engaging personality, Salim Hatubou was a true cultural figure of the 15th arrondissement where he arrived in 1982 and which saw him grow up.  A Franco-Comorian writer, poet and storyteller who passed away in 2015, Salim Hatubou lived in Saint-Antoine since the age of 10. He left a deep mark on the neighborhood of his childhood through the transmission of culture and tradition.
He was recognized by all and had a particular interest in libraries and their educational vocation. The City of Marseille wanted to pay him the tribute he deserved by giving his name to this new cultural facility in the heart of his childhood neighbourhood.

Services offered: loan and return of documents in the libraries, reopening of the document return terminals.

The following services are again available: consultation of the press, consultation of documents on the spot, access to computers, access to the reprography service (computers and photocopiers), stay on the spot.

label: Bibliothèque Marie Mauron
comment: Municipal library of Rognonas.
shortDescription: Municipal library of Rognonas.
description: The cultural center where the library is in the centre of the village, on the market square, next to the Town Hall and the Church. The market square is renovated and offers a beautiful setting, Provence and nice to walkers.

label: La fée des berges Manon
description:
In 2011, members of the Rives & Cultures association, which brings together inhabitants of the eastern districts of Marseille, expressed the desire to enhance the value of Huveaune and its valley through an artistic commission. Accompanied by the Office of Skills and Desires, a mediator delegated by the Fondation de France for the implementation of the New Sponsors in the Deep South action, they asked the artists Lucy + Jorge Orta to imagine a route of works that would allow them to rediscover Huveaune, from its source in the heights of the mountains of Provence, to its mouth in the Mediterranean Sea.

The artists were inspired by the history of this coastal river, but also by myths and legends related to it, to create five sculptures, which are as many benevolent fairies installed on the banks of the Huveaune, drawing a path that extends over thirty kilometres.
streetAddress: ['Avenue Gabriel Péri', "Parc de l'îlot des berges"]

label: Maison de Jean Daret
description:
Jean Daret was born in Brussels in 1613. 

He settled in Aix en Provence, and in 1639 he married Madeleine Cabassole, from a well-known Aix family. They had two sons, Jean-Baptiste and Michel, who were both painters like himself.


He specialised in the decoration of houses, and in particular Hôtel de Chateaurenard on Rue Gaston Saporta in Aix-en-Provence. Daret's output in the south of France was considerable, and many paintings by him hang in churches in Aix (Saint-Sauveur Cathedral, 1640, Church of La Madeleine, 1637-1643, Saint-Esprit Church, 1653) and in the region (Cavaillon, Saint-Chamas, Salon, Lambesc, Saint-Paul-de-Vence).


He also produced the magnificent paintings commissioned by the lord of Covet for his Marignane Château.


Responsible for the paintings of Château de Vincennes, and having created the majestic decor of Hôtel de Châteaurenard, he was noticed by Louis XIV in 1660 and became the king's painter. He died in Aix-en-Provence at the age of 55.

label: LE ROCHER DE VITROLLES
comment: Crowned by the chapel Notre Dame de Vie and the tower known as Sarrasine, the Rock (or "Roucas" in Provencal) is a mound of pink limestone dating back nearly 65 million years. Its summit is accessible by a staircase carved into the rock.
shortDescription: Crowned by the chapel Notre Dame de Vie and the tower known as Sarrasine, the Rock (or "Roucas" in Provencal) is a mound of pink limestone dating back nearly 65 million years. Its summit is accessible by a staircase carved into the rock.
description:
Its dominant position (30 metres high) made it, in the 5th century, a refuge and observation point to ward off barbarian and Saracen invasions.
 
For those who take the trouble to climb the stairs leading to the top, the reward will be a breathtaking panorama of the surroundings of the Etang de Berre (staircase not accessible to the disabled).

label: Fontaine Fontvieille
comment: Fontvieille fountain in Eyguières
shortDescription: Fontvieille fountain in Eyguières
description: Third source of the village, it flows at the foot of the Monument au Morts.

label: Le David
description: It is a copy of Michelangelo's David, offered by the sculptor-marbarbrier Cantini to the city of Marseille.

label: Jardin de Payan
description:
Referenced in the Provence Alpes Côte d'Azur, gardens guide book, this botanical garden has an arboretum (oak maple, fruit trees), a vegetable garden and a greenhouse over about three hectares. More than 800 taxa are listed.
Access by reservation only from April 15 to November 15.

label: L'Arc
comment: The Arc is the river that crosses the department from the Mont Aurelien to the Etang de Berre.
shortDescription: The Arc is the river that crosses the department from the Mont Aurelien to the Etang de Berre.
description:
The banks of the Arc de Saint Pons in Roquefavour and the Grand Torrent cover 245 ha and are protected as they are of ecological, faunistic and floristic interest.
85 km long, the Arc has its source near Pourcieus, at an altitude of 473 m, crosses Aix en Provence and flows into the Etang de Berre through a small delta.


Protected area: Natural area of ecological, faunistic and floristic interest

label: Palais Longchamp
comment:
Longchamp Boulevard.
This boulevard planted with plane trees was created by an association of owners who, after having left it to the city to open the boulevard in the 1830s, built apartment buildings and private mansions.
shortDescription:
Longchamp Boulevard.
This boulevard planted with plane trees was created by an association of owners who, after having left it to the city to open the boulevard in the 1830s, built apartment buildings and private mansions.
description:
The boulevard Longchamp with its plane trees was created by an owners association. They let the city open the boulevard in the 1830s and then built apartment buildings for rent and private mansions.
This was an immediate success, and soon a quarter with a very homogenic architectural style developed. Here can be found the typical " three-window " building, a design often repeated in several quarters of Marseille.
The observatory, the oldest scientific establishement of Marseille, will soon celebrate its 300th birthday. Before the transformation of the Longchamp plateau, it was installed in the Accoules quarter, in the old part of Marseille in the Collège de Sainte-Croix, where it was created in 1702 by the Jesuits by royal order.
The observatory is attached to the Ministry of National Education and the CNRS research organization. Today it is a processing centre for data obtained from the largest telescopes of the world and from sclale space experiments, and also a laboratory for the development of instruments. The main research themes are at present aimed at the study of galaxies and interstellar environment. Since January 2000, the observatory has expanded by becoming, together with the Laboratoire d'Astronomie Spatiale at Trois Lucs in Marseille and the Observatoire de Haute Provence, the Observatoire Astronomique Marseille Provence attached to the University of Provence.
Apart from its research activity, the observatory is open to the general public and school groups and regularly proposes educational activities on astronomy. The association Andromède organizes exhibitions, school visits, group visits (children and adults), lectures, sky observations and planetarium shows. Furthermore, the observatory has a very fine room of old instruments which the Patrimoine group presents to the general public and school groups.
The Palais Longchamp.
The city had a shortage of water and since the 16th century, there had been a plan to dig a canal to supply Marseille with water from the river Durance. The water problem became an obsession for the municipality in the 19th centuury, aggravated by a cholera epidemic in 1835. From 1838 onwards, projects for the digging of this canal were designed finally the plan of the public works engineer Franz Mayor de Montrichier was adopted. To dig this canal of 85 kilometres, underground ducts and 18 aqueduct bridges had to be made. This took 10 years, helped by the tenacity of certain councillors like Mayor Consolat. Right from the beginning of the works in 1839, a monumental reservoir to celebrate this so precious water was planned. After several projects, the design of the architect of Notre-Dame de la Garde, Henry Espérandieu, was chosen to build the most remarkable of all edifices constructed during the Second Empire.
Usually, the front is 7 metres wide and the depth of the building is 14 metres. According to the means and the wishes of the client, the buildings are more or less decorated especially around the entrance doors and the window frames. Sometimes, the three-window module was doubled and some buildings can have six windows, but these were built later. Apart from the three-window type, you can see private mansions built for only one family with very fine decoration. Most of these buildings have a garden, and those with even numbers open towards the south. This shows that the quality of living was already one of the preoccupations of 19th century architects.
This historic building, inaugurated in 1869, commemorates the arrival of the water of the canal between the river Durance and Marseille. On the same site, it brought together the Museum of Fine Arts, which before was in the former Bernadines chapel, the Museum Natural History, a botanic park and a zoo. The rich decoration of the building evokes the abundance and fertility brought by the water of the canal. Here sculpture has a dominating role, and this work was entrusted to the greatest artists of that period. The famous animal sculptor Antoine Louis Barye created the lions and the tigers of the entrance, and the monumental fountain in the centre of the row of columns is the work of Jules Cavelier. It represents the river Durance surrounded by figures symbolizing the vines and wheat on a cart pulled by the bulls of Camargue.
The interior decoration of the museums is also remarkable. The main stairs of the Fine Arts Museum are adorned by two large painting by Puvis de Cavannes, commissioned in 1867: Marseille, the Greek colony and Marseille, Gateway to the Orient. In the Provence room, painted by Raphaël Ponson, the museum has preserved a fine example of historical museography. The Fine arts Museum, installed in the left wing of the building. In the right wing of the building the Museum of Natural History has been instaled since 1869.

label: Place des Moulins
comment: The square is located at the top of the hill of the Mills, a name due to the presence of windmills at the end of the 16th century.
shortDescription: The square is located at the top of the hill of the Mills, a name due to the presence of windmills at the end of the 16th century.
description:
The hill is approached from the Place de Lenche, now a market place and café. Climbing up by the Accoules, one discovers on the Place des Moulins two towers integrated into the houses, the last archaeological remains of the 15 windmills of the town
In the 19th century, the town had everything razed to the ground, giving this square the appearance of a village square. In the basement there is an old cistern, a real underground monument accessible during the Heritage Days and guided tours of the Tourist Office.

label: Chapelle Saint-Martin du Sonnailler
description: Three km from Vernègues on the way to the "Petit Sonnailler", a small Romanesque chapel with a single nave from the 12th century, entirely restored in the early 2000s by volunteers from the Franciscan Fraternities .

label: Portail neuf
comment: The arch of the new Portal was erected in 1607 (passage on the current Place de la République).
shortDescription: The arch of the new Portal was erected in 1607 (passage on the current Place de la République).
description:
On the Place de la République, the arch of the new gateway overhangs one of the most recent gates of the old town

Erected in 1607, it completed a system of openings in the rampart that included, up to that date, the town gate to the south (the seat of the town hall), the false gate to the east (no longer in existence), the postern in the rue de la Cité (destroyed in 1920, but of which some remains can be seen), and finally the breach known as the "vendanges" to the west (closed by the chapel of the penitents in 1609-1610)

The new gate was offered to the community by Jean-Baptiste I de Covet, in exchange for the transfer of the old false gate to enlarge his castle, as well as an important loan of money. Moreover, with this construction, he compensated the inhabitants of the district who were inconvenienced by the stagnation of water caused by the filling in of the northern ditch and the acquisition of the gardens that bordered it to move back the limit of the seigneurial property

The new gate was built on the site of a house owned by the Barrons, who were in joint ownership at the time

It opened up the town onto a small esplanade (today's Place de la République), then known as the "Pradin" or "Pradeau de la seigneurie". Jean-Baptiste de Covet entrusted the earthwork and construction to the mason Jean Davin, originally from Signes and settled in Trets where the baron had his first castle

The craftsman had already, from 1603 to 1605, completely restored the one in Marignane, which he had acquired in a sorry state. He kept the remains of the arch of the original house, still visible on the left of the portal, and launched an arch of ashlar perhaps originally furnished with battlements, in any case stipulated in the contract. The installation of hinges indicates that heavy wooden doors were used to close this gate, especially at night

This gate marks the beginning of the modern development of the village, now far from a place of entrenchment, which is crossed from side to side.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de la Merci
comment: The chapel is located inside the convent of the same name, where a community of Sisters of the Blessed Virgin of Mercy still lives.
shortDescription: The chapel is located inside the convent of the same name, where a community of Sisters of the Blessed Virgin of Mercy still lives.
description: The chapel is located inside the convent of the same name, where there still lives a community of the sisters of the Blessed Virgin of Thank you. The sisters host some students during the academic year.

label: Bibliothèque municipale du Grand Pré
description:
Municipal library and media library of the town of Jouques, including literary works, DVDs and CDs.

The ground floor includes the adult and adolescent sections, the first floor is dedicated to children.

The team regularly organizes cultural events such as concerts, readings, children's shows and many others.
streetAddress: ['13bis Boulevard Du Réal', 'BP 22', 'Bibliothèque du Grand Pré']

label: La Trévaresse
comment: The massifs of the Roques, the Chaîne des Côtes and the Trévaresse form a large wooded area in the north of the department.
shortDescription: The massifs of the Roques, the Chaîne des Côtes and the Trévaresse form a large wooded area in the north of the department.
description:
The Massif des Roques, Massif de la Chaîne des Côtes and Massif de la Trévaresse form a large, wooded chain situated to the North of the Bouches-du-Rhône. This massif is bordered to the North by the river Durance, to the South by the Massif des Quatre Termes and the plain of Aix, to the West by the A7 highway and to the East by the A51 highway.

The Massif des Roques, whose altitude varies from 394 m at Vernègues to 83 m in the plain, is characterised by a varied and very uneven relief, with steep slopes, deep valleys and interior plateaux. Its chalky cliffs are mainly west-southwest / east-northeast facing, while the valleys are mainly oriented North-South. This section of the massif is crossed by the RD16 and RD22 roads, and the TGV Méditerranée high-speed railway line.

The Chaîne des Côtes is a more compact massif, characterised by chalky rock formations and cliffs. It is set opposite the Luberon mountain, located beyond the river Durance. This massif rises to a height of 482 m and stretches out globally from East to West, between the plains of Durance and Lambesc. Its very ragged relief, in particular on the northern slope, lends it a quasi-mountainous aspect, and it can only be crossed via the D67 road and Plateau de Malivert. It is sheltered by the sub-massifs of Saint-Estève and La Quille, which form a succession of small and less rugged hills with gentle shapes descending from Bassin Saint-Christophe and petering out near Plateau de la Trévaresse. This northwest / southeast facing entity, regularly carved with northeast / southwest facing valleys, can only be crossed via the D66 road, linking Saint-Estève Janson and Rognes. 

Plateau de la Trévaresse forms a tabular, East-West facing barrier to the North of the plain of Aix. This plateau is crossed by numerous public roads, generally running from North to South: D13, D14, D543 and D18. It rises to an altitude of 502 m to the South of Cabannes, and is clearly divided into a northern and southern face, both with even slopes.

Situated in the coastal Provence climate zone, the Massif des Roques, Massif de la Chaîne des Côtes and Massif de la Trévaresse benefit from fairly warm average annual temperatures (13° C) and average to fairly low rainfall (600 to 700 mm/year). The prevailing wind is a diverted Mistral. …

Part of the small, natural region known as the Coteaux de Basse Durance, the Massif des Roques, Massif de la Chaîne des Côtes and Massif de la Trévaresse are, alongside Concors and Sainte-Victoire, the Bouches-du-Rhône's most highly-forested massifs. 
…

Their densely-forested and wild aspect is an intrinsic part of the quality of life of the surrounding villages, but despite this, they do not benefit from any particular protective measures. The northern hills are part of the vast ZICO (Bird Conservation Zone) covering the Plateau de l’Arbois, garrigues of Lançon and Chaîne des Côtes and intended to preserve the quality and authenticity of the environments available to birds inhabiting the Durance area (Bonelli's eagle, Egyptian vulture, eagle owl, Montagu's harrier, etc.). A voluntary nature reserve covering 700 acres was set up around Barben (Réserve Naturelle Volontaire de la Propriété de Saint-Pons) in 1991. These three massifs are also the site of several Natural Zones of Ecological, Faunistic and Floristic Interest (ZNIEFF), relative to their valleys, open peaks and unusual geological formations.

label: Plan d'eau de Cabannes
comment: Fishing on the lake of Cabannes, in the heart of Terres de Provence
shortDescription: Fishing on the lake of Cabannes, in the heart of Terres de Provence
description: The water surface of Cabannes measures 145 x 95 m. It is used by fishing associations and for some local nautical events.

label: Bibliothèque Li Campaneto
comment: Li Campaneto, annex of the Méjanes library is located in the heart of the village of Les Milles in the premises of the old Li Campaneto school.
shortDescription: Li Campaneto, annex of the Méjanes library is located in the heart of the village of Les Milles in the premises of the old Li Campaneto school.
description:
Li Campaneto, annex of the Méjanes library is located in the heart of the Les Milles village in the premises of the old school Li Campaneto.
Like the Halle aux grains, the Deux Ormes and the Méjanes, it offers many services.

On the ground floor of this 750 m2 building, there is a newsroom where you can comfortably read the press and discover documents selected by the librarians, a performing arts room, including music, cinema, dance and TV series. Children have plenty of space to satisfy their curiosity or participate in a workshop. On the first floor are gathered novels, literature, history and civilizations and everything related to practical life and leisure. On the second floor, a room dedicated to group work, to digital work and to exchange as part of a writing, visual arts or a club reading workshop.

A room also allows to plan cultural actions for all: meetings, workshops, screenings, readings, exhibitions, debates.

label: Eglise Saint-Michel
description: In the eighteenth century, Coudoux, a hamlet built two centuries earlier and dependent on Ventabren, was marked by a fierce determination by its inhabitants to create a genuine autonomous community and a full-fledged community, which it will become in 1950. Saint- Michel is the symbol and the founding act of this emancipation. Indeed, it was at the end of a legal struggle in 1707 that the inhabitants of the hamlet were able in 1746 to attend the offices without having to make the journey to Ventabren.The church is distinguished by a particularly original bell-tower and a tormented history. It was not built until 1788, with the participation of the entire population. At first it escaped from the fire of 1789 and then from lightning in 1901. It is surmounted by a wrought iron railing, a kind of light campanile and a weathercock, formed by an angel blowing in a trumpet. In front, next to a statue of Virgin and Child, the sundial bears the Latin poetic inscription Sic lucat lux vostra. Hoec ultima forsan (Let your hours shine like these: the one I mark is perhaps the last). The tradition, as was the case in many communes of Provence, is that the inhabitants are the custodians of a santon that they maintain and deposit in the nursery of the church for Christmas and then recover it on February 2.

label: Eglise de la Madeleine
comment: The church of the Madeleine was completed before 1410, and many campaigns of work have been carried out over the course of history, giving it its present appearance. Until the current neoclassical facade, a realization of the architect Revoil in 1855
shortDescription: The church of the Madeleine was completed before 1410, and many campaigns of work have been carried out over the course of history, giving it its present appearance. Until the current neoclassical facade, a realization of the architect Revoil in 1855
description:
The Madeleine Church stands in front of the Law Court in Place des Prêcheurs, built in the 15th century by René of Anjou, which was the centre of public and society life before Cours Mirabeau was opened. The church was built in 1691-1703 by Laurent Vallon, on the site of the former Dominican convent of Les Prêcheurs, founded in 1274. The façade was not completed but was given a monumental veneer by Revoil in 1855-1860. 

On the southern exterior and in the church chevet, medieval elements that were reused in the Vallon project can still be seen: the aisles, buttresses and gable walls. This church-museum contains work by a large number of artists who have lived in Aix, including the exceptional Altarpiece of the Annunciation dating from 1444. 

Paul Cézanne was baptised here. 

A new altar was built in 2004 using noble materials, including rock crystal. In 1988 the church was officially registered as a protected building and the convent listed. There is a Virgin with Child in Rue Portalis.

label: Chapelle Saint-Pierre-es-Liens
description: It is the oldest of the three Romanesque chapels of Alleins (11th century). Built close to a mausoleum from the Roman period (it preserves two listed capitals dating from the first centuries of Christianity), it is the former parish church of Alleins. Its facade was redesigned in the 19th century.

label: PLAGE DES MARETTES
comment: The beach of Les Marettes in Vitrolles is supervised from 15 June to 31 August. For those who do not appreciate overcrowded beaches. This little corner of paradise is ideal for the whole family.
shortDescription: The beach of Les Marettes in Vitrolles is supervised from 15 June to 31 August. For those who do not appreciate overcrowded beaches. This little corner of paradise is ideal for the whole family.
description:
Situated on the edge of the pond, the beach of Les Marettes is composed of a long stretch of sand fitted out with a wooden pontoon and bordered by tamarisk trees

This beach accessible to all, supervised from June 15 to August 31, is very pleasant to relax in the sun, to swim, to walk or to cultivate all summer long thanks to the animation "Read and play at the beach" proposed by the librarians of the city of Vitrolles.
 
Practical information :
Toilets and showers on site,
Handicapped access,
Parking nearby,
Tourist information point,
Water quality monitored.

label: Tombe seigneuriale sous arcade
comment: Vestige of a seigneurial tomb under an arcade (12th century), oriented and built in freestone.
shortDescription: Vestige of a seigneurial tomb under an arcade (12th century), oriented and built in freestone.
description: Excavations carried out in the 1970s, revealing 27 early Christian sarcophagi (5th-7th centuries), have demonstrated the antiquity of this funerary site, already attested by the use of the name Saint Vincent. The site of the necropolis is inscribed on the supplementary list of Historical Monuments.

label: Médiathèque du Roulage
description:
The media library is a public service responsible for contributing to the culture, leisure, information and documentation of the population.
In Lançon, the Roulage media library welcomes you in a warm and friendly setting. You will find more than 28,000 documents, including many new releases, nearly 4,000 CDs, 1,400 DVDs, 2,500 comic strips and a wide choice of magazines.
The media library is open to all. However, you must be registered to borrow
Registration is free of charge on presentation of proof of identity and proof of address. For minors, parental authorisation is required.

label: Tour de l'Horloge
description: The Clock Tower : built in 1900 with its dials in direction of the four cardinal points.

label: Chapelle Saint-Marcellin
comment: Nestled in the middle of the countryside and vineyards, this chapel with its bucolic airs attracts walkers and believers who come to seek calm and serenity in a natural environment of great quality.
shortDescription: Nestled in the middle of the countryside and vineyards, this chapel with its bucolic airs attracts walkers and believers who come to seek calm and serenity in a natural environment of great quality.
description:
Built on a site already dedicated to worship since the 8th century, the chapel dates from the 12th century. In Romanesque style, it is built on the simple plan of a single nave. In the 17th century, a hermitage was built perpendicular to the south façade. Until the middle of the XIXth century, hermits lived there, in charge of the care and maintenance of the chapel.
Mostly destroyed by the 1909 earthquake, it was restored between 1989 and 1996, notably by European youth workcamps. A new bell was installed as well as gargoyles created for the occasion. A modern sculpture of the bishop Saint Marcellin was placed in the lintel over the entrance door of the hermitage. At the top, we discover a stone sculpted with a double cross reinstalled in the 17th century. During the excavations which preceded the restoration, anonymous graves were found on the site as well as a carved stone vestige of a Gallo-Roman altar.
Until the end of the 17th century, on April 20th, the feast day of Saint Marcellin, after the procession to the chapel, the new consuls were elected for the year. The tradition of the pilgrimage will continue with the lunch on the grass after the mass. Today, the rognens perpetuate this festival in September. The mass takes place in the open air, followed by the blessing of the grape harvest and the country meal in the enclosure of the hermitage. Saint Marcellin, protector of the winegrowers, is the second patron saint of Rognes after Saint Denis (Dionysus). Source: Les Amis du Patrimoine de Rognes.

label: Fontaine de Bormes
comment: Historical fountain whose water supplied the village of Eyguières
shortDescription: Historical fountain whose water supplied the village of Eyguières
description: The spring called the Fountain of Borme owes its name to a Roman villa "Bormae" whose remains have been found nearby. It was the most important source of water in the village and was tapped towards the end of the 1950s and supplied the village with drinking water.

label: Hôtel de Mazargues
description: The monumental entrance is listed in the inventory of Historic Monuments.

label: Eglise  la Sainte Trinité
comment: This parish church, consecrated in 1829, is built on a plot of land of the former convent of the Trinitarians.
shortDescription: This parish church, consecrated in 1829, is built on a plot of land of the former convent of the Trinitarians.
description: This parish church, consecrated in 1829, was built on a plot of the former Trinitarian Convent ( Couvent des Trinitaires). The semi-circular baptistery, located on the left as you enter, is vaulted in a " cul-de-four" ( a vault in a shape of a quarter sphere). Beautiful paintings by Dominique Magaud' (19th century) and his sister Marie, representing the baptism of Christ, and Saint Michael with a child.  A large cross overhangs the baptismal basin.

label: Phare de Faraman
comment: This lighthouse is in the form of a tapered tower which stands 46.5 metres above sea-level. It is one of the highest Mediterranean lighthouses. It is a stone construction, widened at the base and with a corbel at the top.
shortDescription: This lighthouse is in the form of a tapered tower which stands 46.5 metres above sea-level. It is one of the highest Mediterranean lighthouses. It is a stone construction, widened at the base and with a corbel at the top.
description:
In 1934, the smooth masonry was painted with six alternating horizontal black and white stripes. It was restored between 1947 and 1950, due to damage suffered in the Second World War. In 1972, it received a wind turbine and was automated.
In 1967, it was used as the set for a scene in Robert Dhéry's film 'Le Petit Baigneur (The Little Bather) with Louis de Funès.
The lighthouse is now powered by the national electricity network and is no longer manned.

label: Arènes
comment: Arena of Orgon.
shortDescription: Arena of Orgon.
description: The arenas were created in 1907 by Albert Laty, passionate cafetier of bullfighting. Bullfights are interrupted at the time of the second world war. Arenas then welcome various performances and were often used as bowling alley. These arenas are now maintained by the City Council and managed by the bullfighting Club.Seat of the bullfighting Club: Bar in the future.President: Mr Michel.Phone number: 04 42 55 61 51.

label: Réserve naturelle du Parc de l'ancienne Poudrerie royale
comment: Created under Louis XIV, the Poudrerie is an exceptional and unique natural area of 118 hectares on the edge of the Etang de Berre located in the communes of Miramas and Saint Chamas.
shortDescription: Created under Louis XIV, the Poudrerie is an exceptional and unique natural area of 118 hectares on the edge of the Etang de Berre located in the communes of Miramas and Saint Chamas.
description:
An industrial past of national importance, a unique built heritage that evokes the life of the royal powder factory at the time of the production of explosive powders. Nowadays, a remarkable and diversified natural heritage. Since the end of the activity in 1974, the fauna and flora have found a real sanctuary. 130 species of birds have been listed, and the trails allow visitors to discover the wetlands, drylands and salt flats on foot or by bike.
Presence of surprising species.

Free site, open every Wednesday, and 1st, 3rd and 5th Sunday, from 9am to 6pm
July - August: open from Monday to Friday, from 7am to 12pm

Management natural area: Area of the Conservatoire de l'Espace Littoral et des Rivages Lacustres. Natura 2000 site.

label: Le Rhône
comment: The Rhône and its delta not only gave their name to the department, this peaceful and majestic river is also the backbone of the Bouches-du-Rhône.
shortDescription: The Rhône and its delta not only gave their name to the department, this peaceful and majestic river is also the backbone of the Bouches-du-Rhône.
description:
The Rhone and its delta have not only given their name to the department, but this peaceful and majestic river also forms the backbone of the Bouches-du-Rhone. From Avignon to the Camargue beaches, the river passes through the most authentic Provençal landscapes. Famous for a long time for the rapidity of its current and the fury of its floods, the Rhone was only really developed from the 19th century, with diking and the creation of locks and canals.
Along its banks stand Avignon, Tarascon, Beaucaire and Arles, where the river splits into two branches - the Grand and the Petit Rhone - between which lies the Camargue. These two branches of the river are navigable and offer tourists access to the most unique discoveries of the Camargue.

label: Mas du Juge
comment:
Former viguerie of the Prosecutor of the Prince of Monaco.
An avenue of plane trees running alongside an olive grove, a shady courtyard with trees, a terrace offering a panoramic view of the Alpilles.
shortDescription:
Former viguerie of the Prosecutor of the Prince of Monaco.
An avenue of plane trees running alongside an olive grove, a shady courtyard with trees, a terrace offering a panoramic view of the Alpilles.
description:
Everything in the town evokes the memory of the great Provençal poet. The Mas du Juge, where Mistral was born in 1830, is in Maillane. This 18th century building, which entered the possession of the Mistral family in 1803, had a permanent effect on the poet's soul. It was here that he spent 25 years of his life and found the inspiration for 'Miréio', which he started to write within its walls. Since Mistral's time and despite the passing of the years, the dining room in the Mas is still in almost its original condition. Room and museum open to visitors.
The Mas du Juge recently became a venue for temporary exhibitions, seminars and receptions.

label: Plage de Beauduc
comment: The beach of Beauduc in Camargue is one of the last totally wild beaches in France. Located at 11 km from Salin de Giraud
shortDescription: The beach of Beauduc in Camargue is one of the last totally wild beaches in France. Located at 11 km from Salin de Giraud
description:
Its vast sandy expanse over several kilometers is bordered by ponds. After a long chaotic drive, you will arrive at one of the most beautiful natural areas in the region. Beauduc is also one of the most famous spots for kitesurfing fans

On the parking lot of Beauduc and on the back beach, dogs must be kept on a leash. On the beach, dogs are allowed without restriction

label: Le Lavoir
description: This former wash-house is located on the road to Plan d'Aups at the level of the bridge of St Roch. The washerwomen used to go there to wash their clothes and chat with each other.

label: Les Oratoires
comment: Above the Vieux Bassin, in the old "Surloir" district, you can take the rocky path that goes up to Notre Dame du Château.
shortDescription: Above the Vieux Bassin, in the old "Surloir" district, you can take the rocky path that goes up to Notre Dame du Château.
description: Above the old basin, in the old district of "Surloir", can take the Rocky path which climbs up to Notre Dame du Ch��teau. Four oratories along this trail. They are dedicated to St. Sebastian, St. Blaise, Saint-Antoine, and Saint Vincent. After having followed some ruins of old city walls, the remains of the former castrum of the XII th century appear.

label: La Fabrique
description: C ' is on the small road to the gardens that stands this magnificent property, created at the beginning of the 19th century by the Mistral family.It is a remarkable example of the industrial dynamism of the time, linked to agriculture, the transformation of the madder and Thistle Teasel.In 1985, the factory hosts the panigel Foundation "60 years of collection" of the famous musicologist and cinematologue Armand Panigel.Recognized public utility, the factory becomes a true witness of the cultural heritage of the 20th century.

label: Ecomusée de la Forêt Méditerranéenne
description:
With its 1000 m2 of exhibitions on 3 levels and a landscaped trail crossing a 13 ha forest park, the forest ecomuseum offers you a fun and interactive way to discover the secrets of the Mediterranean forest. It aims to convey ideas and knowledge about the environment but above all to raise awareness among a wide public to this regional forest heritage so rich and so fragile. An enriching visit full of surprises awaits you.
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 650
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 240

label: Fontaine Cocotte
comment: Discover this fountain, classified as a historical monument
shortDescription: Discover this fountain, classified as a historical monument
description: Fountain built in 1830, one of the most beautiful in the village. Listed as a historical monument in 1923.

label: Village de Saint-Savournin
description:
Small Provencal village, Saint Savournin is built under the rock of the Etoile chain. It is located between Aix and Marseille. Composed of several districts and the hamlet of Valentine, the village extends in the middle of cultivable lands and forests.
There are several signposted footpaths with walls full of history for ideas for walks (the fountain opposite the post office, the philharmonic circle, the château comtal and its farm...)
From the Chemin de Croix and the old feudal castle of Castellas, you can admire a magnificent panorama that extends to the Sainte Victoire,

This village has the particularity of having had to build no less than 4 churches since the year 768!
A first church was built between 768 and 923, probably on the ruins of a temple dedicated to Saturn on the place currently occupied by the Post Office
A second church was built on the site of the first in 1683, but was demolished in 1865
A third one was built 200 meters further between 1851 and 1853 by the archbishop of Marseille on the place of the current city hall. In 1873, the church was decorated with superb paintings recalling the martyrdom of Saint Saturnin. In 1932, two other bells were added to the only one called "Félicité", the "Philomène Noémie" and the "Louise Noémie"
From 1937-38, the work on the Germain Well caused many tremors in the whole village and particularly in the vicinity of the church. In October 1942, a violent storm flooded the country and further weakened the building which slipped and sank. The rains that followed worsened the situation and in 1946, the church was divided in two: the upper part remained clinging to the rock, while the lower part was gradually sliding down. After some unfortunate work, the town council decided to demolish the church in 1960. A fourth church was then built in 1961 on the site of the parish hall, in a more contemporary style, wiping out the previous churches.

label: Le Jardin Remarquable du Château Val Joanis
comment: Val Joanis castle was built on the vestiges of an ancient Roman villa.
shortDescription: Val Joanis castle was built on the vestiges of an ancient Roman villa.
description:
The formal (French style) garden was created in 1978 and is composed of 3 terraces with a vegetable garden, an orchard, a botanical garden, an olive grove, a central basin and a quadrangle. 

Since 2005, the garden has been listed as a 'remarkable garden' by ruling of the French Ministry of Cultural Affairs. 

Free wine and olive tasting.

Groups welcome upon request.

label: Grotte Rolland
comment:
The Grotte Rolland is a deep excavation created by an underground river.
Its name comes from an 18th century highwayman, who was rampant in Marseille with his band of brigands and had set up his lair in this cave
shortDescription:
The Grotte Rolland is a deep excavation created by an underground river.
Its name comes from an 18th century highwayman, who was rampant in Marseille with his band of brigands and had set up his lair in this cave
description:
The entrance of the cave, 3 meters high, and a path that can be dangerous, leads to the "Devil's Chapel", a beautiful room 10 meters in diameter and 20 meters high, and then to the "treasure gallery", several dozen meters deep.
Access on foot only, on a signposted path.

Management of natural areas: Domaine du Conseil Général

label: Eglise Saint-Paul
description:
Paul of Tarsus or St. Paul, also bearing the Jewish name of Saul, pronounced "Shaul" (probably born in Tarsus in Cilicia at the beginning of the first century and died about 67-68 in Rome), is an apostle of Jesus Christ, although he is not one of the "Twelve". He is a Roman citizen by birth and a Jewish Pharisee. The New Testament presents him as a persecutor of the followers of Jesus until his mystical encounter with Christ, c. 32-361, but the reality of these persecutions is debated in modern historiography, as is the use of the term "conversion" in relation to him.

During the 1940s, Paul founded several churches in the territory of present-day Turkey, and made a second missionary journey to Asia Minor and Greece. In the 1950s and 1960s, while continuing his itinerant mission, he addressed a number of letters to these new churches.

These letters, known as the "Pauline Epistles", are the oldest documents of Christianity. All were written before the Gospels. They represent one of the foundations of Christian theology, especially in the field of Christology, but also from a historical point of view.

Reception from Monday to Saturday from 9am to 11am.

Masses on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8:30 am, Saturday early mass at 6:30 pm and Sunday at 10 am.

label: Place Jean Jaurès
description:
Born from the ruins of the earthquake that shook the town in June 1909, Place Jean Jaurès is a space located in the heart of the historic town centre, surrounded by old mansions from the 17th and 18th centuries.
The shade of the hundred-year-old plane trees that adorn it make it a very pleasant place for concerts and shows throughout the summer.

label: Musée d'art contemporain de Marseille [mac]
comment:
Waiting  for  re-opening in decembre 2021. You  will be able to see 5  exhibitions divided in  5 parts. In different areas of the  city 1/7,2/3,4/5 and 15/16. An artistic walk shared with different city's  annexes.

With almost 800 works of art. The Mac collection gives an account of most of the  production of  the second half of the twentieth century and the begginning of the twenty  first. It is  made up of  works of art of high quality.Whether it those of the  New realists support surface, Arte povera, Land Art or the  Fluxbus movement.
shortDescription:
Waiting  for  re-opening in decembre 2021. You  will be able to see 5  exhibitions divided in  5 parts. In different areas of the  city 1/7,2/3,4/5 and 15/16. An artistic walk shared with different city's  annexes.

With almost 800 works of art. The Mac collection gives an account of most of the  production of  the second half of the twentieth century and the begginning of the twenty  first. It is  made up of  works of art of high quality.Whether it those of the  New realists support surface, Arte povera, Land Art or the  Fluxbus movement.
description:
With almost 800 works of art. The  Mac collection gives an account of most of the  production of the  second half of the twentieth century and the beginning of the twenty first. It is made up of works of art of high quality. Whether it those of the New realists support surface, Arte Povera, Land Art on the Fluxus movement.

In the garden adjoining the  museum, many piece of  from Alberola, Julien Blaine, César, Erik Dietman and Fabrice Guygi complete the  exhibition.

Surface of the permanent exhibition : 1700
Surface of the temporary exhibition : 800

label: Calanque des Pierres Tombées
comment: Cove of rocks and stone slabs, 100 meters long, adjoining the cove of Sugiton. Naturism is tolerated.
shortDescription: Cove of rocks and stone slabs, 100 meters long, adjoining the cove of Sugiton. Naturism is tolerated.
description:
This cove is now included in the Calanques National Park.
End of the bus B1 then 1 hour walk.

label: La Maison de la Boule de la Pétanque et du Jeu provençal
comment: The Maison de la Boule awaits you, in a friendly atmosphere, to share a moment around the mini track or to enrich your boulomanes knowledge.
shortDescription: The Maison de la Boule awaits you, in a friendly atmosphere, to share a moment around the mini track or to enrich your boulomanes knowledge.
description: The Maison de la Boule awaits you, in a friendly atmosphere, to share a moment around the mini track or to enrich your boulomanes knowledge.

label: Parc Christine Bernard - Promenade de l'Arc
description:
A walk along the banks of the Arc which flows to the south of the city. The walk follows the meanders of the river and includes play areas for children, a fitness trail, and meadows shaded by large trees near the water.


It covers an area of 100,000m2. History: The municipality purchased the land in 1976 to make it into a walk. It has been open to the public since 1977.

label: Jardin des 5 sens et des formes premières
comment: In the enhanced garrigue, this shaded area of 2.5 hectares offers a contemporary interpretation of the baroque style that has left its mark on the gardens of Aix.
shortDescription: In the enhanced garrigue, this shaded area of 2.5 hectares offers a contemporary interpretation of the baroque style that has left its mark on the gardens of Aix.
description:
Contemporary garden of 2 hectares 50 located at the exit of Aix-en-Provence in the direction of Vauvenargues. Spaces have been specifically created to appeal to the five senses of visitors. The association and the strong and well-integrated presence of the Primary Forms and various works of art invite a symbolic approach to this bucolic space where a dialogue between nature and culture is proposed.

In a Mediterranean scrubland setting, spaces have been created where vegetation and water appeal to the senses, and the boudoir of scents awakens the sense of smell. Closely interwoven, the primary forms complete the symbolism of the place. The tour also offers visitors the opportunity to discover works of art, some of which are permanent, as well as the creations of a guest artist for the summer period.
streetAddress: ['220 Chemin de Repentance à la forêt']

label: Les fours à céramique
description:
The ceramic industry of Saint-Zacharie played a leading role until the 19th century in supplying the South and, beyond, the colonies.

The most spectacular testimony is currently the recently restored battery of four flame ovens.

With impressive dimensions (between 5.20 and 5.80 m high, about 7 m wide and 8.65 m long), these buildings have a very simple internal structure. A single baking chamber above the fireplaces is built of rubble lined with bricks and largely scraped.
The vaults and tiles are made of thin masonry blocks mounted on arches. These elevations are doubled by two heating chambers, with access corridors and fireplaces each supplying coal to an oven.

This device is both the last witness of the industrial past that shaped the identity of Saint-Zacharie and the last visible witness in France, to our knowledge, of this type of installation, which probably dates from the end of the 19th century

label: La nécropole Saint-Vincent
comment: In 1964, while digging a new access to the cemetery, nine sarcophagi of an early Christian necropolis were discovered.
shortDescription: In 1964, while digging a new access to the cemetery, nine sarcophagi of an early Christian necropolis were discovered.
description:
In 1971, 18 more sarcophagi were uncovered
The abundance of Campanian shards dates the site to the 1st century BC.

label: La place de l'Ange
comment: In the 1900s, an elm tree shaded the square. Many small shops surrounded it. The houses of the notables were already quite degraded but people still went to fetch water from the old fountain...
shortDescription: In the 1900s, an elm tree shaded the square. Many small shops surrounded it. The houses of the notables were already quite degraded but people still went to fetch water from the old fountain...
description:
A SQUARE IN THE HEART OF THE CITY
Located in the Royère district, it dates back to the first extension of the city in the 12th-13th centuries. It is the heart of the Old City. The origin of its name remains unknown. In the Middle Ages, the only spring in the city flowed here, the miraculous water that gave birth to the city. It seems that there has never been an angel on the fountain, or elsewhere on the square, a hypothesis that is dear to the hearts of the people of Pertuis
The communal oven of the Angel, where the population had to bake their bread, as well as one of the five oil mills, were located nearby: the oven, behind the Consuls' house, the mill, at the beginning of the rue Fontaine
At the end of the 18th century, the perspective view shows a lively square with well-ordered facades. Only a few examples remain.

THE HOUSE KNOWN AS THE CONSULS' HOUSE
With its corner bossing and its niche with a cul-de-four saint, this notable house would have been built in the 17th century by the Spigoni or Spain family who gave the city many consuls
Its facades were redesigned in the 18th century, its crosses replaced by large windows topped by segmental arches. The very beautiful original door framed by two sculpted heads and its transom decorated with a wrought iron gate are remarkable.

THE FOUNTAIN
The oldest fountain of the city is the only source inside the ramparts. The second spring, called "l'Aubarestière" (1), was located on the Place de la Diane. At the beginning of the 16th century, the water supply was insufficient for the population, which was increasing rapidly. The city council decided to divert water from the abundant Font de Viade, which flowed at the limit of the territories of Pertuis and La Tour d'Aigues. This did not go without armed contestation from the Tourrains!
An arbitration had to intervene and the lord of the Tour d'Aigues, François de Boliers, gave up the water of Viade only against 200 cups (2) "of good and old red wine"!
In 1509, the fountain of the Angel was rebuilt. The current state dates from 1620: octagonal basin, godroned urn (3) in the center whose four masks, worn by time, pour the water.

THE HOUSE OF FRANCOIS 1ER
On October 5, 1522, after the invasion of Provence by Charles Quint, François I, on his way to Italy, was welcomed in this house
It was Antoine de Chabert, syndic of Pertuis, who presented the king with the city's requests for reparation for the damage suffered during the war.
The king granted all these requests and the name of François 1er remained attached to the house of the de Chabert.
The present house, at the corner of rue Saint-Pierre, was built later, at the end of the 16th century, by one of the descendants of this family.
The mullioned windows of the main facade on the Place de l'Ange can still be seen. An imposing molded stringcourse, supported by acanthus leaf brackets, highlights the first floor. But it is the monumental portal of the rue St-Pierre in Mannerist style, very similar to the one of the house known as Queen Jeanne, which evokes the former wealth of this residence.

(1) Crossbow shooting range
(2) 50hl, 1 cup = 25 l
(3) Godron : ornament of elongated oval shape

label: La Placetto
comment: Small square located in the city center of Châteaurenard.
shortDescription: Small square located in the city center of Châteaurenard.
description: At the foot of the facade of No. 23 of the square, a well dug into the rock marks its originality by its position both inside and outside the house.

label: Le forum culturel d'Aix-en-Provence
comment: Aix-en-Provence, modern and contemporary with this new cultural forum in the extension of the Allées, which focuses on five major facilities, with great names in architecture
shortDescription: Aix-en-Provence, modern and contemporary with this new cultural forum in the extension of the Allées, which focuses on five major facilities, with great names in architecture
description:
Aix-en-Provence, modern and contemporary with its new cultural forum, an extension of the Provencal Alleys. It offers five major facilities, designed by well-known architects.

The Grand Théâtre de Provence (inaugurated in 2007), was designed by the Milanese architect Vittorio Gregotti who wished to harmonize the architecture with the urban context. The amphitheater can accommodate 1366 spectators.
Next to the Grand Theatre (GTP), is the National Choreographic Centre, the Pavillon Noir . It was designed by Rudy Ricciotti French architect worldly known who also signed the MUCEM in Marseille. The architect has developed a cube with four rehearsal rooms and a stage. 

Since 2006, Pavilion Noir hosts the Ballet Preljocaj.
Down the street, you will find the Conservatory Darius Milhaud, designed by Kengo Kuma and inaugurated in 2013. This building looks like the Origami, it has 62 rooms of music education, two drama classrooms, four dance studios and a 500-seat auditorium.

In the same area, is the Méjanes Library that contains many literary works.

In the immediate vicinity of the conservatory, is the water wall inaugurated in 2014. Designed by Christophe Ghion, it is the largest in Europe with its 700m2. On its northern slope, the green wall of Patrick Blanc consists of more than 20 000 plants.

Free wi-fi coverage in this area ("Aixmaville" network).

label: Moulin à huile de Puyloubier
description:
The mill was in operation until the frost of 1956 which destroyed the olive groves. Since 1998, the tourist office has used the renovated Oil Mill Museum to hold a series of exhibitions in summer.


The Museum was renovated in 1992 on the initiative of the mayor of Puyloubier, André Guineri. It also houses the village library. It displays agricultural tools, presses and other utensils used for pressing the oil. 


This magnificent, unique site is used as an exhibition space, with artists showing 20 paintings. The artistic directors encourage work by amateur artists and beginners

label: Chapelle des Minimes
description:
This chapel has been restored by the municipality.
The 32 metres long and 6 metres wide chapel, was, during the French Revolution, the headquarters of the Anti-Political Club, a popular society recognized as a subsidiary by the centre of Thubaneau Street in Marseille (1791).
The Chapel is adjoining, on the left, the synagogue open to the parking lot (Square Verdun) and, on the right, the dance academy opening onto the former courtyard of the convent.
Note the three-hundred-year-old door of beautiful craftsmanship.

label: Plage calanque de Samena
comment: Small cove covered with small pebbles, surrounded by white rocks, in the direction of Les Goudes. This cove is now included in the Calanques National Park.
shortDescription: Small cove covered with small pebbles, surrounded by white rocks, in the direction of Les Goudes. This cove is now included in the Calanques National Park.
description: Between Madrague de Montredon and les Goudes, bus 19 to the terminus then bus 20.

label: Mémorial des déportations
comment: Located at the bottom of Saint-Jean Fort, the memorial of the Death camps was  inaugurated in 1995 on the  occasion of  the  50th birthday of  the freedom of the camps.
shortDescription: Located at the bottom of Saint-Jean Fort, the memorial of the Death camps was  inaugurated in 1995 on the  occasion of  the  50th birthday of  the freedom of the camps.
description:
It is located in a blockhaus of the  second world  war built  by the german  army as a part of defensive lockdown to prevent an allied landing in provence.

In 2019, it has been renovated in a  bigger  concept of  Memorial of the deportations in order to realize the singularity of Marseille during the Second World War : the main refuge city in the  non-occupied zone, a transit city, a destroyed city, a strategic port city. The  Memorial contextualises the policies of genocidal deportation and repression organised in Marseille and its  region thanks  to maps, movies, testimonies, victim's  stories because born jewish or repressed as politic resistant or hostage. The exhibition deals with tragic events of 1943 led by the Nazis with Vichy  collaboration : rafle , deportation and destruction of the old districts and  north bank of the  Old port.

The Memorial of  deportations is combined with the Marseille history museum .
Free admission within the limits capacity.

label: Monument aux morts de l'Armée d'Orient
comment: This monument was erected by the architect Castel in 1927 in memory of the soldiers of all denominations who "died for France" in North Africa.
shortDescription: This monument was erected by the architect Castel in 1927 in memory of the soldiers of all denominations who "died for France" in North Africa.
streetAddress: ['Corniche J.F Kennedy près du Vallon des Auffes']

label: Palais du Pharo
comment: The Pharo promontory was once called More's Head. It was a rocky plateau on which only rushes and sea grasses grew and where a few guinguettes were installed.
shortDescription: The Pharo promontory was once called More's Head. It was a rocky plateau on which only rushes and sea grasses grew and where a few guinguettes were installed.
description:
The Pharo promontory was once called Tête de More, meaning Moorish Head. It was a rocky plateau on which only rushes and wild grasses grew, with a few "guinguettes" (small restaurants with music and dancing). Pharo was the name of the cove just to the west of the Tête de More. The “Farot” was a mound separating the cove from the open sea, and providing a look-out point, first mentioned in the 14th century.
The residence was not much appreciated and the Emperor never actually used it. On the death of Napoleon III, the Empress Eugénie became the sole owner of the Pharo, and generously donated it to the city. In 1904 major changes were made to the Palais du Pharo to convert it into a medical school. The balance of the volumes was disrupted by raising the wings and the interior distribution was ruined.
It was Prince-President Louis-Napoleon who decided to build an imperial residence in Marseille. During a visit in September 1852, he expressed the desire to have "a house at the water's edge". At the end of that year, he commissioned the architect Vaucher to find a site for his residence and draw up the plans. Then Napoleon III's architect Lefuel was put in charge of the project. For their part, the City authorities decided to donate the selected sites: La Réserve and the Pharo. Napoleon III accepted the donation "wishing in this way to convey to the City of Marseilles another expression of friendship and to further strengthen the bonds linking him to this great patriotic city".
However, thanks to its exceptional location and the creation of a Conference Centre that receives up to 60,000 people a year, the former Imperial Residence is today a prestigious architectural complex, one of the finest in Europe. Tradition has been respected and the site protected, by integrating the new spaces into the Palais and creating underground conference rooms under the forecourt of the original building. The site comprises ceremonial rooms, a 1200 m2 exhibition hall, a 500 m2 restaurant and a 900-seat auditorium which can be adapted to accommodate conferences or seminars by means of a highly sophisticated system.

label: Hôtel de Roquesante
description:
Designed by the architect Jean Lombard, this seventeenth century baroque gate has a single door. 

The interior designs are called pearls and pirouettes. 


The diamond-shaped studs on the front are used to connect the different thicknesses of the gate.


Text : OTAIX/ENTE

label: Chapelle du Calvaire
comment:
Rural chapel, in neo-gothic style, with an elongated plan and a single nave ending in a choir with cut-off sides.
The high windows are pointed arches and decorated with stained glass windows.  The vault of the choir is framed.
shortDescription:
Rural chapel, in neo-gothic style, with an elongated plan and a single nave ending in a choir with cut-off sides.
The high windows are pointed arches and decorated with stained glass windows.  The vault of the choir is framed.
description: Built over a large cross, hence its name, the chapel was struck by lightning and burnt down in 1890. Restored by its owner and a group of volunteers, this beautiful stone chapel is a cultural and meeting place Hosts exhibitions, concerts, conferences ...

label: Bibliothèque municipale
comment: Venelles Library
shortDescription: Venelles Library
description: Throughout the year, the library hosts cultural events, mainly focused on literature, through the discovery of texts, authors...

label: La Camargue
comment: The Camargue is a wilderness formed by the Rhone delta. It is classified as a biosphere reserve by UNESCO, and also protected by a Regional Natural Park.
shortDescription: The Camargue is a wilderness formed by the Rhone delta. It is classified as a biosphere reserve by UNESCO, and also protected by a Regional Natural Park.
description:
The Camargue begins at the gates of Arles, in the commune of Saintes Maries de la Mer, and continues to Port-Saint-Louis du Rhône.

Come and discover the fauna (including bulls, horses and pink flamingos), the flora and the agriculture thanks to its visits, routes and itineraries between marshes, rice fields, manades and protected areas.

label: Chapelle Notre-Dame d'Aide
comment: Located at the top of the old village of Pennes-Mirabeau, the small building built of bare rubble, has a double-arch bell tower
shortDescription: Located at the top of the old village of Pennes-Mirabeau, the small building built of bare rubble, has a double-arch bell tower
description: Located at the top of the old village of Pennes-Mirabeau, the small building constructed of bare stones, presents a bell-tower with double arches. The interior of this chapel of the White Penitents has been preserved, with its laterally arranged benches, the seat of the rector of the brotherhood, and the attributes of procession, monstrance-sun, lanterns, and crucifixes. Six ex-voters show in a moving way, the benefactory intervention of the Virgin and the testimony of recognition of the survivors. A painting, the Assumption of the Virgin, represents the White Penitents. A few meters from the chapel are the Lantern of Memory, which is none other than the monument to the dead of the Pennes, an oratory, as well as a windmill, from which one enjoys a panoramic view of the pond of Berre and the chain of Nerthe. Visit by appointment with the Tourist office.

label: Musée d'Histoire de Marseille - (MHM)
comment:
"Oldest town of France with 2 600 years of history, Marseille will open the doors of its new history museum in September, Thursday, September 12, 2013. 
At a few steps from the Old Port, around the ancient port where Marseille was founded by Phocians, the History Museum, with exceptional technology, will present collections unique and previously unpublished 3,500 m2, evidence of a particularly rich past.
shortDescription:
"Oldest town of France with 2 600 years of history, Marseille will open the doors of its new history museum in September, Thursday, September 12, 2013. 
At a few steps from the Old Port, around the ancient port where Marseille was founded by Phocians, the History Museum, with exceptional technology, will present collections unique and previously unpublished 3,500 m2, evidence of a particularly rich past.
description:
Archaeological remains.
The largest fleet of ancient vessels in the world, fully restored and presented to the public for the first time.-Lʼéglise de Malaval of 5th century discovered during archaeological excavations helped to better understand the beginnings of Christianity in Western Europe and to reconstruct the Holy oil manufacture.-La Grotte Cosquer testifies one human occupation in Marseille, long before its foundation in 600 BC. Thousands of paintings and prints adorn this cave, inhabited more than 27,000 years ago.

A Museum without walls.
Thanks to ultra-modern multimedia tools, the Museum presents history of Marseille, beyond its own borders.A numerical application will allow customers with smartphones or tablets to discover some places and monuments of the city such as HMR were once (antiquity, middle ages...). This technology will provide both historical information and a faithful reconstruction of the site, thanks to augmented reality.

Until the end of the month of June History Museum entrance ticket allows you to visit the La Marseillaise memorial Saturdays and Sundays at fixed hours and on prior registration.

Guided tours on permanent collections : first  saturday of the  month.
Historic way tour: first sunday  of the  month.
Discovery booklet-game " le jeu des petits  massaliotes", for children aged 8 to  12.
The Marseillaise  memorial, the museum of the Roman Docks and the memorial of the Death camps ( curretly  closed for works) are located on the same routes and are attached to the Marseille History museum.
Find the museum and its related sites on the Facebook page of the Museum of History.
Entrance on rue Barbusse.
The tactile tablets are  no longer available, nor the audio guides, nor the doc for  children, because of the Covid-19.
Surface of the permanent  exhibition : 1800
Surface of the temporary  exhibition: 150.

label: Chapelle St Roch
description:
Built in 1643 on the initiative of the Notre Dame de la Rose congregation, this chapel stands on the site of a leper colony, La Maladie, abandoned in 1585.

Rectangular in shape, it ends in a truncated triangle apse. Only one very narrow window in the north wall opens onto the choir. The façade, almost square, gives this small monument an impression of solidity. The rectangular door has only a straight lintel, forming a cornice, for decoration only, and an oculus as an internal light source. The whole is topped by a very simple bell, whose bell bears the following inscription: "Dieu, Le roi, La France" (God, The King, France).
During the Revolution, the chapel was sold as a national asset. In 1820, put up for sale by its owner, a group of seven Lambescains bought it to restore it and donated it to the parish in 1821.

Today the chapel belongs to the commune, which leaves the use of it to the Protestant Church for the celebration of worship.

label: Meunerie hydraulique de Barbegal
comment: The remains of the largest known concentration of mechanical power in the ancient world, the Barbegal mill (2nd century) would have produced flour for the city of Arelate (Arles).
shortDescription: The remains of the largest known concentration of mechanical power in the ancient world, the Barbegal mill (2nd century) would have produced flour for the city of Arelate (Arles).
description:
The remains of this imposing testimony to ancient engineering were identified and excavated by Fernand Benoît in the immediate post-war period. Until then, they had been interpreted as either a retention pond, part of the hydraulic network taking water from the Alpilles to Arles, or as a fulling mill.
Two sets of eight flour mills were placed on either side of a covered central staircase along which the water from a diversion of the Caperon aqueduct ran in two parallel channels.
