label: Eglise St Julien
description:
Also previously called Saint Antoine
Era: Classical period
Type: Religious architecture
Originally built in the 12th century, during the mediaeval Renaissance, Saint Julien Church was rebuilt in the 17th century during another period of religious restructuring in the Church.
It is located on the boundary of the Cavalerie district, where a number of noblemen built their sumptuous residences during the same period, having made their fortune through trade.
Its architecture is a curious combination of late Gothic and Classical.
Stripped of most of its wonderful furniture during the Revolution, the building suffered again during the 1944 bombings, which left it in ruins.
Saint Julien was restored, but is no longer the parish church that it was for centuries. It can still be visited during the concerts held there on a regular basis.
Site plan of the church
The southern Gothic style of this church, which was rebuilt in the 17th century, can still be seen in its typical Arles religious architecture.
A beautiful Classical façade, with elements of Baroque décor (cherubs, niches, etc.), precedes the Gothic nave.
Most of the furniture, as well as the historiated stained glass windows by Guibert d'Anelle (19th century), disappeared in the bombings.
The only survivor from the 17th century is the beautiful gilded wood altarpiece, a gift from the Brotherhood of the Saint Sacrement. The central painting depicting Saint Julian the Hospitalier (1686) is by Louis Parrocel. On either side of this are The Last Supper and an Adoration of the Magi attributed to Gabriel d'Aix.
On either side of the chancel are statues of Saint Julian the Hospitalier and Saint Antoine, the Abbot. Finally, visitors can see a marble Virgin whose design is attributed to Revoil, a student of David, and a Way of the Cross painted in 1958 by Guy Renne.
The church's bell tower has two bells, one of which, from 1691, is one of the oldest in the town.

label: Abbaye de Montmajour
comment: Located at the gates of Arles, the Benedictine abbey is an example of a monument that testifies to nearly 8 centuries of history and architecture in Provence intended for a community of 50 to 80 monks.
shortDescription: Located at the gates of Arles, the Benedictine abbey is an example of a monument that testifies to nearly 8 centuries of history and architecture in Provence intended for a community of 50 to 80 monks.
description: Located on the outskirts of the city of Arles, the Benedictine abbey of Montmajour is an exceptional example of a monument that bears witness to nearly eight centuries of history and architecture in Provence for a community of 50 to 80 monks consists of several buildings and forms a repertoire of Romanesque, Gothic and Classical styles presenting eight centuries of history and monastic architecture from 949 to 1791. It is also a place of inspiration for modern and contemporary art, the site fascinates Van Gogh (1853-1890) who made many drawings there in 1888-1889. "Ascension", the work that Alain Kirili (born in 1946) created for the abbey choir, pays tribute to his use of color "in thickness".Since April 14, 2017, the Abbey has once again opened access to the visit of the hermitage. The only testimony in Western Europe of a pre-Roman architecture in its entirety. The work of the hermitage Saint Peter is completed after 4 years with the restoration of the exterior cladding, the cleaning of the walls, the realization of plasters of gaps and decorative supports, the resumption of the floors, rock, stone and the lighting of the interior volumes of the cave parts. This 11th century cave chapel, originally a simple rock shelter for a few anachorets, is the oldest architectural witness to the abbey.

label: Musée Regards de Provence
comment: Regards de Provence is housed in a former maritime  health station buit by F.Pouillon in 1948 which is 20 th century label.
shortDescription: Regards de Provence is housed in a former maritime  health station buit by F.Pouillon in 1948 which is 20 th century label.
description:
Museum honours its collections of paintings, sculptures, photographies and drawings dedicated to Marseille, "la Provence", "la Méditerranée" from XVIII to nowadays.

It also offers temporary modern  and contemporary exhibitions all year long.
The museum offers  a panoramic view on the Joliette port. Saint Jean fort, Mucem and villa mediterranée Café.

Free guided tours on reservation (  except for groups): saturday at 10.30 (  from 6  to 25 people maximum).

Guided tours( except groups) on reservation  :  from monday to saturday  entrance fee + 6  euros per person (6 to 25 people)

Guided tours on reservation except groups : tuesday  and saturday at  3 pm, entrance fee + 6 euros (6 to  25 people maximum)

Subscriptions closed the day  before at  6 pm.
Temporary  exhibition surface : 420.

label: Médiathèque Edmonde Charles-Roux Defferre
description: The media library provides you with printed and audiovisual documents to help you get informed, relax and educate yourself. It is open to all. Entrance is free and free of charge for the use of the premises and the consultation of documents on site. In addition, a free internet access allows you to carry out your research on the web. 5 postmen are at your disposal.

label: Les ruines du Castellas
description:
The perched ruined castle dates from the 12th century. It dominates the city and gives a view overlooking the Crau plain.
Its remains reflect a siege in 1592 of the castle to dislodge the troops of Captain Rondellet. The gate of the castle was restored a few years ago. It remains 2 sections of wall.

label: Le Parc des Tours
description:
Located in the heart of the village, on the Griffon hill, the garden of the towers surrounding the medieval castle of the 13th and 15th centuries is a real invitation to stroll. It offers a view of the Mont Ventoux, the Alpilles and the plains of the Durance and the Rhône. There are games for children and a restaurant "la Guinguette des Tours" open from April to October.
A real green lung of the city, it has been labelled Refuge LPO (League for the Protection of Birds) since September 2013. The management of the green spaces put into practice favours the biodiversity of this 18-hectare site. In 2016, the Parc des Tours is the only LPO refuge managed by a local authority in the Bouches du Rhône out of the 354 local authorities in the department.
The diversity of the environments present provides refuge, feeding and nesting areas for many species of birds. LPO inventories have identified 27 species on the entire site. Some are non-nesting but fly over the area or exploit its food resources, such as the fitis warbler, which is a threatened species
In addition to birds, many insects (butterflies, dragonflies, grasshoppers, locusts, crickets, cicadas, hymenoptera, etc.) are also found.), amphibians (the pedagogical pond shelters the alyte accoucheur which is a toad which has the particularity of carrying on its back the eggs laid by its female, this species is protected by the Bern Convention of 1979 relating to the conservation of the wild life and the natural environment of Europe) as well as many reptiles (Taranto de Maurétanie and Wall Lizard) and small mammals (among which the squirrel).

label: Passage du Canal de Craponne par Alleins
description: Created by the engineer Adam de Craponne between 1554 and 1559, it allowed, by diverting the waters of the Durance, to irrigate the dry land of Provence. In Alleins many lands are cultivated and in the village beautiful houses with Renaissance facades testify to the enrichment of the inhabitants. The Canal fed the Moulin Loin (16th century), the Moulin Saint-Paul (18th century) as well as the village fountains. Disused in the years 1950-1960, its banks have been converted into a walking circuit (pedestrian access at the bridge, opposite the Saint-Paul mill).

label: Kiosque à musique Vincent Scotto
description: The first bandstand was inaugurated on August 19, 1900. It was in 1895 that the Municipal Council gave a favourable opinion to the project of installing a new bandstand on the same site as the old one. It is the municipality which will be in charge of the construction of this bandstand. Inauguration on September 12, 1993.

label: Le Jacquemard
description:
The Jacquemard tower was built on one of the gates of the city walls.
In 1646, a jacquemart clock (an automaton clock system) with four steel automatons was installed on the tower's terrace.
The automatons represent a blacksmith, his wife and their two children, a boy and a girl
The children ring the quarter hours on two small bells: the blacksmith and his wife, the hours and half hours on a very large bell
The inhabitants gave the automatons the name of the monument, jacquemard, which thus became a proper name. Then the Jacquemard family was born. The wife was named Margarido, the little girl Jacqueto and the boy JACQUET.
Since a restoration in 1882, the figures are made of wood and locked in a campanile.

label: Chapelle Saint Roch
comment: This chapel was built outside the walls in 1729 on the initiative of the consul Honorat JOURDAN in homage to Saint Roch, who would have protected Fuveau from the plague of 1720.
shortDescription: This chapel was built outside the walls in 1729 on the initiative of the consul Honorat JOURDAN in homage to Saint Roch, who would have protected Fuveau from the plague of 1720.
description:
The votive feast of Saint Roch is still celebrated every August 16 in the form of a service accompanied by songs in Provencal
It is also open for guided tours, as well as for the Heritage Days in September.

label: Calanque et anse de Figuerolles
comment: Due to its exceptional relief, Anse de Figuerolles offers you a unique panorama.
shortDescription: Due to its exceptional relief, Anse de Figuerolles offers you a unique panorama.
description: Because of its exceptional relief, the Anse de Figuerolles offers a unique panorama. The calanque offers a beautiful beach and water of very good quality. When you take the Route des Crêtes from Cassis, you head southwest and the area of the creeks. From the center of La Ciotat, walk along the quays of the old port and, after passing the Avenue des Calanques then the Avenue de Figuerolles, you reach the creek by a charming little staircase. Only connoisseurs frequent this place full of charm.

label: Les 16 fontaines de Saint-Zacharie
comment: Saint-Zacharie has no less than 16 fountains, most of them built between 1838 and 1848.
shortDescription: Saint-Zacharie has no less than 16 fountains, most of them built between 1838 and 1848.
description:
Fountain of the Marianne, Fountain of the Lion d'Or, Fountain of the Place Dréo, Fountain Saint-Roch, Fountain of the Cours Mirabeau, Fountain of the Place de l'Église, Fountain of the Place de Maintenance, Fountain of the Place de la Céramique.
The other smaller ones are in the Pavillon district, Bd de la Libération, Av Mistral, la Petite Foux, Av Juramy, montée des Potiers, Bd de la Révolution and Bd Palissy.

label: Eglise Saint Paul
comment: St. Paul's Church, Romanesque style.
shortDescription: St. Paul's Church, Romanesque style.
description: This Romanesque style church, rebuilt in 1704, contains splendid altarpieces and paintings of rare quality, including a faithful copy of the great altarpiece donated by Monsignor de Grimaldi, the Archbishop of Aix en Provence and Lord of Jouques to the church of this neighbouring village. It is all the more precious as the original has unfortunately been destroyed since then.

label: Mosquée Mariam centre musulman de Marseille
comment: In addition to religious services, the Muslim Centre offers leisure and educational meetings and workshops.
shortDescription: In addition to religious services, the Muslim Centre offers leisure and educational meetings and workshops.

label: Parc de Font Obscure
comment: Its topography offers a panoramic view of the harbour of Marseille, (Frioul Islands to the west), the Massif de l'Etoile and the Vallon Dol reservoir, to the north and the basilica of Notre-Dame de la Garde and the massif of Marseilleveyre, to the south.
shortDescription: Its topography offers a panoramic view of the harbour of Marseille, (Frioul Islands to the west), the Massif de l'Etoile and the Vallon Dol reservoir, to the north and the basilica of Notre-Dame de la Garde and the massif of Marseilleveyre, to the south.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


This 11.3 hectare park, developed in successive phases since the 1970s, is located in the Bon Secours district, near the Merlan life centre. Its topography offers a panoramic view of the harbour of Marseille (Frioul Islands to the west), the Massif de l'Etoile and the Vallon Dol reservoir to the north, and the Basilica of Notre-Dame de la Garde and the Marseilleveyre massif to the south.


In 1969, the land was acquired with the project to build social housing. But the demands of the local residents for the protection of this site led to the creation of a large urban park, with vast areas of lawn, groves of typically Mediterranean vegetation, a fitness trail, playgrounds, etc. Recent works have enabled the requalification of the retention basin, intended for the storage of rainwater.

label: Moulin Jean Bertrand
description:
Built at the end of the 18th century on the Pelisanese branch of the Craponne Canal, the Jean Bertrand mill is the furthest upstream of the seven mills installed on the Craponne Canal.
Its first owner, Jean Bertrand bought a water concession from the Marquis de Gallifet in 1775 and obtained permission to build a mill on the canal.
The mill, which will operate until 1960, is composed of two parts: an oil mill (1786) and a flour mill (1789).
Registered in the inventory of historical monuments in 1992, part of the mill was put back into operation in order to exploit and enhance the quality olive oil produced on an exceptional terroir.

label: Fontaine Pascal
comment: A fountain was built on this site in 1713 but the spring which fed it did not provide enough water. During times of drought the district suffered from this lack of water, and epidemics spread among the people.
shortDescription: A fountain was built on this site in 1713 but the spring which fed it did not provide enough water. During times of drought the district suffered from this lack of water, and epidemics spread among the people.
description:
In 1833, as these repeated shortages had to be stopped, the well was dug deeper and the result was successful. To celebrate this new supply of water a fountain was built, with water flowing from four pipes, after the old fountain, a reminder of hardship and disease, had been demolished.

The situation remained unchanged until 1922 when Sylvain Pascal, a rich merchant from Rue des Cordeliers, decided to honour the residents of his district with a prestigious fountain symbolising the beauty and charm of Provence.

The monument was designed by the architect Lieutaud and executed by the sculptor Baille. On an urn at the top are four young Provençal women dancing the farandole, accompanied by a tambourin drummer on the pedestal.

On each side of the block in the centre is a young Bacchus, with pipes sending the water into two huge shells.

label: Maison natale de Marcel Pagnol
comment: It was in this 19th century bourgeois house that Marcel Pagnol was born on February 28, 1895.
shortDescription: It was in this 19th century bourgeois house that Marcel Pagnol was born on February 28, 1895.
description:
The Native Home of Marcel Pagnol
In this 19th century comfortable house, located on the Barthélemy walk, Marcel Pagnol was born on the 28th of February 1895.
You can visit its ground-floor (130 square-meters) with its two spaces: the reconstitution of the Pagnol family's flat (furniture and objects of the end of the 19th century), an exhibition space (with photographs, objects and letters) as well as a projection room (20 seats).

label: Fort Saint-Jean
comment: In the 13th century, the Hospitallers of Saint John of Jerusalem set up a fortress and a commandery at the entrance to the port.
shortDescription: In the 13th century, the Hospitallers of Saint John of Jerusalem set up a fortress and a commandery at the entrance to the port.
description:
The Tour Carrée was built by King René, Count of Provence, in the 15th century. The Fanal tower, built in 1644, signaled the entrance to the port. Louis XIV, in the 17th century, separated the fort from its neighborhood by digging a large trench, and thus kept the Marseillais in check by building the entrance to the port on the other side, Fort St. Nicolas. 
The fort is an integral part of the MuCEM: its access will be reopened at the time of the museum's inauguration.
"The vaulted rooms housed in the stone bowels of Fort St. Jean, a 12th century historical monument, will offer exhibition galleries on the themes of celebration and entertainment. A unique opportunity to approach in a playful way facts revealing the evolution of societies, especially in the Mediterranean. In this public space, visitors will also be able to stroll through a Mediterranean garden suspended on the heights of the fort and marvel at the magnificent panorama offered over the sea." website www.mucem.org

label: Le château de Confoux
comment: The Château de Confoux is an old castle probably built in the 13th century.
shortDescription: The Château de Confoux is an old castle probably built in the 13th century.
description:
The inhabitants settled around it.
It is a vast construction that included a Romanesque style church.

The origin of the word "Confoux" comes from the fact that two plains, one to the north and the other to the south of the village of Lançon, come together here.

label: Hôtel Hubaud
description: Former private mansion of the 18th. century, listed in the inventory of Historic Monuments.

label: Place des Etats Généraux
description: Main square of the village, recently built on the site of the former Barbier-Dauphin food canning factory which was bought by the municipality in 1965. All that remains of the factory is the "estive" where the canned food boxes were stored and which has been transformed into the Association Hall. The name of the square recalls the "Etats Généraux de Provence", the oldest meeting of which was held in 1286 under Charles II, Count of Provence. These States General are suppressed in 1639 by Richelieu and replaced by "The General Assemblies of the Communities of the Country of Provence" which sat in Lambesc from 1646 to 1786, that is to say 140 years.

label: Oratoire Saint-Pierre (oratoire Sainte-Catherine)
description: This shrine is on Route de la Bégude, opposite the path leading to the cemetery and where the chapel of St Catherine stood.

label: Hôtel de Ville
comment: The building of 12,000 m2 stands proudly on the banks of the Chenal de Caronte.
shortDescription: The building of 12,000 m2 stands proudly on the banks of the Chenal de Caronte.
description:
The Martigues town hall - both a public service building and architectural curiosity - was created by Claude Delaugerre in 1983.

It is built on stilts where salt marshes once lay. 

In the entrance hall: mosaic by Bazaine  on the doors: sculptures by Cardenas  in the city council meeting room: tapestries by Ubac  in the wedding ceremony room: tapestry by Vinard and works by the Aubusson workshop. The ceramic blue façades represent fish scales.

label: Musée de plein air Paul Cézanne
description: The Paul Cézanne open-air museum is located on the hill of the brothers facing the Cézannian motif that is the old village of Gardanne. A walk arranged for this purpose retraces the life of the painter in Gardanne from 1885 to 1886 as well as his works.

label: Castrum du Mont Paon
comment: Troglodyte habitat, occupied mainly between the 11th or 12th century and the 14th century. The remains are located on top of a hill of the same name, at an altitude of 230 metres.
shortDescription: Troglodyte habitat, occupied mainly between the 11th or 12th century and the 14th century. The remains are located on top of a hill of the same name, at an altitude of 230 metres.
description:
It is thought that the site was besieged in the 11th century, a controversial hypothesis based only on the testimony of papal bull.
All that remain today are a few strata of ramparts, the foundations of a seigniorial dwelling and the chevet of Saint Marie castle chapel on a huge terraced plateau. Its destruction seems due more to abandonment than to pillage, judging by the piles of stones strewn over the rocky promontory. Located opposite Les Baux fortress, a seigniorial fortress on which the Castrum de Mont Paon depended, the Castrum was an ideal point for keeping watch over the Les Baux marshlands, a highly desired fishing zone and the border with the nearby Kingdom of France.

label: Ancienne école de filles
comment: The former girls' school marks a true republican pole on the Cours Mirabeau, set up opposite the main entrance of the former seigniorial mansion, partially acquired as the town hall in 1892.
shortDescription: The former girls' school marks a true republican pole on the Cours Mirabeau, set up opposite the main entrance of the former seigniorial mansion, partially acquired as the town hall in 1892.
description:
The former girls' school marks a true republican pole on the Cours Mirabeau, set up opposite the main entrance of the former seigniorial mansion, partially acquired as the town hall in 1892

Its construction was begun the following year, on a plot of land in the former castle park that was supposed to have been the site of a legendary "Little Versailles" (more likely a simple "gardener's house" mentioned in 1693)

But here everything leads back to the aspirations, including architectural ones, of the Third Republic and its emblematic law of Jules Ferry on free education, which was the driving force behind the municipalities' educational efforts in this area. The girls' school in Marignane is thus to be credited to the municipality of Casimir Amavet (1893-1895)
A first school for boys had been built in 1877, followed by this one for girls. They were already being educated in a house on the outskirts of the town, and previously in the religious establishment known as l'Œuvre, located in the present rue du pilote Larbonne

The construction of this new building was awarded in 1893 to the public works contractor Louis Salomon Delhorme (1829-1896), of whom very little is known to this day. Originally from Aubenas in the Ardèche, he first lived and worked in the Var at Les Arcs, but only moved to Marseille in 1892

The almost cubic front building that he built as a "school house" is characterized by a bourgeois and republican sobriety. It probably housed the teacher's or headmistress' apartment, as well as the first classrooms on the first floor. The façade is composed of two levels and three bays. The windows with panels and louvers have a slightly lowered arch. Four pilasters with Doric capitals, the most austere of the classical orders, connected by a molded cordon, surround the building, which is well ordered under a cornice that serves as a solid foundation for a four-sided roof. Only a few dentils, barely visible, enliven the whole in height. At the rear, a long building housing a series of classrooms, probably built around 1900, since an estimate for the exterior painting of May 1901 corresponds exactly to its surface. It overlooked a courtyard, today accessible to the public, where any curious person will notice the touching testimony of a small bell ringing the hours of recreation, left in its original state

This school complex functioned as such until 1980, before the devolution of the front building to a civil status service and then to the Tourist Office which occupies it today. The perpendicular building houses the music conservatory. The whole has been enhanced by the clearing of the Cours Mirabeau esplanade, on the city side, and the development of the Salvador Dali garden and its bandstand behind.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Musée des Enfants - Préau des Accoules
comment: The préau  des Accoules is  a  place  for raising  awarness of the arts  and heritage.It  occupied  part of the  former observatory  of  Marseille.
shortDescription: The préau  des Accoules is  a  place  for raising  awarness of the arts  and heritage.It  occupied  part of the  former observatory  of  Marseille.
description:
This building has a rich history, built in 1702 by the jesuits on top  of the Montée des Accoules offer a  fun exhibition to young  public for  an  original approach to art objects. it invents with respect  of  work, mise en scenes , tools and educational  routes often renewed.
Animations  and  workshops (  on registration) for  groups and individuals.

The  exhibitions are completed by  different  kind  of events, concerts, shows and meetings.

The  programme mainly focuses on discovering the rich  heritage  of Marseille  museums and  covers a  wide range of themes : archaeology, Fine arts, American  and  African  cultures,  regional heritage,history, photography, contemporary  art.

label: Chapelle Sainte-Catherine
comment: The chapel of "Saint-Catherine" is adjacent to the church of Saint-Laurent. It was built in 1604, for the White Penitents "les Pénitents Blancs". Its late gothic vaulting with liernes and tiercerons is unique in Marseille.
shortDescription: The chapel of "Saint-Catherine" is adjacent to the church of Saint-Laurent. It was built in 1604, for the White Penitents "les Pénitents Blancs". Its late gothic vaulting with liernes and tiercerons is unique in Marseille.
description:
The chapel contains many works of art, some of which are from "Saint-Laurent". 
It is only open during concerts and cultural conferences that it hosts.

label: Musée de la Camargue
comment: Between Arles and Saintes Maries de la Mer, in the middle of the Camargue, the museum is a real gateway to the discovery of this vast territory.
shortDescription: Between Arles and Saintes Maries de la Mer, in the middle of the Camargue, the museum is a real gateway to the discovery of this vast territory.
description:
The island of Camargue, between the Rhône and the Mediterranean, has an exceptional environment, the result of the meeting of fresh and salt water and the human activities that have developed there. The Parc de Camargue aims to protect and bring to life this natural, cultural and human heritage in order to build the future of this territory.

A museum
It is at the Mas du Pont de Rousty that the Natural Park has installed the Camargue Museum, a showcase for the territory. Renovated in 2013, with a view to sustainable development, the sheepfold, under its original framework, offers an immersion in the Camargue of yesterday and today with the permanent exhibition "The thread of water, the thread of time".
Historical pieces, interactive, playful and sound installations, videos and contemporary works of art invite young and old to surf between past, present and future, far from the clichés conveyed.

An extension                  
In 2019, the Musée de la Camargue has been extended to provide a larger reception area, a temporary exhibition room and new services for its visitors.

A trail
The experience can be extended thanks to the path that runs along the canal and rice fields to the marshes, passing by the gardian's hut. (3.5 km. Free access 7 days a week)

A cultural programme 
All year round, shows, screenings, meetings, debates and thematic visits to the museum or the Park territory offer a fun and different approach to Camargue culture.

Artistic trails
At the start of the trail, a work by Tadashi Kawamata, Horizons, invites you to reflect on the issues surrounding water in the Rhône delta. 
On the Park's territory, the Water Paths route invites you to leave the beaten track to see the Camargue in a different way with Tadashi Kawamata's installations, Décise, on the banks of the Grand Rhône in Arles and Escale at the Grande Montlong pumping station.

label: Cadran solaire
comment: Historical sundial in Eyguières
shortDescription: Historical sundial in Eyguières
description: The sundial is located on the façade of the Tourist Office, which used to be the Town Hall. Its East-South-East orientation means that the time can only be read until noon, with the maxim engraved in stone: "Sol Umbras prudentia civis" - the sun casts its shadow, the wisdom its citizens.

label: Place Alexandrine Bremond
description:
In memory of its poetess, the town of Tarascon erected a statue in her honour and named one of its squares after her.
Elisabeth 'Alexandrine' Brémond (29 October 1858, Tarascon - 22 June 1898), better known by the name of Brémonde de Tarascon, was a Félibran poetess. The recurrent themes of her lyrical poetry include the contemplation of Nature, the link she maintained with the History of her region and the expression of her feelings as a woman; her verses express her enthusiasms as a young girl and her happiness and disappointments as a woman: love, hope and despair as well as amazement at the idea of Beauty.

label: Porte d'Auguste
comment:
Sometimes called Porte de la Redoute
Date: End of the first century BC
Era: Antiquity
Type: Fortified military architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1886 and a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1981
shortDescription:
Sometimes called Porte de la Redoute
Date: End of the first century BC
Era: Antiquity
Type: Fortified military architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1886 and a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1981
description:
The Porte d'Auguste, also called the Porte de la Redoute after the fortressed built there in the Middle Ages, was the main entrance to the Roman town.
Located at the highest point in the town, to the east, it was on a diversion of the Via Aurelia from Rome.
It is the best preserved part of the Augustan ramparts, built just after the founding of the Roman colony.
The gate's current high position does not correspond to its original height, but to the digging of the Boulevard Emile-Combes at the end of the 18th century.
The aqueduct which brought water from the Alpilles arrived close to the gate's northern tower.
On the split caused by the digging of the boulevard, it is still possible to see limestone deposits on the wall.
The building underwent major redevelopment work in late Antiquity and the Middle Ages.
The door, framed by two solid rectangular pillar, covers a vast half-moon shaped area of approximately 100 metres in the eastern part of the rampart. 
At each end, a semi-circular tour provided a connection with the curtain wall (part of the enclosure between two fortifications.
The gate itself was 35 metres wide. Unlike the enclosure, it was built of large blocks of stone with butt joints. 
The two semi-circular towers which surround it, also made of large blocks, have a relatively simple moulding at the base, which can also be found at the top, although in very damaged condition.
The space between the two towers made it possible to create two 15-metre wide passageways; these were probably not big enough for pedestrians to pass through, as was the case with the larger Porte d'Auguste in Nîmes.
The gate was bricked up in the Middle Ages and only a small postern can be seen today.

label: Arènes
comment: Arena of Châteaurenard
shortDescription: Arena of Châteaurenard
description:
Place of bullfighting shows (Camargue races, bullfights...) and shows (concert, one man show...)
Contactable by phone only during the events.
Essential element of the summer festivals but also stage place with strong capacity these arenas are a major asset for the city being able to welcome 4500 spectators.

label: Sur les pas d'Antonin, père de Jean Moulin
comment: Walking tour to discover the heritage of Saint Andiol, in memory of Jean Moulin and his family.
shortDescription: Walking tour to discover the heritage of Saint Andiol, in memory of Jean Moulin and his family.
description: The walking route for the discovery of the communal memorial heritage has been designed around the Jean Moulin Museum of Saint-Andiol "Souvenir de mon pays", so that everyone can visit the places, monuments and important buildings in the history of Saint-Andiol where Jean Moulin and his family lived.
streetAddress: ['Place du Maréchal de Lattre de Tassigny']

label: Jardin aquatique "Aux fleurs de l'Eau"
comment: In Graveson, there is a magical place born from the imagination of a man passionate about water and plants. In his spare time, Mr. Stroppiana imagined and built his garden with ponds, waterfalls, plants and fish.
shortDescription: In Graveson, there is a magical place born from the imagination of a man passionate about water and plants. In his spare time, Mr. Stroppiana imagined and built his garden with ponds, waterfalls, plants and fish.
description: It's a sweet walk in the water garden "Aux fleurs de l'eau" that awaits you. A succession of pools and waterfalls where Koi carp flourish: challenge your children to count them, this should ensure a little moment of peace!

label: Le Bayle-Vert (Centre Mas-Felipe Delavouët)
comment: Le Bayle-Vert (Baile-Vert) is an 18th century Provencal farmhouse, listed as a National Monument, situated on the banks of the Crau river, in the middle of farmland.
shortDescription: Le Bayle-Vert (Baile-Vert) is an 18th century Provencal farmhouse, listed as a National Monument, situated on the banks of the Crau river, in the middle of farmland.
description:
Since 2003, the Centre Mas-Felipe Delavouët has been preserving the memory of Max-Philippe Delavouët (writer-poet born in Marseille, 1920-1990), his works and his house "le Bayle-Vert". It is a place of documentation intended to receive researchers and artists.

Visits by appointment or during event openings (lectures, readings, temporary exhibitions, heritage days, etc.)

label: Collégiale Saint Martin
description:
This Church was already in existence in 1122 and was extended and embellished in 1331 when the Pope of Avignon, Jean XXII, decided to transform this priory into a collegiate church.
Saint Martin Collegiate Church replaced an older church, part of which collapsed in 1818 following building work. It was rebuilt in 1821 and the 16th century bell tower was conserved. The Great Organ of this Classical-style church is a masterpiece. Rebuilt in 1983 by Pascal Quorin, it comprises of 62 stops (5,000 pipes), 3 keyboards and pedals. It also has a splendid polychrome chest. Organ recitals are held on Saturdays at 5.30 p.m., from June to September.
The existence of the parish church in the town is attested from 1122. The Romanesque building was extended with a huge Gothic chancel during the construction of the collegiate church by Pope John XXII in 1331.
Organa Festival every Saturday at 5.30 p.m., from 01/07 to 30/09.

label: Parc Jean-Baptiste d'Albertas
comment: Park in the city centre with playground and recreation area for all.
shortDescription: Park in the city centre with playground and recreation area for all.
description:
This garden in the heart of the city is a place of relaxation and leisure with a magnificent lake * (not for swimming)
A playground is available for children.
Numerous events are organized there during the summer.

label: Maison classique
comment: 19th century house
shortDescription: 19th century house
description: Classical house from the 19th century, on the Avenue Général de Gaulle with a facade bearing two large niches each housing a statue representing one Adam and the other Eve. It seems to have been a former theater.

label: Chapelle Saint Roch
comment: Discover the Saint Roch Chapel in Eyguières
shortDescription: Discover the Saint Roch Chapel in Eyguières
description: Chapel built in 1725 in honour of the protector Saint Roch during terrible plague epidemics. The inside of the chapel is decorated with murals.

label: Plage des Combattants
comment: The combattants beach is a small beach made of pebbles and gravel which overlooks the Gulf of Fos.
shortDescription: The combattants beach is a small beach made of pebbles and gravel which overlooks the Gulf of Fos.
description:
Supervised beach in summer from 1 p.m. to 6:45 p.m.
Two items of equipment that improve the comfort of people with reduced mobility are available and delivered to the beaches on request from the supervisors: the "Hippocampe" wheelchair facilitating movement on the sand and entering the water and the "Tiralo", wheelchair amphibious, allowing accompanied swimming.

Restaurant on site
The beach is bordered by the road serving the entire coast.

label: Musée du Pavillon de Vendôme
comment: Beautiful atlantes on the façade announce this classical style "folly" which was built in 1665 by Pierre Pavillon and Antoine Matisse for the Duke of Vendome, governor of Provence and cousin of Louis XIV.
shortDescription: Beautiful atlantes on the façade announce this classical style "folly" which was built in 1665 by Pierre Pavillon and Antoine Matisse for the Duke of Vendome, governor of Provence and cousin of Louis XIV.
description:
The Pavillon Vendôme is the most attractive folie bequeathed to us by the 17th century. It was built at the request of Louis de Mercoeur, Duke of Vendôme. The grandson of Henry IV and Gabrielle d'Estrées, he was appointed Governer of Provence in 1652.

Legend has it that the prince fell in love with Lucrèce de Forbin Solliès, known as the "Belle du Canet", and had this "folie" built for her.
A series of owners succeeded him. In 1906, Henri Dobler, an enlightened art-lover, bought and restored the Pavillon and obtained official recognition for it. In 1914, the Pavillon de Vendôme became the first building in Aix to be listed as a Historic Monument. Dobler bequeathed the building and collections to the City of Aix, and the site was opened to the public as a museum on 8 July 1954.

The double helix staircase in the Pavillon de Vendôme is one of the finest of the Aix series and dates from the early 18th century. It combines a harmonious structure with grandiose decoration. The cast-iron handrail and the plasterwork, garlands, putti and eagle sculptures combine to produce a majestic Baroque effect.

The immense French-style garden has been listed among the Historic Monuments since 1953.
The Pavillon de Vendôme Museum collection is made up of works from the 17th until the early 21st century, including an important group of graphic art works. It regularly hosts contemporary art exhibitions, helping to develop a dialogue between cultural heritage and contemporary creation.
The museum is listed as a historic monument.
streetAddress: ['13, rue de la Molle ou', '32 Rue Célony']

label: Arènes municipales Christian Massard
comment: Municipal bullring located in the park of the castle.
shortDescription: Municipal bullring located in the park of the castle.
description: Capacity: 1,200 places. Shows: Cocarde racing (race to snatch a rosette from the bull's horns).

label: Moulins
comment: Eyragues counted nine mills on its territory, they have now disappeared
shortDescription: Eyragues counted nine mills on its territory, they have now disappeared
description: Moulin de la Porte or Moulin de Conil (Rue du Moulin): water mill which existed in 1326 and was restored in 1881, - Moulin de Fabre (Chemin des Près): water mill first mentioned in 1493; it was operational until 1940 and is now private property. - Michel Oil Mill (Rue du Moulin): remains of this Oil Mill can be seen in what is now the Maison Michel. - Moulin de la Poule: circa 1850 (the weather vane represents a moorhen), north west. - Moulin des Labeaux: built by the Bionneau family circa 1810, south. - Moulin du Val: first mentioned in 1559, south west. - Oil mill known as Moulin Lagnel: 1929, on the site of the former Hospice. - Wheat mill, on the outskirts, south east.

label: L'Etang des Aulnes
comment: The estate’s old Provençal-style building with its various annexes, is a residence for artists and an place for outdoor concerts.
shortDescription: The estate’s old Provençal-style building with its various annexes, is a residence for artists and an place for outdoor concerts.
description:
Since 1988, Aulnes Lagoon estate is the property of the General Council of Bouches-du-Rhone, which is responsible for the restoration, management and protection of this unique place. 
 The foundations of this 300 hectare area, located in the heart of the Crau, date from 1213.
Its setting is quite remarkable: a large driveway lined with oleanders and pine trees leads to a park with lawns leading down to a lake. The opposite bank, still wild, remains a refuge for migratory birds.
A place of artistic residence from winter to summer, the area is transformed to accommodate different summer concerts including:
- The Roi des Aulnes festival
- The Aulnes Rouges pop, rock and other festival - The international Piano Festival of La Roque d'Anthéron A brief history: 
The history of the area began in the 13th century with the sale of the Dole Elmes lagoon and land from the Temple house. Over the centuries, sales were concluded on the condition to build a farmhouse. In 1749, the owner Mr Bichairon bought the two farmhouses, the lagoon and the land: the estate was thus built.
The battle that preserved the estate:
Thirty years ago, long before the Department acquired it, a development project at the Aulnes lagoon planned to build 2,000 homes, shops, a school and a police station.
During the deliberations of the council of April 12, 1972, the project was voted 11 in favour and 9 against. After unsuccessfully seeking the annulment of the vote at the regional prefect, four councillors decided to follow Claude Vulpian, who was the first deputy, and made an application to the Administrative Tribunal of Marseilles on the grounds of ultra vires.
After several steps, they won the case on January 30, 1974. The decision of April 12, 1972 was void of form. The estate was saved from construction and classified as a protected area.

label: Auriol
description:
Auriol has a heritage presenting various periods of history :
Ruins of the medieval castle (dating from the 1001 year)
The Sainte Barbe place and its fountain
The ‘Sainte-Croix chapel' and its panoramic view on the village (cover of this file)
The ‘Clock Tower' (1564)
The ‘Barres Treasury': more than 2000 coins of pure silver dating from the 6th century before J.C.
More than 20 oratories in the village area
The hamlet of Moulin de Redon: a typical of the smallest Provencal villages.

label: Museon Arlaten - musée de Provence
comment: The Museon Arlaten, a departmental museum of ethnography created at the end of the 19th century by the poet Frédéric Mistral, is a "place of memory" of Provencal society.
shortDescription: The Museon Arlaten, a departmental museum of ethnography created at the end of the 19th century by the poet Frédéric Mistral, is a "place of memory" of Provencal society.
description:
After 11 years of closure, the museum has been thoroughly renovated and is now open to the public again. Respectful of the Mistralian heritage and of more than a century of museographic history, the Museon Arlaten-musée de Provence offers a brand new experience of visit among 3500 objects, costumes and paintings. Thanks to a variety of scenographies and a number of multimedia devices, it offers an almost infinite choice of possibilities for further exploration and discovery. 

From the 18th century to multimedia

Founded in 1899 by Frédéric Mistral, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature and champion of the Provençal language and culture, the Museon Arlaten, a "poet's museum" and "museum of living life", has been closed to the public since 2009.
While the dioramas, 18th, 19th and 20th century costumes, the Tarasque, festive objects, furniture and earthenware, shepherds, amulets, the works and the spirit of Mistral are still present, the scenographies have been revisited to be sometimes faithful to the original, sometimes endowed with a new historical depth. The public will also be able to discover the results of ethnographic surveys on today's Provence carried out by the museum's teams.
Nearly sixty digital devices (videos, texts, readings in Provençal, sounds, games, music, multimedia creations and frescoes, etc.) bring to life the Provence of yesteryear and evoke the Provence of today with relish.

A unique and inspired place

To cross the threshold of the Museon Arlaten is to enter a place shaped by two thousand years of history! The end of the Forum in Roman times (a set of Roman remains, an exedra, columns, a street, pavements and pavements are still visible in the museum courtyard), an aristocratic residence during the Renaissance, a Jesuit college from the 17th to 18th centuries, prison and place of debate during the French Revolution, again a college and then a museum, today renovated, the Museon Arlaten is a major witness to the architecture and history of Arles from Antiquity to the 21st century.

Thanks to the renovation, two new architectural features have been added to enhance the visit:

- the grand staircase, designed by the architect of the renovation, Michel Bertreux (Tetrarc agency), is enhanced by two creations by Christian Lacroix. Distributing all the floors, its decoration was conceived by the great Arles designer as "a gesture of gratitude and love" for the collections of the Museon Arlaten, here assembled and freely recomposed in two large backlit glass totems.

- The Jesuit Chapel, completely restored, is finally attached to the museum and will provide a sumptuous setting and volume for temporary exhibitions.

For its location, for its collections, for the journey back in time offered as well as for its contemporary outlook, the Museon Arlaten-Musée de Provence is an essential step in any journey of discovery of the riches of the city of Arles.
*** Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator (free version) ***

label: Parc Ferrage
comment: Very nice urban park
shortDescription: Very nice urban park
description:
With a surface area of 3.5 hectares, the lawns and flowerbeds of Ferrage Park welcome garden lovers. Tree lovers will notice the great diversity of the park's species: 48 present on the site

The youngest will find outdoor games and the elders a large bowling green. Dogs, two-wheelers and balls are not allowed

125 parking spaces are available in three parking lots.

Free access.

label: Centre de documentation historique : Algérie - Maroc - Tunisie
comment: The CDHA was created in 1974 in response to the wishes of various people, most of them "Algerian repatriates", who wanted to ensure the preservation of documents in their possession evoking the history of Algeria until 1962
shortDescription: The CDHA was created in 1974 in response to the wishes of various people, most of them "Algerian repatriates", who wanted to ensure the preservation of documents in their possession evoking the history of Algeria until 1962
description:
The historical archive centre for Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia is a public welfare organisation. It collects, stores and provides any documents, archives and testimonials about the French period in the history of Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia.

It hosts conferences and exhibitions on these themes.

The centre also welcomes student researchers and anyone with an interest.
streetAddress: ['29 Avenue De Tübingen', "36ter Avenue De l'Europe"]

label: Médiathèque municipale de Meyreuil
comment: Media library of the town of Meyreuil.
shortDescription: Media library of the town of Meyreuil.
description: The media library provides a wide range of books, DVDs, CDs, scores, books in large font and activities all year round: readings, stories, shows, concerts, exhibitions, screenings, kids' workshops, author events, digital workshops, books to borrow and free Wi-Fi.

label: Quartier des Savonniers
comment: The commercial boom of the 1880s led to the emergence of a new bourgeoisie whose wealth marked the architectural physiognomy of the city.
shortDescription: The commercial boom of the 1880s led to the emergence of a new bourgeoisie whose wealth marked the architectural physiognomy of the city.
description: The merchants built ostentatious mansions adjacent to the warehouse and offices. Of all the villas built in the 19th century, the most original is the Château Armieux, now the courthouse. This medieval castle was built in 1905 by a wealthy soap merchant as a tribute to his wife.

label: Etang de Berre
comment:
This lagoon covers 15,500 hectares, and its 75 km shoreline is quite charming.
Surrounded by low limestone hills, it receives fresh water from the Rivers Arc and Touloubre and the canal from the EDF hydroelectric power station. It is connected to the sea by the Caronte canal and Le Rove canal.
shortDescription:
This lagoon covers 15,500 hectares, and its 75 km shoreline is quite charming.
Surrounded by low limestone hills, it receives fresh water from the Rivers Arc and Touloubre and the canal from the EDF hydroelectric power station. It is connected to the sea by the Caronte canal and Le Rove canal.
description:
The area has always been a place of human settlement, as shown by the archaeological digs of Saint-Blaise, Flavians Bridge, the mediaeval town of Miramas-le-Vieux and the 17th century town walls of Port-de-Bouc. From the end of the 19th century, the traditional economy based on wine, olives, peaches and salt mining was overturned by industrialization. 
There is a clear distinction between the northern and southern parts of the area: the south and south-east have sacrificed a lot to industrialization, while the north and north-west have retained a more traditional character, with pinewoods and crops.

label: Anse de l'Arène
description:
A cove of sand (in the water), pebbles and rocks of 400m by 15m. Bordered by a pine forest. Access to the sea a little difficult, by rocks. Nearby La Madie parking area equipped for 160 vehicles (avenue du Révestel). Natural cove not supervised. Restricted access in summer. It is forbidden to smoke and make fire on the beach in periods of major fire risk.
Animals not allowed.
Direction Casino de jeux and the Arena.

label: Eglise des Stes Maries de la mer
comment: The Church of Our Lady of the Sea is the soul of the village.
shortDescription: The Church of Our Lady of the Sea is the soul of the village.
description: This fortress church, built in the 9th and 11th centuries on an old Gallo-Roman sanctuary, replaced an oratory that, according to legend, was erected by the Saints. This site was fortified in order to withstand attacks by the Saracens. Human figures can be seem emerging from the capitals decorated with plant motifs. The crypt (1448) houses Sarah, patron saint of Gypsies, covered with robes and coats. The boat of the Saints Marys is in the left alley of the church. The 4th BC century pagan altar in the crypt is also remarkable.

label: Eglise Saint-Sauveur
comment: The church of Saint-Sauveur was first mentioned in 923, at the same time as the castrum.
shortDescription: The church of Saint-Sauveur was first mentioned in 923, at the same time as the castrum.
description: Erected on the highest point (32m), it is in charge of protecting the gate of the nearby castle, but also the village and its necropolis which stretches out at its feet. Built entirely of local shell limestone, Saint-Sauveur is a two-nave church with two flat-bottomed archaic chevets on the east side, with partly rocky foundations, dating from the High Middle Ages (9th century?). The northern nave, dated at least to the First Romanesque (11th century) is supported inside by eight round arches resting on pilasters. The south nave, of great sobriety of lines, and built in fine craftsmanship, is barrel vaulted. It is a remarkable example of the second classical Provençal Romanesque art (late 12th century), illustrated in Fos by other medieval monuments: the towers and the North Gate of the Hauture and the Notre-Dame-de-la-Mer chapel.

label: Parc de l'Oasis
comment: Park of 2.3 hectares. Playgrounds, bowls, physical activities, pond, parking.
shortDescription: Park of 2.3 hectares. Playgrounds, bowls, physical activities, pond, parking.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.


Park of 2.3 hectares. Playgrounds, boules, physical activities, water, parking.

comment: Park of 2 hectares, playgrounds. School of horticulture.
shortDescription: Park of 2 hectares, playgrounds. School of horticulture.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


Park of 2 hectares, playgrounds. School of horticulture.

label: Lavoir
description: Built in the reign of Napoleon III, this construction has two distinctive features, namely the fact that its timbers are placed at an angle, while the women stood upright to do their washing.

label: Square François Blanc
description: Area of relaxation, popular spot for photos of the bride and groom...

label: Eglise Saint Pierre Es Liens
comment: The parish church of Fontvieille was built in 1695 with stone from the Fontvieille quarries. It has the particularity of having two bell towers of different appearance, built about 100 years apart (1765 and 1866).
shortDescription: The parish church of Fontvieille was built in 1695 with stone from the Fontvieille quarries. It has the particularity of having two bell towers of different appearance, built about 100 years apart (1765 and 1866).
description:
Saint Pierre-ès-Liens, the commune's parish church, is built in the Classical style.
Construction began in 1695, as the former Saint Pierre-ès-Liens parish church had become too small to accommodate the villagers due to the growth of the village (growth due in part to the operation of the quarries from the 15th century).
From 1790 and throughout the post-Revolutionary period, the building was used as a community room. It was re-consecrated in the early 19th century. Founded in part on an old château, Saint-Pierre-ès-Liens church is made of stone from Fontvieille quarry. Its imposing 19th century façade was inspired by those of Doric temples; on each side of the portal, two pilasters topped with capitals support an entablature composed of an architrave with two fasciae, an unadorned frieze dotted with triglyphs and metopes and a cornice, all surmounted by a triangular fronton. Visitors can admire sculpted bas-relief coats of arms on the central part of the fronton. (We have no information on the origin of these coats of arms). The church was taken over for the first time in 1765 and then for the second time in 1865/1875, which explains the fact that the two bell towers have different appearances and decorative styles. The first bell tower has a square base, topped with a drum dome cut through with semi-circular arches. At the top is a wrought iron weather vane representing a greyhound; this is the crest of the Canillac family and it can also be found on the town's coats of arms. The clock tower, added in 1866, is a square construction decorated with cornices at the top and surmounted by a domed roof.

label: Fontaine des Minimes
comment: This very modest-looking fountain is probably contemporary with the Ville des Tours, and hence one of the oldest in Aix.
shortDescription: This very modest-looking fountain is probably contemporary with the Ville des Tours, and hence one of the oldest in Aix.
description:
The lord of this episcopal city, which occupied the site of the present-day Seds district and stood outside the fortifications of Aix, was the archbishop whose seat was in the church of La Seds.

The prelate had acquired all the king's possessions within the area, and in particular the hot-water spring. This fountain used to be called Sainte-Croix, probably because the city was completely controlled by the church. 

However, its location adjoining the Pères Minimes monastery gave it the new name of Minimes Fountain. It is a beautiful fountain, with cut-off corners and a large portal which frames soft stone panels. The water flows from two cannons protruding from two mascarons, two fine heads with curly hair.

label: Domaine le Manueye
comment: An already changing vegetation, where the oak meets the pine... A scrubland still present but already undergoing shrubby colonization. Not very vast, the Manueye departmental estate is nevertheless pleasant to explore with the family.
shortDescription: An already changing vegetation, where the oak meets the pine... A scrubland still present but already undergoing shrubby colonization. Not very vast, the Manueye departmental estate is nevertheless pleasant to explore with the family.
description:
Indeed, a shepherd grazes his sheep there, thus composing picturesque paintings to be discovered at the bend of a path or trail. In short, a pretty pastoral world! The purpose of this type of breeding is to participate, with the same efficient means used by our ancestors, in the maintenance of the premises and their almost constant surveillance. An asset in case of fire !

It was between 1986 and 1988 that the Department acquired the Manueye, one of the particularities of which is that it is spread out on the hill, not far from Meyrargues, west of the summit of the Concors, near which stands the little chapel of Sainte Consorce, where in the past, in times of drought, people used to come to beg for rain. A pretty little building on a serious elevation at more than 700 meters above sea level, which trails allow you to join the time of a quiet ascent.

Management of natural areas 
Domain of the General Council

label: Cité de la Musique de Marseille - L'Auditorium, Médiathèque
comment: Amateur practice, listening, discovery and musical creations are the rhythm of life at the Cité de la Musique de Marseille throughout the year.
shortDescription: Amateur practice, listening, discovery and musical creations are the rhythm of life at the Cité de la Musique de Marseille throughout the year.
description:
City? The word fits the spirit. If it extends over eight sites, scattered in all the districts of the city, from the Porte d'Aix to the Magalone, passing by the Oasis park and the Square de la Pauline, the Cité de la Musique is a place of welcome, training and sharing. Each year, this unique structure allows more than 2,200 students, both children and adults, to follow quality courses, to discover an instrument, to improve their practice. To play together above all. And to meet the public... if they feel like it.

Amateur practice, listening, discovery and musical creations are the rhythm of life at the Cité de la Musique de Marseille throughout the year.

The Auditorium is an example of architectural rehabilitation typical of these old classical hotels from the beginning of the 20th century. All musical expressions and aesthetics can be presented. The artistic priorities remain focused on the development of contemporary music, electroacoustic music, world music, jazz, French song and shows for young audiences...

As for the media library, it is open to all and includes books, records, documentary films, magazines, sheet music, etc. Its rich and up-to-date collection, available for consultation or even for loan, meets the needs of both amateurs and professionals.

label: Bibliothèque Méjanes - Halle aux Grains
comment: Located in the former grain market, a building built in the 18th century for the wheat trade, this library annexed to the Méjanes library enjoys a privileged location in the heart of the historic centre.
shortDescription: Located in the former grain market, a building built in the 18th century for the wheat trade, this library annexed to the Méjanes library enjoys a privileged location in the heart of the historic centre.
description:
Situated in the former grain hall, a building built in the 18th century for wheat trade, this annex library of the Méjanes library enjoys a privileged location in the heart of the historic center.

It offers free access to a collection of books, magazines, newspapers and DVDs for adults and a selection of albums, magazines and comic books for children.

To facilitate access to reading for the elderly or visually impaired, a selection of books in large print and books recorded on CD (novels, poetry, and theater) is available.

On-site reading is free.

label: Le Donjon
comment: Visible from afar, both dungeon and bell tower, it is the symbol of Pertuis.
shortDescription: Visible from afar, both dungeon and bell tower, it is the symbol of Pertuis.
description:
THE KEEP, VESTIGE OF THE COUNT'S CASTLE
Vestige of the new castle (1), that William II, Count of Forcalquier, had built between 1190 and 1209 in the cemetery of Saint-Nicolas, the keep of Pertuis is one of the rare examples of military architecture of the Middle Ages in Provence.

It is composed of a first floor and two superimposed rooms, vaulted in broken barrel and covered with a terrace surrounded by a crenellation on machicolation -1-.
A staircase is included in the masonry of the northern wall. The entrance was located on the second floor: it is the small bay placed above the two current doors.

The castle probably included the keep and four surrounding walls with towers
At the end of the 14th century, Guillaume Roger, Lord of Pertuis and his son, the famous Raymond de Turenne, at war with the Countess of Provence, reinforced the fortifications and transformed the castle. A vast main building was then built on the south side -2-
From 1596, at the end of the Wars of Religion, the castle is gradually dismantled. The destruction of the northern enclosure, on the side of the city, allows the enlargement of the Market Square (today's Mirabeau Square). The big round tower, called the Prison or Jalette tower, was destroyed when the rue Neuve (rue Danton) was built in 1819, as well as the Porte de la Ville (3)

A BELL TOWER ON THE KEEP, A CHURCH WITHOUT A BELL TOWER
Between 1605 and 1607, the keep acquired by the city from the King's estate was raised with a bell tower -4-.
Since the ruin of the old bell tower of the former church of Saint-Pierre, there was no more bell tower in Pertuis.
In 1605, the inhabitants complained about this situation: "it seems that we are in the worst village in Provence", they said.
The bell tower project, adopted by the city council, was designed by Esprit Boyer, a mason from Aix, Controller of the Royal Buildings. Topped by four belfries, it houses a large central bell, the 17th century drone and two smaller ones.
The two large openings on the first floor were made during the installation of the auditorium of justice and the royal registry at the beginning of the 17th century.

THE COMMUNAL CLOCK
The oldest mention of a communal clock "l'orrologe Vieux" dates from 1407 (2). Installed on the facade of the keep in 1609, it will be replaced only in 1808, indicating the time to the Pertuisiens during almost four centuries!
The current clock was made by Maison Paul Odobay from Jura in 1887. But its mechanism had to be changed at the end of the 1960s.

The keep was classified as a historical monument on December 21, 1984.

-1- The keep, end of XIIth century.
-2- The main building, XIVth century.
-3- The city gate called "du château".
-4- The bell tower, beginning of XVIIth century.

(1) The first seigniorial castle (located on the current Saint-Pierre square), had become a priory of the Abbey of Montmajour in the 12th century.
(2) Contract signed with Master Jean de Troyes, locksmith and clockmaker from Avignon

label: Eglise Saint Sébastien
comment: This church, built in 1625, replaces an old chapel of 1511 dedicated to the same Saint probably because he was implored during the plague.
shortDescription: This church, built in 1625, replaces an old chapel of 1511 dedicated to the same Saint probably because he was implored during the plague.
description: This church built in 1625, replaces a former chapel of 1511 dedicated to the same Saint probably because he was implored at the scourge of the plague.With its polychrome Bell Tower and the octagonal Dome, it is the replica of the Church of the Major in Marseille. His master altar is attributed to the school of Pierre Puget, sculptor, painter and architect French. The Church contains a number of classified objects: two Angels door-torch wood Golden of the XVIII th century, the Grand organ built by the factor of organ Beaucourt between 1850 and 1860, the triptych which is located at the bottom of the Church above the altar, signed B. Chase.It also has a very large canvas of Monticelli. And finally the stained glass representing the history of the creation and are the work of master Pascale.
streetAddress: ['Eglise Saint Sébastien, place du Dct Chevillon']

label: L'obélisque romain
comment:
Date: 4th century
Period: Antiquity
Type: Public votive architecture
Status: Public domain Listed as a Historic Monument (1840), Unesco World Heritage (1981)
shortDescription:
Date: 4th century
Period: Antiquity
Type: Public votive architecture
Status: Public domain Listed as a Historic Monument (1840), Unesco World Heritage (1981)
description:
Date: 4th century
Era: Antiquity
Type: Votive public architecture
Status: Public estate listed as a national Historic Monument in 1840 and a UNESCO Heritage Site in 1981
The obelisk seen from the town hall roof
The large stone needle, a kind of pivot on the Place de la République, actually comes from the Roman circus and dates from late Antiquity.
The obelisk was discovered in the 14th century, but it was not until the 17th century that it became a symbol of the sun once again.
It was transported and installed, with great difficulty, in front of the newly built hôtel de ville.
It is adorned with a fountain and a basin and it sets the standard for the harmony of the different styles of façades around the square.
It is also the best viewpoint for taking in vast panorama of the Place de la République.
A symbol of the sun and the Empire in Antiquity and a decorative feature, the obelisk also served as a landmark for charioteers in the heart of the Roman circus.
We now know that the structure was created from granite taken from a Roman quarry in Asia Minor.
It is monolithic in design (it was split in two at the end of Antiquity) and, together with the pedestal designed by the Arles architect Jacques Peytret, it measures around 20 metres.
Fassin and Lieutaud (1909) provided the following information: 15.26 m high, 1.7 wide at the base; the pedestal is 4.55 m high.
The point was surmounted by a bronze globe scattered with fleur de lys, which was topped with a golden sun.
The obelisk comes from the spina (central wall around which the track ran) of the Roman circus.
It was erected there during major work carried out on the building in the 4th century.
After the building was abandoned in the 6th century, the obelisk collapsed and broke in two.
It was rediscovered in 1389 and regularly shown to important visitors, such as Henri IV, who wanted it to be placed in the centre of the amphitheatre.
However, the consuls decided to erect it on the Place Royale, in front of the new hôtel de ville, 'for the greater glory of King Louis XIV'.
It took 40 days to transport and required colossal manpower to move it a distance of a few hundred metres.
The majority of the shaft was close to the original site and the four-metre long point was on Place Antonelle, in the La Roquette district... where it was being used as a bench.
But it was even more difficult to raise it on its pedestal (its foundations revealed the existence of Roman thermal baths on this site).
Mariners specialised in handling boat masts were called in. On 26 March 1676, the operation ended with the installation of the point.
It was then possible to install the Royal symbol, a bronze globe topped with a sun. This globe was later replaced by other symbols, including a Phrygian cap, a Napoleonic eagle and the cockerel of the July Monarchy, before the Royal sun was put back (removed permanently in 1866).
The stone lions, originally placed there in the 17th century, were replaced in 1829 by bronze lions sculpted by Dantan.
Henri Révoil restored the building in 1866-1867 and added fountains and a basin, decorated with masks of Hercules.

label: Eglise de Montolivet
comment:
The church of Saint Fortuné on the plateau of Montolivet houses an organ that is sometimes played.
Masses on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10 am, and at 11:30 am in Polish for the Polish community.
shortDescription:
The church of Saint Fortuné on the plateau of Montolivet houses an organ that is sometimes played.
Masses on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10 am, and at 11:30 am in Polish for the Polish community.

label: Atelier de Cezanne
comment: Cezanne's studio, also known as Atelier des Lauves is a veritable place of memory, marked by Cezanne's imprint. It allows to discover the familiar objects of the painter and his artistic preferences.
shortDescription: Cezanne's studio, also known as Atelier des Lauves is a veritable place of memory, marked by Cezanne's imprint. It allows to discover the familiar objects of the painter and his artistic preferences.
description:
On 1st September 1902, Cezanne gradually settled into his large country studio. He worked there every day during the last four years of his life. All of Cézanne's admirers are well aware that this is where you can feel the painter's presence most strongly. 

It is here, on the Lauves hill, among the objects he treasured, the models of his last still lifes, his furniture and his work tools, that you will feel the painter's presence most intensely. 

From 1902 until his death in 1906, Cezanne worked every morning in this studio of light and silence, the birthplace of dozens of paintings that are now owned by the world's great museums, including the last series of Large Bathers. 

The studio has a shop selling books and souvenirs, regularly hosts temporary exhibitions and holds cultural and gastronomic events in season.

➜ Duration : 30 minutes

Guided tour in French, all the year at 11:30am and from June to September at 11:30am and 2:00pm
Guided tour in English all the year at 3.30pm and from June to September at 10:00am and 3.30pm  
Free tour every 30 minutes depending on the opening hours.

Booking at the information desk of the TOurist Office or on the website of the Tourist Office.

⚠ No luggage storage at the Cezanne workshop ⚠

label: Chapelle Saint Jean du Grès
comment: The building is of Romanesque origin: only the apse has been preserved. In 1069, the monks of Montmajour took possession of it. It served as a parish church until 1768, when Saint-Pierre-ès-Liens was consecrated.
shortDescription: The building is of Romanesque origin: only the apse has been preserved. In 1069, the monks of Montmajour took possession of it. It served as a parish church until 1768, when Saint-Pierre-ès-Liens was consecrated.
description:
The building is of Romanesque origin: only the apse has been preserved. In 1069, the monks of Montmajour took possession of it. It served as a parish church until 1768, when Saint-Pierre-ès-Liens was consecrated.
The chapel is the subject of a procession on 24 June (re-established since 1964). It is currently used for various cultural events.
Located on the olive-growing estate of Mas Saint-Jean, visits are possible on written request to the owners.This small building has a rather singular appearance: 4 large buttresses support the side walls. A small semi-circular apse closes the nave. The barrel vault that covers it rises to more than 8 m. A stone bench runs the length of the nave walls. The dedication of the church to St. John the Baptist and St. John the Evangelist can still be seen on the northern pilaster of the triumphal arch. The entrance, which is now to the east, was originally through a door in the south side, which was later closed. The stone altar, decorated with two statues of St Peter and the Virgin Mary, is reached by means of three steps. To get there, take the "Route de Saint-Jean" to the north-east of the commune of Fontvieille. Today this place is used for cultural events.

label: Village de Pélissanne
description: Situated on the banks of the Touloubre river, Pélissanne is an astonishing shell village, typically Provençal, which takes on the allure of "big" due to its rich rustic and classical architecture. Its old centre, of which the Saint-Maurice church is the heart, reveals a maze of small streets that have preserved all the charms of this ancient fortified town.

label: Abbaye Notre-Dame de la Fidelité
comment:
On its vast and solitary plateau, the Abbey of Notre Dame de Fidélité is part of the religious and cultural heritage of the region and is very much part of the rural life of the region.
Discover the community of Benedictine nuns in all tranquillity.
shortDescription:
On its vast and solitary plateau, the Abbey of Notre Dame de Fidélité is part of the religious and cultural heritage of the region and is very much part of the rural life of the region.
Discover the community of Benedictine nuns in all tranquillity.
description: This monastery, founded in 1967 and elevated to the rank of abbey in 1981, is the retreat of about fifty Benedictine nuns, in the heart of a pine forest, surrounded by fields of olive trees and lavender, vines and beehives. This peaceful and harmonious place is an opportunity to soak up an atmosphere full of serenity and to go and meet this community, which can welcome visitors to the monastic store where you can find their handicrafts: jams, wines, soaps, perfumes... In the respect of the monastic rules.

label: Parc de Maison Blanche
comment: The Maison Blanche park is a 5-hectare park located in the 9ᵉ arrondissement of Marseille. The park has a lake and lawns and wooded areas.
shortDescription: The Maison Blanche park is a 5-hectare park located in the 9ᵉ arrondissement of Marseille. The park has a lake and lawns and wooded areas.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


The park and its bastide were built around 1840 by the merchant Cohen. The complex was immediately named Maison Blanche. In 1920, a Swiss family bought the property and transformed it by creating a lake and opening large windows in the bastide's façade. The estate was sold to the City by the descendants in 1978. It was then decided to keep the park as an amenity, the bastide hosting, a few years later, the city hall of the 9th and 10th districts. Most of the remarkable trees on this site, such as magnolias, redwoods, cedars, yews, plane trees, liquidambars and a Siberian elm, date from the first half of the 19th century.

Other species joined these first deciduous trees: bald cypress, gingko biloba, chestnut, beech, maple, poplar, oak, sophora, tulip tree, holly and ash. More recently, hazelnut trees, hackberry trees, a paulownia and a banana tree.

label: Chapelle Saint-Anne dites Chapelle Mère de Dieu
comment: The portal of the Chapel of Saint Anne (17th century) is of Mannerist inspiration, combining elements belonging to the ornamental repertoire (pilasters, pediment, foliage) associated without respect for classical architectural standards.
shortDescription: The portal of the Chapel of Saint Anne (17th century) is of Mannerist inspiration, combining elements belonging to the ornamental repertoire (pilasters, pediment, foliage) associated without respect for classical architectural standards.
description: The fortified bell tower with campanile, off-centre in relation to the axis of the church, is dated 1664. It is built in Calissanne stone.

label: Eglise Saint-Georges
description: The church was inaugurated in 1963 and hosts a beautiful crib every year during the Christmas holidays. Reception from Monday to Friday from 10:15 to 11:15 and from 17:00 to 18:30. Parish priest: Michel Lombard. Weekday mass: Wednesday at 8:30 am, Thursday at 7 am, Tuesday and Friday at 6:30 pm. Mass on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday 10:30 am.

label: Eglise Saint Césaire
comment: Visit the church of Saint Césaire, in Romanesque and classical style
shortDescription: Visit the church of Saint Césaire, in Romanesque and classical style
description:
The church dates back to at least 1041, a deed dated this year indicates its erection to replace the parish church of Cataruscum.
This construction must have taken place in parallel with the construction of the city walls.
Several times enlarged to cope with the evolution of the population, it visually bears the traces of these various works.
The original Romanesque style, rather austere, and the successive styles more borrowed from classicism.
Lightning had destroyed the original bell tower in 1973, it is now brand new with its spire raised to the sky and built in the same condition as it was originally.
The church dominates the old centre and its bells punctuate the hours from the top of its large white bell tower.

label: Parc Jean Moulin
comment: A green setting of 10 hectares, 4 of which are landscaped and 6 are natural areas.
shortDescription: A green setting of 10 hectares, 4 of which are landscaped and 6 are natural areas.
description:
The park includes 3 playgrounds for children, a fitness area, picnic tables and water points nearby, waste baskets, two sanitary facilities.

This green space close to the center attracts sportsmen and women who come to train, as well as simple walkers or picnic lovers.

It is also the privileged place of reception of various cultural, sporting events or for the photographs of marriage..

label: Cheminée de l'usine à fer
description: Former iron factory, chimney classified as a historical monument, access by the Bestouan car park to reach the site itself.

label: Le pigeonnier du Parc St Michel
comment: This place is curiously a strong symbol of the abolition of privileges due to the French revolution. Originally one of the four grain mills of the village, partially destroyed by a storm in 1839, it was transformed into a dovecote by Charles Verminck.
shortDescription: This place is curiously a strong symbol of the abolition of privileges due to the French revolution. Originally one of the four grain mills of the village, partially destroyed by a storm in 1839, it was transformed into a dovecote by Charles Verminck.
description:
The peasants were obliged to use the mills in exchange for a very substantial "ban" fee, which was collected by the lord owner.
It can be visited from time to time during heritage days
The park Saint Michel where it is located with the chapel is used every summer as a backdrop for a great historical sound and light show.

label: Les croix de Maillane
comment: Cross of Maillane.
shortDescription: Cross of Maillane.
description:
- The white cross is located at the entrance of the road to the Bérard estate, this family probably had the monument erected.
This stone cross is sculpted on both sides (Christ and the Virgin).
This cross is the oldest in the village, it is mentioned since 1697.
