- Cross from Arles to Maillane: Located on RD 32, mentioned as early as 1532, knocked down during the Revolution, raised in 1804: delicate wrought iron cross on a high pilaster with a capital.

- Croix de Saint-Jean : Cross from the XVIIth century located in front of the church until 1851. On May 20, 1852, it was transferred to the road to Graveson, then moved back a few meters due to the enlargement of the road. High square cippus topped by a truncated pyramid. The wrought iron cross is worked, the Christ is haloed.

- Cross of Valettes : Erected in 1878 in cut stone - Petite Route d'Eyragues.

- Croix du Coq (Route d'Eyragues): Erected in 1733 and restored in 1824, the image of the rooster was once associated with the image of the cross in memory of the crowing of the rooster that was heard during the Passion, at the denial of Peter. Square skullcap at the base of an octagonal column, which supports a wrought iron cross topped by a rooster. On the base, a rooster is engraved, surrounded by the words "La Croix du Coq".

- The Jubilee Cross is located on the site of the old cemetery, now the church square. Built in 1851, originally in walnut with a cast iron Christ, it was knocked down on a mistral day in 1864, and replaced the same year by the present wrought iron cross.

- Cross of Mas Mouret : Built in 1875 on the road to St Rémy. An inscription on each side of the base: three in Provencal, one in French by Victor Hugo

- Cross of the Mas du Juge : Erected by a nephew of Mistral. End of the XIXth century.

- Cross of the Poet: It succeeded two other mission crosses, one erected in 1740, the other thirty years later. Mutilated during the Revolution, it was restored in 1824. Frédéric Mistral was photographed several times in front of this cross, located in front of the poet's house, which is why it is called "La Croix du Poète".

label: Domaine de La Palissade
comment: Located between the sea and the Rhône, the Domaine de la Palissade, a site belonging to the Coastal Conservatory, is located outside the dikes, which gives it a particular ecological interest, with specific flora and fauna.
shortDescription: Located between the sea and the Rhône, the Domaine de la Palissade, a site belonging to the Coastal Conservatory, is located outside the dikes, which gives it a particular ecological interest, with specific flora and fauna.
description:
Located between the sea and the Rhône, the Domaine de la Palissade, a site belonging to the Coastal Conservatory, is located outside the dikes, which gives it a particular ecological interest, with specific flora and fauna. It is the last territory which bears witness to the natural evolution of the Rhône delta.

The La Palissade estate, located between Salin de Giraud and the coast, covers 702 hectares on the right bank of the Grand Rhône. It is entirely outside the dikes that protect the lower Camargue from invasion by river or sea waters, which gives it a very particular ecological interest, with specific flora and fauna. It is the last territory which testifies to the natural evolution of the delta. Formerly an area used exclusively for breeding, fishing and hunting, the Coastal Conservatory acquired it in 1976.

label: Musée Auguste Chabaud
comment: The Auguste Chabaud Museum presents the works of the painter from the Fauvist period.
shortDescription: The Auguste Chabaud Museum presents the works of the painter from the Fauvist period.
description:
The Auguste Chabaud Regional Museum presents a permanent collection of works by this Provençal artist from the first half of the 20th century. He was a companion of Matisse and the Fauvists whose subjects included the landscapes of the Alpilles and La Montagnette, everyday life in the villages and the night-life of the shady side of Paris at the start of the century. Temporary exhibitions are hosted from time to time, on a theme connected to the work of Auguste Chabard or another artist.
Auguste Chabaud - Fascination & Nostalgia between Provence and Tunisia: from 9 February to 2 June 2013. Exceptional exhibition as part of Marseille Provence 2013.

label: Plage de la calanque de Sormiou
comment: If you are in Marseille and want to cut yourself off from the world, to stop hearing the noise of the city and discover an enchanting landscape, go for a walk on the beach of the calanque of Sormiou.
shortDescription: If you are in Marseille and want to cut yourself off from the world, to stop hearing the noise of the city and discover an enchanting landscape, go for a walk on the beach of the calanque of Sormiou.
description:
You can get there via the Baumettes district, south of the city, by taking the Sormiou pass and its small winding road which goes down directly to the cove. In summer, the descent is more complicated because cars are not allowed, it is done on foot just like the ascent! But what a pleasure to be on this small sandy beach, not to hear any car noise but only the lapping of the turquoise water and the voices of the children who play at the water's edge. 

The beach of the calanque of Sormiou is also a very good starting point to discover the calanques by kayak. A small marina, cabins, a restaurant of traditional and Provencal cuisine as well as a sports center UCPA occupy it. The parking is compulsory and paying : 5 EUR. The beach is equipped with toilets.

The beach is supervised by a rescue team in July and August.
This cove is now included in the Calanques National Park.

label: Site de plongée des Impériaux
comment: In the Calanques National Park, at the eastern end of the island of Riou, the diving spot is composed of three rocks and a dizzying drop off, offering a wealth of free and fixed fauna.
shortDescription: In the Calanques National Park, at the eastern end of the island of Riou, the diving spot is composed of three rocks and a dizzying drop off, offering a wealth of free and fixed fauna.
description:
It is an intermediate level spot (from 20 to 65m), accessible by boat near the Ile du Riou in Marseille. Around 3 rocks which stand out in the South-East of the island (named "les impériaux" or "les empereurs").
- Imperial de Terre : Max. -25 meters,
- Imperial du Milieu : Max. -45 meters,
- Imperial du Large: Max. -65 meters.

You will be able to observe groupers, lobsters, sea breams, barracudas, scorpion fish, red gorgonians, moray eels, in a majestic palette of colours.

label: Musée archéologique municipal de Pélissanne
description:
Located in the old town hall (17th century) classified as a historical monument, the museum presents the archaeological remains from the excavations of Pélissanne and its surroundings. The museum traces 6000 years of history through three exhibition rooms. First room: presentation of the history of the village from the Neolithic (4000 BC) to the beginning of the modern era (17th century). Second room: presentation of Pélissannaise ceramics, Provencal pottery used from the 18th to the 19th centuries and made in several workshops in Pélissanne. Third room: presentation of the works of Vincent Barot, potter and santon maker from Aubagne who came to settle in Pélissanne at the beginning of the 20th century.
Surface of the permanent exhibition : 100

label: Parc des Collines de Cuques
comment: Situated in the southern districts of the city access via Avenue de la Cible, Chemin Gilles Borel.
shortDescription: Situated in the southern districts of the city access via Avenue de la Cible, Chemin Gilles Borel.
description:
The park, covering 24,850m2, has been created on areas of hillside recolonised by natural vegetation: pines, viburnums and rosemary, linked by paths winding through the pine woods. 

Vast lawns have been laid, and there are play areas and a paddling pool.

label: La Capelière - Société Nationale de Protection de la Nature - Réserve Nationale de Camargue
comment: On the banks of the Vaccarès, La Capelière was opened in 1979 in a former Camargue farmhouse surrounded by marshes. Nature trails, nature information center, exhibitions, the Capelière is also the administrative center of the Natural Reserve of Camargue.
shortDescription: On the banks of the Vaccarès, La Capelière was opened in 1979 in a former Camargue farmhouse surrounded by marshes. Nature trails, nature information center, exhibitions, the Capelière is also the administrative center of the Natural Reserve of Camargue.
description: An information centre and a nature observation site in Camargue: reception, library, Camargue natural environment exhibition, a trail of 1.5 km equipped with information boards, four observatories of the marshlands and two observation decks over the Vaccarès reedbed.

label: Plage Napoleon
description: Beach of fine sand monitored on weekends from June 15 to July 1, and July 1 to August 31. Beach 10km x 120 m.-Road sign. -Identifying the site Panel.-Free parking outside the range (before the toll station)-Parking on the beach, fully equipped and pay area. Bars, post of relief, playground, two wc, trash cans, telephone booths. On-site water activities: windsurfing, kitesurfing.Possibility of access to the beach by a bicycle path along the road, track opened in July 2006.

label: Basilique Notre-Dame de la Garde
comment: Notre-Dame de la Garde " La Bonne Mère ", emblematic figure of the city, watches over the sailors, the fishermen and all the inhabitants of Marseilles.
shortDescription: Notre-Dame de la Garde " La Bonne Mère ", emblematic figure of the city, watches over the sailors, the fishermen and all the inhabitants of Marseilles.
description:
The Garde hill (154 m) has always been an observation post.
Tradition has it, but there is no proof, that the look-out post exists since prehistorical times and more probably since the Roman era. In the 15th century decree of Charles II d'Anjou enumerates the Garde hill in the lists of relays. This look-out system is improved over the centuries and this function continues on the hill until 1978.
To protect Marseille from the armies of Charles the Fifth, led by the Constable of Bourbon, François the 1st has a fort built in 1524 on the top of the hill, which, together with the Châteay d'If, forms a maritime defense which serves as a foundaion for the present basilisa and find above the north porch the signature of the King l a salamander.
But the Garde hill acquires all its meaning as a sacred as well as an urban symbol with the construction of the basilica in 1853. From then on, the silhouette of the building becomes inseparable from the image of Marseille. However, several churches have preceded its construction. The first one was in 1241 when a hermit, master Pierre, received the authorization to build on this site which belonged to the Abbey of Saint Victor. From the 16th century onwards the church is gradually transformed into a center of religious devotion of the sailors. From this period date the first ex-votos which they deposit here.
Since then the Garde hill has a triple function: look-out post, fortification and place of worship and pilgrimage. In thhe iddle of the 19th century, the sanctuary proves to be too small for the numeroux pilgrims who visit it. Monseigneur de Mazenod decides to buil a large basilica on this site. The foundation stone is laid on 11 september 1853, the building is entrusted to the architect Espérandieu and the consecration takes place on 5 june 1864.
In a Romanesque-byzantine style with domes, multicoloured stone, gold and mosaics, the basilica fits in perfectly in the programme of the large constructions undertaken in Marseille under Napoléon III.
The edifice consists of two parts: a lower cherch, a vaulted crypt which houses in particular a multi-coloured crucifix dating from the 16th century church and a "mater dolorosa" of marble of Carpeaux and an upper church, the sanctuary, dedicated to the Virgin (name day and pilgrimage on 15 August) where mosaics with a gold background and muli-coloured marbles abound, giving it the appearance o a reliquary. Of particular interest are the bronze doors and the high altar designed by Revoil, Virgin in silver by Chanuel, an Annunciation low relief in multi-coloured glazed earthenware, a Florentine work of the 16th cebtury.
The presence of numerous ex-votos exhibed on the walls, hung between the supports of the nave, are a true collection of naïve art, a charming chronicle of the community of Marseille, eloquent witnesses of popular faith, dedicated to "la bonne mère", the name given to her by all the marseillais, wathever their religion. The belfry supports a monumental statue of the virgin created by the sculptor Lequesne. It was executed in bronze, gilded with gold leaf, by the Christofle workshops and installed in september 1870.
From the esplanade, in front of the sanctuary, there is a most impressive view of Marseille and its site.
Between 2001 and 2007, the part outside and the decor inside the church have been restored.

label: Archives départementales
comment: The mission of the Bouches-du-Rhône Departmental Archives is to preserve, communicate and promote the archival documents produced in the department from the 9th century to the present day.
shortDescription: The mission of the Bouches-du-Rhône Departmental Archives is to preserve, communicate and promote the archival documents produced in the department from the 9th century to the present day.
description:
The Departmental Archives were born of the reforming and centralizing will of the revolutionary legislators

From the very beginning of the Revolution, they wanted to bring together in a single place all the papers and titles of the ecclesiastical institutions and administrations of the Ancien Régime that had been abolished. The aim was to give all citizens free access to the papers that now belonged to the nation.

However, since it was not possible to house all of the country's archives in Paris, the Directoire, by the law of 5 Brumaire An V (26 October 1796), ordered them to be collected in the chief towns of the départements. This text is the birth certificate of the departmental archives.

The mission of the Bouches-du-Rhône Departmental Archives is to preserve, communicate and promote the archival documents produced in the department from the 9th century to the present day
Equipped with a vast reading room allowing consultation of the originals, the Departmental Archives are also a place for cultural exchanges on the historical and human heritage, open to the issues of the district, the city and the territory.

They offer a varied programme of cultural activities, favouring free access and projects for individuals and schools, as well as for the public in the social field.

label: Médiathèque d'Arles
description: Free entrance, free individual registration on presentation of proof of identity, proof of residence and a photo ID

label: Coopérative vinicole
comment: Wine cooperative, from the beginning of the 20th century; sales shop of the Vignerons de Mistral
shortDescription: Wine cooperative, from the beginning of the 20th century; sales shop of the Vignerons de Mistral
description:
The wine cooperative

Since the Middle Ages, viticulture has shaped the landscape and conditioned the enrichment of the inhabitants of the town and the area of Marignane
A very early "muscatelle" wine was produced here in the 1460s, followed by white muscatel wines that were renowned throughout the region in the 18th century
There are numerous heritage testimonies about the seigneurial domains, the large vineyard areas, the vaulted rooms with fermentation vats, a wine cellar in the château in the 16th century, and the wine-making process, an image of which can be found on a revolutionary ex-voto kept in the Notre-Dame de Pitié chapel

In the 20th century, a dozen winegrowers joined forces to found the wine cooperative. The design of the building was entrusted in 1925 to the architect Hourst, a specialist in this category (he was found in Pélissanne, Puy-Sainte-Réparade, Eguilles and many other communes), relayed by the contractor Célestin Coq for the implementation. It was quickly enlarged in 1929 by the architect Grava and the contractor Albert Calvin, just before the old distillery was transformed into a vat house in 1933
Between 1953 and 1957, the Castel agency, in association with Gaston and his son Auguste, known as Ello, built an extension with new vats, signing here the plans for one of the twenty or so Marignane buildings bearing their name
As for the shop, it dates from 1962

The central body, which houses the accommodation on the first floor, is distinguished by its pediment with a gendarme hat crowning a southern facade coloured red. The south-west facing building continues with an extension of the original vat house to the north, where the shop opens out onto a weighbridge to the south-east

Listed in the supplementary inventory of historical monuments in 1986, it is now a warehouse of the agricultural cooperative of Berre, Les Vignerons de Mistral, with a beautiful sales area for wines (AOC Côteaux d'Aix-en-Provence and IGP vins de Provence) and delicatessen products.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021
streetAddress: ['7 Avenue De la Premère Armée Française']

label: Centre d'art Tadao Ando - Château La Coste
comment: The Tadao Ando Art Centre at Château La Coste combines art, architecture and wine.
shortDescription: The Tadao Ando Art Centre at Château La Coste combines art, architecture and wine.
description:
Château La Coste is a vineyard where art, architecture and land have come together. Artists invited to participate, were encouraged to choose a place on the domaine and given the freedom to create something that would live there.

Château La Coste will continue to evolve as new projects and 
installations find their place.Here you can walk at your leisure through 180 hectares of wooded hilltops, valleys and vines discover works by:

Tadao ANDO, Louise BOURGEOIS, Alexander CALDER, Mac COÍLÍN, 
Frank O. GEHRY, Liam GILLICK, Andy GOLDSWORTHY, GUGGI, 
Carsten HÖLLER, Paul MATISSE, Tatsuo MIYAJIMA, Jean NOUVEL, 
Jean-Michel OTHONIEL, Jean PROUVÉ, Sean SCULLY, Richard SERRA, Tom SHANNON, Michael STIPE, Hiroshi SUGIMOTO, TUNGA, Franz WEST.


Allow approximately 1.30 minutes to complete the walk.
Comfortable walking shoes are recommended.

label: Vallée des Pinchinats
comment: This valley, with the hillsides dominating it, is the natural water reserve of the city of Aix-en-Provence. It is located to the north of the city.
shortDescription: This valley, with the hillsides dominating it, is the natural water reserve of the city of Aix-en-Provence. It is located to the north of the city.
description:
It owes its name to the combing (penchinat in Provençal) and cloth pressing (paradou) workshops of the Middle Ages, whose industry required a large quantity of pure water.

This valley is very pleasant in summer because it keeps its freshness thanks to the numerous shady, wooded areas and the network of streams that used to supply the mills, factories and gardens of the bourgeois houses in the area.

Listed site

label: Chapelle Notre-Dame de la Nerthe (La Galline)
description:
The small chapel of the "Nerthe"( Myrte, in provençal) is the ancient church of a small village of which nothing remains. Consecrated  in 1042, it became a very popular place of pilgrimage in Marseille. People come there to pray to the Madonna of the Hen (Hence its other name  : Notre-Dame de la Galline). 
Access on foot, by bike, by car.
Mass on the first Saturday of the month at 10am.
The church is open by appointment after contacting Mr. Fouque.
Pilgrimage : September 8.
Paul Guigou painted it in 1860.

label: Square Mouton
description: Petanque ground, kids' playground, toilets

label: Maison des Chevaliers
comment:
First seigneurial residence in the heart of Barbentane, contemporary with the beginning of the construction of the church.
It probably owes its name to the existence of several knights of the Order of Saint John of Jerusalem among its descendants.
shortDescription:
First seigneurial residence in the heart of Barbentane, contemporary with the beginning of the construction of the church.
It probably owes its name to the existence of several knights of the Order of Saint John of Jerusalem among its descendants.
description: "Home of the Knights of Malta", known as "the House of the Knights" is the former stately home of the Marquis de Barbentane. Located opposite the Church in the middle of the fortified Center of the village, its construction dates from the beginning of the twelfth century (1133).The House is divided and sold from 1665. The northern part became the home of the Consuls and Hotel City 1670 to 1888, the southern part is occupied by families and the low Gallery is used as a Hall. The Town Hall party was strongly reworked between 1838 and 1843, only the corner tower is preserved, with a monumental sculpture of the first coat of arms of the village. The South façade, on the street Pujade, is dressed again around 1740 and treated in classic hotel. All has been restored in the year 2000.

label: Hôtel de la Tour de Brau
description: This former hotel de Glandèves, class historical monument, dates from the end of the 14th century. By donation of the King René, in the 15th century, it became the property of the powerful family of the Tour de Brau (lou brau, "wild bulls"). Two models reflect the State of the castle of Baux de Provence in the 13th century and the Renaissance. Hotel de la Tour de Brau (entrance to the Castle) recalls the lavish residences that had built the most powerful families of Provence to leases. Inside, the visitor discovers the bass, beautifully furnished room. The warheads of the vaults are decorated with, at the level of the keys, badges armoriés bearing the famous star sixteen points of the family of Baux de Provence. Two models reflect the State of the castle of Baux de Provence in the 13th century and the Renaissance.

label: Chapelle Saint Cyr et Sainte Julitte
comment: Romanesque chapel dating from the 11th century
shortDescription: Romanesque chapel dating from the 11th century
description:
The chapel of Saint Cyr is located on the edge of the national road 113, and dates from the end of the 11th century. It was at the time the center of the old village before the inhabitants came to take refuge higher up, sheltered behind the ramparts. It is built in the Romanesque style, with no ornamentation inside or outside, but its proportions are harmonious. It consists of a single nave and two side chapels. The western facade is blind, only the choir and the crosspieces are pierced with small openings. The roof is made of slate and its bell tower adds to the harmony of the whole.
At the time, the cemetery surrounded the church, and there was a well decorated with an iron cross, the remains of which are preserved in the museum of old Salon.
Thanks to its beauty and the purity of its lines and volumes, the Saint Cyr chapel is one of the most remarkable small churches in the region

label: Château de Gréasque
description:
The 17th century castle, where the Count of Castellane-Majastre lived,
today it hosts the activities of the music school, theatre, painting and dance classes, as well as art salons, and is the meeting place for the village associations.
From the courtyard, where the original fountain of the Place Lescure is located, there is an exceptional view of the Sainte Victoire.
The shady park includes a children's playground and a green theatre where shows and concerts of the Jazz festival are offered.

label: Bibliothèque du Lézard
comment: The Lizard Library is housed in the Maison du Lézard, built in the 17th century, where Frédéric Mistral lived from 1855 to 1876. The poet completed Mirèio and wrote Calendau there.
shortDescription: The Lizard Library is housed in the Maison du Lézard, built in the 17th century, where Frédéric Mistral lived from 1855 to 1876. The poet completed Mirèio and wrote Calendau there.
description:
The Bibliothèque du Lézard was the house in which Frédéric Mistral lived from 1855 to 1876.

You will find novels, documentaries, comics for adults and children and a very rich youth collection. There are almost 3700 documents at your disposal which you can consult on the spot or borrow. The Library works in partnership with the network of the Bibliothèque Départementale de Prêt, a service of the Bouches du Rhône Department, which enables us to enrich our own collections.

In addition, the Maillane Library also holds two particularly interesting archival collections: on the one hand, the collection of the former Capoulié du Felibrige and Sorbonne Professor Charles Rostaing, and on the other hand, part of the collection of the writer Charles Galtier, whose abundant and high-quality literary work touches on theatre, stories, poetry and Provençal ethnography.

Registration: 10 € per year and per family.
Loan per person: 3 books per borrower for 3 weeks.
Access your reader account: bibliothequemaillane.biblix.fr

label: Musée Réattu
comment: Built at the end of the 15th century, the Grand Priory of the Order of Malta owes its destiny to Jacques Réattu (1760-1833), an Arles painter and winner of the Grand Prix de Rome. The building became a museum in 1868 and houses his work and personal collection,
shortDescription: Built at the end of the 15th century, the Grand Priory of the Order of Malta owes its destiny to Jacques Réattu (1760-1833), an Arles painter and winner of the Grand Prix de Rome. The building became a museum in 1868 and houses his work and personal collection,
description:
*The Réattu Museum is accessible without reservation, but in accordance with the legal provisions in force since Wednesday 21 July, a health pass must be presented at the entrance to the Réattu Museum.

Open to photography since the 1960s (4000 works today), enriched by exceptional donations (Picasso, with 57 drawings and two paintings, Alechinsky...), very sensitive to sculpture (Germaine Richier, Toni Grand...), the museum created in 2008 a listening room dedicated to sound art. The museum is a real meeting place, commissioning artists and mixing disciplines, and offers thematic exhibitions and new displays to discover art in a different way.
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 2500
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 200

label: La maison dite de la Reine Jeanne
comment: Mythical name for a small Mannerist "palace" of the end of the 16th century.
shortDescription: Mythical name for a small Mannerist "palace" of the end of the 16th century.
description:
THE ARCHITECTURAL DATING CONTRADICTS THE LEGEND
Oddly located in a dead-end alley, at the corner of Petite and Beaujeu streets, this "little palace" is "an extraordinary example of Aix-en-Provence Mannerist style, from the 1590s" (1). Although it is nowadays quite dilapidated, it is the most remarkable house in the Old Town
The people of Pertuis gave it the name of the legendary queen evoked in many Provençal sayings: "Se crei la rèino Jano", "Parla coumo la rèino Jano", to say that she is the most beautiful...
But none of the three "Queen Janes" who were Countesses of Provence in the 14th and 15th centuries were able to have this residence built, not even Queen Jeanne de Laval (1433-1498), wife of the "Good King René", who was "Lady of Pertuis" a century before its construction.

(1) Gloton J-J. Renaissance and Baroque in Aix-en-Provence. Thesis, 1975.

A SMALL MANNERIST PALACE "À L'ITALIENNE
The rigor of the order of the two facades, alternating Tuscan and Ionic bays on three levels, and cross-beams devoid of ornamentation, is only apparent. The treatment of the decorations is a matter of singular choices, of sought-after complications: the leaning columns are sunk into the wall, the entablatures discontinuous. The main portal, which protrudes strongly, conceals truncated Tuscan columns. Equipped with strange pilasters, in the form of consoles, it is decorated with a frieze, where bucranes (sculpted ox skulls) can be guessed. This Mannerism, between Renaissance and Baroque, recalls the architecture of the Italian palaces of the end of the 16th century
This masterpiece remained unfinished. It is assumed that it was commissioned by a wealthy patron: the Duke de la Valette, brother of the famous Duke of Epernon, Governor of Provence from 1587 to 1592, who made Pertuis the seat of his government during the Wars of Religion

Registered as a historical monument on January 12, 1931.

label: BIBLIOTHEQUE MUNICIPALE Georges Brassens
comment: Library located in the southern district to meet all demands in terms of reading, culture, information, continuing education and leisure.
shortDescription: Library located in the southern district to meet all demands in terms of reading, culture, information, continuing education and leisure.
description:
The two municipal media libraries are there

Kingdom of the written word, image, sound, and the Internet, they offer 

100,000 books and documents available (books, comic strips and manga, records, DVD films)
180 subscriptions to newspapers and magazines
800 new products per month
An important musical background also offers the latest news and CDs of recorded readings.
A multimedia space that allows you to access the Internet free of charge and to participate in training workshops

Opening hours :
tuesday, Friday: 2pm-6pm
wednesday, Saturday: 10am-6pm
streetAddress: ['Allée Philippe de Brocca', 'Quartier de la Frescoule']

label: Plage des Ours
comment: The Ours beach in Port de Bouc is located after the Frédéric Mistral college and just before the Pointe de Vella.
shortDescription: The Ours beach in Port de Bouc is located after the Frédéric Mistral college and just before the Pointe de Vella.
description:
Pebble beach of 250m x 12m

Supervised beach in summer from 1 p.m. to 6:45 p.m.
Two items of equipment that improve the comfort of people with reduced mobility are available and delivered to the beaches on request from the supervisors: the "Hippocampe" wheelchair facilitating movement on the sand and entering the water and the "Tiralo", wheelchair amphibious, allowing accompanied swimming.

Site of discovery of a necropolis of 12 tombs dating from 200 BC
By the way along the coast.

label: Chapelle Jean de Renaud
description: Dedicated to the one who was military architect in the service of King François 1 er of Henry II this Chapel is a gem unknown to our city.Heavily bruised during the Revolution and then by the time, she comes to benefit from a long restoration under the direction of Historic Monuments. Dating back to the beginning of the 16th century, it is nestled at the foot of the Bell Tower of the collegiate church Saint-Martin, last remnant of the medieval church which collapsed en1818. Of flamboyant Gothic style, it has wealth to discover: a vault "has anti-SAG and tiercerons" of rare in our region where Romanesque architecture is ubiquitous, a beautiful fresco depicting Jean de Renaud with his mortuary helmet surmounted of a Unicorn and red and gold feathers, stained-glass windows bearing the same arms, a slab of marble bearing the epitaph of Jean de Renaud recounting the deeds of his military career.

label: LA VILLA GALLO ROMAINE
comment: We have reconstructed the villa GALLO ROMAINE, its close environment, but also its particularities.
shortDescription: We have reconstructed the villa GALLO ROMAINE, its close environment, but also its particularities.
description:
A Gallo-Roman villa dating from the first centuries AD has been uncovered in the Parc du Griffon
It was dependent on a larger villa, discovered near the Fontblanche estate and consisted of 3 rooms with sophisticated wall decoration.

label: La chapelle des Pénitents Blancs
description:
Currently Maurice Pezet Museum
Open from mid-March to mid-September Every Sunday and holidays

label: Place de Lenche
comment: It is one of the oldest sites in Marseille, one can even say that it was the center of ancient life since all archaeologists agree that the Agora des Massaliotes was located on the current site of the Place de Lenche.
shortDescription: It is one of the oldest sites in Marseille, one can even say that it was the center of ancient life since all archaeologists agree that the Agora des Massaliotes was located on the current site of the Place de Lenche.
description:
Moreover, the Rue Caisserie, which in an ancient world was called the Voie Décumane, and which was the main traffic axis in Marseille, ended at the Place de Lenche. Down below, on the south side, were discovered the buildings of the Abbey of Saint Sauveur, the women's monastery created in the 5th century by Saint Cassien. For a very long time, this place was called Saint Sauveur square.
 The northern part was occupied by a royal foundry created by Louis XII in 1507 but which, demolished in 1613, gave the square its almost current surface area. In spite of the presence of the Convent of Saint Sauveur and the old name of this square: place Saint Sauveur, it took the name of Lenche as early as the 16th century
Originally from Corsica, the Lenche family, as soon as they settled in Marseille, made an extremely advantageous and brilliant place for themselves as several of their members became consuls, and had their private mansion built and a coral workshop and shops set up there. The mansion now houses the Lenche theatre.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Blancs
description:
Chapel dating from the first quarter of the 17th century, with a typical late 17th century facade
It was used as a meeting place for the brotherhood of the Pénitents Blancs d'Alleins. They took care of social works and were used for funerals. All the social conditions of the Penitents were erased thanks to the uniform and the hood they wore. These brotherhoods still exist in some parishes.

label: Eglise Saint Jacques
comment: The eighteenth century building is located on the site of a medieval chapel placed under the same name. In 1740 the construction of a new church was entrusted to the Tarasconnais master Antoine Damour, according to the plans of the architect Jean-Baptiste Franque.
shortDescription: The eighteenth century building is located on the site of a medieval chapel placed under the same name. In 1740 the construction of a new church was entrusted to the Tarasconnais master Antoine Damour, according to the plans of the architect Jean-Baptiste Franque.
description:
The facade, in classical style, is made of Beaucaire stone.
Architectural description:
The baroque style was chosen for the ornamentation of the building, with a system of arches. The facade with its double lateral volutes is inspired in its composition by the Italian Baroque: it combines elements borrowed from ancient architecture-two pilasters with Ionic capitals frame the main portal, which is surmounted by a triangular pediment-and refined, finely worked decorative motifs-garlands of plants punctuate the upper part of the facade and emphasise the curves of the imposing oculus pierced above the door. The dome that caps the transept crossing, of daring conception, is a beautiful stereotomic work. The baldachin and the 18th century organs in Saint-Jacques come from the ursuline convent.

label: Esplanade du J4
comment: The esplanade J4 located between the fort Saint-Jean and the cathedral La Major, in edge of sea, it profits from a superb framework.
shortDescription: The esplanade J4 located between the fort Saint-Jean and the cathedral La Major, in edge of sea, it profits from a superb framework.
description:
The proximity of the Old Port, the A55 Littoral (and thus A51 North), and the A50 East via the Prado-Carénage tunnel makes it easily accessible.

It has become a place for urban walks, which offers to discover recent achievements. It invites you to discover the heritage of tomorrow, with the MuCEM and the Villa Méditerranée. 
Most of the buildings have been designed to host permanent or temporary exhibitions.

label: Eglise Sainte Rita
comment:
The church is dedicated to Rita de Cascia: it is a place of pilgrimage on May 22.
Masses on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10 am
Parish priest: Pierre Dumoulin
shortDescription:
The church is dedicated to Rita de Cascia: it is a place of pilgrimage on May 22.
Masses on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10 am
Parish priest: Pierre Dumoulin

label: Pont Van Gogh
comment:
Formerly called Langlois bridge
Period : XIXth century
Type: Public architecture : civil engineering
Status : Property of the Arles Tourist Office Classified as a historical monument (1988)
shortDescription:
Formerly called Langlois bridge
Period : XIXth century
Type: Public architecture : civil engineering
Status : Property of the Arles Tourist Office Classified as a historical monument (1988)
description: Named formerly bridge of Langlois time: 19th century Type: public Architecture: engineering status: property of the Tourist Office of the Arles class Monument historic (1988) the name of the staff member responsible to keep it and manipulate it, the 'bridge of Langlois' has acquired world fame through performances that made Van Gogh at the end of the 19th century. The bridge can be seen at a few kilometres south of the city centre, on the Arles to Bouc canal, isn't yet one painted by the artist. It is not more to its original location. The advances in technology, the evolution of urban planning and the vagaries of war made that we see today that an identical copy, once installed in Fos. However, the will of the painter, as well to restore an ancient technique, yielded to relocate the work in its functional integrity, and in a landscaped setting near that seen by Van Gogh. The book is a mobile bridge-type drawbridge: it means that the apron is pivoting on one end, connected by chains to one or two pieces in rocking, the arrows. The Langlois bridge is symmetrical and two decks of 4 metres in length allow a range of eight meters. This is the width of the channel, net of the abutments, part masonry which sets the book on the edge of the banks. The two aprons, ties, provide a width of four meters for the movement. The fixed parts on which the arrows rotate are assembled into a kind of porch of some five metres in height. Arrows, they measure 8.30 m. the major part of the book is wooden, except the abutments, lifting chains and metal parts mounting and Assembly.

label: Fontaine Calandalo
comment: Discover the historical fountain of Eyguières
shortDescription: Discover the historical fountain of Eyguières
description: The Calandalo fountain is used on the day of the toy fountain to collect games for the children.

label: LA PIERRE PLANTEE
comment: The Planted Stone stands prominently in the centre of the roundabout that bears its name, in the urban centre, in front of the bus station.
shortDescription: The Planted Stone stands prominently in the centre of the roundabout that bears its name, in the urban centre, in front of the bus station.
description:
This white limestone monolith (monument made of a single stone) is said to date back to prehistoric times. Its meaning remains unclear. Landmark, rallying point or burial stone?

The Planted Stone was discovered in the 1900s in the Hermes district and then moved to be erected at the entrance to the village, avenue Camille Pelletan, in the private garden of the current day hospital (villa Mélodie). It has been on its current location since 1996

The numerous plantades of this type already discovered in Provence, rooted in the earth and rising towards the sky, allow us to advance, in addition to the symbol of eternity, that they would be, according to their location, seasonal landmarks

This planted stone would have been erected by the Salyens, a Celto-Ligurian people who colonised the region between the Rhône and the Var around the second century BC

Unlike the Greeks of Massalia, the latter, to protect themselves from the Hellenic invasions, lived entrenched in the oppidums until the beginning of the pax Romana.
streetAddress: ['Centre ville - rond point de la Pierre plantée Gare routière Jean DUPAS', 'gare routière Jean Dupas']

label: Vieux village de Fuveau
description:
The old village of Fuveau stands proudly on a rocky outcrop facing the Sainte Victoire. The old quarters are clustered around the church of Saint Michel (19th c.), whose majestic facade is strongly inspired by the Italian Baroque style.
The medieval history of Fuveau is, nevertheless, always present, one of the last vestiges of this period is the Porte de Bassac, pierced in one of the 1.50m thick ramparts, which was the southern entrance to the village.
 We invite you to come and lose yourself in this maze of winding and shady streets typical of Provence, where you can discover a chapel, a breathtaking view of the Sainte Victoire...

label: Bibliothèque-Médiathèque Municipale de Bonneveine Léon G. Gros
comment: The Bonneveine media library is located in the heart of the southern districts on the site of the Bonneveine shopping centre.
shortDescription: The Bonneveine media library is located in the heart of the southern districts on the site of the Bonneveine shopping centre.
description:
As of Wednesday, May 19, 2021, Marseille's libraries will continue to welcome you but will adapt to the new sanitary measures linked to Covid-19 and will try to meet your expectations and needs as best as possible.

RECEPTION CONDITIONS

- Wearing a mask is compulsory for children aged 11 and over,

- Disabled people can be exempted from wearing a mask on presentation of a medical certificate,

- Hand washing with hydroalcoholic gel is compulsory, available to users,

- Respect for distancing,

- Respect for the directions of circulation in the spaces,

- Airing the conference room and the Alcazar auditorium for half an hour between each event.

SERVICES OFFERED

- Loan and return of documents in the libraries.

- Reopening of the document return terminals

- Click and collect in all open libraries:

Log on to the bmvr.marseille.fr website under the heading my account with your user number and your secret code (day + year of birth unless you have personalized it).

Choose the document you are interested in and click on reserve (on the right). The document must be available (DI) or on loan. You can reserve up to 5 documents. Choose the location of withdrawal.

When you receive a confirmation email with a deadline, your reservation is available!

- The external return boxes are available 24 hours a day in the Alcazar and La Grognarde libraries. The Castellane return box is available from 9am to 5pm from Tuesday to Friday and on Monday from 1pm to 5pm.

- Appointments can be made for consultation in the Rare and Precious Materials department at the following e-mail address: dgac-patrimoine-bmvr@marseille.fr, and at the Ile aux Livres at the following e-mail address: ileauxlivres-bmvr@marseille.fr.


THE FOLLOWING SERVICES ARE ONCE AGAIN AVAILABLE

- Consultation of the press,
- Consultation of documents on site,
- Access to computers,
- Access to the reprography service (computers and photocopiers),
- Staying on site.

CULTURAL PROGRAM
 
- The cultural program starts again on May 19th.

- Information on the program available on the website of the libraries and dedicated social networks,

 - Conferences filmed online on our Youtube channel.


OPENING HOURS AND CAPACITY OF THE LIBRARIES

Bonneveine Library

Tuesday to Saturday from 1pm to 6pm (except Saturday 22 May)

Simultaneous capacity: 100 people.

_______________________________________


The Bonneveine media library is located in the heart of the southern districts on the site of the Bonneveine shopping centre.

 Whether you have a little time between your shopping or a whole day to stroll, the team will be happy to welcome you and guide you in your research.  

 Video

Offer and services
more than 140,000 multi-media documents to discover - books, magazines, CDs, language methods, DVDs, readings
14 internet and office workstations.
wifi access in all areas.
online resources that can be consulted on site and remotely.
 
To discover
 
A space for the training of adults, students and candidates for competitive examinations, as well as a centre for secondary school students for tutoring


- Extracurricular collections from secondary school to higher education, general and professional subjects
- Annals of competitive examinations and methodological guides to prepare for the tests
- Works on orientation, careers, job hunting
- Language methods
- Seats for quiet work
- A wifi access to connect you
- A librarian to help you with your research

Online resources
Digital resources that can be consulted on site or from home

Tout apprendre.com
The Maxicours module includes courses from first grade to high school level, plus courses on vocational courses (CAP, BEP...) and to prepare for competitive exams. English, Japanese, Arabic, Indonesian... a large choice of online courses to learn languages

Vodeclic
Self-training site in video to new technologies. You will find tutorials and exercises on office automation, multimedia and computing. At your disposal, more than 10,000 training courses on more than 400 software and applications. And many other sites that can be consulted from the "digital resources" tab.

label: Plage privée de la brasserie Equinoxe
comment: The Equinoxe brewery offers every summer (from mid-May to mid-September) and every day access to its private sandy beach, with the rental of deckchairs, mattresses and parasols.
shortDescription: The Equinoxe brewery offers every summer (from mid-May to mid-September) and every day access to its private sandy beach, with the rental of deckchairs, mattresses and parasols.
description: Weekly package from Monday to Friday deckchair, mattress, parasol, salad, drink.

label: L'hôtel de ville
comment: Pertuis has had a town hall since the end of the 14th century. But it is in 1793 that the private mansion of the de Croze family became the town hall.
shortDescription: Pertuis has had a town hall since the end of the 14th century. But it is in 1793 that the private mansion of the de Croze family became the town hall.
description:
COMMUNAL INSTITUTION AND ANCIENT COMMON HOUSES
As early as 1251, the abbot of Montmajour, lord of Pertuis, granted the inhabitants the right to meet in "parliament" and to designate two notables or "estimators" to represent them. In 1380, they obtained the right to elect three syndics and ten annual advisors. But it is only in 1539 that the syndics will take the name of consuls
Under the Old Regime, the city had three "common houses" in succession. The exact location of the first one, close to the 14th century fortified enclosure, is unknown. The second was located near the former hospital of the Saint-Esprit, rue Saint-Jacques. It was exchanged in 1548 for a more spacious house on rue Saint-Nicolas (now rue Voltaire). The latter was destroyed in 1866, when the street was aligned, to clear the area around the new city hall.

THE CROZE MANSION
Originally from Les Mées, the de Croze family settled in Pertuis in the 16th century. Several of its members were "benefactors" for the city's poor. In 1705, Melchior de Croze founded the new Saint-Jacques hospital, today the Hospice, in the street that bears his name
The de Croze mansion was built at the end of the 17th and beginning of the 18th century, in the Saint-Nicolas district. Built on vaulted cellars of the 16th century, it consists of two wings in angle and a courtyard. The current City Council room, supported by two Tuscan columns, is decorated with gypseries typically XVIIIe.

THE NEW TOWN HALL : 1793
The private mansion of Croze is sequestered by the revolutionary Municipality: Joseph de Croze is at the top of the list of "Emigrants and traitors to the Fatherland" of the commune of Pertuis
He is accused, it seems wrongly, of having joined "Toulon, with the English and other troops enemies of the Republic". When he came back to Pertuis under the Consulate in 1803, he contested the occupation of his house. After long negotiations, the commune finally acquired the town hall in 1828.
At the beginning of the 20th century, it housed the police station, the town hall and the savings bank.
The facade and the current square date from a restoration in the 1970s.

THE COAT OF ARMS OF THE CITY OF PERTUIS
"Gold with a fess of gules (1), and a fleur-de-lys of azure passing among the said fess and inserted in it". These coats of arms were granted by Charles VIII, king of France, count of Provence and Forcalquier by Letters Patent, in October 1493: "in consideration of the good and ancient fidelity" of its inhabitants. With all power to use it in perpetuity in blazon, banners, standards, signs, doors and houses, and everywhere they want.

These coats of arms are nowadays the logo of the City

(1) fess: band cutting the shield; gules: red, in heraldic color.

label: Caserne Audéoud
comment: The Audéoud barracks is the Marseille-Aubagne defence base: it hosts 10 organisations and is the support base for the 3 army corps. Its territory of competence extends over the Southern region and part of the Occitanie region.
shortDescription: The Audéoud barracks is the Marseille-Aubagne defence base: it hosts 10 organisations and is the support base for the 3 army corps. Its territory of competence extends over the Southern region and part of the Occitanie region.
description:
450 soldiers and civilians occupy it all year round.
It houses the Allées du Souvenir, marble plaques engraved in memory of the 50,000 Provençal soldiers of the 15th Corps who died for France.

label: Eglise Saint Denys
comment: Romanesque style church.
shortDescription: Romanesque style church.
description:
Behind its 19th century façade, Saint Denis parish church conceals 
a great Romanesque nave and a beautiful Gothic chancel. In the side-naves, 
woodwork and paintings by Mignard adorn the
different altars of the rural brotherhoods. The eyes are drawn to the
bell tower, which was originally a 'watch tower'. Until the Revolution, the church, the only
important 'public space', was a place where
the public could come together. Its architecture follows
the town's demographic growth. This place
of worship, prayer and refuge in times of war, was also the site
of the first Republican elections! In 2008, the Chapel located
in Saint Denis Church was renovated; it contains statues
of the Three Marys surrounded by a pictorial landscape
relating the main events in the life of the Virgin.

label: Balade des familles
comment: Nice and safe walking route for cyclists and pedestrians. After crossing the Cadière near its mouth, the route follows the banks of the Bolmon pond and the Rove canal. A beautiful Camargue atmosphere for young and old!
shortDescription: Nice and safe walking route for cyclists and pedestrians. After crossing the Cadière near its mouth, the route follows the banks of the Bolmon pond and the Rove canal. A beautiful Camargue atmosphere for young and old!
description:
The family walk, a place of relaxation for all

It was built on the banks of the Bolmon pond and the banks of the Canal du Rove
You can walk in peace and quiet, cycle (2-lane cycle path) on access roads that have been completely redesigned and rehabilitated

Two areas have been created, one before the fishermen's village (former estuary of the river Cadière), the other in front of the so-called swan area on the banks of the Canal du Rove.
They allow a stop for contemplation in front of the pond or a moment of amusement for the little ones since children's playgrounds, totally protected, have been installed there
The family walk nowadays integrates the base of sports and leisure activities

2 accesses: a car park, avenue Edmond Rostand in front of the covered tennis courts of the Bolmon, the other chemin de l'Esteou (canal du Rove), close to the Esteou sports and leisure base,

You can download on the Tourist Office website a circuit sheet as well as a fun observation questionnaire.
streetAddress: ['Avenue Edmond Rostand', 'Parking face au tennis couvert du Bolmon']

label: Eglise Saint Pierre
comment:
St. Peter's Church was built between 1786 and 1790 on the site of an old church that had become too small and unstable because of the clay soil
The place of worship was enlarged by the annexation of two houses located near the old church.
shortDescription:
St. Peter's Church was built between 1786 and 1790 on the site of an old church that had become too small and unstable because of the clay soil
The place of worship was enlarged by the annexation of two houses located near the old church.
description:
Two bells still punctuate the life of the village, the first one is stamped with the year 1634, the second one named Joséphine Léoni dates back to 1891. The godfather of this bell is Paul Léon and the godmother is Joséphine Penon, benefactors of the church.

The church has a very rich liturgical furnishings including seven works of art protected as Historic Monuments. The nave is decorated with altarpieces, paintings, statues and other works of art from the 17th to the 20th century

The church is open to the public by appointment or during ceremonies.

label: Square Mauron (parc pour enfant)
description: Square / games for children

label: Parc des 7 Collines - Château de la Buzine
comment: Four hectares for outdoor relaxation!
shortDescription: Four hectares for outdoor relaxation!
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


La Buzine castle owes its fame to Marcel Pagnol. Having bought it with the project of opening a real cinema city, the writer was surprised when he arrived on the spot to recognize the building he used to walk along with his family on the chemin de la Treille, and which would become - and remain forever - "Le Château de ma mère" (My mother's castle) in the second volume of his "Souvenirs of childhood".

The castle was listed as a historical monument in 1996. Today it attracts tens of thousands of visitors who appreciate the style and materials of the building, and its wide range of events, animations and activities, for all tastes and ages. It is the headquarters of the Maison des cinématographies de la Méditerranée. As such, La Buzine has a modern cinema that meets the latest technical standards.

But the dark room of the castle, however pleasant it may be, opens onto a park which alone deserves a visit to La Buzine and a walk in the green setting of the "jewel" that made Augustine Pagnol dream while walking along the canal.

The initial park of the castle covered 40 hectares from which one could see the 7 hills (according to Joseph Méry's count) surrounding Marseille. It offered greenery, freshness, fruits and vegetables to the inhabitants of the castle who stayed away from the miasma of the city. After the sale of the estate, the City of Marseille kept 4 hectares of parkland around the castle, which it had completely restored. South-facing, sheltered from the wind and facing the St-Cyr mountain range, the Buzine park has several remarkable original features.

The park is an Ecojardin labeled Jardin de Noé. Its particularity is to be a natural space in which the hand of man must be as light as possible. The disciples of Le Nôtre are not at work here. It is the sky that provides the watering. The mowing is late and those that are declared "weeds" elsewhere have a right to live in this landscape. Shredded bark and vegetation are placed at the foot of the trees. As you move away from the castle, nature is left more and more to its imagination. There is therefore a real fauna.

label: Château de Roussan
description:
This château is located at the western exit from Saint Rémy de Provence, on the road to Tarascon.
Its first known owner was Captain Bertrand de Nostredame, brother of Michel de Nostredame.
The Mas de Roussan was later transformed by Melchior- Jacques de Joanis, (adviser to the King), husband of his grand-daughter Thomine de Nostredame, and became the current château.
The park was redeveloped in the 19th century, using the former Roman aqueduct that brought water from Eygalières to Arles.
The Château de Roussan has become an exceptional tourist hotel, whose clientèle should be respected.
A restaurant is open for lunch and dinner.

label: Eglise et clocher triangulaire de l'Observance
comment: Of the 17th century church built by the Observantine fathers, only the chapel of the Observance and its triangular bell tower remain.
shortDescription: Of the 17th century church built by the Observantine fathers, only the chapel of the Observance and its triangular bell tower remain.
description: The Observance triangular bell-tower : built at the end of the XVIIth century.

label: Musée des amis de Castrum Vetus
comment: The mansion of Seytres-Caumont, the last lords of Châteauneuf-les-Martigues, houses the museum of the Friends of Vetus Castrum.
shortDescription: The mansion of Seytres-Caumont, the last lords of Châteauneuf-les-Martigues, houses the museum of the Friends of Vetus Castrum.
description:
This is a collection concerning the prehistoric, Celto-Ligurian and Gallo-Roman periods, objects found during excavations on the Grand Abri site of Font de Pigeons.
Several rooms contain archaeological treasures (scrapers, ceramics, polished axes), others Gallo-Roman remains (oil lamps, various coins).
A room for local geology, another dedicated to the lords of the city with family trees and coats of arms (1150 to 1789).
The Chapel of the Marquis de Seytres Caumont dates from the 17th century.
Surface of the permanent exhibition: 250 square meters.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Blancs
description:
The " Penitents Blancs " Church (White Penitents) : built in 1772.
The statues of Saint Peter and Saint Paul can be found on its frontage.

label: Place Lulli
description:
Place Lulli owes its name to the composer and musician of the court of Louis XIV, who is sometimes played in the opera.
The square is home to trendy ready-to-wear and decoration boutiques, cafés and restaurants.
At its centre since 2013 is the Opéra Noir, a sculptural work by the artists Berdaguer and Péjus, and the setting for a variety of one-off shows.

label: Archives communales
description: Ensure the collection, processing, preservation, communication and the development of documents from the local administration to guarantee rights of the community and individuals and for the safeguarding of the memory of the commune: including civil status, the deliberations of the City Council, the cadastre, but also the complete collection of official newspapers, as well as maps and plans, posters, photographs.The consultation of archives is free and cannotbe place.Inscription on presentation of proof of identity and by subscribing to the rules of procedure. A specialized library on the history of Arles and Provence is available to the public.Genealogists can consult in the form of microfilm collection of parish registers of Arles since the 16th century (current counting file).The Archives preserve civil status more of 100 years (existence of decadal tables). Possibilities of research by correspondence under certain conditions. Organization of exhibitions, conferences, Director of publications and participation in the heritage days. Paleography courses: to learn how to decipher the ancient texts, the service organizes sessions initiation and development in Palaeography: Paleography modern for beginners (16th to 18th centuries) and confirmed
streetAddress: ['Espace Van Gogh, 1er étage', 'Rue Du Président Wilson']

label: Obélisque
comment: Built by Pinchaud under Napoleon 1st who had put them in fashion after his campaign in Egypt. It used to be on the Place Castellane from where it was moved in one block.
shortDescription: Built by Pinchaud under Napoleon 1st who had put them in fashion after his campaign in Egypt. It used to be on the Place Castellane from where it was moved in one block.

label: Eglise de Vauvenargues
comment: Built on a primitive church of the 5th century, it was rebuilt in the 10th century, from which its Romanesque part came, then in the 16th century with the addition of the side chapels.
shortDescription: Built on a primitive church of the 5th century, it was rebuilt in the 10th century, from which its Romanesque part came, then in the 16th century with the addition of the side chapels.
description: Constructed on a primitive church of the 5th century, it was redesigned in the 10th century from which its Romanesque part is derived, then in the 16th century with the addition of lateral chapels. Originally placed under the protection of Saint Sidonius, the first archbishop of Aix-en-Provence, it is currently dedicated to Saint Etienne and Sainte Victoire. Although not visible from the village because of its encashment, it enjoys a magnificent view of the massif of Sainte-Victoire and the castle thanks to a charming belvedere located in front of the court. It contains 9 ex-voto of the nineteenth century.

label: Oppidum de St Pierre les Martigues
comment: Facsimile of mud-brick houses from the iron age, stone quarries and medieval chapels.
shortDescription: Facsimile of mud-brick houses from the iron age, stone quarries and medieval chapels.
description: On the knoll in the centre of the farmed plain, vestiges of the habitat and fortifications of a Gallic oppidum and a Gallo-Roman town (600BC to 100AD) where a population of peasants and fishermen had close ties with Marseille.

label: Château de Bouc Bel Air
comment: The castle of Bouc Bel Air was built in the 8th century to resist the Saracen invasions, on a rock at 279 m.
shortDescription: The castle of Bouc Bel Air was built in the 8th century to resist the Saracen invasions, on a rock at 279 m.
description: The castle is mentioned as early as 997 in an act and in many charters of the cartouche of the St Victor Abbey. It was an important fortified post between Aix and Marseilles which collected a toll fee, reported in 1420 in the archives. The medieval character so clearly preserved in the castle is found in the old village huddled in the shade of the fortress. The narrow and winding streets on the side of the rock are lined with irregular houses, not aligned with the roofs uncoupled, the second floor low. They have picturesque names: the Barri, the Pie, the Virgin ... The castle is now owned by the municipality and many events are organized in its beautiful vaulted rooms.

label: Bibliothèque municipale de Mimet
comment: Take advantage of the books available at the Mimet public library
shortDescription: Take advantage of the books available at the Mimet public library
description: Novels, comics, poetry, theatre... there's something for everyone!

label: Square Frédéric Mistral
comment: Relaxation area, near the Cadière river, in homage to Frédéric Mistral, the poet founder of the Félibrige.
shortDescription: Relaxation area, near the Cadière river, in homage to Frédéric Mistral, the poet founder of the Félibrige.
description:
The Frédéric Mistral square is located in the heart of the city, at the top of the Cours Mirabeau and at the corner of boulevard Frédéric Mistral and rue Lamartine

It offers a small space for relaxation on the banks of the Cadière River, while marking the entrance to a very old medieval district already devoted to gardens and winegrowing, the Via Clausa, now rue Lamartine. Approximately opposite, on the present-day Place du 11 Novembre, the large grape crusher, also of medieval origin, known as the "Trulhat", certainly extended

Redesigned in 2018, the square is now embellished with a bench, resting chairs, and a dozen Mediterranean plant species participate in the landscaping of the river

The old stele dedicated to Frédéric Mistral, a tribute to the poet founder of the Félibrige, has found a new place there, where commemorations in his honour are now held, organised by the Provençal associations of the commune.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Calvaire
comment: Calvary located in the middle of the pines, halfway up the hill where the Golden Virgin is erected.
shortDescription: Calvary located in the middle of the pines, halfway up the hill where the Golden Virgin is erected.
description:
There are six crosses in the local countryside. They are the Croix de Piquette, the Croix de l’Oratoire, the Croix de la Mâtarde, the Croix du Mas de Cartier, the Croix Rouge and the Croix de la Crau. They were erected during the second half of the 19th century and some of them have recently been restored.
The following crosses are located in the town: the Croix du Rond Point (at the intersection of Bd Gambetta and Bd Jules Ferry and Avenue Général de Gaulle and Avenue Trouillet) was erected in 1865. The Croix de l’Ancien Calvaire is on Rue de l’Ancien Calvaire, near the Oratory of St Eloi.
A large cross, known as the Croix du Jubilé, was erected circa 1836 in the first plot of the cemetery. It dates from 1875. According to the Book of Leviticus and the Law of Moses, a Jubilee year is dedicated to God. There is no sowing or harvesting, debts and sold assets are cancelled and slaves are freed. It occurs every 50 years. The tradition of a Jubilee year was abandoned during Antiquity; in the Middle Ages, however, Pope Boniface VIII established a holy year in 1300 and forgave the sins of the pilgrims to the Basilicas of the Apostles in Rome.
Near the Monument to the Dead is a Cross from the 1956 Mission.
1844 Calvary
Until the 1950s, a Way of the Cross led from the church to the Calvary. This Calvary, erected in 1844, consists of a monumental cross on top of a large stone base. This representation of the passion of Christ is located in the middle of a pine groves, half-way up the hill. The Way of the Cross provided easy access to the Calvary; from there, it is possible to climb up to the Golden Virgin.

label: Place aux Huiles
comment: On the site of the Arsenal des Galères installed by Louis XIV, there is now a large Italian-style pedestrian square designed and lit by the architect Charlie Bové, inaugurated in 1988.
shortDescription: On the site of the Arsenal des Galères installed by Louis XIV, there is now a large Italian-style pedestrian square designed and lit by the architect Charlie Bové, inaugurated in 1988.
description: It is lined with restaurants, various stores and piano bars.

label: Site médiéval de l'Hauture
comment: On its tabular plateau, perched 32m high, overlooking the sea, the salt marshes and the entrance to the Etang de Berre, the castrum of Fossis, mentioned as early as 923, acts as a sentinel and a point of attachment at the gates of the Camargue and its marshes.
shortDescription: On its tabular plateau, perched 32m high, overlooking the sea, the salt marshes and the entrance to the Etang de Berre, the castrum of Fossis, mentioned as early as 923, acts as a sentinel and a point of attachment at the gates of the Camargue and its marshes.
description: If it currently retains only an enclosure with a parapet walk, two towers and two gates to the north and south, all dating from the end of the 12th century, written sources attest that in the Middle Ages the castle had many seigneurial buildings, with residential, economic or military function. The quality of its defences as well as its silhouette, proud and haughty as its lords, may have made people write about it "the castel fort is so strongly batillié,... will only take it those who are in heaven"!

label: Maison Sainte Victoire
comment: The Sainte-Victoire House is a reception and information centre designed to make visitors aware of the fragility of our environment.
shortDescription: The Sainte-Victoire House is a reception and information centre designed to make visitors aware of the fragility of our environment.
description:
Its exhibition room and its discovery trail offer to all the public, tourists, schoolchildren and other hikers an active discovery of a heritage whose protection thus becomes everyone's business
Museographic space, conference area, relaxation area, exhibition room, are available to a wide public, schoolchildren and other visitors sensitive to environmental protection.
The Sainte Victoire House organizes free hikes, accompanied by eco-guides, on the departmental domains. Walks or donkey rides.
Surface of the temporary exhibition : 100

label: Arènes Chomel Coinon
description: Capacity: + 500 pax. Performances: bullfights, Bulls, Camargue Olympics races, races of little cows.

label: Hôtel de Caumont - Centre d'Art
comment: The Hôtel de Caumont is one of the rare urban residences in Aix "between courtyard and garden" which, by reminding us of castles in the middle of their parks, allowed their owners to show their aristocracy.
shortDescription: The Hôtel de Caumont is one of the rare urban residences in Aix "between courtyard and garden" which, by reminding us of castles in the middle of their parks, allowed their owners to show their aristocracy.
description:
A new art center opens in one of the most beautiful eighteenth century mansions in Aix-en-Provence.

As of May 6, 2015, the Caumont Art Centre presents an ambitious cultural program putting the fine arts in the spotlight.

Located close to the Cours Mirabeau, it is currently undergoing a complete restoration that will restore it to its former glory. Visitors will discover two annual exhibitions dedicated to the great masters of the past as well as to contemporary artists.

A film on Cezanne's life in Aix screened daily, as well as concerts and lectures will complement the programming of the Hôtel de Caumont that aims at becoming a major cultural center in Aix: a place where we discover and share art with passion. Broadcasting from 10.25am to 4.55pm, every 30 minutes.

The tea room and gardens offer a haven of peace in the heart of the Mazarin district.

On the ground floor, learn more about the Arts Centre and its exhibitions in the book and culture shop. It has the same opening times as the Art Centre.

The Art Centre provides two wheelchairs that cannot be booked in advance.

label: La Chapelle Immaculée Conception d'Entressen
comment: The Entressen Chapel, also known as the Chapel of the Immaculate Conception, has for several years hosted the Printemps des Poètes, a literary and poetic event. Exhibitions are also staged there.
shortDescription: The Entressen Chapel, also known as the Chapel of the Immaculate Conception, has for several years hosted the Printemps des Poètes, a literary and poetic event. Exhibitions are also staged there.
description: The chapel of Entressen, also referred to as the chapel of the Immaculate Conception, welcomes the spring of poets, literary and poetic event for several years. It is also a place of exhibition.It is located near the Town Hall annex, on the Avenue de la Crau.

label: Parc de la Colline Saint-Joseph
comment: St. Joseph's Hill is a vast, well-wooded natural area, rich in pedestrian paths and much appreciated by the residents of the large residential complexes that surround it.
shortDescription: St. Joseph's Hill is a vast, well-wooded natural area, rich in pedestrian paths and much appreciated by the residents of the large residential complexes that surround it.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.


Acquired by the City in 1977, with the exception of the chapel and its immediate surroundings, St. Joseph's Hill is a vast, well-treed natural area, rich in pedestrian walkways and much appreciated by the residents of the large residential complexes that surround it. Developed as a green space, the hill has been equipped with children's playgrounds. The existing paths were improved and new ones were created. Rest areas were also created to allow walkers to enjoy a shaded rest area. Finally, this area naturally lent itself to the creation of a sports trail. A facility that has met with great success.

label: Salles d'exposition des Outils Anciens
description:
The museum of tools presents the collection of Paul Tamisier, given by his heirs, patiently collected at flea markets, you will find the tools classified by profession: the ironing machine, the clog maker....The objects are highlighted with explanatory cards or panels.
By appointment only

label: Bibliothèque du métro Castellane
comment: Opened in 1990, the Castellane library is located in an unexpected place: the Marseilles metro station
shortDescription: Opened in 1990, the Castellane library is located in an unexpected place: the Marseilles metro station
description:
As of Wednesday, May 19, 2021, Marseille's libraries will continue to welcome you but will adapt to the new sanitary measures linked to Covid-19 and will try to meet your expectations and needs as best as possible.

RECEPTION CONDITIONS

- Wearing a mask is compulsory for children aged 11 and over,

- Disabled people can be exempted from wearing a mask on presentation of a medical certificate,

- Hand washing with hydroalcoholic gel is compulsory, available to users,

- Respect for distancing,

- Respect for the directions of circulation in the spaces,

- Airing the conference room and the Alcazar auditorium for half an hour between each event.

SERVICES OFFERED

- Loan and return of documents in the libraries.

- Reopening of the document return terminals

- Click and collect in all open libraries:

Log on to the bmvr.marseille.fr website under the heading my account with your user number and your secret code (day + year of birth unless you have personalized it).

Choose the document you are interested in and click on reserve (on the right). The document must be available (DI) or on loan. You can reserve up to 5 documents. Choose the location of withdrawal.

When you receive a confirmation email with a deadline, your reservation is available!

- The external return boxes are available 24 hours a day in the Alcazar and La Grognarde libraries. The Castellane return box is available from 9am to 5pm from Tuesday to Friday and on Monday from 1pm to 5pm.

- Appointments can be made for consultation in the Rare and Precious Materials department at the following e-mail address: dgac-patrimoine-bmvr@marseille.fr, and at the Ile aux Livres at the following e-mail address: ileauxlivres-bmvr@marseille.fr.


THE FOLLOWING SERVICES ARE ONCE AGAIN AVAILABLE

- Consultation of the press,
- Consultation of documents on site,
- Access to computers,
- Access to the reprography service (computers and photocopiers),
- Staying on site.

CULTURAL PROGRAM
 
- The cultural program starts again on May 19th,

- Information on the program available on the website of the libraries and dedicated social networks,

 - Conferences filmed online on our Youtube channel.


OPENING HOURS AND CAPACITY OF THE LIBRARIES

Castellane Library

Monday, Tuesday and Thursday from 1pm to 6pm.
Wednesday and Friday from 10am to 1pm and from 2pm to 6pm

Return box: Monday from 1pm to 5pm and Tuesday to Friday from 9am to 5pm
Capacity: 3 persons at the same time.

_________________________________


Opened in 1990, the Castellane library is located in an unexpected place: the Marseilles metro station. Thanks to its central location and the Metro/Tramway connection, the library not only serves the inhabitants of the district, but also attracts a wider public.

The library was completely renovated in 2020 with a more user-friendly youth area. For adults, the new layout gives pride of place to fiction, without forgetting documentaries, focused on everyday life.

Although it is the smallest library in the network, it offers a varied collection of 15,000 documents, regularly updated: 10,000 books for adults and children, 2,000 DVDs, 2,500 CDs and 26 periodical titles.

label: Croix du Mas de la Croix
comment: Cross of the Mas de la Croix in Noves.
shortDescription: Cross of the Mas de la Croix in Noves.
description:
The cross at the intersection of the Route des Paluds and the Chemin de l'Eau is of unknown origin. It gave its name to the Mas on the edge of which it is located. It is a very beautiful and sombre stone monument, whose motifs have been eroded, and was listed as a national Historic Monument in 1922.
Architectural description
Stone cross with bas relief symbols engraved at the intersection of the hexagonal branches. It rests on a small column, which is also hexagonal, with a square base. A bas relief figure can be made out on the front and back of the central part of the cross.

label: Réserve naturelle de Sainte Victoire
comment: The nature reserve is located to the west of the Montagne Sainte Victoire, in the Departmental Park of Roques Hautes. It is 140 hectares protected and forbidden to the public since 1994.
shortDescription: The nature reserve is located to the west of the Montagne Sainte Victoire, in the Departmental Park of Roques Hautes. It is 140 hectares protected and forbidden to the public since 1994.
description:
It is one of the 10 sites in the world where dinosaur eggs, dating from the end of the Cretaceous, are preserved. They are fossilized in red clay and sandstone, which is very fragile and sensitive to erosion, hence the protection prohibiting access to the deposit.

In addition, habitats of protected species have been identified within the perimeter of the reserve. For more information on the environment, fauna and flora, the Maison du Grand Site Sainte Victoire and its museum area welcomes you to Saint Antonin sur Bayon.

label: Rue des Juifs
description:
The Rue des Juifs, once called the 'Rue droite des Juifs' and now known as 'Rue du Château' marks the entrance to Tarascon's old Jewish district.
Almost 300 people lived in this part of town in the Middle Ages.
The community, which was clustered together in the Jewish district, the 'carreria judayca', had two cemeteries outside the town (one on Jarnègues Island, on the current Boulevard Itam, and the other in the Les Ferrages district after the Porte Condamine). It also had a synagogue located near the ramparts with an entrance on the Rue droite des Juifs. It was both a place of worship and a meeting place for the Jewish Council. The building had one floor and contained a ritual bath. The exact location of the synagogue has not yet been found.
In the 15th century, urban Judaism was at a steady level and experienced its last period of relative tolerance during the time of King René. After the death of the monarch, the atmosphere in this now French province (1481) deteriorated, announcing the end of the communities (1500-1501).
There is evidence of Jews in Tarascon from 1150. The surname of some Tarascon Jews reveals their Langue d'Oc origins. Their ancestors must have fled the Kingdom of France during the expulsion in 1306 and they took the name of villages in the Nîmes and Montpellier regions, e.g. Jacob de Lunel, Isaac de Lattes, etc.)
In the 15th century, urban Judaism was at a steady level and experienced its last period of relative tolerance during the time of King René. After the death of the monarch, the atmosphere in this now French province (1481) deteriorated, announcing the end of the communities (1500-1501).

label: Jardin du Château de Roussan
description: The 18th century with a beautiful English-style park greenhouse of the 19th century, parts of water and fountains. Exceptional visits.

label: Viaduc du TGV Méditerrannée
description: A work of art from the end of the 20th century, the TGV viaduct is a technological and aesthetic feat that brings the village of Vernègues into the third millennium.
