label: Chapelle Notre Dame du Rouet
description:
The commune of Carry-le-Rouet is located on the "Côte bleue", a marvellous limestone massif carved out of a succession of creeks and calanques to the north-west of Marseille. To the east of Carry, between the beach of Le Rouet and the calanque des Eaux-Salées, the Cap de la Vierge is a triangular promontory which dominates the sea from the top of a cliff. In the middle of this area planted with a pine forest, the Notre-Dame-du-Rouet chapel was built to replace another older one that had existed since the time of the Saracens. This first construction was then called "chapel of despair" because the inhabitants came to take refuge there in case of attack by Moorish pirates (805-905).

 The foundations of this first building still remain, visible on the edge of the cliff forty metres north-west of the present one. The oldest reference that speaks of it is a document from 1253, which states that it belonged to the Abbey of Saint-Victor. The abbey also had a herd of sheep on the site, whose income was used to maintain the chapel. The chapel is still mentioned in 1278, 1290, 1302 and 1370. In 1302, under the name of "Rot" or "Rouet", the place was used for the surveillance of the coast organized by the great seneschal with the help of signals.
Every year, on 8 September, for the feast of the Nativity, the blessing of the sea and the boats is celebrated there.

label: Hôtel de Cabre
comment: Cabre's hotel is a curiosity. Built in 1535 for Louis de Cabre, alderman of Marseille, this private house is one of the oldest in Marseille.
shortDescription: Cabre's hotel is a curiosity. Built in 1535 for Louis de Cabre, alderman of Marseille, this private house is one of the oldest in Marseille.
description:
A mix of Gothic and Renaissance styles, it borders the Grand' Rue. Spared by the destruction of 1943, the hotel avoided demolition two years later when the street was enlarged. It was moved in one piece on hydraulic jacks and turned 90° to be aligned with the streets.

It is not open to the public.

label: Fort de Corbière
comment: Beach and public garden, from where the view over the bay of Marseille is remarkable. The present battery dates from the Second Empire, but as early as the 17th century, another construction, now disappeared, housed six cannons and two mortars.
shortDescription: Beach and public garden, from where the view over the bay of Marseille is remarkable. The present battery dates from the Second Empire, but as early as the 17th century, another construction, now disappeared, housed six cannons and two mortars.

label: Temple de l'église protestante unie de Grignan
comment: The constant increase of the Protestant community explains the construction of this temple. It dates from 1824 and was built by M.R.Penchaud.
shortDescription: The constant increase of the Protestant community explains the construction of this temple. It dates from 1824 and was built by M.R.Penchaud.
description:
The building is built on a basilical plan closed by an apse and whose façade is a Doric order portico. On either side of the nave a Doric colonnade and a flat coffered ceiling are the interior fittings of the temple
The organ case and the instrumental part were made by the Kern establishments in Strasbourg in 1982.
The service is at 10:30 am on Sundays, except July and August when it is at 11 am.

label: Mx espace musée
comment: An immersive museum space, the Mx Experience, offers a discovery tour around aniseed.
shortDescription: An immersive museum space, the Mx Experience, offers a discovery tour around aniseed.
description:
This museum offers a cultural and sensory experience that cannot be found anywhere else. Designed around a spice and a flavor, aniseed, which is inseparable from the DNA of the city of Marseille, Mx Experience is a mix of fun and knowledge, in which you are the main actor. Interaction is at the heart of the experience: open digital drawers, smell the ingredients, leaf through a virtual book and handle vials..
Workshops are organized around gastronomy and cocktails. The Mx is truly a multi-sensory experience!
streetAddress: ['10 place de la Joliette', 'Les Docks Village']

label: Médiathèque du Clocher
comment: Media library of Verquières.
shortDescription: Media library of Verquières.
description: Media library connected to the BDP network; free Internet access. Loan of books, periodicals, CDs and DVDs.

label: Chapelle Saint-Jean de Mélissane
comment: The oldest rural chapel of Fuveau stands, sober and isolated, in the fields on the edge of the old bed of the Arc, charged with a rich past, despite its very modest appearance and despite its multiple mutilations and transformations.
shortDescription: The oldest rural chapel of Fuveau stands, sober and isolated, in the fields on the edge of the old bed of the Arc, charged with a rich past, despite its very modest appearance and despite its multiple mutilations and transformations.
description:
Exterior visit. From the 12th or 13th century. Under its most modest appearances, this venerable Romanesque chapel seems forgotten and ignored by passing motorists without even noticing it, despite its long history.
We know that the Knights Templar (12th-13th centuries) owned land here, and they were probably the builders of this Romanesque chapel. Contrary to the other places of worship in the valley, this important priory, attested since the 14th century in various acts, did not depend on the abbey of Saint Victor, but on that of Montmajour (bishopric of Arles). Its influence continued from the Middle Ages to the 17th century.
Open on Heritage Days and during events organised by the Cercle St Michel.

label: Base des loisirs de l'Esteou
comment: The Base des Loisirs is a beautiful landscaped park of 6.6 hectares located on the edge of the town and close to natural environments (Bolmon pond, Rove canal, Palun marsh). It harmoniously combines vegetated areas and sports activities.
shortDescription: The Base des Loisirs is a beautiful landscaped park of 6.6 hectares located on the edge of the town and close to natural environments (Bolmon pond, Rove canal, Palun marsh). It harmoniously combines vegetated areas and sports activities.
description:
The Esteou sports and leisure centre covers a 6.6 hectare plot of land on the banks of the Rove canal and the Bolmon lake, with two different atmospheres based on the topography of the site

- A protected and landscaped natural area located near the shore of the pond of Bolmon. The tranquil area enhances the natural character of the pond, with a viewpoint on the existing promontory and a landscaped walkway. The plant species characteristic of Mediterranean wetlands are highlighted.

- A leisure and entertainment area (the largest skate park in France and the most technical in Europe (3000m2) and many tracks for skateboarding, rollerblading, BMX, mountain biking ... and games for children.

It is a peaceful place in a natural environment of quality which aims to facilitate the meeting between several publics. The town has rediscovered its past where hunting and fishing activities took place

To note more specifically 
- a 200 m2 viewpoint that allows you to admire the 360-degree panorama of the Bolmon pond, the Jaï dune line and the surrounding hills,
- paths with information panels on the geography, flora, fauna, history..
- a walkway (wooden decking) overhanging the Rove canal with an explanation of the Petite Camargue of Marignane on the opposite bank,
- and an area for the contemplation of swans.

label: Le Géant de Provence
comment: The plane tree "Giant of Provence" is classified as a natural monument of artistic character, and is part of the Remarkable Trees of France. This oriental plane tree is also the largest in Europe!
shortDescription: The plane tree "Giant of Provence" is classified as a natural monument of artistic character, and is part of the Remarkable Trees of France. This oriental plane tree is also the largest in Europe!
description:
Next to the castle of Lamanon, you can admire a three hundred year old plane tree classified as a natural monument, nicknamed "Le Géant de Provence" (53 meters high, 8 meters in circumference).
Two versions are shared: planted around 1658 by Diane de Roux de Lamanon to celebrate the baptism of her daughter, or planted in 1564 by Catherine de Medici ... you choose!

The tree is on a private property, you can see it from the street, at the intersection between the D23 and the Grand Rue de Lamanon.

label: La Barasse
comment: La Barasse in Marseille is an area of 700 ha of hills above the Huveaune valley, between the Massif de St Cyr-Carpiagne, St Menet, St Marcel and La Valentine.
shortDescription: La Barasse in Marseille is an area of 700 ha of hills above the Huveaune valley, between the Massif de St Cyr-Carpiagne, St Menet, St Marcel and La Valentine.
description:
It is the starting point of many paths with "Pagnolesque" landscapes, up to the summit of Carpiagne (600m) from where you can see the whole Etoile chain.

Management of natural areas: Domaine du Conseil Général

label: Parc Henri Fabre
comment: Located at the end of the boulevard de Gabès, behind the dance school, the Henri Fabre park is a space made up of large expanses of lawn and natural copses.
shortDescription: Located at the end of the boulevard de Gabès, behind the dance school, the Henri Fabre park is a space made up of large expanses of lawn and natural copses.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.



Located at the end of the boulevard de Gabès, behind the dance school, the Henri Fabre park is a space made up of large expanses of lawn and natural groves. This place frequented by families and bowlers is also a natural playground for the future Zidane of the district. The development of a pedestrian path along the banks of the Huveaune River, between Michelet Boulevard and the entrance to Borély Park, reinforces the vocation of Henri Fabre Park as a place dedicated to walking.

label: Plage du Ranquet
comment: The Ranquet beach stretches over 1,850 m2 in the south-east of the town of Istres, a strong element of the district, its development and that of its immediate surroundings reinforce the family identity of the site.
shortDescription: The Ranquet beach stretches over 1,850 m2 in the south-east of the town of Istres, a strong element of the district, its development and that of its immediate surroundings reinforce the family identity of the site.
description:
A supervised beach on the Etang de Berre with facilities for a moment of relaxation and idleness much appreciated.

The facilities 
- Picnic areas
- floating platform anchored at 2.5m depth for bathers
- Accessibility and parking for the disabled
- first aid station and autonomous sanitary facilities
 
Supervised swimming from June 18 to September 11.

This summer, from 12:00 to 18:00 on weekdays and from 12:00 to 20:00 on weekends, access the beach by electric tuk tuk (free)

label: Château de Vauvenargues
comment:
Pablo Picasso bought the property in 1958 and painted some of his famous paintings there. The illustrious artist was buried there in 1973.
The Château de Vauvenargues remains a private property
shortDescription:
Pablo Picasso bought the property in 1958 and painted some of his famous paintings there. The illustrious artist was buried there in 1973.
The Château de Vauvenargues remains a private property
description: Flanked by two towers of the 14th century and surrounded by a 16th century wall, the property belonged in 1257 to the archbishops of Aix. Its history, linked to that of Provence, passes by King René in 1473, who then yields his land to his doctor Pierre Robin d'Angers. The families of Cabanis, Jarente and Séguiran owned the castle until 1548, when, through the marriage of Marguerite de Séguiran and François de Clapiers, it passed to the Clapiers. Under the impulse of Henri de Clapiers, lord of Vauvenargues, first consul of Aix and procurator of the Pays de Provence in 1674, important works modify the medieval stronghold of the castle and give it its current configuration, taking seated on the Outcrop of the rocky peak as well as the strong walls that will be preserved. In 1722 Joseph de Clapiers saw his lands erected as a marquisate for services rendered during the Great Plague of 1720. And it was the third Marquis of Vauvenargues who sold the castle in 1790 to the Isoard family, whose coats of arms are still visible today On the ramparts and facades of the building. Inside, in a drawing-room still velvet, remains the portrait of Cardinal d'Isoard. In 1943, the estate was sold by Simone Marguerite d'Isoard Vauvenargues to three Marseilles industrialists. It was then transformed into a holiday camp for the children of the merchant navy personnel (a few parasitic installations remained of this period), and then sold in 1954 to the civil society Société Agricole du domaine de Vauvenargues. Pablo Picasso bought the property in 1958 and painted some of his famous paintings. The illustrious artist was buried there in 1973. The castle of Vauvenargues remains a private property.

label: Médiathèque municipale Pablo Neruda
description:
Free registration on simple presentation:
An identity document.
Proof of address.
A parental authorization for children under 14 years old.
Access and consultation of the documents on site are free.
Computerized documentary research.
Free Internet access on presentation of the membership card.

label: Théâtre Antique
comment:
Date: End of the 1st century BC
Period: Ancient times
Type: Public Culture Architecture
Status: Property of the City of Arles Listed as a Historical Monument (1840), Unesco World Heritage Site (1981).
shortDescription:
Date: End of the 1st century BC
Period: Ancient times
Type: Public Culture Architecture
Status: Property of the City of Arles Listed as a Historical Monument (1840), Unesco World Heritage Site (1981).
description:
The Roman Theatre of Arles, which preceded its famous neighbour the amphitheatre by a century, is less well preserved.
Constructed at the end of the 1st century BC, it dates from the first phase of urbanisation of the Roman colony founded by Caesar in 46 BC.
It was built on the L'Hauture hill and was part of the Roman grid system, on the decumanus (East-West road).
It was fortified in the Middle Ages and lost to encroaching construction work; its material was often reused for neighbouring buildings. Even the original function of the monument is unknown.
This function was rediscovered in the late 17th century and its origin was confirmed over the following centuries thanks to a number of archaeological finds excavated from the ground, including the famous 'Venus of Arles'.
It was not until the 19th century that the site was completely cleared.
All that remains are a few seating rows, the orchestra section, the stage curtain area and two tall marble columns topped with a fragment of entablature.
However, the theatre is once again being used as a performance venue, particularly in summer.
The Roman Theatre in Arles has a diameter of 102 m.
Its 33 rows of seats, many of which have now disappeared, backed onto an outer enclosure consisting of three levels of arches.
The theatre could accommodate 10,000 spectators.
The orchestra section is separated from the cavea by a wall, the balteus, in front of which a 1.2 m wide area was reserved for the portable seats of the colony's nobility.
The pulpitum wall marked the separation between the orchestra and the stage area. It was adorned with decorated niches, including with the altar to Apollo which was found in 1828.
Many other areas of the site have revealed remains of this sumptuous decoration. Two staircases connected the orchestra to the stage.
Excavations and scientific studies have revealed the stage's main features.
It was approximately 6 metres deep and flanked by vast parascenia (wings) The stage wall was highly decorated.
It had three levels of columns and a large statuary, including the colossal statue of Augustus which is currently in the Departmental Museum of Ancient Arles. The famous statue of the 'Venus of Arles' is kept at the Louvre.
In the middle of the wall was the Royal gate, flanked on both sides by two columns; only those on one side are still in place today.
The theatre's outer enclosure comprised 27 arches resting on strong pillars. This façade had three levels, which can today only be seen in the southern section, included in the Tower of Roland, which was built in the early Middle Ages.

label: Hôtel d'Arbaud
description:
Built in 1670 by Jean Claude Rambot. 


The door is framed by two Atlases: two grimacing fauns, with powerful bare torsos, protruding shoulder-blades and twisted biceps, have supported a heavy pediment, with no effort spared, for three centuries.

label: Château de Montauban
comment: This beautiful residence was above all a place of rest and inspiration for Alphonse Daudet. The museum offers a prefiguration of a vast project and presents the permanent exhibition on the medieval archaeological discoveries of the area.
shortDescription: This beautiful residence was above all a place of rest and inspiration for Alphonse Daudet. The museum offers a prefiguration of a vast project and presents the permanent exhibition on the medieval archaeological discoveries of the area.
description:
This house, the setting for many of Alphonse Daudet's novels, was above all a place of calm and rest for the author: "Blessed house, how many times I have come here to reconnect with nature, to cure myself of Paris and its fevers...".
This superb building, with its monumental 19th century façade adjoining an 18th century farmhouse, was the home of the Ambroy family who welcomed the author during his stays in Provence. Daudet regularly visited the house with his wife Julia from 1863, at the invitation of his cousins.
Now a museum centre dedicated to the history of the village, the Château de Montauban is the forerunner of a vast cultural project which already includes a permanent exhibition on the medieval archaeological discoveries of the area.

label: Habitats troglodytiques
comment: Two kinds of caves: some natural but few in number, the others were built from 1615 following the transfer by the lord of St Chamas of his property rights to the Community Council.
shortDescription: Two kinds of caves: some natural but few in number, the others were built from 1615 following the transfer by the lord of St Chamas of his property rights to the Community Council.
description: It is he who grants permission to dig balms into the baou. He limits the extent of the digging, but this recommendation is not respected. These caves have been used as warehouses for the port's goods, mills, shelters... It is during the XVIIIth century that these caves started to be used as a habitat.

label: Eguilles
description:
The hilltop village of Eguilles, at an altitude of 300 metres, is only 10 km to the west of Aix en Provence, and has succeeded in preserving its authentic character down the ages. 


Its superb geographic location offers an incomparable view over the surrounding countryside. 


The village has succeeded in preserving its authentic character down the ages. In its centre stands the castle built by the Boyer d’Eguilles family in the 17th century, which now houses the town hall. In the shade of its majestic entrance, the clock has run smoothly for 140 years. 


Walking through the village you will see its pretty narrow streets, typical steep flights of steps leading to the different wash-houses, and the ruins of the ancient Romanesque church. 


In the village you can also see the garden of artist Max Sauze, which was listed as an Outstanding Garden in 2004, and the grave of the poet Joachim Gasquet in the village cemetery.

label: Stèle Henri Fabre
comment: The stele was installed in commemoration of the inventor of the seaplane who accomplished his first flight over the Étang de Berre on 28 March 1910.
shortDescription: The stele was installed in commemoration of the inventor of the seaplane who accomplished his first flight over the Étang de Berre on 28 March 1910.
description:
Born in Marseille in 1882 to a family of shipowners, Henri Fabre set up his workshop in Martigues in 1906, on the quai Toulmond (in the Île district), to design his creations.
This workshop has become a restaurant, Villa Sorriso.

On March 28, 1910, he flew from La Mède and landed in Martigues, thus making the first flight in a seaplane.
A stele was inaugurated on March 28, 1965, in his presence, to celebrate the 55th anniversary of this historic first flight. On this occasion, the brilliant aviator was made honorary citizen of the city of Martigues.

label: Oratoire Notre-Dame-de-Lourdes
description:
This oratory was erected following a miraculous healing in 1902.
No name is mentioned in connection with the healing.
This oratory is elaborately decorated and the edicule is surrounded by a metal grill. It has a very strong base bearing four columns with Corinthian capitals, which support a heavy domed roof topped with a pine cone. There are four votive or dedicatory inscriptions and a guardian statue.

label: Hôtel particulier de Preigne
comment: This former private mansion of the Gras de Preigne family has been home to the Palais de Justice since 1858. Built at the beginning of the XVIIth century, in Renaissance style.
shortDescription: This former private mansion of the Gras de Preigne family has been home to the Palais de Justice since 1858. Built at the beginning of the XVIIth century, in Renaissance style.
description:
It was later redesigned in the French or Parisian style with the main buildings arranged in a U-shape around a main courtyard (Place du Bâtonnier Louis Gonthier). At the back, the current entrance of the Law Courts giving onto the Dr. Braye square has a Mannerist style facade from the 1620s. The small square was arranged at the end of the 18th century in order to give more light and cheerfulness to the classical façade. The windows are surmounted by triangular pediments, once decorated with fleur-de-lis, responding to the large pediment over the front door.
Its monumental door and its leaves are registered in the inventory of historical monuments.
This private mansion is described in a heritage booklet "Belles demeures" available at the Tarascon Tourist Office.

label: Salines de Rassuen et de Fos sur Mer
comment: The Etang de Rassuen is a small brackish water body of 15 ha, with marshes all around a surface of 40 ha, in the commune of Istres.
shortDescription: The Etang de Rassuen is a small brackish water body of 15 ha, with marshes all around a surface of 40 ha, in the commune of Istres.
description: Surrounded by scrubland and pine forests, these bodies of water are a fishing ground and the marsh has a multiple plant cover depending on the environment: duckweed, in open water, reed beds in belts and islands.

label: Parc de la Moline
comment: Park of 11 hectares: there is a butterfly garden and almond, jujube, maple, oak trees..., local species par excellence, which reinforce the image of a Mediterranean landscape.
shortDescription: Park of 11 hectares: there is a butterfly garden and almond, jujube, maple, oak trees..., local species par excellence, which reinforce the image of a Mediterranean landscape.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of parents who must ensure that health regulations are respected, including physical distance.

With a surface area of 11 hectares, it was created by the landscape designers of ILEX, with a main entrance on bd Marius Richard, in the 12th arrondissement: it has been open to users since September 2005.

Created to mask the infrastructure of the L2 expressway cover, the park links the surrounding neighborhoods while maintaining a pedestrian and bicycle connection from the north to the east of the city. It was designed and built with a view to preserving the memory of the neighborhood and recalling the agricultural and bastide history of the site. Its development was therefore oriented towards the creation of a natural country park.

There is a butterfly garden and almond, jujube, maple and oak trees, local species par excellence, which reinforce the image of a Mediterranean landscape.

This park has received the Ecojardin label

label: La Muraille de Chine
comment: The Great Wall of China is located in ... Marseille!
shortDescription: The Great Wall of China is located in ... Marseille!
description:
In the 9th arrondissement, this site of the calanques is protected because it is a reserve of exceptional fauna and flora. It is composed of three mountains: Mont Lantin, Mont Carpiagne and Mont Saint Cyr. At more than 600 m of altitude, you will be able to discover there a unique panorama on the roadstead of Marseille, the archipelago of Frioul, Notre Dame de la Garde, the Velodrome and the Sainte Victoire.
Protection of Bonelli's eagles (50 ha).

Protected area: Prefectoral decree for biotope protection

label: Eglise de l'assomption Sainte Marie
comment: Discover the Church of the Assumption of Saint Mary in Le Puy Sainte Réparade
shortDescription: Discover the Church of the Assumption of Saint Mary in Le Puy Sainte Réparade
description:
Inside this very plain church is a splendid Baroque altar-piece created in 1708 by the Aix sculptor Claude Routier. 
The original altar-piece is in the Augustinian convent in Aix en Provence

label: Château de Barbentane
comment: The castle of Barbentane, nicknamed the "Little Trianon of Provence" is a Provencal castle of Italian style.
shortDescription: The castle of Barbentane, nicknamed the "Little Trianon of Provence" is a Provencal castle of Italian style.
description: This castle which some sections of the wall date back to the 15th century, is located in the heart of the village of Barbentane, in a wooded area of 4 hectares Park. The area of the castle of composed of a park, a private in the heart of Woods Chapel (closed to the public) and a tower Anglica (XIVth century) ranked and remarkably preserved.

label: Moulin Louis Ricard
comment: The Moulin Louis Ricard, the fifth and last mill built on the Frédéric Mistral esplanade, was built in 1729 by Louis Ricard, a baker in Allauch.
shortDescription: The Moulin Louis Ricard, the fifth and last mill built on the Frédéric Mistral esplanade, was built in 1729 by Louis Ricard, a baker in Allauch.
description:
The Louis Ricard mill is the only one of the 5 mills located on the esplanade that has a cellar. Only a few mills in Provence are built with a cellar. They are called "moulins de crotte", a term which means cellar in the Oc language. The cellars were used as granaries to store grain and sails. This particularity is very rare in Provence since the mills were generally built on a hillock.

The Louis Ricard mill is cylindrical in shape and is of the "tower" type. Its fixed base is made of masonry and is topped by a roof that can be rotated 360° in order to direct the wings towards the wind. The Provençal mills have only one floor, generally with a wooden frame and staircase. The wings, driven by the wind, activate the lantern and the big iron which transmit their movement to the rotating millstone. The wheat, poured into the hopper, is then crushed between the stationary millstone and the rotating millstone. The milling is collected on the first floor in a wooden hutch

In small groups, the miller tells you the history of the mills and explains the transformation of the wind into a driving force and the wheat into flour.

label: Port Antique - jardin des vestiges
comment: The site of the Ancient Port (named Jardin des vestiges when it was opened to the public in 1983) presents the results of the first major urban archaeological excavations carried out in France.
shortDescription: The site of the Ancient Port (named Jardin des vestiges when it was opened to the public in 1983) presents the results of the first major urban archaeological excavations carried out in France.
description:
The remains, revealed in 1967 on the construction site of the Centre Bourse, are major historical witnesses. The site is structured around the Roman road, the Greek ramparts and around the Ancient Port where the largest visible wreck in the world was discovered. 

This Roman road, lined with funerary monuments, enters the city through a monumental entrance.

The entrance is through the Museum of History, inside the Exchange Center.

label: Emmanuel Signoret place Eugène Pelletan
comment: Bust of Emmanuel Signoret
shortDescription: Bust of Emmanuel Signoret
description: Emmanuel Signoret, whose bronze bust adorns the Place Eugène Pelletan, was a poet and literary critic in the 19th century. Born in Lançon in 1872, he published several collections of poetry in his youth, and dedicated many poems to his native village. "La souffrance des eaux" was crowned by the French Academy in 1899. He also became deputy of the Bouches du Rhône and then senator in 1876. Suffering from tuberculosis, he died in 1900 at the age of 28, in destitution. To pay tribute to him, a street in the old centre of the village now bears his name. The bust dates from 1914. It was once enthroned on the Champ de Mars square, then was hidden during the Second World War so as not to end up transformed into a cannon. It has been in its present location since 1957.

label: Le Domaine de Saint Martin
comment: Forest of pines, oaks and olive trees, paths to discover some bories, and a medieval chapel (11th century).
shortDescription: Forest of pines, oaks and olive trees, paths to discover some bories, and a medieval chapel (11th century).
description:
The Domaine de Saint Martin is located two kilometers west of the village, in the heart of a forest made up of pine forests, garrigue and olive groves.

You will discover the charm of a Provencal country house renovated in 2016 to welcome the children of the Eguilles leisure center.

The whole domain, which covers more than 13 hectares, offers a remarkable bio-diversity, exceptional viewpoints, a park planted with hundred-year-old cedars. There is also the Saint Martin chapel restored in 2015.

The Domaine de Saint Martin now houses the premises of the extracurricular leisure center which allows children to benefit from a true natural environment for their vacations.

label: Val d'Enfer
comment: The mineral and chaotic world of the Baux-de-Provence has inspired many writers. Its tormented landscape with cliffs pierced by caves has given rise to many legends.
shortDescription: The mineral and chaotic world of the Baux-de-Provence has inspired many writers. Its tormented landscape with cliffs pierced by caves has given rise to many legends.
description:
In the Val d'Enfer, guarded by stone monsters, legends and poets have given shelter to witches and fairies. Dante was inspired by this valley nestled at the foot of the village to write his Inferno and Mistral, in Mirèio, located the lair of the witch Taven. A golden cabro guards the treasure of a Saracen prince buried for centuries!

In this valley, certain rock formations, here a few steps from the Carrières de Lumière in Les Baux de Provence, have the appearance of skeletal skulls. An unusual curiosity in the heart of the Alpilles Massif.

To get there, take the departmental road 27, which weaves its way between the rocks. A winding road but with beautiful views.

label: Eglise du Saint-Esprit
comment: Located in the historical and pedestrian centre of Aix-en-Provence (rue Espariat), the Church of the Holy Spirit is protected by a classification as a historical monument
shortDescription: Located in the historical and pedestrian centre of Aix-en-Provence (rue Espariat), the Church of the Holy Spirit is protected by a classification as a historical monument
description:
Located on the site of the Saint-Esprit Hospital and demolished neighbouring houses, this church was built by the Vallon brothers between 1706 and 1728 to a new design. 

It was designed as a Latin cross inside a rectangle. The decision to link the transept arms to the side aisles and the choir was an innovation in the religious architecture of Aix at the time, and created greater balance and fluidity between the volumes. 

It was blessed by Canon De Forbin-La Barben in 1716, and named Saint-Jérôme in memory of its founder, Monseigneur de Grimaldi.

Its frontage is simple and sober, emphasised by the plain vertical lines of the pilasters. 

The church was listed in 1985 it was here that Mirabeau and Mademoiselle de Marignane were married.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents et Tour de l'Horloge
comment: A magnificent panorama is offered to the walkers who venture here, where you can admire the village, the whole valley, the slag heap and Saint Victory.
shortDescription: A magnificent panorama is offered to the walkers who venture here, where you can admire the village, the whole valley, the slag heap and Saint Victory.
description:
Situated on a rocky promontory, it is highly probable that the Clock Tower, also known as the Saracen Tower, served as a lookout post on the Chaîne de l'Etoile
Built in the 13th century, the tower has a peculiar shape, it is pentagonal on the outside but square on the inside. The pediment bearing the clock was added in the first half of the 20th century

Below the tower are the ruins of a Romanesque chapel, which belonged to the Abbey of Montmajour, and was later used by the Brotherhood of White Penitents of the village. It was destroyed during the Second World War.

label: Porte du Fort
comment: On the hill of Baou is the Fort Gate, the last vestige of the surrounding wall of the old Castrum. The hill is also occupied by the Chapel of Mercy. The gate dates from the 15th century.
shortDescription: On the hill of Baou is the Fort Gate, the last vestige of the surrounding wall of the old Castrum. The hill is also occupied by the Chapel of Mercy. The gate dates from the 15th century.

label: Rempart et Tour Carrée
description: As early as the year 1000, the town of Berre was fortified by a surrounding wall ensuring security. A square tower still remains with a remnant of a covered way.

label: Cap Canaille
comment: By taking the ridge road between Cassis and La Ciotat, we discover the cliffs of Soubeyran which overlook the coast. The highest point is Cap Canaille (399 meters), the highest cliff in Europe.
shortDescription: By taking the ridge road between Cassis and La Ciotat, we discover the cliffs of Soubeyran which overlook the coast. The highest point is Cap Canaille (399 meters), the highest cliff in Europe.
description:
The very beautiful route des Crêtes, cut through the limestone puddingstones, leads to Cassis, this famous little village, a former Roman fishing port that has become a lively seaside and climatic resort, in La-Ciotat.
The port of Cassis, a fishing center in the 19th century in the heart of an agricultural basin and a resort center in the early years of the 20th century, is sheltered by the cliffs of La Gardiole and Cap Canaille. The reputation of its hillside vineyards adds to its tourist vocation. Cassis welcomes up to 35,000 inhabitants in summer.

label: Tour de l'horloge
comment:
Date: 1558
Era: Renaissance
Type: Public communal architecture
Status: Property of the town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1920
shortDescription:
Date: 1558
Era: Renaissance
Type: Public communal architecture
Status: Property of the town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1920
description:
The Tower viewed from the Place de la République
Although the Clock Tower now seems like to be an integral part of the hôtel de ville, more than a century actually separates the construction of the two buildings.
It was in fact constructed in the mid-16th century, to replace an older tower. 
During a particularly prosperous period in the history of Arles, its construction complied with the will of consuls wanting to affirm their power. 
The Tower therefore sits imposingly in the heart of the town, next to the town hall of the municipal officials, and opposite the bell tower of Saint Trophime Cathedral, itself a symbol of religious power.
Its architecture is typically Renaissance and largely inspired by Antiquity, which became a great source of inspiration and curiosity in the town during this period.
Elevation of the Tower,
integrated into the north-east corner of the hôtel de ville
The architectural structure of the Clock Tower and its antique décor imitate the Roman Mausoleum of Les Antiques in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence.
Its entablatures with sculpted friezes, fluted columns and Ionic and Corinthian capitals are particularly sophisticated.
Four clocks, only one of which remains, were installed in the upper part of the tower. 
Inside were several bells (one large and two small), which rang at important times in the life of the town and particularly as a warning.
The highly sophisticated mechanism of the clocks took up most of the space. A bell rang on the hour. This bell was melted down on several occasions and each time had the names of the new consuls engraved on it. 
The rotunda above is surmounted by 'the bronze man', a statue representing the god Mars, another evocation of Antiquity. It was created in 1555 by Laurent Vincent, an Avignon foundry owner.
It is said that it was made with bronze from the canons that the army of Charles V abandoned during its incursion in 1536. 
During the Revolution, the 'bronze man' was almost removed and melted down to make arms.
The conservation of the Tower and its integration during the construction of the hôtel de ville were in accordance with the consuls' wishes. 
The chosen solution is one of Jules Hardouin Mansart's contributions to the project.

label: L' Amphithéâtre romain
comment: The amphitheatre is the most important monument of the ancient Roman colony that we can admire, some two millennia after its construction. A monument that alone is worth a stay in Arles.
shortDescription: The amphitheatre is the most important monument of the ancient Roman colony that we can admire, some two millennia after its construction. A monument that alone is worth a stay in Arles.
description: The amphitheatre is the most important monument of the former Roman colony that we should admire, some two thousand years after its construction. Its architecture is entirely designed in relation to its vocation of place to great shows, hosting a large audience. In their initial rise, the bleachers could receive approximately 21 000 viewers, streams were cleverly organized by a network of doors, galleries and stairs, on several floors.Become at the beginning of the middle ages a city close and fortified, the building was cleared only in XIX century. He himself then for part, its original function, including bullfighting, which earned him his current common appellation of "arenas".It is today the monument of the most visited city, bringing the image of Arles in the world.With a major axis of 136 meters in length and a minor axis of 107 meters, the amphitheatre of Arles is slightly larger than that of Nîmes and the 20th ranked among those of the Roman world. It has a shape of an ellipse. The façade includes two levels of sixty semicircular arches, separated by the abutments, massive rectangular section. A wider opening points out the ends of the two axes of the monument. The main entrance was not North as today, but the West where we can see the remains of a staircase overlooking the city.The cavea, space reserved for spectators, included 34 stands, divided into four series: the maeniana, where viewers were divided according to their social status. It is estimated the initial capacity of the monument to some 21,000 people. To allow visitors to access the different stands, had developed an ingenious device of circular galleries, horizontal passages, and prepared Alternatively stairs.On the ground floor, the outdoor Gallery is particularly noteworthy, especially for its coverage of large monolithic slabs. She gave access to an indoor gallery, vaulted arch, which opened on the first maenianum and on the lower part of the second. The outdoor Gallery, stairs also allowed to reach the first mezzanine, whence it had access to the second maenanium either the outdoor Gallery of the first floor. This vertical and horizontal circulation system allowed to reach the highest level of the building. A penthouse, now defunct, surmounted the façade: there were fixed the masts used to stretch an awning to protect spectators from the Sun.The central part reserved for the games and fighting (the arena itself) was separated from the stands by a carefully matched wall: the wall of the podium dressed in large slabs of stone. The soil of the track was higher about 2 meters than the current level. Indeed, it consisted of a wooden floor, which the blades were based on a stone bead, at the top of the lower part of the podium. The machinery needed for the shows was staying between the walls and floors that ensured the stability of the arena.

label: Musée municipal d'art et traditions populaires
comment: The Municipal Museum of ATP offers a programme of cultural events throughout the year: major thematic exhibitions, educational workshops for schools and children, guided tours.
shortDescription: The Municipal Museum of ATP offers a programme of cultural events throughout the year: major thematic exhibitions, educational workshops for schools and children, guided tours.
description:
Just a stone's throw from the port, in the heart of the city, this one is housed in a former presbytery from the beginning of the 17th century. The building is austere, but the interior, full of charm and balance, seduces from the moment you enter. Permanent and temporary exhibitions follow one another. Christmas is regularly celebrated here in a special way. Its collections of paintings (the oldest canvas dates back to 1601), its Roman remains and its amphorae, offer a diversity that will seduce visitors. A reading corner and a mini-boutique complete this stopover, which has been honoured on several occasions by the major guides: BBC, Athena Review, Figaro Méditérranée and the various radio stations in the region. 
Free admission. Guided tour for groups with a fee upon reservation 15 days in advance
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 200
Temporary exhibition area: 100
streetAddress: ['Hôtel de Ville de Cassis Place Baragnon', "Rue Xavier d'Authier"]

label: Parc Pastré
comment: Between the Pointe Rouge and the Grotte Rolland, the Pastré Park extends to the hills of Marseilleveyre over 112 hectares, including 100 hectares of natural areas.
shortDescription: Between the Pointe Rouge and the Grotte Rolland, the Pastré Park extends to the hills of Marseilleveyre over 112 hectares, including 100 hectares of natural areas.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.



Between the Pointe Rouge and the Grotte Rolland, the Pastré park stretches over 112 hectares, up to the hills of Marseilleveyre. In 1974, the Countess Pastré ceded most of her property to the city. Since then, the site has become a huge public park and is one of the most beautiful jewels in the city's heritage. Its central alley runs for more than 900 metres
Two ponds, a canal, playgrounds and hiking trails seduce its many users. The 19th century castle houses the bastides and outbuildings of the same period, including the Villa Provençale (villa for the guests of the city of Marseille) complete the park.

The upper part of the park retains its wild character and opens onto the hills of Marseilleveyre and the discovery of the calanques. The entire wooded area of the park is part of the classified site of the creeks and is a gateway for lovers of hiking. In the lower part, a water garden has been created, with three different zones: ponds and meadows, the Provençal mall, which provides a shady and quiet walk, and an open-air amphitheatre. The Société des Eaux de Marseille has created a monumental fountain symbolising the Alps where the waters of the Durance are born, a real starting point for the water circuit, designed by the architect Marc Dossetti.

The upper part of the park is concerned by the summer regulations.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de Pitié
description: Built, according to the archives, with one nave circa 1525, Notre Dame de Pitié Chapel was given two side-naves between 1650 and 1670, followed by a porch in 1685. It was sold as a national asset in 1802 and then had a succession of owners until 1919, when it was returned to the parish and then the diocese.  1977 saw the creation of the 'Friends of Notre Dame de Pitié' Association, which began the restoration work. In 1985, the Mario Prassinos Association, the building's tenant, continued the restoration of the chapel and developed it so it could display works of art.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
description: Lending library.

label: Eglise de la Nativité de la Vierge
description: The Church of le Sambuc is part of an order placed in 1636 by Monseigneur de Barrault, for the construction of six parish churches in the Camargue. It was for the Bishop to combat the de-Christianization of the region. Its facade was rebuilt in 1656 and its roof redone at the end of the 19th century. Nothing remains of the altars, baptismal font and benitiers carved stone, originally installed. A second building was next later in the extension of the nave.

label: Parc du Palais Longchamp
comment: Palais Longchamp : under the sign of culture and nature .
shortDescription: Palais Longchamp : under the sign of culture and nature .
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are placed under the responsibility of parents who must ensure that sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


Protected as a Historic Monument, Parc Longchamp, which is currently being reconstructed, has been built up over time through the stratification of different projects, imagined or carried out on the site, since the 19th century.

The Longchamp Park, the Borély Park, the Magalone Garden and the 26th Centenary Park were awarded the "remarkable garden" label by the Ministry of Culture in 2005.

In Marseille, as in all of Provence, water control remained a major problem until the construction of the Marseille canal to supply the city with water from the Durance.

On July 8, 1847, the water arrived on the Longchamp plateau, following the canal traced by the Ponts et Chaussées engineer, Frantz Major de Montricher, transforming at the same time, the Marseilles landscape. 

To celebrate this event, the architect Henry Espérandieu conceived in 1862 a large-scale project including a monumental fountain surrounded by two wings, one housing the Museum of Natural History and the other the Museum of Fine Arts. He then designed a double staircase encircling the fountain to access his museums, behind which are three gardens.

The public garden called "du plateau" was inaugurated in 1869, at the same time as the water tower, while the "jardin de l'Observatoire" was created between 1863 and 1864. Under the garden of the plateau, two superimposed rooms were built to collect the waters of the canal of Marseille which were decanted there before being redistributed in the city. These basins, an essential element of the hydraulic system, buried and supported by a forest of pillars, will soon be restored.

Finally, the Zoological Garden, open to the people of Marseille since 1854, illustrates the passion of the Second Empire for exoticism and travel. A victim of public disaffection, the zoo closed in 1987. The cages, now deserted, evoke the great era of the zoo, in which the big cats themselves only had a few square meters to escape their boredom.

Of the three gardens created, only two are open to the public today: the "plateau garden" and the "zoological garden".

The "jardin du plateau", conceived by Espérandieu as a setting for the "Palais Longchamp" and created behind the water tower, was laid out in the French style, in the spirit of Edouard André. The wide, winding paths highlight the sculpted group representing the Durance River and the stalactite-adorned waterfall celebrating the arrival of the Canal in Marseille. The transparency of the central body of the water tower allows a perspective view of the city.

The zoological garden belongs to the current of "picturesque" or "English" gardens integrating a reconstituted nature and giving pride of place to decorative elements. One can still observe a bandstand, some orientalist structures (the giraffe and elephant pavilions and the wild animal cages decorated with turquoise ceramics), rock garden elements (the seal cascade, the aviary and the bear cage) and a "rustic" hut, formerly occupied by ostriches. Other cages are adorned with naïve paintings and feature decorated fences and brick houses.

label: City stade de l'Argelier
description: City stadium of Argelier

label: Fondation Vasarely
comment:
Architectural center of Aix-en-Provence classified as a historical monument. 
The Vasarely Foundation is a Museum of France since December 10, 2020
shortDescription:
Architectural center of Aix-en-Provence classified as a historical monument. 
The Vasarely Foundation is a Museum of France since December 10, 2020
description:
Architectonic centre in Aix-en-Provence, listed as a historic monument.

Immerse yourself in the fascinating world of op art inside a lumino-kinetic building, designed and financed by Victor Vasarely.
On the ground floor are 16 modules with a hexagonal base, linked together like a gigantic construction game, including 42 monumental architectural units and 2 sculptures. The works are made of anodized metal, tapestry, ceramics, enamel and silkscreen-printed glass. They result from a fruitful collaboration between the artist, the architects and companies with the aim of creating a multi-coloured city of happiness.

On the first floor, an area called "Vasarely Plasticien" ("Vasarely Plastic Artist") includes a visit and cultural mediation elements, giving visitors the chance to explore the artist's world, from his beginnings as a graphic designer to his work on monumental units, with almost 200 original works and documents.
Temporary exhibitions, workshops, concerts, conferences, plus cultural mediation activities with workshops for children, families and adults are regular features of the Foundation program all through the year. 

The cultural mediation service can also organize birthday parties for your children and introduce them to the site during a visit and a creative workshop.

Facilities for disabled people: all the rooms are accessible to people with reduced mobility.

▶ Booklets in 24 other languages available for consultation
▶ Booklets in Braille for blind or visually impaired visitors

label: Chapelle Saint-Michel
comment: Romanesque chapel from the 12th century.
shortDescription: Romanesque chapel from the 12th century.
description: It dates from the 12th century and meets the characteristics of rural Romanesque chapels of Provence. The windows and front door were the South because of the violent mistral existing windows are not the original that had to be very close and the old front door can still be seen outside the Chapel, on the south wall. Coverage of the chapel was entirely made up of lauzes, the roof has been redone in the 17th century. It is built in Orgon superbly cut stone: these stones were thrusted on the Durance, and then sent to the Chapel by the path of the Devens. It served as the parish church until the 13th century when the Church current, much larger, located at the foot of the castle was built: the village moved so a few hundreds of meters.The fresco behind the altar of the chapel represents the Holy Trinity with the specific insignia of the Carthusians.Jean Girard, grandson of the last prior of the brotherhood, launched a call in 1974 to the penny: this appeal was heard and the chapel was completely restored.

label: Oratoire Saint Eloi
description: This Chapel is dedicated to Saint Eloi, a saint very well known on the territory of the country of Arles, the boss of the "household", small owners.The oratory was built in the nineteenth century (1859) and marked, to the South, the city limits.He still plays an important role in the course of the feast of saint Eloi, since it is the crossing point of the cart and the Carters during the preparations and the party itself. The 1st Sunday in December, the brotherhood celebrates at the foot of this oratory Saint Eloi winter.Between religious symbols and landscaped lairs, oratories are erected to thank a saint to have granted a wish to protect the inhabitants against epidemics.It consists of a moulded cippus, which rests on a base. The niche is semicircular protected by a grid. It is surrounded by fluted columns, topped by a roof with two slopes. The pediment is triangular. On the top of the roof, there is a small metal cross. You will see the statue of saint Eloi.
streetAddress: ['1 Rue des Carrières', '2 Rue du 8 Mai 1945']

label: Fontaine Bellegarde
comment: As you go around the city by the outer boulevards, Cours Saint Louis takes you to Place Bellegarde.
shortDescription: As you go around the city by the outer boulevards, Cours Saint Louis takes you to Place Bellegarde.
description:
The fountain is built on a small esplanade, and flights of steps lead from it to the Mignet district.
Like the Saint Louis fountain, its construction was decided on in 1632  it was then built, moved, altered and installed in its present location in 1849.

When he died François Marius Granet, who was born in Aix, had just bequeathed a large collection of paintings to the city. In gratitude, the city commissioned a bust of the artist from Hippolyte Ferrat, to be placed on the fountain's Roman column. 

This ancient column with its historical connotations recalls one of Granet's favourite places to live and work. Although his features are not easily visible, he faces the city as if inviting you to visit the museum. 

The monument is extremely elegant with its four outlets from which water flows symmetrically into the geometric split-level basin, and the column, taken from the Roman remains of the 4th and 5th centuries, seems to be trying to dominate the trees, with Granet at its top, as captain.

label: La petite ferme pédagogique de Saint-Rémy
comment:
La petite ferme de St Remy offers education in sustainable development.
Discovering a new approach to the environment and citizenship. You will also find
local products for sale.
shortDescription:
La petite ferme de St Remy offers education in sustainable development.
Discovering a new approach to the environment and citizenship. You will also find
local products for sale.
description:
La petite ferme de St Remy offers education in sustainable development,
in particular education to the environment and citizenship. Through educational activities to discover the rural and agricultural world in a concern of accessibility to the greatest number.
You will be able to meet donkeys, goats, chickens, but also to learn the life cycle and the respectful practices of the environment in a farm autonomous in water and electricity.
You will also find local products for sale.

Several formats are available on appointment, do not hesitate to contact us on Facebook or by mail.

label: Château d'Estoublon
comment: Rebuilt at the end of the 17th century on the site of an ancient fortress destroyed by the inhabitants of Les Baux, the castle and its chapel were not given the name Estoublon until the 18th century. On the estate, passion since 1489, the tradition of olive oils and exceptional wines.
shortDescription: Rebuilt at the end of the 17th century on the site of an ancient fortress destroyed by the inhabitants of Les Baux, the castle and its chapel were not given the name Estoublon until the 18th century. On the estate, passion since 1489, the tradition of olive oils and exceptional wines.
description: Rebuilt at the end of the 17th century on the site of an ancient fortress destroyed by the inhabitants of Les Baux, the castle and its chapel were not given the name Estoublon until the 18th century. On the estate, passion since 1489, the tradition of olive oils and exceptional wines.

label: Cours Voltaire
description: Cours Voltaire is one of the suburbs that developed from the 15th century to the present day. The Cours Voltaire is the site of a large fruit and vegetable market, mainly from local producers, which attracts a very large clientele, reputed to be one of the most important in the region. It is held every morning on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays.

label: Eglise St Jean de Moustiers
description:
12th century
Also known as Saint Agatha.
This Provençal Romanesque-style church in the L'Hauture district, near Saint-Césaire Monastery, was once a parish church.
Built in the 12th century, only part of it remains, including a remarkable semi-domed vaulted apse with exterior décor inspired by Antiquity.
As with other monuments in the town, its apparent burial testifies to the difference between the current ground level and that of the mediaeval period. The intention here was perhaps to conserve the Paleo-Christian level. Outside, the semi-circular chevet is decorated with fluted pilasters with capitals adorned with acanthus leaves, topped with an overhanging cornice.
This décor is directly inspired by ancient monuments, particularly the amphitheatre.
The burial of the apse, which is currently half-interred, is due to the raising of the ground level at the time of construction; this can also be seen at the nearby Saint Blaise Church.
All that remains of the nave are two bays, one of which is partly incorporated into the neighbouring house.
Two doors in the north and south walls, as well as a window, testify once again to the difference between the ground level at the time of construction and now.
The building is particularly noteworthy for its semi-domed vaulted apse, whose ribs end in capitals around the keystone, which was once decorated with a lamb.
The apse wall has a partially restored décor of arches.

label: Etang de l'Olivier
comment: Pond of 220 hectares, close to the town centre with the highest Jet d'eau in France, gushing out at more than 50 m, and the Dinosaur'Istres park.
shortDescription: Pond of 220 hectares, close to the town centre with the highest Jet d'eau in France, gushing out at more than 50 m, and the Dinosaur'Istres park.
description:
The pond has a preserved ecosystem, formed of reed beds and cliffs of saffre which shelter many birds and fish. The lake is full of fish, including mule and mullet, eel, carp, roach, perch, pikeperch and pike.
The Etang de l'Olivier is linked to the Etang de Berre by the Cascaveau canal

Provençal jousting, a traditional sport that requires strength and skill, is practiced here. The society of the Istréens Players, several times champion of France, trains and organizes tournaments from June to September. One also finds there the traditional rowing practised by the "Les rameurs de l'Olivier" (Rowers of the Olive Tree).

According to legend, Lou Coulobre, a gigantic snake, still lives in the depths of the pond, who knows?

label: Couvent des Dominicains
comment: Work of the famous Lyon architect Pierre Bossan between 1868 and 1878.
shortDescription: Work of the famous Lyon architect Pierre Bossan between 1868 and 1878.
description:
Built by the famous Lyon architect Pierre Bossan between 1868 and 1878, this building, dedicated to the Holy Rosary, shows the will of the Dominicans, reinstalled in Marseille by Lacordaire, to take over the spiritual direction of this very popular Marian devotion in the city.

To be noted : the nudity of the crypt, the high church richly decorated with polychrome marble, the sculptures of Millfaut ( theme of the Rosary), the furniture of Bossan and Sainte-Marie-Perrin, the stained glass windows representing the Saints and Blessed of the order.

Visit by appointment for groups only. Service times : weekday Lauds at 7.30am, mid-day service at 11.50am, mass at 12.05pm, vespers at 7pm, compline (or vigil) at 8.30pm.

Sunday : Lauds at 8.30am, Mass at 10.30am, Vespers at 6.30pm,  Adoration of the Blessed Sacrament at 7pm, Salvation of the Blessed Sacrament at 8pm.

label: Grotte aux Palmiers
description: This cave is unique in Europe! It contains palm tree fossils 6.5 million years old. One of these fossil trunks measures 1m in diameter and 2m high. Opening: only by appointment taken 24 hours in advance with the tourist service.

label: Observatoire du Parc Marin de la Côte Bleue
comment: The Marine Park Observatory opens its doors on Thursday afternoons in July and August. Reservations can be made at the Tourist Office of Carry-le-Rouet. Intended for children (minimum 6 years old).
shortDescription: The Marine Park Observatory opens its doors on Thursday afternoons in July and August. Reservations can be made at the Tourist Office of Carry-le-Rouet. Intended for children (minimum 6 years old).
description: The joint association Parc Marin de la Côte Bleue (which brings together the General Council, the Regional Council and the 5 municipalities) is intended to take over and extend the action led by the association Parc Régional Marin de la Côte Bleue. Its objectives are as follows: the management, protection and enhancement of natural marine and coastal environments, the contribution to the economic and social development of activities related to the sea and in particular small-scale professional fishing, the reception, information and education of the public, the implementation of experimental or exemplary actions in the above fields and the contribution to scientific research programmes. The Joint Syndicate's field of action covers the entire coastline of the Côte Bleue, from Anse des laurons in the west to the point of Corbières in the east and the adjacent marine environment up to 2 miles offshore. It operates in front of the communes of Martigues, Sausset les Pins, Carry le Rouet, Ensuès la Redonne and le Rove. Since 1983, the marine park has carried out a number of actions, information and public awareness.

label: Oratoires Saint Roch
description: The Oratory of Saint Roch, dated 1854, marked the Western City limit.This votive Aedicule is dedicated to saint-Roch, patron of the plague: it is a very popular saint in Provence of the fact of the major epidemics of cholera and plague which particularly marked the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.This carries a dedication of 1854.It consists of a niche in a high main body stone, four columns that are based on semicircular arches. Support is low. The roof has four slopes and a metal cross. You will see the statue in niche representative saint-Roch.

label: Collegiale Sainte Marthe
description:
Saint Martha Church is entirely devoted to the Saint who managed to overcome the mythical Tarasque. The upper church is one of the most beautiful Gothic sanctuaries in Provence. It houses paintings by Parrocel and Vien and important works from convents, such as the Triptych of Saint John, Saint Roch and Saint Laurent. The church is also home to a recumbent marble statue of the Saint dating from 1653 and 15th century organs. The crypt, 3 m below ground, precedes the Christian era.
The organs are listed as national Historic Monuments.

label: Chapelle de Saint-Cannat
comment:
Open to the public only on request and during the European Heritage Days.
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 40
shortDescription:
Open to the public only on request and during the European Heritage Days.
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 40
description: Chapel of the seventeenth century in Provencal style. Raised in 1657 to thank the Saint for protecting the city from the plague epidemic of the seventeenth century, the relics of the Saint were officially relocated in 1992. Opening to the public only on request, for crèches contests and the 2 Days of Heritage.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
comment: Come and take advantage of the books available at the Ceyreste Public Library
shortDescription: Come and take advantage of the books available at the Ceyreste Public Library
description:
Novels, comics, poetry, theatre... there's something for everyone!

Departmental Library Network Library.

label: Eglise Saint-Jean-Marie Vianney (Camp-Major)
comment:
The church of St. John Mary Vianney was built in two parts.
The first part was built in 1927, it was a small chapel with a central nave. It was enlarged in 1930, in an Arts Deco style.
shortDescription:
The church of St. John Mary Vianney was built in two parts.
The first part was built in 1927, it was a small chapel with a central nave. It was enlarged in 1930, in an Arts Deco style.
description:
Reception: Tuesday: 3pm to 5pm - Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday 9am to 11am
