UNESCO listed the art of Armenian cross-stones in November 2010 as intangible cultural heritage.

label: Médiathèque Jean d'Ormesson
comment: Large media library of Marignane
shortDescription: Large media library of Marignane
description:
Built by the architect Jean Doldourian and inaugurated by Jean D'Ormesson, the media library extends its 2000 square meters on two levels in a green area

This beautiful facility offers a real showcase for over 100,000 written references and 10,000 audio documents.

They can be consulted on site or borrowed

The Media Library is organized with an adult area with comics and mangas and a youth area

Thematic exhibitions and conferences are held regularly.

label: Bibliothèque du Merlan
comment: Located on the site of the shopping centre, the Merlan cultural centre houses the library but also the Merlan theatre and a BMDP. The librarians offer cultural activities and services for all ages.
shortDescription: Located on the site of the shopping centre, the Merlan cultural centre houses the library but also the Merlan theatre and a BMDP. The librarians offer cultural activities and services for all ages.
description:
As of Wednesday, May 19, 2021, Marseille's libraries will continue to welcome you but will adapt to the new sanitary measures linked to Covid-19 and will try to meet your expectations and needs as best as possible.

RECEPTION CONDITIONS

- Wearing a mask is compulsory for children aged 11 and over,

- Disabled people can be exempted from wearing a mask on presentation of a medical certificate,

- Hand washing with hydroalcoholic gel is compulsory, available to users,

- Respect for distancing,

- Respect for the directions of circulation in the spaces,

- Airing the conference room and the Alcazar auditorium for half an hour between each event.

SERVICES OFFERED

- Loan and return of documents in the libraries.

- Reopening of the document return terminals

- Click and collect in all open libraries:

Log on to the bmvr.marseille.fr website under the heading my account with your user number and your secret code (day + year of birth unless you have personalized it).

Choose the document you are interested in and click on reserve (on the right). The document must be available (DI) or on loan. You can reserve up to 5 documents. Choose the location of withdrawal.

When you receive a confirmation email with a deadline, your reservation is available!

- The external return boxes are available 24 hours a day in the Alcazar and La Grognarde libraries. The Castellane return box is available from 9am to 5pm from Tuesday to Friday and on Monday from 1pm to 5pm.

- Appointments can be made for consultation in the Rare and Precious Materials department at the following e-mail address: dgac-patrimoine-bmvr@marseille.fr, and at the Ile aux Livres at the following e-mail address: ileauxlivres-bmvr@marseille.fr.


THE FOLLOWING SERVICES ARE ONCE AGAIN AVAILABLE

- Consultation of the press,
- Consultation of documents on site,
- Access to computers,
- Access to the reprography service (computers and photocopiers),
- Staying on site.

CULTURAL PROGRAM
 
- The cultural program starts again on May 19th.

- Information on the program available on the website of the libraries and dedicated social networks,

 - Conferences filmed online on our Youtube channel.


OPENING HOURS AND CAPACITY OF THE LIBRARIES

Merlan Library

Tuesday, Thursday, Friday: 1-6pm,
Wednesday and Saturday: 10am-1pm and 2pm-6pm (except Saturday 22 May)

Simultaneous capacity: 100 people.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Located on the site of the Carrefour shopping centre, the Merlan cultural centre houses the library, the Merlan theatre and a local municipal office. The librarians offer cultural activities and services for all ages, but above all a warm welcome and personalised advice whatever your request.

  
 Services offered :

- 2000 m2 air-conditioned on 2 levels with a generalist, multi-media offer of - 130 000 regularly updated documents. [to find out more]
 numerous workstations with the possibility of plugging in your laptop.
-  internet and wifi in free access
 - 21 computers connected to the internet (USB key accepted)
-  The cyber-space to research, play on your own or in a group or learn thanks to the free computer workshops (reservation at 04 91 12 93 67)
-  the 70-seat auditorium to watch a film, follow a lecture, take part in a workshop, listen to a story....
- the hall to listen to our concerts and follow our shows (see our newsletter)
-  relaxation areas with armchairs and poufs to read, relax or chat with friends.
 - the space dedicated to babies with furniture and adapted collections
-  the reserve with 6500 books for communities and teachers.
 - free access to our reserves to discover and borrow the document immediately

label: Musée Martin Duby
description: The Martin Duby museum, concerning art and popular traditions, offers regular temporary exhibitions of quality.

label: Lac Zola
comment: Lake Zola, the "little brother" of Lake Bimont located a few kilometers upstream, is accessible on foot from the Bimont parking lot, the Bibémus parking lot or Le Tholonet.
shortDescription: Lake Zola, the "little brother" of Lake Bimont located a few kilometers upstream, is accessible on foot from the Bimont parking lot, the Bibémus parking lot or Le Tholonet.
description:
Lake Zola is an artificial water reservoir created following the construction of the Zola Dam. A building realized by François Zola (1795-1847), Italian engineer and father of Emile Zola, and finished after his death in 1854. It is one of the first arch dam in Europe, it retains the northern runoff of the Sainte Victoire mountain, channeled by the Infernet. But the project took a long time to be completed. In 1838, the Colonel Marquis de Gallifet asserted his rights as lord owner of the waters of the Infernet and opposed the project of the dam Zola, adopted by the city of Aix. The last straw: the castle and the park are now the headquarters of the experimental centre (irrigation processes) of the Canal de Provence company. The available water flow of 1m3/s is insufficient for the needs of the town and the market gardens. A second project, the Verdon Canal, was completed in 1876. The Verdon canal was in turn gradually replaced, from 1969 to 1980, by the Canal de Provence, which diverts the pure waters of the Verdon in large quantities. Today, the Zola dam is half emptied, but remains maintained. It can be used as a back-up capacity for an emergency draining of the Bimont. The Zola dam was decommissioned in 1980, but not destroyed

The Zola dam is one of the first arch dams in Europe. With a height of 37.25 m, the capacity of the dam was originally 2,500,000 cubic metres of water.
Surface area: approximately 4ha, i.e. 200,000m3 of water (332.00m NGF).

It is strictly forbidden to access the bank and to swim in this reservoir, for safety and environmental reasons.

label: Eglise Sainte-Madeleine
comment: Romanesque style church.
shortDescription: Romanesque style church.
description: This 13th century Romanesque church, renovated in 1874, was built with stones from the Convent of the Knights Templar. The 14th century bell tower on the cross-section has a pyramidal spire.  Classical-period seigniorial chapels. Two Romanesque Corinthian capitals are re-used in the parish church. Monumental organs dating from 1956.

label: Moulin Camoin
comment: Dating from the 17th century, this mill was first renovated in 1936 for its shell and in 1970 for the roof and wings.
shortDescription: Dating from the 17th century, this mill was first renovated in 1936 for its shell and in 1970 for the roof and wings.
description: It will be entrusted by President Augustin Camoin to the Syndicat d'Initiative, which will turn it into the Musée du Vieil Allau. The inside of the mill cannot be visited, but we can observe through its glass door, a "scene" of the life of a miller and millerwoman in the 17th century.

label: Médiathèque
description:
Lending and consultation of books, CDs, tapes, music scores, CD ROMs, magazines, DVDs. Internet access.
Free registration for residents of the town, those who attend school there and those who work there. For the others, 31 euros (individual registration) or 51 euros (family registration). Documents to be provided: an identity document.

label: Pavillon de Grignan
comment:
A listed historical monument.
Built around 1575, this small château was originally a hunting lodge. It belonged first to the Craponne family and then, up until 1853, to the Comtes de Grignan.
shortDescription:
A listed historical monument.
Built around 1575, this small château was originally a hunting lodge. It belonged first to the Craponne family and then, up until 1853, to the Comtes de Grignan.
description:
The oldest part was probably restored during the reign of Louis XV as it is in the style of that period. The other part, dating from 1792, bears the mark of the Louis XVI style. It now belongs to the town and is used for receptions but its last private owner was the well-known Concorde trial pilot André Turcat.

The Pavillon de Grignan hosts the Nuits d’Istres festival each year.

label: Ilot Post Tenebras Lux
comment: The Calvinist inscription and motto of Geneva "Post Tenebras Lux 1571" (After the Darkness the Light) appears on the entablature of this remarkable Renaissance mullioned window.
shortDescription: The Calvinist inscription and motto of Geneva "Post Tenebras Lux 1571" (After the Darkness the Light) appears on the entablature of this remarkable Renaissance mullioned window.
description: Opposite the majestic façade of the Hôtel de Manville was a large residence dated 1571 (known as the Logis de Brisson-Peyre); all that remains is a muntin window whose entablature bears the Calvinist inscription 'Post Tenebras Lux 1571' (Light After Darkness). This affirmation of Protestant faith suggests the existence of an oratory of reformed worship. The reformed religion had many supporters in Les Baux, thanks to the tolerance of the then Baron of Les Baux, Honoré des Martins.

label: Les Calvaires
comment: The Calvaries of Orgon.
shortDescription: The Calvaries of Orgon.
description:
Croix de la Durance (The Cross of the Durance)
Together with the Cross of the Grey Penitents, this cross dominates the Orgon landscape. It stands above the Durance Valley, on the Port Vieux cliff, as a symbol of Christian faith visible by villagers and travellers from many miles away.
The Cross at the Porte la Durance
This cross overlooks the Porte de la Durance fountain; here is a drawing of the cross by René Fages in the monograph he co-wrote with Louis Tertian.
The Cross of the Grey Penitents of Avignon
This cross was erected in Beauregard in 1903, after being blessed in the Carmelites of Avignon Church a week earlier. Cut from a 10 metre-long oak, it was first displayed in Beauregard Chapel; there were 6,000 people on the hill on that Sunday 23 August 1903. The pedestal is 2.8 metres high and was made of dressed stone from the Jury Véran quarries in Ménerbes. Four marble plaques, made by the sculptor Galinier, contain engravings of Latin inscriptions, a poem in French and another in the Mistralian language, testifying to the influence of the Félibrige association. The Cross had to be taken down in April 2009 as it was swaying dangerously during the Mistral winds. The municipal council decided to replace it. The new cross was identical to the original and was put in place in December 2009. 
The wooden cross at the entrance to La Pinède cemetery
Until quite recently, this cross was still at the start of Rue Sous le Fort, but was moved when the road was repaired. It is now located at the entrance to La Pinède cemetery on the Route de Beauregard.
The cross on the forecourt of the parish church
On the terrace, near the Town Hall, at the bottom of the church, a decorated cast iron cross sits on top of a stone alter where the priest of the commune would officiate in certain circumstances. This cross replaced an old wooden cross which supported a very large Christ. In the middle of the last century, this Christ was transformed into a recumbent statue and moved to the church, under the altar of Sacré-Cœur Chapel.
The Croix des Missions (Cross of the Missions)
This cross was blessed in 1902 and placed at the top of the fronton of the parish church. The words 'Mission de 1902' are engraved on its base.
The Faubourg Sainte-Anne Cross
This decorated cross is embedded in a stone base on the corner of Faubourg Sainte-Anne and the Montée du Paradis.
The Place de la Conillière Cross
This is the most remarkable cross in the village. It was placed on a large stone base in memory of those who died in the plague of 1721.
The Cross of Saint Roch Chapel
This cross stands by the side of the road leading to Saint Roch Chapel. It was erected in 1803 as testimony of the religious revival that followed the Revolution.
The Chemin de de la Mine Cross
This decorated wrought iron cross is located by the side of the Chemin de la Mine.
The Cross of the Perdigale
This cross marked one of the stations of the Rogation processions to the pumps, to ensure the success of the cereal harvests. 
Cross of the Mas de Bréguier
This cross is on private property on the Route d'Eygalières.

label: Hôtel de Ville d'Aix-en-Provence
comment: The first town hall of Aix-en-Provence was located on the Place de l'Annonerie-Vieille. In the 14th century, in the years following the reunion of the Bourg Saint-Sauveur and the city of the counts, it was moved to the Painted Gate.
shortDescription: The first town hall of Aix-en-Provence was located on the Place de l'Annonerie-Vieille. In the 14th century, in the years following the reunion of the Bourg Saint-Sauveur and the city of the counts, it was moved to the Painted Gate.
description:
The first town hall in Aix en Provence stood on Place de l'Annonerie-Vieille. 

In the 14th century, after Bourg Saint-Sauveur merged with the City of the Counts, it was moved near the Portail Peint (Painted Gate). 
The façade, inspired by Italian palaces, was designed by Pavillon, with the assistance of the sculptors Rambot and Fossé.

The rich ornamentation of the frontage – statues of angels, and busts of counts of Provence and King Louis XIV – has suffered the ravages of time and the Revolution.

The entrance is framed by two double Doric columns linked by an entablature which support a fine wrought-iron balcony dating from 1661. 

Each leaf of the wooden door is decorated with a lion's head knocker designed by Pierre Pavillon. This door leads to the square inner courtyard. 

At the back is a porch supporting a state balcony.

The twin winding staircases lead to the magnificent Salle des Etats de Provence (House of Representatives). Its decoration, dating from the period between 1716 and 1732, was destroyed in 1792. 

The present paintings illustrating the history of the city and of Provence were done between 1899 and 1905.
streetAddress: ["Mairie d'Aix en Provence", "Place De l'Hôtel de Ville"]

label: Domaine du Lac
comment: After years of procedures and colossal administrative work, the Domaine du Lac was transferred to the public domain of the municipality on 1 August 2007.
shortDescription: After years of procedures and colossal administrative work, the Domaine du Lac was transferred to the public domain of the municipality on 1 August 2007.
description:
After years of administrative procedures and a colossal work, Domaine du Lac was transferred to the public domain of the municipality on August 1, 2007. 
The waterways of the Domaine du Lac constitute a beautiful, natural area. The inhabitants of Saint Martin will have to wait a little longer to walk safely in its surroundings.
In fact, rehabilitation started a few months ago and should continue until the good weather sets in.
In the meantime, large projects are in the offing: further strengthening of banks, repair of the pathways, installation of a wooden fence around the lake, planting of new trees... The mound will be redesigned and landscaped, and all the green spaces will be restored. In addition, numerous benches and bins will be installed.
Finally, in this attractive natural area, dogs must be leashed, and dog excrement bags will be made available to owners.

label: Hôtel de Boisgelin
description:
This mansion is on Place des Quatre-Dauphins.
It was built in 1650 by Pierre Pavillon and Jean-Claude Rambot by order of King Louis XIV who permitted the archbishop Michel Mazarin to enlarge the city southwards, on land previously owned by the Order of St John of Malta.


Noble families lived in the mansion in the past. 
The courtyard and garden reflect the Parisian model (identical to the Marais district in Paris). The entire monument is built of stone from the Bibémus quarry, where Cézanne painted. This stone is an orange-yellow colour. The mansion took three years to build. 


Inside, the ceilings are painted and plaster reliefs highlight the sculptures. 

On the north side of the courtyard are the outhouses and orangeries with wide basket-handle arches, and on the east, the fine carved door. A staircase of polychrome marble marquetry, inspired by the Versailles models, was built in 1875. 

This mansion was bought in 1937 by the Caisse des Dépôts et Consignations. It used to be a love nest for Alain Delon and Mireille Darc.

Hôtel de Boisgelin has often been used as a film set, notably for The Horseman on the Roof (2005) by Jean-Paul Rappeneau with Olivier Martinez, and more recently, in May 2009, A View of Love by Nicole Garcia with Jean Dujardin.

label: Aqueduc de Parrouvier
description:
The small town crowds around the foot of an imposing mediaeval castle that was altered in the 17th century. 

Behind the castle, at the bottom of the Pas de l'Etroit valley, stand three arches of a Roman aqueduct. The exact date of its construction is not known. 

The aqueduct brought water from La Traconnade to Aix. It was 40 km long. The conduit was supported by bridges on solid walls and arches to cross the valleys along the route between Jouques and Meyrargues

label: Parc de la Gare
comment: The station park named "Esplanade de la Gare".
shortDescription: The station park named "Esplanade de la Gare".
description: The Parc de la Gare invites you to relax by walking along the flowered paths, planted with various species. A panel entitled "Plants and trees with edible fruits" invites you to discover the vegetation of the park, a playful way to learn about the plant world.

label: Lavoir couvert
comment: Washhouse without water.
shortDescription: Washhouse without water.
description: This former covered washhouse was restored in 1996 has a frame on square pillars. It is one of the rare said standing sinks where women washed up.

label: Chapelle Saint Clair
description: Situated in the north of the commune's territory, on a hill from which it eventually took its name, this chapel was built by order of Bringier-Monnier in 1542 and was then called Sainte-Croix. A few years ago, a team of volunteers restored this chapel, which was inaugurated and blessed on 16 September 1991 and in which a mass is regularly said.

label: Cathédrale de la Major
comment: The new cathedral  "La Major" was built by Léon Vaudoyer between 1852 and 1893 in a romano-byzantine style.
shortDescription: The new cathedral  "La Major" was built by Léon Vaudoyer between 1852 and 1893 in a romano-byzantine style.
description:
Its exotic style and sumptuous interior decoration are reminiscent of Orient churches. It is the largest cathedral built since the Middle Ages. It is located on the site of the baptistery of the Gauls " les Gaules" and adjoins the former cathedral " La Major", which was cut down by two spans in the mid-19th century. Worthseing : the statues of Botinelly, this "Carli", the altars of "Cantini" and the tomb of " Saint Eugène de Mazenod". Parish priest : Alain Ottonello.ouverture 

Opening times of the cathedral : every day from 10am to 7pm in summer and from 10am to 6pm in winter. Closed on tuesday.

Parish reception : at "Saint-Laurent" church from tuesday to saturday from 2 to 6:30 pm
Tel : 04 91 90 01 82
Rector of the cathedral : André Mariotti
Parish priest : Alain Ottonello

Masses are celebrated at "Saint-Laurent" church and at "Les Accoules" church :
At "Saint-Laurent" church : Tuesday and Thursday at 6:00 pm, sunday and feast day at 10:30 am.
At "Les Accoules" church : on saturday and the day before the feast day at 6 pm.

label: Eglise Saint Laurent de la Bourdonnière
comment: In 1843, the former chapel of La Bourdonnière was erected as a parish. Built in the 17th century, it was renovated and enlarged in 1841 by the Sauvaire family who owned it.
shortDescription: In 1843, the former chapel of La Bourdonnière was erected as a parish. Built in the 17th century, it was renovated and enlarged in 1841 by the Sauvaire family who owned it.
description: It was in 1847, that were solemnly laid the first stones of the St. Laurent Church. In October 1849, the building was already covered, and in December 1850 the work was completed and Bishop de Mazenod blessed the new building.Today Parish Church of the Logis Neuf.

label: L'église Saint-Martin-de-Castillon
comment: Saint-Martin parish church in Paradou!
shortDescription: Saint-Martin parish church in Paradou!
description:
A text from 981 mentions the existence of the Priory of Saint Martin from the 10th century and the endowment made to the Abbey of Montmajour by the Lord of Les Baux, Pons le jeune, of land located near the "church of Saint Martin en Félaurie", Félaurie being the ancient name of the southern slopes of the Alpilles.
It was supplanted for a time by the castle chapel of St. Mary of Castillon before resuming its function. It will undergo the ups and downs of the conflicts between the parishes of Les Baux, Maussane and St-Martin-de-Castillon before becoming the church of the village of Paradou.

label: Vallon de Riaux Haut
description: Here the routes of several artists intersect. Cézanne painted Maisons à l'Estaque, a farmhouse that was at the time the birthplace of Pierre Puget. Braque, in 1908, when he was immersed in Cézanne's lesson, depicts the railway viaduct. A moving encounter between teacher and pupil, 25 years apart. Derain also painted a lot in this area. It was also here that Macke came, following in Braque's footsteps.

label: Arènes
comment: Municipal arena of Noves.
shortDescription: Municipal arena of Noves.
description:
Throughout the year, and particularly during the summer season, many events take place in the bullring in the thirteen municipalities of the territory: bullfighting events, shows, festivities

Information is available at the Terre de Provence Tourist Office in Châteaurenard and in the various Tourist Information Offices.

label: Cimetière
comment: Landscaped cemetery near the Saint Vérédème Chapel
shortDescription: Landscaped cemetery near the Saint Vérédème Chapel
description: Cemetery classified as landscaped. Chapel of Saint Vérédème from the 11th century.

label: Espace Benjamin Priaulet
description: Located behind the town hall of Maussane les Alpilles, the Espace Benjamin Priaulet is a shady place where benches are available for resting.

label: Anse des Sablettes
comment: Small sandy cove surrounded by rocks, in the direction of Goudes, equipped with toilets.
shortDescription: Small sandy cove surrounded by rocks, in the direction of Goudes, equipped with toilets.
description: Before arriving at Les Goudes.

label: Eglise Saint-Pierre-ès-Liens d'Aurons
description: The church of Saint-Pierre-ès-Liens d'Aurons is on the Place Louis Estienne, in the heart of the village. The neo-classical tympanum stands out from the sobriety of the building to symbolize its entrance. Note the polychrome inscription (colours) "Haec est Domus Domini": "Here is the house of the Lord".

label: Château d'If
comment: In 1516, François I, King of France, stopped in Marseille after the victory of Marignan. From the island of If, he studied the city's defenses and noted that nothing protected it against invasion.
shortDescription: In 1516, François I, King of France, stopped in Marseille after the victory of Marignan. From the island of If, he studied the city's defenses and noted that nothing protected it against invasion.
description:
He then ordered the construction of a fortress on the island. It was only in 1524, after an attack by Charles V, that the first walls of the castle were built to protect the access to the port of Marseille. The construction of the castle was completed in July 1531.

The dreaded Château d'If was never attacked. Thus, the prison function of the château d'If began only a few years after the end of its construction, in the middle of the 16th century. The geographical location of the castle and its architecture made it an ideal prison from which it seemed impossible to escape. The first prisoner was probably the knight Anselme in 1580, then Mirabeau locked up in 1774 on a lettre de cachet. General Kléber was the last famous prisoner, but it was after his death - assassinated in Cairo in 1800 - that he was repatriated to France. His coffin remained in the Château d'If for 18 years.
Following the riots of June 1848, 120 people were imprisoned in the Château d'If. The inscription "Hôtel du peuple souverain" (Hotel of the Sovereign People) which appears above the old access door to the courtyard, dates from this period.
304 prisoners were crammed into If after the coup d'état of December 2, 1852, while awaiting deportation to Algiers and French Guiana.

The legends of the Château d'If 
Over the centuries, legends and reality have marked out the history of If. Even before the castle was built, the first supposed prisoner was the only Asian rhinoceros to have touched European soil at that time. It is said that the gift of King Emmanuel of Portugal to Pope Leo X stopped over on the island of Yew during his long journey. For the anecdote, the pope received his gift not alive but stuffed, the ship carrying it having sunk in the bay of Genoa. 
The visitor accosting no longer discerns what is reality or imagination. In front of him stands a very real fortress, just like the will of François I to assert the power of the French royalty in Provence. 

The Count of Monte Cristo
During his childhood, Dumas heard his father speak of the Château d'If as a place dedicated to the memory of Kleber. In the 19th century, the prison was infamous for its squalid and unsanitary conditions. He visited it for the first time in December 1834, during a trip to the Mediterranean. When he established the plot of his story, between the success of the hero in Rome and his revenge in Paris, he placed the beginning of the plot in Marseille.

In 1842, during a boat trip to the Tuscan archipelago with Prince Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte, Dumas sailed around the small island of Monte Cristo, near the island of Elba. Legend has it that in the Middle Ages, monks chased away an evil dragon. Once they became masters of the archipelago, they collected high royalties on these islands and would have constituted a real treasure, long sought by pirates. 
In memory of this discovery, he promised to name one of his novels Monte Cristo, a title that would also echo the land of his Dominican ancestors.
The island of If with the whole archipelago of Frioul is part of the National Park of Calanques.

The guided tour is offered on site every day at 11:15 am, 2:30 pm and 4 pm. A booklet for children and a visit application are also available free of charge.

label: Parc Départemental de l'Arbois
comment: This 800-hectare estate is located in the heart of the 4,500-hectare Arbois plateau, southwest of Aix en Provence. It is a varied area, alternating pine forest around the Europôle with typical Mediterranean vegetation on the rest of the plateau.
shortDescription: This 800-hectare estate is located in the heart of the 4,500-hectare Arbois plateau, southwest of Aix en Provence. It is a varied area, alternating pine forest around the Europôle with typical Mediterranean vegetation on the rest of the plateau.
description:
This site is crossed by some temporary streams but above all it is marked by a strong mineral presence, a remarkable fauna and flora which give it a unique character.

If you are lucky, you will be able to see a couple of Bonelli's eagles on this site. Arbois is one of the rare sites in the Bouches-du-Rhône that welcomes these rare and protected birds.

The General Council is developing sports programs on this site, including archery, mountain bike trails and orienteering. In addition, this site is home to the former horses of the departmental guard.anéenne on the rest of the plateau.

label: Collégiale Saint-Laurent
description: Situated "outside the walls" and built by the will of the Salonais, the collegiate church of Saint-Laurent expresses the spiritual power of the archbishops of Arles. Its first stone was laid in 1344 by Jean de Cardonne in place of a chapel with a cemetery next to it. Following numerous interruptions in the construction campaigns (plagues, invasion of the city by armed bands, collapses), the building was completed nearly a century and a half later, in the 1480's. Because of its status as a collegiate church, its imposing silhouette is above all a visible sign of the archbishops' hold over the city, as they had full authority over the college of canons who presided at the services. Gothic art had difficulty in conquering Provence. However, Saint-Laurent was inspired by it in its octagonal bell tower, but above all by the vaulting of its nave over a cross vault, which allowed the building to rise significantly. The reminiscences of the Romanesque style are still very present however: few stone hollows (thick buttresses, reduced openings - this last observation can also be explained by the desire to protect the building from the mistral and heat - rarity of sculpted decorations). Inside, the plan and elevation are remarkable in their balance: a single nave, without aisles or ambulatory, but flanked by 11 side chapels. Exterior renovation in 2008 and 2009

label: Les Mines de Saint Savournin
description:
Saint-Savournin is one of the many communes that make up the coalfield of Provence, of which Gardanne is perhaps the most emblematic, with the closure of the last mine shaft in February 2003. This basin extends from the Etang de Berre in the west to the Arc valley towards Trets in the east, passing through the Chains of Estaque, Etoile and Huveaune in the south
As early as the 16th century, there were coal quarries in Saint-Savournin. At the end of the 17th century, lignite was better exploited and was used, among other things, for cement works and other tile factories, soap factories and refineries. It was also used to heat lime kilns, particularly in the Valdonne area, below the Valentine, on the Bouilladisse road. Around 1790, there were nearly three hundred workers in the Saint-Savournin mines
In the 18th century, the coal was transported to Marseille on mules. Two itineraries were used, the sentier du Terme (the current Allauch road after Cadolive) or longer but safer, the old Aix-en-Provence road which reached Aubagne via the Huveaune valley. In 1863, a railway line was built between Aubagne and La Barque (current commune of Fuveau) to serve the mines. In 1868, a track was opened between Aubagne and Valdonne, where a station was built in 1870. This train will also carry passengers until 1939 and will be definitively suppressed in 1960

The main wells were dug between the 19th and 20th centuries
The Dubreuil well in 1820 (70 meters deep)
The Saint-Pierre well in 1842 (56 metres)
The Castellane well in 1844 (150 metres)
The Léonie well in 1866 (203 metres)
The Saint-Joseph well in 1866 (193 meters)
The Notre-Dame-du-Château well in 1871 (250 meters)
The Armand shaft in 1891 and definitively closed in 1954
The Germain shaft was opened in 1927 (600 meters) and closed in 1961.

label: Bastide de Trébillane
comment: Trébillane, a beautiful building dating from the 12th century, was initially a seigniorial castle, which was transformed into an important agricultural estate (13th century). Trébillane was restored by the municipality of Cabriès which made it the house of the associations
shortDescription: Trébillane, a beautiful building dating from the 12th century, was initially a seigniorial castle, which was transformed into an important agricultural estate (13th century). Trébillane was restored by the municipality of Cabriès which made it the house of the associations
description: Trébillane is a very beautiful building dating from the 12th century, it was initially a seigneurial castle, which in the course of time has transformed into an important agricultural domain (XIII ° century). Trébillane was restored by the municipality of Cabriès which made it the home of the associations. In 1993, L'Oustau per Toùti (the house for all) was inaugurated and became a meeting place for the artistic and cultural associations of Cabriès.

label: Eglise St Césaire
description:
Date: 1450
Era: Middle Ages, 19th century
Type: Religious architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a regional Historic Monument in 1941
The former chapel of the Convent of the Great Augustinians, Saint-Césaire is now the only church in the La Roquette district to still be consecrated. 
It is of southern Gothic style and dates from the mid-15th century; however, it was modified several times, particularly during the 19th century.
It houses the tomb of Quiqueran de Beaujeu, Grand Prior of the Order of Malta in the 17th century. 
Its vocation as a mariners' parish can be seen in some of the works it contains, some of which come from the other two former parish churches in the district, Saint Laurent and Sainte Croix.
Its name, Saint-Césaire, after the 6th century Bishop of Arles, only dates back to 1839, when it was re-established as a place of worship.
The building' was originally constructed, in 1450, in the southern Gothic style.
On the side-wings of the façade, which was modified in the 19th century, it is easy to see where the the church's two bays were destroyed during a fire in the 17th century. 
It is still possible to see the remains of the Cloister of the Great Augustinians near the church. 
Inside, the building consists of a nave with four ogival vaulted bays, flanked with side chapels. 
The chancel, which was transformed in the early 19th century, has an octagonal cupola roof with lanterns (17th century). 
The church has taken in several items of furniture from the district's other two churches, which were destroyed in the Revolution. 
At the back of the chancel is the 1638 old painting by Trophime Bigot from the main altar of Saint Laurent Church
Saint Césaire is the only church in Arles to still have some of its original floor, which features coats of arms and funeral epitaphs. 
In 1866, François Mader presented the church with the organ loft at the back of the nave; it is the only one in Arles currently in working order. 
This instrument, which replaces an older model, has a Neo-Gothic organ case with three turrets and pinnacles. 
The historiated stained glass windows bear the words Guilbert d'Anelle, 1875, Avignon.

label: Eglise des Grands Carmes
comment: Church classified as a Historic Monument in 1983 for its interior and registered as a Historic Monument for its facades and roofs.
shortDescription: Church classified as a Historic Monument in 1983 for its interior and registered as a Historic Monument for its facades and roofs.
description:
In the 13th century, religious from "Mount Carmel" arrived in Marseille and settled in the "Aygalades". First int he caves called the " l'Ermitage", then in the village bathed in the living waters which gave their name to the site, the abundant waters. In 1285, they founded a monastery within the city walls.
Thanks to the generosity of the "Monteux family", a first church was built. Having fallen into disuse, it was rebuilt at the beginning of the 17th century. Bishop F. Ragueneau laid the first stone in 1603. The octogonal bell tower was completed in 1640. The church was very popular and many corporations were held in its chapels. Processions and festivals take place on the square.
During the Revolution, it was used for patriotic meetings. The church was closed, but its bells remained. During the 19th century, the church was reduced by a third of its length due to the demolition of the choir's dome, which was threatening to collapse.
In 1898, after its refurbishment, the parish priest Décanis undertook the redesign of its decoration , covering it with paintings and introducing more than 300 statues, of all origins. To be seen : the woodwork and stalls with paintings by "Serre", the high altar by "Duparc" and a beautiful pulpit.. 
Parish priest : Alain Ottonello.

label: Eglise Saint Vincent
comment: The 12th century building is characteristic of Baussian constructions as it is half troglodytic. Inside, splendid modern stained glass windows by Max Ingrand were donated by Prince Rainier III of Monaco in 1962.
shortDescription: The 12th century building is characteristic of Baussian constructions as it is half troglodytic. Inside, splendid modern stained glass windows by Max Ingrand were donated by Prince Rainier III of Monaco in 1962.
description: The old village had three churches: Saint-André in the La Fontaine Valley, the first parish church, abandoned in 1481 and since disappeared; Notre Dame du Château or Sainte-Catherine Chapel (12th-16th centuries), the castle chapel in the citadel enclosure, and Saint-Vincent Church, the former priory which depended on Saint-Paul de Mausole in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence. To the right of the portal, hidden behind a pillar, the Provençal poet Frédéric Mistral is said to have engraved his name in the stone, together with the name of his home village of Maillane. Inside, visitors can see modern stained glass windows by Max Ingrand (1955) given to the commune by Prince Rainier III of Monaco in 1962. In the Chapel dug into the rock is the chariot from the Midnight Mass Pastrage ceremony, celebrated on 24 December every year in the presence of Arlésiennes in traditional dress; this chariot is used to transport the newborn lamb presented by the shepherds. Saint Vincent Church is now an almost square building, which faces east in accordance with tradition. Built in the 12th century, the building was extended for the first time in the 16th century and then modified in the 17th and 19th centuries. It was restored in the 1960s. This monument is characteristic of Les Baux constructions, thanks to its semi-troglodyte southern section. The façade exterior was heavily modified by 19th century restoration work, which transformed the staircase which ran along the wall. Above the portal and a semi-circular window, there is a very beautiful sculpture of a lion. The Lantern of the Dead on the southern flank is an elegant circular tower topped with a cupola adorned with gargoyles; there, according to tradition, a flame once burned when a resident of Les Baux died. The large broken barrel vaulted nave was extended eastwards in 1609 without disturbing the overall Romanesque harmony, which is completed by a flat chevet. The Chapel of Manville, built by Claude de Manville and his wife Philippine de Brion in the second quarter of the 16th century, still has some beautiful Renaissance architectural features: an attractive vault adorned with liernes and tercerons (a copy of the one constructed in the Château Chapel in 1520), with the arms of the Manville family on the keystone, a window where visitors can admire, on the cornerstone, the remains of a 16th century stained glass window representing a crucifixion (Christ on the cross is surrounded by the Virgin, Saint John, the sun and the moon), and a beautiful archway leading to the next chapel, Saint Sebastian. The Neo-Gothic style monument erected to the memory of the deceased in the Manville family dates from 1906. The tomb, which features a princess lying on a divan, is made of Carrara marble. The first chapel, starting from the back of the church, to the right on entering, has ogival vaults and contains baptismal fonts whose basin could date from the 17th century. Before entering the second chapel, admire the vault of the side-nave (serrated décor on the transverse arch and cornice, dating from the 12th century). The second chapel was dedicated to Saint Mark. It contains an ancient tomb and a basin, dug into the rock. A beautiful tombstone, which must have once been on the church floor, was embedded in the first pillar of the nave in the early 19th century. It belongs to a gentleman, perhaps from the Court of Jeanne de Laval, who died in Les Baux in October 1467. He is portrayed on bended knee, hands together, dressed in the clothes of the time. The last chapel was that of the Brotherhood of sheep shearers and the brotherhood of vine-growers. The keystone and corbels which support the ogival arches bear the emblems of these two Brotherhoods: vine leaves and shearers. The stained glass window portrays a sheep shearer.

label: Médiathèque - Bibliothèque Municipale
description: Novels, documentaries, CDs, videos, books in foreign languages, music, albums, children's literature.

label: Parc Départemental de Roques Hautes
comment: Below the Sainte-Victoire Mountain, the Parc Départemental de Roques Hautes straddles the municipalities of Saint-Antonin-sur-Bayon, Beaurecueil, Le Tholonet and Aix-en-Provence.
shortDescription: Below the Sainte-Victoire Mountain, the Parc Départemental de Roques Hautes straddles the municipalities of Saint-Antonin-sur-Bayon, Beaurecueil, Le Tholonet and Aix-en-Provence.
description:
With a surface area of 700 hectares, you can enjoy a panorama of rugged terrain and ochre colors (red, orange, yellow) and rock.

Paul Cézanne, easel on the shoulder, then Emile Zola immortalized it many times.

Roques-Hautes is also ruins, a deposit of dinosaur eggs classified as a nature reserve (forbidden to the public) and a marble quarry from the breccia of Tholonet. 

It is also 25 hectares of tree plantations - almond trees, fig trees, truffle oaks, olive trees producing an AOC (Appellation d'Origine Contrôlée) oil - which attest to the strong involvement of the Department, which bought the site between 1973 and 1988, in the preservation and rehabilitation of the site.

Management of the natural area : Domaine du Conseil Général
Classified site

label: Fontaine du Pélican
description:
It was built in 1769 by Jean-Baptiste Louche, master mason in Pélissanne and Bernus, master sculptor in Salon-de-Provence
Its clover-shaped basin surrounds a column surmounted by a sculpture representing the city's coat of arms: a pelican and its young in a nest.
The fountain has been classified as a historical monument since 1942.
It is made of Calissanne stone (local stone).

label: Les Sources des Nayes
description:
At Les Sources des Nayes, there were traces of a Roman camp.
Today, the crown of greenery that surrounds the springs welcomes many visitors every Sunday. Several springs offer fresh and limpid water.
Access regulated in summer.

label: Rue du Château
description: Located close to the mediaeval fortress of King René, the Rue des Halles, near the Jewish quarter and the Hôtel de Ville, contains some superb 16th and 17th century buildings. Take the time to stroll along this magnificent mediaeval street which is still just as charming as ever!

label: Abbaye Sainte-Marie de Pierredon
comment: Built on a simple plan, it is a Romanesque chapel, sober and modest. It has two bays and a cul de four. The door is round-arched with a keystone. The chapel has a small square bell tower.
shortDescription: Built on a simple plan, it is a Romanesque chapel, sober and modest. It has two bays and a cul de four. The door is round-arched with a keystone. The chapel has a small square bell tower.
description:
This rural chapel is attached to the Order of Chalais of Benedictine Obedience.
The chapel is one of the last in this Order, after Valbonne. It is Romanesque in style; the monastery is still visible, although it has been encompassed into the buildings constructed over the centuries.
In 1205, Michel de Mouriès, Bishop of Arles, gave Sainte-Marie-de-Pierredon church to Jourdan and Guillaume, Abbots of Chalais and Boscodon respectively, so they could found an abbey with one Abbot and twelve monks.
It is a sombre, modest Romanesque chapel constructed according to simple plans. It has two bays and a semi-dome. The door is a semi-circular cupola brick arch. The chapel has a small square bell tower. The remains of a later adjoining priory can still be seen.

label: Bassin de Saint Christophe
comment: Durance river water decantation works for the city of Marseille.
shortDescription: Durance river water decantation works for the city of Marseille.
description:
Situated in a natural valley between the communes of Rognes and Roque d'Anthéron, 3 km from the hydroelectric plant of Saint-Estève-Janson, where the Marseille canal has its source today, Saint-Christophe is the first treatment plant on its route.

The surface area of the basin is 20 hectares (a basin 800 m long and 249 m wide). It is an ideal place to rest, have a quiet picnic, or simply walk or cycle around its 2.3 km contour.

label: Cours du 4 Septembre
comment: The redesigned course has become an ideal place to host events.
shortDescription: The redesigned course has become an ideal place to host events.
description:
Renovated and pedestriised, the course has regained the vocation of Esplanade that it had at the end of the nineteenth century. 
Restaurants, breweries and bars welcome you all year round.

label: Plage Olga
description: Sandy beach of 180 m x 70 m. Road sign. Panel identification on site. Close to the beach and not pay parking area. Capacity of the area: 40 vehicles. Bars, playground, garbage cans, telephone booths.

label: Parc de la Bastide du Jas de Bouffan
comment: Since 1941, the Jas de Bouffan Park is a classified site. It is located west of the city. Access by from Route de Galice.
shortDescription: Since 1941, the Jas de Bouffan Park is a classified site. It is located west of the city. Access by from Route de Galice.
description:
Some history
This property was purchased in 1859 by Paul Cézanne's father. The painter was then 20 years old. Then in 1880, he set up a studio in the attic. Many paintings such as The avenue of chestnut or La Sainte Victoire were achieved in this property.

On the death of the artist's mother, the property was sold to Louis Granel. His daughter married Frederick Corsy, professor at the Faculty of Medicine of Marseille. In 1956, their son sold the property to the city of Aix en Provence, reserving the usufruct until his death in 2002.

Today
The park entrance, marked by a monumental gate opens onto a path lined with towering plane trees leading to the mansion.

Not to be missed the typical 18th century magnificent mansion of the Jas de Bouffan. Reservation at the Office of Tourism of Aix en Provence (Mansion closed in 2017).

label: Fontaine des Danaïdes
comment: The forward sequence of the Danaïdes group is treated in a beautiful Carrara marble: the sculptor borrowed this theme from mythology to exalt the theme of water.
shortDescription: The forward sequence of the Danaïdes group is treated in a beautiful Carrara marble: the sculptor borrowed this theme from mythology to exalt the theme of water.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame du Château
description:
In the heart of the Alpilles, the chapel of Notre Dame du Château has been the object of particular devotion by the Tarasconnais since the Middle Ages
An ancient Madonna, sculpted from the trunk of a stump, was brought from Briançon, around 1350, by a hermit named Imbert and placed in a chapel adjoining the castle at that time. At that time, the rue du château was also the Jewish quarter. The Jews were annoyed to be in constant contact with the Christian populations who were going to venerate the Virgin of Briançon, and proposed to the town to build a chapel to Notre Dame in another district at their own expense.
The Christians accepted and a chapel was built in the Alpilles, between Tarascon and Saint-Remy.
Since 1420, Notre Dame precedes the Ascension, the Tarasconnais go to fetch the saint in her old chapel and bring her to the magnificent collegiate church Sainte Marthe where during forty days, she is the object of a very particular worship on behalf of the Tarasconnais and the neighbouring populations. On the fortieth day, she is brought back to the sanctuary of the Alpilles.
streetAddress: ['Chemin Notre Dame du Château', 'St Etienne du Grès']

label: Eglise St Jean-Baptiste
description:
The church, the first part of which dates from the 11th century with successive additions up to the 17th century, is listed as a historical monument, as is the Chapel of the Penitents built in 1844, built at the eastern end of the square and separated from the church by the sacristy, the presbytery and a private house. It is an artistic and homogenous ensemble which has preserved its furniture: choir panelling, stalls, pulpit to be preached, tribune with balustrade, communion grid and 19th century paintings. In this church are preserved the Altarpieces of St. Eloy and the Marriage of the Virgin, a bronze-gilded altar-tomb, as well as a curious relic "Lou San Sabatoun "*

*"Lou San Sabatoun": According to the oldest documents and traditions, how did the Holy Relic arrive in Provence? Although there is quite a lot of obscurity on this point, here are the two suppositions that can be made:
- The first, based on very ancient local traditions, allows us to note the simultaneous presence, in several points of our southern region, of the precious relics listed above, most of which seem to have been transported from Palestine by our first apostles, that is to say in the first century of the Christian era.
- The second would delay their arrival in Provence until the time of the last Crusades.

label: Chapelle de l'Oeuvre de Jeunesse
description:
Built between 1866 and 1871, she was put into service in 1872. Dimensions of the building Length 26 meters - Width 9 meters - Height 14 meters.
The stained-glass windows of a very big invoice are to be seen, commanded in 1867, are Alphonse Didron's work (big glassworker), who also made the stained-glass windows of the cathedrals of Troyes and Soissons.

label: Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle
comment:
Created in 1819 driven by the Marquis of Montgrand, mayor of Marseille and Comte "Earl" de Villeneuve, Bouches du Rhône préfet. 
The muséum gathers  XVIII th century cabinet of curiosity of the city and state  donations.
shortDescription:
Created in 1819 driven by the Marquis of Montgrand, mayor of Marseille and Comte "Earl" de Villeneuve, Bouches du Rhône préfet. 
The muséum gathers  XVIII th century cabinet of curiosity of the city and state  donations.
description:
Before settling in 1869 in the Palais Lonchamp's right aisle, built to celebrate the  water, the arts  and sciences' arrival.
Today, the museum includes a room devoted to world zoology, a room about evolution and adaptation of  life,  a room about prehistoric, another  one  about Provence (XIXth century). Museum houses a  scientific  and consultation library for adults and  children on appointment.
Museum welcome a new visit trail " Terre d'evolution"

Permanent  exhibition surface: 1200
Temporary  exhibition surface: 400

label: Fontaine Cantini
comment: Fountain offered by the marble mason Jules Cantini, sculpted by the Marseille artist Allar in 1911. At the top, a statue symbolizing Marseille and on the pedestal, four groups of statues representing the Rhone, the sea, the source, the torrents.
shortDescription: Fountain offered by the marble mason Jules Cantini, sculpted by the Marseille artist Allar in 1911. At the top, a statue symbolizing Marseille and on the pedestal, four groups of statues representing the Rhone, the sea, the source, the torrents.

label: Ancien moulin à vent
description:
This old mill preserves the rubble of its original construction, dated in the 16th century. They can be seen at the base of the monument
Above it, the dressed stones date from its reconstruction in the 17th century.

label: Eglise Notre-Dame de Vie
comment: The Church of Saint-Cannat was rebuilt after the 1909 earthquake that destroyed the village.
shortDescription: The Church of Saint-Cannat was rebuilt after the 1909 earthquake that destroyed the village.
description:
Cette église d'aspect assez simple est le fruit de circonstances qui sont loin de l'être. 

A l'origine, Canus Natus, fils d'officier romain, ermite devenu évêque
de Marseille à la fin du Ve siècle fut l'objet d'une vénération de la part de
fidèles et pèlerins qui constituèrent autour de sa tombe un hameau qui est à l'origine de la ville. 

C'est dans ce contexte que les Templiers obtiennent l'autorisation d'édifier un prieuré qui devient très rapidement une place forte incluant une chapelle dédiée à la Vierge. 


Devenue l'église paroissiale, elle est entièrement détruite en 1909 lors du terrible tremblement de terre. En 1927, l'église est réédifiée au centre du village. Les seuls témoins discrets d'un tel passé sont un sarcophage chrétien où Saint-Cannat est représenté (à l'extrême gauche), ainsi que l'ancienne chapelle ruinée de Notre-Dame de Vie elle-même, située dans le quartier Sainte-Marguerite.


Ouverture uniquement lors des offices.

label: Bastide du chemin de Paradis
comment: Home of the writer and academician Charles Maurras.
shortDescription: Home of the writer and academician Charles Maurras.
description:
Exceptional closure.
Bourgeois house from the early 17th century. Characteristic Provencal Bastide, with its square plan, two levels and its 4-pitched roof.

Visits (every day except Saturdays, Sundays and holidays) only by reservation at the Ziem museum at 04.42.41.39.60.
The garden is accessible to individuals and groups, the interior of the country house for groups of 5 visitors.

label: Eglise de Saint-Giniez
comment: The church dates from the 19th century and is adjoining the private school town of Provence.
shortDescription: The church dates from the 19th century and is adjoining the private school town of Provence.
description:
The church organ was built in 1912 in the workshops of the famous Parisian organ builder Aristide Cavaillé-Coll under the direction of his successor and first foreman Charles Mutin.

It has 2 keyboards, 1 footswitch and 13 stops. It is therefore a musical instrument worthy of being part of the valuable organizational heritage of the city of Marseille.

The church hosts concerts.

label: Eglise Notre Dame de Nazareth
comment: Parish church, in Provencal Romanesque style, dating from the 12th century, the church of Our Lady of Nazareth has a magnificent 17th century baroque altarpiece and a beautiful series of reliquary busts. The massive Gothic bell tower dates from the 14th century.
shortDescription: Parish church, in Provencal Romanesque style, dating from the 12th century, the church of Our Lady of Nazareth has a magnificent 17th century baroque altarpiece and a beautiful series of reliquary busts. The massive Gothic bell tower dates from the 14th century.
description:
CHURCH OF OUR LADY OF NAZARETH.
Parish church, of Provencal Romanesque style, dating from the 12th century, the Church of Our Lady of Nazareth is made up of an apse vaulted in cul-de-four and a Romanesque nave vaulted in barrel vault. The chapels and the massive bell tower, whose upper part is unfinished, are 14th century and of Gothic style.
Reported in the year 1000, we know that in 1056 it was part of the fiefdom of the Abbey of Saint-Victor de Marseille. After a long period of abandonment, it was enlarged and consecrated on 23rd September 1325. The building has been classified as a historical monument as a whole since September 1945 and contains many classified objects. Its most interesting elements, inside, are a magnificent 17th century baroque altarpiece by the Tretsois sculptor Christophe Veyrier, and a beautiful series of reliquary busts of Saints dating from the 17th century.
streetAddress: ['Eglise de Nazareth', 'Place Des heros et martyres de la resistance']

label: Parc Jacques Prévert
description: Salon de Provence Park opened in the month of June 2007. On the road to Eyguieres, many swings and games for children.

label: Porte de Bassac et vestiges de remparts
description: Breakthrough in the medieval ramparts, allowed the access to the village fotified. The current construction dates from the 18th century. This unique vestige of the ramparts consists of a 1.5m thick wall.

label: Site Archéologique de Glanum
comment: More than a century of archaeological research allows us to present the witnesses of an exceptional architectural ensemble. Situated in the heart of the Alpilles massif, the Gallic city was bathed in Greek and then Roman influences.
shortDescription: More than a century of archaeological research allows us to present the witnesses of an exceptional architectural ensemble. Situated in the heart of the Alpilles massif, the Gallic city was bathed in Greek and then Roman influences.
description: The former capital of the Glanic people of Ancient Provence, Glanum is now an extraordinary archaeological site. The town became Hellenised due to its contact with Marseille, created grandiose public monuments under Roman influence, then disappeared circa 270 as a result of Barbarian invasions. Excavations have unearthed a residential district of houses with central courtyards surrounded by columns, streets with drains, mosaics, thermal baths and the forum, testifying to a certain degree of sophistication.

label: Plage Saint Jean
description: Sandy beach and of gravel. Panel of regulations on the site. Parking area near the beach, fitted out and not paying. Capacity of the area: 30 vehicles. Refreshment rooms, restaurants, businesses. Nautical activities nearby: windsurfing board, veil, canoeing.

label: Bibliothèque Municipale d'Alleins
description:
Opening hours :
Monday: 3pm-6pm
Wednesday: 10am-12pm and 3pm-6pm
Friday: 3pm-7pm

label: Presqu'île du Mazet
comment: The peninsula of Mazet (and They du Mazet) is an area of 144 hectares in Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhône. It is located at the mouth of the river Le Rhône.
shortDescription: The peninsula of Mazet (and They du Mazet) is an area of 144 hectares in Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhône. It is located at the mouth of the river Le Rhône.
description:
A "They" is a sandy formation shaped by the sea and the river. A path "Le They du Mazet", is equipped with observatories, free of charge and open all year round. And a cycle path allows access to the site from the town.
144 ha.

label: La Pointe San Crist de l'Île
comment:
Pointe San Crist extends the ancient town of Martigues to the west.
Pointe de l'Île is an artificial peninsula built from 2009 to 2010, measuring 130 m long and 30 m wide. The architect of this project is Gilles Amphoux.
shortDescription:
Pointe San Crist extends the ancient town of Martigues to the west.
Pointe de l'Île is an artificial peninsula built from 2009 to 2010, measuring 130 m long and 30 m wide. The architect of this project is Gilles Amphoux.
description:
It is a magnificent site fitted out with water jets and fountains conducive to relaxation and strolling.
You will also be able to contemplate the giant sculpture of Bernar Venet which sits as a figurehead towards the viaduct. Named “219.5 ° Arc x 15”, it was installed in 2019.
The last cities to have been able to exhibit such pieces are none other than New York, San Francisco, Beijing, Berlin, Paris or even Tokyo.

label: Observatoire de Vauvenargues
comment: Behind the Sainte Victoire mountain, at an altitude of 600m, the Sinne observatory benefits from an exceptional setting, favourable to astronomical practice.
shortDescription: Behind the Sainte Victoire mountain, at an altitude of 600m, the Sinne observatory benefits from an exceptional setting, favourable to astronomical practice.
description:
Behind Sainte Victoire mountain, at an altitude of 600m, La Sinne observatory enjoys an exceptional setting, ideal for astronomy.


Discover our cupola and the large Schmidt-Cassegrain 355-mm telescope as well as other instruments for visual observation.


Practical astronomy for members. Monthly public evenings: slide show, identification of stars and constellations by laser, celestial mythology. Observation of deep sky (galaxies, nebulae, star clusters, planets of the moment and planets of the Moon) with instruments and in the cupola. 


Free monthly lectures in Aix-en-Provence. School and corporate groups welcome. Outside events, partnerships with other associations. 

Possibility of private evening functions: contact us for details.

label: Place des Prêcheurs
comment: The square is in front of the Palais de Justice. It was laid out in the 15th century and was the centre of public and social life before Cours Mirabeau was created.
shortDescription: The square is in front of the Palais de Justice. It was laid out in the 15th century and was the centre of public and social life before Cours Mirabeau was created.
description:
About 1640, the architect Jean Lombard continued the work begun by Jean de Paris, when the town was expanded with the creation of the Villeneuve district, by setting the eastern side of Place des Prêcheurs against the large cornerstone buttresses. The Prêcheurs fountain was decorated with four medallions by Jean Pancrace Chastel in 1748. They were destroyed in 1793, then restored in 1833 in large part thanks to an American patron.

The Madeleine church was built between 1691 and 1703 by Laurent Vallon. The façade was added between 1855 and 1860, with a monumental design by Revoil. The church was listed in 1988. It contains a large number of works by artists who lived in Aix, including the exceptional Annunciation Altarpiece (1444), which can now be seen in Saint-Esprit church (Rue Espariat) during restoration work to the building. This is where Paul Cézanne was baptised in 1839, his parents were married in 1844 and his wife Rose married the lawyer Maxime Conil in 1881.

(Fountain listed in 1905 - Church listed in 1988)

The redevelopment of the Verdun and Prêcheurs areas gave rise to the biggest square in Aix-en-Provence.

label: La léproserie Saint-Lazare
description:
Date: 12th and 17th centuries
Era: Middle Ages, Classical period
Type: Hospital architecture
Status: Private property listed as a regional Historic Monument in 2005
In the Arles charitable sector, the Saint Lazare Leprosarium enjoyed a permanence which was rare for this type of establishment.
Set apart from the town, on the boundary of the Alyscamps necropolis, the establishment, which was built in the Middle Ages, remained operational until the 18th century.
Due to its location and the architectural interest of its remains, the establishment is currently involved in different projects concerning the regeneration of the site of the former SNCF workshops.
Although the church has disappeared, the hospital building is still fairly visible.
The building forms a rectangle around a closed courtyard and, to the east, consists of two levels of covered loggia galleries.
To the west, another well-ordered courtyard borders the main courtyard.
The one-storey mediaeval building is characterised by its medium-sized stones with butt joints. The southern façade has been conserved and can be accessed by a semi-circular gateway.
A building was attached at a later date, made from large blocks with thin joints.
This construction was largely destroyed or encompassed into the construction of the main northern building, made of rubble stones and blocks connected with thick joints.
The southern façade was cut through with an ogee-lintelled doorway and a window; the first floor was cut through with a chamfered frame door and a mullioned cross.
A double-arched cove portico connected the western wing. It still has its southern gable end and western façade, which use the the same type of masonry.
The central room on the ground floor is divided by crosswalls and opens onto outside via a door with a semi-circular archway; this door is opposite a large archway which leads onto the central courtyard.

label: Eglise Saint-Dominique
comment: Built on the site of a medieval chapel, the church consecrated in 1739 is distinguished by the beautiful rusticity of its dissimilar rubble stones
shortDescription: Built on the site of a medieval chapel, the church consecrated in 1739 is distinguished by the beautiful rusticity of its dissimilar rubble stones
description: Built in the site of a medieval chapel, the church consecrated in 1739 is distinguished by the beautiful rusticity of its dissimilar stones. Inside, intelligently laid bare in the choir, they offer a remarkable contrast with the painted walls and confer to this modest construction, a certain charm. A reliquary bust of Saint Dominique is highlighted in a niche decorated with moldings and mascarons.

label: Village d'Aurons
description: Small village perched on the last movements of the Alpilles Range which dominates the Durance plain. It can be reached by a picturesque road lined with pine trees to discover the ruins of Castellas and a magnificent panorama.

label: Place de la Libération
comment: Pedestrian square, place of the first market in 1359.
shortDescription: Pedestrian square, place of the first market in 1359.
description:
In the Center, a fountain erected in 1881, to celebrate the arrival of fresh water in the city from the Durance

The famous place becomes a dance floor in summer, for the "dances in the Miiroir", milonga evenings and all dances on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.

Cafes and restaurants border the square.

label: MEDIATHEQUE MUNICIPALE "La Passerelle"
comment: Welcome to the website of the municipal media libraries of Vitrolles. You will find all the information about our collections, animations, services, as well as a digital library.
shortDescription: Welcome to the website of the municipal media libraries of Vitrolles. You will find all the information about our collections, animations, services, as well as a digital library.
description:
We welcome you to "La Passerelle", the media library in the city centre, and to the Georges Brassens media library, located in the southern districts.

In our spaces, you can choose the activity you like: reading, listening to music, playing board games or video games, following a conference or watching a film, having a drink while reading the press, learning a foreign language, taking part in a workshop, studying, discussing... or contributing to the Vitrolles Family Album

All (cultural) uses are permitted, within the limits of the internal regulations.
streetAddress: ['1 place de la Liberté', 'Avenue Des Salyens', 'Bât La Passerelle']

label: Ikaria
comment: Gift of the sculptor Igor MITORAJ to the city of Cornillon-confoux, in 2001
shortDescription: Gift of the sculptor Igor MITORAJ to the city of Cornillon-confoux, in 2001
description: In order to thank the municipal team and the people of Cornillonnais for their welcome, the Polish sculptor Igor MITORAJ, who periodically resides at the Château de Confoux, wished to offer our town one of his works of art: a bronze sculpture from his artistic period on the new mythology: IKARIA, the Victory.

label: Ancien pigeonnier du château
comment: The imposing round tower marking the south-west corner of the Parc Camoin is none other than the former dovecote of the Covet castle. Private property, cannot be visited.
shortDescription: The imposing round tower marking the south-west corner of the Parc Camoin is none other than the former dovecote of the Covet castle. Private property, cannot be visited.
description:
The imposing round tower marking the south-western corner of the Parc Camoin is none other than the former dovecote of the castle

Probably built between 1480 and 1500 under René Cossa, Lord of Marignane, it is only documented from 1526, near the false gate of the ramparts
Located at the end of the first large garden of the castle, it experienced many vicissitudes at the beginning of its history
Dismantled by a farmer of the seigniory in 1529, it was used as a quarry for the bastide of a private individual sued by Louise de Savoie, Lady of Marignane
Rebuilt, it suffered the assaults of the League and then of the Duke of Epernon's troops between 1574 and 1589, probably integrated as a watchtower and defence tower to the fortifications built in the seigniorial garden on the edge of the town. As soon as he arrived in Marignane, Jean-Baptiste I de Covet had it restored at great expense in 1605 by the mason Jeannet Arvel, certainly giving it its present appearance. Emblematic of the wealth of the owners, it has always occupied a place of choice in the park redeveloped in the 18th century, clearly visible on a supposed plan of 1696, on a canvas painted around 1770 or 1780 (from the convent of Minimes but passed in public sale in 1939), and on the Napoleonic cadastre of 1818. It also fed the kitchens of the castle, pigeon being a recurrent dish on the aristocratic tables, often accompanied by the vegetable productions attested in the large garden

Sold as a national asset during the Revolution, it has been privately owned since then, and in the 19th century it passed into the hands of the Camoin family, serving for a time as housing for farm workers.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Aqueducs romains de Barbegal
comment: The aqueducts and mills of Barbegal were a complex work of two parallel aqueducts, leading drinking water to the city of Arles from the Alpilles and also made turn the mills that could produce flour for "Arelate".
shortDescription: The aqueducts and mills of Barbegal were a complex work of two parallel aqueducts, leading drinking water to the city of Arles from the Alpilles and also made turn the mills that could produce flour for "Arelate".
description:
The aqueducts, remains of which can still be seen near the Barbegal mill, are a diversion of the 'De Caperon', aqueduct which channelled water from the southern slope of the Alpilles. The construction techniques used for the section before the mill differ from those observed on the route of the Caparon aqueduct.
Fernand Benoît had originally dated this construction to the 4th century AD, connecting it with the spread of Christianity and the increasing scarcity of the slavery it would have entailed. However, research carried out by the CNRS and the University of Provence in the 1980s refuted this hypothesis and dated the construction of the complex to the 2nd century AD. The columns are built from small stones, although some of their bases consist of large reused blocks; the arches are also made of small blocks, supplemented with brick. However, this system can also be found from time to time along the course of the aqueduct on the southern slope, particularly on the section parallel to the aqueduct that supplied the mill. This leads us to believe that the mill was constructed at the same time as a campaign was carried out to restore the hydraulic network. These two wonderful vestiges are unique in Europe and are 2 km from the centre of the village.

label: Escale Borély
description: Seaside promenade with bars, restaurants, shops, most of them open on Sundays and holidays. It hosts festivals and events in the summer.

label: Etang d'Entressen
comment: Pond of 100 hectares on the edge of Crau
shortDescription: Pond of 100 hectares on the edge of Crau
description:
On this stretch of water, surrounded by reed beds, away from the urbanization, one can admire the magnificent Alpilles under clear skies. Its surface area is 100 hectares and its depth does not exceed 10m.
 
Nautical activities are offered from the Entressen Nautical Base: sailing, windsurfing, sea kayaking, white water swimming, sea cruising, model regattas. You will find there a place favourable for the discovery of water sports. Courses and sea classes without accommodation are offered by Istres Entressen Canoe Kayak.
On the pond many fishermen also devote themselves to their favourite leisure activity. Sandander, carp, tench, tench, roach, rotengle, bream, the pond is full of fish.


Protected area: Natural area of ecological, faunistic and floristic interest

label: Le Village des santons en Provence
comment: Le Village des santons en Provence, is 19 villages in a continuous decor featuring more than 3000 santons.
shortDescription: Le Village des santons en Provence, is 19 villages in a continuous decor featuring more than 3000 santons.
description:
The "Village des Santons en Provence" is a combination of 19 villages in a continuous scenery.
3,000 clay-figurines -iconic symbol of Provence- are staged in villages, hills, scubland, calanques, ...
The type or size of these clay figurines used varies according to the scenery.
They are represented in Provençal playlets : working in the fields or in shops, dancing, playing cards or petanque, cooking, fishing...
Animals, trees, flowers, objects or accessories, the very special care given to details gives authenticity to each scene.
A second room is dedicated to the Nativity representation by each clay-figurinemaker.
This large village, covering 230 m2, was created by the craftsmen and figurineproducers organization of " Pays d'Aubagne " area and gathers 17 santon-makers.

label: Anciens Arcenaulx
description:
After building the Citadel of St. Nicholas, Louis XIV ordered the modernization of the galley arsenal. In 1748, after the departure of the galleys to Toulon, the arsenal was disused and the slow decay of the buildings led to their demolition in the 1780s. Only one pavilion, at 23, cours d'Estienne-d'Orves, escaped destruction: it is occupied by the restaurant, bookshop, shop, publishing house Jeanne Laffitte.

Open from Tuesday to Saturday from 10am to 11pm.

label: Musée Edgar Mélik
comment: Cabriès Castle houses the Edgar Melik Museum, home to the painter's collection
shortDescription: Cabriès Castle houses the Edgar Melik Museum, home to the painter's collection
description:
The old castle, destroyed at the end of the 12th century, was rebuilt in the 18th century and split up during the Revolution. 

The museum houses the collection of painter Edgar Mélik, who died in 1976 and whose mural paintings are a unique feature of the region. 


Temporary exhibitions are displayed here, as well as furniture from local archaeology.

label: Croix et oratoires
comment: Crosses and Oratories.
shortDescription: Crosses and Oratories.
description: Numerous in the countryside, the best known are: the cross of Saint-Eloi (1810), the oratory of Saint-Roch, the cross of Mas de Belly, the cross of Mas des Prés and the cross of Jubilee (1852)

label: Esplanade Charles de Gaulle
comment: At the heart of the revival of the Olive Tree Pond, the Saint Catherine esplanade has undergone a huge facelift and has changed its name
shortDescription: At the heart of the revival of the Olive Tree Pond, the Saint Catherine esplanade has undergone a huge facelift and has changed its name
description: Istres has paid tribute to former Mayor Bernardin Laugier, who has worked for 40 years at the service of the city by giving its name to the square in front of the new town hall. On the 6,000 m"from the esplanade Bernardin Laugier, one can discover the long diagonal with its 57 pillars of 114 505 cm in height, in the colours of the city, without forgetting the famous stripes which recall columns to the black and white stripes that made the fame of Buren.

label: Mas de la Cure - Maison du Cheval Camargue
comment:
Meeting with an exceptional horse:
Come and discover our mares and our Camargue horses, in their natural habitat. Visit of 2 hours on reservation, 1,5km of walk.
shortDescription:
Meeting with an exceptional horse:
Come and discover our mares and our Camargue horses, in their natural habitat. Visit of 2 hours on reservation, 1,5km of walk.
description:
Historical discovery through the life of a 19th century farmhouse, its agricultural and traditional activities (viticulture, breeding, ...) ecological discovery by walking along a path allowing notably exceptional woodlands. Discovery of the extensive breeding of the Camargue horse and bull.
Open for groups.
Open only during events.

label: Cap Croisette
comment: Located in the South of Marseille, this corner of paradise for divers, bathers and walkers is also very appreciated by the inhabitants of Marseille.
shortDescription: Located in the South of Marseille, this corner of paradise for divers, bathers and walkers is also very appreciated by the inhabitants of Marseille.
description:
When you arrive at Les Goudes, rather than continuing towards Callelongue, turn right to reach Cap Croisette. A diving club, a restaurant and a very small cove are located in the middle of nowhere, facing the Maïre island.

Cap Croisette is also a diving spot. Between the local fauna and flora, you can also discover an old wreck dating from 1902, the Liban, a liner lying behind the island of Maïre at 30 meters depth.

The island of Maïre is a protected ornithological reserve, seagulls have taken up residence there and can be very aggressive during the brooding period. Although easily accessible by swimming, land access is forbidden, as for the majority of the islands of the Calanques National Park: protected area.

label: Ancien couvent des Ursulines
description:
In 1657, the Ursuline nuns set up a house for the free education of young girls in the former St. Nicholas's Storm. This convent is installed on the buildings of the former St Nicholas' Hospital, dating from the 11th century, intended for the reception of the poor and the care of the sick.
The Order of the Ursulines, from their first name "The Company of Saint Ursula", was founded in Italy in 1535 by Saint Angela Merici. Specialized in teaching young girls, the order arrived in France in the 16th century and settled in the Comtat Venaissain as well as in Bordeaux.
Piazza Pio is so named in memory of the visit of Pope Pius VII-the same pontiff who canonized Saint Angela Merici after her liberation by Napoleon.
Private property

label: Plage anse du Bain des Dames
comment:
Small pebble and gravel beach, with a few huts and a restaurant and public toilets, in the Madrague de Montredon area.
Direction Pointe Rouge les Goudes.
shortDescription:
Small pebble and gravel beach, with a few huts and a restaurant and public toilets, in the Madrague de Montredon area.
Direction Pointe Rouge les Goudes.

label: Eglise Sainte-Cécile
comment:
In 1844, the proposal to build a new church was adopted by the city council.
Begun in 1846, the parish church of Sainte-Cécile was completed in 1853. The bell tower was completed in 1855.
shortDescription:
In 1844, the proposal to build a new church was adopted by the city council.
Begun in 1846, the parish church of Sainte-Cécile was completed in 1853. The bell tower was completed in 1855.
description: In 1857, a violent storm destroyed it, reducing the area of the building. It was rebuilt in 1865, but it was not until 1868 that the church returned to its initial form as a palatine cross.

label: Canal de Craponne
comment: The Canal de Craponne (16th century) takes the waters of the Durance at La Roque d'Anthéron, to take them to Salon de Provence and the Pays d'Arles
