shortDescription: The Canal de Craponne (16th century) takes the waters of the Durance at La Roque d'Anthéron, to take them to Salon de Provence and the Pays d'Arles
description: Genius realization of the engineer Adam de Craponne, we can still admire at the eastern entrance of the town (Gontard), the architecture of the last water intake (XVIIIth S) that the Durance did not carry away.

label: Plage Fernandel
comment:
A small pebble beach a few steps from the port and the town centre
The beach marks the beginning of the lizard trail, a coastal path popular with families and sportsmen.
shortDescription:
A small pebble beach a few steps from the port and the town centre
The beach marks the beginning of the lizard trail, a coastal path popular with families and sportsmen.
description:
Plage de la calanque de Fernandel
Many moons ago, this beach was an anchorage for Roman vessels come to load up with stone from the surrounding quarries.
Centuries later, the Marseille-born actor Fernandel chose to set up home in Carry-le-Rouet at the "Villa des Mille Roses", offering panoramic views over the open sea and little fishing port so dear to him. At the time, a stone staircase ran down from the villa to a private beach.
Today, Fernandel has passed on, the villa has been sold and the beach has now been opened to the public again thanks to French coastal laws. Renamed the "Plage de la calanque de Fernandel", this handkerchief-size stretch of shingle covers no more than 100 square metres, but is a wonderful departure point for discovering the stunning sea beds of the Côte Bleue coast armed with a mask and snorkel.

label: Four à pain
description:
Behind a bay window, is preserved a bread oven from the end of the 18th century built in stone (cinerites).
Next to it is the premises of the Friends of Old Aubagne who explain the history of Aubagne free of charge during their stay.

label: Bibliothèque municipale Jorgi Reboul
comment: Come and learn at the municipal library of Septèmes les Vallons
shortDescription: Come and learn at the municipal library of Septèmes les Vallons
description: Municipal library offering exhibitions, meetings, debates, storytelling hours and shows throughout the year.

label: Eglise Saint-Jean Baptiste
comment: Built in 1669 in the village of quarrymen, At the corner of the bell tower, the artisans have engraved their signatures. Inside: the showcase of quarry tools.
shortDescription: Built in 1669 in the village of quarrymen, At the corner of the bell tower, the artisans have engraved their signatures. Inside: the showcase of quarry tools.
description:
Since the Middle Ages, a village occupied the place called La Couronne Vieille, on the coast, not far from stone quarries where many fishermen went to get supplies. It is found named for the first time in an act of the mid-fourteenth century. Its inhabitants were parishioners of the Saint-Genies

In 1666, new quarries were opened on a nearby site soon named La Couronne. The population that resided on the coast came to settle there: a church was thus built, dedicated to Saint-Jean-Baptiste, and a parish was erected, like branch of Jonquières.

Today, Saint-Jean-Baptiste parish of La Couronne still exists, but La Couronne has become a district of Martigues

label: Mas de Brau
description:
This is the most remarkable farmhouse in the municipality. The construction, dated 1570, is attributed to Jeanne de Quiqueran, wife of Honoré des Martins, governor of Les Baux from 1568 to 1581.
A large, long mas with a rich facade to the south. This is only visible from the road, as the building belongs to a private individual. In front of it stretches a vast, well-shaded garden, listed in the inventory of listed sites.
The building is made of Fontvieille stone.
This farmhouse has a splendid facade with Renaissance decor, thus combining rustic and learned architecture. If the ground floor is punctuated by simple bays, the first floor is punctuated by about twenty fluted columns with Corinthian capitals supporting an entablature composed of a frieze with scrolls and a cornice with dentils. The decoration employs not only elements of French mannerism but also local references such as the friezes with foliated scrolls from the ancient theatre of Arles or variations on the Corinthian order of the Maison Carrée.

label: Le pigeonnier du Parc St Michel
comment: The original Romanesque chapel was restored in the 15th century.
shortDescription: The original Romanesque chapel was restored in the 15th century.
description: It can be visited from time to time during heritage days. The park Saint Michel where it is located with the dovecote is used every summer as a backdrop for a great historical sound and light show.

label: Eglise Notre Dame de l'Assomption
description:
Situated on the site of the former castle of Saint Eldrad, this masterpiece of Provençal Baroque style replaces a Romanesque church which received a huge crowd during the opening masses of the General Assemblies of the Pays de Provence in the 17th century, which explains its imposing dimensions
This vast church has no less than ten chapels decorated with paintings and altarpieces by the great painters of the 16th to 18th centuries (Jean Daret, Nicolas Mignard, André Bardon...). The great organs, of very beautiful workmanship, which we owe to the organ builder Joseph Isnard, were inaugurated in 1797. Outside, the church is distinguished by an octagonal dome, of a strong baroque style, which stands next to the bell tower of the old Romanesque church, built on the tower of the castle. The church of Lambesc houses several paintings of Provencal painting of the seventeenth and eighteenth century. The church of Lambesc shelters several paintings of the Provençal painting of the XVIIth and XVIIIth centuries (Faudran, Daret, Jevieux, Mignard, Dandré-Bardon.), as well as magnificent altarpieces in gilded and carved wood. 18th century church built between 1700 and 1741 on plans of Jean Vallon, famous Provençal architect, author, among other things, of the nave of the Cathedral St Sauveur of Aix en Provence. It was built on the site of a 13th century church, which was considered too small.
With its dome, its elongated nave, its pyramid-shaped facade as if plastered on top of the building, the church is reminiscent of the Italian late Renaissance style.
The church houses about ten chapels, all decorated with altars, altarpieces and paintings by 17th and 18th century artists. In particular, the chapel Notre Dame de Lourdes is home to a painting representing "The vision of St. John Matha" painted in 1636 by Nicolas Mignard and classified in 1912.

label: Hôtel de Porcelet
comment: The Yves Brayer Museum occupies one of the most beautiful houses in the centre of the village, the Hôtel de Porcelet. It hosts an important retrospective of the painter's work, which is among the most representative of 20th century figuration.
shortDescription: The Yves Brayer Museum occupies one of the most beautiful houses in the centre of the village, the Hôtel de Porcelet. It hosts an important retrospective of the painter's work, which is among the most representative of 20th century figuration.
description: This beautiful 16th century residence has an original façade and elegant, finely sculpted mullioned windows. The Hôtel de Porcelet was the residence of one of the most famous families in Arles, which still has a street named after it. On the ground floor, the interior décor still includes a vaulted room decorated with 17th century paintings of the Four Seasons and the Allegories of the Four Cardinal virtues. One first floor room still has a French-style ceiling decorated with floral motifs in shimmering colours. A fresco in a medallion on the fireplace shows a mythological scene, the Fall of Phaeton, struck down by Zeus. The building was used as a school until 1979. It was restored between 1991 and 1997.

label: Les Arènes Municipales
comment: Municipal arenas of the town of Fos-sur-Mer
shortDescription: Municipal arenas of the town of Fos-sur-Mer
description: More than 1000 seats, host many Camargue races entered in the Trophées des As or l'Avenir, toro-piscines, they are also the training place of the bullfighting school every Tuesday evening.

label: Clocher des Accoules
comment: The bell tower which dates from the 18th century replaces the "Sauveterre Tower" ( la Tour Sauveterre) which rang the tocsin and convened the municipal councils : it is the last vestige of a gothic church razed in 1794, the arrow being rebuilt in the 17th century.
shortDescription: The bell tower which dates from the 18th century replaces the "Sauveterre Tower" ( la Tour Sauveterre) which rang the tocsin and convened the municipal councils : it is the last vestige of a gothic church razed in 1794, the arrow being rebuilt in the 17th century.
description: Mass celebrated on religious and lithurgical feast days at 6 pm.

label: Lac de Bimont
comment: The Bimont dam, the centrepiece of the Aix branch of the Canal de Provence, was built by Joseph Rigaud from 1946 to 1951.
shortDescription: The Bimont dam, the centrepiece of the Aix branch of the Canal de Provence, was built by Joseph Rigaud from 1946 to 1951.
description:
The lake of Bimont is an artificial water reservoir created in the 50s following the construction of the Bimont dam. This reservoir can store 40 million m3 of water from the Infernet and Verdon rivers. It is used to supply water to the large industrial and urban centres of the Arc valley and Marseille.
Once crossed, the dam allows access to the many marked paths leading to the Sainte Victoire or the Zola dam

A car park near the dam allows you to cross the building and enjoy a beautiful view on the side of the Sainte-Victoire Mountain.

It is strictly forbidden to access the shore and to swim in this reservoir, for safety and environmental reasons.

Surface area: 73ha, i.e. 14 million m3 of water (329.50m NGF)

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de Caderot
comment: Chapel of Notre Dame de Caderot in Berre l'Etang
shortDescription: Chapel of Notre Dame de Caderot in Berre l'Etang
description:
It is the oldest monument of the city, it was erected on the ruins of a Pagan temple, the Chapel is already listed in the 3rd century of our time.
At that time it was a parish church located in the place called Cataruscum.
The plans have never been modified, only the roof, originally made of flat stone, has been reworked. During the siege of the city by the Italians in 1591, it was partially destroyed. It will be rebuilt identically.
Inside the building, there is an imposing and magnificent altarpiece, a perfect representation of the Renaissance, dating from 1507.

label: Eglise Saint-Pierre de Saliers
description:
This church was built on the site of an old chapel which probably dated back to the 12th century.
The building was at risk of collapse around 1930. It was therefore fully renovated at the end of the 1930s, mainly through the generosity of Mlle de Jonquières, who financed a large part of the work and paid for a new altar.

label: Eglise Sainte Croix
description: Visitors are often surprised by the imposing size and impressive Classical façade of this building, which was constructed in 1754. The pulpit jutting out from the pillar, the walnut woodwork of the ambulatory and the 19th century marble altar are all remarkable features which justify the Church's classification as a Regional Historic Monument.

label: Lac de Peïroou
comment: Lake Peïroou is an artificial lake near Saint Rémy de Provence, in the heart of the Alpilles. The lake ends with a small dam joining 2 cliffs.
shortDescription: Lake Peïroou is an artificial lake near Saint Rémy de Provence, in the heart of the Alpilles. The lake ends with a small dam joining 2 cliffs.
description: The stretch of water is little frequented by tourists, and allows you to rest in the summer in the shade of the pine forest. It is also a place of passage for a hike in the Massif des Alpilles. However, beware of orders forbidding access to the forest in summer.

label: Musée du savon de Marseille. Marius Fabre
comment: Since 1900, in the heart of Salon-de-Provence, Marius Fabre soap factory has perpetuated the artisanal production of Marseille soap and black soap with olive oil.Complete your visit by discovering our Marseille soap museum.
shortDescription: Since 1900, in the heart of Salon-de-Provence, Marius Fabre soap factory has perpetuated the artisanal production of Marseille soap and black soap with olive oil.Complete your visit by discovering our Marseille soap museum.
description:
The Marius Fabre soap factory has preserved the most precious witnesses: engraved boxwood stamps, tools, the first soap molding machines, stencils for shipping boxes, old packaging, headed paper, washing boards... Reflecting a very old activity still alive.
Surface of the permanent exhibition : 600

Come and discover the authentic atmosphere of our soap factory and its workshops during a guided tour. A moment of exchange and discovery, young and old will discover a unique know-how still alive, transmitted from generation to generation in our family.
 
Visits to the Marius Fabre soap factory are free and can be booked on our website www.marius-fabre.com under the heading "visit the soap factory".
 
Until June 30th they are proposed:
 - For individuals :
Tuesday and Thursday at 10:30 am and 11 am; Wednesday and Saturday at 2:30 pm and 3 pm
- For groups: on demand and on reservation tourisme@marius-fabre.fr
 
From July 1st and until August 31st : 
- For individuals: Monday to Saturday at 9:45 am, 10:15 am, 10:45 am, 11:15 am, 2:15 pm, 2:45 pm, 3:15 pm, 3:45 pm, 4:15 pm, 4:45 pm, 5:15 pm and 5:45 pm
- For groups: visits suspended during the summer, resumed in September on request and by reservation tourisme@marius-fabre.fr
 
Exceptional opening on July 14th and August 15th. 
 
The Marseille Soap Museum will reopen its doors on July 1st!
 
If you wish to receive additional documentation, do not hesitate to contact us.

label: Plage des Laurons
comment: "Plage des Laurons" in Martigues is a pocket-sized beach set next to the port of the same name. Combining shingle and grass, it is situated along the "Sentier du Littoral" coastal footpath and is easily accessible to all.
shortDescription: "Plage des Laurons" in Martigues is a pocket-sized beach set next to the port of the same name. Combining shingle and grass, it is situated along the "Sentier du Littoral" coastal footpath and is easily accessible to all.
description:
Showers and toilets have been fitted as well as a play area for children.
Free parking is available nearby and the beach is signposted in summer to ensure the safety of swimmers from the boats leaving the small port.

Its main feature is this picnic area fitted out with tables, benches and shaded corners which allows you to spend a day with the family without leaving the beach.

The beach is supervised every day from June 25 to August 28, 2022, from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.
Blind guide dogs accepted.

label: Chapelle des Jésuites - Lycée du Sacré Coeur
comment: The Chapel of the Jesuits illustrates the second baroque style in Aix by its architectural rhythm and the quality of its decoration: its large windows with stained glass windows in grisaille and its choir, topped by a monumental dome, are characteristic of this style
shortDescription: The Chapel of the Jesuits illustrates the second baroque style in Aix by its architectural rhythm and the quality of its decoration: its large windows with stained glass windows in grisaille and its choir, topped by a monumental dome, are characteristic of this style
description:
This was the first church built by the architect Laurent Vallon, followed by the Saint-Esprit, Prêcheurs and Saint-Jean-Baptiste-du-Faubourg churches. He positioned it at the end of Rue Félicien David.

The high frontage was to be decorated in Baroque style, but was never completed.

In 1973 the site was listed as a historical monument and was renamed "Jesuits' Convent". 
The chapel occasionally hosts cultural events.

label: La place d'Albertas
comment: The Place d'Albertas is located in the heart of downtown Aix-en-Provence, a stone's throw from the Cours Mirabeau, on the edge of Rue Espariat.
shortDescription: The Place d'Albertas is located in the heart of downtown Aix-en-Provence, a stone's throw from the Cours Mirabeau, on the edge of Rue Espariat.
description:
In the 18th century the Albertas were one of the city's leading families.

In 1724, Henri Rainaud d'Albertas instructed Laurent Vallon to design the frontage and entrance of his private mansion. 

To create an open outlook, between 1735 and 1741 he bought the houses opposite and had them demolished. He wanted a square to be built on the Parisian model of the royal palaces. It was Jean-Baptiste d'Albertas, his son, who continued his work from 1742 to 1746, assigning the project to Laurent Vallon's son Georges. 

The fountain in the centre was built in 1862.

label: Oratoire Sainte Anne
description: Since we have no information about this oratory, we will limit ourselves to recalling that it is to Saint Anne that the chapel of the convent of the Récollets was dedicated. They had to use this passage to get to the path of the Friars Minor who kept their name.

label: Cloître Saint Paul de Mausole, Centre culturel et touristique Van Gogh
comment: At the foot of the Alpilles, next to the Roman ruins of GLANUM, there has been, since about the year 1000, a monastery containing a beautiful Romanesque cloister where monks from different congregations succeeded one another.
shortDescription: At the foot of the Alpilles, next to the Roman ruins of GLANUM, there has been, since about the year 1000, a monastery containing a beautiful Romanesque cloister where monks from different congregations succeeded one another.
description:
Its name comes from the Mausoleum of Les Antiques. This former monastery near Les Antiques, which has been transformed into a health spa, still has its church and a Romanesque cloister which opens onto four barrel vaulted galleries. A large alley leads to this peaceful site, which is famous for having housed Van Gogh (1889-1890). The monastery also welcomed another famous guest, Doctor Schweitzer (1914 to 1918).
It was just a priory in 1605, when it housed Observantine monks who cared for mentally ill patients there. After the Revolution, Doctor Mercurin founded a health spa there, which is still in operation.

label: Le Beffroi d'Alleins
description: A remnant of the old rampart, this square tower was the main entrance to the village in the 16th century. The machicolations and the passage of harrow, are of period. The slightly pyramidal tower which surmounts it is probably from the XVIIIth century and the crenellations from the XIXth century. On either side of the entrance vault, one notices fragments of sculpted frieze: vegetal garlands, cherubs and comedy masks, coming from a Gallo-Roman mausoleum, like those in the church of Saint-Pierre. Above, the coat of arms of the Renaud d'Allen family: "de gueule à dix losanges d'or posté 4-4-2".

label: Place de la République
description:
The Place de la République, in the town centre, is the result of progressive development through a number of architectural and urban operations. 
It is to the south of the old Roman forum. In the Middle Ages, it was reduced to a narrow forecourt between Saint-Trophime Church and Sainte-Anne Church. Its current surface area was then occupied by several residential blocks.
It was mainly after the construction of the town hall, in the 17th century, that the Place changed considerably. 
Over time, it gained monuments of different styles and with different purposes; it eventually contained original features, punctuated by a number of façades, giving it the appearance of an Italian square. 
Its large size allows the public to gather there during major traditional events, such as the triannual election of the 'Queen of Arles'.
The Place de la République is noteworthy for the very diverse architecture of its monuments, making it a remarkable collection of art history.
Antiquity is well represented, with the obelisk from the Roman cirque. The façade of Saint-Trophime church, built in the 12th century, was given its magnificent historiated portal for the coronation of Emperor Frédéric Barberousse in 1178.
The clock tower with its antique décor is characteristic of sophisticated Provençal Renaissance architecture. Local councillors wanted to conserve it during the construction of the hôtel de ville, itself a triumph of the Classical style. 
Saint Anne Church, built between 1614 and 1630, has clear remnants of the southern Gothic style in its nave. The archbishop's palace was redeveloped in the 17th century; its current façade was, however, rebuilt at the end of the 18th century. 
Finally, the former post office, constructed in the late 19th century, epitomises in itself the eclectic architecture of the era just as well as the square.

label: Château du Duc de Guise
comment: Castle of the Duke of Guise in Orgon.
shortDescription: Castle of the Duke of Guise in Orgon.
description:
The 'Castrum druentioe', still called the Château of the Duc de Guise, is a former Celto-Ligurian oppidum built in a strategic location. It was fortified at the end of the Roman Empire and was a strategic point for keeping watch over the Durance Valley. A population of men-at-arms and shepherds lived at the base of the fortress. The stronghold was destroyed in the 6th century by the Visigoths, who had come to lay siege to Arles. It was rebuilt in the 11th century and became the fiefdom of the Counts of Provence. In the 12th century, it was a well-known military fortress responsible for keeping watch over the Durance Valley. It was a place of justice and a dreaded prison. Louis XI had it destroyed again in 1483. It was taken over by the De Guise family during the Catholic Holy League in the 16th century, but was demolished for a fourth and final time by Richelieu in 1630, following orders from Louis XIII, to the great relief of the villagers. This remarkable site bears witness to the chequered history of Orgon and Provence.
It hosts a Mediaeval Festival and banquet every year on the first Saturday in July.

label: Le Mugel
comment: Tiny with its three hectares, but vertiginous, proud above the Mediterranean, the Mugel is part of the classified site of Cap Canaille.
shortDescription: Tiny with its three hectares, but vertiginous, proud above the Mediterranean, the Mugel is part of the classified site of Cap Canaille.
description:
Tiny with its three hectares, but vertiginous, proud above the Mediterranean, the Mugel is part of the classified site of Cape Canaille. Not far from the heart of La Ciotat, it harbors botanical rarities, due to the very special composition of its soil and its cliff. It is indeed a "poundingue": a curious natural assemblage of earth and pebbles.

It was in 1982 that the General Council became the owner of this enclave. It was necessary at all costs to protect this Edenic landscape. Wise work has therefore been undertaken with a dual objective: to respect the integrity of the natural environment while securing the site in order to better accommodate the public.

In the future, this development should lead to the creation of a House for the reception of the public aimed at sensitizing the visitor to the environmental problems linked to this fragile site, while revealing the astonishing diversity of the various environments associated with marine world.

label: Le Bec de l'Aigle
comment: The Bec de l'Aigle is one of those natural curiosities that reminds us of the authenticity of Provence.
shortDescription: The Bec de l'Aigle is one of those natural curiosities that reminds us of the authenticity of Provence.
description: A magnificent natural site, a geological fortress built on the secondary streams whose pebbles formed during the eras in a reddish conglomerate, the "Poudingue" de la Ciotat.

label: Calanque de Morgiou
comment: Neighboring the Sormiou cove, Morgiou is also one of the places where many Marseillais go swimming and walking. It is crossed by the GR98-51 hiking trail.
shortDescription: Neighboring the Sormiou cove, Morgiou is also one of the places where many Marseillais go swimming and walking. It is crossed by the GR98-51 hiking trail.
description:
Calanque de Morgiou
Situated just next to "Calanque de Sormiou", Morgiou is also a popular bathing and walking spot for the people of Marseille. You can reach the fjord by car outside restricted periods, by foot starting out from the Baumettes quarter, or by boat. Morgiou is characterised by deeper waters than Sormiou, and is partly occupied by a small fishing port still in operation. You can sunbathe in the tiny cove on the left as long as you get your towel down early! Even better, the pretty and flat limestone rocks offer up an excellent solarium.
This is also one of the rare inhabited fjords found on the coast and its little cottages blend perfectly into the backdrop. 
If you take the narrow footpath to the right you will come to Cap Morgiou, home to a number of ruined military buildings and offering fabulous views over the Mediterranean. Cap Morgiou is also the site of the famous Cosquer cave - a prehistoric cave discovered in 1991.

label: La citerne des Moulins
comment: Built between 1851 and 1852, the basin with a capacity of 12,000 m3 is located 35 metres above sea level, under the Place des Moulins, which is the highest point of the Panier.
shortDescription: Built between 1851 and 1852, the basin with a capacity of 12,000 m3 is located 35 metres above sea level, under the Place des Moulins, which is the highest point of the Panier.
description:
On engravings of the XVIIth century, one counts about fifteen windmills. Today only three remain, unfortunately swallowed up in the urban fabric. The use of water as a driving force will gradually force the windmills to cease all activity. In the middle of the 19th century, the town razed the existing buildings to the ground in order to create an architecturally homogeneous square
This huge reservoir is made up of a structure with small brick vaults resting on 160 pillars made of Cassis stone, 5 metres high and spaced 4 metres apart from axis to axis in one direction and 2 metres apart in the other. On these vaults (lowered arches) a layer of topsoil about one metre thick was placed to intercept the action of the sun on the water. Since then, the upper surface has been covered with road materials used for the development of the Place des Moulins.
The construction of this basin, undertaken at the same time as the Longchamp and Bpnaparte-Puget hill basins, allowed the regularisation of the city's water supply service. This operation, initiated during the first half of the 19th century, was then limited after the construction of the Sainte-Marthe basin on the derivation of the Longchamp basin. The distribution of water from the latter was carried out by cast iron pipes which, in turn, carried the water by means of secondary pipes connected to the main pipes. The water was previously filtered in the two-level Longchamp reservoir and from the lower level of the Longchamp basin, the Moulins pipeline was laid
Several projects for the development of the Moulins cistern are under study: it remains closed because the safety standards for its visit are not yet assured.

label: Médiathèque Edmond Rostand
comment: Médiathèque Edmond Rostand : A space dedicated to literature and art.
shortDescription: Médiathèque Edmond Rostand : A space dedicated to literature and art.
description: Opening hours: Tuesday from 10:00 to 12:00 and from 16:00 to 18:30.Wednesday from 9:00 to 12:00 and from 14:00 to 18:30.Friday from 10:00 to 12:00 and from 16:00 to 18:30.Saturday from 10:00 to 12:30. Still, cultural activities will take place on Saturday afternoon.Leisure and study are available on the mode of discovery and diversity:-borrow from the funds made available.The media library provides 14 305 documents:-12 652 books (fiction and documentaries) including 545 books wide vision - 1 146 CD - 495 DVD - 8 periodicals: Courrier International, Guide kitchen, the individual, the friend of the gardens, phosphorus, Girls,. Ideas, methods and work, philosophy magazine Marie-Claire.-4 youth periodicals: I like reading, Popi, I read, Julie - attend the broadcast of documentaries.-Listen to stories.-Speaking with a writer such as Claudie Galley for "breakers" and José lenzini for "the last days of Camus" - attend shows.-Participate in a writing workshop, in literary, philosophical meetings.-Participate in a Visual arts workshop.-Be helped in his studies with "academic support": in partnership with the youth point, an educator welcomes at the library on Wednesday and Saturday from 10:00 to 12:00 on Tuesday from 17:00 to 18:00 students and elementary school children. At the same time librarians participate in the documentary search for the presentations.-Use computer multimedia tools including the internet.Every month:-the first Saturday of the month at 14:30: literary meeting. Open discussion about the last books read by the participants, crush or vice versa! -The third Saturday of the month at 14:30: meet "Phil between friends", Café philo in partnership with the lez' Arts of the cliffs.-The first Wednesday of the month at 10:30: Storytime for children.

label: Oratoire Saint-Marc
description: This Oratory was built in 1852 in praise of Saint Mark, patron saint of shepherds, and consecrated an area where the herds used to rest during the transhumance.

label: Médiathèque
description:
Registration is free of charge on presentation of an identity document and parental authorisation for minors.
Book-carrying at home for people living in Cuges and unable to travel.
Wifi, on simple request of the codes from the librarians you can connect in wifi with your laptop, your tablet or your Smartphone.

label: Bibliothèque municipale Joseph Roumanille
comment: Joseph Roumanille municipal library in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence.
shortDescription: Joseph Roumanille municipal library in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence.
description:
Opening hours to the public
- Tuesday: 2:00-6:00 p.m
- Wednesday: 9am-12pm, 2pm-6pm
- Friday: 14:00-18:00
- Saturday: 9am-12pm, 2pm-5pm

label: Grotte de l'Escale
comment: Saint-Estève-Janson is home to a major site of very ancient European prehistory, the Escale cave. Access forbidden, only visible from the outside.
shortDescription: Saint-Estève-Janson is home to a major site of very ancient European prehistory, the Escale cave. Access forbidden, only visible from the outside.
description:
The Grotte de l'Escale, discovered in 1958 by Eugène Bonifay, during the construction of the EDF canal, which passes near the site, contains important paleontological deposits. Bones of birds, rodents and carnivores, but also a large deer (close to the megaceros) dating from 700,000 to 600,000 before mordern age, as well as traces of human presence (fire, rudimentary tools).

The Grotte de l'Escale is a listed historic monument. In order to protect the site, access is strictly forbidden. You can only see the entrance from the departmental road 66.

label: Parc des poètes
comment: In the central alley you can admire the busts of the Félibres
shortDescription: In the central alley you can admire the busts of the Félibres
description: The poets Park created around the country house where the Heritage Museum, hosts the busts of the Arène: Frédéric Mistral, Joseph Roumanille, Pierre Aubanel, Jean Brunet, Paul Giera, Alphonse Tavan and Anselme Mathieu. Decorated with fountains, a children's play area, the visitor can wander the aisles lined with multiple flowers.

label: Chapelle Notre-Dame de l'Espérance
comment: Large Romanesque chapel of the 12th century in the heart of Bouc Bel Air, located a few meters from an old mill, in the pine forest near the old village, which offers a beautiful view over the plain and the entire massif of Etoile
shortDescription: Large Romanesque chapel of the 12th century in the heart of Bouc Bel Air, located a few meters from an old mill, in the pine forest near the old village, which offers a beautiful view over the plain and the entire massif of Etoile
description: This large 12th century Romanesque chapel in Bouc Bel Air is located a few meters from an old mill, in the pine forest near the old village, which offers, besides the attraction of a typically Mediterranean forest, a beautiful point of view on the plain and on all the massif of the Etoile. In addition, it is a precious testimony to the fervor of the boucaine faith, since an annual procession took place on Sunday after Easter and Assumption day, and it was home to many ex-votos, mostly in the eighteenth century. The 48 ex-votos are currently kept in a secure place, waiting to be able to present them again in the Church of St. Andrew and in more suitable furniture. Reflecting a popular culture, they are of an extreme variety (diseases, epidemics, accidents, drownings, shipwrecks, falls ...) and enlighten us in an often moving way on the daily life of our ancestors.

label: Pavillon de la Reine Jeanne
comment: In the heart of the Vallon de la Fontaine, is the pavilion of Queen Jeanne also called "Temple of Love". This Renaissance style temple inspired Frédéric Mistral who made a copy for his tomb.
shortDescription: In the heart of the Vallon de la Fontaine, is the pavilion of Queen Jeanne also called "Temple of Love". This Renaissance style temple inspired Frédéric Mistral who made a copy for his tomb.
description: Nestled in the Valley of La Fontaine, near the old wash house, is an elegant Renaissance-style corner pavilion built by Jeanne de Quiqueran, widow of Honoré des Martins, Baron of Les Baux from 1568 to 1581. Frédéric Mistral had a copy made for his tomb in Maillane. The site has been baptised 'Temple of Love' by the Félibres, writers in Occitan, in memory of the legendary lessons in love given there. This small temple was build according to a hexagonal plan. With its ornamental architecture, it adorned a garden belonging to the Les Baux family and was known as 'Count's Garden' or 'King's Orchard'. The grotesque masks above the fluted columns are slightly surprising.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Blancs
comment: This 17th century chapel, built on the initiative of the Confrérie des Pénitents blancs, is decorated with frescoes by the painter Yves Brayer, representing the Shepherds' Christmas in the Provencal tradition.
shortDescription: This 17th century chapel, built on the initiative of the Confrérie des Pénitents blancs, is decorated with frescoes by the painter Yves Brayer, representing the Shepherds' Christmas in the Provencal tradition.
description: In the mid-17th century, a lay brotherhood of penitents had this chapel built on the Place de l'Eglise, shaded by cypress trees, on the edge of the cliff overlooking the Valley of La Fontaine. Its underground cellars contained the bodies of members of the Brotherhood. It was unearthed from the ruins in 1937 by the 'Maintenance des Confréries of Langue d'Oc'. It was then dedicated to Saint Estelle, who looks after the memory of the old Penitents of Les Baux and is patron saint of the Félibrige Association. The building is architecturally very sombre and is built of dressed stone. The monumental entrance door, adorned with rusticated stone, is surmounted by a bas-relief of two penitents, their heads covered in a hood (bourras), kneeling; above them is a chiselled Latin inscription: 'In nomine Jesu omne genus flectatur' (In the name of Jesus, every knee shall bow). The inside of the chapel, which was once vaulted with intersecting ribs, is decorated with frescoes painted in 1974 by Yves Brayer on the theme of the Nativity, representing the Christmas of the Shepherds in Provençal tradition. Above the door is a round or oculus window, surmounted by an arched bell-turret.

label: Eglise Notre Dame de Beauvoir
comment: Registered by decree on the Supplementary List of Historic Monuments on the 14 October 1997, the Notre Dame de Beauvoir church dominates the town due to its enormous size and the buttresses on its façade, which can be seen from afar.
shortDescription: Registered by decree on the Supplementary List of Historic Monuments on the 14 October 1997, the Notre Dame de Beauvoir church dominates the town due to its enormous size and the buttresses on its façade, which can be seen from afar.
description:
Called Beauvoir, Belveyre or Beauvezer (to see well), people say that it is, “closer to the angels than men on the ground.” Its panorama is definitely magnificent.
It is a parish church, built in the Provençal Romanesque style and dedicated to Notre Dame de Beauvoir.

The church and its façade were renovated in 2017 and 2018.
Since 28 April 2019, it has housed a unique relic: a stone from Golgotha. Directly from Jerusalem, this fragment of the rock on which Jesus Christ was crucified was a gift from the Custodians of the Holy Land to the parish of Istres.

label: Plage Arène Cros
description: Beach of pebbles and rock. Car park nearby. Admitted dogs. Accommodation, restoration nearby.

label: Plage Cap Rousset
comment: In the heart of a rocky cove, it remains sheltered from the wind and waves. Rearranged in terraces, it is located in the heart of the marine reserve and is very popular with families. Gravel and pebble beaches.
shortDescription: In the heart of a rocky cove, it remains sheltered from the wind and waves. Rearranged in terraces, it is located in the heart of the marine reserve and is very popular with families. Gravel and pebble beaches.
description:
Plage Cap Rousset
"Plage Cap Rousset" is situated in Carry-le-Rouet – one of the many enchanting little villages lining the Côte Bleue coast. Once you're at Carry port, take the coast road to the left and simply follow the signs! The shingle beach is bordered by rocks where you can also stretch out to sunbathe if the beach is overcrowded... The water is exceptionally clear and pure here  this stretch of the Côte Bleue coast actually forms part of a nature reserve, so fishing and underwater hunting are prohibited. A genuine aquarium, and a haven for divers and snorkelers, it is now one of the Mediterranean's top diving spots! The beach is attended by a lifeguard and showers and toilets are available. So all you have to do is jump in and enjoy the treasures of this delightful, natural cove...

label: Miroir aux oiseaux et canal St Sébastien
comment: The picturesque Miroir aux oiseaux has made Martigues famous internationally.
shortDescription: The picturesque Miroir aux oiseaux has made Martigues famous internationally.
description:
The area including the Canal St Sébastien, the Miroir aux Oiseaux and the Quai Brescon was listed in 1942.
This strip of sea straddled by the Pont Saint Sébastien and the line of colourful fishermen's houses with random heights has fascinated numerous painters since the end of the 19th century including Delacroix, Corot, Loubon, Ziem and Dufy.

label: Archives nationales d'Outre Mer
comment: The National Overseas Archives is a department of the Ministry of Culture with national competence.
shortDescription: The National Overseas Archives is a department of the Ministry of Culture with national competence.
description:
The National Overseas Archives, established in Aix-en-Provence in 1966, keep documents relating to the French colonial presence overseas, except for in Morocco and Tunisia, the archives of these countries being kept at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.


It is a national department of the Ministry of Culture service.

label: Etang de Rassuen
comment: The Rassuen Pond is a biodiversity hotspot.
shortDescription: The Rassuen Pond is a biodiversity hotspot.
description: Linked to the salt mining and then to the fertilizer factory (closed in 1989), the Rassuen pond is once again a freshwater pond classified as a natural protected area (ZNP), an important area for the conservation of birds (ZICO) and a natural ecological, floristic and faunistic interest zone (ZNIEFF).

label: Eglise Notre-Dame de Grâce d'Eyguières
comment: Visit the church Notre Dame d'Eyguières
shortDescription: Visit the church Notre Dame d'Eyguières
description: The blessing of this church was given on September 8, 1783. There are organs dating back to 1802 on which Frederic Chopin played in 1839 as well as 12 chapels. Rarer is a statue of the Virgin waiting to give birth!

label: Chapelle du Castellet - Saint Victor
comment: The site of Castelet, a small rocky plateau, was occupied by an oppidum in the 4th century BC. Abandoned two centuries later, it was reinvested in the 12th century. These remains are located on the grounds of a private farmhouse and are therefore inaccessible to the public.
shortDescription: The site of Castelet, a small rocky plateau, was occupied by an oppidum in the 4th century BC. Abandoned two centuries later, it was reinvested in the 12th century. These remains are located on the grounds of a private farmhouse and are therefore inaccessible to the public.
description: The Le Castellet site, a small rocky plateau, was occupied by an oppidum in the 4th century BC. It was abandoned two centuries later, but redeveloped in the 12th century.  Within the château walls was a high tower, which no longer exists, as well as a church dedicated to Saint Mary. Only the apse remains standing: it is semi-domed and supported by eight ribs resting on corbels. These remains are currently located on the land of a private Mas and are therefore inaccessible to the public.

label: Etang de Bolmon site de Patafloux-Barlatier
comment: The Etang de Bolmon, separated from the Etang de Berre by the Dune du Jaï, is a vast lagoon bordered on the south by the Paluns de Marignane marsh.
shortDescription: The Etang de Bolmon, separated from the Etang de Berre by the Dune du Jaï, is a vast lagoon bordered on the south by the Paluns de Marignane marsh.
description:
The two names, Patafloux and Barlatier, refer to a pine forest and a marsh. In the pine forest of Patafloux, a botanical path allows you to see typical Mediterranean and protected plants. In the wetland of the marsh of Barlatier, one can observe, according to the seasons, a fauna and a flora which evokes the Camargue.
These sites are important for the wintering and migration of water birds.
The site of the pond of Bolmon is a protected area.

label: Chapelle Saint Sixte
comment: Situated on a rocky mound, 1 km from the village, near a spring, it was built in the 12th century on the site of an ancient sanctuary.
shortDescription: Situated on a rocky mound, 1 km from the village, near a spring, it was built in the 12th century on the site of an ancient sanctuary.
description: The chapel is located on a rocky knoll 1 km from the village, near a spring, and was constructed in the 12th century on the site of an ancient sanctuary. A pilgrimage on Easter Tuesday, in honour of Pope Sixtus, still continues today. Mass is celebrated there weekly in summer.

label: Les Tours de l'Amphithéâtre
comment: These towers date from the 12th century.
shortDescription: These towers date from the 12th century.
description: From the early Middle Ages, the Roman monument was used as a fortress and contained 212 houses. The arches were bricked up and three towers were built.

label: Le Jardin d'Alcinoos
comment: The discovery of the Alcinoos garden is done without any predefined itinerary. The visitor lets himself go towards an emotion of perfumes and colours in a free association to meet my creations expressed in an intuitive and singular disorder.
shortDescription: The discovery of the Alcinoos garden is done without any predefined itinerary. The visitor lets himself go towards an emotion of perfumes and colours in a free association to meet my creations expressed in an intuitive and singular disorder.
description: In the heart of the Alpilles Regional Natural Park between Saint Rémy de Provence and les Baux de Provence. A wonderful garden of colours and scents with 4000 rose bushes and Philippe's sculptures. A very quiet domain

label: Médiathèque Municipale
description: In the heart of the village, a cultural place for the whole family, themed events, tales, readings.....

label: Etang de Vaccarès
comment: The Vaccarès pond, covering 6500 ha, is part of a vast complex of brackish ponds of more than 10 000 ha.
shortDescription: The Vaccarès pond, covering 6500 ha, is part of a vast complex of brackish ponds of more than 10 000 ha.
description:
From August to April, these ponds are home to tens of thousands of water birds, who come from northern Europe to spend the bad season in the Camargue (mainly ducks, coots and grebes). In April, terns from Africa come here to nest in colonies, together with sedentary gulls and otters. Finally, all year round, these are the favourite feeding grounds for pink flamingos and herons (egrets, grey herons). The fish, very abundant, give rise to active professional fishing at the edge of the Reserve (atherines, eels, muges, sea breams, sea breams, wolves, soles, carps, breams, pike-perch).


Listed site
Listed site
World's heritage

label: Amphithéâtre
description:
Roman amphitheatre inspired by the 3rd century and the life of the Romans in Provence at that time created by a passionate man: Mr. Jean Vargas.
This passionate of bouvine of architecture and music began his work at home in 1980. It measures 40m by 32m. The track is 26m wide and 31m long, the walls are decorated with bas-reliefs, mouldings, sculptures, rosettes, statues that he realized in part while being almost blind.
The monument has been studied acoustically to lend itself to theatre, concerts, ballets...
It can be visited free of charge on Tuesdays and Saturdays from 10am to 12pm or by appointment.

label: Plage de Calieu
comment: Sandy beach in the town of St Mitre les Remparts
shortDescription: Sandy beach in the town of St Mitre les Remparts
description:
Range 100m x 5m. Nature of the soil: sand. Dogs accepted. No parking nearby. Beach cleaning and algae collection from 15 June to 15 September. No nautical activities. Daily control of the physical quality of the water. Bacteriological sampling twice a week.
Unsupervised beach.
Follow CD52 "avenue de Varage", Massane, "Allée du bord de l'eau".

label: Fontaine des Bagniers
comment: Placed at the intersection of two streets (rue des Chapeliers and rue des Bagniers) in a craftsmen's district in 1685, the Bagniers fountain, which supplied hot water to the grateful residents, had to be removed from the road in 1759 due to the increase in traffic.
shortDescription: Placed at the intersection of two streets (rue des Chapeliers and rue des Bagniers) in a craftsmen's district in 1685, the Bagniers fountain, which supplied hot water to the grateful residents, had to be removed from the road in 1759 due to the increase in traffic.
description:
The fountain was in the way, so the Vallons (father and son) were commissioned to install it against a wall to make space. This move deprived the fountain of its supply of hot water which now flowed to the Mossy Fountain on Cours des Carrosses.

Today only the elegantly rounded basin is original, and the fountain is vertical, against the wall. The entire upper part, the two corner pilasters surmounted by a projecting cornice and the decorations, have been renovated.

The two gargoyles, placed at a suitable height to avoid splashing passers-by, look like a father and son, both with plump cheeks.

In 1926, noticing that the entire top inner part of the fountain was an unused space, Ambroise Vollard, the art dealer and friend of Paul Cézanne, asked for permission to pay tribute to the famous painter by installing a medallion there with his portrait surrounded by a wreath of flowers and fruit. Permission was granted and a drawing by Renoir was used as a model for the portrait. The fountain is nicknamed the "Cézanne Fountain".

label: Médiathèque Varadier d'Estourmel
comment:
Municipal media library located in the former shed of the castle.
Wide choice of books, novels, comics but also CDs and DVDs.
shortDescription:
Municipal media library located in the former shed of the castle.
Wide choice of books, novels, comics but also CDs and DVDs.
description:
The library invites you into its calm, peaceful interior.
Visitors will find a reading area and computer terminals for a quick consultation or for research.
Detailed documentation on the region and the village are available for loan.

label: Marseille bord de mer
comment:
The Corniche.
This beautiful promenade overlooking the sea from the Anse des Catalans to the Prado seaside park offers magnificent views of the Frioul islands and the Castle of If.
shortDescription:
The Corniche.
This beautiful promenade overlooking the sea from the Anse des Catalans to the Prado seaside park offers magnificent views of the Frioul islands and the Castle of If.
description:
This beautiful walkway overlooking the sea, running from the Catalans cove to the Prado beaches, offers some magnificent views of the Frioul islands and the Château d'If. In 1848, it was decided to create a seaside thoroughfare in order to provide work for the numerous unemployed of the time, leading to the creation of the Municipal Workshops and the hiring of 8,000 workers. The 25 m wide thoroughfare initially consisted of two sections: the first part as far as the Fausse Monnaie cove and the second up to the Pharo, Napoléon III's imperial residence. The work lasted 15 years. From the twenties on, the Corniche became a very popular spot with the locals for a day out, thanks to the tramway line which ran along it and could carry up to 20,000 passengers on a Sunday. There were departures every 5 minutes
Today the Corniche is 5 kilometres long. It was redeveloped at the end of the fifties and renamed Corniche J. F. Kennedy in 1963. In the 19th century, rich merchants had magnificent villas built here, of which there remain a few very beautiful examples. They are hidden away from public view in grounds planted with luxuriant vegetation. Standing on the Corniche, and towering over the sea is a huge propeller blade, a sculpture created in 1971 by César , a native of Marseille in commemoration of people repatriated to France from North Africa...
The opening of the entire Corniche during the Second Empire, gave Marseille' rich bourgeoisie the opportunity to have some magnificent villas built. It was considered good taste only to stay in them for a short while, in spring, just before leaving for the country house for the summer season. The merchants and ship-owners employed famous architects and sculptors to build eccentricities for them whose whimsical nature has something of the 18th century about it. Indeed, historic references are numerous if one takes the time to look at these villas of which the most remarkable are Château Berger and Villa Valmer.
Villa Valmer, the "Vague à la Mer" villa was erected in 1865 by the Marseille architect Condamin, in a renaissance style. It is situated at the top of vast grounds planted with tropical plant species brought back by the owner, who was a trader in oleaginous plants, from his journeys to the East. The villa currently belongs to the City of Marseille. Château Berger was built for Baron Houitte de la Chesnaye in 1860 in the French renaissance style of Château de Chambord. It is currently a seawater therapy centre.

label: Plage La Tuillière
comment: Natural cove made up of polished pebbles and frequented by regulars who come here for its charm and authenticity. It is also a surf spot during the non-summer seasons.
shortDescription: Natural cove made up of polished pebbles and frequented by regulars who come here for its charm and authenticity. It is also a surf spot during the non-summer seasons.
description: Located on the lizard trail, this cove left in a wild state offers few services. A restaurant is present on the spot.

label: Parc Brégante
comment: Set against the hillside of La Viste, this park, with a surface area of 3 hectares, occupies a belvedere position over the bay of the northern coast of Marseille.
shortDescription: Set against the hillside of La Viste, this park, with a surface area of 3 hectares, occupies a belvedere position over the bay of the northern coast of Marseille.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


This 3-hectare park is located on the Viste hillside, overlooking the bay of Marseille's northern coastline. It was built around a 19th century country house on land that had been disturbed by the old oil mills. In the 1960s, the municipality and the Société des Eaux de Marseille had to create a large capacity water reservoir on a high spot in the city. The Brégante park (named after a former deputy delegate for green spaces) is therefore equipped with underground water tanks enhanced, on the surface, by two round shallow basins with water jets. Around this structural element, an "English-style" garden is laid out in shaded terraces and grassy slopes. This space will, in the coming years, become part of the Parc du Belvédère de Séon, which will constitute a green lung for the districts of the 15th arrondissement, stretching from the Saint-Exupéry esplanade, which overlooks the coastal motorway, to the Plan d'Aou plateau.

label: Bibliothèque municipale Charles Rostaing
comment: With its 450 m2, welcomes young and adult audiences with books, magazines and DVDs.
shortDescription: With its 450 m2, welcomes young and adult audiences with books, magazines and DVDs.
description: Its staff is at the disposal of members for help in finding documents and reading advice. It also offers free access to the Internet on two computers and web/email training by appointment, as well as digital workshops according to the programme. Various activities (exhibitions, shows, storytelling evenings) are presented throughout the year. The program is available on site and in Saint Mitre Informations.

label: Eglise Saint-Laurent
comment: The parish church of the Saint-Jean district, the oldest district of Marseille, it is the fishermen's parish.
shortDescription: The parish church of the Saint-Jean district, the oldest district of Marseille, it is the fishermen's parish.
description:
Severely shaken by the explosions that demolished the neighbouring houses, it was disused for a long time and then partly restored and returned to worship.  
It is located on the probable site of the first Greek temple dedicated to Apollo. 
An enormous and magnificent capital was found at the foot of the mound when the sewage system was installed in the district of Saint-Jean.

In the Middles-Ages, Marseille was in danger of the Saracen invasions "invasions Sarrazines". In fact, the Saracens took and plundered Marseille in 838, so much so that in order to prevent further incursions, a bishop named Babon had an enclosure built a refuge castle, called the Babon Castle on the Saint- Laurent Hill.
The present church, which succeeds the much older chapel in the Babon Castle, was built in the 12th century, after the "Major", of which it was a priory.
 
The monument has undergone numerous alterations over the years and its façade, notably, was cut in 1668 when the fort Saint-Jean was built. 
It still preserves the essential elements of Romanesque architecture.

Parish priest : Alain Ottonello.

Masses are celebrated at Saint-Laurent and at "Accoules church".
At Saint-Laurent, on Tuesday and Thursday at 6pm, Sunday and feast day at 10.30am
In "Accoules Church", Saturday and eve of feast day at 6pm.

label: Cours d'Estienne d'Orves
comment: The course (square) is in the heart of the district of the former "Arcenaulx des Galères", 17th century, rehabilitated since 1980.
shortDescription: The course (square) is in the heart of the district of the former "Arcenaulx des Galères", 17th century, rehabilitated since 1980.
description: Since then, the area has been reserved for pedestrians and many restaurants, cafés, art galleries and shops have set up there to the delight of the people of Marseille and tourists who enjoy the Italian charm of the site, which regularly hosts open-air events. Underground public car park.

label: La Bastide de Fontvieille
comment: This mansion, built in 1845 for the Marseille merchant Louis-Xavier Pinatel, is one of the most important and one of the only witnesses of Marseille's mid-19th century architecture.
shortDescription: This mansion, built in 1845 for the Marseille merchant Louis-Xavier Pinatel, is one of the most important and one of the only witnesses of Marseille's mid-19th century architecture.
description: This House built in 1845 for the Marseilles merchant Louis-Xavier Pinatel, is one of the most important and one of the only witnesses to the marseillaise architecture of the middle of the 19th century. It is built on the location of "the villa Alaudii" (former location of the inhabitants of Allauch). Registered with the Historic Monuments, the castle is distinguished by innovative architecture of the time. While keeping a traditional provision, the architecture breaks from la Bastide to make the House a real castle: a cubic volume, a roof concealed by a classical balustrade, two large terraces and a pediment underlined by two stairs and symmetrical ramps. The property also consists of a Court of honour with two monumental portals and front of the fa��ade a large garden woodland of plane trees, Palm trees and Cedars dating from the construction of the home with a pool in the centre of it. This monument is closed to the public.
streetAddress: ['Bastide de Fontvieille - 780 Route Des quatre saisons']

label: Monuments aux morts
comment: War memorials
shortDescription: War memorials
description: Statue of a Poilu (French WWI soldier) on a high pedestal bearing commemorative plaques. Listed as a national Historic Monument in 2010.

label: Parc de la Pelouque
comment: Park of 2.5 hectares, playgrounds.
shortDescription: Park of 2.5 hectares, playgrounds.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used, but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary instructions are respected and, in particular, that physical distance is maintained.


Park of 2.5 hectares, playgrounds.

label: Hôtel Villeneuve d'Ansouis
description:
This residence has a marvellous composition of rocaille. This decor dates from the renovation of the older building by Georges Vallon in 1757. 

The architect's aim was to soften the strict classical design with this interplay of rounds and curves

label: Rue Médiévale des Halles
description:
Under the Ancien Regime, the Rue des Halles housed the town's covered market; today it is the last covered street in the Department.
Its oldest arches date from the 14th century. On one side were fishmongers and on the other side, butchers.
Nearby, the Place du Marché, formerly the Place aux Herbes, was once the location of fruit- and vegetable-sellers, but it was also the main site of the Tarasque games, as the race took place around the well in the middle of the square.

label: Eglise Saint-Sauveur de La Barben
description:
Near the Château, you will discover the Saint-Sauveur chapel dating from the 11th century. Formerly the property of the Marquis de Forbin, it was bequeathed to the commune of La Barben by the Marquis Antoine Palamède de Forbin. Inside is a completely restored "Transfiguration" signed by the painter Mimault and dated 1632.
Offices are celebrated there every Tuesday as well as on the occasion of baptisms and weddings.

label: Château des Baumes
comment: The Château des Baumes is an Italian-style mansion, dear to the hearts of the people of Istré, which has been entirely restored to become a seminar and work place for institutions and companies.
shortDescription: The Château des Baumes is an Italian-style mansion, dear to the hearts of the people of Istré, which has been entirely restored to become a seminar and work place for institutions and companies.
description:
The name of this house comes from the caves (baumes) that were once visible before the urbanization of the neighborhood.  Auguste Balthazard Denis Arduin (1854-1920) had inherited from his parents an agricultural property in the Pepi district. On this property was a mansion that the new owner had restored and transformed into an Italian villa. It was at this time that the people of Istré called it Château Arduin, notably for its second floor and its 7-bay loggia which offered unobstructed views of the Berre and Olivier ponds. During the Second World War, the Germans used it as a hospital

In 2020 and 2021, the Château des Baumes underwent a complete renovation.

The Tourist Office is specifically in charge of animating the reception room on the first floor through conferences, visits, thematic evenings and other events in relation with local institutional partners and tourism.

In addition, a specialized service provider has the mission to make the link with the economic world. It provides the meeting and conference rooms on the second floor for seminars and colloquia and rents out the six coworking offices on the second floor.

label: Eglise Saint-Lazare
comment: Church built on a basilica plan with coffered ceilings, an architectural work by Pascal Coste.
shortDescription: Church built on a basilica plan with coffered ceilings, an architectural work by Pascal Coste.
description:
The unfinished façade was to be a portico with Corinthian columns. Worth seeing : the marble high altar, the pulpit and the carved wooden Stations of the Cross, the great organs and a collection of paintings.

Sunday mass at 10:30am, weekday mass at 9 am.

label: Le Jardin d'Eguilles
comment: The Garden of Eguilles is an artist's garden on 950m2, The garden itself is remarkable by the harmony that reigns between the natural (the plant, the treatment of the soil) and the artificial (books, plastic ...).
shortDescription: The Garden of Eguilles is an artist's garden on 950m2, The garden itself is remarkable by the harmony that reigns between the natural (the plant, the treatment of the soil) and the artificial (books, plastic ...).
description:
Hidden in the heart of the village, this is an artist's garden. 


The works of contemporary sculptor Max Sauze are displayed in 950 m2 of lush, varied vegetation, creating scenes in carefully organised disorder. 


Open all year by appointment on 06 03 77 67 40. 
Permanent exhibition in the artist's gallery.

label: Écomusée de la Crau
comment: Come and discover the richness of the Plaine de la Crau in Saint-Martin de Crau!
shortDescription: Come and discover the richness of the Plaine de la Crau in Saint-Martin de Crau!
description:
Built in a playful and educational way, the permanent exhibition of the Crau Ecomuseum allows to understand the interaction between man and nature on this plain grazed by sheep for millennia.

In a scenography that is both modern and elegant, the exhibition tackles the major issues of the Crau region: the breeding of "Arles Merino" sheep, the production of Crau Hay PDO, the management of water resources, on which 270,000 inhabitants depend. We also discover the rich natural heritage contrasting between arid steppe and green bocage, the rare environments and protected species that make this unique territory unique in the world, as well as the challenges taken up by the managers to conserve them.

The Crau is also presented through playful videos, culminating in an animated film directed by Eric Serre, 1st assistant director of "Kirikou" and "Azur et Asmar", which gives a dreamlike version of the formation of the Crau plain based on the myth of Heracles. Other animated films and interactive multimedia devices will allow to discover in an unusual way the stakes of this territory.

The Maison de la Crau shop offers a multitude of books on fauna and flora, as well as guides, maps, publications from the Conservatoires d'Espaces Naturels PACA, but also some souvenirs and postcards.
streetAddress: ['2, Place Léon Michaud', 'Maison de la Crau']

label: Jardin du château de Tarascon
description: Facing the castle service quarters, dominated by cypress planted early last century, the King René garden is a haven of greenery in the heart of this magnificent architectural ensemble. At the foot of a linden tree is the "Fountain of Wealth", a reference written by King René d'Anjou”, the "Loving Heart", in which the Heart knight, allegory and literary incarnation of the king, made a stop at the threshold of black fountain in which flows an evil water...

label: Chapelle Sainte Croix
description:
Built on the hill of the same name in 1872 on the site of another place of worship once occupied by a hermit, this private property dominates the town.
It is not open to visitors at all times but is open on 14 September (Day of the Holy Cross) in the late afternoon and, in some years, on Heritage Days (guided tour).

label: Médiathèque des Quatres Tours
comment: Lending of printed and audio documents, reading committees, musical conferences, meetings with authors, discovery of countries.
shortDescription: Lending of printed and audio documents, reading committees, musical conferences, meetings with authors, discovery of countries.
description:
The media library has books, magazines, comic books, scores, CDs, DVDs and board games, which can be consulted or borrowed.

You can come freely to the Media Library, the consultation of documents on the spot and access to the different areas is free.

For the loan of documents, you will have to register, you will have an individual card valid for one year.

A grain library is completely free of access, and allows the barter of seed.

Free wifi and internet access upon registration.

label: La Montagnette
comment: Traditional place of walk of the locals
shortDescription: Traditional place of walk of the locals
description: The montagnette, forest of Barbentane.Picnic possible in the montagnette according to periods (opening of the massive restrictions).

label: Parc Saint-Martin
description:
Large shady park with playground for children between 2 and 6 years old.
Open all year round from 8am to 6pm.

label: Réserve des Impériaux
comment: The nature reserve "Les Impériaux" is located in the Camargue, near Saintes Maries de la Mer. It is an area with a typical marshland landscape.
shortDescription: The nature reserve "Les Impériaux" is located in the Camargue, near Saintes Maries de la Mer. It is an area with a typical marshland landscape.
description:
Guided tours by boat, on foot or on horseback are possible.

Management of natural areas: Domaine du Conseil Général
Protected area: Natural area of ecological, faunistic and floristic interest
Listed site

label: Chapelle Notre Dame Du Bon Voyage
description:
Located at the entrance of the Calanque of Port Miou, built on the site of an ancient temple dedicated to Promylius, the protective divinity of travel built in 1649 by the Consuls and dedicated to the Virgin, protector of Cassis following the beginning of the plague.It was destroyed in 1847 hindering the exploitation of a quarry and then built next door the following year. The interior has only one altar. This chapel is not open to the public but groups and individuals can be transported by small train to visit it.
In 1220 following a plague epidemic brought to Marseille by a ship, the population of Cassis vowed, if the plague ceased, to go on pilgrimage to the chapel for eternity.
This vow is still respected. That day, 1st Sunday of July, the chapel opens to pilgrims.

label: Eglise du Coeur Immaculé de Marie
comment: Spanish-speaking parish, Philippine chaplaincy.
shortDescription: Spanish-speaking parish, Philippine chaplaincy.
description:
Mass in Filipino on the 2nd, 3rd and 4th Sundays of the month at 5:30 pm. Parish Priest: Fr. Percival Redona. Mass on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 11 am. Mass in Spanish at 5:30 pm: 1st Sunday of the month with readings in French and English. Weekday Masses: Monday, Wednesday, Friday at 11am.
 
Weekday Masses: 11am Mon, Wed, Fri

label: Les Alyscamps
comment: In Antiquity, cemeteries were outside the city walls and along road routes. From the beginning of the Empire, incineration graves, sarcophagi and mausoleums were erected on the outskirts of the Via Aurelia, constituting a vast necropolis.
shortDescription: In Antiquity, cemeteries were outside the city walls and along road routes. From the beginning of the Empire, incineration graves, sarcophagi and mausoleums were erected on the outskirts of the Via Aurelia, constituting a vast necropolis.
description:
However, the cemetery became extremely significant during the Paleo-Christian era, with the inhumation of the martyr Saint Genest and the burial of the first Bishops of Arles, who were placed in a chapel later surrounded by a large number of tombs grouped together in several rows.
A priory known as Saint Honorat was constructed circa 1040; it depended on Saint-Victor Abbey in Marseille. The necropolis became an important stop-off point on the pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela and the 'chansons de gestes' (songs of heroic deeds) located Charlemagne's battles against the Saracens there, to explain the large numbers of tombs. Dante immortalised this site in his poem 'Inferno'. 
The Allée des Alyscamps, which still exists today, was created by the Minimes monks in the 18th century. In 1888, Van Gogh and Gaugin came to paint in these romantic 'Champs Elysées' of Arles. In Antiquity, cemeteries were always outside the boundaries of the town and were often located along major roads. At the start of the Empire, cremation graves, sarcophogi and mausolea were dotted along the side of the Via Aurelia, creating a vast necropolis. 
However, the cemetery became extremely significant during the Paleo-Christian era, with the inhumation of the martyr Saint Genest and the burial of the first Bishops of Arles, who were placed in a chapel later surrounded by a large number of tombs grouped together in several rows.
A priory known as Saint Honorat was constructed circa 1040; it depended on Saint-Victor Abbey in Marseille. The necropolis became an important stop-off point on the pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela and the 'chansons de gestes' (songs of heroic deeds) located Charlemagne's battles against the Saracens there, to explain the large numbers of tombs. Dante immortalised this site in his poem 'Inferno'. 
The Allée des Alyscamps, which still exists today, was created by the Minimes monks in the 18th century. In 1888, Van Gogh and Gaugin came to paint in these romantic 'Champs Elysées' of Arles. The site consists of an alignment of tombs and an excavated section of the Paleo-Christian necropolis. The path runs along the sarcophogi, which are made of local limestone and generally fairly simple in style, with no decoration apart from a kind of adze or ascia (bent iron axe with a cutting edge perpendicular to the handle) and a corner block with lead piping. Some sarcophogi have a funereal inscription on a cartouche in the centre. Many of these texts are now illegible.
The Allée then continues to the remains of the Paleo-Christian necropolis, in front of the church of Saint Honorat Abbey (12th century). All the Abbey's convent buildings were destroyed after the Revolution. Excavations carried out in the 1930s-1950s unearthed piles of sarcophogi with no décor or epigraphs, placed in funeral enclosures. Shards of ceramics and coins led to them being dated to the 4th and 5th centuries. 
In the Middle Ages, this site contained a number of vaults, chapels and funeral monuments. Few vestiges of these constructions remain. Saint Accurse Chapel was built in 1520 at the entrance to the site, next to Saint-Césaire-le-Vieux Church, of which only the Romanesque porch remains. It was built in expiation of the death of Accurse de la Tour, who was killed in a duel by another Arles nobleman. An imposing monument is located further to the right. This is a monument to the consuls, erected in the 18th century in honour of the municipal councillors who died during the 1721 plague. Slightly further on, to the left, is the funeral chapel of the Porcelet family, constructed in the 16th century. 
Now isolated between the SNCF workshops and the Route de la Crau is the 16th century La Genouillade Chapel, also once known as the Chapel of the Smallholders, who had their base there.

label: Théâtre
description: This Baroque-style theatre is a former church which belonged to the Friars Preachers. In 1333, having abandoned Jarnègues Island, they settled in the St Nicolas district of Tarascon, where they were given St Jean Batiste Chapel. They replaced it with a very beautiful church, dedicated to the same Saint. In 1825, the chapel was transformed into a theatre, which was officially inaugurated in 1828. It was destroyed by a fire in 1884. The reconstruction of the theatre began in 1887. The façade was completely recreated and a huge, deep stage was built. The theatre now puts on high-quality performances and accommodates large numbers of spectators.

label: Parc des Bruyères
comment: Located between the districts of Saint-Loup, Saint-Marcel and the Mont de Carpiagne, the Parc des Bruyères was designed on a 101-hectare property.
shortDescription: Located between the districts of Saint-Loup, Saint-Marcel and the Mont de Carpiagne, the Parc des Bruyères was designed on a 101-hectare property.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


Located between the districts of Saint-Loup, Saint-Marcel and Mont de Carpiagne, the Bruyères park was designed on a 101-hectare property, bought by the city in 1980. On the edge of the urban area, it occupies both sides of the Evêque valley and is a green hinge between the eastern districts and the calanques. Its relief is characteristic by its altitude variations ranging between 120 and 570 meters. Its endemic vegetation is made up of remarkable shrub species (rockroses, arbutus...) and in particular, the heather Erica arborea which inspired the name of the site. Very popular with walkers and hikers, it offers a starting point in the massif of Saint-Cyr, as well as a cultural walk to discover ancient remains (lime kilns, terraces of olive trees, old sheepfolds ...). In 2006, the municipality joined forces with the Conseil Général and other site managers to inform users about fire hazards and the opening of reception areas in the massifs: a single telephone number to find out everything from 1 July to 9 September: 0811 20 13 13 (cost of a local call).

label: Le Musée de l'aviation
comment: Come and discover the Saint-Victoret Aviation Museum, unique in the region!
shortDescription: Come and discover the Saint-Victoret Aviation Museum, unique in the region!
description:
The Aviation Museum, created in 2005, is developing thanks to the work of volunteers, most of whom come from the aeronautical world, but who share the same passion. The growing collection allows visitors to get closer to the aircraft, most of which were designed and manufactured in the Eurocopter factory, only a few kilometres away. The viewing and model rooms are also an opportunity to learn more about the aircraft, a children's video area, and a souvenir shop

The museum is open every day (except Sunday) from 9am to 12pm. Guided tour with commentary by retired volunteers (Airbus, aviation...)

The Municipality, which is in charge of the project, does not intend to stop there and is soliciting aeronautical companies and the various army staffs to obtain other aircraft to be exhibited to the general public.

Today, the museum houses many aircraft such as Mirage III, Fouga Magister, Paris Morane-Saulnier, Robin, Tracker, as well as helicopters from the former Eurocopter Djinn range, Alouette II and III, Gazelle, Ecureuil, Dauphin, Super-Puma, an equipped Canadair cabin, a gyrocopter, hang gliders and many other aeronautical pieces.

Last acquisition : Tucano, Air plume, Pou du Ciel X3 Girodyne Experimental AS350 Ecureuil EC120 (HCE COLIBRI) EC155 Dauphin Derive Fenestron motorized AS365 Dauphin Alouette 2 Alat Ejection simulator Tucano Drone ORKA and TANAN NH90 and the MIRAGE F1
Surface of the permanent exhibition : 2211

label: Hôtel de Ville
comment: The town hall is housed in a former Renaissance-style hostel.
shortDescription: The town hall is housed in a former Renaissance-style hostel.
description: On June 26, 1514, Jérôme de Varadier bought a house with a Renaissance-style courtyard. On the façade, he had the coat of arms of his family's three rings carved. In 1650, Sieur Villard bought the hotel and transformed it into an important post house. In the following century, it becomes Auberge de France. In 2001, it was bought by the municipality, to become the new Town Hall in 2008.

label: Mémorial des Rapatriés l'hélice de César
comment: This sculpture was made by César, a child of the town, in 1971 as a tribute to the repatriates from North Africa.
shortDescription: This sculpture was made by César, a child of the town, in 1971 as a tribute to the repatriates from North Africa.
description: From the esplanade, you can see the islands of Marseille in the distance, which mark the entrance to the calanques, and looking to the left, the Prado seaside park and its green spaces.

label: Le lavoir Notre-Dame
comment: A troglodyte washhouse at the eastern exit of the town of Pertuis.
shortDescription: A troglodyte washhouse at the eastern exit of the town of Pertuis.
description:
A "TROGLODYTE" WASHHOUSE
Established in 1882 in the city wall, near the old Notre-Dame gate, this washhouse is sheltered by a low vault, forming a bridge under the rue des Tisserands.
Its parallel basins, fed by a gutter dug against the back wall, are subdivided into two: at the top, the "refrescador", or washing basin, from which the water flows into the "lavador", the actual washhouse.

THE BUGADO
Women used to kneel in wooden boxes lined with straw to wash their clothes. the "bugado", a big white laundry, made at home with wood ashes in the "lou tineu" or laundry vat, was usually done only once or twice a year, in spring and autumn! The laundry was then taken to the wash house or to the river to be rinsed with running water.

"LOU LAVADOU DI PEVOU
The Notre-Dame washhouse is popularly called "des Poux". The proximity of the fountain that adjoins it is perhaps not foreign to this name. Horses, mules and other draught or pack animals entering the town used to drink there.

label: Place Jules Morgan
description: The square Morgan main and inescapable stage of the city of Salon, for the tourist, for the salonais. It hosts various events.

label: Murs peints de Marignane
comment:
The city center is decorated with several beautiful and varied recent painted walls.
Many decorations also refer to aviation or to the history of Marignane.
One can also notice large portraits of Raimu (photographs) on a façade of the Museum.
shortDescription:
The city center is decorated with several beautiful and varied recent painted walls.
Many decorations also refer to aviation or to the history of Marignane.
One can also notice large portraits of Raimu (photographs) on a façade of the Museum.
description:
Developed in the 1980s, muralist art has been invited into the urban planning of Marignane in various parts of the city centre
