A stroll will allow you to appreciate a range of different styles, subjects and artistic choices, traditional, historical, contemporary, colourful or graphic

The identity and specificities of Marignane are thus expressed through Provencal landscapes, local historical figures or tributes to the great names of aviation

Amongst the remarkable works, there is an Emilie de Covet de Marignane at the window of the Aix private mansion from which the sulphurous Mirabeau descended to provoke the scandal that precipitated their unhappy marriage (rue des Bruyères), a series of portraits of the great composers (Beethoven, Bach, Mozart and Stravinsky) set in precious cartouches decorated with garlands of flowers.
These historical winks punctuating the façade of the Conservatoire de musique (7 rue de Verdun, signed by Richard Campana from Marseilles), introduce the great tradition of painted decor
"Le Jardin de Maïthé", a work by Pierre Carnavaggio, at the corner of rue Antoine de Saint-Exupéry and Cours Mirabeau, fully recalls the great hours of Italian architectural trompe-l'œil
A large composition by the artist Armande covers the wall of the building at No. 2 rue Saint-Exupéry, paying a bluish tribute to the aviator Jean Mermoz, and a recent graphic creation from 2010 honours Henri Fabre in his seaplane, immortalised in full flight on the facade of the school group named in his memory
Among the works that have disappeared, Marignane already has the memory of a 20th century muralist heritage, through a "Field of lavender" overshadowed by the new Frédéric Mistral square, or "The South", a vast panorama inspired by the paintings of Vincent Van Gogh, covered by a sober false urban facade now harmonizing the Laurens Deleuil esplanade.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Parc Maureau
description:
The Parc Maureau is located between Places Pisavis and Roux de Brignoles. In the 17th century, the clos Chauffier, named after its owner, included the Place Pisavis, the streets Portalet, de la République and Camille Pellletan. For nearly a century various families acquired the property. In the fifties, the owners were Léonie Renée Chauvet and Eugène Emile Maureau whose daughter Sophie married the painter Raymond Rischman. The property has been laid out as a park, a vast green space in the heart of the town centre.
Open every day from 8am to 6pm.

label: Plage de la Calanque de Figuerolles
comment: Town center towards Calanque de Figuerolles.
shortDescription: Town center towards Calanque de Figuerolles.
description:
Nature: pebbles and rocks. Panel of regulations on the site. Parking area near the beach, fitted out and not paying. Capacity of the area: 20 vehicles. Restaurants, accommodation nearby. 
Dogs, fires, campsite and kite surf forbidden.

label: Domaine de Lagoy
comment: The Domaine de Lagoy is an agricultural property located north of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence and integrated into the Parc Régional des Alpilles. Its central point is the castle of Lagoy, classified as a historical monument, whose construction dates back to 1714.
shortDescription: The Domaine de Lagoy is an agricultural property located north of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence and integrated into the Parc Régional des Alpilles. Its central point is the castle of Lagoy, classified as a historical monument, whose construction dates back to 1714.
description:
The Domaine de Lagoy produces "organic" red and rosé wines which benefit from the IGP Alpilles appellation. These are wines of character that express their terroir with fruity notes and a beautiful freshness. The vineyard was established for the major part of its 18 ha in 1976 on the Petite Crau plateau and has been producing "organic" wines since 2001.

It is composed solely of noble grape varieties: Grenache (34%), Cinsaut (21%), Syrah (14%), Merlot (11%), Cabernet Sauvignon (9%), the remaining 11% being divided equally between Caladoc and Marsellan.

The terroir on which the vineyard is located is particularly favourable to quality production.

The estate is only open during the Heritage Days. You can taste the wines at the shop in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence.

label: La Pastorale du Regagnas
comment: Come to this farming estate for an educational experience. Nature and discovery trips organised for school groups.
shortDescription: Come to this farming estate for an educational experience. Nature and discovery trips organised for school groups.
description:
Educational farm

Themes:
- Find out about the Rove goat: its origin, appearance and life cycle (reproduction, growth, etc.)
- Behaviour and lifestyle (character, living in a herd, diet, etc.)
- Milking goats and the transformation of milk into cheese
- History of the Rove goat and 'brousse du Rove' cheese. The role of dogs in herding. The goat farming profession in Provence. 

All year round: marked trails for a self-guided tour of the farm and farm animals (goats, donkeys, horses, chickens, ducks, geese, etc.).
Bookings are compulsory for group guided tours. From February: feeding the newborns from a bottle at 5pm.

Visitors welcome: holiday camps, high schools, disabled people, the elderly.
streetAddress: ['5553 Route de Saint Zacharie', 'Hameau de Kirbon']

label: Oppidum de Teste-Negre
description:
Ruins of Teste-Negre Oppidum. 

Remains of dwellings from the La Tène period, inhabited by the Ligurians. There is no longer any access to this site.

label: Médiathèque de Cornillon-Confoux
comment: Media library of Cornillon-confoux
shortDescription: Media library of Cornillon-confoux
description: With temporary exhibitions, an intermunicipal media library and a complete documentation to discover our village and its surroundings...

label: Parc Maurin
description: Maurin Park offers three complementary areas: a playground for children, a botanical garden devoted to Provencal species and a park around a lake.

label: Passage Agard
comment: Created in 1846 by Félicien Agard, who owned a large part of the former Grands Carmes convent.
shortDescription: Created in 1846 by Félicien Agard, who owned a large part of the former Grands Carmes convent.
description:
This arcade is the busiest and most direct way from Cours Mirabeau to Place du Palais de Justice. 

Now an open-air shopping mall, it preserves some architectural elements of the former Church of the Madeleine. 

The southern end of the arcade is narrower because Félicien Agard never managed to buy No. 57 of the Cours. 

The arcade is closed with grille gates at night.

label: Fontaine d'Espéluque
comment: The spring, named Espeluco, located at the top of the present Jules Isaac Avenue, north of the city, poured in the fourteenth century into a water point in the Saint-Sauveur chapter, outside the city walls.
shortDescription: The spring, named Espeluco, located at the top of the present Jules Isaac Avenue, north of the city, poured in the fourteenth century into a water point in the Saint-Sauveur chapter, outside the city walls.
description:
The oldest is the Espeluque fountain (Espeluco means “cave” in Provençal). 


For many years the only source of water for the old market town of Saint-Sauveur (15th century), it was moved several times before being finally installed in the new place de l’Archevêtché by Georges Vallon in 1756. 


It has been adorned with a medallion commemorating Marcel Provence since 1953.

label: Musée René Verrier
description:
A place steeped in history as it served as a prison stopover on the road leading convicts from Paris to Toulon between 1750 and 1850. The museum exhibits many objects and tools of daily life, collected over the years. A journey through time in Roquevaire.
By appointment only

label: Passage du Canal de Craponne par Pélissanne
description:
Thanks to the Canal de Craponne, built between 1554 and 1559 by the engineer Adam de Craponne, the Pelisan farmers could have plenty of water to water their crops.
Numerous mills were installed on its course: oil mills, wheat mills and sheet trimmers.
The Canal and its bridges can be seen on the old road to Lambesc as well as at the Moulin Jean Bertrand.

label: Hôtel particulier Clerc de Molières
description: Joseph Clerc de Molières was Cannon of the Collegiate Church and did a lot of work to help the poor. He bought this private mansion in the 17th century and dedicated part of this house to be transformed into a charity hospital.

label: Conservatoire du Patrimoine Médical de Marseille
comment: In 1998, At the request of the association, a responsability centre 5 RC) was created within the framework of the AP-HM and by decision of it s directions, called the conservatory of Medical heritage.
shortDescription: In 1998, At the request of the association, a responsability centre 5 RC) was created within the framework of the AP-HM and by decision of it s directions, called the conservatory of Medical heritage.
description:
The original  concept of the conservatory of medical Heritage is to gather in one place a documentation centre, historical research and museum collection.

The conservatory of Medical Heritage is regularly consulted by historians, students, journalists, writers, scholars lookin for bibliographical references on documents on the  history of health care in Marseille, on the  history of its hospitals and its actors. 

The conservatory exhibit part of its museum collection in renovated premises which include objects, statues, paintings and documents from the heritage of the AP-HM and the association.

The reconstitution of an old medical practice and operating theatre of the  period highlights the elements of the  heritage in a  real situation.

label: Halle aux Grains
comment: Taxes on wheat were one of the main revenues of the city. In 1759, from a pre-existing building, the grain market was built by the architect Georges Vallon.
shortDescription: Taxes on wheat were one of the main revenues of the city. In 1759, from a pre-existing building, the grain market was built by the architect Georges Vallon.
description:
He chose the site where the market was regularly held. The pediment was created by the sculptor Jean-Pancrace Chastel. It represents an allegory of the Rhone, the Durance and the fertility of the region.

Currently, the grain market houses the post office, the town hall and an annex of the Méjanes library.

label: Le Regagnas
comment: Located at the eastern end of the department, the Regagnas massif extends into the neighbouring department of the Var.
shortDescription: Located at the eastern end of the department, the Regagnas massif extends into the neighbouring department of the Var.
description:
Situated to the far East of the Bouches-du-Rhône, the Massif du Regagnas stretches into the neighbouring Var region. It is framed to the North by the Massif du Concors and Massif de la Sainte-Victoire, to the West by the hills of Gardanne, and to the South by the Etoile and Garlaban chains and the southern part of the Massif de la Sainte-Baume.

From a topographical viewpoint, the central area of the Massif du Regagnas resembles a northwards-sloping plateau, carved with mainly North-South facing valleys, some of which are fairly wide and suitable for crop growing, as at Kirbon. The plateau is bordered to the south by the North-facing crest line formed by Regagnas mountain, set overlooking the town of Bouilladisse. This crest line stretches northeastwards to the Var region's Monts Auréliens. The eastern section of the massif is characterised by a sloping relief oriented northwest and southeast. A second crest line, situated to the far South of the town of Trets, is separated from the first by the Clos de Barry dip.

…

The Massif du Regagnas benefits from a Provencal Mediterranean type climate, characterised by a high rate of sunshine, long summer droughts, high average annual temperatures, a frequent Mistral wind (diverted by the Sainte-Victoire massif) and, to a lesser extent, southeasterly and southwesterly winds.

…

Forming a transitional zone between the Sainte-Victoire and Sainte-Baume massifs, its tower-like relief constitutes a visual frontier to the Pays d’Aix area. Highly forested, its northern face is nonetherless barren in places this is particularly visible from the Plaine de l’Arc to the foothills of the Sainte-Victoire. Its piedmont is still used for farming purposes, with predominant wine growing (Côtes de Provence AOC area). 

The southern face is more discreet and difficult to observe: the massif's foreground tends to obstruct more distant views over its high chain. This face is home to highly typical sites, including ancient farms still in operation and little chapels. …

Animal farming in the Massif du Regagnas is relatively well-developed, and a study in 2002 confirmed the presence of two industrial farms at La Barque (700 ewes raised for meat) and Trets (70 goats and ewes raised for milk), plus grazing herds at the Peynier site (30 castrated goats and rams), Fuveau (1,000 ewes from the town of Alleins) and Trets / Fuveau (120 milk-producing ewes from the town of Saint-Savournin). 

Horse riding is a popular activity, but is mainly practised in the plains bordering the massif, home to several horse breeders, who use the massif for trekking purposes rather than grazing. 

Although agriculture in the massif has regressed, in particular due to urban development, it remains a relatively thriving industry in the Vallée de l’Arc and in certain areas of the massif, in particular thanks to wine growing. Local agriculture is favoured by the presence of various AOC and quality labels, with several vineyards producing Côtes de Provence AOC wines. The massif is located at the edge of the Aix-en-Provence AOC olive oil growing area and also produces "Red Label" honey and Herbes de Provence.

… 

Public frequentation is fairly widely distributed throughout the massif but remains concentrated on the existing tracks and footpaths. It is increasingly popular with mountain bikers, and reputed for its various itineraries and downhill runs.

Last but not least, urban development is rife in the area, where population growth is far above the Bouches-du-Rhône regional average. Houses are mainly of pavilion type and are widely installed in both natural and agricultural zones, hence exacerbating forest fire hazards. However, development projects currently appear to be slowing down somewhat.

label: Eglise Saint Canadet
comment: Visit the church of Saint Canadet in Le Puy Sainte Réparade, in baroque and roman style
shortDescription: Visit the church of Saint Canadet in Le Puy Sainte Réparade, in baroque and roman style
description: It owes its name to Saint Pierre aux Liens, in Provençal, "San ¨Peyre Encadenat" who gave his name to Saint-Canadet. The altar and the altarpiece of baroque style are of the XVIIth century. A magnificent Romanesque portal adorns the facade, topped by a Provençal campanile.

label: Eglise Saint Michel
description: Romanesque church with three naves, in Cassis stone, it was built and opened for worship in the 19th century. Masses and possibility of baptisms and weddings.

label: La porte Gachiou et les anciens remparts
description: The Gachiou gate : XIVth century, the last vestige of the medieval area of Aubagne, one of the seven gates of the ramparts built in 1373 by Raymond de Baux, baron of Aubagne. These ramparts surrounded the castle demolished during the French Revolution.

label: Fondation Louis Jou
comment:
A talented artist, engraver, illustrator, typographer and publisher, Louis Jou
shines through with a work that combines creative power and perfection of execution.
shortDescription:
A talented artist, engraver, illustrator, typographer and publisher, Louis Jou
shines through with a work that combines creative power and perfection of execution.
description: The most beautiful works of Louis Jou are exhibited in an intimate setting in the six rooms of the Hôtel Renaissance Jean de Brion, amidst the marbles and the many collections of incunabula, old books, engravings by Dürer and Goya, paintings, sculptures and ceramics. Also visit the workshop containing the hand presses of Louis Jou, master typographer, engraver, printer and editor. Louis Jou (1881-1968) was one of the greatest typographers of the century. He was the only one of his peers to design and produce a work completely on his own. A xylographer and metal engraver, Jou designed and created his own characters. He decorated some of the bindings of works printed on his presses. Originally from Catalonia, he produced books which have had a major influence on the development of the contemporary book. The master typographer was also a fully-fledged artist - engraver, painter, sculptor and ceramicist.

label: Musée de l'Empéri, de Salon et de la Crau et salle Théodore Jourdan
comment: Perched on the rock of Puech overlooking the town of Salon, the medieval fortress of the Empéri was residence of the archbishops of Arles 9th to 18th centuries.
shortDescription: Perched on the rock of Puech overlooking the town of Salon, the medieval fortress of the Empéri was residence of the archbishops of Arles 9th to 18th centuries.
description: It now houses the old collections Raoul and Jean Brunon, rich of France, devoted to the French military history from Louis XIV up to the great war (1914-1918), and property of the Museum of the army. The beautiful architecture of the 30 rooms of the Castle helped to highlight the 10,000 authentic pieces exposed in a modern and varied presentation: uniforms, weapons, flags, paintings and graphics.

label: Terre de Méjanes
comment: The site is built around the Mas de Méjannes (or Domaine Paul Ricard), on 64 ha in the commune of Les Saintes Maries de la Mer.
shortDescription: The site is built around the Mas de Méjannes (or Domaine Paul Ricard), on 64 ha in the commune of Les Saintes Maries de la Mer.
description: On the edge of the Etang du Vaccarès nature reserve, the Domaine Paul Ricard de Méjanes offers a privileged approach to the Camargue and its traditions, and offers many tourist activities: guided tours, trails, arenas, local products.

label: Musée de Ventabren
description:
The municipality of Ventabren has preserved its heritage, you can discover it and part of the history of the village at the archaeological museum in the tourist office. Exhibition of many and various objects from the excavations of the Celto-Ligurian Oppidum of Roquefavour, some remains of the castle of Queen Jeanne, some fragments of frescoes from the Hermitage Saint-Honorat.
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 25
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 10

label: Aqueduc de Roquefavour
comment: The Aqueduct of Roquefavour is a 19th century work of art
shortDescription: The Aqueduct of Roquefavour is a 19th century work of art
description:
The Roquefavour Aqueduct allows water from the Marseille canal to cross the Arc over the communes of Ventabren and Aix to supply the city of Marseille. Its creation was decided by the mayor of the city of Marseille, Maximin de Consolat, who entrusted the project to a young engineer, Franzt Mayor de Montricher. The work is composed of three rows of arcades, it is 375 meters long and 83 meters high. Its construction started in 1841 and was completed in 1847. Registered in the register of historical monuments in 2002,
the Roquefavour aqueduct has been recognized as the largest stone work in the world.

label: Archives Municipales
comment: The Municipal Archives are one of the oldest and most important municipal archive centres in France. More than 12 linear kilometres of documents are kept there, the oldest dating from the 12th century.
shortDescription: The Municipal Archives are one of the oldest and most important municipal archive centres in France. More than 12 linear kilometres of documents are kept there, the oldest dating from the 12th century.
description:
Housed in the renovated premises of the former Belle de Mai tobacco factory, the Municipal Archives are one of the oldest and most important municipal archive centres in France. More than 12 linear kilometres of documents are kept there, the oldest dating from the 12th century.

The mission of the cultural action is to enhance and promote the collections of the Municipal Archives of Marseille.

This is done through mediation towards all publics through various actions in situ and outside the walls:

- design and presentation of exhibitions based on our own collections (but also hosting co-produced exhibitions)
- Guided tours of the collections and the building
- Open days during the European Heritage Days
- Conferences, study days and symposiums in an auditorium with 148 seats.
- Design and publication of books and virtual exhibitions
- Design and distribution of derivative products: posters, postcards, etc.
- Reading of archives, concerts...

On the occasion of Marseille, European Capital of Culture 2013, we are planning events in partnership with other cultural establishments in order to once again broaden our audience and help people discover our riches.

The aim is to enable as many people as possible, whether young or old, educated or not, from Marseille or elsewhere, to access the memory of the City of Marseille. Through the archives, the aim is to make everyone aware of the fact that they need to know more about the past, both their own and that of their city

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Bleus
description:
Called also Notre-Dame of Grace Chapel, it is a model of the architecture of the Counter-Reformation.
This chapel was successively property of the Hospital, the place of worship of the local Italian community, to end in a place of exhibition and culture today.
It is particularly recommended to admire the octagonal bell tower, the sculptures of the facade, the gargoyles and the characteristic windows.
The octagonal bell tower was built from 1633 till 1650 and the interior design of certain windows carries dates 1693 or 1694.
The Chapel was classified as Historic Monument on March 31, 1992.

label: L'Estaque et les peintres
comment: At the far north of Marseille, nestling at the foot of the Nerthe mountain range which protects it from the Mistral wind, the small port of l'Estaque (attache, in Provencal), remains one of the most picturesque districts of the city.
shortDescription: At the far north of Marseille, nestling at the foot of the Nerthe mountain range which protects it from the Mistral wind, the small port of l'Estaque (attache, in Provencal), remains one of the most picturesque districts of the city.
description:
In the northernmost part of Marseille, nestling at the foot of the Nerthe massif, the little port of Estaque (meaning attachment in Provençal) is still one of the most picturesque districts of the city. Its development over the centuries has been closely associated with the traditional tile-making industry. At the beginning of the 20th century, people would come to L'Estaque to try sea urchins, bouillabaisse, panisses and sardines in hotels and restaurants built on the water's edge. Bastides, seaside villas (Château Fallet, Villa la Palestine, etc.) veritable architectural follies, etc. started to spring up next to the traditional small houses belonging to the workers from the nearby tile factories and cement works.
For art enthusiasts, Estaque is above all one of the key locations in the birth of modern painting. From Collioure to Menton, just to consider the Mediterranean coast, there are plenty of places that have attracted great painters. However are there many places that can boast to have been frequented over a period of sixty years (1860-1920) by ten or so renowned artists? The name of L'Estaque is associated with impressionism, fauvism, cubism: these three periods that to a great extent determined the nature of painting in our time. Although Cézanne and Braque are the two major figures, we should not forget painters such as Derain, Dufy, Marquet, Friesz, Macke, Renoir, Guigou and Monticelli. Most of them painted dozens of canvasses at Estaque. An unusual destiny indeed for this village, which can firstly be explained by its situation: it offers an exceptional view point, where the panorama of the bay of Marseille is often very striking.
The explanation for the painters' inspiration can also be found in the large number of different subjects, and in the variety of shapes and colours, all concentrated in a relatively small space: the horizontal sea, the vertical factory chimneys, the curves of the hills and the arches of the viaducts, the play of ochres and reds responding to the intensity of the myriad of greens and blues.
A walking tour presents the history of this colourful working-class district with a strong character, little different nowadays from the village the painters knew and loved. Many of the themes are still here. To see them you just need to know how to look. Starting from the harbour jetty, take the painters' path, and after this walk lasting roughly two hours you will understand why these artists were so attracted to these sites. Eight enamelled lava information panels are positioned at various points of the walk.

label: Le Grand Caunet - La Marcouline
comment: The Calanques, Grand Caunet and Sainte-Baume massifs are located at the southeastern end of the department and extend over nearly 26,000 ha, from the southern outskirts of the city of Marseille to the border with the Var department.
shortDescription: The Calanques, Grand Caunet and Sainte-Baume massifs are located at the southeastern end of the department and extend over nearly 26,000 ha, from the southern outskirts of the city of Marseille to the border with the Var department.
description:
This ensemble presents a rugged relief whose altitude varies from 0 to 1,000 m and whose slopes are often steep in its most coastal part. This gradually softens towards the North-East (Montagne de la Sainte-Baume) while remaining fairly marked.

These three massifs are located in the climatic zone of coastal Provence

Average temperatures are mild (13 to 14°C) with amplitudes attenuated by maritime influences. Rainfall is low, between 500 and 700 mm/year on average, even if the maritime inlets are generally accompanied by rising air humidity. ..

Situated within the small natural region of the southern limestone ranges, the Calanques, Grand Caunet and Sainte-Baume massifs are characterised by a rather low average afforestation rate (47%), with several distinct entities, however, from the point of view of vegetation :

- east and South Sainte-Baume as well as the Calanques and Cap Canaille, which have been regularly burned in recent decades and are composed of garrigues and young pine forests in regeneration, more or less dense
- north-East Sainte-Baume and the large area between La Penne-sur-Huveaune, Aubagne, Gémenos Sud, Roquefort-la-Bédoule, Carnoux, Cassis Est, La Ciotat Est and Ceyreste, made up of mature stands of Aleppo Pine or Holm and White Oak to the north.
- The forest stands are overwhelmingly composed of Aleppo Pine (90%), the other species being deciduous as an accompaniment (Holm Oak and White Oak in particular) or pure stands on the north-eastern slopes of the Sainte-Baume and Fontblanche.

The Calanques form an emblematic massif. It is very popular throughout the year, but particularly in the summer period by the attraction that this area represents for tourism

The Calanques, Cap Canaille and Grand Caunet parts are characterised by very high landscape, ecological and human stakes, linked to a marked peri-urban context, a very attractive coastal location and the special status of a classified site (Calanques, Cap Canaille...) and a Natura 2000 site (Calanques - Saint-Cyr, Cap Canaille, Grand Caunet).

The Marcouline and Grand Caunet sectors, which have been spared from major forest fires for several decades, are less frequent during the summer. Nevertheless, they contribute to the landscape quality of the eastern part of the department by standing out due to their more forested atmosphere.

This remarkable context has given rise to the establishment of many ZAPEFs, whether in peri-urban areas or in a more forested context. However, there are still several highly frequented areas on the coast, including during periods of risk, which will require specific measures: Ile Verte, Mugel, Figuerolles sur La Ciotat, Port Miou, Port Pin, En Vau, Morgiou, Sormiou and Marseilleveyre on the Calanques.

comment: A site anchored in its history, a past to be reappropriated..
shortDescription: A site anchored in its history, a past to be reappropriated..
description:
This former agricultural property, whose origin dates back to the French Revolution, was once a cultivated area and is a symbol of Mediterranean polyculture.
This rehabilitated heritage has become a unique place offering 235 hectares of public natural spaces.
It is also the gateway to the hills for walkers and hikers.

We invite you to use public transport as an alternative to the car in order to preserve the site (no parking on the estate).
streetAddress: ['Chemin De la Font de Mai', "Route d'Eoures"]

label: Fontaine de Cassis
description: The 18th century fountain is listed in the inventory of Historic Monuments and was inspired by the more monumental fountain built in Paris on the Place des Victoires, which commemorated the fountain of Louis XIV. The Fountain of Cassis was built in 1651 and accidentally destroyed in 1785. This monument could be at the origin of the saying "Qu a vist Paris se noun a vist Cassis, pou dire: n'ai rén vist (Frédéric Mistral).

label: Le Garlaban
comment: Situated in the south-eastern quarter of the department, the Etoile and Garlaban massifs largely surround the southern conurbations of Marseille and Aubagne.
shortDescription: Situated in the south-eastern quarter of the department, the Etoile and Garlaban massifs largely surround the southern conurbations of Marseille and Aubagne.
description:
Located in the southeastern quarter of the Bouches-du-Rhône, the Massif de l’Etoile and Massif du Garlaban encircle a major part of the territories of Marseille and Aubagne, situated to the South. These chains are bordered by the Arbois, Montaiguet, Collines de Gardanne and Regagnas chains to the North, by the Valley of Aubagne to the East and the A7 highway to the West, which forms a barrier between the massif and the Côte Bleue coast. 

The two massifs are separated by the D908 main road.

 The relief and general East-West orientation of the Etoile-Garlaban chain provoke a strong masking effect, with striking contrasts between the adret (South-facing) and ubac (North-facing) slopes. 

The southern slopes of the Etoile and Garlaban are characterized by a typical Mediterranean climate.

The northern slopes are characterized by a cooler and wetter micro-climate, with lower temperatures, higher rainfall and shorter summer droughts. The prevailing wind is the Mistral, which blows from the north-northwest. 

The aerological phenomena created by the numerous valleys crossing the southern slopes are complex. The prevailing winds are northwesterly on the peaks, and southwesterly to southeasterly blowing from the bottom of the valleys upwards, with a general acceleration on the slope due to its steep incline. …

The Massif du Garlaban offers the same contrasts, with the presence of evergreen oak woods and durmast oaks to the North, and sparse Aleppo pine populations to the South. Forestation is very low (7.5 %, i.e. 1,370 acres) further to repeated fires in the massif. The predominant formation is garrigue (kermes oaks, spiny Brachypoda, Cistus, Aphyllante of Montpellier and gorse). The arborescent stratum essentially comprises Aleppo pines (75% or more) these populations represent just 865 acres, located in a discontinuous fashion to the northwest of the massif and on the piedmont.

The Massif de l'Etoile and Massif du Garlaban comprise a natural barrier between Marseille, Aix, Gardanne and Aubagne, and largely influence the urban dynamics of the surrounding towns. Their peri-urban location means they are the target of extensive development projects moreover, the absence of a transition zone between the highly urbanized and natural areas is extremely apparent.

In their role as a peri-urban massif and genuine green lung of Marseille, Aubagne and their neighbouring towns, the Massif de l’Etoile and Massif du Garlaban play a significant social role, with an estimated frequentation of 250,000 visitors per year, most of which are locals due to their somewhat "confidential" access routes. …

The Massif du Garlaban is an emblem and symbol of "authentic" Provence, brought to international fame by the films of Marcel Pagnol. The Garlaban attracts many visitors and has now been fitted with numerous footpaths. Moreover, the site is home to over a hundred rare or protected species, many of which are protected by international laws, such as the Bonelli's eagle, eagle owl and short-toed eagle. 

These two massifs form part of the Etoile-Garlaban Natura 2000 site. The Massif du Garlaban is also a coveted hunting site.

label: Les Oratoires d'Orgon
comment: The Oratories of Orgon.
shortDescription: The Oratories of Orgon.
description: The path of oratories: on the five oratories which, formerly, along through the Hill the trail to Notre-Dame de Beauregard, three are still present two missing oratories are probably the second and fifth of the series. The second, La Visitation, which there is more no trace, was following the Oratory of Annunciation. This fifth and last, located near the rocks forming a sort of door to door to a hundred steps of the Chapel, kept the solid mass from its base currently supporting a steel cross that replaces the old building.-Oratory of Annunciation: the Oratory of the Annunciation is located opposite the rectory and near the gate of the Hortet. It is attached to the retaining of an orchard of olive trees wall. It is a massive building in stone with a slightly curved slab topped with a metal cross formed roof. Its low base supports a large niche at the bottom of which a very mutilated sculpture depicts the Virgin and the Ange.The history of this oratory, recorded in the annals of the country in 1515 is described by Amable Columbus in a manual of 1877: «one day, a downpour fell on Orgon.» Real torrents rushed from the top of the mountain and came to fight with fury the ramparts of the city. The walls collapsed with a bang and fell on nearby houses which is shot down with debris from the walls on the first oratory. Believed totally crushed. But, incredibly, when excavation was done, the oratory appeared standing, as it was prior to the disaster, without cracks or crevices, in a Word, in a wonderful state of preservation. » - Oratory to the glory of Jesus and Mary: this remarkable oratory still has his same elegance of architecture Renaissance. It consists of a pedestal narrower than the niche that it supports and the whole edifice is backed on a wall. The niche is framed by two pillars. The right one is very crafted. Inside of the niche, a bas-relief represents four people beheaded by the years. Two beautiful figures of angels animate the pediment top. Under the Arch of the niche, there is the inscription: Hoc opus fieri Amedeus Roverely and Urgone Anno Domini aleata 1516 fecerunt.Here's the translation: "Amédée Rovereli and Alet, his wife, Orgon, have been raising this monument the year of our Lord 1516.Louis Espérandieu, artist painter born in Orgon (1787-1857) is the author of a painting "Scene of Rogation" before this oratory. This canvas carried out in 1835 faithfully reproduces the female costumes for the last century. This oratory is listed in the supplementary inventory of Historic Monuments since July 22, 1935. The base is adorned with sculptures: at the centre a coat of arms bearing an inscription at the bottom shell and above, under the slab supporting the niche a head, an allegorical motif symbolizing the Sun and an acanthus leaf. -Oratory of the massacre of the Innocents and the flight into Egypt: the third oratory existing on this picturesque door mounted, the vault, an engraved inscription which allows to know the word: Come Herod Inocens SIBS for Jesus will die martyrdom it consists of a large niche arches framed by two fluted pilasters topped with capitals, lying low above the ground-based. The pediment, with roof, bears in its Center a figure of Christ. Two bas-reliefs occupy the bottom of the niche. They may, by their composition evoke: the top, the most important, the Massacre of the Innocents the lower, the flight into Egypt.Oratory of Saint-Antoine: in front of the Oratory of the Annunciation, a small niche which housed a statue is recessed in the corner of the wall, which runs alongside the path leading to the portal giving access to the ancient village of "La Savoie.Oratory of the Madeleine: the District of Bazardes, along the path of the Madeleine at the bottom of the Saint-Roch Chapel, is a graceful monument of the 17th century, backed by a dry stone wall. This is the Oratory of the Madeleine. Raised in three markets, it is built of Ashlar and consists of a large niche semicircular, framed by pilasters with Ionic capitals, in which one sees a polychrome relief depicting Christ after his Resurrection in Madeleine. On the basis of the building there, in a nice cartridge, coat of arms which cannot distinguish the engravings. The top cartridge bears the inscription: Noli me tangere (touch me not) and the vintage 1663.Oratory our Lady of oak: This oratory also known as Michel hides in the Oaks, sue Valdition road, on a hill bordering the road. He was high in 1870 by the Dacla family, remembering the healing miraculous Miss Anaïs Montanier, which occurred on September 1, 1858 after swallowing a sheet torn to the oak of the appearance of August 30, 1953. Built in stone, its solid base that rests on a wide base of both markets, is surmounted by a niche willowy containing a statue of the Virgin Mary protected by a grid. The roof supports a cross ornate iron forged. Four terminals interconnected by channels play all. Two columns supporting each and the building was surrounded by two street lamps cast an ornamental vase. Lampposts have been missing since 20 years. There are more than a very dilapidated column.

label: Hôtel d'Ailhaud
description:
This classical Louis XV style tripartite walnut door is very high. 

The panels are asymmetric with a faun's head on one side and a girl's head on the other. 

The lower panels are decorated with low-relief floral mosaic.

Text : OTAIX/ENTE

label: Tour de l'Horloge - Beffroi
comment: Gateway to the military post of Sextius, then to the town of Saint Sauveur, the communal tower spans the street on a Roman base of white limestone.
shortDescription: Gateway to the military post of Sextius, then to the town of Saint Sauveur, the communal tower spans the street on a Roman base of white limestone.
description:
Straddling the street, on Roman bases of white limestone, the clock tower was the gate of the military outpost of Sextius and then the Bourg Saint Sauveur. 

Raised in 1510 and redecorated with flamboyant pinnacles and ogees, the "great clock tower" was already the symbol and vehicle of the city's unity in the 14th century. 

It carries (top to bottom): the proclamation or "ban" bell, in its 16th-century wrought-iron cage, which called the people to council or defence within a one-league perimeter ("banlieue" or "ban-league" is the modern French word for suburb). 

Today it strikes the hours and the tocsin. The hourly clock, flanked by two modern statues, and the astronomical clock, from 1661, above the wooden figures of the four seasons (early 17th century) which appear in turn. 

Since 1801 a funerary urn dedicated to the spirits of the country's defenders has replaced the bust of Louis XIII in its triumphal frame, which recalled the royal visit in 1622. 

An inscription commemorates the liberation of Aix in August 1944

label: Anse du Corton
description:
Very small pebble cove.
Gastronomic restaurant nearby: La Villa Madie, imagined by Jean-Marc Banzo . A unique, convivial and inventive place where everyone can share their know-how. La Madie parking area, equipped for 160 vehicles (avenue du Revestel). Natural cove not supervised. Animals not allowed.
Direction Casino de jeu, then avenue du Révestel, then le Corton.

label: Maison de la Nature et de la chasse
comment: A splendid farmhouse dedicated to the natural riches of the Crau, the Camargue and the Alpilles
shortDescription: A splendid farmhouse dedicated to the natural riches of the Crau, the Camargue and the Alpilles
description:
The Maison de la Chasse et de la Nature opened its doors in September 2008. This museum aims to introduce the public to the art of hunting and the natural wealth of La Crau, Camargue and the Alpilles.
The Maison de la Chasse et de la Nature is the result of a two-fold ambition. In addition to discovering the region's natural heritage, different nature-lovers can come together with the common objective of preservation.
On the ground floor, permanent exhibitions are displayed in three sections.
- The discovery of the wealth of the three geographical entities of La Crau, Camargue and the Alpilles: geology, fauna, flora, etc. The public can enjoy three extremely realistic slide slows by the Saint Martin painter Marignan, representing different Provençal landscapes and portraying a collection of naturalised animals.
- A range of traditional human activities in the region, such as pastoralism, salt extraction, rice production, oil production and reed cutting.
- A focus on cynegetic activity in the region since the dawn of time.
Upstairs, a large mezzanine is dedicated to temporary exhibitions by wildlife artists and conferences. You can discover the current events in the News/Events section. Finally, the Maison de la Chasse et de la Nature can organise guided visits or nature walks for schoolchildren and groups of adults. Contact us for further information during opening hours.
The project has won the Rubans du Patrimoine Award.
The Rubans du Patrimoine competition has been organised for the last 13 years by the French Building Federation, the Association of Mayors of France, Dexia Crédit Local and the Heritage Foundation. It rewards dynamic actions by Mayors with regard to the restoration of heritage. In 2007, following a selection process involving a large number of dossiers, the project submitted by the town for the future Maison de la Chasse et de la Nature was awarded a Departmental Prize.
There is an educational apiary on the premises. Guided visits available.

label: Village de Roquevaire
description:
Located in the valley of Huveaune between Aubagne and Auriol, Roquevaire is characterized by its relief. Surrounded by the Sainte-Baume and the Garlaban Mountains, Roquevaire regroups the village of Roquevaire and the Pont de l'Etoile, Pont de Joux and Lascours hamlets.
You can admire there a typical landscape made of “restanques” on the slopes, shaped by the orchards (in Lascours particularly).

Roquevaire has two strong patrimonial elements: the most ancient Merovingian chapel of Provence and one of the most important organs of the world.

The ‘Pierre Cochereau's organs': Pierre Cochereau, an organist, was in charge of the Great Organs of Notre-Dame, in Paris, from 1955 to 1984. He used to own an organ of 70 games on 5 keyboards. A part of this organ composes the 5.000 pipesgames of Roquevaire church.
This organ is known as one of the best instruments of the world.

The ‘Saint Vincent chapel': the most ancient Merovingian chapel of Provence (excavations in process).

But also...The oratories, the ‘Bonaparte Bridge', dating from the 16th century, the castle ruins, the steeple dating from the Middle Age.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Blancs
comment: The synagogue of the local Jewish community stood on this site until the beginning of the 14th century.
shortDescription: The synagogue of the local Jewish community stood on this site until the beginning of the 14th century.
description:
Until the early 14th century, the synagogue of the local Jewish community stood on this site. Pope John XXII had the synagogue destroyed after driving out the Jewish community and in its place he had a chapel built and dedicated to Notre-Dame-d’Enville; this was distinct from Saint Bauldile Church, which was then 'extra muros'. It was inaugurated in 1320 and the marriage contract between Hugues de Sade and Laura de Noves was signed there on 16 January 1325.
It was badly damaged at the end of the 16th century and the residents, who were anxious to restore it, created a Brotherhood of White Penitents. (By order of 18 May 1581) It was deconsecrated in 1884; the municipality then sold it to a masonry business, which used it as a warehouse. The commune bought it back in 1950 and transformed it into public baths; it was not until 1995 that it finally became the Marc Mielly Library.
All that remain are the 14th century pentagonal apse and the wall paintings recently discovered under the 18th century whitewash: gothic portal facing the street.
