label: Chapelle Notre-Dame-de-Consolation
comment: The present chapel is located on the site of a former Romanesque church from the 11th century.
shortDescription: The present chapel is located on the site of a former Romanesque church from the 11th century.
description: Ancient Romanesque church originally dedicated to Saint-André belonging to the Hospital St-Jacques, welcomed passing travelers. It becomes towards 1326 Notre-Dame-de-Consolation.

label: Eglise paroissiale Notre-Dame de l'Assomption
comment: The parish church of Rognes does not let its austere architecture reveal the art treasures it contains. Who would believe, when passing by this monument of great sobriety, that it contains a part of the rich heritage of Provence!
shortDescription: The parish church of Rognes does not let its austere architecture reveal the art treasures it contains. Who would believe, when passing by this monument of great sobriety, that it contains a part of the rich heritage of Provence!
description:
Leaning against the ramparts of the city of Rognes, the church dedicated to Our Lady of the Assumption was built from the end of 1607 and completed around 1610. The base of the bell tower is one of the towers that defended the village.
It replaces the church of Notre-Dame de Belvezet located in the medieval district of Saint-Martin, which, dilapidated and too small, was destroyed at the end of the 16th century.
The new parish building was enriched throughout the 17th century, thanks to the orders and financing of the various brotherhoods, with numerous altarpieces and other furniture (today classified as historical monuments) attesting to the know-how of Provencal artists. Among these works is the medieval statue of Notre-Dame de Belvezet, depicting Mary holding the infant Jesus in her arms.
The body of the church has undergone numerous alterations, notably in the 19th century (bell tower, turrets, moving the main door), and other transformations took place after the earthquake of 1909. The mention on the pediment "French Republic" reminds us that it is a building that belongs to the State, law of separation of the Churches and the State in 1905
(Source: Les Amis du Patrimoine de Rognes)

label: Pinède des 4 vents
comment:
A 6-hectare pine forest ideal for nature outings, running or cycling.
A perfect opportunity to try some physical activity adapted to your abilities in a remarkable natural environment, on the edge of the etang de Berre.
shortDescription:
A 6-hectare pine forest ideal for nature outings, running or cycling.
A perfect opportunity to try some physical activity adapted to your abilities in a remarkable natural environment, on the edge of the etang de Berre.
description:
An initial area with outdoor fitness equipment is provided for cardio training, weight training or stretching.

Then, after you have recovered, there is a circuit featuring agility apparatus, which you can complete walking or running.

Interactive terminals will guide you along the route, as you can discover an exceptional natural and cultural heritage through short videos.

label: Chapelle Saint-Pierre
comment: Surrounded by vineyards, a few pines and cypresses from the neighboring cemetery, this building in perfect condition is a superb example of a Provençal Romanesque chapel
shortDescription: Surrounded by vineyards, a few pines and cypresses from the neighboring cemetery, this building in perfect condition is a superb example of a Provençal Romanesque chapel
description: Old stones, apse in the form of an oven, robust buttresses and bell-tower, constitute the archetype. A procession, on the first Sunday in August, thanked Saint-Pierre for sparing the Peyniérens during the terrible epidemic of plague in 1720. Visit of the church possible the first Sunday of August and during the Journées du Patrimoine.

label: Médiathèque intercommunale (Ouest Provence)
comment: The intermunicipal media library Istres Ouest Provence gathers the media libraries of the communes of Cornillon-Confoux; Entressen, Fos-sur-Mer, Grans, Istres, Miramas, Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhône..
shortDescription: The intermunicipal media library Istres Ouest Provence gathers the media libraries of the communes of Cornillon-Confoux; Entressen, Fos-sur-Mer, Grans, Istres, Miramas, Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhône..
description:
It allows its members to borrow books, CDs and DVDs
These documents are classified by theme: art/music/cinema, languages and literature, science/sports/practical life, society and civilization.
A space is reserved for young people following the same themes.

Registration is free for residents of Ouest Provence. It is 9 euros for others.

label: Plage Champigny
comment: Sand beach of 300m by 15m.
shortDescription: Sand beach of 300m by 15m.
description:
The bathing is supervised in July and August
 Water control from June 15th to September 15th. Identification sign on the site. Parking area near the beach, equipped, not paying and supervised. Disabled access.
The Bus de l'étang serves the beach of Champigny regularly during the summer.

label: Ciergerie de l'Abbaye des Prémontrés
comment: In Tarascon, since 1858, authentic candle factory, the shop open to visitors from Monday to Friday.
shortDescription: In Tarascon, since 1858, authentic candle factory, the shop open to visitors from Monday to Friday.
description:
The Ciergerie de l'Abbaye des Prémontrés has been awarded the Entreprise du Patrimoine Vivant (Living Heritage Company) label, perpetuating the ancestral know-how of the Prémontrés White Fathers of the Abbey of Saint Michel de Frigolet in Provence. The Living Heritage Company label is a mark of recognition from the French government awarded to manufacturers with excellent craft and industrial know-how.
It is here in Tarascon, at the foot of the Alpilles mountains, that the master candle makers draw new creative forces from the know-how accumulated over the years so that the history of the White Fathers is perpetuated. They produce candles of all sizes according to two manufacturing techniques dating from the 15th century: "à la louche" and "à la plongée".

label: Musée des outils agraires et des traditions
comment: Museum located in the city center of Châteaurenard.
shortDescription: Museum located in the city center of Châteaurenard.
description: Take a colourful walk through the museum and learn about the development of agriculture in the area, thanks to a collection of ancient tools which were used by cereal farmers, wine makers and market gardeners, some dating back to the 19th century. Find out how these women strived to get the best from land and water, and about their lifestyle, celebrations and traditions.

label: Chapelle Sainte Cécile
comment: Discover this Romanesque style chapel
shortDescription: Discover this Romanesque style chapel
description:
Built in the 8th century, this chapel remains a living testimony of the Middle Ages. Built on the Roman road, the Sainte-Cécile chapel, which gives its name to the district, is the oldest in Châteauneuf. The chapel was given by Hugues des Baux in 1088 to the Abbey of Saint-Gervais de Fos.
In 1975, it was restored by the Municipality and its gardens were developed. It was classified as a historical monument on 14 February 1946.

label: Ruines du château seigneurial de Vernègues
description: On the plateau of Grand Puech stand the ruins of the former seigniorial castle partly destroyed by the earthquake of 1909. Built from the 10th to the 15th century on the rocky escarpment overlooking the village, this fortified castle from the late Middle Ages is typical of the feudal architecture of Provence. Currently forbidden to the public, rehabilitation work should allow its next reopening.

label: Orgue de Sainte Marthe
description: The organ sits against the wall which separates the narthex from the main nave. The instrumental part dates from 1484. It was enlarged in 1712 and given a magnificent polychrome chest created by Charles Boisellin. The structure is listed as a national Historic Monument.

label: Cadolive
description:
Typical Provencal village, with shady squares, narrow streets that wind through the middle of houses topped with round terracotta tiles coloured by the sun.
Like all the surrounding villages, Cadolive is animated by a strong mining tradition
The old wash-house (1894)
The lime kilns or boilers, vestiges of the mining basin.

label: Salle d'exposition archéologique
comment: Archaeological exhibition room with remains from the 5th century
shortDescription: Archaeological exhibition room with remains from the 5th century
description:
The archaeological exhibition room is open to the public by appointment only. You will find in a modern and renovated space ceramics, ornaments, jars as well as a reconstituted hut dating from the 5th century B.C. and coming from the Lançonnais site of Coudounèu.
Surface of the permanent exhibition : 80

label: Centre ancien de Grans
comment: The old centre includes a remarkable set of ornate facades (late 18th-early 19th centuries) especially on the Cours Camille Pelletan.
shortDescription: The old centre includes a remarkable set of ornate facades (late 18th-early 19th centuries) especially on the Cours Camille Pelletan.
description:
Several facades are dated from the reign of Louis XV (Provençal Rocaille style) in particular the n°34, decorated with mascarons the hotel at n°29 has a three level facade, with panels carved with oak and olive leaves, the windows framed with ferns' sticks. At no. 36, the neo-classical-inspired facade is decorated with fluted collosal pilasters unifying the two upper levels in a single flight
This neo-classical style was taken up again during the Restoration (early 19th century), and was made more emphatic and rigorous with thickening of the pilasters and an increase in the decoration and entablature, particularly in the hotels on Place de la Fontaine d'Or and Rue du Four. The luxury of these beautiful residences of the local landed bourgeoisie, which draws its income from the cultivation of mulberry and olive trees, denotes a sense of urban décor, which detracts from a rural setting and seems to have been the work of architects from Avignon or Aix-en-Provence.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame du Château
comment: Romanesque chapel built on an ancient oppidum, it dates from the 11th century and was renovated in the 14th and 19th centuries. It is privately owned and can only be seen from the outside.
shortDescription: Romanesque chapel built on an ancient oppidum, it dates from the 11th century and was renovated in the 14th and 19th centuries. It is privately owned and can only be seen from the outside.
description: Private property; can only be seen from outside. Known under the name Notre Dame de Piargue, this chapel was built by the side of the old Via Aurelia. Although Notre Dame de Piargue is of modest architectural beauty, it faces an exceptional landscape; opposite its old walls lie the magnificent Alpilles, which inspire visitors to stop and admire one of the most harmonious views in this corner of Provence.

label: Parc de la Poudrerie Saint-Chamas - Miramas
comment: The Parc de l'Ancienne Poudrerie Royale, a natural site of more than 100 hectares, protected Natura 2000, is accessible from Saint-Chamas or Miramas-le-Vieux. During the summer, it is open to the public on weekday mornings.
shortDescription: The Parc de l'Ancienne Poudrerie Royale, a natural site of more than 100 hectares, protected Natura 2000, is accessible from Saint-Chamas or Miramas-le-Vieux. During the summer, it is open to the public on weekday mornings.
description:
The Poudrerie Royale was created in 1690, then definitively abandoned in 1974. It remained closed and forbidden to access for about thirty years, which left a natural environment with a remarkable biological diversity: a reed bed, a wetland and a dry environment mainly composed of rockroses, brooms and hackberry trees.

The priceless architectural and historical heritage has remained on site, partly redeveloped and secured: the former powder factory presents strange landscapes with a sometimes baroque and sometimes romantic atmosphere: ruins covered with ivy, mysterious tower dug into the cliff..

Thus, the nature recolonizing the ground offers to the visitor a fabulous spectacle, to be visited by taking the paths.

label: Plages de Corbières
comment: The three beaches of Corbière (la Lave, la Batterie and le Fortin) were built south of l'Estaque, below the N568. A path dug in the rock and stairs allow access on foot.
shortDescription: The three beaches of Corbière (la Lave, la Batterie and le Fortin) were built south of l'Estaque, below the N568. A path dug in the rock and stairs allow access on foot.
description:
Beach surveillance will be from June 1 to August 31, 2022, 7 days a week from 9:30 am to 7 pm.

Shallow and partly shaded, they are made of fine sand and pebbles, equipped with garbage cans, toilets, showers, first aid station.

Nearby there is a refreshment bar, a playground (volleyball...), and a nautical base (sailing school, diving, canoeing, rowing)

Direction "l'Estaque", follow highway A55 du Littoral.
Bus 35 from Place de la Joliette to Plages de Corbières.

label: Centre d'Archéologie Antique - Hôtel de Sade
comment: The Hotel de Sade is an archaeological museum: it was originally occupied by a vast thermal complex dating from the 4th century AD, gradually revealed thanks to the various excavation campaigns conducted since the 1940s.
shortDescription: The Hotel de Sade is an archaeological museum: it was originally occupied by a vast thermal complex dating from the 4th century AD, gradually revealed thanks to the various excavation campaigns conducted since the 1940s.
description: The Museum, located in a Renaissance hotel on the square opposite the Museum of the Alpilles Favier, contains archaeological furniture found at Glanum, an important statuary and a lapidary abundant, consisting of architectural elements, funerary steles and altars votive of time celto-ligure, Hellenistic and Roman. Its visit perfectly complements the discovery of the Gallo-Roman site. Entries are free the first Sunday of each month from October to April

label: Oppidum de Roquepertuse
comment: Roquepertuse is a site classified as a Historic Monument for the remains discovered there. In particular, two statues of warriors and the famous Bicéphale have been unearthed and are now exhibited in the History Museum of Marseille.
shortDescription: Roquepertuse is a site classified as a Historic Monument for the remains discovered there. In particular, two statues of warriors and the famous Bicéphale have been unearthed and are now exhibited in the History Museum of Marseille.
description:
Roquepertuse is a site occupied from the Final Neolithic (2000 BC) to the 2nd century BC. The community of Roquepertuse begins to develop from the 5th century BC, but it is 200 years later that it reaches its maximum size. It is then an important oppidum (fortified Gallic site) which carries out commercial exchanges with the great cities of the region and the Mediterranean basin. The remains visible on the site date from this period
Roquepertuse underwent various attacks during these centuries of occupation. During the 3rd century BC, one of them destroys a large part of the city. Only a few people returned to live there. Around 200 - 190 BC, they are victims in their turn of an attack, which will be the last, the site will be definitively abandoned
In the 19th century, the site of Roquepertuse is covered with fields. It is in 1820 then in 1860 that a farmer working his land discovers two statues of seated warriors, particularly spectacular. He has just unearthed sculptures made about 1500 years earlier!
The first archaeological excavations began in Roquepertuse in 1919. They were directed by Count Henri de Gérin-Ricard, assistant to the director of the Borély Museum in Marseille.
This first research allowed the extraction of more than 200 fragments of lapidary (a set of stone objects) and the discovery of a high quality Bicéphale. In 1967, Roquepertuse is classified as a Historic Monument
A new campaign of excavations will take place from 1992 to 2002. Thanks to these ten years of study, the archaeologists established a precise chronology of the history of the site, which was not a religious sanctuary as the first archaeologists thought, but a great Gallic city.

label: Plage de Fromage
comment: Sandy and rocky beach on avenue Frédéric Mistral
shortDescription: Sandy and rocky beach on avenue Frédéric Mistral
description:
Sand and rock beach 50m x 10m.

Water sports on site with the water sports center accessible for people with reduced mobility
By the way serving the coast.

label: La Poterne
comment: On the way up to Notre Dame du Château, you pass under the Poterne, the old fortified gate of the medieval castle (built between 1141 and 1148).
shortDescription: On the way up to Notre Dame du Château, you pass under the Poterne, the old fortified gate of the medieval castle (built between 1141 and 1148).
description:
It is surmounted by a 17th century niche that once housed a statuette of the Virgin Mary.
The legend tells the story of Janeton, a young shepherdess, eager to meet Prince Charming: One day, she prayed to the Good Mother to answer her prayer, but the Virgin didn't answer. Red with anger, Janeton threw pebbles at the statue, the fifth one got stuck, the Madonna came alive and rebuked Janeton: "You sent 5 pebbles against me, you'll wait 5 years to get married."
Today this monument is the pilgrimage of the country's lovers who want to know how many years they have to wait to get married. They try to put stones on it. Each missed shot represents a year's wait before the wedding.

label: Eglise Saint-Vincent
comment: The church of Saint-Vincent, (unclassified) in Provençal Romanesque style is mentioned in the form of Sanctae Mariae in the 12th century.
shortDescription: The church of Saint-Vincent, (unclassified) in Provençal Romanesque style is mentioned in the form of Sanctae Mariae in the 12th century.
description: With two bays, a single nave with round arches on double arches resting on two side arches, the church has lost its initial simplicity through works and vicissitudes especially in the 19th century: the side arches were then pierced for the creation of side chapels the side pilasters to save space and light are also planed. Then, around 1860, the widening of the square and the main street forced the relocation to the west, and its reconstruction on orgives in a neo-gothic style. At this time, the circular tower on the south side of the church was lowered. The facade, which collapsed in the earthquake of 1909, was fitted with a three-arched bell tower. The church houses a wooden Christ dating from the 17th and 18th centuries and a 15th century statue of Saint Vincent.

label: Arènes d'Alleins
description:
Capacity: 800 places
Shows, cow racing, abrivado, Camargue race, pointe race
They are only open during the races.

label: Caireval et Tresquemoure
comment: With 150 hectares in the commune of Rognes, the estate comes from a bequest established at the beginning of the 20th century. Today it attests to the quality of the department's forest heritage.
shortDescription: With 150 hectares in the commune of Rognes, the estate comes from a bequest established at the beginning of the 20th century. Today it attests to the quality of the department's forest heritage.
description:
Under proud oaks and tall pines whose branches form harmonious patterns in space, the walks are enchanting. The clearings of this Provencal version of the forest of Broceliande open onto magnificent views of the Bouches-du-Rhône. On a clear day, you can even see the sea.

Management of the natural area : Domaine du Conseil Départemental

label: L'Hauture
comment: The Hauture district is the highest part of the city (25 meters above sea level), the only rocky eminence within the surrounding alluvial plain.
shortDescription: The Hauture district is the highest part of the city (25 meters above sea level), the only rocky eminence within the surrounding alluvial plain.
description:
The L'Hauture district is the highest part of the town (altitude of 25 metres), the only rocky knoll on the surrounding alluvial plain.
It was a major base for the urbanisation of the Roman colony and the current district still contains the remains of some of its structures, particularly the amphitheatre, theatre and ramparts.
Furthermore, the remains of the first cathedral complex have been revealed on the south-east corner of the district.
Later, its population of smallholders, shepherds and artisans made their mark on the attractive physiognomy of small simple houses and narrow winding streets, some of which are still paved.
Its heritage, rich past and charm make this district very popular with visitors. The district falls within the protected area, as does the whole town centre.
In the 6th century BC, the L'Hauture rock was occupied by the indigenous population who traded with the Phocaean town of Massalia (Marseille). The district, like the whole of the nascent town, later became predominantly Celto-Ligurian and then Italian.
But it was with the foundation of the Roman colony in 46 BC that the district first experienced large-scale urbanisation. The theatre was built (and the amphitheatre a century later), while an enclosure was constructed, the eastern outlines of which are still visible. The Porte d'Auguste, which opens onto the rampart overlooking the end of the Aurelian Way from Italy, made L'Hauture a key stopover point.
This district was also home to the Paleo-Christian cathedral, before it was moved to the forum.
In the Middle Ages, when the religious authorities gave L’Hauture to the neighbouring district of La Cité, it became no more than a parish entity of Notre-Dame-de-la-Major Church. Until the Revolution, this parish was the largest and most densely populated in town.  The amphitheatre, constructed and reinforced with towers, confirmed its defensive role.
During the Renaissance, political authorities and town planning led to this district moving further to the west, giving L'Hauture a more rural and artisanal character. Apart from the development of Saint-Césaire Abbey and the operation of the 'château d’eau' (water tower) in the 20th century (see the old reservoirs and the tower), the L'Hauture district has retained its characteristic small old individual houses.

label: La plage d'Arles - Plage de Piémanson
comment: Arles, the largest commune of France, includes a large part of the Camargue and extends between the arms of the Rhône to the beach located 45 kilometres from the city centre.
shortDescription: Arles, the largest commune of France, includes a large part of the Camargue and extends between the arms of the Rhône to the beach located 45 kilometres from the city centre.
description: The Piemanson beach or beach of Salin-de-Giraud (naturist area at the eastern end), the amazing architecture of Northern corons village, and Beauduc beach. It is 28 km from non urbanized beaches which are the largest natural beach of Mediterranean Sea. 2 kilometres of sand dunes, a belvedere overlooking the salins to admire the salt marshes, the area of crop and salt storage.

label: Hangars Boussiron
comment: A real architectural feat, made of reinforced concrete, this 2 hectare building, built between 1950 and 1953, is sometimes called the "Marignane double hangar". Simon Boussiron, an Eiffel collaborator, gave his name to the architectural work.
shortDescription: A real architectural feat, made of reinforced concrete, this 2 hectare building, built between 1950 and 1953, is sometimes called the "Marignane double hangar". Simon Boussiron, an Eiffel collaborator, gave his name to the architectural work.
description:
Built near the Etang de Berre between 1950 and 1953, this 2 hectare building is sometimes called the "Marignane double hangar"

It belongs to the airport complex established in 1920, destroyed at the Liberation, and precedes the terminal built on the plans of Fernand Pouillon in 1961

It was originally intended to house the construction of seaplanes and was the subject of a competition initiated by the Chamber of Commerce of Marseille in 1943, interrupted and resumed in 1949

The design of the hangars was then entrusted to the architects Auguste and Gustave Perret, known for the complete reconstruction of Le Havre, associated with the engineers Nicolas Esquillan and Eugène Freyssinet

However, it was Simon Boussiron, Gustave Eiffel's collaborator and founder of the first reinforced concrete company, who gave his name to the architectural work

It is distinguished by its roof, which is made up of six thin reinforced concrete walls, each just 6 cm thick, forming a double-curved wave over each nave, each with a span of 101 metres. They were made on the ground, in pre-stressed concrete and expanded metal reinforcement, then hoisted on jacks to a height of 19 metres, while the walls were raised underneath as they were built. A film recounting this epic construction site was entrusted by Auguste Perret himself to the photographer Fred Delvert, who witnessed the construction of what has long been recorded as a record.

It cannot be visited and is located on the airport's right of way. It can be seen very well from the road that goes to the Jaï

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Les jardins
comment: Public Gardens of Cornillon-Confoux
shortDescription: Public Gardens of Cornillon-Confoux
description: Whether it is for a moment of relaxation, to admire the extraordinary view offered by these spaces or simply to get in shape, the green spaces of Cornillon-Confoux offer themselves entirely to your desires.

label: Bastide de la Magalone
comment: The "Bastide de la Magalone" is located in the "Mazargues" district in Marseille, just opposite the "The Radiant City" ( Cité Radieuse )  of the famous architect "Le Corbusier".
shortDescription: The "Bastide de la Magalone" is located in the "Mazargues" district in Marseille, just opposite the "The Radiant City" ( Cité Radieuse )  of the famous architect "Le Corbusier".
description:
Its construction dates from the end of the 17th century, a time of architectural innovation and research. Directly inspired by Italian architects, the Bastide is designed in a confusing way, mixing elements of classical and baroque styles. A 200 sqm hall, now with parquet flooring, occupies the whole of the ground floor, while in the wings a boudoir and a library open onto the elaborately designed garden, with a small wood, an avenue of plane trees, boulingrins, rose gardens, fountains, ponds, statues and meadows.
Since the 17th century, the Bastide of the Magalone has passed through the hands of different owners, each one making changes. In the 19th century, one of them built a small circular chapel at the entrance to the garden.
The place is magical : when you pass in front of the "villa", you don't stop, you linger. Music courses and concerts are offered all year round by the "Cité de la Musique de Marseille". What could be better than the Magalone for artistic inspiration ?
The Bastide and its gardens are open during the music lessons of the "Cité de la Musique".

label: Cour de Manville
description: The town's most beautiful Renaissance mansion was built at the start of the second half of the 16th century by the rich Protestant family of Claude de Manville. The irregular façade which follows the course of the main road features large mullioned windows. The inner courtyard, flanked by a portico, repeats the same pattern as the Renaissance windows.

label: Parc François Billoux
comment: Protected by a dense and very diverse vegetation, the park, which covers an area of 5.2 hectares, provides an opportunity to isolate oneself from a dense industrial and urban environment.
shortDescription: Protected by a dense and very diverse vegetation, the park, which covers an area of 5.2 hectares, provides an opportunity to isolate oneself from a dense industrial and urban environment.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.

Picnics are authorised in public parks provided that social distancing is respected, the grouping must be less than 10 people.



The history of this park goes back to the 12th century. It was then a huge plot of 19 hectares, owned by Etienne Audiffret. In 1770, Joseph François Xavier Fabron de Chaudelle built one of the two bastides, the Villa Laplane, which today houses the town hall of the 15th and 16th arrondissements. Three hectares of this property will see the construction of the Villa Aurenty, towards the end of the 19th century, as well as the first sugar refineries. The François Billoux Park was developed in 1978 on a 6-hectare property that became municipal. More recently, an open-air theatre, La Sucrière, has been made available for cultural events. This park is made up of 2 large areas

One, located in front of the rue de Lyon, offers bowling, children's games and a refreshment bar with public toilets. The other extends as far as the Ruisseau des Aygalades and offers exceptional vegetation and freshness: plane trees, lime trees, white poplars, maples, ash trees and vast lawns... As for the areas surrounding the Laplane and Aurenty villas, they are laid out as "French" gardens that highlight the particular charm of these Marseille country houses.

label: Buste et tombeau de Charloun Rieu
comment: Charles-Henri Rieu (Charloun) was born in Le Paradou on 1 November 1846. Peasant poet, and is introduced by Frédéric Mistral in the middle of the Félibre and becomes "Majoral". He died on 11 January 1924, at the mas d'Auge.
shortDescription: Charles-Henri Rieu (Charloun) was born in Le Paradou on 1 November 1846. Peasant poet, and is introduced by Frédéric Mistral in the middle of the Félibre and becomes "Majoral". He died on 11 January 1924, at the mas d'Auge.
description:
Charles-Henri Rieu (Charloun) was born in Le Paradou on the 1st November 1846 on the road to St Roch, near the Caladat. He is the eldest of a family of eleven children. His father is a small landowner, a peasant who supplements his income with
seasonal work. Charloun goes to primary school to learn to read and write. Lucien--Marc Chabaud, the teacher, is said to have given the young Charloun the rudiments of Latin and Greek to make him a priest. From the age of 15, Charloun was employed in the digging of the drying canal in the Vallée des Baux.
Eldest of the family, he does not have an easy life and when he rents himself out in a farmhouse in the Camargue, his father quickly repatriates him. The situation of the peasants becomes more and more difficult. Charloun works in the big farmhouses, in the oil mills. His father and mother die leaving a meagre family inheritance to share. Charloun, the peasant poet, captures all the moments of this life close to the land, harsh and without concession. He delivers the sweetness, the sorrow. His poems are published in three collections. "Li Cant dóu Terraire". "Les chants du terroir" contains 133 songs. Frédéric Mistral prefaces the first "chant". Charles Rieu also writes chronicles, a dramatic comedy: "
Margarido dóu Destet" and a translation of Homer's Odyssey into Provençal. He carries his songs from mas to mas, from party to party. As his popularity grew, he was soon introduced by Frédéric Mistral to the Félibre milieu and became "Majoral" on November 1, 1910. He died on 11 January 1924, at the mas d'Auge.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
comment: Come and take advantage of the books available at the municipal library of Roquefort la Bédoule
shortDescription: Come and take advantage of the books available at the municipal library of Roquefort la Bédoule
description: Novels, comics, poetry, theatre... there's something for everyone!

label: Villa Valmer
description: Villa Valmer, the villa "Vague à la Mer", was built in the 1865s by the Marseille architect Condamin, in a renaissance style. It is located at the top of a vast park planted with tropical plant species brought back from the owner's travels to the East, a rich oilseed merchant. The villa now belongs to the City of Marseille.

label: Chapelle de Bagalance
comment: Chapel of Saint Andrew of Bagalance in Romanesque style.
shortDescription: Chapel of Saint Andrew of Bagalance in Romanesque style.
description: It is near the potential site of Bellinto (ancestor of the village of Barbentane) that was built, before the IX century, the Chapel, then the Hermitage of Saint-André-de-Bagalance. It is one of the many priories that have been scattered throughout Provence since the 12th century, often built in isolated places, but always on the outskirts of the roads used by the Roumieux (pilgrims) and/or the shepherds.

label: Chapelle Saint-Gervais
comment: Saint-Gervais chapel in Orgon.
shortDescription: Saint-Gervais chapel in Orgon.
description: Access is by way of Saint Gervais.The chapel Saint-Gervais was built in the 15th century for the burial of the Elzéar de Mouriès family who founded the Hospital of Orgon in 1428. The building was stone.The Priory of Saint Gervais was served by a priest to which an annuity of 599 pounds was allocated to fulfill his office. The building is stone, one of the two foothills of the west facade remains.Very damaged, she is the subject of a rehabilitation project.It is impossible to visit the Interior.

label: Palais de l'Archevêché
comment:
Date: 17th and 18th centuries
Era: Classical period
Type: religious architecture
Status: property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1922 and 1959
shortDescription:
Date: 17th and 18th centuries
Era: Classical period
Type: religious architecture
Status: property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1922 and 1959
description:
The façade of the Archbishop's Palace
on the Place de la République
The former Archbishop's Palace has an imposing façade on the east of the Place de la République.
The building was associated with the Church of Arles in the Middle Ages, but has since undergone a number of transformations, whose history and visibility remain problematic.
However, thanks to these transformations, we are still able to admire a wonderful example of Classical Arles architecture.
The original function of the monument was lost during the Revolution.
Since then, it has been used for civic purposes, such as a municipal library from 1829 to 1988 and is currently a branch of the university.
The physiognomy of the mediaeval building remains relatively unknown, as archaeological remains and documentary sources are extremely rare. 
The modern palace has also undergone a number of modifications, particularly during the 19th century. An architectural study of the building is therefore particularly complicated.
The only remains of f the 17th century building are the entrance porch, the monumental staircase and the rooms decorated with wall paintings, woodwork and stucco. 
The staircase, the Archbishops' study and the ceiling of the Bishops' former bathroom are listed as national Historic Monuments. 
These features, in addition to the sombre, majestic 18th century façade (also listed) are nevertheless a wonderful example of Classical architecture in Arles.

description: Facing the West Tower of the amphitheatre, hotel de Luppé rears its amazing facade looks like a Florentine Palace.Its successive owners evoke the past of several large arlesiennes families and bear witness to their major contribution to the favorable domestic architecture.Although dating from the 17th century, only remains visible from the outside facade erected at the beginning of the twentieth century by Gaston de Luppé, artist and scholar, passionate about Italy.

shortDescription: In St Paul lez Durance, take a walk along the Cadarache Dam
description:
The Cadarache Dam and the water body are works linked to the Durance-Verdon hydroelectric scheme designed to produce electricity, irrigate crops, supply drinking water to towns and regulate floods.
51 ha.

Protected area
Natural area of ecological, faunistic and floristic interest

label: La cité des Baux de Provence
comment: The village of Les Baux-de-Provence, perched on a rocky spur, has an incredibly rich architectural heritage. The city is classified "Most beautiful village in France".
shortDescription: The village of Les Baux-de-Provence, perched on a rocky spur, has an incredibly rich architectural heritage. The city is classified "Most beautiful village in France".
description: The village of Les Baux de Provence, perched on a rocky promontory, has an incredibly rich architectural heritage. Its citadel dominates extraordinarily beautiful natural sites. It contains exceptional décors which relate the testimonies of the past, continue traditions, house the art of the men who settled there and host prestige events. These sites are loaded with history and offer many more temptations. The tradition of hospitality is even more present than ever, thanks to its gastronomic restaurants and its charming hotels which receive distinguished guests. The name Les Baux de Provence is a symbol of quality; its wines are warm, products of the rocks and the sun, and its olive oil is strong and fruity. Les Baux de Provence lies in the heart of the Regional Natural Park of the Alpilles. It is Listed Resort, one of the Most Beautiful Villages in France and a Remarkable Taste Site and is unique for being a little bit more magical and a little bit more illustrious. And the very essence that creates the distinctive charm and aroma of Provençal villages can be found in the small squares, shady terraces, narrow streets and boutiques.

label: La Chapelle Saint Martin
description:
As early as 1056, the Chapel of Saint Martin was mentioned in the cartulary of the Abbey of Saint Victor in Marseille. It became communal property in 2007. The municipality is consolidating and restoring the Chapel in order to preserve the identity of the Provencal chapels of the Middle Ages.

The chapel consisted of a single nave with a heavy barrel vault and a semi-circular apse with a cul-de-four vault. Only part of the apse and a section of the north and east walls remain of the work.

label: Eglise Saint-Blaise
comment: Rebuilt on the site of a primitive church probably dating from 1070, itself built on a pagan temple probably dedicated to Cybèle, the main part of the construction dates from 1869-1871
shortDescription: Rebuilt on the site of a primitive church probably dating from 1070, itself built on a pagan temple probably dedicated to Cybèle, the main part of the construction dates from 1869-1871
description:
Rebuilt on the site of a primitive church dating probably from 1070, itself built on a pagan temple presumably dedicated to Cybele, most of the construction dates from 1869-1871. The bell tower, square at the base, octagonal in the upper part was later elevated in 1879, then surmounted by a large bell tower around 1930. The building is remarkably free from rough terrain. In the interior there is a marble slab carved in 1056 and, above all, a very interesting sculpture in 1476, a work by the Italian Francesco Laurana, representing three generations, Saint Anne, Mary and Jesus, but also rarely showing the Virgin Breast nursing nursing Jesus.
Opening only during the offices and by appointment with the Tourist office of Pennes-Mirabeau.

label: Tour des abbés
comment: Built at the request of the abbot of Montmajour, between 1348 and 1353, it is both a defensive and residential construction. It is combined with other buildings housing the seigneurial dwelling as well as a ceremonial room where justice was administered.
shortDescription: Built at the request of the abbot of Montmajour, between 1348 and 1353, it is both a defensive and residential construction. It is combined with other buildings housing the seigneurial dwelling as well as a ceremonial room where justice was administered.
description:
This Tower was erected at the request of the Abbey of Montmajour, Pierre de Canillac, between 1348 and 1353. It is both a defensive and residential construction; although the tower was an important symbol of power and military strength in those times of war (the 14th and 15th centuries were punctuated with a series of conflicts, better known as the Hundred Years' War). It was combined with other constructions which housed the seigniorial residence and a ceremonial room where justice was administered.
The adjoining buildings probably date from the 13th century, but were extended and fortified during the second half of the 14th century. They underwent minor modifications in the 15th and 16th centuries (modifications to the windows, etc.).
Together with Montmajour Tower, it is one of the few examples of residential towers which can be dated to between 1350 and 1360. The crest of the Canhilac family was a greyhound, which now forms part of the coats of arms of the town of Fontvieille.
This site is also used to house temporary exhibitions, primarily by the famous painted Carl Liner.

label: Plage Figuières
comment: Pebble beach in the Calanque des Figuières
shortDescription: Pebble beach in the Calanque des Figuières
description:
Type of soil: gravel. Road sign. Beach accessible only on foot. Private area to cross. Warning: strict parking regulations. Dogs accepted. No sanitary facilities.
Direction les calanques. La Redonne, chemin de Méjean. Les Figuières going down on the right.

label: Les principaux attraits d'Orgon
comment: The main attractions of Orgon
shortDescription: The main attractions of Orgon
description:
The typically Provençal village of Orgon, overlooked by Notre Dame de Beauregard Chapel and the ruins of the old fortress of the Duc de Guise, has a rich and illustrious past.
Listed below are its main sights, which visitors can discover on four themed walks. Details are available at Orgon Municipal Tourist Office.
Calvaries and Oratories:
The Orgon landscape is dominated by crosses and oratories, revealing the popular fervour for Catholicism and the Virgin Mary throughout the ages.
- The Cross at the Porte la Durance.
- The Cross on the forecourt of Assomption Church and the Les Missions cross.
- Oratory of Saint Antoine.
- The Chemin des Oratoires: Oratory of The Annunciation, Oratory to the Glory of Jesus and Mary and Oratories of the Massacre of the Innocents and the Flight into Egypt.
- The Cross of the Grey Penitents of Avignon and the Cross of La Durance.
- The wooden Cross in La Pinède cemetery.
- The Faubourg Sainte-Anne Cross.
- The Cross on Place de la Conillière.
- The Oratory of the Madeleine, the Saint-Roch Chapel Cross and the wrought iron Cross on the Chemin de la Mine.
- The Cross of La Perdigale.
- The Cross of the Mas Bréguier.
- The Oratory of Notre-Dame du Chêne.
Places of worship:
Several places of worship and symbols of our religious heritage are worthy of attention.
- L'Assomption Church.
- Notre-Dame de Beauregard.Chapel.
- Saint Roch Chapel.
- Saint Gervais Chapel.
- Saint Véran Chapel.
Strolling around Old Orgon:
This route will allow you to discover the defensive and civil heritage of Orgon.
- The Porte Sainte-Anne.
- The Porte de l’Hortet.
- The La Savoie district.
- The Château of the Duc de Guise.
- The Porte de la Durance.
- Façades characteristic of Renaissance architecture. N°20 rue Jules Robert, N°4 rue Georges Coste and N°15 rue Edmond Coste.
Chemin de la Pierre:
The village of Orgon is one of the few places in the world to have an internationally recognised facies. The chalky limestone layers just beneath the surface contain distinctive, characteristic fossils which led to the definition of the Urgonian stage, from the Latin name for Orgon, by one of the founders of palaeontology, Alcide d’Orbigny, in 1850.
Take the time to walk down the Chemin de la Pierre, following the Urgonian route.
- Walking trail to the Urgonian limestone quarries.
- Discover the Urgonian stage and life in the Beaker Culture on the Notre-Dame de Beauregard site and in its monastery.
- The Chemin de Pierre, from the quarries to Notre-Dame de Beauregard.

shortDescription: Underwater museum of Marseille is  an amazing site, a museal area atypical offering a  full immersion :  unusual experience with  an unprecedented underwater encounter and observation in vivo  of relationship between Men and Nature.
description:
A 100 meters from the beach shore and 5 meters deep, 10 sculptures are summerged. 
One  of them is connected to a build-in application.This museum's goal is to make the guest  enjoy the discovery of the beautiful and the surpring scenery. It is  a really  strong  asset  to raise awarness of environmental issues and to awaken curiosity about the world of arts  and water sports.

The museum visit  is free and covered by  the museums's staff in charge.   Booking in advanced is mandatory.They give you advices and recommendations and also provide gear rental.

For individuals ou  groups guided tours, please feel free to contact our sponsor club : GRASM

label: Parc du Mugel
comment: Splendid botanical park of 12 hectares, located above the Calanque du Mugel. Countless tropical and Mediterranean species. Picnic area and playground for children. Belvedere at 82 meters altitude with panoramic view.
shortDescription: Splendid botanical park of 12 hectares, located above the Calanque du Mugel. Countless tropical and Mediterranean species. Picnic area and playground for children. Belvedere at 82 meters altitude with panoramic view.
description:
Nested shielded from the impressive massif of the Cap de l' Aigle, the Park of Mugel represents a real harbor of greenery at the heart of La Ciotat. From the entrance, an exotic garden welcomes the visitor. Afterward a herb garden, drawn according to a fan-shaped plan. Resting areas and shaded paths completed the set. This case becoming integrated into a conservation area, receives wonderful landscaped and botanical wealth, with rare tropical plants and a rich flora.
The set extends on about 12 hectares today and includes a picnic area and a playground for children.

label: Eglise Saint-Michel
comment: Built at the foot of the castle around the beginning of the 13th century, in the heart of the city's activity, the Saint-Michel church opens onto a square crossed by one of the main communication axes.
shortDescription: Built at the foot of the castle around the beginning of the 13th century, in the heart of the city's activity, the Saint-Michel church opens onto a square crossed by one of the main communication axes.
description:
The church's chevet faces east, a particularly common practice, as people turn towards Jerusalem [and the rising sun] to celebrate mass. The building illustrates the specificities of Provençal art by its arcaded bell tower and the sobriety of its sculpted decorations, which are part of the Romanesque style, a style that also explains the simplicity of its plan (a single nave with no aisles or ambulatory), as well as the thickness of the walls and the narrowness of the openings. The sober and massive aspect of the church is enlightened by the luminous warmth of the stone used for its structure.

 From the same period, the sculpted tympanum that decorates its portal evokes the archangel Saint-Michel crushing the forces of evil symbolized by the serpent. If the general aspect of the building is typical of the Romanesque art, the vaults on ribbed crossings of the nave and the apse illustrate one of the first breakthroughs of the Gothic style in Provence. The church was therefore the object of several successive construction campaigns, even adding a bell tower in the 15th century, crowning the façade and used as a clock until the 17th century. Romanesque-Gothic building. Classified as a historical monument

label: Place Général de Gaulle
comment: The Place Général de Gaulle is an easy and important landmark in downtown Marseille, near the Old Port: it overlooks the famous Canebière and faces the Chamber of Commerce and the Office de Tourisme et Congrès.
shortDescription: The Place Général de Gaulle is an easy and important landmark in downtown Marseille, near the Old Port: it overlooks the famous Canebière and faces the Chamber of Commerce and the Office de Tourisme et Congrès.
description:
This is where Rue Paradis begins, and the other small streets adjacent to it are rich in fashion boutiques and food shops. 
This square has often hosted gatherings, various events and markets. 
Its underground public parking and the nearby metro station make it an easy meeting place.

label: Hôtels particuliers de Tarascon
description:
The prosperity of the town of Tarascon led to a number of noble families settling there from the 15th century.
Aristocrats, bourgeois, traders and clergymen who wanted to make their mark on the urban landscape built splendid private residences here. 
Thanks to their wonderful exterior decoration, the façades of these mansions testify to many different individual solutions, replaced by the magnificent expression of Provençal Mannerism in the early 17th century, a low-key period for architecture in Provence.
These civil buildings, located around Saint Marthe Collegiate Church, as far as the shopping street of Les Halles and in the old districts of Saint Nicolas and La Condamine which used to connect the château to the Route d'Avignon, generally played a strategic role in the town.

shortDescription:

label: L'Ermitage Saint -Honorat
description:
Listed on the inventory of historic monuments in 2001, the Hermitage Saint-Honorat was a monumental complex consisting of a vaulted chapel troglodyte whose first foundations date back to the Middle Ages, many outbuildings, gardens, a spring, a natural rocky cirque closed. The place became very touristy during the construction of the Roquefavour aqueduct, the population of Ventabren had taken the habit of coming here on pilgrimage.
A monastery once occupied by the monks of the Order of Saint Benedict under the title of Priory Claustral, its use as a place of worship ended in 1914 and it was from this date that the Hermitage deteriorated and only the spring remained.

comment:
Sandy beach of 100 m on 40 m.

Guide dogs are accepted.

label: Chapelle Saint-Laurent
description:
Rebuilt in the 11th century, the chapel belongs to the Provencal Romanesque style and has a single nave.
From the 17th century, it was used as a priory.
Sold as a national asset in the 18th century, a potter settled there and built his oven in the apse.
At the beginning of the XIXth century, a bastide is attached to the chapel.
It was only around 1893 that it regained its religious function within the Order of the White Penitents.
Little by little abandoned, it was used as a barn at the beginning of the 20th century.
Today restored and classified as a historical monument, the chapel Saint-Laurent de Cabardel is accessible from the roads of Saint-Jean and Lançon-de-Provence.

label: Fontaine des Quatre Dauphins
comment: Situated in the heart of the Mazarin district, this fountain dates back to 1667. Built by the sculptor Jean-Claude Rambot, it flows into a circular basin made of Sainte-Baume stone.
shortDescription: Situated in the heart of the Mazarin district, this fountain dates back to 1667. Built by the sculptor Jean-Claude Rambot, it flows into a circular basin made of Sainte-Baume stone.
description: With its four dolphins and their raised fins on a bed of waves which support the obelisk, it is an example of the baroque art so prized by Aix's nobility .

label: Parc national des Calanques
comment: Known throughout the world for its grandiose landscapes of limestone cliffs plunging into the sea and the Cosquer cave, the Calanques site is also home to exceptional biodiversity and cultural heritage.
shortDescription: Known throughout the world for its grandiose landscapes of limestone cliffs plunging into the sea and the Cosquer cave, the Calanques site is also home to exceptional biodiversity and cultural heritage.
description:
The Calanques (rocky coves) along the coast between Marseille and Cassis are of exceptional beauty by their striking relief, their scale and their white rocks.

For more than twenty kilometres, the limestone cuts into the coastline, giving Marseille a splendid natural monument. Nibbled away by erosion and hacked by the waves, the rock starts to rise from the sea bed and culminates at heights of almost 400 metres above sea level.
An absolute must for rock climbers, the area is also a hikers paradise. Hiking paths snake between the rocks, offering infinite possibilities for hikes, leisurely strolls and bathing. Starting from La Madrague, you can follow the coast by crossing the "end of Marseille" - Les Goudes, Callelongue and Cortiou - then continuing via Sormiou to Morgiou, Sugiton, En Vau, Port-Pin and lastly Cassis.
You can make the same trip by sea. In summer, a launch leaves the Old Port, passes by the islands in Marseille Bay (Riou, Jarre and Maïre) and goes into each of the calanques as far as Cassis, the last stage of an unforgettable trip. You can also make the same trip from Cassis.

label: Maison de la Transhumance
description: Home of Transhumance, interpretation of Mediterranean pastoral culture centre, will open its doors to the 2010/2011 year into the fold of the domain of Alders, property of the General Council of Bouches.In a magnificent setting, it will cover an area of more than 500 m². It will first offer on 300 m², a space for temporary exhibitions renewed each year. It will also include a public reception area and a shop. Finally, it will house a centre for information, as well as administrative offices and services.The dynamics of the House of Transhumance will be also ensured by a program of festive events around transhumance and animations: demonstration of mowing, bells concert, shepherds dog competitions... Meetings, trainings, seminars can take place in the other existing buildings in the area of Alder.In the meantime, it is through the association of the same name that its future is taking shape. The House of Transhumance association was founded in April 2007 by breeders, experts from agriculture, environment and science, human, cultural operators and local elected officials.All were convinced that only the union of all their skills could lead to efficient and sustainable actions to preserve the great sheep transhumance. The association is designed to bring together all the partners that contribute to maintaining the great transhumance and pastoralism.To do this, it focuses on four main objectives: entice, explain, involve to find in history and the area support the profession and finally produce knowledge, share it and implement.

label: Musée Yves Brayer
comment: The Yves Brayer Museum occupies one of the most beautiful houses in the village, the Hôtel de Porcelet. Since 1991, it has been hosting an important retrospective of the painter's work, which is very attached to Mediterranean countries.
shortDescription: The Yves Brayer Museum occupies one of the most beautiful houses in the village, the Hôtel de Porcelet. Since 1991, it has been hosting an important retrospective of the painter's work, which is very attached to Mediterranean countries.
description: The Museum Yves Brayer occupies one of the most beautiful residences in the centre of the village, the hotel of piglet. It hosts a major retrospective of the work of this painter, very attached to the Mediterranean countries, which include the most representative of the figuration of the 20th century. In his youth, Yves Brayer is attracted by the Spain and the Italy which he expresses with power-specific characters, both oils by gouaches and of monotypes. In 1945, begin his regular stays in Provence, first at Saint - Rémy, and then to leases. It strives to translate the appearance arid and wild limestone ridges, beyond peaceful olive groves. Attracted by the nearby Camargue, he is seduced by its vast expanses of birds, horses and bulls. His oils, watercolors and lithographs make these landscapes familiar to the public during exhibitions in Paris and in various capitals abroad also. His life is shared between its mas in les Baux-de-Provence and his workshop in Paris. Invited to make exhibitions in various capitals, it also has the opportunity to travel to the Mexico, the Japan and all around the Mediterranean, where he reports mostly watercolours. In 1974, referring to the Nativity in the Alpilles, he produced frescoes of the white Penitents Chapel, facing the Church Saint-Vincent.

comment: The service takes place on Sunday at 10am, the prayer meeting with Bible study on Tuesday at 7.30pm.
shortDescription: The service takes place on Sunday at 10am, the prayer meeting with Bible study on Tuesday at 7.30pm.

comment: Plage de la Redonne, in the commune of Ensuès-la-Redonne
shortDescription: Plage de la Redonne, in the commune of Ensuès-la-Redonne
description:
Nature of the soil: sand. Parking area close to the beach, no charge (parking 4mn from the beach). Difficult access to the beach. Capacity of the area: 20 vehicles. Facilities: 1 bar-restaurant in the cove 600m from the beach. Dogs forbidden. No sanitary facilities. Unsupervised swimming.
Follow the Calanques after the town centre. At the crossroads towards the Madrague de Gignac. After 600m turn left, chemin de la digue

label: Oppidum d'Entremont
comment: At just 3km from the city center of Aix-en-Provence, the oppidum d'Entremont is an archaeological site classified as a Historic Monument of great importance.
shortDescription: At just 3km from the city center of Aix-en-Provence, the oppidum d'Entremont is an archaeological site classified as a Historic Monument of great importance.
description:
Entremont is a Gallic village dating from the 2nd century BC. The site has been excavated since 1946. Remains of ramparts, housing, workshops, a room displaying the heads of enemies (a Celtic custom), statues and a wide range of objects have been found here. The oppidum (Roman settlement) is in a pleasant green park with open access during the site opening days and times. 
The excavated statues and objects (ceramics, tools, etc.) are displayed in the Granet Museum. 

The oppidum is owned by the French state and is chiefly managed by the Regional Archaeology Department (DRAC, Ministry of Culture). The Entremont Archaeological Association works to enhance the site.

label: Centre de la Vieille Charité - (CVC)
comment: Located in the district of " Le Panier", this old hospice of the 17th century is composed of several wings closed on the outside and opened on a rectangular court by galleries on the three  levels.
shortDescription: Located in the district of " Le Panier", this old hospice of the 17th century is composed of several wings closed on the outside and opened on a rectangular court by galleries on the three  levels.
description:
In the center, a chapel with a baroque style dome is the work of Pierre Puget.

The Old Charity 'La Vieille Charité" is classified as a historical monument since 1951. It is currently a multidisciplinary center with scientific and cultural vocation. It houses the Museum of Mediterranean Archaeology and the Museum of African, Oceanian and Amerindian Arts, as well as temporary exhibitions.

Due to a temporary technical failure, the elevator of the Museum is currently out of order. Th Museums of Marseille apologize for the inconvenience caused and will do their utmost to welcome you in the best conditions.

label: Moulin communal
comment: Communal mill of Maillane.
shortDescription: Communal mill of Maillane.
description: This mill was built in 1627 in La Loube, to the north of the village, and supplied the village with flour. It had several successive owners, before once again becoming the property of the commune in the 19th century. It operated until the middle of that century, but only on four days a week; on the other days, the water was reserved for watering gardens. After the death of the last tenants in 1985, the mill was destroyed following a decision by the municipal council. All that remains today is the paddle wheel, which is in good condition.

label: Hôtel de Manville
comment: The Renaissance style building is the witness of a rich history. This private mansion built in the 16th century by Claude de Manville, now houses the Town Hall.
shortDescription: The Renaissance style building is the witness of a rich history. This private mansion built in the 16th century by Claude de Manville, now houses the Town Hall.
description: Current Hôtel de Ville.  The town's most beautiful Renaissance mansion was built in 1571 by the rich Protestant family of Claude de Manville. The irregular façade, which follows the course of the main road, contains mainly mullioned windows. The inner courtyard, flanked by a portico, repeats the same pattern as the Renaissance windows. The monumental first floor fireplace has an interlacing mantelpiece (1571) surmounting a frieze decorated with triglyphs resting on Doric columns. The Town restored the building at the end of the 1960s.

label: Canaux et Etang de Rambaille
comment: In a green setting at the foot of the Alpilles Regional Nature Park for a fishing trip alone, with friends or family, a moment of relaxation and tranquility at the edge of a shady pond.
shortDescription: In a green setting at the foot of the Alpilles Regional Nature Park for a fishing trip alone, with friends or family, a moment of relaxation and tranquility at the edge of a shady pond.
description: Picnic areas.

label: Réserve naturelle volontaire Haras Saint Estève-Janson
comment: Discover the Voluntary Nature Reserve of the Stud Farm in the commune of Saint-Estève-Janson
shortDescription: Discover the Voluntary Nature Reserve of the Stud Farm in the commune of Saint-Estève-Janson
description: The Saint-Esteve-Janson reserve has a surface area of about 74 hectares and comprises two areas which look very different but are also rich in fauna and flora: an old gravel pit which has become a pond and a well-preserved part of the Durance river ripisylve.

label: Chapelle Saint-Roch
comment: The chapel of St Roch stands at the entrance to the village, alongside the Trets road.
shortDescription: The chapel of St Roch stands at the entrance to the village, alongside the Trets road.
description:
It dates from the 13th century. With Saint Sébastien as its patron saint, it was the chapel of the village cemetery from the 16th century to the late 19th century, after which it was abandoned. It was restored by volunteers in the mid-1970s.

The two stained-glass windows were made by Monique Curto and installed in 2000.

Work on the surrounding area was carried out by the municipality in 2001: repair of boundary walls, installation of art metalwork (entrance gate, fences), exterior lighting, renovation of the choir roof and the cross.

label: Hortus
description: Roman-inspired garden. This garden, real plant Racecourse is inspired by a text written at the end of the first or beginning of the second century a.d. by Pliny the younger.Come and discover this public space in the form of Roman circus. You can play (playing kit available at the Museum), stroll, relax in the Roman...

label: Le petit musée de Carro
comment:
The exhibition is based on a collection of photographs and numerous everyday objects related to the trades of stone, earth and sea from antiquity to the present day.
Located on the port of Carro, the entrance is free.
shortDescription:
The exhibition is based on a collection of photographs and numerous everyday objects related to the trades of stone, earth and sea from antiquity to the present day.
Located on the port of Carro, the entrance is free.
description:
Two villages that are one. La Couronne has the town hall and the church, Carro has the port. Their past activities were stone cutting, fishing, agriculture and sheep farming.

Old objects of daily life rub shoulders with those of fishing, natural treasures from the seabed and the cargoes of beached ships.

Its collection contains more than 150 objects and several hundred old photos and documents. It continues to grow thanks to donations and acquisitions.
The simple daily life of our ancestors, fishermen, peasants or shepherds.
It is this more or less distant past that we have tried to restore for you. Research has enabled us to find objects and documents that bear direct witness to the past and to the history of our villages, which are ultimately closely linked. 

Individuals: free visit without reservation.
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 50 square metres.
streetAddress: ['15 Place Joseph Fasciola', 'Cercle St Pierre des pêcheurs (1er étage)']

label: Médiathèque Léopold Vidau
comment: Léopold Vidau media library in Cabannes.
shortDescription: Léopold Vidau media library in Cabannes.
description: The Léopold Vidau Media Library consists of an adult room, a youth room and a computer room.

label: Parc Gilbert Vilers
description:
An unfenced park in the heart of Jas de Bouffan, adjoining Avenue Saint John Perse. 

The landscaping of this 12-acre park blends with the grounds of the buildings and the countryside around. Footpaths connect various areas of Jas de Bouffan. Fine vantage point for viewing Sainte Victoire Mountain to the east. 

The land is very undulated and the relief is an important feature of the landscaping. A number of paths lead to the main attractive and decorative features: a lake of some 2,000m2, an open-air theatre seating 800, in the style of an ancient Greek amphitheatre. 


The plantations consist of groves and trees chosen from regional species and nearly 10 acres of lawns accessible to the public. Architect: Longepierre, designer, in collaboration with the Parks Department.

label: Saint Estève Janson
comment: Village of St Esteve Janson
shortDescription: Village of St Esteve Janson
description:
This charming little elevated village, one of the smallest in the department, offers beautiful panoramas over the Durance and the Luberon.
Numerous hikes allow you to appreciate its remarkable fauna and flora

label: Eglise  Saint-Pierre
comment: The church was built and completed in 1858 by Sixtus Rey in a monumental neo-Romanesque style, at the same time as he laid out the cemetery.
shortDescription: The church was built and completed in 1858 by Sixtus Rey in a monumental neo-Romanesque style, at the same time as he laid out the cemetery.
description:
The church was built and completed in 1858 by "Sixte Rey" in a monumental  neo-romanesque style, at the same time as he laid out the cemetary. The cot is famous at Christmas time. Reception from Monday to Saturday from 5pm to 7pm. Parish priest : Bernard Lorenzato. 
Mass on Sunday at 6 pm, on weekdays Thirsday at 8:30am.

label: Calanque de Callelongue
comment: In Marseille, when we go to Callelongue, we say that we go to the end of the world.
shortDescription: In Marseille, when we go to Callelongue, we say that we go to the end of the world.
description:
So take a bus, the n°20, a bike, a scooter or a car and go along the sea towards the southeast. Little by little, you will have the impression of leaving the city to enter another dimension. The road, enchanting and winding, between white rocks and blue sea, will lead you to Callelongue or "Calo Longo" meaning in Provencal small narrow and long creek. 
This little corner of paradise marks the end of the city and is worth the detour in itself. Cabanons with evocative names, Mediterranean gardens carefully maintained by the inhabitants and barquettes moored in the shelter of the Mistral.
As an open door to the Massif des Calanques, you can discover the calanques of Marseilleveyre, Morgiou or Sormiou, via marked hiking trails.
And if you don't have enough time, you can simply climb a few rocks to admire the view or take a dip before heading back to Marseille the city.
The roads of Morgiou, Sormiou and Callelongue are closed:
- In May and October: every weekend and during school holidays.
- From June to September: every day.
Pedestrian access on these roads is still allowed under certain conditions.

label: Les Oratoires de Maillane
comment: The Oratories of Maillane.
shortDescription: The Oratories of Maillane.
description:
- Oratory of the Virgin of Massabielle: Located at the entrance of the Dumas countryside, named after the last owner, judge and mayor of Maillane who carried out important works, the oratory was erected in 1875 by one of the daughters of the above-mentioned Joseph Dumas. The processions of the rogations used to stop there. The place is pleasant, calm and shady.

- Oratory of the Mas du Cast : The statue was erected at the end of the 19th century by the new owner of the Cast, Mr. Omer Martel, on the edge of a small road in the domain (the Mas du Cast was the residence of the Porcelet family in the 17th century).
As a friend of Mistral, he ordered some verses from him which he had engraved on the cippe supporting the statue of the Virgin. Square cippe on steps with Mistral's verses engraved. The statue represents Notre-Dame-de-Grâce.

- Notre-Dame-de-Grâce Oratory (Cours Jeanne d'Arc): This oratory built in 1954 commemorates the miracle of 1854, in thanks for the healing of the inhabitants of Maillane during a cholera epidemic.
Indeed, cholera raged in the town during the weeks of August, and there were many deaths of all ages. Some people fled the village: only 110 souls remained out of 1500.
On August 28, 1854, a few people took out the Madonna of Our Lady of Grace and went in procession. The Madonna was dressed in a purple dress.
When she arrived on the public square, she was welcomed by about sixty people. The miracle took place during the procession: Marthe Gauthier, whom the doctor thought would die before the next day, opened her eyes when she heard the bells ringing... She is cured.
After this miracle, the people of Maillan organize a festival in her honor every year, on August 28 and 29.
Originally, the shrine was carried by the miraculous, and only those who had been cured of this disease wore the "velet" (an embroidered tulle veil), an office and privileges transmitted to their descendants.
The procession in honor of Our Lady of Grace begins with a mourning and ends with a feast, like the unfolding of an epidemic.
Architectural description
This aedicula consists of a low stone cippe from Rognes, in the classical style. On this cippe is engraved the cross of the Félibrige (literary association initiated by Frédéric Mistral and 6 other Provençal poets to ensure the defense of cultures and the traditional regional language - the langue d'oc -). You will notice the presence of a holy water font, below the niche with three openings where the statue dressed in a virginian outfit is placed. The oratory leans on the wall of a lateral bench. It rests on a rounded base.

- Oratory of Saint Martha (Chemin Sainte Marthe): For a very long time, an oratory existed at this place, but it would have been destroyed during the Revolution.
It was raised in 1852 by François Pitra, and destroyed in 1986 during the widening of the road. It was rebuilt as it is today.
The statue of Saint Martha, patron saint of Tarascon, reputed in the past to cure eye diseases, has been replaced by another of Our Lady of Grace.
Architectural description
This work is made of dressed stone, the base is the same as a cippus. The statue of Our Lady of Grace can be seen in the rounded niche. The roof has two slopes on a triangular pediment and a metal cross tops the building.

- Oratory of Saint-Eloi: Oratory erected in 2000, by the Brotherhood of Saint-Eloi.

label: Bibliothèque d'Eguilles
description:
More than eight thousand books are at your disposal. Policemen, novels, travel stories,..., the books remain in the general in order to satisfy the greatest number of inhabitants.

A department for children and teenagers is present (from 4 years old).

label: Le Panoramique
description:
Le Panoramique is the name given, since its inauguration in October 1964, to the civic centre built between 1962 and 1964 by the architects Marcel and Pierre Guesnot, on the initiative of the municipality.
The civic centre, planned in the reconstruction and development plan by Pierre Vago, was to symbolize the rebirth of the city after the Second World War, by constituting the "bridgehead", a true symbolic and monumental gate facing Beaucaire and the Languedoc.
The symbolic significance of the Civic Centre results from its location and its vocation. The architects imagined a building with a certain monumentality: symmetrical and orderly facades, use of ashlar, colossal colonnade, classical modenature. The main facade has a rhythmic pattern, obtained by alternating projecting and recessed stones, which gives depth and density to the building, a direct reference to Fernand Pouillon's architecture.
As the interior decoration designed by the architects was considered too modernist, they were discarded in favour of Michel Placidi, who used the Louis XIII style (staircase railing) and Louis XV style (fireplace, tables, chairs). This radical change in aesthetic bias led to a curious balance between modern architectural lines and an interior decoration inspired by another age that has been preserved today (banister, fireplace, chandeliers).

label: Cimetière Saint-Pierre
comment: Necropolis created in 1824 by the acquisition of private land adjoining two existing cemeteries: the Israelite cemetery and the Protestant cemetery. The Saint-Pierre cemetery, covering 7 hectares, gave its name to the district in which it is located.
shortDescription: Necropolis created in 1824 by the acquisition of private land adjoining two existing cemeteries: the Israelite cemetery and the Protestant cemetery. The Saint-Pierre cemetery, covering 7 hectares, gave its name to the district in which it is located.
description:
Saint-Pierre cemetery is situated just a short walk from Aix-en-Provence town centre. It has 2 annexes: Carré 9 is located on Traverse Saint-Pierre and Carré 10 on Avenue des Déportés de la Résistance Aixoise.

This necropolis was created in 1824 through the acquisition of private lands adjoining two existing cemeteries: the Jewish cemetery and the Protestant cemetery. Saint-Pierre cemetery, which extends over seven hectares, has given its name to the district in which it is located.

An interactive terminal has been installed inside the cemetery to enable visitors to find the grave of a relative by typing in the name on the terminal. A map of the cemetery is located at the entrance. The main war memorials can be found in Saint-Pierre cemetery, as well as the memorial for police officers killed in the line of duty, the national monument dedicated to the memory of French and Overseas Repatriates and the Harki memorial. Aix's priests are buried in this cemetery.

Electric buggies are available for elderly people or people with reduced mobility and the cemetery is accessible to people with reduced mobility.

Many famous people are buried in Saint Pierre cemetery, a map can be obtained from the warden's office at the entrance to the cemetery.
streetAddress: ["Avenue Des Déportés du Pays d'Aix et de la Résistance aixoise"]

label: Eglise de l'Estaque
comment: Mass on Wednesdays at 5:30 and 6:30 pm.
shortDescription: Mass on Wednesdays at 5:30 and 6:30 pm.

label: Grand Site Concors Concors Sainte-Victoire
comment: Created in August 2000, the Grand Site Concors Sainte-Victoire, labeled "Grand Site de France", is a territory of nearly 50,000 hectares of which 6,525 are classified.
shortDescription: Created in August 2000, the Grand Site Concors Sainte-Victoire, labeled "Grand Site de France", is a territory of nearly 50,000 hectares of which 6,525 are classified.
description: Located between the Durance valley to the north and the Arc valley to the south, it borders the Var department to the east and includes, to the west, part of the town of Aix-en-Provence. The Grand Site Concors Sainte-Victoire project concerns the development and protection of the natural and cultural environment and involves 14 communes.

label: Eglise Notre Dame de l'Etang
comment: Also known as "church of Mède" or "chapel of Notre-Dame-de-l'Etang".
shortDescription: Also known as "church of Mède" or "chapel of Notre-Dame-de-l'Etang".
description:
Consecrated in 1957, it is of a new conception.
Its modern lines combine sobriety and elegance.

label: Parc Saint-Mitre
comment: Originally, it was a private domain of 6 hectares for residential and agricultural purposes. The municipality acquired this property in 1978 as part of its spatial planning policy and entrusted the project to the Green Spaces Department.
shortDescription: Originally, it was a private domain of 6 hectares for residential and agricultural purposes. The municipality acquired this property in 1978 as part of its spatial planning policy and entrusted the project to the Green Spaces Department.
description:
Access to the park is from Route de Berre. An imposing gate opens on to two avenues lined with ancient chestnut trees and box, which circle a meadow and meet on the other side, enclosing a pond with a waterfall, on an esplanade planted with leafy trees.


In the centre of this esplanade is a mansion built in 1875. The main features of this part are an old covered wash-house, and a large pond and the stream which contain aquatic plants, fish and frogs. To the east is an arboretum containing a fine collection of trees. Dutch greenhouse and rose-garden. 


The park is open from 9am until 30 minutes before sunset. In the centre of the park you will find a planetarium which has a children's play area and a botanical path. The fixed planetarium has been in operation since April 2002 in a temporary municipal building in Parc Saint-Mitre.


It is a small planetarium due to the diameter of its cupola (5m), and cannot accommodate more than 25 adults or 30 children. In collaboration with the local authorities, it is examining a long-term solution for a larger cupola. The mobile planetarium has an inflatable dome which enables it to be moved as required.


Animals not allowed (except assistance animals).

label: Le Petit Monde de Marcel Pagnol
comment: Marcel Pagnol's Little World is a heritage institution dear to the heart of the people of Aubagne.
shortDescription: Marcel Pagnol's Little World is a heritage institution dear to the heart of the people of Aubagne.
description:
Here's the sort of miniature world with a unique provençal twist:
a display of 200-odd clay figurines acting out quirky scenes from Marcel Pagnol's life, books and movies.

It neatly combines two of the things for which Aubagne is famous: the local clay and Pagnol.

Sounds, images, lights, reconstructions... modernity serving tradition to rediscover this outstanding heritage.

label: Fontaine du Roi René
comment: Carved in Paris, it was transported to Aix-en-Provence with some difficulty, and unveiled in 1823. In his hands the king holds a cluster of Muscat grapes (which he imported into Provence) and his sceptre decorated with dolphins. At his feet are books indicating the King's knowledge and culture.
shortDescription: Carved in Paris, it was transported to Aix-en-Provence with some difficulty, and unveiled in 1823. In his hands the king holds a cluster of Muscat grapes (which he imported into Provence) and his sceptre decorated with dolphins. At his feet are books indicating the King's knowledge and culture.
description:
