The diversion, by a convent, of water from the Carmelites fountain, which was discovered by the authorities in 1683, obliged the municipality to move the fountain. 

The chosen location was at the top of Cours des Carrosses (now Cours Mirabeau). 

For a long time there was no statue on the stand of this fountain it was not until 1819, after many projects had been abandoned, that the decision was made to erect a statue of King René on it. 

This location at the top of Cours des Carrosses, the town's main thoroughfare, shows the gratitude of the people of Aix towards their Good King René. 

Note that the statue, entitled "King of Jerusalem" and "King of Anjou", does not bear the name "Count of Provence". The statue was renovated in 2009 for the 600th anniversary of King René's birth

label: Canal et Tunnel du Rove
comment: Impressive work dug from 1910 to 1925; the longest river tunnel in the world (7.2 kilometres)
shortDescription: Impressive work dug from 1910 to 1925; the longest river tunnel in the world (7.2 kilometres)
description:
It meanders away, silent, making hardly any waves for a long time now, except for those of the news. It wanders its banks, calm, from Marseille to the Etang de Berre and even beyond

Is it still real, this canal that finally made Marseille a river port linked to the tumultuous Rhone? Wanted since Antiquity, thought of over the centuries by Vauban, Napoleon or the engineer de Montricher, a canal linking Arles with the Rhône was essential for Marseille and its trade. This opened up great commercial prospects with the north of the country, and even with northern Europe

The Chamber of Commerce tenaciously held on to its project. Politicians, such as the deputies Jules Charles-Roux and Bernard Cadenat, would support it

Prepared in 1879, decided by law in 1903, started digging in 1910, finished in 1925, officially opened by the President of the Republic Gaston Doumergue in 1927, this half-river, half-sea route made Marseille and its region proud. For the surrounding villages, Gignac, Châteauneuf, Marignane, Martigues, Port-de-Bouc, Berre... it was a gigantic enterprise full of future: pipes brought drinking water to the tap, schools were created, industries were set up along the canal... It was Léon Chagnaud, a senator from Creuse and already a well-known entrepreneur, who won the contract to build the Rove tunnel in 1909. Thousands of workers worked in very difficult conditions. The hard and militant strikes, the accidents, always terrible, the indispensable foreign workers, all bear witness to the daily life of the building sites, which is well forgotten today. Germinal was not far away!

The digging of the Nerthe mountain range was "pharaonic": 7.2 km dug underground made the Rove Tunnel the longest in the world (still registered today in the Guinness Book of Records). From the excavation 2.5 million m3 of rubble were extracted! The construction lasted more than 15 years, interrupted only by the strikes but not even by the First World War! Let us emphasize that our canal will serve the propaganda when it will be quoted as an example of France which works at the same time as it fights in Verdun!

The constantly increasing traffic marks, by its mutation, the transformations of the port of Marseille. The food transport of the 40s and 50s gave way to hydrocarbons. The Etang de Berre became industrialized, and the Canal de Marseille au Rhône played its part

The collapse of June 1963, under the tunnel, caused the end of a beautiful and great story: the traffic was interrupted, the works will never open the blocked way

The canal had had its day: it was time for large vessels and the Fos-sur-Mer complex. Since then, however, billions have been released to ensure the safety of the structure and the villages, such as Le Rove or Gignac, located vertically above it, by providing the necessary reinforcement for the construction

The Marignan portion of the underground is still distinguished by the imposing northern head designed by the architect Gaston Castel between 1925 and 1927. It was to be decorated with statues entrusted to the sculptor Antoine Sartorio according to an abandoned project. Made up of an arch and four massive pylons with chains, its elevation follows the division of the slopes criss-crossed by berms, thus integrating into this new industrial landscape.

Source: Michel Méténier

label: Bibliothèque de Bouc Bel Air
comment: The library has more than 32,000 documents
shortDescription: The library has more than 32,000 documents
description: The library houses over 32,000 documents including several new publications, 1100 DVDs, 2900 comics and a wide range of reviews as well as digital readers so you can read new novels for free.

label: Parc des Roches Blanches
comment: The Roches Blanches Park is a peaceful place for relaxation and fun for locals and tourists.
shortDescription: The Roches Blanches Park is a peaceful place for relaxation and fun for locals and tourists.
description:
It is an integral part of the town’s history as evidenced by the fossilized oyster beds in the eastern part of the park. Dating from around 15 million years ago (Miocene), according to some, these oysters gave the town its name, ‘Ostreion’ designating a bed of oysters in Greek. These oyster beds show that this park was under an immense sea for a very long time.

It is a crossing point for the ‘Amongst town and nature’ and the ‘From one great view to another’ hikes.

label: Plaque Commémorative des Frères Lumière
description: A commemorative tablet in the train station reminds that La Ciotat is the city of the Lumière brothers. They shot here their first movie: the arrival of a train to the station of La Ciotat.

label: Eglise Saint-Pierre Saint-Paul
description:
Priest: Father René Boyer. (Reception at the church on Fridays between 4 and 6:30 p.m.).
Saturday Mass: 6:30 pm
Sunday Mass: 10:00 a.m.
Reception from Monday to Friday from 10:00 to 12:00 and from 16:00 to 18:00,
saturday from 10am to 12pm and from 5pm to 6.30pm
streetAddress: ['161 Boulevard De la Libération', '64 rue Léon Bourgeois']

label: Vieille Font
comment: A "font" in Provençal means a fountain or sometimes a spring. The commune takes its name from this fountain, "Vieio font" in Provençal, which translates as "old fountain". It still feeds the washhouse which is located a few steps away.
shortDescription: A "font" in Provençal means a fountain or sometimes a spring. The commune takes its name from this fountain, "Vieio font" in Provençal, which translates as "old fountain". It still feeds the washhouse which is located a few steps away.
description:
In Provençal, a 'font' was a fountain or sometimes a spring.
This is a small building constructed in 1150 in the Fontvieille countryside. It housed the commune's first spring.
The commune took its name from this fountain, 'Vieio Font' in Provençal, which translates as 'old fountain.'.
It was already in use in Roman times and still supplies the wash house located nearby.

label: Hôtel de Clémens ou Maison de l'Abbesse
description:
This civilian building was partially built in the 15th century, sold to the Ursulines and then redeveloped in the early 17th century; it was encompassed into the convent extension and then used as a residence by the Abbess. Only the façade on Rue du 4 septembre still has Renaissance features, such as pilasters and capitals (1619).
All that remain of the first religious building, which was on the same site, are the apse (visible from Impasse Monge) and the vault of a chapel whose foundations were blessed in 1096 by Pope Urban II on his way back from the Council of Clermont, where he ordered the first crusade.
Place Pie, named after the visit of Pope Pius VII (following his release in 1814 by Napoleon I, who had imprisoned him in 1809) was not a public place, but was the inner courtyard of the Ursuline convent.
Closed to visitors

label: Salins de Berre
comment: The Berre saltworks, which have been installed for several centuries on the ancient alluvial terraces of the Arc, are bordered by beaches and marshes. They present an interesting ornithological heritage.
shortDescription: The Berre saltworks, which have been installed for several centuries on the ancient alluvial terraces of the Arc, are bordered by beaches and marshes. They present an interesting ornithological heritage.
description: Being a private property of the Salins du Midi, access is forbidden.

label: Porte Calendrale
comment: The Calendrale gate is a Romanesque gate corresponding to the northern entrance of Barbentane.
shortDescription: The Calendrale gate is a Romanesque gate corresponding to the northern entrance of Barbentane.
description: The recently restored Porte Calendrale commanded the northern entrance to Barbentane. There is a wonderful view of this gate from the end of the Grand'Rue. All that remains of the 11th century ramparts is a defensive tower which was transformed into a prison and used until 1826.

label: Hôtel Boyer de Fonscolombe
description:
Built in 1650 for Charles de Grimaldi, Marquis of Régusse, this mansion was sold to the Forbin-La Barben family in 1724, passed to the Boyer de Fonscolombe family in 1743, and, by inheritance from his mother Irène de Fonscolombe, to Gaston de Saporta. 

The Boyer de Fonscolombe family renovated the building, and its frontage was redesigned in 1757 by Laurent Alexandre Vallon.

It now houses the Institute of Public Management and Territorial Governance of Paul Cézanne University

label: Eden Théâtre
description:
The Eden Theater opened on 16 June 1889 and is therefore the oldest cinema in the world. It was originally built for theater performances, concerts, and even wrestling shows. However, it became famous thanks to the Lumière brothers. In fact, Eden would not be of any meaning today if it did not host the first private screening of a film in September 1895.
In fact, it was in 1895 that brothers Louis and Auguste Lumière invented their own apparatus which was a camera and a projector, at the same time, thus allowing for images to be displayed on a moving screen.
However, even if Eden had not hosted this historic event, it is the oldest cinema still in existence, making it an integral part of the heritage of the average film.
Eden was purchased by the City Council in April 1992 and was classified as a historic monument on February 12, 1996. The reopening of the Eden, after a complete restoration, took place in October 2013.

label: Forêt domaniale de Cuges les Pins
comment: The national forest of Cuges-les-Pins is a haven of peace in the heart of Provence
shortDescription: The national forest of Cuges-les-Pins is a haven of peace in the heart of Provence
description: This state-owned forest of 311 ha is located north of Cuges-les-Pins and extends to the southern slope of the Sainte Baume Massif.

label: Jardin de Corbières
comment:
Located beyond Estaque, at the limit of the municipality, the cove of Corbières offers an exceptional view of the entire harbor of Marseille
The garden gives access to small sandy and pebble beaches and to the municipal water sports centre.
shortDescription:
Located beyond Estaque, at the limit of the municipality, the cove of Corbières offers an exceptional view of the entire harbor of Marseille
The garden gives access to small sandy and pebble beaches and to the municipal water sports centre.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


Located beyond l'Estaque, at the limit of the municipality's territory, the Corbières cove offers an exceptional view of the entire harbour of Marseille. Attracted by the light so particular to the Provencal region, the Impressionists were not mistaken in planting their easels in these parts. The site consists of a portion of shoreline (along the road to Rove) dominated by the stepped cliffs of the massif du Rove which includes remarkable architectural elements: fortress of 1861, railway viaduct of the line of the Côte Bleue ... It is on this maritime facade, sheltered from the Mistral, that the city created a garden in 1987. The choice of landscape design had to take into account the narrow topography of the site (with steep slopes and cliffs), the integration of road equipment and the limited possibilities for watering. The choice was made to use natural scrubland vegetation with "exotic" species such as palms, eucalyptus, bougainvillea, yucca, agave, hibiscus, casuarinas... The garden gives access to small sandy and pebble beaches as well as to the municipal water sports centre.

label: Eglise Saint-Julien
description:
The church of Saint Julien is nestled in the heart of the medieval village of Peynier in a small labyrinth of narrow streets full of character.
The lower part of the tower, rebuilt in the 12th century, now surmounted by a beautiful bell tower, was originally the choir of the church.

label: Plage Les Arènes
description:
Plage les Arènes
As its name implies, the "Plage des Arènes" in Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer is situated just behind the town's famous Roman arena. This handkerchief-size beach, measuring just 200 square metres, offers easy access for the disabled. It is attended by a lifeguard in summer only and animals are not allowed on the sand...
Located immediately next to the town centre, this is a highly practical choice for families and you'll have no problems if you forgot to bring some water or a bucket and spade for the kids! What's more, you'll be spoilt for choice at lunchtime with a myriad of tempting little restaurants serving local specialities such as the "Gardianne de taureau" (bull beef stew), or "tellines" (cockles) prepared with garlic and parsley...

label: Médiathèque Pierre Bottero
comment: The Pierre Bottero municipal media library is located in the Parc Maureau in the heart of the city centre, with all access and parking facilities.
shortDescription: The Pierre Bottero municipal media library is located in the Parc Maureau in the heart of the city centre, with all access and parking facilities.
description: advice on reading and document research, home porting, digital services, permanent Wi-Fi access, office automation courses, game sessions, departmental library partnership

label: Plage Calanque de Sugiton
comment: Small cove with varied relief, shaded, with sand, pebbles and rocks. The waters are fresh and crystal clear.
shortDescription: Small cove with varied relief, shaded, with sand, pebbles and rocks. The waters are fresh and crystal clear.
description:
The large elongated rock facing it is called "Le torpilleur". Its access can be limited according to a prefectural decree in spring and summer. Be careful: the access path is quite long and with some levelled ground
Sugiton will be the subject of a study in summer 2022 to better manage the flow of hikers.
Bus stop B1 then 1 hour walk.

label: Eglise Sainte-Marguerite
comment:
Church that hosts occasional concerts. Parish priest: Nicolas Lubrano.
Mass on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10:30 am. During the week Tuesday at 7pm, Wednesday and Thursday at 8am, Friday at 7pm, preceded by adoration of the Blessed Sacrament at 6.30pm.
shortDescription:
Church that hosts occasional concerts. Parish priest: Nicolas Lubrano.
Mass on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10:30 am. During the week Tuesday at 7pm, Wednesday and Thursday at 8am, Friday at 7pm, preceded by adoration of the Blessed Sacrament at 6.30pm.
description:
"Originally a simple priory attached to the abbey of Saint Victor, the present church of Sainte Marguerite was built during the 19th century to the plans of the architect Charles Bodin

The new lighting of this religious building is part of the 2014 program to modernize the public lighting installations of the Place Antide Boyer in the 9th arrondissement

A subtle mix of warm white, neutral white and cold white, the lighting design helps to reveal and magnify the various architectural elements of this Romanesque-style building
- the four pinnacles structuring the façade
- the four pilasters
- the voussures
- the archivolt marking the central porch
- and the triforium surmounted by a delicately underlined frieze and overhung by the cross

On the forecourt, at the entrance to the church, the two cast iron statues, recently gilded, representing Saint Joseph and the Virgin, keep watch." City of Marseille.

label: Médiathèque municipale
description:
Upon presentation of proof of identity and domicile.
For the book: free of charge for residents and non-residents under 15 years of age, €8.00 per year for non-residents over 15 years of age.
For the CD: entrance fee of € 15.00 per family.
For Video and DVD: € 30.00 entrance fee per family.

label: Fontaine du Cours des Héros
comment: The Fountain occupies the main course of the city, the Cours des Héros, which still hosts the practice of petanque but also the market and other activities throughout the year.
shortDescription: The Fountain occupies the main course of the city, the Cours des Héros, which still hosts the practice of petanque but also the market and other activities throughout the year.
description:
This four-gun fountain was built in 1873 in the former seigneurial park to adorn the new promenade du Cours

In the 19th century, the village of Simiane acquired a prestigious fountain like many other villages in the region. At the time, these fountains, with their richly sculpted decoration, played a role of embellishment and social marker in a context of opening up the region to the rest of the country

The carved lions were added later, in 1975, at the request of the municipality.

label: La Tour de l'Horloge
comment: Built in 1672 with stones from the castle, the Clock Tower is the symbol of Eygalières' independence.
shortDescription: Built in 1672 with stones from the castle, the Clock Tower is the symbol of Eygalières' independence.
description: In 1660, the villagers paid the ransom of their lord, the Duke of Guise, who had been taken hostage by the Spaniards. As a reward, they gained the seigniorial rights of their village.

label: Plage du port des Goudes
comment: Small sand and gravel cove, adjacent to the port. Restaurants nearby.
shortDescription: Small sand and gravel cove, adjacent to the port. Restaurants nearby.
description:
Les Goudes are now part of the Calanques National Park.
To know the accessibility of the protected natural areas, between June 1st and September 30th, via a simple phone number, 0 811 20 13 13. (Cost of a local call).
Metro Castellane or Rond Point du Prado then bus n°20.

label: Médiathèque Simone Veil
comment: The Simone-Veil Media Library offers wide access to culture and information technology.
shortDescription: The Simone-Veil Media Library offers wide access to culture and information technology.
description: The distribution of the space has been studied in order to offer spaces and collections specific to the needs of each person. These collections, which are multi-media, cover not only the written word but also music, images, films, multimedia and the Internet and are available to the public. Visitors can access different areas, such as the Adults, Children, Image or Sound sectors, as well as a reading room for magazines. Each room also has a large collection of documents. The media library also offers a rich programme of cultural activities throughout the year. Access is entirely free. Borrowing documents, access to computers and the Internet requires membership of the media library.

label: Chapelle Sainte-Catherine (Chapelle de la Visitation)
comment: Located in the city center of Aix-en-Provence, this chapel is in the northern part of the monastery built between 1647 and 1652 on the plans of Pierre Pavillon.
shortDescription: Located in the city center of Aix-en-Provence, this chapel is in the northern part of the monastery built between 1647 and 1652 on the plans of Pierre Pavillon.
description: Small chapel inside the school of St Catherine of Sienna.

label: Plage des Catalans
comment: The Catalans beach is a sandy beach, the closest to the Old Port, below the sports club Le Cercle des Nageurs. It is equipped with a first-aid post, showers, toilets, garbage cans and a refreshment bar.
shortDescription: The Catalans beach is a sandy beach, the closest to the Old Port, below the sports club Le Cercle des Nageurs. It is equipped with a first-aid post, showers, toilets, garbage cans and a refreshment bar.
description:
The volleyball court hosts high-level competitions and training sessions for the Catalans beach volleyball club.
It is also the home of the underwater museum

The surveillance of the beaches will be from June 1 to August 31, 2022 7 days a week from 10:00 am to 7:30 pm.

In order to allow bathers to enjoy the site in the best conditions of hygiene and comfort, the beach has been reprofiled and sifted to 30 cm deep
It is now cleaned daily. Similarly, a sanitary module has been installed. The showers are operational every day, while the sanitary facilities are open.
From the Vieux Port, bus 83.

label: Espace Muséal
comment:
SCHEDULED TO OPEN IN JUNE 2022

Museum of Saintes Maries de la Mer, maritime archaeology and Baroncelli space... a window on time. Our history from the highest antiquity to the XX century".
shortDescription:
OPENING ON JULY 12, 2022

Museum of Saintes Maries de la Mer, maritime archaeology and Baroncelli space... a window on time. Our history from the highest antiquity to the XX century".
description:
"Visitors, consider that from the top of this bell tower, thirty centuries are contemplating you"
Allow me to borrow here the famous words of Napoleon I to recall the historical and ethnographic richness of these wild lands and this coast of the Camargue, very early frequented by the sailors. Until then, the Camargue as a whole was mainly apprehended as a rough and almost deserted territory, linked to a relatively recent Provencal and Languedoc history. But since these last decades, thanks to numerous campaigns of underwater archaeological excavations, its historical and ancestral horizon was widened to the highest Antiquity. We discover Etruscan, Greek, Massalian, Norman, Saracen and other ships. The will of the municipality to put back in value its rich ethnographic collections, classified today as Museum of France, as well as its most remote maritime heritage, led to the construction of a new structure which will open to the public from July 1st, 2022. The museum of Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer presents to the public, in an innovative scenography, a chronological course devoted to the maritime past of this coast from the 7th century BC, punctuated by the old ethnographic collections of the Baroncelli Museum. A new cultural offer that completes the already rich tourist offer of the village.

label: Site archéologique de Saint Pierre de Vence
description:
Archaeological site of Saint Pierre de Vence
The Gallo-Roman villa of Saint-Pierre de Vence is a villa located in the commune of Eyguières. The site has been inhabited since the end of the Iron Age, but most of its development dates from the Roman period. It is inhabited at least until the ninth century.

The construction of this villa followed the desertion of the oppidum of St. Cecilia and became a residential centre with a dozen buildings.

label: Fontaine Villeverte
comment: Formerly part of the countryside outside the city walls, which the flocks passed through in transhumance, today Villeverte is the Sextius district, and the city decided to built a fountain there in order to develop and enhance the area.
shortDescription: Formerly part of the countryside outside the city walls, which the flocks passed through in transhumance, today Villeverte is the Sextius district, and the city decided to built a fountain there in order to develop and enhance the area.
description:
In 1683 a successful merchant of Rue des Cordeliers, Jean Baptiste Silvacanne, offered to help with the project. He held the rights to a spring which the fountain could use, and offered this to the city. The only condition he laid down was that of keeping a flow of water for his domestic use, in his home. The city agreed and undertook the construction of the fountain. Armand Excursan, a master fountain-maker of Aix, was assigned the building work.

In 1845, with the increase in traffic, the fountain – like so many others in Aix – was an obstruction, and was moved to the square next to Cours Sextius.

Today it has two basins: a large one, with a low edge, was used by animals during their transhumance, and one on the other side, of human height and in the shape of a shell, allowed the population to draw water.

The basin and the shell are each fed by a bronze mascaron representing a man with a severe expression, his mouth open spewing water. A square block stands on a buttressed base. At its summit is a cast-iron urn placed there in 1848.

label: Bibliothèque des Fenouillères
comment: Located south of Aix-en-Provence, close to the Aix-Marseille University faculty, the university library offers collections adapted to the teaching and research carried out on campus: Arts, Letters, Languages and Humanities
shortDescription: Located south of Aix-en-Provence, close to the Aix-Marseille University faculty, the university library offers collections adapted to the teaching and research carried out on campus: Arts, Letters, Languages and Humanities
description:
Located in the south of Aix-en-Provence, close by the Aix-Marseille University, the university library has collections adapted to the courses taught and to the research carried out on the campus: Arts, Literature, Languages and Human Sciences.

It is open 67 hours a week (excepting university holidays), with seating for over 1,000 people, 150 computers, wifi, a book returns box, 11 group work rooms, photocopiers and printers, equipment for visually impaired people, DVDs, newspapers and magazines and relaxation areas.

label: Parc de la Porte d'Aix
comment: Urban park in downtown Marseille.
shortDescription: Urban park in downtown Marseille.
description:
With a surface area of 11,000 m², this green space, whose tiered configuration evokes the calanques, is made up of 8,000 m² of planted areas

Composed of five playgrounds (one of which is accessible to people with reduced mobility), ping-pong tables and checkers games, the Porte d'Aix park also has two drinking water fountains, misters, a shared garden and 600 m² of other spaces.

label: Iles marseillaises
comment: Marseille without its islands would not be Marseille!
shortDescription: Marseille without its islands would not be Marseille!
description:
The islands of Marseille are composed of :
- the islands of Frioul, Ratonneau Island and the Isle of If, accessible by boat,
- of the island of Endoume and the island Gaby (degaby) closest to Marseille,
- and the islands of the Riou archipelago, the Parc National des Calanques.

label: Chapelle Saint Michel
comment: The original Romanesque chapel was restored in the 15th century.
shortDescription: The original Romanesque chapel was restored in the 15th century.
description: It can be visited from time to time during heritage days. The park Saint Michel where it is located with the dovecote is used every summer as a backdrop for a great historical sound and light show.

label: Musée rural d'histoire locale
description:
The museum is located in the former Saint-Jean chapel. Built in the 17th century, it was home to a brotherhood of white penitents. On the ground floor, the museum presents a collection of objects and tools from traditional agricultural and craft life and on the first floor a series of 24 classified ex-votos, the oldest of which dates back to 1676, on wood and canvas, from the Notre-Dame de-Consolation chapel and dating from the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. An area on the first floor is dedicated to temporary exhibitions on rural and craft life and the presentation of artistic works.
The museum offers its publications for sale, in particular its latest work of investigation and research on Jouques, published in 2006: "Jouques un village, son histoire" (Jouques a village, its history).
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 105
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 20

label: Le Marégraphe
comment: It officially indicates the 0 altitude of all nautical charts, and IGN inspectors regularly come to take measurements. It is only open to the public during the European Heritage Days.
shortDescription: It officially indicates the 0 altitude of all nautical charts, and IGN inspectors regularly come to take measurements. It is only open to the public during the European Heritage Days.

label: Fort Saint Nicolas et fort d'Entrecasteaux
comment: The fort is composed of the fort d'Entrecasteaux, above, and the fort Ganteaume below. Located on a strategic site at the entrance of the Old Port, this fort was built under Louis XIV to impose the royal power on the population of Marseille.
shortDescription: The fort is composed of the fort d'Entrecasteaux, above, and the fort Ganteaume below. Located on a strategic site at the entrance of the Old Port, this fort was built under Louis XIV to impose the royal power on the population of Marseille.
description:
Its double enclosure, ditches and bastions, illustrates the necessary adaptation to the offensives of the fire artillery. The salient angle thus formed makes it possible to accommodate the machines and to compensate for the widening of the enclosure which has the effect of recreating the blind spot formerly neutralized by the machicolations. The fortresses testify of the periods of the history where this unit was seen in danger. In the 17th century, Louis XIV ordered the construction of the Saint-Nicolas citadel. This fort could direct its batteries on the city as well as on the invaders. This work, beyond the principle of defense, indirectly delivers another testimony, that of the evolution of the art of the war and the armament. Today, it houses the mixed garrison circle.

It is only accessible to those admitted to the Circle.

label: Château dit de la Reine Jeanne
comment: Discover the historic castle of Queen Jeanne
shortDescription: Discover the historic castle of Queen Jeanne
description: In a dominant position at the border of the hill of Ventabren, the Castle offers a panoramic view of the average Valley of the Arc for increased surveillance of the territory. A simple architecture, his periods of construction would be included between the 12th and 17th centuries. The castle was first under the rule of the Lords of the leases, and then of Queen Jeanne and in the 15th century Henry IV donated land to family Gaillard Longjumeau.Abandoned first, the castle was partly destroyed during the French Revolution in 1789. Included on the inventory of historical monuments in 1989, it has undergone several slices of consolidation.

label: Parc Central de Bonneveine
comment: In 1976, the city of Marseille created this 3-hectare park as part of the development of the Bonneveine Centre-Vie.
shortDescription: In 1976, the city of Marseille created this 3-hectare park as part of the development of the Bonneveine Centre-Vie.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


In 1976, the city of Marseille created this 3-hectare park as part of the development of the Bonneveine Centre-Vie. It is linked to a cultural centre, a swimming pool, a school and provides a link with the entrance to the Museum of Contemporary Art (MAC).

The basic principle of this park of modern design was to compose ground movements of low amplitude from a structure of hexagonal terraces. It is in fact a sculpted garden which combines, in the same ensemble, rest and play areas, an open-air theatre, bowls and a central esplanade. In the northern part of the park, two craters have been developed, one as a mini soccer field, the other as a playground with a modular structure for 6/9 year olds. By their configuration, these craters encourage the surprise effect that children like to face.

These movements of the ground create a very diverse atmosphere. The plantings highlight these lines and with them the atmospheres deliberately suggested. At the heart of this composition, three bodies of water have naturally found their place.

label: Les vestiges de St Chamas
comment: Saint Chamas, proud of its vestiges, of which the Flavian bridge remains the most famous, has managed to preserve all the character of the Provencal villages where life is good.
shortDescription: Saint Chamas, proud of its vestiges, of which the Flavian bridge remains the most famous, has managed to preserve all the character of the Provencal villages where life is good.
description:
Built by the Romans in the 1st century BC at the time of Emperor Augustus, it was saved from ruin at the beginning of the 17th century. It has been restored many times, but it still retains the class of a rare monument. As a testimony of its frequentation, the passage of the carriages have left their marks.

The parish church: Built between 1660 and 1668 by the Aix architect Pierre Pavillon, the façade, a jewel of Provençal Baroque style, contrasts with the sobriety of the almost naked interior. The second chapel, on the right, is adorned with a magnificent half-relief altarpiece depicting episodes from the life of the Virgin: the altarpiece of St Anne (16th century).

Troglodytic habitats: Two kinds of caves: some natural but few in number, the others were built from 1615 following the transfer by the lord of St Chamas of his property rights to the Community Council. It is he who grants the authorization to dig balms in the Baou. These caves were used as warehouses for the goods of the port, mills, shelters? It was during the 18th century that the caves began to be used as habitats.

La Poudrerie : By deed of 20 March 1690, the overflow of water from the canal des moulins was sold to the King to be used for the work of the powder hammer that his Majesty had built in the place called St Chamas. Today it occupies more than 100 hectares by gaining by dykes and embankments on the marshes of the pond. The Powder mill which made live several generations of St Chamassens has today ceased all activity.

Aqueduc du Plan or Pont de l'Horloge: On December 18, 1863, the tunnel "la Goule" collapsed. St Chamas is cut in two and deprived of water. An aqueduct 62m long and 23m high is built.

Lavoir du Polygone: 18th century washhouse once reserved for the contagious.

The gate of the Fort: Last vestige of the surrounding wall of the old St Chamas, it dates from the 15th century.

Chapel ND de Miséricorde: It overlooks the pond and the village and was famous for its ex-votos. Some of these naive paintings have been restored and are now in the museum.

St Léger Viaduct: Built between 1843 and 1847 for the passage of the Paris-Lyon-Marseille line. The vaults are crossed to allow the crossing of the Touloubre river. It has 49 arches and is 25m high.

Ermitage St Léger : It already existed in the 16th century, the notables of the village were buried there. Centre of pilgrimage and devotion of the inhabitants, the chapel has been abandoned for years.

The Roquette bridge: Destroyed by a flood of the Touloubre, it was rebuilt in 1750.

label: Eglise Saint Jean-Baptiste
comment:
Mass on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10:30 am, weekdays at 6:30 pm.
Priest: Christophe Jullien.
shortDescription:
Mass on Saturday at 6:30 pm, Sunday at 10:30 am, weekdays at 6:30 pm.
Priest: Christophe Jullien.

label: Château de la Penne
description:
Ruins of the Château de la Penne.
It is one of the oldest bastides of Pélissanne.
It is said to have served as a refuge for Raymond de Turenne who spread terror throughout Provence in the 14th century.

label: Arènes des Saintes Maries de la Mer
comment: Camargue Races - Bullfighting shows - Horse shows - Visit to the Arena
shortDescription: Camargue Races - Bullfighting shows - Horse shows - Visit to the Arena
description: Built in the 1930s, they can accommodate 3000 people. There are bullfighting shows: Cameroonian races, bullfights, but also folklore and equestrian shows.

label: Oppidum du Salounet à l'Abbaye de Sainte Croix
description: The oppidum, indifferently called Salonet, sits on an independent hill on the heights of the town of Salon-de-Provence, in the heart of the property of the Abbey of Sainte-Croix. Nearby there are the ruins of a medieval chapel. Occupied by Ligurian populations, the oppidum served as a refuge and strategic site.
streetAddress: ['Abbaye de Sainte Croix', 'Route Du Val de Cuech']

label: Fontaine Trinquetaille
comment: The Trinquetaille fountain dates from the 18th century
shortDescription: The Trinquetaille fountain dates from the 18th century
description: Fountain created in 1774 by the Town Council. Fed from the Gilouse. It was rebuilt in 1916.

label: Espace Pébéo
comment:
The paint production plant makes you discover its museum space: the history, the manufacture of paint, the creations of color...
But do you know where the name Pebeo comes from?
shortDescription:
The paint production plant makes you discover its museum space: the history, the manufacture of paint, the creations of color...
But do you know where the name Pebeo comes from?
description:
A COLOURFUL HISTORY
Pebeo opens its doors and invites you behind the scenes of 100 years
of inventions, talent and history, as a living tribute to colour and to all creators.
Come and discover this fascinating saga during a visit of the factory
the factory, the new museum, the contemporary art gallery and souvenir shop
souvenir shop.
To enter the Espace Pébéo is to enter the world of art. From
works of art of all kinds, sculptures, paintings, lithographs decorate
the factory, the administrative buildings and the halls. Designed by the architect
Maurice Sauzet, who was greatly influenced by traditional Japanese architecture, the building that houses it is distinguished by its wide and deep openings, framing powerful landscapes.

label: Site - Mémorial du Camp des Milles
comment: A large French internment and deportation camp (1939-1942) still intact and accessible to the public, the Camp des Milles now houses an important historical museum, with educational and cultural purposes.
shortDescription: A large French internment and deportation camp (1939-1942) still intact and accessible to the public, the Camp des Milles now houses an important historical museum, with educational and cultural purposes.
description:
A unique place in the world. A must visit.

To start with, this place is like a historic slap in the face. But it is also an opportunity to go beyond and grow. A visit to the Camp des Milles is worth all authoritative lessons on civic education and the virtues of democracy and of the living together.

Based on the history of the place, its action is indeed to strengthen everyone's vigilance and responsibility regarding racism, anti-Semitism and all forms of fanaticism.

The camp of artists: one of the features of the Camp des Milles lies in the breadth and diversity of the internees' artistic production. More than 400 works have been created there some are part of the site. This abundance is explained by the presence of many artists and intellectuals (Max Ernst, Hans Bellmer and Lion Feuchtwanger ...) whose survival against persecution and dehumanization depended on their creative impulses. 

“Camp des miles” Memorial-Site: UNESCO Chair. Historic Monument. One of the nine top French memorials.

15 000 m2 visit trail. Permanent exhibitions. Over 25 annual cultural events: exhibitions, films, debates, symposia, conferences, theater, music, young audience and al public cultural programming for all ages, forums, workshops ...
You can also visit the new museum area. This new part of the permanent display has been developed in partnership with the Auschwitz-Birkenau Museum in Poland and the Kazerne Dossin in Belgium.

Handicap facilities: accessible to people with reduced mobility. Chairs are available at the entrance.

Note that access is free in the following locations: Serge Klarsfeld permanent national exhibition about the 11,400 Jewish children deported from France to Auschwitz, exhibition "save the children: 1938-1945" in partnership with the Children Relief Work (OSE) and the hall of paintings with impressive wall paintings by artists internees, the path of the deportees and the memory wagon.

Access to the Museum is very easy from the city center of Aix en Provence - line 4 next to the Tourist Office - Milles Station stop.
Free parking for cars in front of the memorial.

Pay-guided tours are available every day (5 euros extra).
Hours: 10.30 am to 2.30pm

Group visit (minimum 15 people) can also be offered outside of these hours.

It is recommended to dress warmly for the visit in winter, temperatures can vary within the site Memorial.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame d'Astor
description: It was built in the 12th c. on a light mound, around a beautiful vegetation. It is composed of a vault of ridges and 3 semicircular bays which light the room.

label: Médiathèque du CEC
comment: 220 000 documents, on-site and remote services: novels, comics, movies, documentaries, albums, magazines, daily and local press...
shortDescription: 220 000 documents, on-site and remote services: novels, comics, movies, documentaries, albums, magazines, daily and local press...
description: Computer stations, shelves, wifi internet access.A place to revise or to document, armchairs to read and escape, a couch to share a story with her child.A daily shuttle service, which routes your reservations to any point of the municipal network to your media library to Istres and Entressen.Digital: media library offers a bouquet of digital resources available free of charge 24/24 for you.To learn and train, read and learn, listen to... make your choice from a range of possibilities. News, school support, preparation for the contest, methods of languages, advice of librarians, documentary records... And there is something for children as for adults! Navigate in the youth space specially designed for children, with thematic topics tailored to all ages of children.And of course from the website you can: search and book a document, check your account,... Regular meetings: Conferences, exhibitions, musical meetings, workshops, storytelling.

label: Rade de Marseille
comment: Between the hills of Estaque (which announce the Côte Bleue) and the archipelago of the Frioul islands (which lead to the Calanques National Park), the "Rade de Marseille" offers points of views between city and nature.
shortDescription: Between the hills of Estaque (which announce the Côte Bleue) and the archipelago of the Frioul islands (which lead to the Calanques National Park), the "Rade de Marseille" offers points of views between city and nature.
description: The magnificent harbour of Marseille offers excellent sailing conditions in the midst of remarkable landscapes, which is why it was chosen to host the sailing events of the 2024 Olympic Games. Carried by prevailing north-west and south-east winds, you will be able to enjoy the panorama over the city of Marseille and discover the Frioul archipelago.

label: Jardin Antoine Maurel
description: Jardin Antoine Maurel.

label: Le Parc de Fontlaure
description:
In the 17th century, the Fontlaure estate was independent of the Château d'Eguilles, nicknamed the "Grand Jardin" by the Boyer d'Eguilles family

A pied-à-terre called mon repos was built there for the Marquis d'Argens, philosopher and friend of Voltaire and Frederick II of Prussia

The municipality acquired this property which was once the home of Marie Gasquet. Bought in 1902 by the Gasquet couple and named "Fontlaure" the place where there is water and oleander-tin

This island of greenery with trees more than a hundred years old welcomed a host of Provencal artists, including Frédéric Mistral and Paul Cézanne.

 Since spring 2014 the park is offered free access.

label: Chapelle Saint Symphorien
comment: Chapel of Saint Symphorien dating from the 18th century.
shortDescription: Chapel of Saint Symphorien dating from the 18th century.
description:
The Saint Symphorien chapel is located on the road to Coudoux and dates from the 18th century. It is dedicated to the patron saint of the village, Saint Symphorien.
It consists of a house and the chapel. The house is an old presbytery in which lived a hermit. The last priest, Father Passa, died there in 1924. This presbytery was sold by the commune in 1976 and transformed into a guest house.
Until the 1960s, masses were celebrated in the chapel for family events

label: Eglise Saint Louis
description: A chapel had been built in 1844. Its extension was decided in 1878 to become the church "St. Louis" with a pediment of baroque style which will give birth to the church district. On April 9, 1855 the cross was inaugurated on the church square. Inside the church you can admire a painting by Reynaud Levieux who is a Provençal painter born in 1613 in Nîmes and died in Rome in 1699. He made many religious paintings including this one discovered in the attics of the presbytery of the church of St-LOuvert all the year of Plan d'Orgon. After expertise, the canvas was restored by Mr. De Grasset. Also called "the crowning of thorns" this painting is dated 1650 and would belong to a series of four paintings on the theme of passion.

label: Parc des Ateliers SNCF
description:
Formerly the workshops of the PLM Company
The SNCF workshops in Arles occupy an important place in the history of French railways. This is an old site, dating back to the first years of the development of the rail network in France  this important site illustrates the installations of one of the most symbolic rail companies, the Paris Lyon-Méditerranée, and is an exciting testimony to the creation of this company, as each merger of preceding companies left a mark on the development of the eleven hectares dedicated to it. The original constructions, as they were in 1856, included:
- a machine workshop (manufacture and repair),
- a carriage workshop,
- a truck workshop, and
- a machine depot.
The Grande Halle was one of the largest of the old Workshops and used to house the boiler works. This activity required major handling equipment, for example for lifting locomotive boilers, which explains the size of the building and its equipment on overhead gantry cranes. In its current location, it was used from the middle of the century. An initial building housed the forges and, from the 1860s-1870s, was used as the boiler works and for the tender workshops (western part of the current building). Engine sheds, used for the trains to manoeuvre, were built towards the east, by the side of the racks. The external restoration of the Grande Halle was carried out and financed by the PACA Region. The architects responsible for the project were Henri Rivière and Alain Moatti. Its inauguration on 5 October 2007 drew large crowds.

label: Ermitage Saint Jean du Puy
comment: The Ermitage Saint-Jean-du-Puy, dating from the Vᵉ century, was a high religious place of the territory. It offers the most beautiful view of the valley and the Sainte-Victoire. A natural site with a historical and picturesque character, it is an ideal place for nature lovers.
shortDescription: The Ermitage Saint-Jean-du-Puy, dating from the Vᵉ century, was a high religious place of the territory. It offers the most beautiful view of the valley and the Sainte-Victoire. A natural site with a historical and picturesque character, it is an ideal place for nature lovers.
description:
Arriving at the chapel, located on one of the peaks of the Olympus chain, one enjoys the most beautiful view of the Upper Arc Valley and the Sainte Victoire Mountain. There is the hermitage, the common house, the vault of the Chapelle Sainte-Elisabeth and the bell tower with its orientation table.

The Ermitage Saint-Jean-du-Puy and its chapel were founded in the Vᵉ century, during the extramural extension of the Abbey of Saint-Victor de Marseille by Saint-Cassien, on the site of an ancient pagan temple probably dedicated to the goddess Diana. It was occupied by Cassianite monks until the XVᵉ century, then by hermits until the Revolution, when the site was sold as national property and its occupants were driven out
The inhabitants of Trets then become owners of a place that is dear to them.
The hermits will come back and will frequent the site until 1891, then the place will be abandoned and will fall in ruin

The term Cassianite comes from the name of John Cassian, a holy man. "Fathers of the Latin Church", he is at the origin of the Hermitage of Saint-Jean du Puy and deeply marked the beginnings of the Church in Provence in the Vᵉ century. In 415, he founded two monasteries in Marseille, Saint-Victor for men and Saint-Sauveur for women. He left an important doctrinal work, including works dedicated to monastic life, which had a profound influence in the West, especially because of their inclusion in the Rule of Saint-Benoît.

At 658 metres above sea level, at the top of a rocky peak, stands a bell tower resembling a watchtower or observatory overlooking the entire valley.
On November 16, 1779, during a violent thunderstorm, lightning struck the bell tower and
this one was partially destroyed. The date of 1828 would indicate its reconstruction.

The chapel dedicated to St. Elizabeth is said to be the work of the inhabitants of St. Zechariah. It has long since been disused and its vault, the only remnant still visible, has been fitted out to make a fire without risk.

This place has been managed since 1960 by the association "Les Amis de Saint-Jean-du-Puy". The keys to the refuge are available for people wishing to spend a night there.
It is therefore an ideal place for nature lovers and families who wish to have lunch there and relax while enjoying a magnificent panorama of the Sainte-Victoire and Sainte-Baume mountains

On April 20, 1938, Saint-Jean-du-Puy was classified: "Site and natural monument of artistic, historical, scientific, legendary and picturesque character".
Traditional pilgrimage on May 1st. Restricted access during the summer period.

label: Golfe de Fos
comment: The Gulf of Fos is a Mediterranean coastline located between the Rhone Delta and the Etang de Berre.
shortDescription: The Gulf of Fos is a Mediterranean coastline located between the Rhone Delta and the Etang de Berre.
description:
It is both a protected coastline with natural landscapes (in its Camargue part) and an industrialized and port area (on the Etang de Berre side).

An exotic hiking experience due to the proximity of the 2 landscape identities.

label: Médiathèque des Carmes
comment:
The entrance to the library and the consultation on the spot are free.
The whole team of the Médiathèque Les Carmes is happy to welcome you.
shortDescription:
The entrance to the library and the consultation on the spot are free.
The whole team of the Médiathèque Les Carmes is happy to welcome you.
description:
Built on the site of a former convent, this 3000 m2 media library is the first in France to offer a place for digital experimentation, a collaborative work space and adapted collections (tactile and Braille books).

Come and discover :
-60,000 documents on loan (books, records, DVDs)
-a digital fabrication laboratory (fablab)
-a space dedicated to teenagers,
-a youth center with a space reserved for parents,
-an exhibition gallery
-a rotunda dedicated to sound and image
-an auditorium with 100 seats
-a co-working space

Over the centuries, the site has housed a convent, a theater and businesses, before being purchased in 2002 by the Communauté du Pays d'Aix. After more than three years of work, the media library was inaugurated on September 8, 2017, welcoming more than 3,000 visitors for the occasion. Spread over more than 3,000 square meters, this new cultural hub of the Val de Durance, intended for more than 50,000 inhabitants, is the first media library in France that offers a place for digital experimentation, a collaborative work space and adapted collections (tactile and Braille books).

Free parking nearby:
-Vigne-Dévalade (628 spaces): rue de la Dévalade
-Grand Cros (198 spaces): chemin du Grand Cros

The spaces of the Les Carmes media library
-60 000 documents on loan (books, records, DVD)
-a digital fabrication laboratory (fablab)
-a space dedicated to teenagers,
-a youth center with a space reserved for parents,
-an exhibition gallery
-a rotunda dedicated to sound and image
-an auditorium with 100 seats
-a co-working space

label: Plage de Fontsainte
description: Pebble beach (Sand in the water). Car park nearby. Restaurants, Accommodation. Admitted dogs.

label: Basilique le Sacré-Coeur
comment: The construction of the Sacred Heart church dates from 1920 by T. Dupoux. Because it was not completed, the lack of finishing touches gave it a more modernist style than the Romanesque-Byzantine one that was initially planned.
shortDescription: The construction of the Sacred Heart church dates from 1920 by T. Dupoux. Because it was not completed, the lack of finishing touches gave it a more modernist style than the Romanesque-Byzantine one that was initially planned.
description:
To see: the Pietà by Botinelly, the stained glass windows by Pinta, and more generally its sumptuous decoration. 
The case and the instrumental part are by Laval Thivolle (1988) and have reused some elements of the Haerpfer organ of Saint-Charles d'Alger.
Parish priest: Jean-Pierre Ellul. Masses: Saturday at 7:00 pm, Sunday at 8:00 am, 9:30 am, 11:00 am, 7:00 pm, weekdays at 7:00 am, 8:30 am, 7:00 pm, and at 4:00 pm on Friday. Reception in the basilica from Monday to Friday from 9:15 am to 12 pm and from 3:30 pm to 6:30 pm.

label: Le moulin de Pallières
comment: Perched on a rock overlooking the town of Les Pennes Mirabeau, the Pallières windmill, with its brand-new sails, has now been restored to its past glory. It is one of the many windmills that once stood on the hills of the old village.
shortDescription: Perched on a rock overlooking the town of Les Pennes Mirabeau, the Pallières windmill, with its brand-new sails, has now been restored to its past glory. It is one of the many windmills that once stood on the hills of the old village.
description:
The Pallières windmill, named after the plot of land where it was built, dates from the 18th century. It stopped working between 1862 and 1866, the date of the last census. No millers were listed in Les Pennes Mirabeau after that time. The monument became a symbol of the town, but was gradually abandoned until the first restoration work in 1982.
Then, in 2019, a complete renovation was launched. Now it is once again a living monument with a miller at the helm. He makes flour for the village's organic bakery. The flour is also on sale at the tourist information office.

Come and see the only working windmill in the Marseille metropolitan area producing flour all the year round! 
During your visit, the miller will tell you how the windmill works, how the wheat arrives in the flour bolter and how the shaft turns the mill wheel, and will point out all the mechanical elements in the process before the flour ends up in the sacks. Not forgetting the compass rose decorating the wall inside the building.

Sale of flour made at the windmill.

label: La Penelle ou Pennelus
comment: La Penelle would be a mausoleum, or more exactly a rural "pile".
shortDescription: La Penelle would be a mausoleum, or more exactly a rural "pile".
description: The Pennelus: a mausoleum with a hollow pyramid-shape, a classified monument dating from the 1st century after J.C.

label: Ferme pédagogique du Roy d'Espagne
comment: Objective of the farm: to make children aware of and responsible for their environment through the observation of plants and domestic animals.
shortDescription: Objective of the farm: to make children aware of and responsible for their environment through the observation of plants and domestic animals.
description:
Activities: discovery of the rural world and farm work: animal care, vegetable garden, gardening

Topics covered: the adaptation of living beings to their environment, the interdependence of living beings, the milk circuit, etc.

Public: large kindergarten sections, primary schools, leisure centres. Reception free of charge (transport remains the responsibility of the visitors), exclusively by appointment (registration at the end of the school year for the following year, or at the very beginning of the year at the latest)

Half-day or full-day sessions, single visit or follow-up.

Visits to the general public are offered to the general public upon registration by email during the school holidays.

label: Orgue de l'église réformée évangélique
description:
The organ was installed in the church in 1892 and was built by Mader. The case is from the time of Louis XVI, while the instrumental part is of unknown origin.


Both the case and the instrumental part are listed historic monuments.

label: Médiathèque municipale Albert Camus
comment: Pennes Mirabeau Municipal Media Library
shortDescription: Pennes Mirabeau Municipal Media Library
description: Reference library

label: Basse Vallée de la Durance
comment: This protected territory of 6088 ha extends from Jouques to Orgon, along the Durance (river separating the Vaucluse from the Bouches-du-Rhône).
shortDescription: This protected territory of 6088 ha extends from Jouques to Orgon, along the Durance (river separating the Vaucluse from the Bouches-du-Rhône).
description: 6,088 ha of protected land.

label: Les Goudes
comment:
Les Goudes 
Located to the south-east of the city, Les Goudes is the last little "village" of Marseille before Callelongue and the succession of coastal fjords known as the "Massif des Calanques".
shortDescription:
Les Goudes 
Located to the south-east of the city, Les Goudes is the last little "village" of Marseille before Callelongue and the succession of coastal fjords known as the "Massif des Calanques".
description: With its still-active fishing port, Les Goudes is a wonderful little quarter, packed with the typical character of Marseille – suffice to say that it is besieged by holidaymakers and weekenders in summer! Featuring a little cove where you can swim and sunbathe, footpaths leading to the Massif de Marseilleveyre hills, flat rocks where you can chill out in the sunshine, and bars and restaurants with fairytale views over Tiboulen, Maïre and Riou islands, Les Goudes has everything you need to spend a magical moment in both winter and summer. Traffic can get very heavy in peak season and you can expect traffic jams in the evening when people head back from the beaches, but, generally speaking, Les Goudes remains a haven of peace.

label: Cours Foch
description: Ex Cours Legrand, cours Maréchal Foch since 1919, it was built on the former right bank of the Huveaune river. On the site of the Monoprix, there was a tannery. The Cours Maréchal Foch has always been the central square where the great events of Aubagne take place. The Monument to the Dead of the Great War is the work of the sculptor Henri Reybaud and the architect Castel. It was inaugurated in 1922. Listed monument

label: Eglise Notre Dame de l'Annonciation
comment: The Church of Our Lady of the Annunciation is made up of a central nave (1742), the Chapel of the Settlers (ND du Rosaire: 16th c) and the Sepulchral Chapel of Forbin-Janson (Chapel of the Holy Spirit: 1615)
shortDescription: The Church of Our Lady of the Annunciation is made up of a central nave (1742), the Chapel of the Settlers (ND du Rosaire: 16th c) and the Sepulchral Chapel of Forbin-Janson (Chapel of the Holy Spirit: 1615)
description: The church has exceptional acoustics. Its baroque decoration is the work of Abbot Cazin, an artist and man of faith.

label: Bibliothèque municipale Victor Gélu
description:
Registration is made on presentation of the following documents: proof of address (EDF, telephone), an identity card.
The borrowing of books is free, the video library is subject to the payment of an annual subscription of 15 €.
Possibility to consult the internet.

label: Chapelle des Pénitents Noirs - Sainte Anne
comment: From the Esquiros Square, which has been completely rehabilitated, you can see the beautiful stone façade of the Chapel, with its characteristic pediment in the architecture of the Counter-Reformation.
shortDescription: From the Esquiros Square, which has been completely rehabilitated, you can see the beautiful stone façade of the Chapel, with its characteristic pediment in the architecture of the Counter-Reformation.
description:
On the completely refurbished Esquiros Square, we can see the beautiful stone facade of the Chapel, with its characteristic front wall in the architecture of the Counter-Reformation.
The Chapel was set up from 1630 for the brotherhood of Black Penitents. But, this Chapel was too big for the small community and the Black Penitents had to get into debt to continue the building which was, finally, finished in 1656.
Seized as a National asset under the French Revolution, it was sold in September, 1791.
It was converted in prison during the federalist period, then passed by diverse hands before being acquired by Brunet Priest who installed Sainte-Anne's brotherhood.

label: Oratoire Sainte Philomène
description:
The Oratory of St. Philomena is the only votive oratory dedicated to this saint, protector of small children and nannies.
It was built in the 16th century.

label: Maison du Parc Naturel Régional de Camargue
description:
This center is a point of information aiming at sensitizing a broad public on the protection of the environment of the Camargue. For this reason, the human and natural activities implemented to safeguard this protected environment are presented. A huge bay window allows you to observe the birds in their natural biotope.
Surface of the permanent exhibition : 100
Surface of the temporary exhibition : 400

label: Eglise Saint-Joseph
comment: St. Joseph's parish church, with a basilica plan, was consecrated in 1855 by St. Eugene de Mazenod.
shortDescription: St. Joseph's parish church, with a basilica plan, was consecrated in 1855 by St. Eugene de Mazenod.
description:
The baptistery, located in the second chapel on the right, evokes the façade of a temple, with four columns, a pediment decorated with a mosaic representing Noah's Ark, and in its centre, the cupboard with holy oils. At the top of the vault, the dove symbolizes the Spirit of God.

The case and the instrumental part are by Cavaillé Coll (1868), who reused pipes from Callinet's old instrument. Restorations and modifications by Mader, Vignolo and Merklin.Tribune designed by Espérandieu. The buffet and the instrumental part are classified as historical monuments.
Reception from 10h to 12h and from 16h to 18h. Priest: Xavier Maurin. Weekday mass Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday at 11.30 am. Mass on Sundays at 10.30 am.

label: Place du Forum
description:
This Place, in the heart of town, has always symbolised meetings and exchanges. In Antiquity the square was next to the main forum (late 1st century BC), and the economic and political centre of the Roman administration; in the Middle Ages it became the main centre for commercial transactions. It is now known as one of the most social areas in town. Locals and tourists rub shoulders under the patronage of a number of well-known figures such as Vincent Van Gogh and Frédéric Mistral.
On the Place du Forum, the solitary painter Vincent Van Gogh began or completed his journey amidst the night-owls. He put his easel down there one evening in 1888.
Towns can be beautiful at night. Vincent Van Gogh found Arles beautiful, as he did the intense colours of the countryside in spring ('this yellow sea') and the deep sky during the day.
He stayed on Place Lamartine, but travelled throughout the town during his short stay. The night-life took place in the cafes and cabarets, where he met the few acquaintances we know about.

label: Le Parc de l'Olivier (Miouvin)
comment: On the outskirts of Istres, below the Route de Miramas, this park, developed by the town is home to a wide variety of fauna and flora, a vegetable garden, an orchard and several biotopes including hedges, meadows and marshes.
shortDescription: On the outskirts of Istres, below the Route de Miramas, this park, developed by the town is home to a wide variety of fauna and flora, a vegetable garden, an orchard and several biotopes including hedges, meadows and marshes.
description:
The 13-hectare space is ideal for raising awareness about the environment amongst young people.
The Olivier Park also has a lovely shaded area under the trees where you can relax. Picnic tables, benches and bins are available. 
A dinosaur plant! 
While strolling through the park, from March to October, you will see a surprising plant: the horsetail. Present on Earth for more than 250 million years, it can reach 50 centimetres in height. Herbivore dinosaurs loved it! Today, this plant is used for its medicinal properties.

label: Château de Gueidan
description:
Opposite the Four Towers pavilion, was built at the end of the 17th century the castle of Gueidan, whose facade was refurbished in 1734 by Franque for Gaspard de Gueidan.
This building is nowadays occupied by the Civil Security Application School.
Open days during the Heritage Days.

label: Bibliothèque Méjanes - Deux Ormes
comment: Located in a former bastide, in the western districts of the town, the Deux Ormes library, an annex of the Méjanes library, offers free access to an encyclopaedic collection of books, magazines, newspapers and audio CDs.
shortDescription: Located in a former bastide, in the western districts of the town, the Deux Ormes library, an annex of the Méjanes library, offers free access to an encyclopaedic collection of books, magazines, newspapers and audio CDs.
description:
Located in an old mansion, in the western districts of the city, the library, annex of the Méjanes library offers free access, an encyclopaedic collection of books, magazines, newspapers and audio CDs.

A specific children fund is being developed: collection of albums and room for toddlers.

label: Fontaine des Fontêtes
comment: Fonteto, a Provençal word translated into French as fontêtes, means small fountains. In the Middle Ages, and until 1676, the square, with many houses nearby, had numerous springs of water. Several wells were therefore built there, giving rise to the plural name of small fountains, or fontêtes.
shortDescription: Fonteto, a Provençal word translated into French as fontêtes, means small fountains. In the Middle Ages, and until 1676, the square, with many houses nearby, had numerous springs of water. Several wells were therefore built there, giving rise to the plural name of small fountains, or fontêtes.
description:
In 1676 the square was paved and the various wells were grouped together to form a single one. However, the development of water technology, and Vallon's plans for the Sextius Baths, meant that the well was not used by the people after 1715.

In 1858 the municipality decided to build a fountain using the Pinchinats water on the site of the former well.

The Fontêtes fountain was named to commemorate the past of its location.

The cube-shaped block of Calissane stone stands in a circular basin and has a gargoyle on each side: two lions' muzzles and two cherubs' heads. Each motif is placed in an arcature surmounted with a wreath of roses.

At the top of the pedestal, a statue of a young Triton sits astride a turtle and blows a horn, free and peaceable. This is actually a replica of the original, made in 1988 (after a theft), by the School of Engineering, always loyal to the fountains of Aix. 

Note, however, that the new Triton is already missing an arm…

label: D' hier et d' aujourd'hui
comment: Today, the town has a heritage from this period that we invite you to discover.
shortDescription: Today, the town has a heritage from this period that we invite you to discover.
description:
In the heart of the village, enveloped in a sea air and perfumed, this walk takes you through the history of Sausset, between Mediterranean landscapes, coastline, alleys and typical houses with unique atmospheres.
Sausset of yesteryear and today, taken at certain identifiable points in the town.

label: Calanque du Petit Nid
comment: The beach of Petit Nid de Sausset les Pins is located in the cove of the same name on the road to La Couronne (D45) in a large bend towards La Couronne.
shortDescription: The beach of Petit Nid de Sausset les Pins is located in the cove of the same name on the road to La Couronne (D45) in a large bend towards La Couronne.
description:
This beach is largely made up of pebbles and is located in a small sheltered bay. The environment is pleasant even if the road is close by. Free parking is available. Out of season this beach is very popular with divers looking for sea urchins.
By the CD 49 towards the Crown.

label: Parc de La Rode
comment: Created on land won on the pond of Berre, it offers a privileged view on the pond, the Sainte Victoire, the rocks of Jaï and the forest of Escourillon, thanks in particular to 3 axes whose well is the point of departure.
shortDescription: Created on land won on the pond of Berre, it offers a privileged view on the pond, the Sainte Victoire, the rocks of Jaï and the forest of Escourillon, thanks in particular to 3 axes whose well is the point of departure.
description:
1.5 ha decorated with plane trees, Micocouliers, pines, stroll along the pond and relaxation area.

Also discover the two giant sculptures by Bernar Venet installed in 2019: “Two indeterminate lines” and “9 Oblique lines” rise majestically towards the sky.
The last cities to have been able to exhibit such pieces are none other than New York, San Francisco, Beijing, Berlin, Paris or even Tokyo.

label: Statue Saint Esteve
description:
It is not possible to evoke the history of Plan d'Orgon without stopping in front of the gates of the St Estève castle. "Le plan de St Estève" was the name of a part of the area that would become "Le plan d'Orgon".
This hunting lodge built in the 17th century was to become a castle in the 18th century, a meeting place for many celebrities.
Originally from Tavel, the Parrocel family came to settle at Château St Estève in the early 18th century.
Today this castle is a private domain

label: Arènes Titi Boncoeur
comment: Surface area: 1106 m2. Camargue races, abrivados. 1800 seats. The bullring was built in 1977.
shortDescription: Surface area: 1106 m2. Camargue races, abrivados. 1800 seats. The bullring was built in 1977.
description: Surface: 1,106m2. Camargue races, abrivados. 1,800 places. The arenas were built in 1977.

label: Viaduc ferroviaire de Caronte
comment: This art work built on the Marseille Miramas railway line was commissioned in October 1915 at the opening of the line.
shortDescription: This art work built on the Marseille Miramas railway line was commissioned in October 1915 at the opening of the line.
description:
With a length of 943 m, it crosses the Caronte canal located between the pond of Berre and the Mediterranean Sea. 
Dynamite in August 1944 by the Germans, it is rebuilt almost identically between 1952 and 1954. 

By opening, the bridge releases a navigable channel 43 m wide. When closed, the movable span is 23 m high allowing the passage of large boats.

label: Primatiale Saint Trophime
description:
Date: 12th and 15th centuries
Era: Middle Ages
Type: Religious architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles and listed as a national Historic Monument in 1840 and a UNESCO World Heritage Site in1981
The Christian community of Arles was one of the first in Gaul, with the presence of a Bishop documented in 254.
Furthermore, for a while Arles Cathedral had the status of Primatial Church of the Gauls and remained the site of an Archbishopric until the Revolution. It is currently a parish church.
Originally located near the ancient rampart of L'Hauture, the cathedral was moved close to the old Roman forum around the 5th century.
It was built in several stages and the majority of the monument we see today dates from the 12th century, when its originally sombre façade was accentuated with its magnificent historiated statues.
The building is one of the largest in Romanesque Provence.
It is also a church of relics on the Way of St James. A Gothic chancel has replaced the 15th century Romanesque apses. 
The monument was erected in several stages.
It has the characteristic layout of Provençal buildings: a high nave with five broken barrel vaulted bays, flanked by narrow side-aisles and a very short transept whose cross is surmounted by a cupola and supports the bell tower.
The chancel had a main apse and two absidioles.
To the west, a sumptuously decorated portal completes the layout.
Finally, a long Gothic chevet with ambulatory and radiating chapels replaced the old Romanesque chancel in the mid-15th century.
The portal, dedicated to Judgement Day, is also faithfully reproduced model and an illustration of the glories of Arles Church.
The composition superposes three main themes: the assembly of patron saints, the Divine Epic and the Human Epic, from the Fall to the future fate of the chosen ones and the damned.
The composition culminates in the solemn, triumphal image of Christ. The dominant feature of this magnificent work is the extent of its ancient inspiration; its Roman cultural heritage is a symbol of a real 'renaissance'.

label: Lavoir
comment: Also called the Old Mill washhouse.
shortDescription: Also called the Old Mill washhouse.
description: A small double basin. Recent restoration.

label: Villa Camoin
comment: The Villa Camoin, built at the beginning of the 20th century, marks the development of bourgeois architecture in Marignane.
shortDescription: The Villa Camoin, built at the beginning of the 20th century, marks the development of bourgeois architecture in Marignane.
description:
Located at 3 avenue Jean Jaurès, the Villa Camoin occupies a plot of the former park of the Covet castle, which was devoted to the large vegetable garden from the Middle Ages until around 1700

Built at the beginning of the 20th century, this villa, like its three other counterparts in Marignane, marks the development of a bourgeois architecture that is half country house and half private mansion along the old road to Aix

It still bears the name of the family that founded it on part of the former seigniorial park, reconstituted on the land and cadastral plan in 1900 by the acquisitions of Léonard Alphonse Camoin, known as "le Terrible" (1840-1910). A legendary angry farmer and pig farmer born in the hamlet of Laure in Gignac, he succeeded in transforming this ancestral activity into an international trade thanks to the establishment, from 1890 onwards, of the slaughterhouses in the bastide of Tron. It was this mansion, turned towards the countryside and entirely rebuilt in the taste of the Belle Epoque (today private property that cannot be visited), that inspired the construction of the urban version of the Villa Camoin by his son Félicien Philippe (1867-1936). After his father's death, he bought the shares of his two brothers and began work on the future villa in 1915 on a marshy plot of land halfway between soil and garden. Oral tradition attributes the construction to the mason Joseph Louis Marie Jauffret (1869 - before 1934) of Berroise origin, who had settled in Marignane since his marriage in 1901, probably based on the plans of an unidentified architect

In 1956, the son of Félicien Philippe Camoin, Léonard Alphonse Pierre (1897-1976), sold his park to the municipality, which built the Camoin Park real estate complex, while the house remained in the family domain until its acquisition by the Caisse d'Epargne in 1975. It still houses a branch

Despite the almost total disappearance of the old garden (mentioned in the recent development of the Salvador Dali garden) and the entrance courtyard overlooking the avenue, its architectural qualities can be appreciated from all sides

The villa adopts a quasi-square plan and rises on two levels magnified by a facade of cut stone, chosen for the fineness and luminosity of the shell limestone used. A balcony with a rich sculpted balustrade, resting on elaborate brackets, highlights the main floor. The classical order is respected, superimposing bosses and sober ornaments on the first floor, more detailed and decorative on the upper floor, such as the pediment stamped with cut leather, laurel branches and shell. The ironwork railings displaying the entire plant repertoire of Art Nouveau truly inscribe the building in this stylistic trend of the years 1900-1914. A discreet touch of polychromy enlivens the composition through six sky-blue enamelled half-spheres punctuating the brackets and the lintel under the pediment. The ridge of the roof allows the ornamentation to take flight, all in terra cotta, consisting of a crest of serrated and openwork panels flanked by two bulbous finials. A western addition invites you to turn around the villa in order to guess the southern facade, more sober but evoking this opening on the intimacy of the terrace and of the old English garden originally designed. A part of the original marshland had been preserved. On the other side, it faces the Villa Paradis, which the similarity invites us to attribute to the same designers and craftsmen, probably also at work on the façade of the Cercle de la Renaissance dated 1909.

Source Patrick Varrot, art historian - February 2021

label: Musée Automobile de Provence
comment:
The summary of a century of automotive history through different eras.
Sports and popular cars, motorcycles and bicycles of all ages.
shortDescription:
The summary of a century of automotive history through different eras.
Sports and popular cars, motorcycles and bicycles of all ages.
description:
Nestled between the Alpilles and the Luberon is a collection just waiting to be discovered. A round-up of a century of automotive history through the different eras of this fabulous epic story... sporting and popular models of all ages share this space with bicycles, motorcycles, posters from the time and other unusual items. Artifice is not necessary in the Provence Automobile Museum, as passion alone drives this sanctuary of mechanics. The museum also has a range of spare parts and exhibition sales vehicles.
Open Monday to Saturday from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m.

label: Musée du Vieil Aix - Hôtel Estienne de Saint-Jean
comment: The Estienne de Saint-Jean private mansion, which become the museum of old Aix in 1932, is the town's history museum.
shortDescription: The Estienne de Saint-Jean private mansion, which become the museum of old Aix in 1932, is the town's history museum.
description:
The museum was founded by Marie d'Estienne de Saint-Jean. The collections created thanks to her numerous donations retrace the history and traditions of Aix-en-Provence.

The collections, made up of furniture, earthenware, traditional figurines, objects from craft guilds and puppets from the talking nativity scene, a popular 19th century show, give us a real insight into the life of Aix's inhabitants.
