Some rare pieces can be discovered, such as the screen from the Corpus Christi procession, which evokes a very old tradition celebrated for many years, a modello by G. B. Gaulli, a model of his project for the baptistery of Saint Peter's in Rome, an exceptional piece of 17th century Italian art, or the 'Annunciation' by Barthélémy d'Eyck (one of the painters of the Roy René), a central panel of a 15th century triptych, the other two panels of which can be seen at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam or at the Museum of Fine Arts of Belgium.

label: Montaiguet, Collines de Gardanne
comment: The Massif du Montaiguet forms a small semi-circular massif, standing shoulder-to-shoulder with Aix-en-Provence to the northwest and the town of Gardanne to the southeast. It is delimited to the North and East by the A8 highway, to the South by the RD6 road and to the West by the RN8 road.
shortDescription: The Massif du Montaiguet forms a small semi-circular massif, standing shoulder-to-shoulder with Aix-en-Provence to the northwest and the town of Gardanne to the southeast. It is delimited to the North and East by the A8 highway, to the South by the RD6 road and to the West by the RN8 road.
description:
This hill-shaped massif, oriented northeast / southwest, is carved with numerous northwesterly facing valleys, situated between Vallée de l’Arc and the Gardanne catchment area. It comprises chalky plateaux bordered by cliffs, plus several dips where crops grow. It rises to an altitude of 346 metres and its lowest point is situated to the North, at just 145 metres.

Part of Provence's coastal climate zone, the Massif du Montaiguet benefits from a typical Mediterranean climate, with prevailing Mistral winds due to its orientation. …

Montaiguet forms part of the small, natural region of Bassin de l’Arc. It is fairly thinly forested (50 %), with mainly dense and irregular populations of Aleppo pines mixed with evergreen oaks and durmast oaks on the North-facing slopes and in the valleys. The areas previously devastated by forest fires (in particular those of 1979 and 2005) are mainly covered with garrigue and re-planted trees.

Bordered by several urban centres (Aix-en-Provence, Gardanne, Luynes and Bouc-Bel-Air), the fringe areas and even central areas of the Massif du Montaiguet are relatively densely populated further to the extension of peri-urban business parks and ever-increasing social demand on woodland. However, the multiplication of individual houses in the massif appears to have stabilized in the last twenty years or so. 

This massif is coveted for both its scenery and sporting opportunities, in particular by the inhabitants of Aix-en-Provence, but it also suffers from the effects of human activity. Montaiguet is of ornithological interest, with the presence of three remarkable species: the eagle owl, the common scops owl and the little owl.

The Collines de Gardanne (Gardanne Hills) form a small massif (5,800 acres) situated in the eastern half of the Bouches-du-Rhône region, to the southeast of Aix-en-Provence, between the Arbois, Sainte-Victoire, Regagnas and Etoile chains.

It comprises a set of hills of low average altitude and with gentle slopes. …

Average temperatures are fairly warm, but vary pretty widely throughout the year, with frequent frosts in winter and intense heat in summer. Rainfall ranges from around 600-700 mm/year. Although it is not exactly aligned with the Rhône valley, the Collines de Gardanne massif is frequently swept by the Mistral wind.

Forming part of the small natural region of Bassin de l’Arc, the massif is densely forested (74%) despite its high urban development, with 80 % Aleppo pines, plus around 20% evergreen oaks and rare garrigue.

label: Eglise Saint-Louis
comment: The construction of this church by Sourdeau is due to the strong population growth at the beginning of the century.
shortDescription: The construction of this church by Sourdeau is due to the strong population growth at the beginning of the century.
description: It is built on a centred plan and there is a great use of concrete (monumental statues) and reinforced concrete (beams and pillars). To see: the wrought iron chandelier and the Way of the Cross by M.Ferrière, and two monumental paintings by Victor Vasarely (1906-1997) exhibited since September 2005 (loan from the city of Charenton-le-Pont). Works conceived as a diptych: Christ (5.66 x 3.24 m) and Saint Peter (5.73 x 3.10 m).

label: Relais nature Saint-Joseph
comment: Next to the Grand Seminary park, the Saint Joseph nature center covers 7,000 square meters: it includes an educational garden, an orchard, a greenhouse, a small wooded area and several activity rooms.
shortDescription: Next to the Grand Seminary park, the Saint Joseph nature center covers 7,000 square meters: it includes an educational garden, an orchard, a greenhouse, a small wooded area and several activity rooms.
description:
The themes of the activities are recycling and waste recovery, biodiversity, food and garden.

Public events, such as open days, are organized from time to time.

label: Presbytère de Pélissanne
description:
It dates from 1842 and was built in place of an oil mill.
Note the neo-classical style entrance door: the two Doric pilasters that frame the door are topped by a dentilled cornice and a baluster decorated with carved balls.

label: Chapelle Notre-Dame de Nazareth
comment: It is Romanesque-Provençal in style and faces East-West. The present porch dates from the 16th century.
shortDescription: It is Romanesque-Provençal in style and faces East-West. The present porch dates from the 16th century.
description:
It is Romanesque-Provençal in style and faces east-west. The present porch dates from the 16th century. The present square bell tower was built in the 16th century, when it replaced the bells on the gable wall in a wall-belfry on the west side when the church was extended.
The wooden arrow was replaced by a cupola in 1820 following lightning damage. The old bell was blessed in 1820 and replaced in 1925.  It was cast by the "Toussaint Maurel workshops".
The cross, on the North-East façade a large mission cross, recalling the one preached in 1840. The tin hat has been replaced by a small tile construction.
At the back of the choir is a gilded wooden statue of Our Lady Of Nazareth dating from the 17th century.

label: Arènes
comment: Barbentane Arena.
shortDescription: Barbentane Arena.
description: Barbentane Arena.

label: Statue de la Vierge dorée
comment: Statue of the Virgin.
shortDescription: Statue of the Virgin.
description: Statue raised in the nineteenth century (1867) on the occasion of a Mission on the heights of the town, at the top of the peak Chabaud. The mission was decided by Fr. Louis Alexis, then the parish priest.The order of the statue was placed to vine of Lyon institutions, based on a model created to Lourdes by Joseph Fabisch. It took all the energy of the men, the Carters and horses, to bring the 1860 kg of the statue at the top of the Hill.Installed on a base of stone, it culminates ten meters of height. On the pedestal of the statue you had engraved the inscription: "Posueront me custodem" (they have established their guardian).The statue is located at the site of a calvary of 1844. Way of the cross was rising from the city to the statue.

label: La Croix des Clapiers
comment: This cross is now in the old cemetery. Erected in 1660 in the cemetery south of the church, moved in 1702 and 1873. It bears a quatrain of Charloun Rieu.
shortDescription: This cross is now in the old cemetery. Erected in 1660 in the cemetery south of the church, moved in 1702 and 1873. It bears a quatrain of Charloun Rieu.
description:
This cross is now in the old cemetery. It was originally erected in 1660 in the cemetery to the south of the church and moved in 1702 to the cemetery to the north of the church. The cemetery was moved north again in 1873 and the cross took its present place there. It bears the quatrain of Charloun Rieu:

< Our vow is coming to an end Our journey is coming to an end
Aro es per iéu deman will be perished today for me and for you tomorrow.
Blessed is the soul of Camino. Blessed is the man who walks..
Dins lou draióu de la Virtue! On the path of righteousness>

This cross has a legend: Clapier, Pierre Clapier and Marie Giber had promised to build it. When the husband died, his wife would have forgotten the promise a little.

One day a little girl of the family saw a dove who said to her: "Go and tell your godmother to fulfil her promise to raise a cross in the cemetery and to celebrate masses for the repose of the soul of the poor Hutch, otherwise the horses of the farm will all be struck with a mortal evil". But the widow Clapier waited again, one horse died and then a second one. When the third died, she finally executed her wish!

label: Jardin des Quatre Saisons
comment: A garden composed of four parts representing the four seasons.
shortDescription: A garden composed of four parts representing the four seasons.
description: Designed as a transition between the Montagnette hills and the village of Graveson, it combines relaxation (maze games area for children), animation (round and spacious entrance to accommodate shows) and four parts representing the four seasons where you can stroll or rest. The groves and flowerbeds host rare varieties of local plants to highlight the qualities of each. The alleyways, the perspective, the colour of the flowerbeds and the plant collections offer something for everyone's taste. A national viburnum collection is being created.

label: Arènes Georges Tarascon
comment: Georges Tarascon Municipal Arena.
shortDescription: Georges Tarascon Municipal Arena.
description: Venue for bullfighting and cultural events.

label: Chapelle Sainte Catherine
description: The chapel is at the entrance to the Château des Baux de Provence. Although it was originally dedicated to the Virgin Mary, it has been dedicated to Saint Catherine since the 15th century. The castle chapel was within the surrounding walls which symbolically protect the entrance to the Château, as was common in the Middle Ages. The building set vertically to the small ditch, remains of which can still be seen, was part of the Château; on the first level, that of the courtyard, it housed the castle chapel. The gaps in the cliff reveal the existence of two levels above the chapel. On the third level are clear traces of an opening which crossed the cliff and overlooked a small balcony; to the east this balcony overlooked the entrance to the 'hare hole' and was part of of its defence. On the second level, this building also had an corbel construction projecting over the small ditch. This was also part of the defence system. The 1426 inventory confirmed the existence of a 'chamber' above the chapel, but it seemed to have only a secondary role, as its development was minimal at the time of this inventory. It was very close to the entrance to the small ditch. The castle chapel opened onto the courtyard to the right of the château entrance; it is known as a 'gateway' chapel, as it welcomed visitors as soon as they arrived. However, it could be accessed directly from inside the château. This structure is particularly important for appreciating the size of the mediaeval château, as it is the only one to contain remains of 12th century Romanesque art from the former 'Sainte Marie' chapel. This chapel underwent major restructuring work during the Renaissance, but the original southern wall can still be seen above the facing put in place in the 16th century. The chapel became known as 'Saint Catherine', but it is not known exactly when this happened. The chapel's bell tower had been built at the top of the building, level with the gallery located on the crest of the cliff. It was restructured and now features rows of ribbed vaults with wall arches, liernes and tercerons; however, it still has its Romanesque sculptures, making it the oldest testimony currently visible at the Château des Baux de Provence.

label: Abbaye Saint Michel de Frigolet
description:
Saint Michel de Frigolet Abbey (12th-14th century), in the heart of the unspoilt landscape of La Montagnette, takes its name from the many thyme bushes ('ferigoulo' in Provençal) that dot the hills.
In 1133, a community of St Augustine canons settled in Frigolet; the current heart of the monastery dates from this period - the cloister (early 12th century), Saint Michel Church (12th century) and the small Notre Dame du Bon Remède Chapel (11th century).
The monastery was gradually abandoned in the 15th and 16th centuries, to be occupied once again in the 17th century by monks (the Fathers of Saint Jerome), who rebuilt and embellished the ruined buildings. The chancel of Saint Michel Church was extended and the 17th century Salle du Chapître and the adjoining rooms, with their magnificent stone vault, were added. Notre Dame du Bon Remède Chapel received the wonderful Baroque décor which can still be admired today.
 The Neo-Gothic Abbey which surrounded the Romanesque Chapel of Notre Dame houses 14 canvases by the painter Mignard and is adorned with 17th century woodwork.

label: Eglise de la Transfiguration
comment:
This former 10th-century castral chapel, rebuilt between 1510 and
1526, has a square bell tower surmounted by a small campanile.
shortDescription:
This former 10th-century castral chapel, rebuilt between 1510 and
1526, has a square bell tower surmounted by a small campanile.
description:
Part of its furniture comes from the monastery of Notre-Dame des Anges, located in the Etoile massif, with the oldest santons in Provence, a choir fence and a 17th century carved and gilded wooden bas-relief. There are also two moving statues: a 16th century olive wood Pietà and a 17th century marble Notre Dame des Anges.

Open only during services.

label: Médiathèque AGASC
comment: Media library of Graveson.
shortDescription: Media library of Graveson.
description: During your stay, the library offers you: novels, documentaries, comics for adults and children.

label: Palais Daviel
comment: The Daviel palace, which is the work of the Gerard brothers, was built between 1743 and 1747 on the site of the former courthouse.
shortDescription: The Daviel palace, which is the work of the Gerard brothers, was built between 1743 and 1747 on the site of the former courthouse.
description:
The elegant facade evokes the charm of 18th century Provencal architecture. The sculptures are the work of the artist J.M. Verdiguier. The wrought iron balcony whose decoration says "à la Marguerite" is remarkable.

It now hosts municipal services that are not open to the public.

label: Musée Borély – Musée des Arts décoratifs, de la Faïence et de la Mode
comment: Dated of the  second  half of the 18th century chateau  Borely is emblematic of pleasure homes built  around the city by the  rich families from Marseille thanks to the trade with East (Egypt, Levant scale)
shortDescription: Dated of the  second  half of the 18th century chateau  Borely is emblematic of pleasure homes built  around the city by the  rich families from Marseille thanks to the trade with East (Egypt, Levant scale)
description:
Successful traders settled in Alexandria. Borely held official positions in the service of the King of France. Mostly visited  during, hot season and weekends Borely located in the  district of Bonneveine is  seen as the most beautiful bastide from its construction. Quite rare, the castle still retains much of its original décor  designed by the painter : Louis Chaix, from Aubagne and some of his remarquable : golden  sofa, library, room and chapel.

Sold in 1857, by the last owner, Gaston de Panisse Passis. The Estate subsequently become the  property of the town. Opened to the public in  1863, the castle now houses the archaelogical collections.

Classified as historic monument, fully renovated Borely hosts the Decorative arts and fashion museum. The  guests  will be able to discover the intimacy and the way of  life of an 18 th century family. Visitors will also be able to admire an authentic collection of the 18 th century to nowadays.

To discover : an extraordinary ceramic and glass  collection, furniture, Arts rare exotic object. Furniture, Arts, rare exotic objects, fashion and accessories, the objects will be displayed in period rooms, and fashion in its  study gallery will be shown three times a year. Contemporary works including the large chandelier in the  vestibule especially created by the designer Mathieu Lehanneur are on the entire journey through the  collection.

label: Port Vieux de La Ciotat
description:
We join La Ciotat by the road of crests.La Ciotat is chosen during two years to serve as warehouse of the business of Marseille. The inhabitant of Marseille L. Simpleton realized first workshops of naval construction in 1835. Ciotat possesses beautiful houses of XVIIth s around the port. 
The former City hall, built in 1863 of Renaissance style, dominates the port(bearing) of its high bell tower. It shelters the ciotaden museum. The chapel of penitent blue dates the XVIIth century.

label: Eglise Paroissiale d'Alleins
description: Church built in the 18th century on the former chapel Notre-Dame de l'Annonciade. Inside, it has a nave with three bays oriented North/South. There is a baptismal basin decorated with sculpted cherubs and a Gallo-Greek funerary stele from the 3rd century BC.

label: Monument aux morts
comment: Work of the sculptors Alexandre Magherini and Jacques Martin, winners of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts de Marseille in 1903.
shortDescription: Work of the sculptors Alexandre Magherini and Jacques Martin, winners of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts de Marseille in 1903.
description:
This work dedicated to the Marignanese who died for the Fatherland and the Republic, was born on the Cours Mirabeau, on September 5, 1920, in front of the entrance to the town hall, after some vicissitudes

Indeed, during a town council meeting on March 2, 1919, Mayor Felix Roux and his council, offended by the initiative of an independent patriotic committee to erect a monument to the dead without the approval of the elected officials, decided to vote a subsidy of 1,500 francs to finance the work and thus regain control of the operations
Finally, in a spirit of reconciliation, the mayor, his council and the famous committee joined forces and the monument became a reality after two years of effort

It was entrusted to the sculptors Alexandre Magherini and Jacques Martin, winners of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts de Marseille in 1903. The two students of Emile Aldebert had in fact joined forces after the 1914-1918 war to create numerous monuments to the dead, such as those in Saint-Barnabé, La Valentine and Les Olives in Marseille

The inauguration took place in Marignane in the presence of a young fourteen-year-old war orphan, Juliette Desbant, whose father Emmanuel Desbant was killed at Sénones, on the Vosges front on 7 November 1916. The teenager left a commemorative message sealed in the heart of the monument
The names of the sixty-six victims who fell on the field of honour between 1914 and 1918 have been engraved

In 1950, the work was moved to the esplanade, in front of the current town hall, then transferred in 2014 to the place du 11 Novembre

The four and a half metre high ensemble is designed in the manner of a "victory obelisk" comprising, on the rear side, the national flag, on the upper part in the foreground, the medallion of the helmeted Poilu, framed by four lictor beams, emblems of the unity of the Nation. Under the medallion and on the four sides are the names of those killed in the 1914-1918 war (and then in successive wars), which are honoured and commemorated by an allegory of the town of Marignane crowned with battlements and resting on a shield stamped with the municipal coat of arms.

Source: Jacques Marc Bonatti, municipal archivist - 2020

label: Musée des Arômes et du Parfum
comment: Located near the Alpilles and the Montagnette, near the Baux-de-Provence, near Saint Rémy, the Perfume and Aromas Museum in Graveson-en-Provence takes you to the land of fragrance.
shortDescription: Located near the Alpilles and the Montagnette, near the Baux-de-Provence, near Saint Rémy, the Perfume and Aromas Museum in Graveson-en-Provence takes you to the land of fragrance.
description:
For nearly thirty years now, this magnificent museum of fragrances and aromas has been located in the countryside near Saint Remy and Les Baux - a magical spot full of Provencal fragrances and aromas - an organic garden, the heart of nature. Here you can see an outstanding collection of copper stills. You can stroll through the medicinal and culinary herb garden, you can see the fragrance shop and the courtyard full of old stills. 

You can also take advantage of the special space Espace Aromacocoon for a wonderful well-being session.
streetAddress: ["3213 Ancien chemin d'Arles - Petite Route Du Grès"]

label: Cathédrale Saint-Sauveur
comment: This building, built on the site of the ancient forum and, according to legend, on the foundations of an ancient temple dedicated to the god Apollo, gathers many architectural styles, due to the many alterations it has undergone over the centuries
shortDescription: This building, built on the site of the ancient forum and, according to legend, on the foundations of an ancient temple dedicated to the god Apollo, gathers many architectural styles, due to the many alterations it has undergone over the centuries
description:
The cathedral was built on the site of a temple to Apollo, so the legend goes, between the 5th to the 18th century. 

The variety of its architecture is immediately visible on its frontage: to the right, or south, the 12th-century Romanesque gate adjoins a Roman wall, while to the left (north), the huge, richly carved Gothic gate from the 15th and 16th centuries is surmounted to the north by a bell tower erected between 1323 and 1425.

Inside are three naves of different styles (Romanesque, Gothic and Baroque), which flank the octagonal font which rests on a stand dating back to the 5th century.

Its central basin recalls the ancient rite of baptism by immersion. Crossing the chancel, we reach the cloister, built at the close of the 12th century. 

It is a place which breathes tranquillity and elegance. Small in size, built with solid galleries, while the rich and varied decorations of the pillars are inspired by the animal and plant kingdoms, by fantasy and by the symbols of the evangelists.

As for the organ, the green and gold case was built by Jean-Esprit Isnard in 1745 and the instrumental part by De Ducroquet dates from 1855 both are listed historical monuments. 
The organ was restored by Jean Dunand in 1972.

Wheelchair users wishing to visit the Cathedral should call the Cathédrale Vivante association on 04 42 23 47 40.
streetAddress: ['34 Place Des Martyrs de la Résistance']

label: Eglise Saint-Honorat de Mas-Thibert
description:
Mas-Thibert Church was consecrated in 1857 and dedicated to Saint Honorat. It is the only church in the commune to be built by the architect Henri Révoil.
Mas-Thibert Church changed location three times before moving here.
The building we can see today was constructed in the late 19th century and consecrated in 1900.
It is still used today and houses a number of remarkable relics and statues. A 14th century wooden Christ was discovered there in 1995; it is now at the Réattu Museum in Arles.

label: Propriété Mongolfier et ferme pédagogique La Tour des Pins
comment: Guided tour for all public on reservation (minimum 12 people) (4 euros per child, 5 euros per adult) on Wednesdays from 4pm to 6pm, during the birth period of kids and lambs in February, and during the spring holidays
shortDescription: Guided tour for all public on reservation (minimum 12 people) (4 euros per child, 5 euros per adult) on Wednesdays from 4pm to 6pm, during the birth period of kids and lambs in February, and during the spring holidays
description:
Sale of cheeses, yoghurts, faisselles and eggs, Wednesdays Fridays from 4pm to 6pm.
Workshops for animal care or dairy products, on request from 2 euros to 6 euros per person.

Birthday organization: 2h30 of animation with games, exchange of gifts and snacks brought by the family, then visit and discovery of animals and farm work (minimum 10 children, 8 euros per child).
The farm can welcome groups (all publics), to come and visit the farm and/or the Mongolfier park (12hectares) by appointment.

label: Plage de la Lèque et son parc paysager
comment: La Lèque beach is located at the end of the peninsula between Cap d'Aiguades and the Port le Bouc harbor master's office
shortDescription: La Lèque beach is located at the end of the peninsula between Cap d'Aiguades and the Port le Bouc harbor master's office
description:
Sandy beach of 100m x 20m
About 100 meters of sand for this discreet roadside beach. On both ends, there are rocks. Quite limited charm because of the environment ... On the other hand, it is the most interesting beach in Port de Bouc.
A few parking spaces are available along the road. Unsupervised beach.

label: Le canal de Marseille
comment: Concrete canal built from 1839 to 1854, 80 km long and composed of basins, and numerous technical works (including the Aqueduct of Roquefavour). It starts from Saint Estève Janson, and provides water to the communes up to Marseille.
shortDescription: Concrete canal built from 1839 to 1854, 80 km long and composed of basins, and numerous technical works (including the Aqueduct of Roquefavour). It starts from Saint Estève Janson, and provides water to the communes up to Marseille.
description:
The canal of Marseille collects at the level of Saint Estève Janson, a part of the waters diverted by the EDF canal. With a length of 80 km for its main branch (of which 17 km are underground) and 160 km for its derivations, its vocation is the supply of drinking water to the communes up to Marseille: Lambesc, La Barben, Coudoux, Ventabren, Aix, Cabriès, then Aubagne, Gémenos or Cassis... 

It was built in the middle of the 19th century in about fifteen years under the direction of the engineer Franz Mayor de Montricher. Numerous works (500 in number) were built along its course, the most impressive of which is the Aqueduct of Roquefavour in Ventabren.

label: Bibliothèque Municipale
description:
To register, users must prove their identity and domicile. Any change must be reported
 10 € per family and per year for the inhabitants of the town
- 15 € per person and per year for people living outside the commune
- Free for children with parental permission.

label: Plage Calanque d'En Vau
comment: Pebble cove, framed by high walls of white limestone, bristling with needles and rocky points: the site is extraordinary.
shortDescription: Pebble cove, framed by high walls of white limestone, bristling with needles and rocky points: the site is extraordinary.
description:
The water is crystal clear and fresh. It can be reached on foot (2 GR: 45 minutes and 1h30 from La Gardiole).

This cove is now included in the Calanques National Park.
To know the accessibility of the protected natural areas, between June 1st and September 30th, via a simple phone number, 0 811 20 13 13. (Cost of a local call).
Departure from La Gardiole/GR 98 A: 1h30 on foot. Drop-off of the boat offering the discovery of the creeks from Cassis.

label: L'Hôtel de ville
description: Date: 1676Period: Classical periodType: Public Architecture of the communityStatus: Property of the city of Arles classified as Monument historique (1920)Supervisor: Jacques Peytret and Jules Hardouin-MansartIn the heart of the city, symbol of power and witness of a century of magnificence, the Town Hall masterfully closes the perspective of the place de la République. Completed in 1676, after many studies and a laborious construction, it marks the triumph of classical architecture, inspired especially by Jules Hardouin-Mansart, appointed the same year architect to Louis XIV. It replaces an old common house which stood between the House of the King (former Palace of the Podestà) and the clock tower that the city fathers wanted to keep. The building is particularly admirable by the richness of its decoration, carved in large part by the Arles Jean Davis, and the vault in cradles of his vestibule, technical daring for its time. It is mostly classified Historical Monument, and nonetheless not less headquarters elected officials and a part of the municipal administration.Elevation of the south facade of the Town Hall the Town Hall marks the triumph of the classical style. Raised on three levels, it has a ground floor treated as a base, with a decor of bosses. The first floor, said "noble", has an impressive central backdrop where double columns framing a patio door that opens onto a balcony with stone balustrade. The second floor is dominated by a central pediment containing a Sun, symbol of Louis XIV, decorated with balusters and pots-to-fire. The flat vault of the Hall consists of two perpendicular cradles of unequal widths and eyeglass basket. It falls on both sides of the vestibule on double columns. The departure of the grand staircase that leads to the Council Chamber, is framed by two stone lions carved by Jean Dedieu, Arles sculptor, who made the bulk of the decor, both domestic and external. Part of it disappeared during the French Revolution. The Council Chamber has kept a beautiful setting of woodwork of the eighteenth century directed by Laurent Bondon who also has the ceiling. The medallions which he is dressed, painted by Mahadevan of Cazan, represent the ancient monuments of Arles. Embossed ornaments were executed by Antoine Reynaud. Above the wainscoting are erect pilasters fluted framing trophies. Frames adorning the room are integrated into the woodwork and have paintings by Jean Roche (circa 1920).

label: Arènes
comment: Arena of Graveson.
shortDescription: Arena of Graveson.
description: Shows: bull branding, young bull racing, traditional festivals.

label: Chapelle Saint-Vincent
comment: A fine example of classical Romanesque style, the chapel at the foot of and outside the village was used in the Middle Ages for funeral purposes. Now with two bays (5.10x12.90m), the chapel has lost its original chevet.
shortDescription: A fine example of classical Romanesque style, the chapel at the foot of and outside the village was used in the Middle Ages for funeral purposes. Now with two bays (5.10x12.90m), the chapel has lost its original chevet.
description:
On the outside, the western façade has a semicircular portal topped by a moulded arch. The bases of the gate include Gallo-Roman funerary stelae in reuse, one of which has an inscription of Q. CORNELIUS (in memory of Philocles Cornelius, a freedman of Greek origin belonging to Quintus Cornelius). In the north-west corner there is also a second stele in memory of PEREGRINA MANTRO.
Inside, the chapel is barrel vaulted with a slightly broken barrel vault on a doubleau. Its only decoration consists of two exceptional figurative capitals surmounting the pilasters, representing crowned heads, on a background of acanthus leaves and lion heads.
In the 19th century, the vault was decorated with painted caissons.

label: L'ancien castrum d'Allauch
comment: The old castrum of Allauch was built between 1141 and 1148 on the site of a smaller building erected by the Canons of the Major de Marseille, spiritual and temporal lords of Allauch since about 1121.
shortDescription: The old castrum of Allauch was built between 1141 and 1148 on the site of a smaller building erected by the Canons of the Major de Marseille, spiritual and temporal lords of Allauch since about 1121.
description: The former castrum of Allauch was built on the site of a construction of lesser importance by the canons of the Major in Marseille, lords spiritual and temporal of Allauch since 1121 approximately between 1141 and 1148.Today, this heritage is us through a path down climbing along in Pine Hill. You will discover this ride the square defence tower, oratories, the postern (old gate of the Castle), the chapel "Our Lady of the Castle" and the remains of the ramparts that once surrounded them.The castle was abandoned with the security gradually found at the end of the 15th century. The population moved to the site of the present village.It was destroyed between 1594 and 1596 by the wars of religion at the request of the Marseillais who feared that it falls into the hands of the protestants.

label: Chapelle Notre Dame de la Garde
description:
It was built by the brotherhood of Blue Penitents and dedicated to the Immaculate Conception. It was blessed in 1613.
It was built in the shape of a side cross. Vaults have an ogival style. Frescoes and hall were executed in 1864.
The altar is in marble white from Carrare and supports a very beautiful statue of Notre Dame de la Garde in sculptured and golden oak given by the Blue Penitents in 1630.
Strategic in the navigation of the sailors, the Chapel is completely decorated with the most beautiful marine ex-voto of Provence, presents of the sailors grateful to the Virgin of La Garde.
The chapel opens the summer and symbolically on December 8th in the daytime of the holiday of Immaculate Conception where a pilgrimage is organized.
The chapel was restored a few years ago but its position in front of sea sprays makes it vulnerable.

label: L'église Saint-Pierre
description:
Since 1880, the church has had an unusual inscription on its pediment: République Française-Liberté - Egalité - Fraternité (French Republic - Freedom - Equality - Brotherhood).
The high altar in Russian oak is of Bavarian origin, the hexagonal pulpit in Burgundy oak is of Belgian origin (both classified as historical monuments), the doors, in Vède walnut, are locally made. Also worth seeing are the stained glass windows, including the north rose window, nicknamed L'Oeil de Mouton (The Sheep's Eye), in memory of the parish priest Mouton who had it installed.

label: Musée-bibliothèque Paul Arbaud
comment: The Paul Arbaud museum-library, named after its creator, is situated in the Mazarin quarter, a stone's throw from the Cours Mirabeau
shortDescription: The Paul Arbaud museum-library, named after its creator, is situated in the Mazarin quarter, a stone's throw from the Cours Mirabeau
description:
Paul Arbaud, a scholar, devoted his life to constituting a large collection of objects and books, remarkable in terms of both their quantity and their quality. On his death, he left not only this collection, but also the mansion which housed it, to the Academy of Sciences, Agriculture, Arts and Letters of Aix-en-Provence.

The collection of objects is made up of some wonderful pieces, notably 18th century Provençal earthenware, a 14th century Flemish triptych and Mirabeau family portraits.

The library, with its 1600 manuscripts and books and its collection of private archives (notably those of the Mirabeau family) attracts researchers from a variety of different fields.

Since it opened, the museum-library has received numerous donations which have enabled it to expand its collections, such as that of Lucas de Montigny, who bequeathed a large collection of items related to the Mirabeau family.

label: Les Jardins de l'Espérance
description:
Les Jardins de l’Espérance
The "Jardins de l’Éspérance" association manages a 2-acre educational garden at the entrance to La Ciotat, near the A50 highway exit. Children can come here to learn how to make compost, use gardening tools, sow seeds, prune, graft, discover nature and plants, and learn how to cherish them... Divided into three separate terraces, the garden has also developed a variety of tools and itineraries for the visually-handicapped and disabled, to allow them to make the most of this exceptional environment. Innovations include the "Abécédaire" invented by children: a short walk amid plants with remarkable fragrances and textures. All labels are in braille and the itinerary is suitable for wheelchairs. A wonderful experience for youngsters and older visitors alike.

label: Palais des Podestats
description:
Date: 13th century
Era: Middle Ages
Type: Public communal architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument
From the Plan de la Cour, four buildings, not one, testify to several centuries of communal power. 
The Palais des Podestats, to the right, is the oldest of the buildings. It is Romanesque in style and dates from the 13th century. 
From west to east are the 15th century town hall, the 17th century hôtel de ville and the 16th century belfry
From the Latin potestas (power), in the Middle Ages the podestat designated the head magistrate who ruled the town, in some parts of Italy and the South.
In the history of Arles, the term refers to a turbulent period when the tensions between the different authorities (Counts, Lords and ecclesiastics) were so high that a professional was appointed to administrate the town.
Until the construction of the hôtel de ville and the development of the square to the south, the communal authorities sat and ruled from the Plan de la Cour. 
Today, the Palais des Podestats, like the neighbouring town hall, is occupied by the municipal services.
The seemingly fortified façade still has its crenellations, gun casements, semi-circular double windows and Romanesque porch.
To the left of this façade, it is still possible to see the 'bench of justice', a stone seat where the Count's officials sat to administer oaths and swear to respect the privileges of the town.
In the courtyard, where the buildings were greatly changed during the redevelopment of the municipal offices, it is still possible to see the former prison cells and interesting graffiti on the wall opposite the porch. 
The town hall, the ancestor of the hôtel de ville, was built by the consuls in the 15th century and stands next to the Palais des Podestats on the left. 
Its façade contrasts with the previous one, particularly through the presence of its large lintelled and mullioned windows.

label: Eglise Saint Jacques le Majeur
description:
Built in the castle at the beginning of the 17th century, Les Moines de Saint Victor served the church until 1656. The priory came under the jurisdiction of the archbishop of Aix. In 1659, Cardinal Grimaldi found everything in order in Greasque. At the end of the XVII century it was the parish priest of Le Fuveau who served the parish of Greasque and the church fell into ruin in 1770. It was rebuilt for the first time on that date, then in 1846.
Renovation work was undertaken in 2012.
On Sunday, February 10, 2013, the Greek people came in large numbers to attend the ceremony planned for the inauguration of the renovation of the church in their village.

label: Autel La Coquille
comment: Taurobolic altar dug into the cliff. For many years, the large fluted shell on top of the altar block led pilgrims to Santiago de Compostela to believe that it was a sign showing them which way to go.
shortDescription: Taurobolic altar dug into the cliff. For many years, the large fluted shell on top of the altar block led pilgrims to Santiago de Compostela to believe that it was a sign showing them which way to go.
description:
Taurobolic altar dug into the cliff. For many years, the large fluted shell on top of the altar block led pilgrims to Santiago de Compostela to believe that it was a sign showing them which way to go.
The construction was probably part of a place of worship,, either dedicated to a water divinity (a drainage channel passed nearby under the quarries and joined the Auge stream), or linked to the operation of the quarries (a number of marine fossils can be seen in the local stone, hence the shell design). It is located on the D17 between Paradou and Fontvieille, along an untarred path which leads to a private property, the 'Mas des Taillades'. In the Middle Ages, the site became a landmark for pilgrims on their way to Santiago de Compostela.

label: Le jardin japonais
comment: The Japanese garden named "Un air de Kumamoto" is located in the west of the city, in the Saint-Mitre park. It is located around the Noh theater.
shortDescription: The Japanese garden named "Un air de Kumamoto" is located in the west of the city, in the Saint-Mitre park. It is located around the Noh theater.
description:
The Japanese garden known as "Un Air de Kumamoto" is in the west of the town, in Saint-Mitre Park. It was created around the Noh theatre. Symbolising the partnership between the towns of Aix-en-Provence and Kumamoto in Japan, the garden is a beautiful green gem. In the centre of the garden is a pond. This is a Mediterranean-style garden based on the rules of a Japanese garden. The rocks come from the region, and the trees and plants are from the Mediterranean varieties found on the Sainte-Victoire mountain. 

Visitors can see the essential elements of a Japanese garden, including a pond, waterfall and lantern in a garden that has made an impact throughout the Aix region. The trees planted here (cherry trees, ginkgos, maple trees) mark the changing seasons and provide shade. The black pines give structure to the new garden, as well as a real Japanese spirit.

The garden resulted from a partnership between the Kumamoto gardeners association and Aix-en-Provence gardeners. Interested visitors will find information about the garden on the panels at the garden entrance.
The garden opening times are the same as for Saint-Mitre Park.

label: Château du Tholonet
description: Castle built in 1776 by the Gallifet family and now occupied by the Société du Canal de Provence.

label: Oppidum Saint Blaise
comment: The Chapelle St-Blaise is a 12th century Romanesque building, restored in the 13th century and whose facade was redone in 1608.
shortDescription: The Chapelle St-Blaise is a 12th century Romanesque building, restored in the 13th century and whose facade was redone in 1608.
description:
Surrounded by medieval tombs, it is preceded by the foundations of an 11th century church. It occupies the site of the city of Castelveyre. The long wall, built in 1231 to protect it, now encloses the excavation field where the ruins of Ugium cover those of the ancient city.

The steep plateau accessible only from the south, therefore easy to defend, was inhabited from the Neolithic until the end of the 14th century with a long interruption during the High Roman Empire (from the 1st to the beginning of the 4th century AD). The excavations undertaken by Henri Rolland in 1935 and continued after his death, have brought to light eight archaeological layers. A very beautiful Hellenistic rampart (2nd century BC) surmounted by the early Christian walls, a Christian necropolis, the substructures of the St-Vincent-d'Ugium basilica ...

Possibility of free visits or guided tours.
Activities and entertainment supervised by a heritage mediator.

label: L'Hôtel de Ville
comment: The site where the present Town Hall is located has been occupied since the 13th century by the Maison de Ville, which brought together the merchants and consuls of the town.
shortDescription: The site where the present Town Hall is located has been occupied since the 13th century by the Maison de Ville, which brought together the merchants and consuls of the town.
description:
The present City Hall stands where the Town Meeting House stood as early as the 13th Century and provided a meeting place for the city's traders and Consuls. In the 15th Century the Palais Communal was founded  the new Town Council met on the ground floor and the Consuls on the first floor. The present building was eventually constructed in the 17th Century to symbolise the new political status awarded to the city by Louis XIV. The King ordered that the city should henceforth be managed by aldermen  he also changed the administration of the port. 
Built by Mathieu Portal and Gaspard Puget, the City Hall was work of the great Marseille architect Pierre Puget.
The unusual aspect of the building was that it deliberately separated the traders, who remained on the ground floor, from the aldermen, who met on the first floor. Consequently, access to the first floor was through a building located at the rear, using a wooden walkway. The Hôtel de Ville was extended at the end of the 18th Century when private houses were purchased to constitute the rear body of the building and to form an arcade. The arcade, which separates the two main sections of the building, comprises a vaulted ceiling that is a masterpiece of the stone-cutter's craft. The arcade and the handsome stairs leading to the rear body were both designed by Joseph-Esprit Brun. Puget's building became a National Heritage site in 1948 and now only houses the private offices of the Mayor. The day-to-day administration of the 16 districts that constitute Marseille is now done from 8 Town Hall annexes.
The architect Franck Hammoutène has designed underground development of adjoining square, to create the Espace Villeneuve Bargemon, which received the 2006 Equerre d’Argent award, a national architecture prize. This new space houses the new chamber of the City Council, work and meeting rooms and a large museum area.

label: Plage La Grande Mer
description:
Plage la Grande Mer
Set in the centre of Cassis, "Plage de la Grande Mer" is an easy-to-reach, family-style shingle beach, cleaned every day and attended by a lifeguard. You will love its stunning views over the adjacent Château hill and handy facilities including showers, toilets, a cloakroom and amenities for the disabled. Access is easy too, thanks to the nearby Port and Centre Ville car parks.
As far as leisure activities go, you can enjoy renting out a pedalo, kayak or funboard. And if you forgot your picnic, you can opt for a bit to eat at one of the neighbouring restaurants and snack bars!

label: Eglise Saint-Louis d'Anjou
comment: The union act between the three districts was signed on 21 April 1581 to create Martigues. Commemorative plaque.
shortDescription: The union act between the three districts was signed on 21 April 1581 to create Martigues. Commemorative plaque.
description:
Église Saint Louise was rebuilt in 1675. 
The steeple is topped by a stone spire with a sober design that characterises the modesty of this church in the Ferrières district, the poorest in Martigues in the 17th century. 

Observe the rustic portal with a broken pediment from the former Chapelle des Pénitents Bleus in the entrance.

label: Chapelle Saint-Sulpice
comment: This is an authentic Romanesque style chapel. It is one of the oldest in the region. It is still unknown when exactly it was founded, but it’s thought to be between the 10th and the 11th centuries.
shortDescription: This is an authentic Romanesque style chapel. It is one of the oldest in the region. It is still unknown when exactly it was founded, but it’s thought to be between the 10th and the 11th centuries.
description: This religious 9th century chapel is a very pure Romanesque style. This is one of the oldest in the region. Its Bell was also called Sainte-catherine. It has a lantern of the dead. The Chapelle St-Sulpice reveals the former Istres, as Oppidium du Castellan, an ancient place Celto-Ligure which overlooks the étang de L'olivier. The chapel Saint-Sulpice is a major building of the Romanesque Provence and is classified since 1942 to the supplementary inventory of Historic Monuments. Today, the chapel has to promote artists and amateur practices in organizing exhibitions around the arts and Visual arts. It offers throughout the year a programme of exhibitions of artistic practices in a spirit of openness on contemporary art.These exhibitions, bringing together professionals and amateurs, are aimed at the broadest audience. The beauty and the acoustics of the place also invite arts of gesture, poetry and song to cross their respective creations.Each exhibition in its staging is designed to resonate with this exceptional place and return the echo of a balance maintained between art and architecture.

label: Calanque de Port Pin
comment: Port Pin is the smallest of the three creeks near Cassis. It offers the softest landscape, with its pine forests that go down to the water and its sandy beach.
shortDescription: Port Pin is the smallest of the three creeks near Cassis. It offers the softest landscape, with its pine forests that go down to the water and its sandy beach.
description:
It owes its name to the Aleppo pines, very present in the massif. It is included in the National Park of Calanques, on the territory of Marseille. It is the last calanque of Marseille, the most eastern.
It is crossed by the GR98-51 hiking trail: walkers can reach it in about 45 minutes from the Presqu'île parking lot (fee required).

label: Les Thermes de Constantin
comment: Inseparables de las comodidades de la vida urbana en la época imperial, las termas combinaban el ejercicio físico en la palestra (sala de entrenamiento) con el baño para la higiene personal.
shortDescription: Inseparables de las comodidades de la vida urbana en la época imperial, las termas combinaban el ejercicio físico en la palestra (sala de entrenamiento) con el baño para la higiene personal.
description: Date: 4th century era: ancient Type: Architecture of sports and recreation status: property of the historic city of Arles (for the clear part) class Monument (1840) the Unesco World Heritage (1981) characteristic Expression of Roman civilisation, the baths were one of the most common public places. Their success begins only at the end of the Republic and early empire: the first public baths do appear in Rome in the 1st century BC and don't develop really only at the beginning of our era, with the invention of the tepidaria.Inseparable buildings in the comforts of urban life in imperial times, the thermal baths associated physical exercises which took place on the palaestra (training Hall) to the bath ensuring personal hygiene. Every afternoon the entire population, the first women, then men observed the rite of sweating in dry, hot bath where the skin sprayed hot water was scraped to the strigil (a kind of small scraper), of the passage in the warm and the cold pool room. It ended with a vigorous massage.In addition to their hygienic function, the baths also had a strong social role and a popular meeting place. The entrance was free, or almost, could a sport, see performances, or attend the library. At Arles, we know the existence of three thermal baths. The first were discovered the Republic square in 1675 when the erection of the obelisk and are therefore today beneath this monument. Another spa construction, including the hypothetical remains plan, was built near the beginning of the 3rd century outside the walls, to the South of the city. These two institutions are the baths of Constantine described here.The success of the baths is due significantly to the invention of the tepidaria. They allowed to circulate warm air under the floor of the elevated parts through the tendons of bricks, the suspensura. The air is then evacuated through the vertical channels of the tubuli, doubling the walls. These elements are still clearly visible in the thermal baths of Arles.Most of the large thermal establishment of origin is included today in the homes of the neighborhood. Currently, only the northern part of the set has been released. It mainly concerns the hot parts and service parts. Despite the almost total disappearance of the suspensura, ground movement, one can understand quite well the Organization of that party, whose main element is the caldarium, the warm room with its vaulted pool. The construction punctuated by an alternation of courses of bricks and of small limestone rubble very regular revolves around a semi-circular demi-abside lit by three tall windows arches, covered by a great oven ass Vault. Two rectangular pools were part and another of the central room, which, to the East, has still its pavement of marble and a part of the tubuli. Several homes were used to heat the caldarium. A real piece of heating was located in the northeast corner of the building, as well as a home in the southwest corner of the room to the South.The caldarium communicated by two doors with a terraced room South, room warm or tepidarium. Completely devoid of its soil, it however retains a Western apse, recently excavated and backfilled pending a restoration. To the East, remains another hot room, probably the laconicum or Proofer.The rest of the complex has not been released. The houses immediately adjacent to the site, to the South, massively remploient the walls of the frigidarium, cold bath. Relics sometimes remarkably preserved, to describe it as a large rectangular room bounded on the ends in an apse.

label: Plage La Brise de Mer
description:
Plage la Brise de Mer
The village of Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer is reputed for its wild beaches stretching between dunes and the Petit Rhône river, ideal for horse riding, admiring the wild flora and fauna of Camargue and contemplating the area's magical sunsets. Separated by dikes designed to protect them from erosion in case of heavy rain, the beaches of Camargue vary in size, but all are delightful. "Plage de la Brise de Mer" is located in the heart of Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer and offers views over the village church. Benefiting from a nearby car park, restaurant, pretty campsite, lifeguard and delicious fine sand, this is an ideal choice for families. No dogs allowed!

label: Bibliothèque diocésaine Charles de Provenchères
comment: The diocesan library offers a collection of approximately 65,000 books, particularly in the areas of theology and philosophy.
shortDescription: The diocesan library offers a collection of approximately 65,000 books, particularly in the areas of theology and philosophy.
description: The diocesan library has a collection of around 65,000 works, particularly focusing on theology and philosophy. In theology: exegesis, ethics, spirituality, church history. There are also works of local history and classic literature.

label: Médiathèque Isidore Rollande
comment: Municipal media library of Châteaurenard.
shortDescription: Municipal media library of Châteaurenard.
description:
Reading (books, newspapers, magazines), work and research (encyclopaedias, dictionaries, reference works, etc.), Electre database (all titles available in bookshops), internet, CD-ROMs, CDs. Free entrance
Animations for adults, children...

The health protocol having evolved, the Media Library puts back at the disposal of the public the working space (tables and chairs) so that the students can come to revise, as well as the daily press.

The 3-day quarantine of returned documents is no longer necessary, but the books will be automatically cleaned before being put back on the shelves by us.

label: Presbytère
comment: Presbytery of Cornillon Confoux on the Place de l'Eglise
shortDescription: Presbytery of Cornillon Confoux on the Place de l'Eglise
description:
Built in the 15th century, it housed up to two priests before being transformed into a municipal site.
Remarkable for its ribbed and barrel vaults.

label: Lac de Peïroou
comment: Discover the Peïroou Lake in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence and its dam.
shortDescription: Discover the Peïroou Lake in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence and its dam.
description:
The Lake of Peïroou is an artificial lake located in the Alpilles in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, direction Baux-de-Provence. The name "Peïroou" comes from the Provençal language and refers to the natural cavities of the rock due to erosion. Its initial use was to supply water to the town of Glanum
There are two ways to access it: from Avenue Van Gogh, take Avenue Antoine de la Salle and continue. Another way to access the lake is from the Route des Baux, leaving the town of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, you will find stairs on your right and you will come across a beautiful physical hike where the GR6 passes.
Access to the lake is subject to summer restrictions due to the risk of fire, so please always ask if access is permitted or not. Please note: the access to the lake is closed to traffic in summer. When possible, you can go to the lake and start a hike on the GR6.
It is also possible to fish when the lake allows it. To do so, you need to get a special fishing card for the Lake of Peïroou, the national fishing card does not work there. You can buy it at the Tourist Office of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence. Possibility to buy it for a day, a week or a month. Attention: fishing is closed from June 1st to September 30th.

label: Médiathèque Intercommunale Marie Mauron
description: Today the media centre intercommunal Marie Mauron has more than 275,000 books, CD, DVD, CD ROMIn 1982, the opening in September of the library public Intercommunale de Port Saint Louis, Central of a network intended to serve a population of 60,000 inhabitants. At the outset, all sections are represented. In 1982, the area dedicated to the library is 3,500 m2. The craze for the library is immediate it attracts not only the public of the city, but also customers for its architecture and professionals for its networking model.Since December 31, 2002, the municipalities of Grans, Cornillon-Confoux, Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhône are part of the SAN. In 2004, extending the network of libraries in the 6 municipalities in Western Provence. January 27, 2004 inauguration of the médiathèque Intercommunale Marie Mauron in Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhône.In 2007, the web portal of the Intercommunale West Provence.acces media library catalogue online Koha.In 2009, commissioning of the booking to remote documents. Opening of the audio-visual spaces. Commissioning of the Internet workshops.In 2010, commissioning web workshops for the children. Launch of the communication campaign of the MBATHA on the territory Western Provence.In 2011, opening of the youth space. Access to purchase suggestions online. Commissioning of remotable subscriptions.In 2012, enrichment of the catalogue by Babeltheque resources commissioning of access wi - fi on the network of libraries. Commissioning of heritage digital library (REM)

label: Bibliothèque municipale
comment: Ventabren Library
shortDescription: Ventabren Library
description:
Come and discover the novels, documents, magazines...and the latest novelties offered by our library.
A "book porting" at home can be set up for people who have difficulties to move around.

label: Médiathèque intercommunale
comment: The media library offers a variety of cultural services throughout the year.
shortDescription: The media library offers a variety of cultural services throughout the year.
description: The intermunicipal media library is part of the territory of West Provence which has a network of 7 media libraries spread over the communes of Fos, Istres, Grans, Port St Louis, Cornillon-Confoux, Entressen (commune of Istres) and Miramas. These 6 towns have natural assets: Mediterranean beaches, the shores of the Etang de Berre and classified wooded areas.

label: Eglise Saint-André
comment: Built in the 11th century, it has been largely modified since then. Its bell tower, made of exposed stone, dates from 1749. Only the porch is from the original construction
shortDescription: Built in the 11th century, it has been largely modified since then. Its bell tower, made of exposed stone, dates from 1749. Only the porch is from the original construction
description: The church depended on the Abbey of St. Victor of Marseilles. Its gate is full of columns, the capitals of which are decorated with foliage supporting the archivolt. The bell tower of 1749 is in stone.

label: Le quartier de la Roquette
comment: This district dates back to the Middle Ages and was for a long time the favourite district of mariners; the La Roquette district remains one of the most attractive in town.
shortDescription: This district dates back to the Middle Ages and was for a long time the favourite district of mariners; the La Roquette district remains one of the most attractive in town.
description:
Its original urban herringbone layout features attractive narrow and sometimes raised houses between the Quai du Rhône and the Boulevard Clemenceau. The façades with their many architectural decorations and the niches which adorn the street corners, attract the eyes and encourage visitors to take their time. 
The district was also brought to life by artisans and traders, and was the home of a number of large families who have left us their beautiful private mansions. 
Following a decline caused by the disappearance of the shipping industry in the 19th century, the district has now been spectacularly redeveloped (La Roquette is in the protected area) and the installation of shops and businesses in the eastern part has given it a new lease of life.
Its 2006 population of 2,427 is a result of the district's distant and recent past and is particularly heterogeneous: social classes, generations and cultural origins come together to give a real village feel.
Remains of the 16th century rampart
After the troubled decline of the Early Middle Ages, Arles experienced a period of renaissance from the 10th century which gradually led it to spreading beyond its walls. In the first half of the 12th century a veritable district, the Vieux-Bourg, arose in the south-east of the town; it is now known as La Roquette.
Its seigniory belonged to the Porcelet family, whose fortress was on the current Place Antonelle. 
With its ovens, its mills, its churches and a boat for crossing the river, it rapidly became a very distinct entity from the original districts of the Roman colony. The new district soon had its own ramparts. From 1250, La Roquette became part of a new enclosed area with the other districts of the town.
During the Revolution, latent antagonism gave way to intense confrontation between La Roquette, a district of Revolutionaries, and the other districts, particularly that of L'Hauture, which was populated by Royalists. The town's first Mayor, Pierre-Antoine Antonelle (1790), came from the La Roquette district. A certain degree of rivalry remained in the life of the commune until the First World War. 
Until the middle of the 19th century and the arrival of the railway, river-based activities ensured the livelihood of the district, which also housed a number of artisans, traders and smallholders. 
La Roquette lost its vitality in the 20th century and welcomed a number of new arrivals during different waves of immigration. Over the last few decades, the district has managed to retain its identity, whilst once again finding a place in the urban fabric of Arles.

label: Fontaine Amédée Pichot
comment: Date: 1887. Era: 19th century. Type: Commemorative architecture. Status: Public domain. Commissioned by: Pierre-Amédée Pichot. Contractor: Joseph Flandrin. The enamel medallion of Paul Balze
shortDescription: Date: 1887. Era: 19th century. Type: Commemorative architecture. Status: Public domain. Commissioned by: Pierre-Amédée Pichot. Contractor: Joseph Flandrin. The enamel medallion of Paul Balze
description:
The building has a fountain built against the wall and was inspired by the one on the Place Saint Michel in Paris. 
The focus of its architecture is to highlight the central medallion, made of enamel on ceramic tiles, and sometimes incorrectly called a mosaic. 
Balze's work is framed by two engaged columns with a Corinthian capital, surmounted by a double entablature. 
At their base is the fountain basin, in the form of a bowl. 
The attic level is decorated with a lion profile, created by Auguste Cain (1822-1894), a student of Rude and one of the best animal sculptors of the 19th century. Next to it is the town's emblem.
Two engraved inscriptions can be made out: the upper one, in Latin, commemorates the inauguration of the building and the lower one, in Provençal, is a quotation by Amédée Pichot.
The fountain today
The Amédée Pichot fountain offers up its elegant form to the curiosity of visitors entering the town centre from the north.
An expression of filial piety, the structure also evokes the memory of a brilliant line of artists, the Balzes, who originated in Avignon. 
It is also the testimony of a friendship between two exceptional men, whose talent took them to Paris where they were brought together by their common Arles roots. 
The enamel medallion of Paul Balze
The building has a fountain built against the wall and was inspired by the one on the Place Saint Michel in Paris. 
The focus of its architecture is to highlight the central medallion, made of enamel on ceramic tiles, and sometimes incorrectly called a mosaic. 
Balze's work is framed by two engaged columns with a Corinthian capital, surmounted by a double entablature. 
At their base is the fountain basin, in the form of a bowl. 
The attic level is decorated with a lion profile, created by Auguste Cain (1822-1894), a student of Rude and one of the best animal sculptors of the 19th century. Next to it is the town's emblem.
Two engraved inscriptions can be made out: the upper one, in Latin, commemorates the inauguration of the building and the lower one, in Provençal, is a quotation by Amédée Pichot.

label: Chapelle Saint-Michel
comment: At the top of Saint-Etienne hill is the Saint Michel chapel (751-987) where Saint John is traditionally celebrated each year.
shortDescription: At the top of Saint-Etienne hill is the Saint Michel chapel (751-987) where Saint John is traditionally celebrated each year.
description: The Chapel Saint Michel is placed as a lookout on the plateau also called "Volturno". Its renovation was undertaken in 1989 by the "Estevenoun" association, the Rotary Club of Istres and other local associations. The new chapel was opened by a mass given by Fr. Abdon DONAIN June 23, 1993, on the occasion of the Saint John the Baptist. At the foot of this Chapel, a breathtaking view awaits you... The two ponds and many istreennes hills are at your feet in this place full of history...

label: Maison du Roy
comment: The Maison du Roy, which today houses the Baux-de-Provence Tourist Office, was once the seat of justice in the name of the sovereign.
shortDescription: The Maison du Roy, which today houses the Baux-de-Provence Tourist Office, was once the seat of justice in the name of the sovereign.
description: Before the Revolution, the town of Les Baux was the centre of both Royal and seigneurial jurisdiction, whose seat was for a long time located in this building, built in 1499. It is where justice was served in the name of the sovereign. This building is now home to the Les Baux-de-Provence Tourist Office. The rampart against which the buildings were built was cut through in the 19th century to allow the opening of the current entrance to the town.

label: Château de Cassis
description: Built in the 13th century by the Counts of Baux, the castle dominates the city of Cassis. The term castle is not quite accurate. It is the old city of Cassis surrounded by walls in which each family had its own home. The inhabitants went out in the morning either to go fishing or to work the land and came back in the evening. The castle is not open to the public.

label: Château de Florans
comment: Former stronghold of the De Forbin family, the complex includes the Petit Château built in 1598, and the Grand Château, started in 1607.
shortDescription: Former stronghold of the De Forbin family, the complex includes the Petit Château built in 1598, and the Grand Château, started in 1607.
description:
Its architecture is characteristic of the Renaissance style
The front wall is preceded by a curtain wall and turrets.
The castle is not open to the public and houses a medical centre.
Since 1980, the International Piano Festival has been held every summer in the park of the castle.

label: Boulevard Joseph Desanat
description: Joseph Désanat was born in Tarascon (1796-1874). He was courtier and then a charcuterie manufacturer in Marseille, where he practised a number of different professions. He founded and managed the newspaper 'Lou Biou-Abaisso' (The Bouillabaisse. 1841-1842 and 1844-1846). He was a pre-Mistral Félibre and both a journalist and a poet. He wrote at a time when Provençal spelling had not yet been fixed by the famous Maillane writer, and was only 16 when this work was edited. It is interesting to note that Mistralian script was different to that of Désanat ('e's and 's's were removed and words were written as they were pronounced). Désanat actually wrote in Provençal patois. Mistral would turn it into a language. It should be noted, however, that the pronunciation of Provençal is still close to that of our Tarascon Félibre.

label: Oratoire Saint-Roch
comment: Oratory dedicated to Saint Roch the protector saint against the plague
shortDescription: Oratory dedicated to Saint Roch the protector saint against the plague
description:
This Oratory was erected in the rectory courtyard in May 1990, during the Jubilee of father Joseph Brell, priest of Saint Martin de Crau.
The Oratory is made of dressed limestone and has a square niche surmounted by a sloped roof and a Camargue cross.
The inscription on the commemorative plaque on the pillar of the oratory reads, In memory of the 40 years of priesthood of Father Joseph Brell. - 24 May 1990 - Priest of this Parish 1975-1991.

label: Hôtel d'Agut
description:
The Hôtel d'Agut was built in 1667 for Pierre d'Agut, a Member of Parliament. 

The two figures supporting the central balcony are by Jean-Claude Rambot, while Jean-Louis Michel made the window ornaments, the corner niche and the overdoor. 

The successive transformations of the interior mean that the decorations are no longer visible the entrance hall alone still has beams covered with moulded garlands. 

The Hôtel d'Agut illustrates the evolution of the atlantes theme reintroduced into the region by Pierre Puget

label: Canal de Montrichet
comment: The Canal de Marseille is the work of the Swiss engineer Frantz Mayor de Montricher
shortDescription: The Canal de Marseille is the work of the Swiss engineer Frantz Mayor de Montricher
description:
Under the impetus of Maximin Consolat, mayor of Marseille, the creation of the Marseille canal began in 1839 to bring water from the Durance to Marseille, under the direction of engineer Frantz Mayor de Montricher.
It took fifteen years, from 1839 to 1854, to build the canal, with its tormented route, its 80 km long, 17 km of which were underground, its 18 aqueduct bridges, its basins and its numerous technical works.
The Montrichet canal (19th century), the third canal of La Roque d'Anthéron, overlooks the commune to the south after having cleaned its hard water in the Saint Christophe reservoir. This dam, particularly astonishing when it is empty, is part, with the Roquefavour aqueduct and the water network of the Palais Longchamp, of the 3 originalities of the technical and social work of Frantz Mayor de Montricher.

label: Eglise Saint-Denis de Calès
comment: The church of Saint Denis de Calès, built in the 12th century, enlarged and restored in the 14th century, has benefited from numerous restorations over the centuries.
shortDescription: The church of Saint Denis de Calès, built in the 12th century, enlarged and restored in the 14th century, has benefited from numerous restorations over the centuries.
description: It can be discovered in the middle of nature, two hundred metres from the Calès circus on the north side. This church consists of a vaulted nave with two bays. It remains the only intact testimony of the occupation of the troglodytic site of Calès. It is open on the first Sunday of April, May and June from 2.30 pm to 5 pm, and for the European Heritage Days.

label: Les bories
comment: the bories
shortDescription: the bories
description:
Bories are small dry stone shelters, round in shape with thick walls. The first ones would date from the 17th century.
Most often isolated in the countryside, they served as a refuge for shepherds who took their flocks to graze far from home. They were therefore built according to the routes that the latter followed.
There are still four of them in Lançon today in more or less good state of conservation: on the RD 19 in the direction of the Val de Sibourg at Camp de Pertus. on the RD 113 after the Col du Télégraphe in the direction of La Fare-les-Oliviers and finally the last one at Les Escalettes which despite the collapse of one of its sides has kept its original shape.
These typical constructions remind us of the know-how and wisdom of our ancestors. You can find a multitude of bories in Provence, near vineyards, lavender or poppy fields.

label: Ponts bleus de la passe Nord
comment: Built as a replacement for the old swing bridge (1853-1998) and the metal bridge (1949-2000).
shortDescription: Built as a replacement for the old swing bridge (1853-1998) and the metal bridge (1949-2000).
description: These two bridges on the Baussengue canal are the culmination of the effort devoted by the city to effectively solve the eternal problem of crossing. waters.

label: Fontaine de l'Hôtel de Ville
comment: In 1737, Georges Vallon was appointed to rebuild the city centre of Aix en Provence.
shortDescription: In 1737, Georges Vallon was appointed to rebuild the city centre of Aix en Provence.
description:
He had bourgeois houses built to the east and the Corn Exchange to the south. A fountain, designed by Esprit Brun, stands in the centre of the square formed by these buildings. 

The Avignon artist Jean Chastel was chosen to decorate the fountain. In the centre of the circular pond is a cube-shaped pedestal adorned with garlands and flowers at each corner, as well as gargoyles representing water gods and goddesses, from which the water flows. 

On the pedestal stands a classical granite column which recalls Roman times and supports a Corinthian marble capital this is topped with a sphere of Calissane stone adorned with a laurel branch, formerly made of gold.

There are inscriptions on the four sides of the pedestal: on the north, a few lines recall the work done on a Roman aqueduct to bring water to the Pinchinats spring to the east, the inscriptions on the south praise King Louis XV and the Duke of Villars, on the west they praise the Consuls of Aix, and the inscription facing the town hall has been altered to suit the whims of successive political regimes.

label: Cénotaphe
comment: This monument was erected in 1912 in memory of Jeanne, Jules and Joseph Jaubert, the wife and brothers of the sponsor, who were killed by an accident at Saint-Jacques level crossing in Fontvieille (inscription on the base).
shortDescription: This monument was erected in 1912 in memory of Jeanne, Jules and Joseph Jaubert, the wife and brothers of the sponsor, who were killed by an accident at Saint-Jacques level crossing in Fontvieille (inscription on the base).
description: This monument was erected in 1912 in memory of Jeanne, Jules and Joseph Jaubert, the wife and brothers of the sponsor, who were killed by an accident at Saint-Jacques level crossing in Fontvieille (inscription on the base).

label: Jardin Public de Ferrières
comment: The oldest public garden in Martigues borders the recently landscaped beach.
shortDescription: The oldest public garden in Martigues borders the recently landscaped beach.
description: Around a pool with jets of water shaded by imposing mulberry trees, white poplars, sophoras, palm trees, canary palm, yew pruned, hackberries, oaks and a unique metasequoia. Shading, playground, catering in summer season.

label: Plage Crin Blanc
description:
Plage Crin Blanc
"Plage Crin Blanc" is located in Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer. Attended by a lifeguard in summer, this is the ideal place for a day out on the beach with the kids, who will love the fine sand and having plenty of space to gallivant. Packed with bathers in summer, it is also a favourite spot for horse riders who come here to gallop along the shore in all seasons – this is where the famous film "Crin Blanc" (White Mane) was shot!
In late May, this "Plage Crin Blanc" provides the stage for the time-honoured Gypsy Pilgrimage, when gypsies from the world over gather to pay tribute to their patron saint Sarah.

label: Porte Jarnègues
description: This construction was built in 1646. It serves as a reminder of a famous knights' tournament, 'Le Pas d'Armes de la Bergère', which was organised by King René and held on the island of Jarnègues in 1449. The branches of the Rhône flowed as far as this district for centuries. It was from here that the boats left, carrying goods and men, and for trading purposes. It is the town's only secondary gate.

label: Rousset
description: At the foot of the Sainte-Victoire, Rousset belongs to Cézanne's painted landscapes. Between the hilly garrigues and the Arc, this little corner of paradise has preserved a quality of life worthy of the charming villages of Provence.Its cobbled and calm streets allow you to stroll quietly with local merchants and craftsmen.

label: Bibliothèque municipale
description:
The public library welcomes you to the :

Tuesday from 10am to 12pm and from 2pm to 6pm
Wednesday from 10am to 12pm and from 2pm to 7pm
Friday from 10am to 12pm and from 2pm to 7pm
Saturday from 10am to 12pm and from 2pm to 6pm

On-site consultation is free of charge. Some works are exclusively dedicated to it (dictionaries, encyclopaedias, codes...)
For the loan of works at home, registration is compulsory.

How to register :
Present an identity document, proof of address
Pay a registration fee of 4 euros per year and per family

Loan Terms and Conditions :
Each user can borrow three documents for three weeks.
For everyone's comfort, it is important to respect the loan period and to take care of the works.

The missions of the Municipal Library
The purpose of the Municipal Library is to promote public reading.
It is intended for all the inhabitants of the municipality as well as for the external public, for various purposes: leisure, culture, education, information...

The Fund
A collection of nearly 15,000 books is available in the most varied fields: literature, documentaries, practical books, comic strips, reference works (dictionaries, encyclopaedias, codes, etc.), works for young people (albums, tales, novels, CD books, comic books), etc
The classification method is adapted from the Dewey classification, as in most public libraries.

Large-print books and audio books (CDs) make reading accessible to the visually impaired.
This fund is regularly replenished by new acquisitions.
It is supplemented by books that the WB borrows from the Departmental Lending Library, either spontaneously or at the request of readers.

The commune also possesses an old collection of about 2000 works, part of which comes from the revolutionary seizures on the former convents of Tarascon. It is kept at the service of the city archives.

label: Saint Mitre les Remparts
comment: It is likely that the foundation of this village, located on a rocky outcrop, dates back to the time when the neighboring town of Ugium (now Saint-Blaise) was sacked by Saracen troops, around the 9th century.
shortDescription: It is likely that the foundation of this village, located on a rocky outcrop, dates back to the time when the neighboring town of Ugium (now Saint-Blaise) was sacked by Saracen troops, around the 9th century.
description:
