But it was only after the town of Castelveyre (built on the ruins of Ugium) had been looted and sacked by the troops of Raymond de Turenne, Lord of Baux, that the Archbishop of Arles authorized the population to protect yourself by ramparts (1395-1410) which still exist almost entirely and which are listed as Historic Monuments.
Beautiful city portals to the North and South.
In the extension of the Irénée Sabatier, beyond the rue Simiot, is a windmill from 1626.

label: Arènes
description: Capacity: 800 pers. shows: little cows races, galas.

label: Anse des Phocéens
comment: Small sandy cove surrounded by white rocks, towards Les Goudes.
shortDescription: Small sandy cove surrounded by white rocks, towards Les Goudes.
description: Before arriving at Les Goudes .

label: Port de l'Estaque
description: Cézanne, who liked dominant positions, was hardly attracted to what was still only a beach. His successors made it one of their favourite motifs. Derain multiplied the versions of his Barques de Pêcheurs. Braque, Friesz and Marque also gave several pictures of the small port.

label: La Petite Provence du Paradou
comment: More than 480 santons are on display, you can discover different scenes such as the famous card game of Pagnol, the game of pétanque, the farandole, the grape harvest..
shortDescription: More than 480 santons are on display, you can discover different scenes such as the famous card game of Pagnol, the game of pétanque, the farandole, the grape harvest..
description:
One of the largest exhibitions of santons (almost 400) presented in a 500 m2 miniature Provençal village.
The best santon-makers in France have devoted almost 8,000 hours of work to making the 32 old buildings (50,000 clay tiles, all made individually by hand) in this mini Provençal village, where the santons, 1/6 of their usual size, take part in amusing or emotional scenes from everyday life.

label: Eglise Notre-Dame de l'Assomption
comment: In Greek style, it has three naves and is surmounted by a splendid campanile
shortDescription: In Greek style, it has three naves and is surmounted by a splendid campanile
description: Built between 1866 and 1869 thanks to the funding of châtelaine de Calas, Louise Gavaraque, this church has a copy of the old altar of the Saint-Sauveur Cathedral in Aix-en-Provence. Greek style, it has three naves and is surmounted by a splendid bell tower.

label: Forêt domaniale de Cadarache
comment: The Fôret domaniale de Cadarache is located in Saint Paul les Durance. Its northern part extends to the banks of the Verdon, on the border between the Vaucluse and the Var.
shortDescription: The Fôret domaniale de Cadarache is located in Saint Paul les Durance. Its northern part extends to the banks of the Verdon, on the border between the Vaucluse and the Var.
description:
This territory of 970 ha, is covered by a forest mainly composed of oaks. The mouflon was introduced here from animals taken from Corsica.

Management of natural areas: State forest
Protected area: Biological reserve

label: Village de Vernègues
description: The village was rebuilt below the Plateau after the 1909 earthquake.

label: Chapelle Sainte Réparade
comment: Discover the Sainte Réparade Chapel
shortDescription: Discover the Sainte Réparade Chapel
description:
La Quilho
Outdoor tour.
This chapel, attested in 1082, stands halfway up the eastern slope of the hill, an ancient Celto-Ligurian oppidum. Restored in 1677, it is the object of a procession on Ascension Day. Offering a breathtaking view of the Durance valley, it is located at the start of a path that leads to the top of the hill (30 minutes).

label: Pôle culturel "Jean-Claude IZZO"
comment: Cultural centre
shortDescription: Cultural centre
description:
Free membership. You can borrow CDs, books, DVDs...
At your disposal exhibition rooms, reading for all tastes, workshops for the youngest. Something to cultivate you.

label: Chapelle Saint-Honorat
comment: Romanesque style chapel.
shortDescription: Romanesque style chapel.
description:
Built from 1102 in the Romanesque style by monks under the authority of the Abbey of Lérins, it was confiscated during the Revolution as national property and sold. Situated at the top of the rue du moulin, one can easily see the cul-de-four apse overflowing into the street. However, the chapel is intact and in a good state of preservation. The Grand Master of the Hospitallers, Foulques de Villaret is said to have been buried there in 1325.
Registered on the list of Historic Monuments since 19 December 1972

label: Fontaine des Lumières
comment: Built during the Enlightenment Century (XVIII°), the fountain was supplied with hot water by the source of Bagniers.
shortDescription: Built during the Enlightenment Century (XVIII°), the fountain was supplied with hot water by the source of Bagniers.
description: It was decorated with a spiked star, moulded in the 19th century and inspired by the one adorning the fountain des Augustins.

label: Le Tétrodon, habitat mobile et modulaire
comment: The adventure of the 30-foot Tetrodon begins with Except ... (territories) the association's project through this passage, infranch. An exploration of the territories from the Étang de Berre to the Golfe de Fos, between habitats, industries and nature.
shortDescription: The adventure of the 30-foot Tetrodon begins with Except ... (territories) the association's project through this passage, infranch. An exploration of the territories from the Étang de Berre to the Golfe de Fos, between habitats, industries and nature.
description:
The association agreed to receive for one symbolic euro in December 2011 this mobile and modular habitat, identified as a Tetrodon by the historian architect Thierry Duroussea, the last in the region.

Inhabitable space, the Tétrodon will offer residences to artists, from the Etang de Berre to the Golfe de Fos. These residences can be extended to experts, researchers, architects, designers, participating in the creation of a laboratory / observatory of the territories.
The modular spaces of the Tétrodon are adaptable: assembly of panels closing the hulls to create an indoor exhibition space, exterior extension by light structures such as canvas ...
The Tétrodon can also be used to accommodate groups for the start of walks, the organization of artistic workshops not requiring significant equipment.

A little history.
This Tétrodon came from an order from Sonacotra in 1972 for 32 6-meter models to house the workers building the SOLMER (Arcelor Mittal) steel plant in Fos-sur-Mer.
This 10 meter model is the only result of this order.

In return, the association decides to renovate it in order to make it its flagship project, a perennial place intended to welcome visitors, walkers, and artists like a peri-urban refuge. The idea of ​​locating it along the GR2013 then emerges when the association participates in 2013 in Marseille European Capital of Culture and contributes to the realization of this first peri-urban GR. It was labeled 'Patrimoine XXème' by the DRAC in 2012, and became the property of the City of Martigues in 2019 after its restoration.
streetAddress: ['18 boulevard Touret de Vallier', 'Base nautique de Tholon', 'Ferrières']

label: Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle
comment: Known for its exceptional collection of dinosaur eggs to the point that the city is nicknamed Eggs-en-Provence by paleontologists, the Museum has been organizing paleontological excavations since 1994.
shortDescription: Known for its exceptional collection of dinosaur eggs to the point that the city is nicknamed Eggs-en-Provence by paleontologists, the Museum has been organizing paleontological excavations since 1994.
description:
Saint-Mitre Park has housed the museum's administrative and educational departments since April 2014 but the collections are no longer on show as there are no exhibition galleries. They are studied and stored in another site before they are put back on public display. The Museum still has much to offer: educational workshops for schools and children, national events such as the Nature Festival in May and Science Festival in October, external exhibitions, monthly conferences and naturalist inventories.
There are lots of opportunities to introduce the masses to the rich heritage that makes our region what it is.

The Natural History Museum was founded in 1838 with the purchase of a collection of birds and now has almost 470,000 specimens in all areas of natural science: zoology, palaeontology, botany, geology, prehistory and ethnology. The museum has run palaeontology digs since 1994 and is so famous for its amazing collection of dinosaur eggs that the city is nicknamed Eggs-en-Provence. It is behind countless scientific discoveries including the Arcovenator escotae, a large carnivorous dinosaur which was unknown in Europe until now.

label: Le Luberon
comment: The Massif du Luberon is a mountain range (pre-alps) in Provence, between Apt, Cavaillon and Pertuis (Vaucluse) and Manosque (Alpes de Haute Provence) and in the North of Bouches-du-Rhône. It is classified as a Regional Natural Park.
shortDescription: The Massif du Luberon is a mountain range (pre-alps) in Provence, between Apt, Cavaillon and Pertuis (Vaucluse) and Manosque (Alpes de Haute Provence) and in the North of Bouches-du-Rhône. It is classified as a Regional Natural Park.
description:
The massif has a length of 60km and a width of 5km. The summit rises to 1125 m.

Protected area: Biological reserve

label: Hôpital de Quiqueran
description: Jeanne de Quiqueran, Lady of Les Baux, was the wife of Honoré des Martins, governor of Les Baux de Provence and successor of Montmorency. Together with her sister, she built Quiqueran hospital between 1542 and 1583 in the upper part of town, near the old Saint Blaise Chapel. The hospital cared for ordinary patients, while Saint-André hospital, in the Valley, was transformed into a leprosarium. It was later renamed 'Hôtel Dieu et Charité des Baux' and remained open until 1787. It is a beautiful building with a remarkable colonnade on the first floor.

label: Oppidum de Verduron
description: The oppidum of Verduron preserves the remains of a Celtic village. It is one of the two Celtic-ligurian sites in the town, the other being in Saint-Marcel in the east.

label: Médiathèque
comment: The multimedia library of Lambesc welcomes you for consultations on the spot or loans, but also on the occasion of the numerous cultural animations which it proposes.
shortDescription: The multimedia library of Lambesc welcomes you for consultations on the spot or loans, but also on the occasion of the numerous cultural animations which it proposes.
description:
The whole team shares with you its taste for literature and more widely for films and music. Indeed, the media library is above all a place accessible to all, just for the pleasure of reading. You can borrow books, comics but also DVDs and CDs. The media library now lends you DVDs, documentaries and other concerts. DVDs can be rented for a maximum of 2 weeks.

The Media Library also organizes many recurrent or occasional activities, for young people and/or adults. These activities are generally free and accessible upon prior registration.

label: Parc de la Jarre
comment: The 2 hectares of Mediterranean vegetation as well as all the fruit trees offer to the residents a green space of relaxation with many outdoor activities.
shortDescription: The 2 hectares of Mediterranean vegetation as well as all the fruit trees offer to the residents a green space of relaxation with many outdoor activities.
description:
In some squares, the playgrounds can still be used but are under the responsibility of the parents who must ensure that the sanitary rules are respected and, in particular, that the children are physically distanced.


The landscaped park of La Jarre (9th arrondissement) is part of the Urban Renovation Project (PRU) in the La Soude / Les Hauts de Mazargues sector, managed by Marseille Rénovation Urbaine, a structure that has since been integrated into the Aix-Marseille-Provence Metropolitan Authority.
The park is the central public green space of a district undergoing renovation and expansion.
Located between the avenue of the same name, the Boulevard Urbain Sud (BUS) and the Centaure theatre, these 20,000 m² of Mediterranean vegetation (2 hectares) and all the fruit trees offer local residents a green space for relaxation with many outdoor activities.

Beyond its vocation as a space for exchange, sharing and social mixing, the Parc de la Jarre is intended to be a "Provençal stopover" also serving as a link between different districts. For this purpose, it integrates a soft path formed by the "allée des calanques" offering a bicycle and pedestrian path.

The creation of this 54th park in Marseille is fully in line with the "EcoNeighbourhood" approach supported by the actors and inhabitants. This title promotes quality and sustainable development for the area, and is a vehicle for new ways of life.

label: Village de La Barben
description: A small rural village of a few hundred inhabitants that has been welcoming visitors for many years now, who come to recharge their batteries in a green and fresh atmosphere.

label: Etang des Aulnes
comment: The Domain shelters a wooded park and a stretch of water. The opposite bank, still wild, remains a refuge for migratory birds.
shortDescription: The Domain shelters a wooded park and a stretch of water. The opposite bank, still wild, remains a refuge for migratory birds.
description:
The Domaine is the property of the Bouches-du-Rhône Departmental Council. It is located in the Crau region, near Saint Martin de Crau. It houses an old Provencal-style building, a residence for artists and an open-air concert hall.

The estate can host various outdoor events.

Management of natural areas 
Domain of the General Council

label: Eglise de l'Immaculée Conception
comment: The church of Rousset was built by Abbot Ferdinand Meissonnier in record time.
shortDescription: The church of Rousset was built by Abbot Ferdinand Meissonnier in record time.
description: The Rousset's church was built by the Abbe Ferdinand Meissonnier in record time, barely two years, because he was able to use all the living forces of the village: most of the Roussettains participated in the work.

label: Médiathèque Marc Mielly
comment: The Marc Mielly Municipal Media Library was inaugurated in 1995 and built in the former Chapelle des Pénitents Blancs. It offers a modern and cultural equipment.
shortDescription: The Marc Mielly Municipal Media Library was inaugurated in 1995 and built in the former Chapelle des Pénitents Blancs. It offers a modern and cultural equipment.
description: For 3 €, you have access to the library, the video library, the games’ library and many CDs.

label: Chapelle Saint-Pierre
comment:
17th century chapel which has housed the Tourist Office since 2006.
The Chapel has become an exhibition room.
shortDescription:
17th century chapel which has housed the Tourist Office since 2006.
The Chapel has become an exhibition room.

label: Plage des Capucins
description: "Plage des Capucins" in La Ciotat is a pretty, shingle beach set next to the little Port des Capucins, offering a lifeguard, showers, toilets, play area for the kids and Beach Volley ground. You can access it easily thanks to the paying car park on the roadside and the beach is also fitted out with facilities for the disabled. Dogs are not allowed! With its nearby snack bars, bars and restaurants, this is a safe and agreeable choice for a day out with the family. And like the rest of La Ciotat's beaches it offers stunning views over Bec de l'Aigle mountain and beautiful bay.

label: Arènes Chabaud
comment: The Chabaud bullring in Eyguières can host various shows, concerts or bullfighting races
shortDescription: The Chabaud bullring in Eyguières can host various shows, concerts or bullfighting races
description: Shaded arenas - 1,000 seats. Various shows during the summer - concerts - cockade races etc...

label: Chapelle Saint-Privat
comment: The façade is Romanesque with an archway gate surmounted by an oculus above which is a bell-cote. The bell has been removed and is inside the chapel. A semi-circular barrel vault runs as far as the apse, while two ex-votos, one dating from 1866, flank the altar.
shortDescription: The façade is Romanesque with an archway gate surmounted by an oculus above which is a bell-cote. The bell has been removed and is inside the chapel. A semi-circular barrel vault runs as far as the apse, while two ex-votos, one dating from 1866, flank the altar.
description:
The legend of its foundation is that in 260, on the ancient Aurelian Way, a man stopped, overcome with fatigue. A young girl came past, who took him to the hovel of her father Jolius. The man was welcomed with open arms and looked after for several days. He then planned to leave, but the residents begged him to stay because his words spoke to their hearts and souls. 


One evening he told them the story of Christ's birth, powerfully describing a cave in Bethlehem and all the events which followed. He had just told, for the first time, the story that was to become one of our region's most important traditions: the Provençal nativity scene. 


The next day the man resumed his journey  his name was Privat and he was going to his diocese in Gévaudan where he had been appointed Bishop. In gratitude for his healing he had vowed to build a chapel on the site where it had taken place. The existence of this chapel is attested as early as 1079.

label: Prieuré Sainte-Victoire
description:
Wherever you are coming from, you will be impressed by the compact mass of Sainte Victoire rising up from the Aix countryside.

Paths of varying difficulty lead from Vauvenargues to the summit where there is still a chapel and the ruins of a monastery. After walking for an hour you will come to the Chapel of St Victoire.

Built in the 17th century, the priory was home to Carmelite monks and then abandoned. Formerly used by hermits, it owes its restoration to Les Amis de la Ste Victoire, who have made it into a refuge.

label: Base nature de la Coueste
comment: La Coueste is located in the hills south of Aubagne. The nature base is in the middle of the forest.
shortDescription: La Coueste is located in the hills south of Aubagne. The nature base is in the middle of the forest.
description: Get your trainers, bikes and compasses! The Coueste nature base and its paths are waiting for you to discover outdoor sports such as hiking, mountain biking, orienteering or jogging on a sports course. Or simply for a stroll along the botanical trail.

label: Chapelle du Saint Sépulcre
description: Listed as a Historical Monument. It is the oldest monument in Peyrolles. Built on a rocky promontory, this small chapel has the peculiar shape of a Greek cross. It contains murals from the 13th or 14th centuries and marine graffiti from the 15th century.

label: Plage Prado Sud (David)
comment: Prado Sud beach is a 280 meter long pebble and gravel beach, preceded by large areas of lawn. There is a first aid station, lockers, toilets, snack bars and garbage garbage cans.
shortDescription: Prado Sud beach is a 280 meter long pebble and gravel beach, preceded by large areas of lawn. There is a first aid station, lockers, toilets, snack bars and garbage garbage cans.
description:
In order for all Marseilles residents to fully enjoy the beaches and swimming, the city of Marseilles has multiplied its initiatives in favor of the disabled and, more generally, those with reduced mobility.
The beaches of Prado Sud and Prado Nord were the first coastal beaches to be awarded the "Tourism and Disability" label in France, as early as 2005.

They were awarded the "Tourism and Disability" label in France in 2005.
This label was renewed in 2016.
Several criteria contributed to obtaining this label: the consideration of different disabilities, the quality of reception, beach and sports activities.
The Prado South and Prado North beaches are fully accessible to wheelchair users and blind or visually impaired people and mentally or psychologically disabled people.
Eight "Tiralos", amphibious vehicles, are available for the more severely disabled to reach the water and enjoy the swim.
For those who are able to swim independently, physical assistance is available for entering and exiting the water.
The staff of the Division of Disabled Persons is present all summer long to welcome and individually accompany people with disabilities.
This staff is reinforced by 9 seasonal workers for the months of July and August.
Two prefabricated structures and a tent complete this device by offering air-conditioned changing rooms, toilets, accessible showers, as well as a medical bed and a patient lift to facilitate the transfers

Reservations must be made by contacting the Division des Personnes Handicapées at 06 32 28 93 99.
Metro Castellane or Rond Point du Prado + bus 19 or bus 83.

label: Bibliothèque Municipale du Panier
comment: Around an inner courtyard, the library spaces are spread out under beautiful brick vaults. The Panier library is a historic building, whose construction dates back to the 1640s, when it was the Refuge Convent.
shortDescription: Around an inner courtyard, the library spaces are spread out under beautiful brick vaults. The Panier library is a historic building, whose construction dates back to the 1640s, when it was the Refuge Convent.
description:
Around an inner courtyard, the library spaces are spread out under beautiful brick vaults.

The Panier library is a historic building, whose construction dates back to the 1640s, when it was the Refuge Convent

The library offers a regularly updated collection of books, CDs, DVDs, texts and periodicals for children and adults.

Two computer stations provide access to the Internet.

label: Ancien Hôtel de Ville
description:
This classical-style building, built in 1682, was the Town Hall of Pélissanne until 1966.
Today it is classified as a Historical Monument and houses the Pélissanne Archaeological Museum (temporarily closed to the public).

label: LA CHAPELLE Notre-Dame-de-Vie
comment:
She sits enthroned on top of the rock
Accessible by a staircase cut into the limestone rock, this modest construction was built at the beginning of the Romanesque period, around the year 1000.
shortDescription:
She sits enthroned on top of the rock
Accessible by a staircase cut into the limestone rock, this modest construction was built at the beginning of the Romanesque period, around the year 1000.
description:
It reflects the influences of the churches of Catalonia, themselves tinged with Arabic inspiration

Typical of early Romanesque art, it houses an ancient polychrome wooden statue of the "Virgin and Child" which is taken down from the Rock in a procession every year on the occasion of the Assumption

The Pilgrimage of Our Lady of Life:

Every year on the evening of August 14, the 17th century statue of Notre-Dame-de-Vie is lowered from its chapel on the rock to the church of Saint-Gérard in a torchlight pilgrimage. Before going to the church of St-Gérard where the statue will remain until the Sunday following August 15.

The chapel is surmounted by a wall-belfry in which is a bell operated by a rope from the nave. A statue of the Virgin Mary is placed on the bell tower.
The chapel includes decorations worn, in particular a ceiling decorated with cartouches surrounded by stucco containing paintings on canvas (five scenes from the life of the Virgin). The whole decoration is in the 18th century style.

A set of engraved ex-votos, the oldest dating from 1881 and the most recent from 1935, are visible from the outside under the porch.


Do not hesitate to take advantage of the view offered on the Etang de Berre and its surroundings.

label: Etang de l'Estomac
comment: L'Etang de l'Estomac is a body of water with a high salt content, located in the commune of Fos-sur-Mer.
shortDescription: L'Etang de l'Estomac is a body of water with a high salt content, located in the commune of Fos-sur-Mer.
description:
The Stomach Pond consists of 3 parts:
- the old saltworks, to the south, near the sea,
- the south pond, an area protected by a nature reserve,
- the north pond, supplied with sea water by a canal.

label: Eglise paroissiale Notre-Dame
description:
Neo-Romanesque style - 2nd part of the 19th century

ELSA Pastoral Unit: Eyguières Lamanon Sénas Aureille

label: Four Banal
description:
Closed on bridges and public holidays 
With its considerable size and its excellent state of preservation, it is a testament to bygone events this day. Besides the historical aspect related to local heritage, the excavations undertaken in February and March 2001 by archaeologists have yielded numerous ceramic objects that confirm the existence of an active port in this area between the first and sixth century A.D..

label: Chapelle de Lansac
description:
This is a Romanesque chapel originally dedicated to Saint Peter. In the 12th century, it became Notre Dame de l'Assomption and at the same time was given to the Arles Chapter. The site of Lansac, a tiny hamlet south of Tarascon, has been inhabited since Roman times, when the residents fled Ernaginum (now Saint Gabriel), where they had originally settled but which was pillaged by the Visigoths.
Architectural description:
Small rectangular building with a broken barrel roof and a semi-domed apse, supported by lateral abutments. A small wall belfry with two round arches raises the height of the façade.

label: Plage du Bestouan
description:
Beach of pebbles and rocks of 150m by 30m. On the horizon, the Cap Canaille in majesty...

Supervised swimming from 9 am to 7 pm on weekends and public holidays, from May 12 to June 10, and
every day from June 15 to September 16 and weekends until the end of September

Presence of a parking area near the beach, equipped and paying (105 vehicles).
Washrooms/snacks, lodging, first aid station, showers, toilets, garbage cans. Animals not allowed.

Private Beaches

The Same Same Beach:
Tel. 06.11.88.92.66
www.samesamebeach.fr

PAM - Le Bestouan :
Tel. 04.42.04.23.39
Cassis direction La Presqu'île, then park in the Bestouan or Presqu'ile car park. Access to the regulated car parks, on weekends in July and August, shuttles from the free car park of Les Gorguettes.

label: Oratoire Saint-Privat
description:
This shrine marks the crossroads of the path leading to St Privat's Chapel. 


The monument is built of dressed stones and is said to stand at the place where the Saint stopped, due to illness, before being taken in by the people of what would become Rousset.


It was restored in 1933 with the help of Les Amis des Oratoires (Friends of the Shrines) and was blessed on the Saint's feast day by the Abbot Michelet.

label: Le canal EDF
comment: The EDF canal collects its water in the lower Durance at Cadarache and flows into the Etang de Berre.
shortDescription: The EDF canal collects its water in the lower Durance at Cadarache and flows into the Etang de Berre.
description:
It is 100 km long and has a dual purpose of producing energy - 6 hydroelectric plants - and of improving a network of canals bringing water to several municipalities.
Walks are forbidden along the banks of the canal.

label: Château de la Mignarde
comment: The House, also called Château de la Mignarde (second half of 17th and second half of 18th centuries) was significantly altered by Sauveur Mignard in 1770.
shortDescription: The House, also called Château de la Mignarde (second half of 17th and second half of 18th centuries) was significantly altered by Sauveur Mignard in 1770.
description:
The interior is as sumptuous as the exterior, faced with dressed stone. At the end of a suite of rooms stands an enormous antique settee. 

The 18th-century frontage is made up of a central wing surrounded by symmetrical structures.

During the summer the gardens are open to visitors accompanied by Tourist Office guides

label: Plage naturiste de Bonnieu
comment:
Gravel and rocky beach, unsupervised and managed by the Martigues Nature Soleil association (MNS).
Reserved for members of the French Federation of Naturism and members of the MNS association.
shortDescription:
Gravel and rocky beach, unsupervised and managed by the Martigues Nature Soleil association (MNS).
Reserved for members of the French Federation of Naturism and members of the MNS association.
description:
I am not a naturist but I would like to try: via the invitation of a person who is a member of the MNS association, you can try naturism 2 times maximum at the rate of 5 euros per day and per person (a receipt will be issued to you ).
Bonnieu naturist beach is located near Martigues. Modest refrain because here we tan without a swimsuit!

By following the direction of Carro, la Couronne by the D5 or the D9, and after passing the EDF thermal power station, a small sign will show you the road to this small private beach.

You will find there, in addition to sanitary facilities, a pétanque court, a small refreshment bar run by Bazile which regularly organizes themed evenings.

label: Chapelle du Serre
comment: In memory of the Liberation, after a deposit of wreaths at the monument to the dead of the village of Les Milles, it is at the Chapel of the Greenhouse that the inhabitants of the village will, as usual every 21 August around 18:30, gather
shortDescription: In memory of the Liberation, after a deposit of wreaths at the monument to the dead of the village of Les Milles, it is at the Chapel of the Greenhouse that the inhabitants of the village will, as usual every 21 August around 18:30, gather
description: This original chapel was erected in 1946 following the wishes of the Abbé Bériat, for the inhabitants of the Milles had been spared by the Nazis. No internal visit possible.

label: Le Grenier du Soldat
comment: Recover, maintain and safeguard military equipment.
shortDescription: Recover, maintain and safeguard military equipment.
description:
Creation of the museum of the liberation of Provence. 
Visits by appointment.
streetAddress: ['5 Rue Daniel Kinet', 'Château du Pigeonnier', "Quartier Pont d'Avignon"]

label: Le cirque romain
comment:
Date: 149
Era: Antiquity
Type: Public leisure architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a Historic Monument in 1992 and a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1981.
shortDescription:
Date: 149
Era: Antiquity
Type: Public leisure architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a Historic Monument in 1992 and a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1981.
description:
The circus is the largest Roman monument and could only be located outside the town.
It was built in the 2nd century to the south-west of the town, on the banks of the Rhône.
It was mainly used for horse and chariot racing, but sometimes also for cavalry fighting and venationes, a kind of animal hunt.
It must have been very difficult to construct. In view of the unstable nature of the land, it had to be built on thousands of timber piles.
Its materials and decorations were dispersed at the end of the Empire and only a few pieces remain.
Some were reused and some are exhibited at the Departmental Museum of Ancient Arles.
However, its most sumptuous decoration is extremely famous; it is the obelisk installed in front of the hôtel de ville in the 17th century.
The Arles circus was 450 metres long and 101 metres wide.
It had rows of seats which could accommodate 20,000 spectators and a vast banked amphitheatre with a long central divide, the spina (spine),
This spina, decorated with sculptures and basins, had a post (or meta) at either end, which the competitors tried to pass by as closely as possible.
The track was surrounded by a wall (the podium), which was high enough to protect the spectators.
The rows of seats were supported by a modular architectural structure of chambers covered by sloping vaults similar to that of an amphitheatre.
Solid foundations were necessary, due to the instability of the clay soil. They consisted of 30,000 piles of wood 2 to 3.5 metres long.
Today, all that can be seen below the museum are remains of the substructure of the cavea (slopes), the exterior of the spendone, the rounded part of the circus.
The Roman circus in Arles was built in 149 AD, representing the largest urban extension of the time.
This dating shows that the developments of the Flavian era continued until Emperor Antoninus Pius, at the apogée of the Empire.
The building was drastically restructured in the 4th century. Excavations have shown that the spina was partially destroyed and then rebuilt with a new décor of marble plating and an obelisk.
Small houses appeared around the circus and in the 5th century alveoles, although races were still taking place.
The monument was destroyed in the mid-6th century, when its stone was needed to strengthen the town's walls.
The rises in the levels of the Rhône soon covered the site in alluvium, and the remains of the circus were not uncovered until the 17th and 19th centuries, before in depth excavations in the 20th century.

label: La Route Cezanne
comment: Route Cezanne is the only road in France that is listed as a Historic Monument. This example of exceptional heritage runs from Aix-en-Provence to the village of Le Tholonet.
shortDescription: Route Cezanne is the only road in France that is listed as a Historic Monument. This example of exceptional heritage runs from Aix-en-Provence to the village of Le Tholonet.
description:
Some people still call it the D17, while others knew it as the little Tholonet road, but since 1959 its official title has been "Route Cézanne". 

This protected site is known all over the world thanks to the extraordinary beauty of its landscapes and the artist who immortalised them: Paul Cézanne.

Once a year, the Route Cézanne association in Le Tholonet closes the road and organises cultural activities from Aix-en-Provence to Le Tholonet. The road is then reserved for pedestrians with free car parks at either end.

La Route Cezanne joined "Impressionisms Routes" networks in early 2022.
The project "Impressionisms Routes" in Europe aims at creating and fostering, within the continent, a link between the sites that have inspired the European impressionist and plein air painters from the mid-19th century until the mid-20th century

label: La Montagnette
comment: La Montagnette is an isolated massif with well-defined contours, located in the extreme north-west of the department.
shortDescription: La Montagnette is an isolated massif with well-defined contours, located in the extreme north-west of the department.
description:
La Montagnette is an isolated mountain with well-defined contours, located in the extreme north-west of the department.
La Montagnette is a low-altitude mountain (150 m), but with rather steep slopes, particularly on its eastern and western faces where slopes prohibit access by roads. This mountain is also marked by a series of hills and valleys generally oriented north-west / south-east, parallel to the axis of the mistral wind as the valley plain was often occupied by estates with their associated crops. La Montagnette includes the departmental roads D81 and D35.
Located in the climatic area of the Lower Rhone, La Montagnette is characterised by mild average annual temperatures (14°C) and a relatively low rainfall (650 mm / year), characteristic of the Provençal Mediterranean climate. At the mouth of the Rhone Valley, this mountain is also strongly under the influence of the mistral wind, which blows regularly throughout much of the year. 
Maintaining important agricultural and pastoral activities, La Montagnette has a relatively low rate of afforestation (30%). The forest populations, mainly located in northern face of the mountain (Barbentane), consist mainly of pine trees (rare deciduous Barbentane and Frigolet populations). The dominant vegetation types are the rosemary, rockrose or Kermes oak (60%) scrubland and the remaining open area hosts crops.
Instead of the traditional walk through Avignon, La Montagnette is particularly popular with the public throughout the year. This is the case of the two ZAPEF present on this mountain: the Barbentane to the north and at the centre, and the Abbey of Saint- Michel de Frigolet, busy on the weekend (300,000 visitors in 2000). 
This peak is explained amongst others by the quality of the site, La Montagnette being integrally inscribed with the presence also of several historical monuments. …

label: Jardin de la ville
comment:
This public garden is located near the Old La Ciotat and the health center.
It allows you to take a break thanks to the presence of many benches and pergolas.
It is also very popular with children with the development of a playground.
shortDescription:
This public garden is located near the Old La Ciotat and the health center.
It allows you to take a break thanks to the presence of many benches and pergolas.
It is also very popular with children with the development of a playground.
description: The garden was drawn, crashed and fitted out in 1889. Till the beginning of the XXth century, a bandstand allowed to present music concerts in this garden. The kiosk was then unsettled for the benefit of more contemporary arrangements, as playgroung for children for example, then reconstituted in 20019 as it used to be. Very appreciated by the elderly and the children, this pleasant place of relaxation and rest is raised by multiple sorts of flowers and by shrubs. A pond and fountains add some charm to this garden of the city center.

label: Ferme pédagogique du Parc de Figuerolles
comment: Created in 1989 on the land of the former Domaine De Verville, it allows children to raise awareness of nature and to know the pets of their region.
shortDescription: Created in 1989 on the land of the former Domaine De Verville, it allows children to raise awareness of nature and to know the pets of their region.
description:
Pending the response from the prefecture regarding the request for a waiver for the opening of the educational farm, the latter remains closed until further notice.

Animations and demonstrations are organized throughout the year by a warm and passionate team: donkey rides, Easter egg hunt, transhumance week, sheep Shearling, exhibitions, tales and shows, demonstrations of herd dogs (bi-annual).

About 100 poultry (ducks, geese, peaceches, Guinea fowl and hens), 20 sheep, 10 goats, 4 donkeys, 4 horses including 1 draught horse, 2 heifers, 2 miniature pigs, 1 Mule, Guinea pigs, rabbits.

label: Les Antiques
comment: The Antiques: symbolic monuments of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, they represent the Arc de Triomphe and the Mausoleum, formerly the entrance to the city of Glanum.
shortDescription: The Antiques: symbolic monuments of Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, they represent the Arc de Triomphe and the Mausoleum, formerly the entrance to the city of Glanum.
description:
The Jules Mausoleum: this funeral monument dates back to 30-20 BC. It was erected by the Julii, descendants of one of the major Roman families, in honour of their father and grandfather. It is particularly well preserved and owes its fame to its distinctive structure, which is unique to Roman architecture as we know it today. A a rectangular base with four magnificently sculpted fasciae is surmounted by a double-entry triumphal arch, on top of which is a small round temple with columns and a pyramidal roof; this temple houses the effigies of the two people to whom this exceptional monument is dedicated.
The Triumphal Arch dates from 20 AD but most of its upper part has disappeared. It was restored in the 18th century, when its roof was replaced with slate stone. It is adorned with beautiful reliefs illustrating Caesar's conquest of the Gauls. However, the fruit and foliage, symbols of abundance, suggest the benefits of pax romana.

label: Eglise Sainte-Madeleine
comment: The first modest building, dedicated to St. Magdalene, was built between 1696 and 1702, but its enlargement soon became indispensable.
shortDescription: The first modest building, dedicated to St. Magdalene, was built between 1696 and 1702, but its enlargement soon became indispensable.
description: The first modest building, dedicated to Saint Madeleine, was built between 1696 and 1702, but its expansion is quickly indispensable. Completed in 1746, it gives it a beautiful coherence, somewhat distorted by the enlargement of the nineteenth century and the weight of years. Today, its square bell tower is surmounted by a campanile while two niches in the bottom of an oven with large sculpted buttocks temper the facade of their curves and rhythm. After the devastating Revolution, Sainte-Madeleine was refurnished with other works from various religious buildings in Aix.

label: Bibliothèque municipale Espace Manson
comment: Municipal library of Mollégès.
shortDescription: Municipal library of Mollégès.
description: Place cultural flagship of the village. The library is open and welcoming space which aims to open culture at all.An exhibition hall allows you to discover the work of regional artists in all areas (painting, photography, drawing of humor...)The library is made up of about 8 000 documents for adults and children books, DVDs, CDs, journals it is supplemented by loans to the departmental library of Saint-Remy-Provence or Marseille. Loans of books, CDs, DVDs, sheet music, as well as Internet access are free.

label: La vieille ville d'Aix-en-Provence, ses places et ses hôtels particuliers
comment: During your escapade in the city of Aix-en-Provence, you will be invited to take a trip back in time. Your steps will lead you to an exceptional architectural and cultural heritage.
shortDescription: During your escapade in the city of Aix-en-Provence, you will be invited to take a trip back in time. Your steps will lead you to an exceptional architectural and cultural heritage.
description:
During your stay in Aix en Provence you will be invited to travel in time. Your steps will take you to an outstanding architectural and cultural heritage. Keep your eyes open: the city's treasures can be seen at every crossroads. 

To the north of the city, Bourg Saint Sauveur occupies the site of the ancient Roman city. It extends from the Cathedral to the Clock Tower (Town Hall). A few streets have kept evocative names, such as rue Esquicho Coudo, a narrow passageway dating from the Middle Ages. 


The remains of the mediaeval ramparts are visible, at the top of rue Jacques de la Roque (to the right of rue des Guerriers). Further down, on the site of the Roman Sextius Baths, excavations have revealed a Roman thermal pool which you can see at the entrance to the hydrotherapy spa. Opposite the Cathedral, on Place de l'Université, the former Faculty of Law (1409) has been replaced by the Institute of Political Studies (IEP). The Palais de l'Université, rebuilt by Georges Vallon in 1734, proudly announces its official function. 


Adjoining the Cathedral, the former palace of the archbishops of Aix en Provence encloses the square created in the mid-18th century (now Place des Martyrs de la Résistance). With their ecclesiastical and political power, these princes of the Church wanted a residence worthy of their rank. The present buildings were constructed between 1650 and 1730, and the gate is attributed to the sculptor Toro. 


On the first floor is the Tapestry Museum. Since 1948, the court of the Archbishop's Palace has hosted the main events of the Festival of Lyric Art, held during July. 


Rue Gaston de Saporta goes down to the town hall and the belfry. Hôtel Maynier d'Oppède, at No.23, belonged to a famous Parliamentary family. Rebuilt in 1730 by the architect Georges Vallon and the sculptor Chastel, it is now the Institute of French Studies for Foreign Students. Its courtyard is used for concerts in June and July every year. 
At No.19 is Hôtel de Châteaurenard, built in 1650. Famous as the house where the young Louis XIV stayed during his visit to Provence in 1660, it has a magnificent staircase, decorated with trompe-l'oeil paintings by Jean Daret. 

At No.17 Rue Gaston de Saporta, in Hôtel d’Estienne de Saint Jean built by Vallon (1652-1724), the Museum of Old Aix contains reminders of Aix's past. Further down, past the belfry, you are in the former City of the Counts. The Episcopal City and the City of the Counts were in fact separated by ramparts in the Middle Ages. This is the oldest part of the centre of Aix. The streets are now pedestrian and full of shops, the perfect place for a stroll. 


The city's old belfry, the symbol of civic power, straddles the street on Roman bases. It was raised in 1510, and contains an astronomical clock (1661) whose four wooden statues can still be seen: they symbolise the seasons, and appear in turn. 

On the square, created in the 18th century, the fountain built by the sculptor Chastel is topped with a Roman column at its centre. It is overlooked by the Town Hall (1655-1670) with its Italian-style frontage, carved wooden doors, and the inner courtyard, whas stood since the 14th century at the foot of the Clock Tower, the city's old belfry with its astronomical clock (1661) on which statues representing the four seasons appear in turn. 

On the same square the Corn Exchange, built by the architects Vallon in the 18th century (1759-1761), recalls the importance of the wheat trade at the time. The north frontage is crowned with an allegorical pediment by Chastel, representing the sources of farming prosperity in Provence: the Rhône and Durance rivers. The south side, giving on to Place Richelme, has a wealth of decorative motifs related to the function of the building: fruit, grain and olives. The fountain, also by Chastel, is topped with a Roman column. A fruit and vegetable market is held here every morning. 

Behind the town hall is Place des Cardeurs. It was created in 1963 on the site of an insalubrious area, which was the Jewish quarter in the Middle Ages, and is now dotted with the terraces of cafes and restaurants. It is lined with fine, renovated period houses, and enhanced with a fountain created in 1977 by the Aix artist Jean Amado. 


Leaving the Town Hall and going down towards Place d’Albertas, you will see Hôtel d'Arbaud (1670) in rue du Maréchal Foch, with its door supported by two Atlases, a frequent theme in the Aix decoration of the 17th and 18th centuries. Further down, at No.13 rue Aude, Hôtel de Peyroneti (1625) with its embossed decor looks just like a palace of the Italian Renaissance. 

You now reach Place d’Albertas. This enchanting square was created in 1745 by the Marquis Jean Baptiste d'Albertas, who had the houses opposite his mansion demolished. The vast mansion, altered in 1724, and the square with its Rococo decor, are the work of the Vallons (father and son) who used as their inspiration the style of the royal squares in Paris. In the centre, the fountain with its cast-iron basin dates from 1912. 
Next to it is Hôtel Boyer d’Eguilles, built of stone from the Bibémus quarries near Sainte-Victoire mountain. The Natural History Museum is now on the first floor of the building. 
You have now reached the Law Courts (Palais de Justice). Formerly the home of the sovereigns of Provence, the Parliament, the Treasury and the Court of Auditors, the old courts were demolished at the close of the 18th century, at the same time as the surrounding district. The architect Ledoux designed a new complex to replace them, but the Revolution prevented its construction. Between 1825 and 1832, Penchaud built the Law Courts and the prison on Ledoux’ foundations. The former prison was converted in 1998 and is an integral part of the new legal centre it now houses the Court of Appeal, the present Palais Monclar. 

Just next to it is the Church of La Madeleine, formerly the Preachers' Monastery (Dominicans), which was set up as early as 1274 and entirely rebuilt between 1691 and 1703 by Laurent Vallon who named it the Church of La Madeleine. Within its 19th-century walls this church-museum contains many works by artists who lived in Aix.

label: Forteresse des Comtes de Provence
comment: Fortress of the Counts of Provence.
shortDescription: Fortress of the Counts of Provence.
description: At the top of the Griffon hill stands the 12th and 15th century castle. This ancient fortress of the Counts of Provence is classified as a historical monument. Guided tours allow you to discover Benedict XIII, an extraordinary character, the architecture, the daily life and the role of this strategic site. The garden is an invitation to walk. It is a real haven of peace for birds.

label: Musée Cantini
comment: This private  mansion built in 1694 by the 'compagnie du Cap Nègre' had been bought in 1709 by the family de Montgrand. They own it until 1801.
shortDescription: This private  mansion built in 1694 by the 'compagnie du Cap Nègre' had been bought in 1709 by the family de Montgrand. They own it until 1801.
description:
Many owners succeeded one another ' le cercle des phocéens' remains more than half a century installed in 1836. Before being acquired by Jules Cantini, important marble worker who was involved in construction of differents kind of many civil and religious buildings in Marseille during the Second Empire.
Great armateur of Art , Jules Cantini donated it to the city in 1916 to be used as a museum for the art of our time.

This amazing cultural establishment  in Marseille is is  devoted to  a 'modern' period 20 th century from  1900 to 1960's.

The collection includes some of the important individuals of the twentieth century such as Henri Matisse, oskar Kokoschka, Pablo Picasso, Jean Arp, Alberto Giacometti, Balthus, Antonin Artaud and Francis  Bacon.

label: Parc du 26e Centenaire
comment: Located in the heart of Marseille, the 26th Centenary Park covers 10.5 hectares. It was developed on the site of the former Prado station.
shortDescription: Located in the heart of Marseille, the 26th Centenary Park covers 10.5 hectares. It was developed on the site of the former Prado station.
description:
Located in the heart of Marseille, the 26th Centenary Park covers 10.5 hectares. It was developed on the site of the former Prado station.


Although very contemporary in design, the park is nevertheless part of the common memory, referring to the twenty-six centuries of the city's history. Some of the remains of the station are witnesses to a past that is still alive in the memories of many Marseilles residents.
Water is omnipresent and echoes the "Tree of Hope" which stands at the main entrance.

Four thematic gardens symbolize the cultural mix of the population and the openness of Marseille to the world:

the Provençal Garden, structured in terraces
the Oriental Garden, in Arab-Andalusian style
the African Garden, with its dunes
the Asian Garden, reminiscent of Japanese gardens
The plants are arranged according to their shape and their ability to illustrate or evoke the desired style. These are not botanical gardens, in the scientific sense of the term, because the plants are not selected according to their true area of origin.
In fact, the people of Marseille, thanks to their large port, have always been in contact with the Mediterranean, but also with Africa, the Middle and the Far East. Thus, various plant species have managed to acclimatize in Marseille.

In 2005, this park was awarded the label "Remarkable Garden" by the Ministry of Culture.

In this 21st century park, the walker discovers a paved and planted mall, bordered by a canal with 26 water jets and a shed, a vestige of the old station, which now houses a tea room.
The landscaped grounds include a 30,000 m² lake overlooked by a belvedere offering a view of Notre-Dame de la Garde and the hills of Saint-Cyr.
It also has a bowling green and two playgrounds for children.
Conference and exhibition rooms have also been built near the main entrance, on the Place de la Fontaine de l'Espérance

label: Anse du Mont Rose
comment: Small rocky cove surmounted by a France Telecom antenna, just after the small picturesque port of La Madrague. Restaurants nearby, and terminus of the bus line 19. The public is rather "gay".
shortDescription: Small rocky cove surmounted by a France Telecom antenna, just after the small picturesque port of La Madrague. Restaurants nearby, and terminus of the bus line 19. The public is rather "gay".
description:
This cove is now included in the Calanques National Park.
To know the accessibility of the protected natural areas, between June 1st and September 30th, via a simple phone number, 0 811 20 13 13. (Cost of a local call).
Metro Castellane or Rond Point du Prado + bus 19, stop "Mont Rose".

label: Hôtel de Peyronetti
description:
Built in 1625 by Jean Lombard, Hôtel de Peyroneti is a fine, rare example of late mannerism in Aix.


The originality of its decor, the arch-stones with starred bossage, a frieze with metopes and decorated triglyphs alternating with rosettes and bucranes, gives this mansion the appearance of an Italian palace.

label: La Rose des Vents
description:
Designed by internationally famous contemporary artist Jean-Michel Othoniel, La Rose des Vents is a monumental mobile sculpture 5.70m high. 


With its steel base and beads of gold-coloured stainless steel, it stands on the Belvedere of the Beisson estate, which is close to Cézanne’s studio and offers spectacular views over the city and Sainte-Victoire mountain.

label: Fontaine Moussue
description: A true mascot of the city, it already existed in the 16th century. Limestone concretions developed, welding the two basins together, as well as the moss and vegetation that today give it its particular shape. The square takes its name from the famous 19th century poet.

label: Hôtel Particulier de Laudun
description:
This mansion could in fact be called Clémens, as it is to François de Clémens that it owes its rich 17th century architecture.
The mansion is attractive, comprising a 15th century building renovated in the 17th century; it is one of the most beautiful mansions in the region of the château, combining the ideal Classicism of the Renaissance, a range of details, layout, structures and refined décor. It has four inner courtyards.
The inspiration for its façade is clearly Renaissance. However, it still retains some elements from the time of its construction, in the 15th century, particularly a cross-vaulted kitchen with a monumental fireplace.
In the main courtyard, behind the main door, it is possible to see the mullioned windows framed by pilasters and adorned with different motifs representing the four seasons.
In September 1632, this sumptuous residence was the temporary home of Cardinal de Richelieu, who had come to supervise the demolition of the Château de Beaucaire.
It was listed as a national Historic Monument in 1941, but was badly damaged during the bombings of August 1944; it has since been restored many times.

label: Oratoire Saint Symphorien
description: The oratory of Saint Symphorien was erected to recall the mission that took place in 1883.

label: Chapelle de l'Annonciade
comment: Listed as a historical monument in 1910, the chapel is located in the town centre of Martigues (Jonquières district), behind the church of St-Genest. It was built in the 17th century for the brotherhood of white penitents.
shortDescription: Listed as a historical monument in 1910, the chapel is located in the town centre of Martigues (Jonquières district), behind the church of St-Genest. It was built in the 17th century for the brotherhood of white penitents.
description:
This jewel of Provençal Baroque art is a must-see! The sobriety of its exterior façade contrasts with its dazzling interior decoration: painted and ornamented ceiling, wall frescoes, painted and sculpted plant motifs, sculpted and gilded ornaments, trompe-l'oeil...

Did you know that? 
- In 1619, the first mention of the chapel near the church of Saint-Genest, it was consecrated by the archbishop of Arles.
- In 1661, the chapel was demolished following the enlargement of the church of Saint-Genest. The Confraternity of the White Penitents of the Annonciade then decided to build their own chapel.
- In 1663, despite the construction of buttresses to the east (rue du Docteur Sérieux) and buttresses to the west (boulevard Richaud), the vault collapsed... the chapel no longer had a roof. 
Of the old vault, a ribbed crossing is still visible from the gallery with graffiti (ships, skulls and crossbones, caricature of the revolutionary period...).
The gallery is accessible by a staircase hidden in the altarpiece, to the north of the building. Exceptionally during the European Heritage Days, you can discover the treasures hidden in this place: the walls are covered with graffiti drawn with charcoal, red chalk or a knife.
- From 1666 to 1671, the penitents opted for a flat pinewood ceiling. 
- In 1677-1678, Jean-Claude Boyer, a master carpenter in Aix-en-Provence, created the sumptuous painted and ornamented ceiling. It contains five oil paintings on canvas relating to the life of the Virgin, by Barthélémy Donneau of Martigues and Anthoine Ollivier of Marseille. 
The original paintings are The Assumption of the Virgin and The Coronation of the Virgin, the rest date from the 1966 restoration campaign.
- The years 1702-1703 saw the creation by Claude and Etienne Darbon of the wooden altarpiece and its majestic high altar decorated in trompe l'oeil.
- In 1734, the coloured murals illustrating the life of the Virgin and the sculpted stalls (wooden seats along the walls) were completed.

What is this brotherhood of the white penitents?
This community of lay people practised mutual aid, prayer, charity and solidarity with the poor. They were dressed in a very simple robe intended to conceal the social differences of civil clothing. 
The Penitents also wore a bonnet, which showed a concern for individual modesty and anonymity so as not to take glory from their charitable actions and to erase their own person in front of the virtues of the group, so that the person assisted would only thank God for the help they received.

In order to save the chapel from the attacks of humidity, the City of Martigues decided to close it to the public in 1993 and undertook its restoration from 1995 to 2015. These 20 years of work have enabled it to be reopened to residents and tourists. The work was financed by the town, the State (historical monuments) and the Region.
Thanks to this exceptional restoration work, the city was awarded the regional Grand Prix des Rubans du Patrimoine 2016.
Its excellent acoustics make it an ideal venue for concerts. As a conservation measure, the capacity is 150 spectators.

Access is via the rue du Docteur Sérieux from July to October and via the Annonciade garden (boulevard Richaud) from November to June.

label: LE KIOSQUE du grand cèdre (Kiosque de Valbacol)
comment: Erected at the foot of a large cedar tree, in place of an old dilapidated gazebo, this kiosk is the result of a project launched in 2011 by the City of Vitrolles and the Union Compagnonnique du tour de France des Devoirs Unis*.
shortDescription: Erected at the foot of a large cedar tree, in place of an old dilapidated gazebo, this kiosk is the result of a project launched in 2011 by the City of Vitrolles and the Union Compagnonnique du tour de France des Devoirs Unis*.
description:
THE LORDS OF THE KIOSK OF THE GREAT CEDAR.

If JJK Tolkien had learned of the existence of a site protected by the Muses on the "land of the centre" of Valbacol's recreation centre, let's bet that a new chapter of the "Lord of the Rings" would have had the kiosk of the great cedar as its setting

Before imagining Frodo and Bilbon Saquet de la Comté making a stop here to escape from the vilest creatures, let's get to know this nugget of Vitrol's heritage, which hasn't finished being brought to light!

For 2 years, about a hundred Companions and young volunteers, from all trades, worked voluntarily to carry out this project. In exchange for food and lodging, young and old imagined, built and produced their "masterpiece" collectively, during weekends devoted to their art. 14 young people from Vitrollais thus had the opportunity to be introduced to the crafts. An approach that may have revealed vocations..

INSPIRED BY THE MUSES
Sculptors and engravers came to embellish the dice of the tailors on the theme of the Muses of Antiquity who represent the arts. The first 8 daughters of Zeus and Mnemosyne are represented by their emblems sculpted in bas-relief and their names engraved on the carved stone bases 

Clio: the Muse of History
Thalie: the country deity who presided over the joyful banquets. Later she became the comedy divinity.
Erato: presided over lyrical poetry but also over lighter, erotic and love poetry.
Euterpe: Muse of lyricism and music, she personified primitive art.
Polymnia: Presided over hymns, religious songs and rhetoric, she represented the faculty of learning and remembering.
Calliope: The most eminent of the Muses, whose name means "has the beautiful voice", presided over epic poetry and sometimes eloquence.
Terpsichore: presided over dance and choral singing.
And Melpomeneus: Her name means "the singer" in Greek. Initially a deity of song, she later became the Muse of tragedy

As the Kiosk was built on an octagonal base, Uranie, who presided over astronomy and geometry, was missing. Made by an Ironwork Aspirant, it is represented by a sphere which contains in its rings a compass and the stars which, with the letters of its name, are 12 in number (referring to the cycle of the earth, its 12 months, and the 12 signs of the zodiac). Raise your eyes, it is quite naturally placed in space, in the center of the frame!

THE POWER OF SYMBOLS
In the Compagnonnage, symbolism is an important research tool. The site of Valbacol being located in the middle of nature, the wood sculptors came to embellish the framework with plants belonging to the symbolic companionship:

The rose represents love, the expression of joy, happiness, tenderness and grace. It is the symbol of the Mother of Companions.
The olive tree stands for longevity, hope, wisdom, peace and reconciliation.
The myrtle is the symbol of joy, bliss and desire.
The oak for strength and prosperity.
the laurel for the glory of companionship, victory and triumph over self
The rush, flexible, it makes the link between earth and heaven; it adorns the canes of the companions.
The wheat and the vine, for the sharing of bread and wine.
The immortal acacia is the bearer of knowledge.

The labyrinth
As a tribute to the master builders of the Middle Ages, the mosaic artists reproduced on the kiosk's slab the drawing of the labyrinth decorating the floor of the nave of Amiens Cathedral (which also inspired the logo of the French Historical Monuments Department).

FINAL STEPS
After the masons, the stonemasons, the sculptors, the engravers... it was the carpenters' turn to lift the kiosk before giving way to the roofers - zingers who came to crown the building with a magnificent spike reaching towards the sky, in the image of the great cedar, symbol of immortality

Video: booth opening (2014) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kKtNjMfpDck
*Since 2010, "le Compagnonnage, a network for the transmission of knowledge and identities through the trade" has been recognised and listed as an intangible cultural heritage by UNESCO.
streetAddress: ['Centre de loisirs de la Ville de Vitrolles', 'Valbacol']

label: Quartier du Panier
comment: On the quai du Port, in the old city, the Panier district tells the story of Marseille.
shortDescription: On the quai du Port, in the old city, the Panier district tells the story of Marseille.
description: This district is located on the butte des Moulins (11ha) and spreads from the butte Saint Laurent to the Hôtel Dieu and from the Vieille Charité to the post-war buildings. It was a district of small trades linked to the sea, but today it is looking to the future with the Euroméditerrannée project. To see: the Daviel palace, the place of Lenche, the place of the Mills, the street of the Panier, the rise of Accoules and the bell-tower, the Hotel Dieu, the Vieille Charité, the cellars of Saint Sauveur...

label: La Palissade
comment: This former private hunting domain of 702 ha is today devoted to the protection of nature and to the reception of the public.
shortDescription: This former private hunting domain of 702 ha is today devoted to the protection of nature and to the reception of the public.
description: This former private 702 HA hunting estate is today devoted to the protection of nature and the reception of the public. It is the last land to be located outside the dykes that isolate the Camargue region of the river and the sea.Three possibilities to discover this unique site:-walking tours (1.5 to 8 Km 3 routes)-Equestrian visits (from 1 h to 3 h)-vists ride (1 h 30)

label: Jardin Palissy
description: A haven of freshness and greenery of 8400 m, right in the city centre. Pleasant, the Jardin Palissy is equipped with games for children: baby modul structure (fireman's mat net) 9 to 14 years, mound slide 4 to 10 years, ecoludic structure (climbing holds, footbridge) 3 to 8 years, swinging portico 3 to 8 years, spring games 3 to 8 years. Boules pitch, multi-sports field in asphalt, fountain and benches.

label: Sulauze
comment: The Sulauze massif is a small unit of about 1,000 ha, located between the Etang de Berre and the Crau plain.
shortDescription: The Sulauze massif is a small unit of about 1,000 ha, located between the Etang de Berre and the Crau plain.
description:
The Massif de Sulauze is a small massif of around 2,470 acres in size, situated between Etang de Berre lake and Plaine de la Crau.

This massif comprises a low-altitude plateau (46 to 118 m) rising gently southeastwards before descending sharply to the banks of Etang de l’Olivier and Etang de Berre lakes.

Massif de Sulauze is located at the limit of the Bas Rhône and coastal Provence climate zones. Average temperatures there are warm (13 to 14 °C) and variations are tempered by maritime influences. Rainfall is low: around 600 mm per year. This massif is positioned along the Rhône valley and as such is exposed to strong and regular Mistral winds (over 100 days per year at over 60 km/hr) which blow upwards over the relief and valleys, hence creating various acceleration phenomena and turbulence at the edge of the plateau.

The northern area of the massif is populated by a mixture of evergreen oaks and Aleppo pines. The more uneven southern area is populated by dense, untended pine trees, interspersed with agricultural zones now occupied by housing developments. The rest of the massif comprises dense garrigue.

The Massif de Sulauze is characterised by a large and private area of farmland to the North and forest / urban interface zones to the South, coupled with a delicate topographical context (steep slopes with dips orientated windward). Public frequentation is low in the northern areas but high in the South, mainly due to the massif's proximity to the town of Istres.

label: Observatoire Astronomique de Marseille
comment: The Observatory of Marseille, created in 1702 by the Jesuits in their college of Sainte-Croix, at the Montée des Accoules, was taken over by the State in 1763 and, a century later, transferred to the Longchamp plateau where it is still located.
shortDescription: The Observatory of Marseille, created in 1702 by the Jesuits in their college of Sainte-Croix, at the Montée des Accoules, was taken over by the State in 1763 and, a century later, transferred to the Longchamp plateau where it is still located.
description:
The association ANDROMEDE makes discover the sky, the constellations, the planets, the movement of the moon, the sun, understand the universe...and makes visit the room of the ancient instruments. Planetarium sessions for all publics are proposed: they are followed when the weather allows for sunspot observation. Before and after these sessions, exhibitions and guided tours allow you to discover: the large telescope of the Observatory, the 80 cm diameter Foucault telescope, "History of a large telescope", "The Moon and the satellites of the planets", "Light and astronomy instruments"...

The association offers three levels of astronomy courses and seminars, open to all.

label: Centre Historique
comment: The old town is an Istrean treasure. Typically Provençal, it is evidence of our beautiful town’s history. It can be visited as a group, with the family or alone, with a guide or with the ‘Istres Through its History’ leaflet.
shortDescription: The old town is an Istrean treasure. Typically Provençal, it is evidence of our beautiful town’s history. It can be visited as a group, with the family or alone, with a guide or with the ‘Istres Through its History’ leaflet.
description: Istres has a real historic centre, which was formerly fortified and was built on a limestone bed rich in fossilised oysters. It formed a hill with an oval base (about 250 m by 188 m) stretching from north to south and with a central peak rising 30 m above sea level. This village perched on a rocky hilltop is typical of Mediterranean rural settlements, around which the town of Istres was built.

label: Place Raymond 1er de Baux
comment: Place Raymond 1er de Baux
shortDescription: Place Raymond 1er de Baux
description: Developed in 2014, Place Raymond 1er de Baux was inaugurated in September 2016 by Michel Mille on the occasion of the celebration of the castle's 900th anniversary. This square is a place steeped in history. Indeed, the Count of Provence confiscated the possessions of the first Lords of the village at the origin of the construction of the primitive castle and gave them to the Lords of Baux who arrived in Lançon in 1116. In 1117, Lançon became the property of Raymond de Baux who took a particular interest in the village because of its strategic position. He then built his castle on the foundations of the old one. On this pretty square stands an orientation table from which a breathtaking view of the plain of Salon and the Alpilles is offered to us as well as a glimpse of the evolution of our beautiful town.

label: Moulin Bonnet
description:
In the Middle Ages, the cereal crop developed considerably. The Bonnet and Berlandier mills in the Montagnette were built in the 18th century (1776), the golden age of windmills. The Rhone valley, swept by the Mistral, is an ideal location for the mills. In operation until the 19th century, they were supplanted at that time by industrial flour mills. In 2002, the Bonnet mill underwent a complete restoration: the tower was once again fitted with a roof and wings. It is the first windmill in the Bouches-du-Rhône to be put back into operation. Open to visitors every other Saturday, it is put into operation on Mistral days.

The site offers a remarkable view of the village and the alluvial plain that stretches out at its feet. An orientation table has been installed by the pupils of the Boulbon primary school.

It is managed by the Association "Les Amis du Vieux Boulbon", which organizes guided tours.

label: Bambous en Provence
comment: Located in the heart of Provence, this 4.5 ha garden will surprise the visitor with its lush green beauty. A spectacular world of bamboos with 300 varieties. A visit for nature lovers in a haven of peace and freshness.
shortDescription: Located in the heart of Provence, this 4.5 ha garden will surprise the visitor with its lush green beauty. A spectacular world of bamboos with 300 varieties. A visit for nature lovers in a haven of peace and freshness.
description: With more than 300 species of bamboo, 40 varieties of grasses and hundreds of shrubs and flowering trees, the bamboo grove, a true model of sustainable development and environmental protection, will amaze your senses while revealing its secrets on biodiversity.

label: Hôtel Particulier d'Aiminy
description:
The 15th century main building, which was renovated circa 1640, belonged to the d'Aiminy family. Many town consuls came from this family. The first printing workshops for 'indiennes' fabrics were created in 1818 and were located in the former Capuchin convent; in 1820 they were transferred to a church by Mr Jourdan and Mr Quinche.
The property arrived in the Deméy family in 1916; Charles Deméry gradually bought 18th century plates from old factories and set up his plant here. It was in this magnificent private mansion that Charles Deméry set up his offices in 1938, the year in which the Maison Souléïado was founded.

label: Centre historique d'Aubagne
comment: Aubagne comes from the Latin Albanea, which means "the white one". The bright color of the limestone of the hills surrounding the city would have inspired this name, but it also evokes the white poplars that once followed the course of the Huveaune.
shortDescription: Aubagne comes from the Latin Albanea, which means "the white one". The bright color of the limestone of the hills surrounding the city would have inspired this name, but it also evokes the white poplars that once followed the course of the Huveaune.
description:
The old city, an ancient medieval place surrounded with bulwarks during the 16th century, inserts several interesting monuments such as 'the Gachiou door' which used to be the main of the seven entries of the city, 'the Saint Sauveur Church' (11th century), 'the Clock Tower', 'the triangular steeple of the Observance', 'the Black Penitents chapel', 'the White Penitents Chapel'...
The narrow streets and the shady places of the old city make of Aubagne a typical Mediterranean city and you can particularly notice streets such as 'the Torte, Rastègue, du Four' streets , places such as 'the Rau, de Guin' places ...
particular hotels with coloured facades or typical decorating of the 16th and 17th centuries ('Du Bausset, or the Royalists' hotels), ancient balconies, doors and doorknockers, and a 18th century bread oven...

label: Plage les Robinsons
comment: Beach les robinsons, swimming allowed from June 1st to September 30th.
shortDescription: Beach les robinsons, swimming allowed from June 1st to September 30th.
description:
Unguarded sandy beach. Parking area near the beach, equipped and free of charge. Capacity of the area: 30 vehicles. Children's games, playground (boules, volleyball and beach volleyball), picnic area, toilets, waste bins. Water activities on site (private club): windsurfing, sailing, kayaking. Disabled access. Dogs accepted. The nautical base is open from April to November. Swimming is allowed from June 1st to September 30th.
From the nautical base, RN 113.

label: L' escalier du Pont de Trinquetaille
comment: From the Quai de la Roquette in Trinquetaille
shortDescription: From the Quai de la Roquette in Trinquetaille
description:
From the Quai de la Roquette; in October 1888, Vincent Van-Gogh observed the metal bridge which straddled the river and allowed people and goods to travel between the two sides of Arles.
He also took in the comings-and-going, the passageway and the staircase by which men and women reached the walkway.

label: Musée municipal Paul Lafran
comment: Since March 10, 2000, the Municipal Museum has been named after Paul LAFRAN, founding President of the Association of Friends of Old Saint-Chamas. It has been installed since 1951 in the heart of the old village, in the old town hall of the 17th Place des Pénitents.
shortDescription: Since March 10, 2000, the Municipal Museum has been named after Paul LAFRAN, founding President of the Association of Friends of Old Saint-Chamas. It has been installed since 1951 in the heart of the old village, in the old town hall of the 17th Place des Pénitents.
description:
The vast majority of the collections come from donations or from the results of forty years of archaeological research carried out by Paul Lafran and his team. Welcomed by a magnificent Arlesian woman in traditional costume from the end of the 19th century, we can discover clothes, ribbons... evidence of the fact that our village belongs to the country of Arles. You can also discover collections of objects of everyday life and religious documents including. At the back, a small room conceals archaeological treasures discovered during the excavations undertaken by Paul Lafran. (for the moment, this part is not visible). On the 1st floor, a magnificent space, under majestic 17th century exposed beams, is reserved for painting. It is an ideal setting for discovering 19th century ex-votos from the Chapel Notre Dame de Miséricorde and paintings by contemporary artists, inspired by Saint-Chamas: works by M. Liéger, A. Charrier, V. Monte, M. Berle, M. Truc and J. Ordonneaud accompany those of the great masters P. Ambrogiani and René Seyssaud.
Surface area of the permanent exhibition: 130
Surface area of the temporary exhibition: 30

label: Cloître Saint Trophime
comment: Built in the middle of the Middle Ages, between the 12th and 14th centuries, the cloister Saint Trophime is classified as a Historical Monument (1846 and 1943) and a Unesco World Heritage Site (1981)
shortDescription: Built in the middle of the Middle Ages, between the 12th and 14th centuries, the cloister Saint Trophime is classified as a Historical Monument (1846 and 1943) and a Unesco World Heritage Site (1981)
description:
Date: 12th-14th century
Era: Middle Ages
Type: Religious architecture
Status: Property of the Town of Arles, listed as a national Historic Monument in 1846 and 1943 and as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1981
Saint Trophime Cloister is at the centre of the canonical buildings of the episcopal town.
In the 12th century, the space to the south of Saint Trophime Cathedral was occupied by two large complexes, on the one hand the Palais de l’Evêque, and on the other hand the Claustrum, a space reserved for the community of canons, 'those who live according to the law of the Church'.
It was around this time that the Arles Chapter was affected by the Gregorian reform.
This reform attempted to impose rules for communal life on the clerics responsible for assisting the Bishop and managing Church assets. Work was therefore begun to construct convent buildings around a cloister.
The first two Romanesque galleries of this cloister contain exceptional sculptures, true masterpieces of Provençal Romanesque art.
In the 14th century, two other Gothic-style galleries were added to the building.
The later modifications to the episcopal town preserved the cloister and the adjacent rooms. However, time, rain erosion and atmospheric pollution have damaged these jewels of mediaeval statuary.
Studies are currently being carried out with a view to restoring the building, in the same way as the portal of the neighbouring church was restored.

label: Eglise Notre-Dame de la Seds
comment: The Romano-Byzantine church is the work of the architect Henri Revoil and dates from 1853, but its origins are much older since the church seems to have existed as early as the 4th century, next to an ancient theatre, which was uncovered in 2004
shortDescription: The Romano-Byzantine church is the work of the architect Henri Revoil and dates from 1853, but its origins are much older since the church seems to have existed as early as the 4th century, next to an ancient theatre, which was uncovered in 2004
description:
The Church of Notre-Dame de la Seds stands within the historic Ville des Tours of Aix en Provence. It was rebuilt in 1853 by the architect Henri Révoil on the foundations of a much older church, dating back to the 4th century.
